route_comments.comment_text: This thing offers some of the most sustained and technical climbing I have done at index, the quality is unreal. Unfortunately it is also pretty dirty, slightly detracting from the quality, be sure to bring a brush and a sense of humor. Apr 5, 2016

Sent this route yesterday--12B seems appropriate (definitely as hard as arete climbs like: "vision","latest Rage", or "Chips Ahoy" down in Yosemite). No stopper moves but unrelenting --making redpointing vs TR distinguishable.  Originally graded 12c (Clint's guide) and then down to 12a (Cramer guide)--the new guide sticking with the latter but eluding to the former. :- Wire brushed for 2... more Sent this route yesterday--12B seems appropriate (definitely as hard as arete climbs like: "vision","latest Rage", or "Chips Ahoy" down in Yosemite). No stopper moves but unrelenting --making redpointing vs TR distinguishable.  Originally graded 12c (Clint's guide) and then down to 12a (Cramer guide)--the new guide sticking with the latter but eluding to the former. :-> Wire brushed for 2 hours. The bushes in the adjacent corner are a visual nuisance but do not affect the climbing.  Previously, there existed a 20' runout to the anchor (protected by a #1BD cam)---I went ahead and placed a bolt--rendering this a sport climb. So good! Definitely worthy of more traffic May 21, 2018
I think this was originally rated .11d by Greg O. Good call on the bolt addition. Nov 29, 2018

routes.route_name: Black Flag of the Schwarzer Kamin, The
routes.route_description: Continuous thin edging up a slightly less than vertical wall. The most thoughtful part may be between the 2nd and 4th bolt, but the climbing never really eases up. Despite it being relatively short, expect to get pumped near the end. No good rests, but lots of good holds.Start by gaining the top of the large flake resting against the wall. Take Ben's direct start from the base to get the most fun from the pitch. But an easier way is on the left side if you so desire. From the top of the flake, start on Sideshow, using its first two bolts. After the second bolt, veer left to the base of a groove and crack feature, then go up. Finish about 10' right of where Domestic violence crosses the roof.You can probably traverse left to the Tree-Studded roof and continue up that route, if its bottom part is seeping.
routes.route_location: Same start as Sideshow. Look for the bolts just above the large flake leaning against the wall.
routes.route_protection: 8 bolts.The top anchor has fixed biners on two bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: Really fun climbing!  Highly recommended for anyone in the area, and a great warmup for the hard stuff nearby.  I'd give it 4 stars if it were longer. Note that we swapped out the old SMC hangers from the first 2 Sideshow bolts, but did not replace these bolts.  They seem OK. May 3, 2014
Primo crimp cruise. Would that it were infinitely long and return to the base unnecessary. Jul 29, 2014

Excellent route Eric and Jon!  Flake boulder now has a bolt for a direct start.  This adds some nice 5.10 climbing up the center of the flake.  Relevant for both "The Black Flag of the Schwarzer Kamin" and "Sideshow". Sep 8, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. w/ sam. this thing is rad!! criiiiimps the whole way. crux for me was the slab before the 1st bolt lol. 5.10 3/4! · Lead / Onsight. Best onsight to date. Clean no beta. Lots of good foot rests. Only one commital move toward the end. Felt confident nearly all the way. · Lead / Flash. “Warmed up” on hardest sport send yet! RIP fingers. Gotta climb after Letty more. · Lead / Flash. Insanely fun! Went straight up the giant leaning flake to start. · Lead / Onsight. Maybe I just didn’t like it as a warm up on a very hot day, but the diagonal line to the right was so much better (and easier) · Lead / Onsight. the slab start was so hard rip. and then the crimps were sooo wet at the top. super fun! · Lead / Onsight. Fell on dirty boulder at first bolt. Cleaned it then sent the rest onsight. Slightly harder and sharper than sideshow, hence the 11a/3 stars. · osl. Primo crimp cruise. Would that it were infinitely long and return to the base unnecessary.

routes.route_fa: Don Harder, Dougal McCarty FFA: Terry Lien, Jon Nelson
routes.route_description: Slightly dicey climbing off the ground leads to better protected but thin climbing through discontinuous cracks to a steep section through a bulge. The technical crux is just below the bulge, but a pumpy section still lurks above.One can stop at the Young Cynics anchor at 75 or continue to another anchor for a slightly longer pitch.
routes.route_location: This is the thin crack right of Killslug and left of Young Cynics and Soul on Ice.A 60m will lower from the midway anchor. If the entire pitch were cleaned, two ropes would be needed.
routes.route_protection: Lots of thin to #2 or 3 Camalot; possibly wider for the very top, if it were clean. Double or triple up on nuts and finger size. Midway anchors are chains on aging bolts; top anchor has been updated.

route_comments.comment_text: It's clean enough to do to the top. Nov 13, 2010
One of the funnest roof sequences I've done on a trad climb. Definitely techy down low. Aug 7, 2014
I did it long ago, but went back this summer and couldn't even TR the techy part just below the roof. It's definitely a challenging route I'll be back for. Aug 7, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. TR. Lots of small offsets, brass, totems to. 75. Plus a 4 and 1 Hard. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Wow. Fun finger crack with face cruxes. When in doubt, get high feet. Getting to roof: L crack, R right, high LF, R Gaston corner, stand up. Whipped after plugging roof pod with gear (dont, good gear and holds right after) · Lead / Redpoint. I used the following gear (all BD). #4, 2 .5, 2 .4, 2 .3, offset yellow/red, #2, .75 · 3 pitches. TR. Crux is wet, rest of the route is dry and pretty clean. Gave it a little brushing on the way down.

routes.route_description: Climb the first 35' of The Antidote--then follow the left hand line of bolts for engaging face climbing up to a jug below the crux of Soul On Ice.  At this point, join Soul On Ice. All SOI crux bolts replaced.  Not sure about grading--likely easier for tall & lean climbers.  I definitely put in lots of TR work and then a few burns for the red-point.  Send it! and leave comments.
routes.route_location: Starts on The Antidote, breaks left at the slab eventually finishing on the crux moves of SOI.
routes.route_protection: 9 bolts and 2 bolt anchor

route_comments.comment_text: Go Ben!! May 17, 2018
We listing projects now? I must say I'm tempted to do so myself.... May 19, 2018
Named after the movie? Nice movie, as I recall. Jun 27, 2018

routes.route_fa: Greg Collum, Greg Child FFA: Andy deKlerk
routes.route_description: Thin edging in the first bit ends at a rest crossing the Sideshow route. Cruxy moves up to and over the roof and some thin face above lead to anchors. The pitch possibly continues past more bolts and natural gear to a higher anchor, but this appears overgrown.
routes.route_location: The next route to the right of Sideshow. Can also be climbed via the start of Sideshow.One 60m will get you down from the anchor above the roof.
routes.route_protection: Bolts. A couple of cams or nuts can mediate the runout above bolt 4, but the climbing there is much easier than the rest of the route. Fixed anchors.

route_comments.comment_text: The bolts on this have been replaced (excluding one above the roof that appears to be extraneous, TBD) and an anchor refurbished with SS and Mussey Hooks.  I have a rope on it to do some scrubbing, and should have it buffed and back in the line up in a few weeks. Sep 30, 2019
Big thanks Matt!  Can't wait to try this rig. Oct 7, 2019

Kill Slug is an awesome route.  Back in the 80s Jon was excited about it so we went up and spent a day cleaning it.  If I remember correctly the day started out ok but soon it started snowing and we spent the rest of the day freezing.  We left a few hexcentrics  in the  crack when we bailed.  As usual Jon already had it named.   We got distracted and didn’t go back.  Many years later the two... more Kill Slug is an awesome route.  Back in the 80s Jon was excited about it so we went up and spent a day cleaning it.  If I remember correctly the day started out ok but soon it started snowing and we spent the rest of the day freezing.  We left a few hexcentrics  in the  crack when we bailed.  As usual Jon already had it named.   We got distracted and didn’t go back.  Many years later the two Greg’s got on it cleaned it up, added bolts and for some inexplicable reason didn’t totally free it.  They kept Jon’s name.  Later the indefatigable Andy waltzed up and eliminated the hangs. Oct 7, 2019

routes.route_description: Waddle on good hands and feet to a hands free rest below a laser cut right facing corner. Techy foot work, delicate crimping and hairspray poise plant you at a rightward traverse. Mississippi halfstep to the good flake and bounce between slopers and crimps. Grab the ancient tablet and read your fate with a slap to a nice flat bar. Finish to the top and protect your tail from the sting!
routes.route_location: Just to the right of biology (huge arete), look for the bolted face
routes.route_protection: 8 bolts and an anchor

route_comments.comment_text: A couple of folks tried this while I was at the wall last weekend. They both thought it was pretty hard, or at least quite cryptic! I haven't hopped on it myself but I'm excited to do some waddling. I'll be sure to put the appropriate hair products in before tying in. Jun 7, 2019
Bolt added at the crux to make the fall a bit cleaner. Might look a touch out of place, but to prevent bolting through a flake, it was the most logical position. Jul 20, 2019

This thing is SICK!  The movement is stellar and memorable top to bottom.  Difficulty felt pretty much the same as sweatshop in terms of how long and sustained the hard bits are, and the hardest moves are a touch more bouldery and a touch less thin facey.  Its well bolted and currently nice and clean, so seriously, do this route. Sep 30, 2019

routes.route_description: Technically a variation to Soul on Ice, this has enough good climbing to stand on its own. Easier than Soul on Ice. Heads left right above the bulge at, I believe, the 7th bolt of Soul on Ice. Steep, sequential climbing leads to the Young Cynics belay.
routes.route_location: Start via Soul on Ice; veer left at the the 7th bolt, right above the roof bulge.60m rope to descend.
routes.route_protection: 8 or 9 bolts, bolted anchors with chains. There are a couple of closely spaced bolts around where the variation veers off that may create rope drag; skipping a bolt and/or backcleaning one alleviates this problem.

route_comments.comment_text: This is route has been scrubbed clean. March 8th, 2014. Mar 9, 2014

This and raggedy Anne are both clean and very popular this season. People are having quite a good time it seems. The bulge section has awesome holds and good powerful movement. All the falls are super clean and the clips are straightforward! May 6, 2019

Anchor replaced. Tried (unsuccessfully) to reuse the old holes. :( one bolt snapped during extraction, and the other hole was too maimed for safe use. I didn’t have putty on me, but they should be patched momentarily. 1/2 in SS + chain and clips. Jul 20, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. technical and sustained. super cool route. sort of run out to the chains. · 2 pitches. TR. Clean TR 2nd go. Shoulder beta at crux, go L hand up · Lead / Redpoint. With Letty. 3 TR laps, 1st lead go. Quickest Index 5.12 so far? Wtf is happening... · Follow. This thing is sweet. Overhanging and pumpy sport moves, a novelty for index · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 hang. Missed the high right foot before going up to pinch. After pinch get feet up on shelf and get the cornery Gaston, get right hand side pull, left crimp, right hand up to higher side pull, right foot stands on pinch, left hand up to slopey block, holds get better and better as you go · Lead / Fell/Hung. So close to the OS. 1-fall at the crux. Think I could get it next go. Pumpy. Best sport route at Index? · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. - 2022-08-06 Soooo close then went low instead of high on the last section of the crux. Aaaaahhh! · Lead. with Aaron. best guess at which route we did. was fun did all but one move · Lead / Fell/Hung. Gotta day this was one of my favorite sport climbs at index. Reminded me of equinox. Fell just after clipping the last bolt so excited to go back for the red point.

routes.route_description: Just before the final slab of Soul on Ice, clip a bolt out left and angle that direction to the anchor of Young Cynics.  This is arguably the best 11+ at Earwax.  Excellent.  This route was scrubbed on March 8th, 2014.
routes.route_location: Starts just right of Young Cynics.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Currently clean! Super good route that has seen quite a bit of (rightfully due) traffic this season. A nice place to go after an UTW romp. Stays shady, skin friendly and fun! Fixed lower offs on the anchor and maybe even some seasonal draws through the bulge. May 6, 2019
This line cuts hard left along a hand rail to the 'Young Cynics' anchor around bolt #10. Jul 17, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Good rail out right after hitting sloper with your left hand · TR. Hangs. Gaston side pull above roof crux with left hand. Definitely match hands below pyramid jug · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hardest lead to date. Felt solid on lower moves. Got a little desperate on the dyno to jug at top of tower where it was thin. · Lead / Redpoint. Got it first go. Have done raggedy Andy so don’t think it’s a flash · TR. 1 take on a dumb spot on second ledge, should have rested longer and got my hands straight. Was right below pyramid jug · Lead / Fell/Hung. need to figure out beta at bulge with right hand crimp, can't find good left hand or left feet. There's a good right sideways jug but need to free my right hand

routes.route_fa: Greg Collum, Larissa Collum, Matt Kerns (~1990)
routes.route_description: A fantastic sport climb using small edges and sidepulls to move across a disquietingly blank-looking wall. The moves all work out and its easier than it appears from the ground. Watch out for the sting in the tail, with a cruxy sequence coming just before the chains.The large roofs above will keep this climb dry for a bit during the rain.
routes.route_location: This route begins atop the large block/flake just left of the thin crack "Earwax". A belay bolt is in place, and the route moves up and right, with a  5.11+ direct start coming in from below around bolt #4.
routes.route_protection: Fully bolted, with Mussy Hooks for lowering. Take 8 (or so) quickdraws.

route_comments.comment_text: greg collum did the first ascent of this route. good warm up. Jul 14, 2009
Very fun route, especially the last few moves. Compared to the other moderate on the wall, The Black Flag..., this route has more rests and seems slightly easier. Jul 29, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. I went up/left and then right to get to the flake at the top - have to commit to gain it and fall into the crack. Pretty solid once you have it · Lead / Fell/Hung. Super smooth until the traverse to the juggy lay back where I fell. After a hang same move was ez but strengthy. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung at 5th and last bolt. Stay a bit lower between ~3/4-5? Clipping 5 from lower instead of leaning in from left would be way chiller. End is friendlier than it looks. Big rest on 6th bolt rail. Hidden megajug directly opposite from final crack. Throw and it’ll stick. · Lead / Onsight. Awesome traverse. The edges are there, heartbreaker final move if you blow it. · Lead / Onsight. trickier moves than black flag, but the holds are just as good · Lead / Onsight. Very enjoyable and true to the grade. TRed the beginning of Earwax off the Sideshow anchors.

routes.route_description: Climb the direct start to Killslug situated just right of the enormous block leaning against the wall.  This variation climbs directly into the finish of Sideshow.  Currently, this climb is filthy and will require a scrubbing.  Haven't been on it.  But, the crux is likely in line with the overall style, thin edging.
routes.route_location: Next route left of Earwax crack.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Slug show is freshly rebolted with 1/2in SS. Note that through the roof (kill slug) is still in need of scrub and new hardware. As for this rig, it is thin, delicate and very technical. Yet another fantastic earwax wall tango. Feels very hard until you learn the dance, and quickly becomes effortless. Easily TRd from sideshow to hang draws and work beta. Jun 26, 2019

routes.route_description: Overhung climbing on mostly positive holds leads over a bulge to very continuous micro-edging on the more gradual headwall. Extremely thin at the crux. This is quintessential Index sport climbing: thin, desperate, and requiring an absolute fusion of poise and raw power. Awesome!
routes.route_location: This is the left of two routes and a number of variations that begin on the wall just left of the obvious arete (Biology of Small Appliances). The route continues more or less straight up the wall, while two variations (Raggedy Andy, .12a *** and Raggedy Ann, .11d ***) take off from the 7th (right after bulge) and 10th (directly right of anchor) bolts. They end at the Young Cynics anchor.A 60m rope will get you down from the top.
routes.route_protection: ~12 bolts to an anchor equipped with lowering carabiners.

route_comments.comment_text: This is route has been scrubbed clean. Feb 2nd, 2014. Mar 9, 2014
Finished SOI yesterday Drew.  Stout 12+ is probably a fair grade.  Now you get back up there and try the direct version I bolted via the start of Antidote.  :-> Jan 14, 2015
This route is still very clean, very cool, and very hard. There's a rad sidepull/handlebar hold a couple bolts from the top that felt both crucial and a little fragile. Oct 12, 2022

routes.route_description: Shocking! another amazing route at the high garden! Once guarded by a potent dose of mixed metal exploding-bolt-hanger mayhem, this route has again been scrubbed and rebolted back into feasibility.Two potential starts see you a nice vertical bar via decent feet and creative crimping. Utilizing some amorphous crystal pockets, pirouette through a crux, and work into a big flake. Easier climbing leads to chains.
routes.route_location: Just left of domestic bliss
routes.route_protection: 9 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: clean and fun! Saw two ascents this past weekend.  I would call this easier than biology of small appliances, but i would also call it 12b. YMMV. Sep 30, 2019

routes.route_description: The second free route to be put up on Earwax Wall, earlier went by a now-redacted name.Follows a crack up the face, then goes over roof at right-facing corner, and then follows the crack up and right (crux). Lots of face holds going up to the roof, the crack often just serving as a place for pro. A slight reach at the roof to a sinker hand jam, and then the crack thins out. The hardest part is above the roof, so save some of that hatred of Helene to channel your energies here.If the part below the roof is wet, you can climb into the route from the Black Flag route just to the right, joining Helene at the roof.
routes.route_location: Left side of Earwax Wall. Starts on top of left edge of big block resting against the wall.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2". Had three fixed pieces. The pins above the roof may be gone, but small cams should work.

route_comments.comment_text: This is route has been scrubbed by Jon Nelson. March 8th, 2014. Mar 9, 2014

At least as good as Earwax.  A body length or two above the roof the cracks become bottoming and more like grooves than cracks.  This is where the pins were located - not sure if they are still there.  Not sure if they were LAs or Bugaboos.  I thought that maybe some larger cams might work there rather than small cams which didn't exist at the time.  30 year old memory might not be so good. Nov 29, 2018

Actually, a slight correction to Ben's comment above: I cleaned the part below the roof in 2014. But then got distracted by the neighboring line. There had been a fixed line up to the anchor, but we didn't know who had left it there or when. It might even still be there- Dec 1, 2018

routes.route_description: Thin edging straight up and over the roof (crux) to the belay on Earwax.
routes.route_location: Right of Earwax crack.
routes.route_protection: 9 bolts. The crux has a large glue-in ringbolt.

route_comments.comment_text: This is route has been scrubbed clean.  March 8th, 2014. Mar 9, 2014
I tried some of the moves just below and over the roof -- very thin cranking below the roof, pumpy slopers just above. Jul 29, 2014
Didn't this route have a distinction as an early roto-hammer sport route? I thought it got the 13a grade? It definitely has a very reachy move at the crux and slipper feet. Jan 29, 2023

area_description: The region from Earwax Wall (which ends at Friends in Holy Places) to all regions further left.
area_getting_there: Same approach as for the Upper Town Wall. Upon reaching Earwax Wall, just keep walking left.An alternate approach is to turn off the UTW trail at Shady Lane, traverse the base of Shady Lane to the end, and meander up and right. It is a scenic way, but less traveled. The last part does not yet have an established trail and involves carefully skirting some bluffs -- so be careful if you choose this approach.

area_comments.comment_text: Has anyone climbed Sportfishing? Jun 13, 2014
Sportfishing looks great, particularly the top. I've never heard of anyone doing it though. Next time I visit the area, and it's dry, I'd like to give it a shot. Jun 14, 2014
Jon, I came across 2 more routes 150' left of Sportfishing, short with ancient slings, overhanging about 40' long. Mar 19, 2017

routes.route_description: Prominent bolted arete.Climb up easy blocky ledges until you can step onto the left side of the arete. Stay on the arete. The crux is near the 5th bolt, though there are 11ish sections near the bottom and top.
routes.route_location: About 60 feet left of House of Helene, just left of a gully.
routes.route_protection: About 12 bolts. The second clip is said to be reachy.

route_comments.comment_text: Great route, the crux sequence is super fun. There are a few old bolts but good ones are never too far away. May require a 70m rope to lower off, but there are intermediate anchors in the chimney to the right just in case. Currently clean. Sep 15, 2016
Wonderful route Sep 28, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Really amazing route. Pretty hard to onsight. Last move to the chains is nice too · Lead / Fell/Hung. Free snake from R til the 5th bolt. Had some trouble at the 1st crux ~2nd bolt. Dangled like a dummy a few times before sorting out longer 5th bolt crux - then sent clean. Spent too long before the finish, didn’t need to go far right. · TR. Fun, at mid crux use L pockets. Bring big gear to protect scary clip · Lead / Onsight. Long and interesting with great position. feels like a pitch off golden road · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the 5th bolt crux, got back on and fell below the chains. Good links, supper fun. All there.

routes.route_description: Fully cleaned and rebolted summer 2021.Pitch one,a short flake under-cling layback onto a ledge. Follow  two bolts traversing a ledge, then up wandering crack/flake systems. Very classic features. Use runners as the pitch zig zags between weaknesses.Pitch two,ascends a very nice hand crack, vertical to gently overhanging. Mind some possibly friable rock just before the belay.****Many years ago this climb topped put the wall. It may be possible but the short section of rock above the second belay is fractured and over grown. Worth recleaning in future years.****Both pitches can be linked and rapped with a 70m rope. You could top rope it with directionals.
routes.route_location: Walk to Earwax wall then continue along the path passing a series of wet corner systems. One of these is “Everest Without Lycra”  The large flake start for Sport Fishing is obvious from the trail after passing these features. Look above for a clean bubbly head wall.
routes.route_protection: Doubles to 3in, Extra finger sizes if linking

routes.route_description: Appears to follow a series of interesting ledgy blocks that make up a giant rectangle of granite. The anchor rests on a ledge above the Jenga puzzle below.In need of cleaning and perhaps rebolting. Doubtful it has been climbed in several years.
routes.route_location: Large block, right of Everest w/o Lycra. Both climbs are separated by a wet chimney
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts, gear at the start.

area_description: This wall is the furthest west of the Upper Town Wall. Pass the west end of Earwax with the murky gully, then Sportfishing, continue past another big overgrown gully, descend along cliff- now traversing west along the Wall of Voodoo. Ascend sod steps, right away you will find Mexican Radio.
area_getting_there: The wall is approx. 300' past Sportfishing. After the flake start of Mexican Radio is a big black blank slab, with a large ledge above. There are two short old routes on the far left end- the very last possible routes on the UTW.

area_comments.comment_text: Might it be better to approach from Shady Lane? I know it can get tricky at the end of Shady Lane, but if there were a few handlines to guide the way, it might be an easier approach. Plus, it would draw attention to the nice possibilities on SL. Dec 18, 2018

Hi Jon, I have hiked up through there too, I guess the passing Earwax is more of a easy trail, so I have gravitated to only going that way. Another option with some trail work is to traverse east from the UTW descent trail- not too far from it, just a bushwhack at present. Dec 18, 2018

I see. I had remembered (perhaps mistakenly) the Shady Lane trail as much more mellow than the trail at the base of the UTW, except at the end (where I mentioned the handlines being needed), but maybe that end part is too much. The other way you mentioned might be interesting too. I think Darryl once scoped it out though with a boy scout (as a possible scout project), but it sounded tough. more I see. I had remembered (perhaps mistakenly) the Shady Lane trail as much more mellow than the trail at the base of the UTW, except at the end (where I mentioned the handlines being needed), but maybe that end part is too much. The other way you mentioned might be interesting too. I think Darryl once scoped it out though with a boy scout (as a possible scout project), but it sounded tough. Dec 18, 2018

routes.route_description: This gorgeous and improbable line follows an excellent corner and finger crack to the base of a soaring, overhung arete. Technical, delicate climbing using a striking quartz dike leads to wild moves around  the arete and a distinct crux  on a weird undercling and crimps with poor feet. Bouldery and pumpy!Might be easier for the tall who can use a good foot and reach to the good holds. If you have less than 5’11” vert or span, the crux may end up being rather fucking difficult.
routes.route_location: Start on the obvious corner of Mexican Radio. Continue straight up the bolted arete.
routes.route_protection: 3 quickdraws, doubles in 00 to .4, single #2, small nuts, and a couple of runners. The crux is equipped with 3 permadraws. Chain anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: Whoa, this sounds pretty cool, wish I still new how to rock climb..! Apr 1, 2021
I've heard that a certain flying hobbit named Ben likes it when things are rather fucking difficult Apr 14, 2021

routes.route_description: Geologic poetry in motion.  Start with a daunting lunge to a pocket. Follow a tedious traverse and execute a stylish mantle into another crystal pocket. Follow dramatic crimps, end with a righteous dyno.
routes.route_location: Left of “Cosmic Dancer” on a water polished, quartzy slab. Look for five bolts, framed between a dyke and crack system.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Daunting, tedious, stylish, dramatic, and righteous. Sounds good. Apr 2, 2021
high feet... semi-committing moves on safe bolting Jun 11, 2021
Still clean.  10b sure.. Jun 8, 2024

routes.route_description: Easy jugs or cracks into a mini fridge cutout. Lay it back through bolts into a tricky side step around or through a scoop.Follow dykes for feet and hands right then cut left on crimps and rocker feet making easy/fun right/left bounces following bolts. Enjoy the views from this secluded granite romp.Very generous bolting on unique rock
routes.route_location: East facing wall left side of the gulley. Technically, between “Wall of Vodoo” and “Left of Earwax” -  Visible from “Everest Without Lycra”
routes.route_protection: 9 clips and a finger size piece if your intimidated by the start.

route_comments.comment_text: A good spot to warm-up before destroying yourself at Earwax! Oct 16, 2022
Nice work, I climbed all over this, noted the cool grippy granite but it seemed like to much work to me. Nov 6, 2022
Still clean!  Good climb. Jun 8, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. seemed hard compared to earwax routes. very fun. very hot day

routes.route_description: N/A
routes.route_location: The only route established on this wall so far, On the right side of the wall dividing a big black slab on the left from a broken buttress on the right.
routes.route_protection: Takes a standard rack, with plenty of extra small cams, bolted rap anchors on both pitches. I am still trying to decide if a bolt is needed for the first 30' up crux. These couple of moves depending on conditions can feel anywhere from 11a to 11c for me with tricky very small pro and committing moves past it.

routes.route_description: Climb a ramp on jugs under an over hang, place a 0.3 and ease left through a wide under cling. Layback past two bolts and enter a finger crack. (crux) These moves over lap the adjacent route slightly. Mind your feet as you enter an excellent moderate dog legging series of crack systems. Aim for another singular bolt high on the face and off to the anchors. The crack is moderate but sustains a 10a tempo throughout.
routes.route_location: Right of Lunar Strain. Look for two bolts, 15 feet above clean granite cobbles.
routes.route_protection: Doubles to 1 or 2 inches. 2 quick draws

routes.route_description: Ascend over hanging cobbles and down sloping ripples. Options  exist left or right to reach a less than vertical slab. Follow a striking white dyke using full and half pad edges with tricky feet. Not as sustained as it looks but reach is essential for the crux moves.Equipped with TR anchor. Bolts shouldn’t go in until someone can solidly solve the moves.Hanging a rope is easy from either Mother North or some swinging from Lunar Strain.
routes.route_location: Furthest right line on the east facing wall just beyond the gulley.* low hanging fruit for the right person *
routes.route_protection: TR for the moment. Bolts may follow the FAs impression of the route.

routes.route_description: Perhaps it's fitting that this only ended up being a one star route; Spaced Man Spliff was probably destined for obscurity since before I even found the line. Why, you might ask? Take a seat pilgrim, and bear witness to the tale I am about to tell.Does the name Spaced Man Spliff sound familiar, yet you can't quite place where you've seen it before? That is probably because at one point there may have been another route in Index by the same name, though if it ever really existed its location has long since been lost to time and the failings of human memory. The only evidence that it may or may not have ever existed lies on the back of the Index T-Shirt, an iconic symbol that has come to represent the almost cult-like reverence held for the Index Town Walls by all who have spent time in its ethereal forests and on its proud granite walls.Made by Richard Ellison, a Seattleite and old school local climber, the back of the Index T-shirt has a checklist of what at first glance appears to be the crag's most classic climbs. Upon further inspection however, there are a handful of routes that don't make any sense; the main one of which is Spaced Man Spliff. I was on a quest to complete the entire list; a feat that had never before been accomplished, so I needed to track it down. I had looked in every guidebook that had ever been printed about Index and found no record of a climb by that name, so I asked Rich about it. He had no memory of what this mysterious climb was (if it had ever even been). I posted on the Climb Index! facebook group for leads  and got a few rumors, but nothing concrete. I asked many of the OGs that had been climbing at Index for many years; still nothing. Eventually I concluded that it was something I would have to create myself in order to complete the T-shirt list. It didn't need to be a classic, not everything on the list is; it just needed to exist.Finally I narrowed my remaining climbs on the list down until Spaced Man Spliff was one of two remaining (the other being Davis-Holland, which was to be my last). I had found this line while working Young Cynics, skipped over by the other developers of the Wall of Voodoo; perhaps for good reason. It was buried deep under a thick layer of typical Index vegetation, but a bit of scraping revealed a crack underneath. From the ground it looked quite promising.Unfortunately the climb didn't end up being all that great, with a short boulder problem crux protected by bolts, and easy gear climbing above and below. In the end that might be fitting though, because the next person to try and complete the T-shirt list will probably have to find it all over again under the ferns and moss that will inevitably reclaim it just like I did. Half the adventure of completing the list is getting off the beaten path onto things one wouldn't otherwise climb, or even know about. Better yet, perhaps they might just put up another Spaced Man Spliff of their own that is a little more worthy.
routes.route_location: The obvious dihedral between Lunar Strain and Cosmic Dancer with two bolts halfway up. It's clean now, but by the time someone else climbs it it will probably have returned to the state of munge I found it in.
routes.route_protection: nuts and gear from 000 to .5, no need to double up on anything. 2 bolts protect the crux, and the tiny gear is over very easy terrain.

route_comments.comment_text: Nice story. Someone once suggested that 'I can see your house from here' (Private Idaho) had been called by this name. Maybe it was just another person seeking the answer. Jun 26, 2021
Though short, the dihedral does look intriguing. Thanks for adding a new adventure to this slowly evolving zone. Jun 26, 2021

Great story. I climbed all the real estate from the 2 very old routes furthest west over to Sportfishing going east. I started cleaning where this is, has some fun short crack sections, a cool overhanging jug arete past a pine tree,( above your line) but I gave up thinking it too broken up with multiple ledges. What about the arching crack at the base, I would guess it is good? Nov 6, 2022

routes.route_description: Work left, onto an obvious foot rail. Right hand undercling. (Clip) FIRE!   ( this is the crux.. gym like…) Obvious right hand.. jump and match with a bolt at your face. Right foot high and flex up into a high right. Left foot to the “fire” hold… clip out left and ascend into a nice moderate finger crack.The opening moves to the crack will test your balance and body control.
routes.route_location: Left of “Custodians of the Useless” two bolts, off a balancy foot rail, into the radical moderate crack above.
routes.route_protection: Two bolts, finger cams.

route_comments.comment_text: Better surroundings than the gym, and it's free. Also, you get some great warm-up exercise on the approach. May 30, 2021
crack eats up gear of almost any size. Jun 11, 2021
Did not make it.  Mossed over. Jun 8, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. fun powerful under clings off the ground with a good .3 placement. cutting left to a giant side pull gives you a delicate stance to get second bolt. following the crack system right with good fingers and some balancing feet takes you up to the top of the crack where the final though provoking crux lays. gear: 3 draws + some small cams and a .75 at the top is nice.

area_description: Steep, clean, but mostly shady.
area_getting_there: Hike the trail to K-Cliff, skirt the cliff on the right and go a short ways up a gully before exiting right to the base of the wall. Another way is to start from the Feathered Wall, and continue up the canyon, skirting the wall. This will take you directly to the gully.

routes.route_description: Thin face, underclinging, and knob climbing on a steep wall.
routes.route_location: Middle of the wall.
routes.route_protection: 6 bolts. Helpful to stick-clip the first bolt.

routes.route_description: Follow the crack on the far left side, just off the gully. The crux is the face-arete climbing just over the small roof.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3".

route_comments.comment_text: Thanks - FA info added. Jun 17, 2013

routes.route_description: Start on a left-facing flake. May bring a small piece to protect. Follow the bolts. The crux is a reachy move after the third bolt.
routes.route_location: On the right end of the crag.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts. May bring small nuts or a cam (~1") to protect the start.

route_comments.comment_text: FA Steve Gerberding, Fred Grafton. Might be more interesting if your short. Jun 17, 2013
I added a bolt to the anchor that helps the rope direction over the top out lip, which is still weird , use long slings or cordellet if TRing. Nov 14, 2013

area_description: South-facing cliff with routes from 5.7 to 5.11c. Less steep than the Lower-Town Wall and more featured, with most routes involving both crack- and face-climbing techniques. It's a nice place to hang out (the base is flat and open) and do moderate routes. An added plus is that the approach is relatively short.
area_getting_there: Take the trail west from the Lower Town Wall towards the Inner Town Walls. When you are almost on top of the little stream, look for the wall to the North (your right). One short trail goes to the right side of the cliff (through some small boulders), another trail further up goes to the left end of the cliff.

area_comments.comment_text: Regarding the description above: in the past, this crag was neglected and usually dirty - mainly due to tree branches that came too close to the wall.  Recently, this crag received some much needed care - many of the routes have been recleaned and some of the branches, etc that kept this crag shady and grimey have been removed.  It feels like a new, much better place. Aug 21, 2011
Lets see some pics Aug 21, 2011
The new trail to this cliff is really nice. A work party in 2012 fixed up the section between Knob Job and K-Cliff, where the trail used to be a root grab. Apr 28, 2013

routes.route_description: Follows a broken right-facing corner to a tree at the top. Steeper than other routes at K-Cliff.
routes.route_location: The route is on a formation just a little further up canyon from K-Cliff.
routes.route_protection: Full range of sizes.

route_comments.comment_text: has anyone climbed this in recent history? looks overgrown. Jan 19, 2014
I've been meaning to, as it looks like a nice moderate. And the formation it is on seems to have other good possible routes. The star rating I gave it came from the rcnw forum. Jan 20, 2014
anybody know if you can get down with a single 70m? Jun 2, 2017

routes.route_description: Unique moves and a bolt get you through the balancy crux down low.  A few face moves to a small bulge, pull over the bulge onto the right trending flake and continue up.  Look for a thin cam placement before, pulling the small bulge at the top of the flake, and continue up ramps above to chains.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 1 bolt, gear to 2 inches.  Creative small stopper placements between 1st bolt and flake, several blue Metolius/red C3 size cams useful on flake.

route_comments.comment_text: This route would be really good if it had more traffic. Had to clean out the crack for all of my placements. Not sure what you'd do with a number #2 on it. Small cams or just a double set of nuts will get you to the chains. Jul 18, 2014
fun TR from Spring Fall. Did not seem like a good lead since I found no gear above the first bolt to protect decking on 5.9 moves. Could use another bolt in my opinion. Jul 31, 2020

As of 7/10/22 leftmost bolt on the anchor is loose; finger tightened and should be fine in the short run, but it could definitely use a wrench. If you've got one - bring it! Three bolt anchor will still allow you to climb the route w/o utilizing the loose bolt. Jul 11, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Moves at bottom are fun but the rest of this route is to forgettable to warrant risking it · Lead / Onsight. Lil spoopy, small nuts required some gardening above the first bolt. Fun tho · TR. i gave up, could get a hand on the jug past the first bolt but didn’t have the will to pull on it · Lead / Onsight. Did my beat to clean, super dirty, but fun face moves · TR. Absolutely loved this route! The beginning was a little tough and I could definitely do it better next time.

routes.route_description: Start in small corner/crack, pull over bulge and clip bolt.  Pull up and get feet established on flake, then make a few committing, balancy moves to gain the positive rail beneath the small diamond shaped corner.  There is an old fixed pin off to the left that can be clipped from here.  Gain the mini corner, pull the bulge, then trend left up fun face moves past a bolt to the chains.Note - the original finish trended out right across dirty, runout slabs towards the anchors of Comes in Quartz, etc.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts, gear to 2 inches.

route_comments.comment_text: Gaining that horizontal rail before clipping the piton can feel significantly stiffer than 5.8+ if you are closer to 5' tall than 6' tall.  This move can be protected with RP's or micronuts--without them, a fall from the crux could be ugly because your last cam is at your feet when you make the move and there are ledges not far below. Sep 13, 2011
Thanks to whomever cleaned this  recently and added another bolt. Aug 27, 2016
It's a short route, but still consider extending the piton to avoid rope drag. Jun 2, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Went well but might need one more lap on tr before wanting to less · Lead / Onsight. Way better than expected. Placed two cams and cut feet cause I'm short. Clipped piton. · Follow. Middle section below the Piton was difficult for me bc of my height. Had to use aid. · Lead / Onsight. Thin pro at crux. Small red z4. Balance move 10a. Hight dependent. · Follow. TR cleaned Bill’s lead. Kept falling at the corner until Bill told me the beta (lie back). Easy to miss the piton at the base of the corner of you just go straight up the slab · Lead. W Leo. Crux on slab in between bolt and pin. Placed #2 in the pocket. Jam right foot below cam, get right hand on rail, jam left foot above cam and stand up on left foot, get better hands on rail, traverse hands and either clip pin or get on rail and place a red cam. · Lead / Onsight. Climbed on the way down from mid wall with Brad. Fun climbing, slightly heady gear beta first half · Lead / Fell/Hung. .3, bolt, then 1 in the flake, i had a heck of a time reaching up to the next ledge , was able to step right foot through into the flake crack and reach it · Lead / Flash. Spice move (but sold once you find it )below the pin · Lead. Led on Amelia’s gear. Took my first gear whip! Super clean fall. Should probably lead again. Super balancy and reach crux (where I fell). The rest is super chill. · Lead / Pinkpoint. First time climbing in Washington. Fun little route! Mostly jugs expect the crack which is also jugs if you use it right. Was lucky enough to meet a gal who let me pink point her gear while I get my trad legs back underneath me out here! · Lead / Onsight. Cool route with a thin move and thin gear halfway up (MR) · Lead / Onsight. fun, bring those small nuts and don't forget to look for the piton · TR. :| got a bit held up on lead near the pin because I wasn't willing to trust my left ankle yet. Josh cleaned it up after I lowered. · Lead / Redpoint. 2 laps. one to lead, one tr to judge Josh's gear · Lead / Fell/Hung. Mostly fun! Got sketched to commit around the piton and hung for a sec. · Lead / Onsight. Much trickier than it looks. Fun, balancy moves lead to easy ramp. Worth doing. · Lead / Flash. Balancy, and more difficult than other 9s on Special K wall imo. · Bottom was most challenging for me. Pretty fun easy climbing the rest. Balancing flake much easier than it looks.

routes.route_description: Crimp up the fun dike past 2 bolts.  After clipping the second bolt, leave the dike and climb directly up the face above and mantel onto a ledge.  Fish in a small stopper behind the horn.  From here, you have two options - go up and right past a bulge where you can get a good .75 inch cam and pull up onto a stance, or trend up and left across the face and follow a small corner up and right to the same stance.  The first option has better gear and harder moves.  The second option, although easier, doesn't protect as well.  From the stance, look for a small cam placement and then pull the bulge.  Continue up ramps to the chains.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 2 bolts, gear to 2 inches.

route_comments.comment_text: A very nice steward of Index replaced the hanger of first bolt. Sep 26, 2011

As of 7/10/22 leftmost bolt on the anchor is loose; finger tightened and should be fine in the short run, but it could definitely use a wrench. If you've got one - bring it! Three bolt anchor will still allow you to climb the route w/o utilizing the loose bolt. Jul 11, 2022
Crux is between the first and the second bolt. Slightly runout from second bolt to the next placement (.2/.3 cam), but not too challenging.  After that two purple friends are useful Mar 18, 2024

routes.route_description: Follow flakes and bolts up the right side of the cliff.
routes.route_location: Look for the long, lower-angle flake on the right side of the wall.
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts and pro to 2." Section between second and third bolts requires thin gear. Some might find this part difficult to protect.

route_comments.comment_text: This route was cleaned and is ready for climbers as of July 30th, 2017. It might take a bit of work to maintain but we cleaned moss well right of the route and trimmed lots of vegetation in hopes of keeping it in good shape. The cracks were excavated between the 2nd and 3rd bolts. Placing a couple of small nuts and cams shouldn't be an issue. Get out, climb it, and hopefully it'll stay in... more This route was cleaned and is ready for climbers as of July 30th, 2017. It might take a bit of work to maintain but we cleaned moss well right of the route and trimmed lots of vegetation in hopes of keeping it in good shape. The cracks were excavated between the 2nd and 3rd bolts. Placing a couple of small nuts and cams shouldn't be an issue. Get out, climb it, and hopefully it'll stay in reasonable shape. It's in the shade most of the day. Jul 30, 2017
Thanks for the clean-up Rodrigo. In the heat of the summer, good clean shady routes like this are so valuable. Jul 31, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. Wouldn't have soiled the trousers if this thing had been cleaned ever. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Yo-yoed up to clip anchors and clean away blackberry vines and get gear · Follow. definitely needs cleaning in the upper section, blackberrys all over the place. fun route though

routes.route_description: Face climb straight up a few feet left of the CF route, joining the CF route at the anchor. One has to fiddle with getting in pro in the seam below and right of the first bolt.Move up and slightly left from the first bolt onto a thin flake, then move back right.The crux is just above the 2nd bolt, where you move right into a short corner and grab the top of the corner. Then it is relatively easy to the anchor.You can easily set up a toprope by first climbing the CF route.
routes.route_location: Between Tilt and CF route, closer to the latter.
routes.route_protection: Small wires and cams protect below the first bolt, though it looks tricky making a solid placement. Then clip two bolts to the top.

route_comments.comment_text: A clean, fun, athletic face route. Also, it is easy to set up a TR on this one. The only downside is that it is short. Aug 13, 2013
FA John Tetzlaff, on gear. Jun 16, 2015
Hey doug what's up with the name... huh ;D Aug 26, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Gear is good but hard to reach at 6’2”. Start could use a quick brush. · TR. 7 or so falls at crux. no need to use left crimp. just stay low and reach through and up with left hand · TR. Led the 5.9 to the right and top roped this with no falls. Fun movement, would climb again. Lead might be sketchy till 1st bolt · Fell at transition back into corner a few times. Was 4" away from static reach. · TR. One hung. Stab your foot right off the flake to the lower incut, not the corner. Then lever over, matching off the sloper. · TR. left hand on jug, left foot on crimp rail, reach up to block with right hand, slowly stand up and sharp left hand crimp, slowly lean out right for handhold on arete, left foot further left on crimp rail, controlled right foot out right · TR. Fun climb. Had to jug through the crux as I couldn't figure out the moves. · Lead / Fell/Hung. At second bolt match by putting left hand under right on sloper move right to small slope hold on right. Have to get feet up and mantle on the sloper. Yellow alien blue ball nutfor gear.

routes.route_description: Face climb to a small, short corner.
routes.route_location: About 10-feet left of Tilt.
routes.route_protection: Four bolts plus nuts and cams to wide-hand size.

route_comments.comment_text: My opinion. Crux down low near first bolt. Sloping holds and poor feet. Aug 24, 2019
This route is often wet and/or dirty. When it’s not, it’s a fun lead. Aug 30, 2020
Does anyone know the story of the titanium glue in bolts on this route? Oct 10, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Ton of fun. Reminder that MP ratings are sort of BS. Day w/ Mehul · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got in my head but no move was all that tough · Lead / Fell/Hung. Led to the reachy airy move to the crack cuz couldn't figure out the balancey short person beta · Lead / Onsight. Haley lead. I used a .3 between 1st and 2nd bolt, a #1 BD cam between 3rd and 4th bolt. Then a .75 and #2 up top. I danced around a little moving up and left into the crack. But so fun. · Lead / Fell/Hung. One hang. W/ James. #2 for after 3rd bolt then and placed 1 and a .75 for final section but only really need one of them. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Zane led most of it, Yoshiko tried, then I finished the last bolt to anchor section. Used a #1 & 2 to protect last moves and practice gear placement. · Lead / Onsight. All the holds are there, just keep looking. Fun! With Jonathan, Kris, and Hasib · Lead / Fell/Hung. pulled through crux up high. think bear hug is the correct beta · Lead / Onsight. I thought the crux was down low at the second bolt. · Lead / Pinkpoint. Quick draws were in place, I placed a couple nuts and a cam · TR. funky crux moving past first bolt, fell once or twice on top rope. I moved way left from the second bolt, there is a tiny feature in the middle of the face below the ledge, used it as a right foot, pulled on the ledge and stepped up with a left hand mantle · Lead / Onsight. Moves at 2nd bolt felt hard for the grade, but maybe I was just tired from Acid Baby (MR) · Lead / Fell/Hung. After climbing this, I learned bolted trad routes are not sport routes, but also not trad routes. Top section was reachy for me so I did some odd movement and strained the right side of my lower back. · Lead / Redpoint. Worked some of the moves lowering from special k then lead it clean first try · Lead / Onsight. Tried to clean, kinda dirty, would be nicer if it wasn’t · Lead. Harder than it looks (felt harder than Index 5.9, but could have been b/c it was very hot). Fun! · Lead / Flash. Very enjoyable route. The crux was near the crack for me. It's a bit reachy. · Lead / Onsight. Difficult, tricky moves. High right foot from left side of ledge for first crux, then right facing layback on crimps up high to stem moves to the top. · Lead / Redpoint. took a couple attempts to work out sequence near second bolt. Redpoint felt easy when I figured it out. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 take to sort out high crux w/ clean fall. definitely take at least two cams for some large run-outs between bolts

routes.route_description: Slight (usually dirty) ramp up to a ledge/mantle to gain the crack. A horizontal crack at the top of the ramp can protect this if needed. Follow the right leaning right facing crack up the dihedral and around the roof to the right and up to a ledge. Continue up the crack to the next ledge and a single bolt. A bolted anchor can be found to the right of the small tree to the right of this bolt.
routes.route_location: Farthest left route on the K Cliff. Distinctive right facing crack/dihedral.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack, pro up to 2 inches. Bolted anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: I believe this route is also known as "Special K".  It is arguably the best line at the K-Cliff. There is a fixed pin at the base of the cracks.  From there, opportunities for pro are everywhere you could want them.  If your second is likely to peel, place gear at frequent intervals to  prevent them from taking a pendulum across the dirty face to the right of the route.  (This mossy area... more I believe this route is also known as "Special K".  It is arguably the best line at the K-Cliff. There is a fixed pin at the base of the cracks.  From there, opportunities for pro are everywhere you could want them.  If your second is likely to peel, place gear at frequent intervals to  prevent them from taking a pendulum across the dirty face to the right of the route.  (This mossy area hides some large, loose flakes which could be easily dislodged.) Sep 13, 2011
If anyone wants to see some first person beta, here is a link to a video of the climb. youtu.be/mKBcMNgFMJM Jun 15, 2019

IMO, along with Great Northern Slab this route is a stellar intro/beginner lead for Index; the pro is good just about everywhere and there’s a nice rest every move or two to place it. No move felt very committing and you don’t have to be a crack climbing pro to have it feel 5.8. This route looks way harder than it is from the ground. Sep 5, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Best 5.8 at index. A great intro of what to expect at index and reasonable grade. · Lead. Some committal moves, but you get a rest after each one. Not hard movement, but leading gets a little heady. · Lead / Redpoint. Mantles at start are very dirty and kinda scary. Placed the low 0.5 w double then locker alpine on piton. Crack pretty wavy, get eyes on cams. Bring 3x 0.4-0.5, 0.3-0.5 offset cams too, 1x0.3 and nothing smaller, 2x 0.75, 1x #2 (#1 maybe better). Save a 0.5 for the end · Follow. Perfect day to be out on the rocks! Aaron got to do his redemption lead on this one - he first climbed it without any climbing experience and got to the 2nd clip. Today he led it clean! Shannah also followed on top rope :) Surprisingly I loved the wide pinch section - super beefy. And then of course the transition from under the overhang to stepping out on the flake. All around a perfect climb! · Lead / Onsight. Extremely dirty leading into the crack. You will be mantling with your hands and feet in muddy tuff. Recommended to place a piece low to protect from a ground fall if you slip here. If dry, probly not an issue. Upper half is money and clean and almost entirely dry. · Lead / Onsight. Ramp was wet - took some shenanigans, cleaning, and teamwork to get up safely. Colin whipped a nut in above the ramp. Pretty epic. Clean lead after that. Wet for about 10 ft above the piton even after 3 days of sun prior. Inside of crack itself was dry though, only edges, face, and feet were wet. · Follow. TR followed Bill’s lead. No falls. Super fun climb, felt really burly for a 5.8, but not my normal style · Lead / Flash. Did this one twice this summer — first time was alright, especially compared to breakfast of champions… last move is a beach whale to the top. Tried the route again a month later and it was actually so fun and chill · Lead. So good. Crack hands, no feet in crack, perfect. Interesting undercling wedge yourself in roof. Fun roof to pull after. Interesting moves and plenty of rest whole way up. Confidence booster! · Lead / Onsight. So fun A great #2 and everything else small Takes great nuts · Lead / Onsight. fun scramble up the finger to small hands. appreciate the mini traverse to gain the mantle and sidepull under the anchor was a great option. great pieces everywhere · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Good warmup. Protects well once you get established on the ledge. Fun! W/ Tanner and Josh · Follow. 5th and final route of the inaugural outdoor day. Was fun. Less crack climbing than the other routes today. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Foot slipped at crux but finished, BB’s first trad lead and crack climb

routes.route_description: Climb the beautiful, splitter finger crack (which ends too soon) and mantle onto the ledge above.  Continue left across the ledge, then straight up climbing past a few bulges to a stance below a small bulge separating you from the finishing ramps.  Pull the bulge and continue up the ramps above to the chains.
routes.route_location: Located right of the obvious dike of Comes in Quartz.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3 inches.

route_comments.comment_text: the rakkup app gives this route 3 stars at 'the best crag in the country'.  i am pretty curious as to which north american semi-classics they are comparing this thing.  lolz... Jun 6, 2017

Thanks to a party earlier this season and a bit of additional work on 30 July, 2017 the vegetation that impeded progress is gone and things have been cleaned up a bit. Some additional protection should also be available due to some cleaning of the cracks. Jul 30, 2017
If your fingers don’t fit in .3 Camelots, you’ll find this more like 5.10. May 5, 2019

routes.route_fa: (Top-rope) Darryl Cramer & Ron Cotman  (Lead) Jon Nelson, 2011
routes.route_description: A few face moves lead to a short, left-angling crack under an overlap. Face climb past two bolts to a final right-facing, steep corner. The crux is finger-tip laybacking in the corner.
routes.route_location: Between K-dav-R and Rise Pumpkin Rise, but slightly closer to the latter.
routes.route_protection: Four bolts plus small nuts and cams.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pretty fun and deserves more traffic. Well protected. Not sure if the bolts up there are necessary, sipnker .3 and black totem would work well. · TR. w Mitch n Adrianna. Fun climbing until the fingertips crux which was just way too hard · TR. super fun first 2/3rds. big moves. hard top moves. setup TR from climb to left. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fun bottom section but lie back was cooking in the sun and not that doable. · TR. Could not pull top move, but was very close. I can lead this safely. · Lead / Redpoint. Really fun movement up to a no hand rest and a pretty tough V3ish boulder problem · TR. crux was tough for me. Hung a lot. needed to focus more on my feet, but hands weren't strong enough. · TR. fell a couple times at the crux but was able to make the moves once I puzzled through them. · TR. 3 hard moves at the top. Key side pull. Bottom is a dirty bird · TR. Cool route, but it is SO dirty! Could use a good scrub and maybe less spiders on it. Would be a tough lead.

routes.route_description: Most likely first route on established on K Cliff.(The cliff was named after the same Keith who climbed Keith’s Crack at the Mid Wall)When first climbed there were a couple FP – an LA near the bottom and a Bugaboo just above the crux.The bottom pin was stolen resulting in some scarring, so both pins were replaced with bolts. The crux is climbing the thin crack/weird arch at the start (kind of off balance laybacking) and making a reach to a jug at the top where the crack ends.The section above the first bolt has several  RP placements.When dirty the moss here is like ball bearings but when clean the rock is quite grippy.Once good holds are reached the next protection is the second bolt.This section is relatively easy but you wouldn't want to fall here.Above the second pin a LFC is followed to the anchor.Not sure what to make of the 5.12 r/x rating in the current guide. I put R here just because a fall above the crux would be bad and the guidebook claims a r/x rating. The climbing in this section is much easier than crux and basically is just standing on the jugs reached after the crux. That said   Its easily top roped as it shares an anchor with another route.   The climbing up the arch is really fun so give it a go!
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Mostly small gear.

area_description: This wall has the shape of a huge boulder partly embedded in the hillside. Surrounded by maples and other trees, it is shaded throughout the summer.
area_getting_there: From the LTW parking lot, take the trail to the Lower Town Wall. Where the trail splits three ways below the Free Area, go left on the trail to the Inner Walls. In a few minutes, you will see Knob Job. You can scramble down and left to get to the base of A Touch Too Much. There used to be a trail from the railroad tracks directly to the base, though it may be overgrown.

area_comments.comment_text: The trail from the railroad tracks is intact and probably the best approach. It is marked with a kairn. Walk toward the Lump the wall is very visible. May 21, 2020
I believe today to be a bit anomalous, but it was blazingly hot on the wall. I think it's cause there's no leaves on the trees yet. And I was so hoping for some shady climbing... Apr 16, 2021

routes.route_description: Start at the base of the wall, on the left side. Ascend the crack, following the rightward curve to end up at the top right side of the rock. The crux is the flaring section on the rightward curve.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Full range of sizes.On an early FA attempt, the leader peeled off near the top (well past the crux), nearly ending on the ground. Gear may have improved since then.

route_comments.comment_text: This is a excellent route. 2 hard cruxes, near the start of the crack.  This is also a flexible flake which is pretty solid, but if you were to fall on a cam it would get stuck, One the rightward traverse as Jon mentions after it goes from good fingers to what fits a #2 camalot it is burly to layback. after that it is tricky to protect. I spent some time cleaning up this pitch, so go get it! more This is a excellent route. 2 hard cruxes, near the start of the crack.  This is also a flexible flake which is pretty solid, but if you were to fall on a cam it would get stuck, One the rightward traverse as Jon mentions after it goes from good fingers to what fits a #2 camalot it is burly to layback. after that it is tricky to protect. I spent some time cleaning up this pitch, so go get it! Jul 15, 2019

yeah Adam, I rapped off that south side before and just did not think much of it. This 11b is great, but that 2nd crux killed me. It is clean now, so someone wanting some burly traversing layback should get on it. Aug 12, 2019

Not to ruin the onsight, but I recall doing the 2nd crux differently. That is, not as a layback. I think all of us back then instead did flaring hand jams, and I recall twisting my lower hand (my left) around so it was thumbs in. It is a bizarre way to jam, but worked for me in this situation. Aug 13, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. this was extremely fun now that's it's cleaned definitely worth the short trip. though expect the crux to feel harder than 11b

routes.route_description: Steep slab route on the right bulge, facing the tracks. Begins with some thin, well protected slab moves to a shallow horizontal crack. Some slopers and a wide left foot pull over the bulge to the steepest slab. Climb over it to a crack in the top and a mono pinch. Delightful thin granite climbing.
routes.route_location: Begins straight up the slab on the right side. To the left of the small corner.
routes.route_protection: 8 bolts and a two bolt anchor with rappel chains. Hard moves are well protected.

route_comments.comment_text: Did this route add a bolt(s) to the top of A Touch Too Much? Apr 23, 2021
Darryl - sort of, yes, IIRC. Apr 23, 2021
Not exactly, I think Social Distancing and Weed be gone are basically the same route. This is farther left. You'd have to ask the FAists why they bolted it... Jul 19, 2021

routes.route_description: Crack climb on far left side of Garden wall.
routes.route_location: Start on wall to left of A Touch to Much, pass to bolts and continue up cracks to a two bolt anchor on left side.
routes.route_protection: 2 bolts, gear to 2"

route_comments.comment_text: Alright Marty and Doug, this is good to see. And it is so close to parking. Weird though how the old 10d "dirty corner" is actually 11+ (Virus). Maybe it had some big roots to grab before? Apr 5, 2021
This is pretty fun and a great way to throw a TR on Virus. There's a bolt to the right of the anchors allowing you to step over to the chains of Virus. Aug 4, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. A nature climb. Very dirty and overgrown but pretty straightforward. Massive banana slug in one of the perfect cracks kinda sums it up. Large block at the top is not well attached, would not place a cam in the crack behind · Lead / Onsight. Did a couple laps practicing gear placements. Not a stellar climb but useful to practice! · Lead / Onsight. this is how it all starts at index. rock? check, dirt? check, moss? check. find a crack and clean it up to expose a fun little line. a great little find, a little mossy but otherwise some great mantles drive you up to the Anchors. will come back and give it a nice brush. thanks to the FA's · Lead. Crux was thin hand jam to mantle on ledge. Placed at least 1 #3

routes.route_description: A short, steep, white wall with a few large knobs, leading to a left-arching crack capped with a small roof. It has one bolt, with the crux just above the bolt.There used to be a fixed pin on the left-arching crack near the top, but that has disappeared. One might be able to instead use a small, flexible cam.
routes.route_location: On the right side of the rock, right off the main trail up to the Inner Walls.
routes.route_protection: One clip and a piece for the horizontal crack at the top.

route_comments.comment_text: This is basically a bouldering problem. We found it to be fun and interesting, and the crux just above the bolt was difficult. The bolt on the face is loose and probably shouldn't be used, but there are two solid bolts on the top of the boulder that can be used for setting up a TR. Happy sending! Aug 22, 2016
I somehow got up this route years ago when it had a 1/4" bolt and a pin above, wow, 10b? I thought it was always 10d, i could barley do it on top rope now. Aug 12, 2019
Apparently, a tree fell right in front of this route, making for an interesting start. Jul 7, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. October 4th, 2024 w/Bugs... used the bolt the 1st send, did it again right after without it - z4 .3 · TR. Stay to the right for better hold and trust the rock to be grippy. Protection is a bit thin though so not comfortable leading it. · TR. Gotta come back and lead this! Was so stoked to see Ethan onsight this · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took at the hard bit, did it next try. Need very thin gear for the top! · TR. Now becoming my tr solo project. Got crux twice but pumped out. Make higher right foot for shorter reach to knob · Lead / Redpoint. Extended a draw down from the anchor to about where the pin used to be

routes.route_description: Bolted face on the far right side. Left hand exit 10b, right side exit,2 bolts, 11a.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Bolts with chain anchor

route_comments.comment_text: yes it is very easy to set a TR for all the routes on the Garden Wall Apr 8, 2021

I wondered about the separate exits. Seems that traversing delicately over to the Touch Too Much finish avoids the crux of either. Still an excellent route, fairly consistent low 10 for the most part. Apr 16, 2021
Is this materially different from WBG only in that it doesn't end on A Touch Too  Much at the finish? Apr 23, 2021

routes.route_description: Fun climbing to crux corner, hard move off thin crimps and bad feet. I have not made it cleanly yet. Still trying think strong. Have some fun.
routes.route_location: Start in corner and follow bolts.
routes.route_protection: bolts

route_comments.comment_text: This thing is a puzzle. Someone do me a solid and PM me the beta for how to get through the upper section of the corner.. 11+? Aug 1, 2022
I gave this a good scrubbing today, this is a super fun climb! The sequence passing the last bolt is brutal. Aug 4, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Solo. Rope solo. Very difficult. Couldn't decide which of the lay back flakes would be better to go with.

routes.route_description: Delicate face climbing with thin cracks.As with A Touch too Much, this route is nicely situated for a toprope.
routes.route_location: On the right side of the lower part of Garden Rock.
routes.route_protection: Small nuts and cams.

route_comments.comment_text: I have been cleaning this, just discovered the 1/4' bolt/ SMC hanger. Still a work in progress. Jul 15, 2019
Thanks Geoff. I wonder if some heavier cleaning would uncover even more slab routes here? It sure is a convenient spot, and like Hag Crag, a little cooler than other sunnier walls. Jul 15, 2019

Hi Jon, I did a final cleaning on this route and it is good. As Cramer says the crux is the mantle. I think it was more like 11a. I found a cheater way around it pulling on the right side arete. Then where the level of the route meets the big maple near the trail Cramer describes ending there and skipping the 5.8 run-out above, 5.8? it was easily 5.10 to traverse into Touch too much. I did... more Hi Jon, I did a final cleaning on this route and it is good. As Cramer says the crux is the mantle. I think it was more like 11a. I found a cheater way around it pulling on the right side arete. Then where the level of the route meets the big maple near the trail Cramer describes ending there and skipping the 5.8 run-out above, 5.8? it was easily 5.10 to traverse into Touch too much. I did some exploratory cleaning a short but good face climb just left of this is possible. Aug 12, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Could use a bolt replacement in the Old SMC and a dedicated anchor. climbing is pretty fun though the best part of it is at the top where it connects to the route from the Left

area_description: The "Black Wall" lies just left of the Great Northern Slab (i.e. The Free Area) at the Lower Town Wall. It has a dark brownish color that contrasts with the neighboring grey rock of the Free Area, and the wall is fairly uniformly vertical. The middle-right side tends to stay wet longer than the rock at the Free Area.On the left of the Black Wall lies a shorter wall of lighter color and different texture. This wall, the Feathered Wall has a corrugated, downsloping, and sharp texture with reddish and whitish rock.
area_getting_there: From the area just below the Great Northern Slab, walk straight towards the wall, going up and behind a large flake to reach a fairly level base. The trail should be obvious. One must do a few scrambling moves to reach the flake, but the whole approach takes only a minute or two.

area_hierarchy.area_hierarchy_name: The Black Wall And The Feathered Wall

area_comments.comment_text: Hi Geoff, I suppose this can be debated. The way I viewed it, part of the Feathered Wall is directly below the Lip, so one could do a short route on it as an approach to the Lip. About moving the Side Walls, I don't know. I prefer breaking things up on the main Index page into more nearly equal quantities, and avoiding having areas with more than about 10 sub-areas. How about... more Hi Geoff, I suppose this can be debated. The way I viewed it, part of the Feathered Wall is directly below the Lip, so one could do a short route on it as an approach to the Lip. About moving the Side Walls, I don't know. I prefer breaking things up on the main Index page into more nearly equal quantities, and avoiding having areas with more than about 10 sub-areas. How about waiting and seeing how other folks want the areas subdivided? It would be nice if there were more routes on the Black and Feathered Walls. Some nice lines exist, and Derek and I started to clean some before getting distracted. Jun 7, 2019

routes.route_name: He Was an Aficionado of Not Only Trains, but of the Entire Railway System
routes.route_description: Start up the large flake on the left edge of the wall. The technical crux, at about 10b, is doing the moves just off the ledge, about 30-feet up (just past bolt 2). (These are the only moves on small holds -- the rest of the route is a jug-fest.) Follow the juggy rail up and right. One can go over the first bulge directly or by moving left (both about 10a). The pumpy crux is at the lip, getting over the overhanging bulge. The route continues about 30 feet on the slab above.The anchor is 3 3/8" bolts with chains. One can break the pitch into two by belaying at the chains on the first ledge.
routes.route_location: Starts on the far left edge of the dark-rock region, in front of the big maple tree. Look for the obvious flake, which may have a fixed runner on top.
routes.route_protection: 13 bolts, but bring a small camming unit (~1/2 to 3/4") or small brass nuts to protect some 5.7 to 5.8 moves on the upper slab. One can also clip a runner or two getting to the ledge about 30-feet up.

route_comments.comment_text: Got on it, not typical index climbing as for there are many positive huge holds. Its good in my opinion not 11a more like 10c. Took only draws so there was a little run out getting to the last bolt. To protect this 00 tcu would work. Nice work on the route. Sep 19, 2011
I did this route yesterday , it's almost been a year since I climbed it . Awesome climb , be careful climbing the flake at the start . Jul 5, 2012

Surprisingly fun, in spite of the cruft and the unfortunate approach pitch. The marginal rock on this wall is uncharacteristic of Index, but the moves are still a hoot.  A 70m rope wasn't quite long enough to reach the ground in a single rap.  We set directionals on the rappel to reach the mid-station. Jun 9, 2013

routes.route_name: Salient Rock Shape of the Locomotive, The
routes.route_description: The start has a bouldery crux in which you move from an undercling to a sloper to a layback. This move is protected by a bolt. After the second bolt, move up to the thin crack on the "feathery" section. Follow the crack, clipping three more bolts, and then use stoppers and cams to 1.5". This section is steep and pumpy. It involves jams, laybacks, and face holds. The crack goes to the left of the roof, above which is a three-bolt, chained anchor.
routes.route_location: From the start of "Aficionado" walk a short distance left along the base of the wall. Where the path starts going uphill, look for the first bolt below the crack splitting the feathered wall.
routes.route_protection: 5 quickdraws plus a selection of stoppers and cams from small wires to 1.5".
routes.route_tick_comments: · sustained once on the feathered wall and the first crux is pretty good to.holds may break one day .

area_description: This cliff is directly above the great northern slab.Be extremely careful up there not to knock anything off!!! The Great northern slab, a very popular area, is directly below.
area_getting_there: Take any of the GNS routes, or Dr. sniff, then walk up and slightly west to these shaded routes.A lot of routes could use some cleaning.

area_comments.comment_text: If you want to approach Winkie Dinkie without climbing GNS or an alternative, there is a walkup and a via ferrata. As of August 2024, the top of GNS was somewhat cleaned off, and a handline to get to Winkie has been installed. To hike up to Winkie, head to K Cliff and keep walking on the climbers' right. You will encounter a couple of handlines.  Once you surmount the handlines, you will find... more If you want to approach Winkie Dinkie without climbing GNS or an alternative, there is a walkup and a via ferrata. As of August 2024, the top of GNS was somewhat cleaned off, and a handline to get to Winkie has been installed. To hike up to Winkie, head to K Cliff and keep walking on the climbers' right. You will encounter a couple of handlines.  Once you surmount the handlines, you will find Laurel's Line. Follow this until you get to Winkie. Aug 4, 2024

routes.route_description: The obvious bolted lieback flake on the middle of the winkie dinkie cliff.The easy start is sometimes wet.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Bolts, gear down low if wet

route_comments.comment_text: Definitely put gear in down low if it's wet.  Someone decked from the 1st bolt recently and had to get helicoptered out of there. Oct 31, 2008

An excellent physical line that will test your endurance and resolve. A #3 Camelot nicely protects before the 1st bolt.  If it's damp off the deck, there's also a place for a tcu lower down.  After the 1st bolt, the clips are where you want them but if you bring a #.5-.75 you may find a nice spot for it somewhere between the upper bolts, though it's not necessary. After you catch your... more An excellent physical line that will test your endurance and resolve. A #3 Camelot nicely protects before the 1st bolt.  If it's damp off the deck, there's also a place for a tcu lower down.  After the 1st bolt, the clips are where you want them but if you bring a #.5-.75 you may find a nice spot for it somewhere between the upper bolts, though it's not necessary. After you catch your breath, be sure to follow the fixed line and short trail uphill to help yourself to a serving of Plum Pudding, a fun 5.9 lieback dihedral.  To the lookers left of Plum Pudding, there is also a mixed line w/new bolts that goes up a chimney-ish corner then around to the right following knobs.  Goes at 5.9ish with a bolted anchor at top. Aug 11, 2012
Here is a video of the climb, youtu.be/l_cT_bNuQYM We top-roped it, but this will give you a good idea of what the climbing is like if you want any beta. Jun 20, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. w/ sam. quite sick! liebacking! got pretty lost getting here and missed the time to turn in scorecards by an hour and a half whoops! great day · Follow.
