Led up a few bolts, left it to Ethan to wrap up the lead & made it up on TR. Dirty disgusting offwidth<3 · Lead. Clean til final bolt, then ran out of energy. Exhausting but really fun. · Lead. Hung a lot and brought gear. Bring #3, 4, .75 for top & .3 for bottom · Lead / Onsight. Haley and Ksenia led. Felt pretty good about getting this one. You really just have to trust the lay back for a lot of the climb. At the 4th bolt, I got into the crack to secure my entire leg to clip. I used a #3 before the 1st bolt and a #.75 between the last 2 bolts. · TR. Top rope solo. Fell twice but mostly still dialing in my top rope solo setup · Lead / Fell/Hung. climb for Quena’s photos. SADLY this was more cracky sport than sporty crack. hardest 10a ever but perhaps it’s the lack of crack technique?? big struggle up the wall ~ · TR. Hard climb! Bailed halfway up, wasn't feeling it today. The first bottom section is probably the trickiest bit. · TR. Still not the gorilla my dreams but a little more than last time · Lead / Fell/Hung. Thought this was the 5.8+ timber jack and got rocked haha. Sustained layback with gear and a few bolts. Think I took twice, good effort but OW is a challenge for me sometimes and laybacks are scary on gear. But stoked I got up it · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got maybe almost there then felt scared and body tired. It’s too hot and my body is not ready for hard climb. Felt like a 10d · Lead / Fell/Hung. Top section wet and not interested in passing. Will do again · Follow. Clean follow. Would be pretty intense on lead, especially the clip right at the roof (pretty far out right). Some good heal toe cams, knee locks, and liebacking (mostly this) to be had. · Lead / Fell/Hung. wigged myself out clipping the 3rd or 4th bolt from a shitty kneebar, then hung to get it back together. Otherwise not too bad, just burly · TR. TR Solo. Very burly. No way it’s a 5.10a. Would be a scary lead but likely a safe one. · Lead / Onsight. Felt insecure, good mental test. Placed .4 and .75, would bring a #4 next time. TRed after bc it was so fun! · Follow. Took the biggest whip of my life at the 4th bolt. Rope was also behind my leg so it was quite the ride. Feet at meh there. Then followed on top rope. If you’re a crimpy sport climber, this one’s quite the challenge! · Lead / Flash. Omfg what a climb! Stellar laybacking up an improbable looking flake. The OW at the top detracts a tad, but it’s still good — just dirty. Kevin hung the draws. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Definitely need to work on my granite footwork.... Laybacked too hard and got seriously pumped. · Lead / Onsight. Really fun and more airy/spooky than hard. Didn’t off width anything but if would be fun to try. With Andrew and Maple! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Turns out climbing this with a pack full of gear was p hard · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ran out of juice before 4th bolt and bailed. Rapped down later to retrieve draw · Lead / Fell/Hung. so much power! Spent lots of time figuring out how to get the feet high on the crux and then figuring out to cam into that offwidth. A good index climb. · Lead. My first outdoor lead! Hung on it once both times I went up, but made it to the top. · Lead / Onsight. Great movement. Lots of kind of tricky moves, a little endurance, and plenty of decent rest. · Lead / Onsight. Fun climb. Would be fun to climb on gear. Climbed as approach to Mid wall, but someone had moved rope b/w chains and tree, making move to tree bit sketchy (RC) · Lead / Fell/Hung. sweb got up half way, whipped twice, and asked me to ropegun. it was a suuuuuuper cool, long, layback pitch. being so sustained, it was definitely harder than 10a. it brings a solid right arm pump · Lead / Fell/Hung. Used stick clip to get up and then got it clean. Lock in that lie back · TR. TRS, one hang before the big move out right 2/3 up. End of day, just burnt, also sustained and hard. Look for mini rests. All moves clean, but top section really slipper, dirty and desperate, knee jammed a couple times for a rest. Dry ish down low, but needs some serious cleaning! · Lead / Redpoint. Fell at the last bolt, took a whip going for the clip (at least 25 feet!) Solid route, sustained liebacking with a physical crux · Lead / Redpoint. Fell before on top rope so had some unfinished business. Solid laybacking was the key. Had a great time hanging out with the roomies! Alana belayed me while danny belated Evan on timberjack. · Lead / Onsight. strong lay back with a tricky off width step around move. · Lead / Onsight. Laybacking gets pumpy by the end. Crux for me was first move over onto the flake. Pretty fun. · Follow. Followed Chris from Outer Space up this route with a full back pack (3 L H2O + double rack of cams) · Follow. Fine pitch but do *not* with heavy pack to access the mid walls. This really sucks · Lead / Fell/Hung. powerful lean back. got to second to last bolt. too hungover; almost puked

routes.route_description: This is an excellent and varied pitch.  Some face climbing, laybacks, and even some hand crack.In my opinion, this route rivals Aries and Mourning Star as one of the best(i.e. only) 5.8's at index.
routes.route_location: Just left of gorilla my dreams
routes.route_protection: mixed

route_comments.comment_text: For a rack, take a set of cams to a #6 friend. The upper crack is much easier to layback than thrutch.  Probably 10a as an offwidth. Those 2 bolts should be chopped as there are perfect gear placements right next to them. Oct 11, 2006
Agreed with the bolts comment.  I climbed the upper part as an offwidth and I didn't think it was too bad.  Definitely hard for grade (even for index). Jul 15, 2008
I think about every pitch on aries is harder.  The largest piece I placed was a 4 four friend.  Good but not that good. Apr 19, 2009

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Great climb with a few pieces of gear. Originally thought the climb was the 10a next to it and was glad to get in it and realize I can climb 5.8+ in index without taking haha. · Two #3’s. About 7 pieces in total plus bolts. It’s all there. Good jams. Trust feet. Take rests when they come. The top lie back isn’t huge jugs but good enough - just go for it. · Lead. Rope solo’d in approach shoes after topping out GNS. Took a ~12ft whip at the bolt. Exhilarating cause it might have been 1st real lead rope solo whip I’ve taken · TR. David Tran led. A good 5.8. Second half was a challenge with the wide off width. · Lead / Onsight. Honestly kinda burly for a 5.8. A tad insecure laybacking up to the offwidth. Either bring a #6 or just clip the bolt. The #5 was a bit too tipped out for comfort. · Lead. Lol climbed it again can’t get to mid walls from here and wet · TR. If leading I would need a 6 for the top or get better at offwidth · Follow. Jenny Led because we couldn't find a 6. took the via ferrata up to it. · Lead / Flash. 5 didn't work, need a 6 if you want to place gear at the end instead of bolt · Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided to first placement due to wet start. Black totem, .5, .75,2x3, maybe a #1?,#2, Bring a 5/6 for the offwidth. · Lead / Onsight. Totems black-purp & red, 2x#3, 5 & 6. Never used 4 or 2's. Clipped lower bolt, flake flexed. Skipped upper bolt cuz I brought the wide. OW climbed top, don't layback it! Be a crack climber! · Lead. Double rack to #3 + #5 is more than sufficient. #5 goes up top. Felt hard for the grade but I was pretty sore already. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ugh today is hard. A few small falls and bailed at the beginning of the upper off width bc I didn’t have wide gear · Lead / Onsight. Fun and weird. Why layback when you have perfect thigh jams?! · Lead / Onsight. Good warmup on the way to the mid walls to climb PBR and FB. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took right before moving into OW near top. Should get clean next time. Alpine draw, 3, 2, draw, 5. · Lead / Flash. Preclipped the first bolt since the bottom of the climb was soaking wet. One of the best 5.8s at Index but still like Aries the most. Felt slightly easier than Mourning Star. · TR. With Kat. TR'd after GMD. Essentially GMD lite - burly liebacks with poor feet. Could lead w/ 3's.

area_description: So very steep and mostly bolted! After sitting dormant the old routes here have been revived with a few new additions. This is a great spot to get some shade and enjoy atypical gymnastic moves for Index. You will quickly become acquainted with the "5.10 high step move" that most routes start on. Consider stick clipping if it's your first time doing it.
area_getting_there: From Lower Rhythm, faint tread heads up and left toward the wall (visible with large roofs). Hug the base of the small cliffs past Metronome. Alternatively, continue past the Lower Rhythm turnoff on the Mid Wall trail until it veers right past a scrubbed lowball boulder and heads under a massive fallen snag. Look for a cairn on the right shortly thereafter and head directly up the hill.

routes.route_description: This is a two bolt direct finish to Unnatural Act that trades UA's techy finish for an awesome boulder sequence out a roof. At the huge jug below the upper roof head left (UA goes right) and fire it to the arete on scrumptious incut holds.If you fail to mount the final arete you'll take an airy but safe fall. The last bolt will be moved higher up in the future but is purely to keep the roof from eating your rope.
routes.route_location: Start as for every route on the wall.
routes.route_protection: Anchor with rings on top.

route_comments.comment_text: This route is a fantastic entry to what Rhythm wall has to offer. Overhung granite sport climbing. If gassed after the crux, you can throw a dynamic leg over the arete, and take a breather. Sep 24, 2020

This is an amazing climb with a little bit everything; some slab, overhang, thin face climbing, an awesome roof move, and a techy boulder problem getting over to and onto the arete. Maybe I'm the worst, but even for Index, this is a really stiff 11a. Jul 28, 2024
Start was the crux for me as a short person. I had to pull on a draw. Would love to hear beta or see a video on how it can be done with limited reach. Sep 9, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Horrendously ugly performance. Gave up three bolts from the top and did some silly ascending cleaning. · Lead. Fell on the first bolt then hung kept going but didn't retry the single leg stand up move. Pulled the roof areas so many times, finally found a good right heel hook left leg bent and right hand in side pull which was so stable and could almost reach bolt area but just couldn't reach to hang a draw or clip a hung draw from there even with full right leg straight extension leaned over on left foot, Anchor to bolt prior and stick clipped the bolt then went up roof to arete, was pretty tired, hung then just grabbed both hands arete and smeared with high feet, great legt hook to rollover and hug the arete. Id do the climb again but try not to burn out repeating roof pulls next time. · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. 3 attempts. * First go, fell at the slab, figured out short person beta. * Second go, clean until the throw to the arete, failed to find the left foot. * Third go, heartbreaker fall on the slab going for the jug, everything felt straightforward though. · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd go. fell on the first move then retried and sent. very very fun. thumb and jump for first move. · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Easy to love projecting the warmup when it’s this fun :) With Garrett and Garrett from epc! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Stick clip or high reach the first bolt then do a little dynamic high step + jump to the high rail. Several very high and somewhat strenuous reaches to hang draws before committing moves. Really fun moves up high though! · Lead / Fell/Hung. couldn't figure out the face climbing crux left of the corner before the roof, thin-ish sidepull was hard to use · TR. Aided the first move then another move in the middle. Not sure how to free this (reachy). Ridiculous leads by Eric. · Lead / Fell/Hung. siiiick. gotta go back for the rp on this beauty. thanks nate! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pulled on the first draw and a few takes on the rest of the route. Hard and powerful but awesome!

routes.route_description: Start with the devious high step as for the other lines and follow Unnatural Act up to the nice ledge below the first roof. From here, follow a series of bolts right out the roof to a stance below a corner. Crank up to two vexing crimps and *LAUNCH* to the arete up and left! Finish at the anchors of Unnatural Act, you can work the dyno on TR from there.It definitely goes but will you be the one to do it?
routes.route_location: Currently the rightmost line on Upper Rhythm.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

routes.route_fa: Michal R, Nate R, Adam W
routes.route_description: The obvious imposing and fantastic roof crack at the top of Rhythm Cliff. Start up an arete before transitioning into the crack itself. Bust out to the lip using surprising pods (11-). Try very hard to pull over the lip and power to the top (12-).
routes.route_location: Look up. Oof. Approach via Stud Farm or Act Natural. Linking via SF is the way to go but there's a stance at the top of AN if you prefer pitching things out.
routes.route_protection: 1x bolt, rings. Assortment of finger sized gear and a 2.

route_comments.comment_text: This thing is awesome. Definitely do as an extension from the ground via  Stud Farm or Act natural. If done this way it's one of the better pitches around. Steep pulls to a nice lock off at lip! Jun 7, 2021

routes.route_name: Several Species of Small Furry Animals Gathered Together in a Cave and Grooving with a Drill
routes.route_description: Stick clipping the first bolt is recommended. Start on the left of the mother tree and walk the plank to a good rail. Wacky moves get you out of the cave (this section climbs much better than it looks). and into the upper weakness. Step right through uninspiring terrain aiming for a corner up high. Pull some balancy moves to get in and out of the corner and continue up and left to the anchor in the roof.Does the crack above go?This route's ledgy center (5.6) is a detractor but it's bookended by sweet sequences. 2.5 stars?
routes.route_location: You will see a massive tree along the base of Upper Rhythm. The route starts on the plank left of the tree but your belayer may want to be on the right.
routes.route_protection: Anchor with rings on top. 6 bolts, a few finger sized pieces (long draws) and a #3.

route_comments.comment_text: Best name I've heard in awhile. Looks like great work on the route as well. Jul 25, 2022

routes.route_description: A tricky first move which may seem really hard for shorter people gives way to easier climbing for a few bolts.  The crux is reached at about halfway, with a tough move getting situated on the arete.
routes.route_location: This route shares the first 3 bolts with Unnatural act, then goes left to the obvious arete, and a two bolt anchor.
routes.route_protection: Quickdraws

route_comments.comment_text: All bad bolts were replaced on 9/1/20. We left the anchor and two bolts around the crux that are in good shape. Aug 29, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. High left foot behind the face requires dynamic movement to get to. No idea how anyone onsights that. · Lead / Onsight. Great movement and position. felt a bit tender for the grade. Nice for a hot day · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Hung draws, then sent 3rd go. B2B with Kurt and Jamie · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Once I sent the start, I sent. Used the shorty stone that was there and had the second bolt pre-clipped per Letty’s rec · TR. sent it on TR. get left hand on upper hidden hold, thigh compression to keep on the arete as you move up. · great climb. fell on lead initially since I didn't realize you needed to compress the thighs to stay on the arete

routes.route_description: A very Indexy boulder problem gets you off the ground. Follow surprising jugs up and right to a good stance at a blank face. Climb up the face (or corner to the right) and pull over the roof onto a hanging slab. Traverse right across the slab and up the final techy corner (or step left and finish via Act Natural's boulder problem crux). Ridiculously cool.
routes.route_location: Upper Rhythm cliff. Same start as everything else via the infamous 10+ high step. Look for obvious roofs.
routes.route_protection: 10 bolts. Anchors now have mussies to lower off, woo!

route_comments.comment_text: Fully rebolted with help from Adam W on 9/1/20, go get after it! Please stay off of the line to the right for now. Aug 29, 2020
Thanks Nate for rebolting this gem!  Super cool little wall, very clean and has both fun techy moves and steep powerful climbing under roofs! Sep 15, 2020
New bolts, but no chains? Guidebook has this pegged at 11c. I think that is more accurate. Jun 19, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Basically aided, 2 loose bolts, incredible rope drag on roof edge. Scary · TR. couldn’t figure out face move. will try corner next time. everything else is great · TR. TRonsight. Should have led but bad back day. W/ Ben, Steve and Emma · TR. Fell at the top but would lead. Fantastic climbing. One of my favorites · Lead / Flash. Aaalmost clip whipped. Going right up the corner is nice at the halfway slab. · Lead / Onsight. Very cool mini index sequences between roofs. “Magic” boulder to pistol squat to thin face to reachy lock to outrageous traverse to a perfect hanging corner. Just the right amount of holds to be consistently moderate · so good! crux was getting established on the traverse and moving up the face at the top. pumpy. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Coolest freaking climb, amazing. Skipped the opening Boulder and hung once after the last traverse, tricky sequence and powerful. Have to come back for it! · Follow. Aid climbed by pulling on first draw to finish the starting sequence getting to the large crimp. · Lead. 10 bolts. Undercling with R foot up start. Somehow shift R foot. Btw 5-6, shift left, L crimp, R foot up. In book- ft up and go up to better R side pull

area_description: A long wall of short but fun climbs on beautiful tacky granite. Grades range from 5.7 - 5.12 and will test you across several different styles.
area_getting_there: Take the UTW trail to the left fork for Blues/Rhythm/Mid walls. Wander along the path for 5 minutes until you see a signed turn off on the right for Rhythm Cliff (just before the left turn for Blues Cliff). The freshly scrubbed wall will be obvious on the right.

area_comments.comment_text: Thanks for the hardwork excited to try these! May 18, 2021
Fun little zone. Nice work Doug, Gabe, Adam, and crew! May 21, 2021
Great addition! A lot of very approachable, moderate climbs that stay shady. Should be a very popular. Thanks for all the hard work guys! Jun 20, 2021

routes.route_description: A variety of TR options exist on this wall.
routes.route_location: Between Coal Train and even left of Jam Session exist lots of fun TR's.
routes.route_protection: A harness and some clothes or no clothes, your choice.

route_comments.comment_text: Great idea. Elevate the standing of top roping and save us from too many bolts. May 15, 2021
So many options, so many games. This section is a Choose your own adventure in a climb, go right, go left, throw a heel hook, it’s all there and wow what a blast! May 18, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tough slabby traverse in the mid section of the route. Trust your feet.

routes.route_fa: Gabe Webster, Doug Taylor, Adam Wood
routes.route_description: Climb some easy face moves past 2 bolts into a short section of laser cut finger crack. Move left across knobs and up to a ledge.  Look Right for hand holds. Now look Left for hand holds.  Now that you see there aren't any, soft-shoe friction your way past a couple bolts.  Eventually a few crimps, knobs and welcome bolts will get you to the anchor.  This is a SUPER fun climb and worth the hike up by itself... but enjoy all of the lines up here.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 8 qd’s plus 2xBD 0.5 to sew up the crack section. Ends on two bolts with chains and permadraws.

route_comments.comment_text: Definitely bring your Mocs for this one! May 17, 2021
Collin getting back on the horse.  It's worth watching to the end. youtu.be/CBuJ7geO3qs May 25, 2021
Did this on TR. Finger crack was hard for me (plot twist: I'm not a 5.10 climber), but hot damn is this rock sticky. The upper slab is so much fun. Sep 28, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Kicked my ass. That slab section is hard. Maybe 11. I never got it fully clean. Good route for sure. · TR. Top rope, bottom section is easier than it looks and protects well, but bolted slab on top is hard and a bit mental · TR. Jacob Yang led, and I top-roped cleanly. The short crack needs maybe two pieces, like #0.5 and #0.75. All the moves feel relatively-doable for me, I should perhaps try to lead this next time. Easy to access the top anchor from Jam Session too. · TR. Cleanly top roped it! Will try to lead next time, slab moves would be very scary though · Lead. Climbed with Burgess - clean this time. I absolutely love this route such great practice on Index slab - trust your feet its better than it looks! Cool finger crack start. · Lead. Climbed with Burgess - foot slip on the slab lets try it again! · Lead. two 0.4s in the crack, shift feet in small increments getting over the bulge part of the slab. · TR. Want to come back and lead this one. Bottom crack takes 2 .5’s and is not that hard. High right foot, then stem · TR. Great slab problem for me to work on. For the bottom part I needed to use the crack on the right and the arete on the left to work my way up. I fell once (?) on the delicate slab above. · TR. fell a bunch but finished. middle section of finger crack is a little wide, tape up next time. · Lead / Fell/Hung. One mini fall when trying to rest the feet and wasn’t paying attention. One actual fall at cruxy section near horizontal seam. Beta at seam: stepped left out from chipped dish edging to friction-y higher left foot. Brought right up to high friction non obvious lower angle patch . Reached up to knob? Slowly reached out to opposite Gaston with right hand. Slowly brought left foot up to above seam, keeping foot in line with body to reduce side force. Powerful pistol squat with aid of knob/gaston. Brought right foot out, sort of stemming across intermediate section. · Lead / Onsight. Super fun and spicy slab climbing! Loved the high feet and trusting moves. Definitely have your friend go first though so you're not the one clearing pine needles off the crimps. · Lead / Flash. for full value, don't use the jugs to the left when starting the slab section · TR. Set up top rope with directionals from Jam Session. Crack feels awesome, should go back and lead. The slab felt like it would be scary on lead. Very well protected by bolts tho so it should be super safe. · TR. Avoided finger crack by bumping up the right arete, top slab is crazy fun · Lead / Onsight. Fun! Felt like LCC in Index. Felt fair at 10b (maybe even 10a). Finger crack is a bit cruxy, the rest isn't too stout. Only a few actual slab moves on this thing. Generously bolted which makes it feel mellow(er). W/ Tanner, Zac and co after cool via feratta and bridge approach from K-Wall. · Lead / Onsight. Lead onsight rope solo, 2nd week in a row was smoother. · Lead / Redpoint. Slabby friction!! Crux is at the top below the last bolt. And final crux before chansons for short people. · Lead / Flash. In TCs. Slipped at the top corner and almost fell off, which would’ve been dumb, but somehow caught myself

routes.route_fa: Michal Rynkiewicz, Nate Redon, Doug Taylor, Adam Wood, Gabe Webster
routes.route_description: Easy climbing to a short crux on the arete followed by more easy climbing and another short crux to the anchor. Top out via "Summer" anchors.  Maybe easy for the grade at Index.  Spot on in lots of places and makes for a good route name.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 9 Qd's

route_comments.comment_text: A worthwhile climb, the cruxes on this route are actually quite good and involve some textbook Index power slabbing. It would be a solid 3 star route if not for the rambly climbing that starts the route and that separates the cruxes. As far as the grade goes, for me this felt very much in line with the other 11/11- Index slabs I've done, however, in modern sport grades 12a seems reasonable. Jun 6, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Did all the moves. Right side pulls to high left foot on obvious sloper for first crux. Be tall for second crux and crimp hard. Lead next time · TR. Sweet cruxes.. lieback, pinch left, throw right, high left.. step left, mono, match feet, high step · TR. got pulled up the crux so no 11 for me but otherwise fun climb · Lead / Fell/Hung. many falls low. up long reach to right up high which feels cheating · TR. A lot of hanging, worked out the moves for the bottom section went for right to skip top crrux · Lead. R on crimp, L on slope. R back down to side pull, move L foot in. R hand way high to sloper, R foot on small ledge, L foot high on crappy foot · Lead / Redpoint. Harder than the slab on And Say, easier than Newest Industry. Who knows...

routes.route_fa: Gabe Webster, Adam Wood, Doug Taylor
routes.route_description: A short but engaging ride up solid hand holds, crimps and solid hand jams.  One can borrow a bolt from 5.10 in B-minor near the top with a runner if the stretch from the last bolt to the anchor feels a bit far, or just scamper to the anchor on easy terrain.
routes.route_location: Left of  "5.10 in B-minor".
routes.route_protection: Single rack + 1 qd and 1 runner if you want to borrow a bolt from 5.10 in B-minor. If you bring a #4, you'll use it. Finishes on a two bolt anchor with mussy hooks.

route_comments.comment_text: Great climb, thoughtful for a 5.8 climber, satisfying for a short route. Really packs a punch. May 18, 2021
A first person view of the route, as well as Jam Session, for anyone that wants to scope it out ahead of time youtu.be/-ZMwbPyB-OE May 31, 2021

Does anybody know what the deal is with the two bolts going up to the hand crack and mini roof above the anchor for this climb? I wanted to climb it but the lower of the two had a bit of red webbing on it so I'm assuming it's something still in development (didn't look too hard so assuming not a closed project)? There was a fixed line going up that way when we were there yesterday. Aug 3, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. Bring a black totem, 4 and QD. Crux is the slabby big step after the bolt · Lead. fun start with a balance slab transition. can protect above last bolt with a black totem · TR. Mock led but used a ton of gear on this, might be nice to have black totem for a placement above bolt · Lead / Onsight. Short but one of the best 5.8 at index. Really friendly intro crack climb. · Lead / Onsight. fun little route, very short but has a nice hand crack in the first half. Used two bolts for protection as well. · Lead / Flash. 1st day leading trad, Marc placed some pieces, first day leading trad · Lead / Flash. placed 3 cams, solid layback crack and chicken heads for feet · Lead / Onsight. Found it just a bit "engaging" for 5.8. Worth doing, but not nearly as good as the others on the wall.

routes.route_fa: Doug Taylor, Gabe Webster, Super Duper Helper Gabe Shank
routes.route_description: "Coltrane Roof" is directly above "Coal Train" and can be an extension to "Coal Train" but is far better if one starts from "5.10 in Bminor".Climb either of those lines, then move up into the corner with the maple tree stump. Awkward and Unintuitive, but not too difficult, movement will get you set with some hand and finger jams to pull around the roof and to the anchor.
routes.route_location: Start preferably from "5.10 in Bminor", or alternatively from "Coal Train".  Ignore the "Coal Train" anchor and move up into the corner below the roof.
routes.route_protection: Whatever gear you used to get to the corner, plus a QD, #1, #.5, #.3.  Extending lower gear with runners will help a lot with rope drag. Ends on a two bolt anchor with rappel rings.

route_comments.comment_text: Video of the first struggle through the roof. youtube.com/watch?v=2NWQN-w… Aug 8, 2022
youtube.com/watch?v=_3ReEoz… Jeremy with a solid send.  Good beta here. Aug 8, 2022
Fun extension to the lower routes.  A little bit of technical climbing and a little power will get you to the top. Aug 8, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Not what I expected from the ground. Finger crack way worse than it looks, hand crack way better · Lead / Flash. Should have placed another piece after the #1, but decided just to pull through and keep climbing. Should have also placed a piece earlier. Gear: - #3 BD - bolt - bolt (anchors) - bolt - #1 BD · Lead / Fell/Hung. The left side of the wall was wet where I needed to smear feet and hands to get into the roof crack, so I ended up pulling on the draw to get into the crack with my right hand. I placed a #1 in there, then whipped two times trying to get around the lip. But I eventually got it on the third try. I'll have to try again when it's dry. Thanks to Austin for encouraging me to try and belaying me. · Lead / Fell/Hung. W/ Adam. Climbed Coal Train and then multipitched the roof with the anchor. Took one fall. Go out left was my beta. Out right worked for Adam · Lead / Fell/Hung. Only need a #1 above the bolt. Left hand in crack, right hand the finger lock, left hand place 1 crossed and clip, left to finger, right to undercling next to 1, left foot to start of crack, right hand above roof, shoulder into roof · TR. So spooky to lead (prolly) but v fun to follow. Shove thine shoulder · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped on 0.3 totem a few times figuring out the roof. · TR. Clean. Awesome movement. Would be an Index classic V3 if it was on the ground. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Blew the onsight. Got suckered in by the finger crack out left. · Lead. #1 for the rooflet, climbing 5.10 in B-minor into this is definitely a better option than Coal train

routes.route_fa: Adam, Gabe, Doug, Sonya, Nate, James, Misa
routes.route_description: Start with the first 2 bolts of Playing By Ear, then walk the sidewalk left to the next bolt.  A baseball knob will pull you into the crack where plentiful gear will be like music to your ears.  It's best to finish LEFT to the Apologies to Kenny G anchor, or more awkwardly, right to the Playing by Ear anchor.  An easy way to set up a TR on Kenny G or Playing by Ear.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 5 qd’s, 1 runner, single set of cams from tiny to 1.

route_comments.comment_text: Short route with some good movement getting into the crack from the ledge. Jul 23, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Went to the anchors on the right, wish I had gone left. Looked more interesting · Lead. can get a sneaky hand jam in around the corner to aid in getting off the foot rail. quite wandering · Lead. fun! comfortable mixed lead can be used to set top rope on 10a · Lead / Onsight. Some fun moves on this one. Just not enough of them to warrant more stars for me. · Lead / Onsight. super awkward for tallies when you get into the crack after pulling the knob. decent enough but not my favorite climb. · Lead / Onsight. Forgot gear so had to down climb lol didn’t want to die for no reason · Lead / Onsight. Jeezo this felt a bit tricky to me going the left anchor, so I went right instead. Probably just being dumb.

routes.route_fa: A. Wood, D. Taylor, G. Webster
routes.route_description: Creative and slightly sinister moves off the deck lead to a powerful and tedious crux. Some high right hand thuggery and left handed underclung improv, unlocks a pleasant 5.9 fingers finish.Extremely good… possibly soft for those with some reach.
routes.route_location: Solitary obelisk, centered between “Jam Session” and “Perfect Pitch”
routes.route_protection: Saign Charlstein Memorial Bolt, can be stick clipped.Small cams…. 2-3 purple metolius, blue/black totems, 0.3s and 0.4s

route_comments.comment_text: The only way this is soft is if your 10 feet tall and can reach the 5.9 finger crack from the ground. Brutal boulder problem off the ground. Jun 8, 2021
It's sharp at the bottom but ain't too bad Hank, though I am 10ft tall. Very body position dependent crux. Fun but over too soon. Jun 18, 2021
Bolt added to the crux today.  No more gear ripping ground fall potential. Jun 19, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. Can’t call it an onsight since I had very helpful gear beta from the comments here · 3 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Got it second go with CG Just an absolute 4 star tech layback QD, .5, .3, .5, QD · 2 pitches. TR. Clean Tr lap Gear: (0.3) QD; (0.5), 0.2, 0.5, 0.4, QD · 4 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Got the crux clean on TR after! Super cool · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on onsight attempt. If I can remember beta it should go just fine. Powerful moves in the crux but really fun. Have ready .5 camalot for in crack above the bolt. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tough layback. Would be nicer if it was dry, but a good one none the less. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got totally shut down on this one on lead. Got it clean on TR right after so there is hope for the future. · 3 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Still felt hard. A lot easier and less committing with the bolt · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Ripped 2 pieces and hit the ground. Cams were stuck in the open position until the kitty litter was removed. Fun little pitch. Will be good with 1 bolt at the crux, or when it cleans up

routes.route_fa: Gabe Webster, Adam Wood, Doug Taylor
routes.route_description: Tie in, scramble up to the sidewalk, put on  your climbing shoes, and throw yourself up one of the most positive wide hand cracks you’ll get at Index. After the crack scramble into the v-slot and shred up to the anchor.  Have a nut tool to easily clean the v-slot crack if needles are in the way.As you lower, stay out of the ROPE EATING crack to the right of the Jam Session crack (Jazz Hands).
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 1 bolt protects the move into the crack (could be skipped/replaced with lower gear at the cost of horrible drag). Single set of cams with 2 - #3's. Thin crack to the top protects well with a black totem/BD 0.2. Ends on two bolt anchor with quicklinks, optionally traverse left from the two bold anchor to use the anchor (mussy hooks) for 5.10 in B-minor.

route_comments.comment_text: It's also great fun to step left into the slabby finish of B minor after romping up the crack. A #2 goes in at your feet. May 16, 2021
Would make for a great beginner lead. Awesome to have something other than Senior Citizens, etc. Thanks fellas!! May 17, 2021

A great accessible, not too funky beginner lead, which are rare at index (many tricky 5.7 & 5.8s). I tried to jam a #4 in but couldn't convince it to so leave it on the ground if you're a gear-beta-round-upper like me. Bring something small (0.2-0.3 BD or black Totem cam) for the V slot finish. If B minor anchors are available (mussies to the left of the quicklink anchors for this route),... more A great accessible, not too funky beginner lead, which are rare at index (many tricky 5.7 & 5.8s). I tried to jam a #4 in but couldn't convince it to so leave it on the ground if you're a gear-beta-round-upper like me. Bring something small (0.2-0.3 BD or black Totem cam) for the V slot finish. If B minor anchors are available (mussies to the left of the quicklink anchors for this route), lower and pull the rope that way (climbers left) to avoid the rope-eating crack. May 22, 2021

routes.route_description: A gently overhanging crescent finger crack located off a short ramp system. The crack is offset and slightly off-balance with minimal feet. An ascent requires absolute commitment to the jams and both precision jamming and body position.The moves are highly unusual locks ending in an explosive yet controlled dyno to hand jam followed by a tricky layback/mantle maneuver to exit the overhang. Once above follow a low-5th slot for another 20 feet to anchors.An incredibly unique and fierce little route with a bold bouldery British feel. Index magic at its best
routes.route_location: Right of Jam session.The flared exit crack often tries to eat top ropes.
routes.route_protection: Small cams. 0.2s and black/blue totems would be nice.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Compressed and fingers got to pod but not hand far enough to jam. Aided through and mantle was cool. Come back when cold and tape cuticles · Lead. 2nd go. Did it twice. Cool boulder problem! Tape your cuticles. Shares anchors with the 5.7 to the left. Highly recommend rappelling.

routes.route_description: Impossible to miss.. A cleaver of granite, keeping time, under the endless cycles of green.  Mind your hips, accept your reach and commit.Stick clip the first bolt; ascend with an understanding of smears and body geometry. Opening moves are the hardest.A test-piece of Granitic Boulderism.
routes.route_location: Left terminus of “Lower Rhythm”Obvious knife arete
routes.route_protection: Bolts, finger size

route_comments.comment_text: epic arete climbing, a would be crag classic if it wasnt contrived a bit. Jul 2, 2022
Unfortunately it is a bit contrived. O well I think it was worth the two hours to clean, bolt and send nonetheless!! Jul 4, 2022
The route wears its contrived nature as a badge of honor. It knows all of climbing to be contrived, and hence to be more contrived is to have more climbing essence.  Five stars. Jul 4, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Many falls. First boulder problem is very hard. Skipped the move getting past first bolt. · Lead. Did the bolted climb to the right of this. Stick clipped my way up- need gear for the top and no anchors, only hangers · TR. Not sure what to think of this climb. Staying right of the arete is forced, and the left side of the arete is giant mossy choss blocks.

routes.route_fa: Gabe Webster, Doug Taylor Adam Wood
routes.route_description: 2 qd’s, 1 #1, and a bunch of finger size cams. This line will have you singing with joy. Challenging but not too tough face climbing leads to a rooflet crux and a laser cut finger crack. Have your finger crack skills honed.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 2 qd’s, 1xBD #1 perfectly protects the mini-roof into the finger crack, a bunch of finger size cams narrowing from BD 0.5-0.2 from there. Two bolt anchor with chains and permadraws.

route_comments.comment_text: Headliner of the new. Index routes are exceptional, in that lines require multiple styles in the same rope length. This one will keep people smiling for many years. May 15, 2021
Stickiest finger locks I've felt at index! May 17, 2021

Finger jams of all sizes from desperately thin to a little baggy. Bring your A game for this one! So incredible, packs a punch for it's height. Careful with the start before the bolts, options for pro if you look. Edit 5/30/21: Main crack seeps mud onto the rail at the roof crux after a hard rain, rail and bottom of crack (where you need to put gear and finger jam) was totally caked and still... more Finger jams of all sizes from desperately thin to a little baggy. Bring your A game for this one! So incredible, packs a punch for it's height. Careful with the start before the bolts, options for pro if you look. Edit 5/30/21: Main crack seeps mud onto the rail at the roof crux after a hard rain, rail and bottom of crack (where you need to put gear and finger jam) was totally caked and still wet even the 2nd day after rain. Scrubbed, dried with chalk, repeated a few times to make it climbable. Scraped out another few inches back of dirt out of the upper cracks (also got a few stubborn roots out) so hopefully less mud will seep out the bottom in the future. It's short but has rather slippery feet throughout, and perhaps because of my beefier fingers this feels so much harder than Pressure Drop to me. May 22, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell three times but overall think it could go! Great movement. I used 2 .5S but wanted a third up top. .2-.5 at least doubles plus red 1 BD. Did not use TCUs,ball nuts, nuts etc · Lead / Redpoint. Much easier on the 2nd go when you know what's coming. · Lead / Redpoint. Such a good day out with LeAnna and Knightley. Perfect temps, sticky rock, sunshine, early fall leaves, superb climbing, and stoke. TR, mock lead, send. gear: 2 draws, #1, blue met, orange met, yellow met, blue met. · TR. 2 laps. Needs work but fun. Loose fingers for me at the start of the crack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 take at the transition from the first laser cut crack into the second one directly above (before the traverse transition into the crack system out left) felt insecure but probably could have punched it through there. Doubles 0.2-0.5 + 1 and two QDs. See prior beta about pulling roof on double finger locks. Place 0.2 right at bottom of roof upper section. Gear beta: 0.5 (removed later), QD, QD, 1, 0.2, 0.5, 0.3, 0.4, 0.2, ? · TR. SUCH A GOOD ONE. Will be thinking about this for quite some time. Such a great finger crack. Definitely a bit of a project and weird crack sizes, but so fun to figure out! · Lead / Redpoint. Got this on the second go. Amazing climb. One of my absolute favorite trad leads to date. Also sent this in the dark, which is always more fun · Lead / Fell/Hung. Trying to flash but got stopped at the entrance to the crack. Fell off the crack maybe 3 times but figured it all out. Hard. Would be 11b in Squamish. Bring extras in the .4 size. · Lead / Redpoint. Felt like an onsight after not having tried in over a year. Great warm up finger crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. One hung on second go! Bit hard to place gear higher up but eats 0.3-5. Pod below crux takes a 0.75 and 1 · Lead / Fell/Hung. Was going great until I lost the feet at the roof and hung. Hung on upper. Made a mess of it · Lead / Redpoint. First attempt today. Rack same as last lap, move through the crux and don't place the blu tot, wait til better stance and place blk tot + draw. STOKED · TR. 1 fall that I saved with left finger lock. Strained my lat but didn't weight rope · Lead / Redpoint. Felt solid. Fumbled a little with 3rd placement before finding good placement Gear: - bolt - bolt - 0.4 grey Alien - 0.3 blue Totem - 0.2 green alien - 0.2 black Totem · 4 pitches. TR. TRS 4 laps: reg TR 1 fall after crack switch, mock lead foot slip in middle crux, mock lead clean but slab felt iffy, mock lead clean with smooth slab. Gear: Left: 0.1/0.2 Offset, red tot+draw, blk tot, 0.5 z4, 0.3 z4, purp tot. Right: 0.3/0.4 Offset, qdx2, yel tot, blk tot+draw (top of R crack), 0.4/0.5 Offset (or 3rd 0.5, or skip). Really plan out locks and feet, don't place 0.3 from shit stance in middle anymore. L hand flared thumbs down jam, R finger jam below it to do crack switch. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Really good. Made it through the roof but struggled with my feet higher up. Wanted to try again but there was a line :/ · TR. Kept working it in top rope, no clean run, but that wasn't the point. The crux roof protects well with a small cam and you can place #1 before that. The roof itself is not that hard - there are two tiny footholds and you can layback to the left while walking your feet on corner/features. Good ring locks higher up get you standing on chicken heads (streanous). The top ring lock (left hand) is thin and more solid. From there, right foot up to the base of a small "corner". convert to lay back (again lean left). You can then place your left foot in the corner (smear, but surprisingly ok) and move right to top of buldge. This is probably real crux. Hard cam placement from the layback, then left hand transitions to the left crack. Easier from there, and pro opportunity in both cracks. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Figured out how to pull into the crack. Left hand thumbs up jam in bottom of crack. Left foot smear (with slight drop knee rotation). Then casually reach right hand up as high as you can and jam until you can step up onto ledge. Gear: - bolt - bolt - 0.4 - 0.5 - 0.3 - 0.3 - 0.5/0.4 offset ? Cant remember if I placed or not - black totem - 0.4/0.3 offset In left crack (wouldn’t place again) · Lead / Fell/Hung. Flash attempt (no beta, but had seen it done). Fell right below the anchor onto an unnecessary poor #1 placement (first proper trad lead fall!). Use different beta next time: pinch the blocky outcrop and get under it to sort of layback. On the bottom section traversing right at the bolt, commit to the right crack/corner completely earlier - actually makes it easier (Viper beta). · Lead / Redpoint. started up and biffed at first draw, lowered, removed draw with a stick clip, and went back up to fire it! superb. with Nina! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Did way worse on the bottom part of the climb and then did much better on the second half of the climb. Not sure what to make of this. · TR. Jacob Yang led, then I top-roped. Hard for me, I fell a few times on top-rope. Excellent pitch of climbing though. · TR. TR to upper crux, lead to finish to get gear back for jacob. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. hung twice on slab, clean from second bolt to chains. TR lap after the sploink went buttery. cranker locks. · TR. Feet slipped several times. Struggled through roof and subsequent finger crack. So basically the whole route. Really fun! · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell at the start of the slide pull crack on left · TR. Big weighted assist to get on and through crack from Cole! Super fun · Follow. Fun as shit finger locks. Met Doug and his all lady posse. Such a good crag for hot days - lots of shade! · TR. get left side in after second bolt, push up into the jug. stay basically on bolt line to second bolt then go right. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Wet. Should be doable dry. Bring three .4, three .3, two .5, one .2 for the top, one 1 for the low horiz crack (this will be more than enough) · Lead / Fell/Hung. A bit wet. Fell at the top. Next time try to lay back a couple moves at the crack switch · Lead / Fell/Hung. Sent on TR but not lead, kind of horrible kind of fun. Will come back for it! · TR. Blew off the slab moving right to dihedral but otherwise clean. Good ringlocks to pull into crack. .75/1 in horizontal. Pull into crack and get feet on ledge before placing · TR. Clean. .3 before bolt. Left sidepull left hand. Step right foot to left to stay in balance bringing left foot in the right foot to dihedral. 1 left 75 right in horizontal. Right hand pod, left thumbs down in crack right thumbs down pull up shift get comfortable place gear. .4 high. Pull through thin middle to good jam high. .3 grab left side stem .4 .5 step across · TR. clean first try. slab down low felt like the crux. money locks after getting established in crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell my way up. Need the finger crack practice, always feel like I'm slowly slipping out. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Feels like it will go next time. Worked out where the good locks are · TR. Gave it two burns. Got it clean on the second one. Need to try it on lead when I’m feeling fresh! · Lead / Redpoint. Fell on first go trying to transition between the two cracks. Figured out some beta, then sent on second go. Awesome climb. Good intro for breaking into harder Index grades · Lead / Redpoint. Fun afternoon/eve sesh w/ Jonathan. Happy to send on my second session with this route. Bravo to the FAist for uncovering this gem. · TR. Bottom is still very delicate feeling. Hardest part for me was transitioning into the crack · Lead / Redpoint. 1 hung on the crux, lowered and rested, then sent. Definitely worth getting on, would do again and again. · 3 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. One fall at roof pull then got the redpoint 3rd go. QD, QD, 1&0.75, 0.5,.3,.2, .4 Just warm up for goodness sake W EO · 4 pitches. TR. QD, QD, 1&.75, .5, .3,(.4), .4, Anchor. Last 2 goes very good · Lead / Redpoint. Whipped a couple times figuring out the top then sent! So stoked. · Lead / Fell/Hung. a fall and a hang fixing gear on the flash burn · Lead / Redpoint. Got the send 2nd go by the skin of my teeth! Left hand small gaston on slab move going to the horizontal. Place .4 before and below left traverse, then get thumbs down L finger jam, perch left foot, place another .4 or .5 and gun it for the top · 3 pitches. TR. (.4), QD, QD, 1 & (.75), step up on crux .5, (.3), .4, .2, .75 (.5), QD. · Lead / Fell/Hung. just slipped out in the finger crack, not in climbing shape this season · TR. Clean follow. Compress with the right seam as you move to the chains. · Lead / Redpoint. W/ Adam. Hardest trad lead so far!! Not great at fingers and took multiple whips on gear. Left crack has a jug but you got keep reaching up to find it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Climbed with Logan - I fell on the lower part but sent the gear section. Bring your fingy locks for this one! Sweet route! · stick clip first bolt or .4 down low. another draw, then triple .3-.5 and a .75 to sew it up. two cruxy sections for me. easy once you get into the last crack. · TR. don't like lower slab crux or upper crux, but there be lots of good fingers on this route.

routes.route_fa: Doug Taylor, Adam Wood, Gabe Webster
routes.route_description: Easy climbing up to bolt 3, then Road Runner your feet up to a couple of high steps.  Tap-dance your way left across knobs to the anchor. Harder than it looks but just as fun.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 7 qd's

route_comments.comment_text: So short. So fun. Don't miss it. May 16, 2021
Is it cheating to clip the chains standing on the knobs with the last bolt still at chest level or so, or are you supposed to move left to the arete? The former worked for a tall guy... Jun 25, 2021

As a fellow tall person, it sure felt like cheating to clip the chains while the last bolt was still chest level. The move to the shelf above the chains was *super* fun and shouldn't be missed (there's good beta that doesn't involve going left to the arete). Jul 4, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Stretched beyond my extension to reach the finger ramp, did a finger pad pull up, far R mantle, very high toe · Lead. Did the easier part but scrapey slab fell a lot on the harder part · Lead / Redpoint. fell a bunch of times on the first go then redpointed it after a rest · Lead / Fell/Hung. messed up the beta, gotta match on the flat rail and get hold slightly right of the target foot · Lead / Fell/Hung. Climbed with Logan - great practice for the classic down turning and slick chicken head knobs at Index. · TR. oof da. big pistol squat on ok foothold and then a powerful crimp layback move · Lead / Onsight. Booty’d a beaner, fun moves last reach above the chains aint that bad, it’s all there. · TR. Short, really challenging after the third bolt. No tricks as far as I could tell. · TR. Fun moves! Especially once the beta is unlocked. It is definitely harder than it looks from the ground. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell and whipped several times at the crux mantle until finally getting the move but being too tired to top out at the anchors. Would love to come back and get it clean on lead. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got it after one fall. Super hard for a couple moves. · Lead / Onsight. Everyone at the crag told me this route was really hard at the grade, but I found it quite reasonable - only really one move that earns the grade. Moving up higher to get my chest at the bolt level of the anchors was the true crux, but felt a little silly since I had already clipped them. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tried it, so hard!! Need to learn how to use granite better · TR. Couldn’t do the move to get above the 3rd bolt. Maybe with fresher fingers to haul on the rail but it was really hard. Even the final move to anchor was really hard crimp lock and push of friction knob · Follow. Holy crap this was hard, way harder than it looked. Spent some time scrubbing it thanks to a brush from some local developers. Grabbed the arete on the left at the end to pull for chains · Lead / Fell/Hung. not clean this time, just mantle it with a high left · Lead. At 3rd bolt- R side pull, L hand on round hold, R foot up, L above it · Lead / Redpoint. I thought the mantel crux was harder than the start of Zoom, and about on par with Climax Control (maybe just a little easier). The move to the chains isn't trivial, either. Considering that, I'd call this 11a, but all the hard stuff comes in a very short, condensed section. · TR. It's only kinda slab climbing. Just crimp and mantle up on the thin rail, then tiptoe left to the arete/jug rail and up to the chains. 1 slip above mantle on nothing feet. Hard slab at this wall.

routes.route_fa: Derrick Meyer, Gabe Webster, Doug Taylor
routes.route_description: Clip the first bolt of Stihl Guitar, then traverse right to the crack in the corner. The spicy start makes for one of the more committing leads at Rhythm Lower.  Probably most enjoyable as a TR after climbing Stihl Guitar, however you can follow the corner to the top to a dedicated anchor.
routes.route_location: Right of Stihl Guitar.
routes.route_protection: 1 extended draw, nuts, #3, #4
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. Everything after first bolt was OS. Start was a bit scary because crack was full of mud so gear was pretty tricky and holds were lacking. I cleaned it out on my way down, and seemed much better with actual cracks, who knew lol · TR. Really fun climb with the most difficult section being in the beginning to traverse rightwards.

routes.route_fa: Derrick Meyer, Gabe Webster, Doug Taylor, Super Duper Helper Brigid Stirling
routes.route_description: A short section of crack climbing to a ledge.  Then a quickly fading finger to seam crack and crux dead point. Delightfully fun climbing to finish.  Tall people may find this much easier than those under 6 feet.
routes.route_location: Farthest Right Climb on Rhythm Lower, Right of Perfect Pitch, etc.
routes.route_protection: 1 qd, small cams to .5

route_comments.comment_text: Heemun banging on the Stihl Drum. youtube.com/watch?v=RwZWOGq… Sep 11, 2022
Nice video. Looks like a fun dyno. Sep 15, 2022
A pretty good exercise in technical toe jamming at the crux. At 5'8 11a felt pretty spot on. Jun 6, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Took once at the crux. Finger sidepull match hand , left hand up bad sidepull. Secure foot, just jump. You can reach the sloper. Then go left, not right. · Lead / Flash. A one move wonder with a bolt protecting it. The rest of the climb is super chill so good for newer leaders (can pull past crux).

routes.route_fa: Derrick Meyer, Gabe Webster, Doug Taylor, with Super Duper Helper John Fisk
routes.route_description: Start off with a few easy moves on weird rock to a stem corner.  Subtle stems will get you to the roof.  Pull past the short roof and on to a few fun and tricky slab moves.
routes.route_location: Around the corner Right from Perfect Pitch and Apologies to Kenny G
routes.route_protection: optional #.75 or #1, 5 QD's, #3, Black Totem/Red Z4 or equivalent

route_comments.comment_text: Strong Slabby Sonya Sending Stihl Guitar youtube.com/watch?v=7mI_pQQ… Sep 11, 2022
Unfortunately, it's easy to get suckered into Stihl Bass 5.9. Try to stay on the face. Jun 22, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. 1 hang Great route Anchor can’t be seen from the ground but it’s straight up. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once over roof on slab didn’t go out farther left or right making it much easier. · Lead / Onsight. Got suckered right off the climb a couple of times. Try to stay left. · TR. clean. Very thoughtful movement. Undercling left side-pull. If direct right foot pistol squats. · Lead / Redpoint. Fun compression and stemming moves in corner with exciting exit, then delicate friction slab. Stick clip first bolt, blue and black alien, #3 cam with extended sling under roof. Shorties may want to take stiff draw for clipping second bolt above roof from the best stance if doing the pistol squat move on the left after first bolt above roof.

routes.route_fa: Doug Taylor, Adam Wood, Gabe Webster, Nate Redon
routes.route_description: Start up Playing by Ear.  After bolt 3 and the high steps, meander up and right and merge with 5.12 Bar Blues to the anchor.  You can bypass the best but hardest moves at the end by stretching up right to the rail which goes at 5.10a. You really should just do the harder moves.  I mean, you'll never know how much you can hate a divot until you try to use it.In Memory of Summer Hanson.Suicide and Crisis Line 988
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 10 bolts
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. top crux required for further left than you might feel like

routes.route_fa: Doug Taylor, Gabe Webster, Danielle Miss-Anthrope, Sherri Lewis, Super Duper Helpers: Olin, Olie
routes.route_description: N/A
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Super fun and engaging new addition to lower rhythm -- slightly contrived start leads to tasty slabby delights. Climb this, it rules! Aug 2, 2023
Here's some video beta of Nate Redon. .... youtube.com/watch?v=fkFBAJ_… Aug 14, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Gear beta: #3 for jam session, then .5 for next crack then .4 and .75 for upper cracks, trust move to upper crack - it's a good jug · Lead / Fell/Hung. foot match w no hands seems to be the crux.. trust feet and hope for the stick · Lead / Onsight. Fun! A bit contrived, but worth the go. Arête up top is committing but juggy. Bring your sticky rubber for the slab and trust those feet. · Lead / Redpoint. Super-engaging slab moves! #3, .5, .3, red metolius, blue metolius(back clean after clipping arete bolt), 5 slings, 5 draws. After placing #3, back clean 1st bolt on Jam session to help with rope drag.

routes.route_fa: Doug Taylor, Adam Wood, Gabe Webster
routes.route_description: A sweet arching hand crack followed by a mantel and delicate stems and knobs.  LOTS of climbing are packed into this short route.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Single set of cams from .75 to 4, two bolts above the crack lead to a two bolt anchor with mussy hooks.

route_comments.comment_text: Forget what you think you know about slab climbing, getting established and the next sequence was a wild mental and physical puzzle. Crux felt more challenging (and more confusing) than 5.10 slabs in the Beetle Bailey area. An arching crack, big mantle and tricky slab all in one route is so rad! Great addition to the lineup of index trickery. May 22, 2021
Sherri’s perfect footwork youtu.be/h-2kJ0Fw1xw Aug 24, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. First slab move felt a bit more desperate than I wanted, but still think this is a pretty soft 10a at Index. 1x #1, #2, and #4 is plenty for this route. · Lead / Onsight. So good! The slab is still grippy(for now), so don’t tell anyone how good it is · Lead / Fell/Hung. Index is not my onsight location. Good pitch. Don’t need a #4. · TR. Still hard in the slab area but got it clean. So much trust and learning when climbing at Index. · Lead / Redpoint. Nice lead. Debatable whether it’s better just to pull the roof without placing a second piece. Felt like more energy was used holding that stance. Gear: - #3 BD C4 - #1 BD C4 · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couldn't commit past first bolt. Very insecure big slab movements off a ledge. · Lead / Redpoint. Gear gets better further along the hand traverse. Don't wear yourself out once the lip is in reach. Fun stemming above! · Lead / Onsight. first 10 onsight in index! definitely faffed a wee bit on the crack but finessed the slab. first time tying in with Noah! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell twice getting start in the slab. Almost had the onsight · TR. Hard! Cheated twice at the bolts getting off the upper ledge. Need to trust your feet. Ah. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped at undercling and whipped above 1st bolt. #4 first then #1 then #2. · Lead / Fell/Hung. W/ Adam. Took a couple wips. Used #3, .4, 1/2?, and something else to protect the crack. Ended up using it as undercling, Adam jammed it palms down and that looked way cooler. Slabs are intimidating but goes well if you trust the feet. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell way to much figuring out the slab above bolt 1 · Lead / Redpoint. Such a fun shorty did a full on iron cross on slab! · TR. Took twice. Climb in the rain. Good jug at the tip of the overhang. Nice finger. Finger, left foot. Finger up. Right foot. Left face knob, left foot up. Finger up. Right foot ledge. Good hand right. Move right. Good route. · TR. Super fun lower section and tricky slabby moves with finger crack up top · Lead / Onsight. kinda tricky arch. slab was switching my right hand from crimp to palm press and bumping my right feet up · Lead. Fours to one in the traverse, pod that takes a 0.5 above. Slab is tricky! Use the left wall, open hips, match foot to right hand. Then stem to and above second bolt. · Lead / Redpoint. # 4 ( could have used #3 ) & 1 plus draws · Lead / Onsight. Stellar route. Placed a #4, .75, .5 and black totem. Save the black Totem for after the last bolt. · Lead. Placed 3,2,1 this time because I misremembered and didn’t check last tick note but it worked lol · Lead. 1 take. Fun and technical slab moves! Can easily get this clean next time.

area_description: This is the cliff directly above the Winkie Dinkie Cliff.  It has some high quality routes with very little traffic.  It is fairly shaded.
area_getting_there: There are at least five ways to access Mid Wall.1) Take the Seamstress route after hiking up to K-Cliff (see images linked to route).2) Hike up all the way from K-Cliff using fixed lines as described below:Traverse right along the base of K-Cliff and follow the trail up the gully past the Lip. Traverse along the faint trail above the Black Wall to the base of Winkie Dinkie. Pass Gorilla my Dreams and walk towards the top of Breakfast of Champions, keeping an eye out for a gully on the left. Go up the gully on a fixed line, then a 50' via ferrata that eventually passes through the tunnel. Now you are on top of Julie's Roof. Follow a second fixed line and a goat trail to a blocky narrow passage. (If you take this third fixed line down you'll access all of the top of the Lower Wall.) If you go up the fixed line, you'll be at the Middle Wall.Update: June 2014: There appears to be no fixed lines on this route now.Update Aug 2020: There are 2-3 fixed lines and a short via ferrata3) Via Winkie Dinkie cliff. Climb something at the Great Northern Slab, Princely Ambitions, or hike in from the trail between K-Cliff and the Lip, and then climb Gorilla My Dreams (or the above fixed lines) to get up there.4) Do a route that either tops out on the Narrow-Arrow end of the Lower Wall, or the wall left of Orc Tower.5) Hike the trail that goes to the Upper Town Wall (from the Country), taking the first turnout left. Where the Blues Cliff trail forks off left, stay right and continue across the top of the Lower Wall. This is a fun hike, but be careful about the dilapidated stairs. Also use caution on the exposed wooden bridge.

area_comments.comment_text: A fun way to reach this wall is to do the two pitches of Princely Ambitions (5.9), walk up and left on a short trail, then do Gorilla my dreams (5.10a). (GMD is on the Winkie Dinkie cliff, just above the Free Area.) From the top anchor on GMD, hand-over-hand your way up a short section with a fixed rope, then walk another short trail. Apr 10, 2012
Great area  for a hot day. Jul 28, 2013

Approach: There is no fixed rope above Princely/ Champions. If you topped out Beak, Beak you would find a fixed line above St. Francis ledge. The old trail is really long compared to Gorilla or Seamstress approach. It is past 1/2 way to UTW, not recommended unless you want a long hike in the dark woods. Jun 20, 2014

routes.route_description: I started cleaning this route in a driving blizzard late winter 2014 and it took some excavating to clear loose flakes.Start in shallow left facing corner/seam,  the crux comes low and is a balance step up over to hold on arete, especially hard if you are under 6' tall,  some fun moves next, and then follow left traversing undercling until possible to go up toward tree.  Continue up crack system, trending left then right to anchor at 100 ft. There is descent climbing for 20' above there, and 25' of trees and dirt above that, if you want to go up to the Blue Tile Lounge.Alternate start in offwidth on the left that requires slab crossing which will add a bolt soon.
routes.route_location: Currently the furthest route left on the main wall. There is a slab with an off width crack on the left, and this goes up the seam on the right.
routes.route_protection: standard rack to 2". extra in finger sizes.Brass nuts could be used in lower seam. Green Alien or the exact size protects the starting crux move.  Brass nuts above this move, or blue Alien. Extra finger size Aliens  for many discontinuous cracks on upper half Bolted anchor with rap chains at top.

route_comments.comment_text: This route is sweet! So many cool juggy flake system switches and moves over bulges. I did a lot of cleaning on lead (everything you need is clean) but the pitch is still scruffy, bring a brush and give back! The first move is a little spooky. A black totem seemed to fit pretty well (I don't have a green alien). Brassies are useful after the hard first move. You'll want plenty of small nuts... more This route is sweet! So many cool juggy flake system switches and moves over bulges. I did a lot of cleaning on lead (everything you need is clean) but the pitch is still scruffy, bring a brush and give back! The first move is a little spooky. A black totem seemed to fit pretty well (I don't have a green alien). Brassies are useful after the hard first move. You'll want plenty of small nuts and cams for the rest of the pitch as well. Jun 6, 2017
can you climb this to set up a TR on keiths crack? Jul 27, 2019
Not easily. Dinky Twinkies in it's current form and Keith's Crack share anchors though. Jul 28, 2019

routes.route_description: Avant Gardener follows the thin corner to the right of The Lawn Rake. Pull a few big moves off the ground and eventually reach a cruxy balance sequence passing a small overlap. The crux grade may be height / finger size dependent.Easier moves above bring you to an anchor up and left past the roof.
routes.route_location: Walk to the right of Folsom Blues along the base of the cliff. You should run into the obvious flake of "The Lawn Rake" in 30 seconds.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack with an emphasis on finger sizes. Gear is a little tricky but safe. Crux has gear at your feet.

route_comments.comment_text: That's nice it goes on all gear. Darryl and I had thought that a bolt might be needed at the crux. Fun slab moves down low with easy moves at the start to warm up. Glad to know that the whole thing is clean now. Am looking forward to hearing about other new routes in the area. Lots of potential up there. Dec 14, 2017

routes.route_description: Sustained climbing (bolts) leads to a difficult mantle crux. From here, follow relatively easy cracks (small-ish gear) and flakes upward to a slightly contrived bolt line going to the right. You can alternatively climb the cracks and corners above at this point.Either way you end up at a bolted anchor up and right.There's definitely potential for more stuff around here. The crack to the left has been climbed, and there is apparently a slabby seam project on the right.
routes.route_location: Behind the Green Door is on it's own to the right of all the other Mid Wall routes. Walk a few minutes along the trail to the UTW until you see a destroyed wooden staircase and a fixed line. The route will be obvious above the trail at this point. If you are approaching from the UTW this will be the first route you see.
routes.route_protection: 8 bolts if you follow the sequence out right at the top. Standard rack with TCUs for the rest.Bolted anchors at the top.

route_comments.comment_text: Route currently has a fixed line (not mine) on it and is clean enough to climb but could use a brushing. May 14, 2017
Nate, is it your rope, or was there a rope there,I left a sling and was TRing that wall, can't remember if I left a rope there. Jun 7, 2017
Hey Geoff, the rope isn't mine. I think I remember it being green? Jun 8, 2017

routes.route_description: Start as for PBR once under small roof go R to off width. up and back to PBR finish.
routes.route_location: Middle Wall
routes.route_protection: BD #6 runners

route_comments.comment_text: great fun! Feb 20, 2015
Got on this today. #6 is not needed, a #5 protects the offwidth much better. A single #4 and #3 protected the rest of the wideness pretty well. Lots of fun and now cleaned up a little! Sep 25, 2016

routes.route_description: Climb up the outside of the large flake. The crux is midway up the flake. At the top of the flake, trend up and left to the belay.
routes.route_location: Left side of crag, on large flake resting against wall.
routes.route_protection: Gear needed for the upper half, though the crux section at the bottom is bolted.

route_comments.comment_text: Missing hanger on 2nd bolt. Aug 1, 2013

This route probably hadn't been climbed in a while before today. I replaced the second hanger and cleaned the upper half to make it worth it (but the upper bit is still pretty dirty). It climbs best if you go up the flake (clean) and then left across the top to the crack, staying on the arete above (good gear). Stay out of the bushy corner as much as possible. This route has some fun... more This route probably hadn't been climbed in a while before today. I replaced the second hanger and cleaned the upper half to make it worth it (but the upper bit is still pretty dirty). It climbs best if you go up the flake (clean) and then left across the top to the crack, staying on the arete above (good gear). Stay out of the bushy corner as much as possible. This route has some fun moves and lets you hang a top rope on Keith's Crack / Wild Boar. May 19, 2017

Fantastic route!  The movement on the flake at the start is techy and fun to warmup on.  The top doesn't need much protection, and drops in difficulty.  Also extremely photogenic ;) No problems with any of the bolts/hangers. flic.kr/p/US51Fq> Jun 4, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Really dislike this climb. Sketchy first bolt if you’re short and then the third bolt is particularly spicy. Should have been bolted lower. 0 stars if I could give it a rating · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fun route, first lead at Index. Long approach up the rebar ladder.

routes.route_description: Starting from the same place as Douglas and Fredly, follow a finger crack straight up that pinches off into an interesting V groove.  Two bolts and some gear protect you until you arive at the final bolt of Douglas and head right to the anchor.
routes.route_location: Same ledge as the other routes on the wide slab over to the right of PBR and Folsom Blues
routes.route_protection: Singles from 0.3 to 1, three bolts

routes.route_name: Douglas the Furry Grizzly Wolf Kitten Goes Chomp
routes.route_fa: Jon Loke, Reed Herbison, Sarah Perryman, Tavish H September 2022
routes.route_description: A fantastic low angle finger crack layback has emerged from the moss!  As good as it gets for the grade.  Some stemmy climbing leads to a reach to a jug, then laybacking 0.4s, 0.3s, then eventually 0.2s and a step left under a bolt.  Continue up right to an anchor at a nice ledge.
routes.route_location: Start off a ledge with a big tree 10 feet above the trail under the large slab.  Over to the right of the Plum Pudding-Folsom Blues area.
routes.route_protection: Single set of cams from 0.2 to 1 will do, one bolt where the flake gets a bit hollow at the top

route_comments.comment_text: Looks awesome nice find y'all!! Sep 9, 2022
The Doug continues!!! Psyched this little patch is getting some long time needed attention. I predict some rad features under that green! Nice job y’all !! Sep 9, 2022
Rather delightful. Anchors will twist your rope. May 25, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Got pretty scared on the slab portion and had to flail to figure out gear but didn’t take · Lead / Onsight. Great friction for feet but took me a second to trust it for the layback moves. Fun and pretty easy. · TR. Warm up with Clemo - this is a high quality route that I wish was longer! · TR. Top roped then mock lead. 3 .3s would not go unused. Perfect .75 placement in a pod near the top after the runout slab, if you want.

routes.route_description: Chimney up the right side of a large flake. At the top of the flake, follow another flake/edge up and left to the belay. For P2, trend up and left until you can move right.
routes.route_location: Look for the large flake left of Hips and Valley. A bolted face route exists on the outside of the flake.
routes.route_protection: Full range of gear.

routes.route_description: Generally follows a right-facing corner.Starts with a short hand crack that goes to a sloping ramp below the corner. Do several bolt-protected layback moves into the corner. When the good layback edges fade (at 3rd bolt), stem right onto the large knob and then move right to climb up the knobby face. At the top of the face, step back left over the top of the corner and trend up and left to the chained anchor on Robin's Ramp.
routes.route_location: Left of Robin's Ramp, just left of obvious finger crack. Shares the same start as Hips and Valleys.
routes.route_protection: Large cam for hand crack at bottom, small wires (brass nuts useful) to protect the clip to the first bolt, at least 4 quickdraws for the 4 bolts, and some finger-to-hand-sized pieces for the top.

route_comments.comment_text: You bolted a route that went free last year on gear, on-sight. We didn't have the temerity to assume that it was an FA, let alone to think about adding bolts. Aug 17, 2012
I think Jon bolted a variation to what you climbed. Aug 18, 2012

There are bolts now inside the flare that protected with gear. Going to the arete may be a variation, but they added bolts to the start in the flare well before traversing to the arete. I understand that the gear is small, tricky and heady, but it's still there. With the knowledge that it is not an FA through the flare, I think the bolters should correct their actions. I'm not trying to be... more There are bolts now inside the flare that protected with gear. Going to the arete may be a variation, but they added bolts to the start in the flare well before traversing to the arete. I understand that the gear is small, tricky and heady, but it's still there. With the knowledge that it is not an FA through the flare, I think the bolters should correct their actions. I'm not trying to be provocative or confrontational, just informative. Aug 20, 2012

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Think we sorta did a variation? Didn’t follow the bolt line but went left into the chimney · TR. Super fun and diverse. Awkward though. Had to take a couple times but would love to do this without taking · Lead / Onsight. Great route! Slipped a bit starting the flare - it was dumb so I’m going to give myself the send · Lead / Redpoint. Got flippo clean! Felt much easier than last time i was on it. Good to feel progress! · TR. Funky! Fell at the transition on the knobs onto the face. Highline day · Follow. can finish at anchor above stems and valleys, which is about 10 ft higher than the anchor for robins ramp · Lead / Fell/Hung. Missed slot hold and whipped at 3rd bolt - so dumb. Remember to look for hands and feet when climbing · TR. Pulled on gear because I didn’t take the time to find the holds. They are all there just look. · TR. Paul put in a high redirect which made this much better to TR. Loved the corner, lots of quite good flakes/layback holds that aren’t apparent til you get there. Moving R onto the chickenheads was hard! Big move for me but fortunately at the bolt. Had to dyno to. LH but it was sinker! Above that my arms were 100% stretched out haha. One slip when moving up RF but when I readjusted to bumping that first it went more easily. The “roof” had some awkward bits, hands were more tenuous, then cruiser above! · TR. Toprope off the shared anchor with MW crack. Crack is pretty good, knobs are harder for short people. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Should have sent, but got spooked after struggling to clip the last bolt before leaving the flare and took. Oh well. Knobs are fun. · TR. Legit. Reaching the knobs at the top of the crack was definitely crux and at my limit. · TR. seems like 2 options, did both. the slab out on the right face is rad. but straight up makes more sense. · TR. Lead this next time!! Don’t forget left ledge foot and trust your strength on the nubbins

routes.route_description: A slightly lower angle buttress just right of PBR. Follow layback edges to a thin crack above an overlap. Climb the thin crack (crux) to a face crack above (10a).
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Full range of sizes.

route_comments.comment_text: Awesome route.  Gear to 1.5". Small gear protects upper crack.  2013 route is clean. Jul 28, 2013
Many thanks to whomever cleaned this route. Awesome. Aug 2, 2013

Repeating what Lukic said, THANKS to whoever cleaned the line.  On lead, this line may feel a little stiff for the grade at first, but tames down with a little work.  Reminiscent of ZOOM, with a strenuous start and fun knobs higher up.  Unlike ZOOM, just about every inch of the climb is protectable. It isn't obvious at first when it's best to kick out to the tips-crack, but don't continue... more Repeating what Lukic said, THANKS to whoever cleaned the line.  On lead, this line may feel a little stiff for the grade at first, but tames down with a little work.  Reminiscent of ZOOM, with a strenuous start and fun knobs higher up.  Unlike ZOOM, just about every inch of the climb is protectable. It isn't obvious at first when it's best to kick out to the tips-crack, but don't continue up the wider, easier climbing once the thin crack becomes an option.  Get out there and squish your fingertips into the crack and smear the knobs. Aug 24, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ugh, the start boulder is tricky. Got stumped hard on it. Rest went well. · Lead / Redpoint. *Fell at bulge and lowered, didn’t pull rope and climbed it with that gear pre-clipped. · Follow. Lead some of it and then bailed. Also couldn’t get the bottom move. · TR. Can lead this, super super small gear at the top like 0s if u have em, bring one 2 for just before the traverse. Roof beta is in my photos from sept 8. Top is spoopy but protectable · TR. Keep hands high ( far left of the flake) for Bouldery Crux. Traverse into finger crack and use knobs to climb up. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Not clean at the bottom but still did the move. Rest was cruiser and awesome · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the crux a few times - great route! Bouldering crux followed by a long sustained finger crack · TR. Lu and I got to TR this after a fellow gal climber put it up. So fun on TR. I laid back and walked feet up then got the right foot into the wedge and left foot out and pulled my right thigh to get into the pod. So cool! Thanks to the gals for figuring out the beta for the crux move. Loved the entire climb. Fun stem section and little knobs with the finger crack in the upper section. · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Clemo - really enjoyed this route! Layback to kneebar rock over for the roof and fingers are easier than they look.
