In hindsight Id place more than one piece below the roof that's the business and has ground fall potential. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at low crux. Clean go on TR after. Have beta for layback down. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a nice whip first go on the boulder problem. Got it second go and sent it to the chains. · Lead / Redpoint. asterisk on the lead. i took a fall pulling the ledge on the boulder problem at the beginning, but the move or two i didnt do from that hang are trivial. anyway this was sick. aaron n max were there. · Lead / Redpoint. put the burners on for the low crux and cruised the rest of the way. always bring doubles in your tinys, you’re in index motherfucker! With Paddington · Lead / Redpoint. Second go, blew the bottom first time around. The top is very fun!! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Layback move at the roof spanked me good. After that nice 10a climbing · Lead / Fell/Hung. Left foot a little out left. Don't try to bring it up to right. Works hands up very high until you can get high right foot and kneebarish · TR. Hardest 10c - .5’s through crust layback bulge - right hand right, left hand slaps arete, get right toe in crack at lip (footjam below) · TR. Did it cleanly without rope help! Would definelty lead next time I’m here. One of my index favorites so far · Lead / Fell/Hung. So confident after doing it on TR a year ago and then totally failed lol. Maybe more than five minutes of rest would help??? who could say · Lead / Fell/Hung. Still had to aid through the first section. Couldn’t figure it out on lead. Looks like from videos, right foot flag to get into layback, right foot up, left foot up under, right foot *high* (almost near hands), left foot press into wall bumping up hands and pulling hard, right foot/heel into crevice and rock over it. Bring either double 0.4s and plug one low in the crux bulge or triple 0.5s and plug two down low. Only need single 1. Triple 0.2s is good for the upper crack. Smallest ball nut for initial step around if possible. · TR. Clean TR burn after one fall in the crux. Will lead next time. · TR. Tried to lead this and whipped like 5 times at the crux. Then top roped it · TR. 2 TR laps. pinned right hand against the arete with knee, lol. don't do that when leading · Lead / Fell/Hung. Foot slipped at the crux, first trad fall, had two bomber cams · Lead / Fell/Hung. Place the .5 as high as possible for real!! Use the left foot rail · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell three times at bottom. Didn’t read old beta, couldn’t figure it out after falls, ended up aiding through. Think I need to layback, bring both feet up and out to side to bump them up, then bring left foot back over for support after right foot is up on top. Feet kept slipping in layback but I think it was because I had them too low. Upper crack was fair but I was a bit rattled from the bottom and didn’t want to commit to moving around and getting back in the finger crack. Thin gear was okay but was up in my head trying to not block the good holds. Maybe strategy is to find the good holds, then place gear at waist/below hands so I know I’m not blocking future holds? · TR. Clean top rope send. Beta on the bottom bulge. Layback out right from the 0.5 crack, bumping hands up and setting left foot out the left to relieve hands someone. Rock up over while grabbing crack (ring lock/finger stack?) down low to get into corner. Finger crack up top is THIN. Index/middle finger tips. Definitely want a healthy number of 0.2 size cams probably and some micro nuts to sew this thing up. Don’t cross over into the finger crack too early or it’ll be too thin. · Lead / Fell/Hung. didn't read it right down low. such a sick upper finger crack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Layback and paste feet on right corner. Left foot on rail, get knee up. Placed a bunch of .2s and .3s in finger crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided the crux. Was fine up top. Super burly crux. Harder than it looks. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Brutally hard, get that .5 as high as possible and then commit to the laybacking. Bring lots of .1-.3 for the final tips part. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the crux but eventually pulled it. The rest is cruiser · Lead / Fell/Hung. 3-4 hangs because I was trying to ring lock and then eventually I realized I could lie back!!! Amazing · TR. surely much harder on lead. probably 3x black totem or equivalent for upper section, 4x if you really want to sew it up. couple nut spots as well. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 3 falls on gear, yeehaw! All trying to figure out the crux down low. Wow it’s physical and insecure. Gotta get your feet high up in the crack and then get a shitty foot out left in a scoop. Very committing pulling it. Yellow metolius protects very bottom. .4 and then high .5 protects the crux. Top is stellar and eats .1 - .3. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Lower overhang is the crux. Use the higher rail and keep bumping feet till into the crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. had to aid past the low crux, but climbed the rest cleanly. top section is incredible · Lead / Flash. Awesome crux move and finger crack at top! Bomber .5 at crux. · Lead / Redpoint. Get gear up high, back off, fire the layback on left stem ledge and high right to foot knob with possible knee bar. Climbed with Brad on a crowded Sunday · Lead / Fell/Hung. thumb catch, r foot high, l foot edge, work hands up, l toe crystal, r high to knee bar, press over. black totems and smaller in crack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux is hard but super fun. Fell a bunch there before figuring it out. · TR. This climb is awesome! Getting over the bulge at the bottom is a really tricky move, need to get a high right foot. The fingercrack is awesome because the chicken heads are great footholds · TR. Fell on the crux the first attempt but got it on the second try while actually crack climbing it (rather than laybacking it). Upper section is really fun and very cool features/knobs. Would love to lead this at some point! · TR. Fucking hard!! Crux is the roof bulge at the bottom. Very tricky body positioning, then thin slab at the top · TR. Very burly lieback to mantle start, then tenuous tips seam up top. Didn't particularly enjoy · TR. Layback at crux is way easier. Get knee into groove and you're golden.

routes.route_fa: Tavish H, Taylor Nick, Chris Owen April 2023
routes.route_description: A fantastically friendly moderate with Squamish like climbing on velcro textured rock.
routes.route_location: Slab zone right of PBR and Folsom.  Start up Douglas then trend left instead of stepping right.
routes.route_protection: Cams 0.2 to 1 with doubles in fingers, some draws to extend with, one bolt at the top.

routes.route_description: Climb the short handcrack as in Flippo. Then traverse left to the right-facing, flaring chimney. Climb the chimney (5.8), then continue up the crack-flake system to the roof. Jam over the roof (5.9, though may be easier due to recent cleaning) into a corner, and continue up the corner for about 20 feet.The route can be toproped using the chained anchor atop Robin's Ramp.
routes.route_location: Same start as Flippo, but follows line left.
routes.route_protection: Finger-sized to fist-sized cams.

route_comments.comment_text: This is a fun route and much cleaner as of 2013. fingers to chimney( 1# 4 camalot) tipped out at first, slide it up and back to good spot. to hands to fingers through a roof, to some techy thin crack stemming. I think the chimney is 5.7 and going past the roof is 5.8. One will want several very small cams for the thin crack after the roof. Jun 25, 2013

This route is really clean now.  I removed the last bit of root ball in the upper part of the dihedral in May I think.  Dirt from that just fell through the lower crack in the dihedral which used to be choked.  First time I tried this about five years ago I couldn't even get into the dihedral because there was nothing for hands.  Now there are great finger locks and good (but small) gear. I... more This route is really clean now.  I removed the last bit of root ball in the upper part of the dihedral in May I think.  Dirt from that just fell through the lower crack in the dihedral which used to be choked.  First time I tried this about five years ago I couldn't even get into the dihedral because there was nothing for hands.  Now there are great finger locks and good (but small) gear. I just lead it for the first time on Thursday after having TR'd many times.  The chimney which is much easier than Butt-lips on Aries was my concern on gear.  I just had to get my head around it and go.  It took a #5 but I wish I'd had Geoff's #4 too.  Jerry followed with approach shoes he wants to take to the Bugaboos and did fine. This route is no harder than Timberjack, the upper pitch of Magic Fern, or Aries/Lizard so yes, I think it is a 5.8.  It is easier than Toxic Shock, Wet Dream and Battered Sandwich and Plumb Pudding which Geoff agrees is a 5.9.  It has great variety and fun moves - I'll keep coming back. Jul 21, 2013

Thanks for cleaning this!  We really enjoyed it.  Recent rains have re-deposited a bit of dirt in the finger crack but not enough to render it unusable--I scraped out some with my nut tool but that section will likely need more attention after the wet season to keep it in such nice condition. I had only a #4 for the chimney which made it feel a little heady (a #5 would have helped, as the... more Thanks for cleaning this!  We really enjoyed it.  Recent rains have re-deposited a bit of dirt in the finger crack but not enough to render it unusable--I scraped out some with my nut tool but that section will likely need more attention after the wet season to keep it in such nice condition. I had only a #4 for the chimney which made it feel a little heady (a #5 would have helped, as the #4 was tipped) but it sure is fun --climbs more like an offwidth than a true chimney and facing toward town gives you more options.  While the chimney is much more enjoyable than Butt Lips on Aries, I would not call it 5.8.  Closer to an honest 5.9, in my opinion. The moves into and through the dihedral were also good. Extras in blue/green alien size come in handy once you hit the dihedral. Sep 14, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Bailed due to not having a 4. Seemed fun, really need a 4 more than a 5! · Lead / Onsight. Off width was scary looking but totally manageable. Finger crack crux after was pretty hard, I almost fell. · TR. Right side in for the chimney worked alright, Pulling the roof was dirty, do some gardening if you can reach - roof move is almost more chimney in the corner? · TR. Minus the chimney, a fun TR. Placing gear would be really tricky - getting deep in the chimney for a 4 or 5, then running out (?) the flake, then the disappearing seam at the top. · TR. Ilja put it up. We Trd it. Would’ve been a scary lead for me in the chimney but so fun on TR · Follow. surprisingly fun. near top, can head up and slightly left to an anchor rather than traversing right towards stem and valleys anchor. · TR. Right side in to the chimney. Reach far inside to find the rail. Pulling the roof is tenuous. Get feet high and trust them. · TR. We TR’d this off the RR anchors but the higher anchors would’ve been better. I had some swing potential then set a high redirect for Paul. Awesome climb all the way! Hand jams low. Chimney was cruiser with right side in, R foot in constrictions, RH rail, LH arete. Would want a 5! Weird X cracks the roof. Def would want microcams but tons of high feet, really solid. · Lead / Onsight. Challenging. Two cruxes? Upper crux felt insecure on tiny tips and foot friction. Gear: tiny to 5”, doubles .1-.5. Nuts. Slings. · TR. so many different crack widths. very cryptic but probably still 5.9 if you know all the moves · Lead / Onsight. Cool route. A little odd on the meander, and a little tenuous at the v-slot, but plenty of fun moves (NZ) · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bring 3x0.75 or use 2 at start, bump one high & ext, back clean 2nd. Chim wet at top, bump 2#4 & 1x#5 but 2x#5 better, back cleaned 2nd #4 never replaced. 2x#1 1x#2 1x#3 1x0.3 0.2/0.3 offset bumped 2x black tots a few times, bring more 0.2's. Hung @ roof · Lead / Fell/Hung. grabbed a cam theough the thin section need at least 3 or 4 tcus min without needing to backclean · Lead / Onsight. heady. places a blue alien and 0 mastercam under the roof

routes.route_name: I'd Rather Be Slowly Consumed by Moss
routes.route_description: This is not fully cleaned yetStarting in the large chimney, up to the right leaning arch passing two bolts to an anchor at a ledge.If anyone would like to tackle finishing this and/or the continuation of the chimney system up and left, feel free.
routes.route_location: Big chimney just right of Folsom Blues
routes.route_protection: TBD

routes.route_description: Start up a slabby ramp using good knobs and incuts. Enter the steep flaring chimney above (bolt out left) and then pull out into the sweet finger crack.
routes.route_location: At the Blue Tile Lounge (above mid wall) to the right of Waiting for the Sun. The flaring chimney is obvious.
routes.route_protection: 1x bolt ; smaller gear. Topo in Sky Valley Rock shows a second bolt at the start but I didn't see it.Anchors with chains on top attached via old carabiners.

route_comments.comment_text: I substantially cleaned this route yesterday, it's now good to go! I did not see the first bolt at the start (as shown in Sky Valley Rock). Jun 22, 2017

routes.route_name: Keep That Tuna Away from My Batteries!
routes.route_description: Tuna and batteries definitely just shouldn't mix...A short layback and mantle brings you to another ledge where the route really starts (as of this posting this 10 foot section has not been cleaned yet).  A thinning lieback leads to two bolts protecting a fun groove.  Incredibly grippy rock on this one.
routes.route_location: Starts from the same ledge as Douglas, to the right of PBR/Folsom area
routes.route_protection: A couple cams from fingers to 0.1, two bolts
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pulled on gear to clip. Hard in approach shoes; feet kept slipping. · Lead / Onsight. Bouldery start takes a .3 but don’t get too worn out placing it. Then tiny tiny gear (.1!) disappears for a few delicate bolted slab moves. · Lead / Onsight. Fun route with thoughtful slabby bit. Can start from the ledge with fun easy moves up the boulder. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Slipped off in the middle but this route is very chill, nothing to write home about but a cruiser warm up

routes.route_description: Follow thin crack to small roof/overlap (11b), then thin crack above, with 11c face moves to the finish.
routes.route_location: Far left side of cliff.
routes.route_protection: Gear for thin fingers.

route_comments.comment_text: the two crack switches are just classic. Nov 30, 2015
Awesome climb. The crux for me (sausage fingers) is the 1st 20 feet. Others had more issues with the final move over the bulge on the upper section. Sep 25, 2016
FFA - Terry Lien. Aug 31, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Tried pulling the start and gave up. Maybe I’ll try again when I’m stronger at crimping and fresh · TR. Hard start. Smeary feet, get right foot into crack and left on face. Towards top of start, just burl layback with a high right foot. To step left, get left foot wide into crack, left hand on jug. Could stick clip up the sport route left a few bolts then lower and set up a “stick clip” so the start is protected. · TR. Tricky start to powerful laybacks, eases out for the second part, tricky transition over the second bulge. · TR. The bottom is still quite damning hard, top is becoming little easier. Need to try fresh. · Lead / Redpoint. Led and fell a couple times from frozen fingers. Then fell a million times on the first piece and down cleaned. Then sent. 4th go · TR. Wowowiwowiwowow - 2 takes, that was a blast, teeeeny pieces obvi, heel hook on the bulge, stay kinda low on the traverse, def a future lead · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. First go: fell on black totem 10 ft up and lowered off 2nd go: sent with black totem pre placed from first attempt. Heel hook to gain last crack. Topout is super easy. · Lead. First go of the day. Crux is definitely the start for my fattys haha · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Got it on the second try. First go I ripped a red z4 out on the second crux super exciting · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd go. .4 in higher pod under hand, .3, .4, .75, .3 before crux, .5 after crux, .3 · Lead / Redpoint. Fun time! 2nd try. Lots of little gear on the right gear loop was nice · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. DMM #7 offset, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, 1, 0.3, 0.2/0.1 offset, black alien (0), 0.4, 0.4 or 0.3 最初のはライバック、左足をノブの上スミアして右足を上に。そこから左手でまあまあいいクリンプ、そこからナットを入れて次のポケットに右手、そしていいポケットに左手、そこから0.1を高く置く。右足を食らってにおいて上る。体を壁の近くに。左足は隣のクラックのポッドに左手がいいクラックに行くはず、０．２を入れる。少し登って０．３を入れてまた０．４を入れる。 左に移動する、右手で上のアンダークリングを忘れずに。１を入れる、少し登って０．３，そのあとは0.2/0.1 クリンプの場所で０を入れる。忘れないのはクラックの右にある小さいノブ、これを忘れて最後に落ちた。それに足をつけると高い左手がおけて右のジャグにとどける · TR. 2 TR burns. Amazing as always. 1st crack: cross through left foot to good nub, establish in good finger pod. Survive thinnest part of layback by using a couple right foot rand smears where crack is diagonal. Then burly but more straightforward. At crux transition from crack 2 to 3: commit to standing up onto decent nub out left and work hands up bad crimps until left hand is as high as possible (crimp deeper there). Right hand far out to good sidepull, fight barndoor, R foot up to sloper. Chill after that. · Lead / Redpoint. Second go black totem, .3/.4 at swoop blew foot almost decked. Number 1, .3 bd, .2 bd at top of crux move right with foot and high left hand. Move right on sloper and .4 · Lead / Redpoint. 3rd try, one to get the rope up, then sent on TR, then red pointed in a day. · Lead / Redpoint. Some heady gear placements right off the deck, then super classic climbing to the chains · TR. .3, .3 at the top of the bloulder. Place .75 (BD), then a blue metoulious, and biggest rp in the last pin scar before the crux. Then .4/.5 will get you to the top. · Lead / Fell/Hung. BD 0.2, black totem, totem 0.4, 0.75, totem 0.3, yellow nut, 0.5, 0.3 · Lead / Fell/Hung. onsight, slipped on transition above first crack. everything else was smooth · Lead / Redpoint. Bouldery, punchy, and fun. Needs to be loved and cleaned each season... · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at upper crux. Didn’t see good foot nubbin out left

routes.route_description: Fun 5.8 flake climbing to a bolt-protected crux face move. (The face move is easily aided by stepping in a sling and reaching the horn on the roof above.) Then go over a small roof and enjoy the 5.5 crack climbing to a ledge with a two 1/2" bolt anchor.The name has nothing to do with gardening, though like all routes at Index, a little moss-scraping and digging was needed to establish the line. You won't be needing to bring a lawn rake though to do the climb.
routes.route_location: On a lower-angle bluff up and right of Plum Pudding and Folsom Blues.
routes.route_protection: Small nuts to a fist-sized cam.

route_comments.comment_text: Jon, I have looked for this, how far over from Folsom is it? Aug 21, 2014

Hi Geoff, I'm guessing about 100 feet or less, and a little uphill. I TRed another route just right of The Lawn Rake that follows some face holds leading to a seam in a left-facing shallow corner. Thin 5.10-5.11 moves. It needed some more cleaning at the top though. Next time I visit, I'll see about finishing it off. Aug 21, 2014
This route is now cleaned up and ready to go. Walk 30 seconds to the right of Folsom Blues along the base of the cliff on a little trail. Jul 23, 2017

routes.route_description: Clint Cummins' book (web.stanford.edu/~clint/index/) calls it "MW crack 5.11a".  Does not have its own anchor - can be considered an alternate start to Robin's Ramp.Mostly 5.10, the hardest move is exiting the crack at the top.
routes.route_location: Directly below the first bolt of Robin's Ramp (~15 feet left of Robin's Ramp start)
routes.route_protection: finger-sized gear (or TR off Robins Ramp with a directional bolt)

route_comments.comment_text: Great bouldery crack. Would be 4 stars if it was longer. Starts easy with every move getting harder till the top. Aug 3, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Struggled a bunch at the top crux. Finally figured out the pinch right hand method and crimp on left · Lead / Fell/Hung. Felt hard. Fiddly gear, kinda flary. Need to figure it out on TR. · TR. Figured out beta. Right foot on smeary hold to get left foot high onto nub. Left foot in crack or nub, right foot on nubs out right, sometimes get right foot high and step up onto it. At top, get right foot in crack on right, right hand pinch high, left hand crimp, left foot in crack, right foot high onto nub by crack, left foot up to slab, bump right hand to jug. Gear needs to be figured out so i can move fast. Burly. Save green/purples for top of Robins · TR. Did not spark much joy. Very sequency bouldery laybacks, crux is leaving the crack. · TR. Trd after setting directional from the 5.7 ramp climb. One take at the crux. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the final crux move. Hardest lead on gear yet! Linked into Robin’s · Lead / Fell/Hung. one fall below crux due to gear fuckery. crux went pretty easily for on-site. probably won't do again · TR. Fell a few times at the top where the crack gets flaring and unjammable · TR. Hung on tr, pretty sweet. Hard at the top. Grab left crimp and then bump right hand high · Lead / Fell/Hung. Blew off standing onto a high foot to acquire the pinky down lock at the top of the route. .3, .2, .4. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard to see gear, blew the onsight right at the top. · Follow. Watch out for a deck fall early on- Nerida and I both fell almost to the ground on the first few moves. · Lead / Fell/Hung. whipped big at last move. stand on good knob, high l crimp, r side pull, jam left toe, r foot to high knob, stand. yellow, black, blue totems · TR. Dogged at top 11a moves. Seems easy for index. Needs good face footwork · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pink on Andrey’s gear. Had to pull on the yellow totem on top of the crack · TR. Went right at the crux, pulling the top in the crack was tricky · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell once at crux. plug 0.4 at highest stance, then simply reach up high with right hand, thumbs-down jam · TR. crimp with left, bump left foot to face feature, bump left out further, right foot up to inside of large knob · Lead / Fell/Hung. x2 TR x2 lead. 1, 0, .1, .2, .3, .4., .5 · TR. At the top exiting to the left, left foot in the crack, hands high below the horizontal seam, bump left to further crimp. Right foot high on the nubbin and stand up · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell once at crux, took once to place better gear. tricky at the top and awesome!

routes.route_fa: (Full, to tree at top) Geoff Georges
routes.route_description: Corner climbing with small roof. Involves jamming and stemming.One can toprope the bottom half from the Plum Pudding anchors.
routes.route_location: Major corner between Plum Pudding and Folsom Blues.
routes.route_protection: To 3". More in the smaller sizes.

route_comments.comment_text: AUG. 2013  2) 1/2"  SS bolts and Fixe hangers with chain at 100' top out of PBR. I have heard from a few folks that climbed this that think it is harder than 10b. If you climb this, rate it  here and maybe the consensus will clear this up. The start is strenuous layback, green/yellow Alien, flaring hand, tricky few moves to gain good hold, hands to fingers around bulge ( face holds for high... more AUG. 2013  2) 1/2"  SS bolts and Fixe hangers with chain at 100' top out of PBR. I have heard from a few folks that climbed this that think it is harder than 10b. If you climb this, rate it  here and maybe the consensus will clear this up. The start is strenuous layback, green/yellow Alien, flaring hand, tricky few moves to gain good hold, hands to fingers around bulge ( face holds for high foot) stump/dirt, then groove to stem over bulge, large crack out right, more stemming till easy upper corner to anchor Aug 20, 2013

Fantastic addition to the mid wall!  The upper third (from the tree stump up) isn't as clean as the start but once it is polished up with a bit more traffic and scrubbing this line is sure to become classic. Sep 14, 2013
Thanks for cleaning Geoff et al!!  Feels 10b to me. Aug 27, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Now i can see the 10b rating. Though my initial impressions was still a 10c · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couldn't quite hold on for the opening sequence. The rest is easy · Lead / Onsight. Super fun. Burly start. Had “stick clip” Loved the airy stem at the top! · Lead / Onsight. First legit 10a/b at Index. Very committing start, weird moves in the middle, eats a lot of smaller pieces. Ending is easy face climbing. Take 3x of #.2-#.5. · Lead / Redpoint. Gear beta: used (removed some other for drag/to use later): Ballnut smallest, 0.2, 0.3 (2), 0.4 (2), 0.75, 1, nuts, many alpines Felt pretty good, used prior beta. · TR. Such a rad climb. Exit Crux by reaching out to jug right and hand jams in crack left - pay attention to feet under first roof. Roofs all go on locks. · Lead / Redpoint. Such a good climb. 2nd time on it, struggled a lot the first time getting out of the layback and around the mini roof. Felt great coming back to it · TR. Still beat up from the winds and fumbled the lead. Ended up just doing some TR. 4 0.3s and 3 0.2s for the lead was nice. Layback layback, 2 hand jams (go for thumbs up), then when getting to the small roof (before roof with hand jam) do right hand in thumbs up under and then left hand thumbs up above. · 2 pitches. Lead. w/Genevieve. Wayyy too hot! 3x0.3 useful. Dump 2x0.4 on layback.Find good finger lock at end of layback start. Stem through scrunchy roof and use hold on right · TR. What the actual fuck on the difficulty of this. It would be better rated as 5.10d. Jacob Yang led it, and I top-roped. Crux is early, maybe 20' up. The pitch goes on forever though, and the upper half eases and has some stunningly cool moves!!! · Lead / Redpoint. excellent climbing, had to get creative when i ran a bit low on gear at the top. With Max!! · Lead / Redpoint. .5 at the top, last right hand finger lock high,full lock off to left flared hand jam, hike feet, then can gain the good hold out right. · Lead / Fell/Hung. I finally talked myself into leading this climb. I had one take at the crux:(. But overall felt pretty good. Used gear from .2-2, triples of .2-.4 helpful (could’ve even used 4 X .3). · Lead / Fell/Hung. Needed some additional small gear. Extra 0.2s and 0.3s next time. · Lead. I remember doing this long time ago felt good to come back and have some fun on it · Lead. Lowered after the first roof cuz I thought I was gonna puke. Rack up left side heavy with .3 for the starting lieback · TR. Lu and I did a couple laps each after another climber graciously offered to put our rope up. Flashed on TR on second attempt. Don’t miss the great right hand jug after the first 20 feet or so. Possible lead? · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung in the start x 2. Pumpy, excited to get back on it. Loved the entire thing. · Lead / Fell/Hung. After leading it and comparing it to other climbs I’ve done like tatoosh, thin fingers, perfect pitch I really do think this climb is 10c. In no way is it 10a. Bo struggled on this while he crushed the other b and d climbs · TR. Clean TR, Soaking wet before final stemmy roof thing. Keep feet low on lieback when leading. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Excellent climb, foot popped on the low crack to miss the onsight. Fun questing on upper section · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 hang near top of layback. Otherwise clean to plum pudding anchors, was a bit too wet for my taste above. · TR. Probably harder than Folsom blues, tr cleanly with a spicy slab traverse. Would try to lead next time · Lead / Redpoint. Good fun, sustained. Fell low down just after the starting layback because I missed a big face hold, but I think moving into the stem up higher is harder. Maybe just because it was wet up top tho · TR. TR bottom section off the PP anchors. Figured out the beta in the roof. Reach around left to get a finger lock thumbs down with the right hand. Press down on the rail out left with left hand to mantle/hand-foot match with left foot on rail. In bottom section, beware the layback with foot blowing off right as the layback gets vertical. Need to press extra hard to stick, and then don’t give up when getting to the flaring spot! Reach high to get a flaring hand jam, but don’t get too crunched up right there with the feet in tight to the body. · Follow. Followed Eric up this sustained 10b and hanged at the lower crux to get a belay tool tossed up to me. Amazed I could climb it having not climbed in several years. Good fun · Lead / Redpoint. Led with 2nd cam preplaced. Notes for myself: left hand deep in the crack.o Miura shoues work great. 2nd crux work with mantle, black totem in a crack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Take again after the layback transition to hand jam. Notes for myself: No need #2, #3. #0.3 at the beginning, yellow TCU near the top of layback. Reach for good handjam, no gear needed. · TR. Followed Micah’s lead on this today. Sick route! Was juiced on the layback & slipped loosing the TRonsight lol but the rest was wicked fun! The top roof was the best, transitioning layback to stem was dope, then the first mini roof had such interesting movement, I find this difficult for a 10b but maybe I’m a bad climber lol… · TR. TRed bottom half from Plum Pudding anchors. Felt solid except the move to traverse left to Plum Pudding anchor · Lead / Fell/Hung. One take down low on layback section where it shifts to flaring hands, one fall at first mini roof where foot slipped and then I wasn’t going to be able to recover. Gear roughly appropriate: double rack 0.2 to 1, single #2. Save a 0.2 for right before the second roof. Bring extra alpines for nuts. Placing a small cam (black totem?) right before the first mini roof is worth it (fell on extended 0.75 in the crack in back which took me for a ride). In first mini roof, used the right side of the block as well (felt okay) in order to get the feet up onto the left face holds/feet. Theresa did not use that beta but looked smooth. · Follow. multiple cruxes, thin finger crack near the bottom, two bouldering cruxes getting over and on top of some blocky rock · TR. Top roped first half from the Plum Pudding anchor. Redpoint. Trying again with different beta (layback the start). Swiss guys said the roof we didn’t do was all jugs. · Lead / Fell/Hung. .4, yellow tcu then orange tcu for beginning. One #1, 2, .5, .75, 3. Blue tcu and 2 .3s also used. .2 at top! · TR. Very hard with multiple crux’s, take tons of gear all the way up. · doubles 0.3-2 with extra 0.3-0.4 (set of offsets to complement doubles). Crux is layback fingers on bottom (0.4 fit best). Climbing eases off after that. Awesome route! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell a couple times, hung a bit, especially down low. Felt safe · Lead / Onsight. Very fun!!! Awkward moves down low but really interesting climbing up high

routes.route_description: This is an awesome layback climb up a right facing corner with finger sized gear.  The climbing is fairly sustained, but a few small feet allow for rests and oportunities to place gear.There is a fun corner to the right that you can TR from the anchors.  That corner, PBR, checks in at around 5.10.
routes.route_location: This is the obvious right facing corner on the right side of the cliff.Rappel with 1 rope from 2 bolt anchor
routes.route_protection: Protection to 0.5 camalot, with extras in the blue and yellow tcu size.  There is a good 2 bolt anchor at the top.

route_comments.comment_text: The Cummins topo lists it as 5.10A, which I would agree it is harder, more sustained than Godzilla. The upper half is the business with a 20' section of yellow/orange TCU or .3 & .4 camolots with limited feet. The last 15' eases off to the anchors. Oct 20, 2013
Great climb!  Thanks to those who have cleaned these routes!  I can imagine without enough traffic (which I'm pretty sure they don't get), these climbs get pretty dirty. Aug 27, 2014
I don't think this is any harder then 5.9, and it would probably be 5.8 in Ca. May 16, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. More pumpy than I remember. Might have to retract my statement that it’s the easiest 5.9 at index · Lead / Onsight. Ran it out quite a bit, felt manageable but required thoughtful moves · Lead / Onsight. Layback after layback. 2x #.3-#.5. Triples if at your limit. Beefier version of Senior Citizens. · Lead / Flash. Fun! Consistent. The business is mostly .4s (triples nice to have), then a .5 right above the corner / lip · Lead / Flash. Just keep it moving between the solid stances to place gear. Triples in .5 and totems in .4 were key, nothing above .75 needed. · TR. Would like to lead somebody, got tired laybacking a couple of times and took, but mostly cruised · Lead / Redpoint. Still a good pitch but felt short this time. Used less cams. Perfect rack might be (1) .3, 4) .4, (1) .5. No nuts or slings. · Lead / Onsight. Only had 3 #.4s and foot slipped after big run out up top… maybe could’ve squeezed a .3 in. Scary with the slip but otherwise so fun and straightforward · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ah, could have been a clean lead. Low down, starting the layback, I had minor unexpected foot slip. After that I led the rest clean. Gear: BD #1 down to #0.2, though three or four in the sizes #0.5, #0.4, and #0.3 would be handy. · Lead / Onsight. send train with Preston and Nina! really fun, like a harder senior citizens · Lead / Onsight. Taking the onsight even tho you can see the whole thing haha · TR. Did the “plum run” starting on the big rock and finishing at the chains. I believe I have the FKY at 43.42 seconds · Lead. All the stars! 3 .3’s, 3 .4s, and a black totem were enough with thoughtful placements and bumping · Lead. If there was a walk off I’d wanna solo this route pretty fun laybacking · Lead / Fell/Hung. 3x.4 and 3x.5, 2x.3, 1x.75, 1x.2 Alternate-ish .5s and .4s, need .4 after turning lip · Lead / Flash. Lu put it up. I trd my first lap, then lead on my second go. So fun. Used mostly .3, .4 x4. Brought .2-.5. · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Clemo - Great layback practice and a real calf burner · Lead / Flash. .4’s. Yellow/orange tcu’s. One 0.5. Nice and sustained but nothing too cruxy. · Lead / Onsight. incredible! so good. would do it 100 times. honestly had to remind myself to place gear, so crisp and clean! · Lead / Fell/Hung. First whip on gear! Wet wet wet wet wet wet foot slipped unexpectedly but fantastic layback · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped a quarter of the way due to massive seepage. Fun! · Lead / Onsight. Classic pure lie backing up a splitter .4 crack. I had 3 .4s, which all protected beautifully till you turn the slight corner, then I put in a slightly tipped .3. As for the bottom section until the stemming rest, I used 3 nuts since that part of the crack is soaking wet. Upper part is dry and fun · Lead / Onsight. good , can probably link through to the top of per for a better route · Lead / Onsight. Improving slowly at the layback on lead. Typical lay back & what you’d expect. I found a .2” helpful fyi Like a more difficult Senior Citizens · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ran out of 0.4 and needed to back clean. Then TRed it in approach shoes · Lead / Flash. Almost took a factor one fall because I wasn’t paying attention to my feet (or pro) · Lead / Onsight. Fun layback. Easy going, good to protect. Gus almost took a factor 2 fall. Good catch buddy. “That would of been factor one” Set up top rope for PBR

routes.route_fa: C. Folsom, D. Rosenfeld, R. Brownstein, D. Brownstein
routes.route_description: This is a very enjoyable route.  The crux moves are well protected by 2 bolts and are fun and somewhat unique, balancing along the edge of the narrow ramp.Continue following the ramp and corner crack to the chains.
routes.route_location: The route and ramp are fairly obvious.  This route shares the same start as Plum Pudding.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 1".  Rappel from the chains.

route_comments.comment_text: This thing catches a lot of debris, so if you're climbing it in the spring bring something to clean it off with. Jun 15, 2009
The 5.8 alternative start in the cracks to the left of the normal start is fun. Some work was done to clean it up. A brush on a stick would finish the job. May 8, 2016

Budding 5.7 leader beware, last few moves up to the first bolt are poorly protected, ground fall potential. Balancey crux may feel committing and surprising if you're expecting a cruiser 5.7 crack. Oct 8, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. Great moderate route. Larger sizes helpful for arete at base. Doubles around 0.4 · TR. hell of a time on the 5.8 handjam start, needed reminders to jam feet. would like to go back and lead the 5.8 start · TR. Followed upper section after doing MW crack lower section. Chill and easy but engaging enough. Slabby. · Lead / Onsight. Good warmup and reminder of the friction here at Index. Agree that the slabby ramp balance below the first bolt with only one piece below and deck potential mentally did not feel like 5.7! · Lead / Onsight. #3 low before bolts, 2 bolts, 0.4, 0.5, 2x0.75. Surprise slab layback middle, felt really insecure. Crack was awkward and dirty. Not that much fun. Have follower clean. · Lead / Flash. I climbed the 5.8 variation in approach shoes to add some · Lead / Onsight. trad lead post quarantine - a little heady at times but good pro spots. · Follow. Followed Allie, a bit bare, ran it out, but crack available on R · Lead / Onsight. 3rd route. Foot stuck on 2nd move & Hank boosted me out, but it was clean. With Hank & Chris · Lead / Flash. Felt a little harder than 5.7. Exposed. Scared. Fun at top

routes.route_description: Begin up Robin's Ramp and traverse along a rail (5.8) to clip the first bolt. You can stick clip or clip a bolt on Robin's Ramp and then cross this section a few times to protect yourself if desired. A series of 3 technical boulder problems along a seam (bolts) gets you to a jug and final mantle. From there, insecure but much easier climbing along the seam brings you to an open corner. Make a heady move and stem up to the anchors.Alternative (less reachy) start: Start up Plum Pudding (gear) until you can stand on top of the big flake. Traverse left using good crimps to clip the 2nd bolt.There are permadraws on the crux bolts. I'll edit this if I remove them.
routes.route_location: Seams Alright follows  the arete  between Robin's Ramp and Plum Pudding. Look for the bolts.
routes.route_protection: 6x bolts ; finger piece and small nuts. I protect the final corner with a small brassie just above the roof but the fall is big and clean if you don't bring it. There is also another option for a good nut.Bolted anchor with rap rings on top. A 60m rope should get you down.

route_comments.comment_text: An awesome new route with amazing movement and classic Index improbable climbing. While maybe a .12 somewhere else, I think 11d is very fair for Index and none of the 3 boulder problems feel harder than V4. As of now, after the last bolt, the thin crack running along the final slabby corner to the chains cannot be protected until the dirt gets cleared out. When it is cleared out, a small... more An awesome new route with amazing movement and classic Index improbable climbing. While maybe a .12 somewhere else, I think 11d is very fair for Index and none of the 3 boulder problems feel harder than V4. As of now, after the last bolt, the thin crack running along the final slabby corner to the chains cannot be protected until the dirt gets cleared out. When it is cleared out, a small brass offset or a red (maybe yellow) ballnut should easily protect the insecure move to get established into the corner. A fall after the last bolt, however, is unlikely if you've managed to get that far. I'm pretty sure you need a 70m rope to get off, there didn't seem to be too much excess rope after I rapped which makes me think this pitch is around 32m or so. Hop on this route guys and give it love! May 11, 2017
Nice! I was looking at this thing last season, wondering.... I'm psyched to hop on it! May 14, 2017
I did a little more cleaning today Adam, a tiny brass nut (#2) protects the final moves well but the fall is clean if you don't have it. A 60m rope does get you down as well. May 19, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Easy to hang draw on robins ramp then traverse to clip first bolt then back clean

routes.route_description: This is an access pitch to quickly get to the Mid Wall from the K-Cliff area.
routes.route_location: See images for the map and topo.
routes.route_protection: Small cams helpful, two bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: I called this Seamstress because I placed knife blades on lead while pulling off clods of moss while water was pouring down the face, and added the bolts on lead for the old school fun of it. It is actually pretty fun when it's dry. Jan 22, 2014

Thanks to Geoff for establishing this as a route.  The bolts make it a quick, solid, and fairly efficient climb up to the Mid Wall when dry.  I ended up placing 1 small cam above the bolts for good measure on my way up since it was still a bit dirty (obviously not often used). As far as the anchor, I added some observations in a comment on the Mid Wall description page. Sep 3, 2017
Cassie, with help from my friend Bill there is now a good solid 2 bolt with chain anchor for repelling from the top of Seamstress. as of 9/3/17 Sep 7, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. did this in hiking shoes with heavy pack and only clipped the 2 bolts. definitely should have brought some pro and worn climbing shoes. it's a dirty approach and climb but can save time over the fixed-line + rebar approach to middle walls if you're quick. good anchor at the top

routes.route_description: Climbable, but needs a tad more cleaning at the moment.Climb a short but fun finger crack to a sloping ledge.  Climb a flake and groove past two bolts to a vengeful 5.9 move off a smear to the anchor ledge...
routes.route_location: Starts on a different ledge above and right of the other routes on the slab.
routes.route_protection: A couple of finger size cams and a few small nuts, then two bolts

route_comments.comment_text: The anchor chains currently atop this climb could use some improvement. One quick link on the left anchor is installed upside down so that it inevitably unscrews itself (it was completed open when I topped out) and both chains are one link short: the bottom links both lay flat against the wall and twist your rope while lowering. Good reminder to always inspect the anchors! May 25, 2023

routes.route_fa: U Lukic, J Tetzlaff, D Taylor
routes.route_description: I'm hoping for input to the rating since the crux felt very height dependent and I suck at figuring out ratings anyways.Start in the same hand crack as for Hips and Valleys, but instead of going up the chimney, go up to the right in the shallow corner and continue up the face via stemming and some delicate features over a small roof and to the chains for Robin's Ramp.It is also possible to go up the chimney for Hips and Valleys and cut in above the crux for a much easier variation and is easily TRed by doing Robin's Ramp. The crux may seem a bit contrived due to the proximity of Hips and Valleys, but bolts were placed where sound rock could be found which was quite close to Hips and Valleys.
routes.route_location: Shares the start for Hips and Valleys.
routes.route_protection: 5 QDs, couple of slings, nuts and a couple of cams to #2BD

route_comments.comment_text: Great job on the route. I tried TRing it last year, and thought it had some pretty hard and dynamic moves near the bottom. So, it might be harder than 11-, but I'll have to go back and try again. Aug 2, 2013

Crux is hard for someone 5'4", but I'll work something out. :-) 11- sounds about right, but being short, I could give it an 11b? Fun stemming up higher! Surprisingly possible moves at the bottom. Aug 5, 2013

Fun climbing that's very tough to give a grade to.  Well protected crack, face and stemming.  Stretch out a bit before you start this one. 5.11- is a good starting point.  You might find it harder or easier, but close enough. Aug 24, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Had the wingspan to reach the crux statically, tricky but definitely not an index 11a for me · TR. After two years I finally made it to the top. I can sleep easier now. · TR. one fall at the beginning, but then sent from the ledge. Real stemming! definitely went left to the ledge on hips and valleys before getting established in the stem and after getting to the slopy chalked handledge, seemed like the only think to do · TR. Kind of stupid. Not worth dirty contrived bits for a couple cool stem moves. · Lead / Redpoint. had tr'd the top before. the first 2 bolts weren't that bad. 10+? · Cheater! Clipped the first bolt, then climbed the chimney at left to bypass the crux.

routes.route_description: Go up the left-facing corner (part of same flake as Dinky and Flee). The crux is down low. Goes to the Wild-Boar anchors (same as the two routes left and the two routes right).
routes.route_location: Just left of the huge flake, the right side of which is Flee Fly Flue.
routes.route_protection: Full range of sizes.

routes.route_fa: Stamati Anagnostou, Randy Ladowski, Rachel Huck
routes.route_description: The crux is right off the ground: a finnicky and highly technical slab problem on crimps and flat edges with terribly poor feet. It took us 2 sessions to settle on beta and something like 20 attempts to send. If you don't get frustrated and give up you're rewarded with excellent powerful and tenuous compression climbing with a finger crack to finish.
routes.route_location: Walk towards Blue's Cliff and the UTW trail from the Mid Walls. Look for a short wall to the left of the trail about 1-2 minutes walk past Mid Wall proper. There is a tree which rests upon it.
routes.route_protection: 2 bolts and 1 green alien sized piece. Stick clip the start.

route_comments.comment_text: Sick stig!! Jul 11, 2018
Get on this thing, folks. It's a real gem. May 31, 2020
Super fun climbing, mix  of techy-balance and power climbing. Jun 1, 2021

routes.route_fa: Stamati Anagnostou, Michal Rynkiewicz, Logan Fusso
routes.route_description: Stick clip the first bolt and execute a memorable boulder problem to a dirty ledge (.11c/d). Climb fun cracks to a roof and obvious flare. Enter the flare with difficulty  on shallow finger locks (.11+, bolted). Rad knob and arete moves exit the flare, easier ground to the right of an incipient crack leads to a chained anchor.Fat fingers will find the second crux quite a bit harder I'd imagine, but both harder sections are short lived and can be aided.
routes.route_location: Start on top of a flat mossy boulder.
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts and wires and small cams with a .5 and #2 C4 to supplement on the easy stuff. Offsets work best.

route_comments.comment_text: I really recommend this sucker. I imagine the ledge atop the initial segment could use a cleaning but it's worth it. Moves up high are great and easily aided. May 31, 2020

routes.route_description: This route has really fun, positive knobs.  Somewhat committing getting to the first bolt - trust your feet on the knobs.Follow the knobs up the face to a 2 bolt anchor.
routes.route_location: This route is located on the small crag known as The Blue Tile Lounge, just above the Mid Wall.  Approach via Robin's Ramp and continue climbing  past the chains on that route through some bushes to a tree belay.  Walk up the slab to the base of the route.
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts plus a green Alien (or red C3 or blue TCU) to protect the start.  The bolts are all right where you need them.Bring a red Alien (or orange TCU) and a green C3 (or blue Alien or purple TCU) to set up a belay at the base.A good strategy for getting down is to belay the follower from the anchors at the top, then rappel from the anchors all the way down to the chains at the top of Robin's Ramp, then rappel from Robin's Ramp to the ground.NOTE: We made this rappel with a 70m rope and had rope to spare - haven't tried it with a 60m rope.

route_comments.comment_text: This route stays wet for quite some time.  There is a moss "carpet" on the slab at the base, so if you commit to climbing above Robin's Ramp and it's wet, the downclimb becomes non-trivial.  I had to leave some cord and a biner to get down when I checked it out this spring. Jun 15, 2009
I cleaned the tat off the anchor to Jaded and Waiting for the Sun they both have chain belays. Apr 7, 2012

Last summer was my first time up to Blue Tile Lounge and the amount of lichen on the route made me think it hadn't been climbed in several years - reading the comments I see I was mistaken.  I scrubbed Waiting for the Sun and substantially cleaned French Canadian. Last weekend Waiting For the Sun is still clean but French Canadian is blooming - literally.  On Thursday July 18th I finally... more Last summer was my first time up to Blue Tile Lounge and the amount of lichen on the route made me think it hadn't been climbed in several years - reading the comments I see I was mistaken.  I scrubbed Waiting for the Sun and substantially cleaned French Canadian. Last weekend Waiting For the Sun is still clean but French Canadian is blooming - literally.  On Thursday July 18th I finally red-pointed Waiting.  I brought my moccosims (sp?) and committed to the final move to the anchor.  Stiff 5.9, but fun and great views from that area. The weak link at the anchor is that the big chains are held to the hangers by aluminum non-locker 'biners that are showing a little corrosion.  My std size quick links I carry won't fit around the fat chain.  I'll look for larger quick links that will fit. Jul 21, 2013

routes.route_description: Climb the start of Folsom Blues and go left into Blue Ribbon variation.  Scrape up the wide flake and plug an extended #4 under the roof, then head up to a jug on the arete.  Be sure to yell "Ve shall continue vit ztyle!" with a Swiss accent before continuing with style out right on knobs to meet with the top of Folsom Blues.  Falling off the crux knob traverse might feel somewhat similar to pitching off the north face of the Eiger.  Spicy.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Singles for the start, #5 for the flake (doable but runout without), #4 for under the roof, then something .3ish for the top of FolsomEasily TRed from Folsom anchors

routes.route_description: Follow knobs and edges near a thin crack. The crux is near the top bolt.
routes.route_location: Look for the bolted face left of the flake.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts.

area_description: This cliff is the host of several great routes, containing anything from slabs to corners to roofs.  Almost all of the climbs are bolted, even some cracks (yikes, when did this become acceptable at index???)
area_getting_there: Take the trail from the country up some steep switchbacks past the boards on the trail, and a giant boulder.  Take a left at an obvious fork(upper wall trail goes right), then two more lefts at subsequent forks.

routes.route_description: On the far left side of the cliff is this deceptively easy looking slab/arete that provides one of the best pitches of the 'low angle' style at Index. Meander up ramps and cracks to the slab for 20' to the first bolt. There is a tree that can be slung along the way if desired. Once on the slab proper, clip bolts and climb classy, highly textured low angle rock past a couple of cruxes, one at the bottom and another higher up.
routes.route_location: A 60m rope is needed to descend.
routes.route_protection: 9 Bolts; potentially some gear for the very beginning if desired. The anchor has a unique rappel ring that should prove more than adequate so long as the webbing it's attached to is decent. See comments below.

route_comments.comment_text: Quality!  Thoughtful pitch with fun tricky slab and arete balance moves.  The first crux between the 2nd and 4th bolts is friction dependent and felt like 5.11, while the upper crux felt closer to 10+.  No gear needed for the bottom as the first bolt can be clipped off the ledge behind the tree before committing to the arete. Aug 14, 2013

This route is fantastic, clean, and never gets done. An onsight would be very impressive but it's all there once you find the holds. Feels like the hard version of Spineless with a very desperate friction crux. I'd recommend a .2 or .3 to back yourself up as you reach the clipping stance for Bolt #2, you can back clean it after clipping. Aug 24, 2020

Really great pitch! I thought it to be quite tricky! Could use a light brushing and a bit of upkeep. I’m sure the old stainless smc’s are plenty strong but still don’t inspire a ton of confidence. One of the anchor hangers looks to be homemade but in decent shape. The tat nest could also be replaced with some metal anchors. After the last bolt, there is a rock over jug that should probably be... more Really great pitch! I thought it to be quite tricky! Could use a light brushing and a bit of upkeep. I’m sure the old stainless smc’s are plenty strong but still don’t inspire a ton of confidence. One of the anchor hangers looks to be homemade but in decent shape. The tat nest could also be replaced with some metal anchors. After the last bolt, there is a rock over jug that should probably be trundled. It’s a decent size part of the flake that has a crack running through the bottom and is slightly gongy, although I didn’t yard to hard on it to see if it flexes. It would be a tricky operation with the via and orc tower/country looming below. This is not to scare anyone off as it’s plenty safe, just could use help from a Good Samaritan. Jul 23, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very fun. Kept me on my toes literally and figuratively 2-4 clips are all tough. First crux Got the right foot feature, and then dropped feet down on the slabbier stuff down low and then went into the good sidepulls. Next on me work right foot up on the side, kinda push the right hand on the slopey part to get the left hand sloper then feet up. Exciting all around! · Lead / Fell/Hung. A little heady - took a few times. Harder than the slab arête part of Wildest Dreams P2 I thought. Is the tree on?? Step across at the bottom is the crux for me · This route has potential to be a great route but it’s really dirty and needs a brushing. The dirt doesn’t vibe well with the friction needed for this climb. · TR. this thing needs some love! there is a big ball of tat at the top that could be replaced with some chains which would be nicer to rap off of vs the big iron ring.

routes.route_description: Start with a difficult crack bolder problem to the right of the obvious flake start to Twelve Gauge IQ. Climb part of that route and step over to a finger crack on the right face. Getting started in the crack is the crux. One can traverse left at the top into the sport climb Twelve Gauge IQ, or, I believe, head right to another anchor. I can't remember if this other anchor currently exists, however.
routes.route_location: A 60m rope lowers from either anchor. This and the aforementioned Twelve Gauge IQ are located on the far left side of the Blues Cliff, to the right of Accidental Discharge.
routes.route_protection: Finger-size cams and stoppers with maybe a couple of hand-size pieces. This climb used to have bolts next to the crack, but as per Chris's comment below they've been removed. Fixed anchors.

route_comments.comment_text: One of the more egregious examples of crack bolting I've seen. A shame, since the climbing is quite good. A few bolts to protect the move from the stance into the crack system and to protect the finish would suffice to keep the route from being R-rated. There is no anchor at the top of the crack system as the guidebook indicates, nor is there one out to the right, so the route culminates... more One of the more egregious examples of crack bolting I've seen. A shame, since the climbing is quite good. A few bolts to protect the move from the stance into the crack system and to protect the finish would suffice to keep the route from being R-rated. There is no anchor at the top of the crack system as the guidebook indicates, nor is there one out to the right, so the route culminates with the steep 'n pumpy bolted finish of 12-gauge IQ. Jun 1, 2014

This route currently has no egregious bolts.  The poorly placed bolts along the crack have all been chopped, and the line is as pure and beautiful as they come.  I give it 4 stars myself.... The climbing is really really good. Aug 27, 2014
Would anyone be opposed to the first bolt also getting chopped? It's 8" from the finger crack as well. I don't know why it also wasn't removed. Sep 15, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. To high anchors, able to jam most of crack straight in with stem feet but still compressing at top. Do slab traverse low, R thumb Gaston to highL pinky down lock. · Lead / Fell/Hung. stick clipped first bolt - crux off the ground. Nothing bigger than .75 needed. Traversing low for the slab crux felt much easier than traversing high on the chalked nubs · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell just after getting in the crack, didn't see the foot nub. Focus on feet · Lead / Fell/Hung. 2 hangs in the finger crack. Entering the finger crack : · Lead / Fell/Hung. Stick clip 1st draw. Fell at slab into crack. 6/7 draws and a sling, 00 c3, 2 .2, 1 or 2 .3, 2 .4, .5 · Lead / Flash. First move to get off the ground took me a couple of tries and a little beta, but onsighted the rest. So rad! · Lead / Flash. *I didn’t do the proper start apparently. Not the crux regardless, but a big asterisk. · TR. Come back for the lead. Bring a stick clip for the opening crux move · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very good route. Took one fall committing to high beta getting into second crack. Pulled lower beta first time. Shade after 2pm Stick clip is safer than starting on black totem. I used two blue, one yellow, one purple, and a black (thank god crux piece) totems. Purple could be another .4 or orange metolius · TR. Clean twice. Psyched to come back fresh and lead. W/ Emma, Ben & Jason · Lead / Redpoint. To unicorn blues anchor. Direct start is egregious lol. But what a good pitch overall. 2x .2-.5 (+graylien, -.3s), 1x .75. Plenty of draws, no nuts · stick clip first bolt. levitate up to finger crack, and pull on one or two fingers once in. crux was ok, was able to gently get 2 fingers in and pull up. upper section after the rest is much easier than it looks. was tiring! · Lead / Onsight. Wowza!! All the climbing on this one. Crack to thoughtful slab into finger crack and arete to hero overhang… index gives again · Lead. One lil’ tug on starting the crack. Move right low with double gast, paste foot high Knob left high is almost certainly better · TR. Was boosted for the difficult Boulder problem. Really fun route though! Tricky transfer into the crack · TR. Clean!!! Use intermediate crimp at second bolt. At Crack traverse way right and compression climb to the finger locks

routes.route_fa: Stamati Anagnostou, Randy Ladowski, Ian Mayer & ?
routes.route_description: This extension to Rhythm and Bolts climbs through multiple roofs on great holds. The crux is just after the second bolt in the roof. Great fun and a unique Index experience.Extend the last draw on the slab, the first 3 bolts of the overhang and the last bolt.
routes.route_location: Just above Rhythm and Bolts.
routes.route_protection: 11 bolts (extend five of them)

route_comments.comment_text: Great rests between cruxes tames this quite a bit. Fun heel hooking through roofs! Sep 29, 2024
At long last, Randy's red tag is removed... Stoked to try this! Oct 1, 2024

routes.route_description: Climb ledges and/or a stump to the first bolt. Steep climbing leads to a beguiling crux encounter turning the arete and entering the corner. Continuously difficult technical climbing leads up the corner and surmounts another bulge higher up. The slippery crux can be both entertaining and frustrating at the same time!
routes.route_location: Starts below the obvious arete and corner system above a snag just left of the midpoint of the wall.60m rope needed for descent.
routes.route_protection: 7 or 8 Bolts. Fixed anchors at the top.

route_comments.comment_text: Quality climbing on this one.  Athletic sidepulls on positive holds lead to a balance move to gain the dihedral, immediately followed by a deceptive power move to the next clipping stance.  More cool finger-slot sidepulls then lead up to a final, easier crux.  Deserves more traffic. Aug 8, 2014

routes.route_description: A short crux around the initial corner leads to easier climbing and a slight traverse left to the anchor. This anchor is shared with Etch-A-Sketch and the bolt line continuing up and right above the roofs is 'BB Cling' 11d. The ledge to the left can also be followed to get on top of 'Blue in the Face'.
routes.route_location: Next bolt line left of Rhythm and Bolts. Look for the diverging corner.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

routes.route_description: Climb past bolts in a pretty orange corner to a right trending crux over a small roof at the last bolt.
routes.route_location: Rightmost bolted route on the Blues Cliff.
routes.route_protection: 8 bolts and a two bolt anchor.

routes.route_fa: Greg Collum, Larissa Collum, Matt Kerns, 7/92
routes.route_description: A short but fun route that climbs a broken dike system on the left side of the wall just before you reach Twelve Gauge IQ on the trail.
routes.route_location: Left side of the wall. Look for the obvious broken quartzite dike.
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts; two bolt anchor. I think it has chains.

route_comments.comment_text: Short, but more powerful than standard Index fare.  The difficulty increases at each bolt, crescendoing to a pumpy little boulder problem.  Fun shortie!! Aug 14, 2013
The anchors on this route were chopped summer '14. You've got to continue up the bolted arete above (5.12) or lower off a single bolt from the ledge where this route had ended. Sep 15, 2014
I replaced the anchor on this. Excellent route, should absolutely see more traffic, especially from the gym folks, as it’s got cool board-esq movement! Jul 25, 2024

routes.route_fa: Greg Collum, Matt Kerns, Oleg Ashirov
routes.route_description: A fun patina-ish start leads to a crux moving left out of an arch. Approach the bolt line of 'Written in Stone' before breaking back right to the shared anchor with 'Blues Riff'. 'BB Cling' continues above or the ledge can be followed to the left to throw a rope on 'Blue in the Face'.
routes.route_location: Obvious arching corner left of 'Blues Riff' and right of 'Written in Stone'.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

routes.route_description: An amazing route in an amazing position.  Unique climbing for Index - steep face climbing on solid quartzite holds reminiscent of the Gunks. But just look around - the Gunks don't have air and views quite like this...Rappel in.  From the 2 bolt anchor at the base of the route, climb up the corner crack through nice, smooth granite and up over a tricky bulge.  From here, the character of the climb changes considerably as you leave the smooth granite and begin working your way up a steep wall through a sea of quartzite holds, placing gear where available.
routes.route_location: Although this climb lies at the upper extent of the Blues Cliff, it is perhaps best combined with routes at the Mid Wall.  Use the Mid Wall approach to get to the route.  At the point where the Mid Wall trail comes to the edge of the cliff and there is a nice viewpoint with a great rock to sit on, you will notice chains directly below (these are the anchors for Starfish (5.9) ).To find the anchors for #9, continue a few more feet along the trail to the top of the stairs and the tree that has fallen on them.  At this point, carefully walk left along the ledge (exposed) to the anchors.  Rappel in to a ledge with a few trees and a 2 bolt anchor.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack to 2 or 3 inches.  There is one protection bolt on the route.  70 meter rope needed to rappel into the route - otherwise you'll need two ropes to rappel in.

route_comments.comment_text: It should be noted that the route name as I originally saw it was written as #9, however MP would not let me use the # symbol in the title of the route. Jun 15, 2009
These are great climbs and very unique for Index.  The bulge at the bottom feels hard/awkward for 10a. Jun 15, 2009
Chris Henson did the FA, I believe. Feb 10, 2012

routes.route_tick_comments: · Definitely has a crux move, which is a blast, consistently felt harder than starfish, but just as fun, maybe more.

routes.route_description: Series of thin cracks starting with a slab and seam. Currently very mossy and likely needing new anchor bolts. Unsure if this route has seen a ground up onsight ascent as it was originally done on preplaced protection.*Certainly an exciting project for an ambitious crack master.
routes.route_location: Between "Color of Pain" and Wedgie. At the edge of the roof capped slab, the line ascends the seam where the slab meets a slightly south facing granite face with patina and thin cracks up high.
routes.route_protection: Unclear, likely small nuts and cams.

routes.route_description: This open project climbs the attractive, blunt arete and face between Wedgie and Previously Exposed. The crux is supposedly V9 or so. The route is mostly clean but would require a session of brushing towards the top.
routes.route_location: Directly between Wedgie and Previously Exposed.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

routes.route_description: This slab route starts near the far right side of the blues cliff.  The crux comes at the last two bolts on some slippery holds, but there are some hard moves lower down as well.  Luckily you get a good rest before the crux.  The top is wet occasionally.
routes.route_location: This route ends at two obvious chains hanging on the under side of a giant roof.  It is just left of an obvious, bolted, left-facing corner climb called Color of Pain.
routes.route_protection: 6 bolts to chains

route_comments.comment_text: Bring a brush, this slab feels hard at the grade when covered in pine needles, dust, and moss.  Several different cruxes, including one at the bottom that could lead to a ledge fall if the belayer isn't alert.  The climbing gets better towards the top, including a powerful/balancey finish. Aug 14, 2013

I agree that the bottom needs to be kept clean. Earlier this year, I slid off the first crux layback (seemed really hard!), though was caught before hitting the ledge. It was a hard catch though, enough to injure a rib ligament and keep me out of climbing for about two months. Aug 14, 2013

Yeah... be careful because the hold you're deadpointing for above the first bolt will probably be covered in pine needles and other shit. I do agree with others that the first part feels quite stout. The top is pretty cool so still worth climbing. Sep 11, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Beginning - heel on left arete, high right foot. Later, left hand crystal then swap to right hand crystal, very wide left hand and switch right hand to side pull crystal, then very high but good right foot. Final sequence: both feet on left sloping ramp, left hand weird sidepull. Right hand on better (further right) of two crimps, left foot to kinda bad sloping dark spot in dyke, left hand near right hand but a little worse, right foot slight flag with toe pressed to wall, bump left hand to thin crimp, wide / high but good right foot, really rock over, ok right hand, left hand to bucket · Lead / Fell/Hung. Clean to 5th bolt then lost stoke; dirty humid slab oh boy

routes.route_description: Face climbing on featured rock.
routes.route_location: Upper left side of Blues Cliff (see beta photo). The usual approach is to rap in from the top. Hike the Upper Wall Trail and take the Mid Wall trail turnoff (first left).  Look for a lookout vantage point just before the first stairs.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack, 4 bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: Quality climbing on quartzite edges and jugs. Well worth the hike from Mid Wall. Needs more traffic to keep it clean. Aug 16, 2015
Currently pretty clean but doing some brushing on the rap in wouldn't hurt. Lots of fun with unique climbing for Index. May 19, 2017

Really fun and atypical style for Index! Quality climb but not surprised it doesn't see much traffic, it's pretty out of the way and a little hard to find. Not as dirty as I was expecting, at least the face holds were mostly fine minus some pine needles. Some lichen but not too slippery. Definitely some dirty cracks that need excavating for pro. Peculiar bolting, some right next to great gear.... more Really fun and atypical style for Index! Quality climb but not surprised it doesn't see much traffic, it's pretty out of the way and a little hard to find. Not as dirty as I was expecting, at least the face holds were mostly fine minus some pine needles. Some lichen but not too slippery. Definitely some dirty cracks that need excavating for pro. Peculiar bolting, some right next to great gear. 3 bolts up top, one has a pretty rusty stud and is half buried in dirt, one is loose is fully buried in dirt and had a red sticker on it, 3rd was ok except quicklink was pretty rusty. Bolts on route looked much better. May 6, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Didn’t love the movement, too many similar moves/ holds. I just top roped it but it seemed like it would be a heady lead with some marginal gear between long bolt spacing · 2 pitches. TR. TRS, 2 laps clean. Cruxes are leaving the anchors below and arriving at the anchors above. Very interesting face climbing w/ a few jams possible, not common for index. Didn't get easier the 2nd time, both cruxes have poor feet. A bit licheny & dirty but not terrible, except some cracks for pro need scraping. · TR. Actually pretty fun. Would be better if cleaned & without via ferratta rungs. · Fun moves, super dirty but climbable. just lots of moss, mostly dead. moves are all there, didn't feel harder than 5.8

routes.route_description: Starts with a prominent right-tending flake and knobs. A steep beginning is  followed by lower angled climbing into a corner. Climb the discontinuous bolted finger crack in the corner up to the large, blocky roof. Turn the roof via a boulder problem and continue up on steep jugs to the anchor. The route gets a .12b/c in books but is less difficult than others of the grade at Index simply because it's more straightforward. The corner and possibly the whole climb could potentially be led with gear, but most will clip the bolts. This route is a true gem and an area classic.
routes.route_location: Located on the left portion of the wall. A 60m rope lowers.
routes.route_protection: Bolts. Fixed anchors on top.

route_comments.comment_text: This route is really fun.  Despite it's bolted nature, the dihedral climbing is high quality on beautiful stone and the roof succumbs to good beta and a few gymnastic pulls.  No doubt easier than the other .12c I've tried at Index. Jul 3, 2014

Truly fantastic, and judging by the relative dearth of comments and star votes, probably a bit overlooked. Especially considering its proximity to the LTW. This would be the best pitch at most other crags. Two notes: 1. Feels about 12a to me in terms of Index grades (but we all know what Index 12b means...). 2. The first big hard move of the pitch (right around the first bolt) goes to a... more Truly fantastic, and judging by the relative dearth of comments and star votes, probably a bit overlooked. Especially considering its proximity to the LTW. This would be the best pitch at most other crags. Two notes: 1. Feels about 12a to me in terms of Index grades (but we all know what Index 12b means...). 2. The first big hard move of the pitch (right around the first bolt) goes to a large jug which is quite loose/flexy. As the belayer, it would be wise to stand well to the side of where that thing might fall; and as the leader, probably smart to either stickclip the first bolt, or place some gear on the way up to it (purple metolius and a .75 or maybe a 1 works well for the direct start... for the circuitous left entrance, not sure on gear). Sep 7, 2022

I'd recommend not climbing this route for the next few months. I climb it last night without realizing that about 3/4 of the way up the route there's a bird's nest (I think some swallows) within ~3 feet of holds that one will use while climbing. Parent birds were clearly distressed when I was climbing near their offspring :/. If they are swallows they'll probably be done with the nest by early... more I'd recommend not climbing this route for the next few months. I climb it last night without realizing that about 3/4 of the way up the route there's a bird's nest (I think some swallows) within ~3 feet of holds that one will use while climbing. Parent birds were clearly distressed when I was climbing near their offspring :/. If they are swallows they'll probably be done with the nest by early September at the latest. Route is sick, psyched to go back for an RP burn. Was able to sort the beta out quite quickly on my first burn and I felt it was pretty reasonable at 12a/b. Bolting is reasonable for working the route too IMO Jul 12, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Wahooo! Shoutout to Kara for the belay and Hayden for hanging the draws. A fight with thermoregulation in addition to pump. · Lead / Flash. Top notch enjoyable. Maybe a bit tender for the grade, but some technical challenges and a bit of power required. Feels a bit easier than unicorn blues. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. What a rig. Crimp super useful in corner. Long draw at roof, clip quick, match, lf on left bump, fire lh up to crimp, rf in corner, rh slap to gaston. · Lead / Fell/Hung. One fall in corner and one hang at lip. Crimp left of bolt 2 of corner. Milk the rests. · TR. went up through the shark fan and then did the quick traverse good beta right foot on knob. left foot high on flake. reach high left hand for jug mantle out tiptoe across the slab. move through the fun gymnastic part key beta slap right hand up first then move left hand up. right foot smears high on slab with double hand jam. when pulling the roof, get right foot out right, toss right hand up to rail and match and then the left foot goes to nib. rest up in the wide stands. get fully shaked out on no hands rest. last part is doable. just move very fast. · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd go! First index 12!! Almost onsighted but procrastinated on the roof too much. Such a fun climb!! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung all over the upper portion of the dihedral crux, sheesh. Roof pull was super fun and managed to get all the way up to the left hand finger slot before realizing I was too pumped to clip the next draw… proceeded to take a big fall · Lead / Fell/Hung. Just as amazing as it’s neighbor. Wow. Flake start to fun traverse to tenuous finger crack w slippery slab to multiple big moves thru the roofs. Crux: after first big move to jug, LF in roof, RF on right jug, L bump up to good point. Couple more tenuous moves up to fingerlock and traverse to exposed jugs. All the stars · amazing but super pumpy. 3 cruxes. getting into the crack and moving up it, which is really hard, then the first hard throw to the block, then keeping moving up it. putting all that together is probably 12b at least · Lead / Fell/Hung. Onsighted through the corner then bolt to bolted the rest. Quality! · TR. got stopped by the super slippery slab. bottom was very fun and the top looks cool. · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd try. Unbelievably good. Tough crack crux to a jug haul through the roof. Don’t forget about the face holds on the left. · TR. Got to the last side pull before roof bc didn’t have directionals and fell :( rly awesome route tho! Got on it while wet so hope to get on it dry another time · TR. Traverse low and remember the reacharound. A left crimp, jugs@ rf both hands on the undercling under the roof and left hand up to the jug. Layback and twist up. Up to the hidden crack (bomber) on the left. Traverse right, match hands and get to the jugs

routes.route_fa: Chris Kalman, Alessandra Patz, Mike Patz
routes.route_description: Unicorn Blues is the extension to Cry Baby. The upper crux is not really more difficult than Cry Baby's crux, just a touch more sustained. This pitch features excellent arete climbing, and some cool bouldery sequences. A very good line!Plenty of ways to skin this cat, but here's how we originally climbed it:1. Climb Cry Baby2. Clip bolt, step around left to other side of arete3. Climb easier terrain on the left side of the arete for another bolt or two.4. Step right back around the arete when you can stand on the pretty good footholds on the right face.5. Layback the right side of the arete to the big jug at the top.I've heard  that folks have tried it staying  on the right side the whole way... That would be quite a bit harder. Not even going to hazard a guess at the grade for that.Two notes:1.) easily toproped from the anchor of 12 Gauge, or probably BCB. Incidentally, also a good way to get the rope onto the anchor of either of those climbs (though perhaps harder than 12 Gauge).2.) Do be careful with the rope when you step left around the arete. The climbing out there is much easier than the rest of the pitch, so you probably won't fall. But the arete is sharp, so if you do find yourself about to pitch, try to jump back and right so your rope doesn't grind over the  edge.
routes.route_location: Immediately right of the splitter finger crack Black Cat Bone
routes.route_protection: 10 quickdraws should do fine.

route_comments.comment_text: Not so much an extension now that the Cry Baby anchors were removed. May 30, 2017

Stamati - when I bolted the extension, I removed two decrepit anchor bolts from Cry Baby, and replaced with a single new stainless bolt for the full pitch. TBH, I found the bottom cruxes of Cry Baby as hard or harder than the upper arete; but the upper arete, IMO, is the best climbing on that pitch. So it didn't make a lot of sense to me to replace the anchor. That said, you are the second... more Stamati - when I bolted the extension, I removed two decrepit anchor bolts from Cry Baby, and replaced with a single new stainless bolt for the full pitch. TBH, I found the bottom cruxes of Cry Baby as hard or harder than the upper arete; but the upper arete, IMO, is the best climbing on that pitch. So it didn't make a lot of sense to me to replace the anchor. That said, you are the second person who has commented on the old anchor being removed. When I'm back in July, let's just put it back. That said, I would def recommend climbing the full pitch. May 31, 2017
Once the anchor is back though, the majority of people will stop there, no matter how good the climbing above is... May 31, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Few tries back in the day and second try tonight. A bit less cerebral once the draws are hanging, but the falls are surprisingly clean. Great route. The bottom is also really incredible.

routes.route_description: Climb up a squeezed left facing/left leaning flare. Thin crack in the back. Currently needing a cleaning and some new bolts. The crux seems to be leaving the flare 2/3s up the climb and entering a bolted face above to anchors.
