routes.route_location: Furthest right feature at Blues Cliff. The first feature encountered when approaching from above. 15 feet right of "Color of Pain" / "Rhythm and Bolts"
routes.route_protection: Bolts

routes.route_description: Classic slab climbing incorporating both features and the lack thereof. Balance moves lead past the first couple of bolts. A featured face above leads to the technical crux: a sparsely featured low-angle slab.
routes.route_location: Located just to the right of Blue in the Face and left of Rythm and bolts. This is the left of two bolted starts that share the same two finishing options: either left to the .11 crux of Written in Stone, or right to the belay below BB Cling.60m rope to get down.
routes.route_protection: Bolts. Anchor is fixed, but I can't recall whether it has chains or webbing; bring some of your own just in case.

route_comments.comment_text: Pitch is a little dirty currently, but still climbable. We added a piece of cord to the anchor to back up the existing webbing on 4/4/2016, if I head back up there soon I will replace the tat. Apr 4, 2016

Anchor is a bit of a junk show. we added a sling but didnt have a knife to remove the tat. Also one of the lockers on the anchor is welded shut.  I'll try to replace this all with some chain on my next visit. regardless, this pitch is amazing!! a tragedy of not being on the LTW, as it is dirty, but it has the makings of a classic index route. 3/4 of the climbing is 5.9esq and the cruxes... more Anchor is a bit of a junk show. we added a sling but didnt have a knife to remove the tat. Also one of the lockers on the anchor is welded shut.  I'll try to replace this all with some chain on my next visit. regardless, this pitch is amazing!! a tragedy of not being on the LTW, as it is dirty, but it has the makings of a classic index route. 3/4 of the climbing is 5.9esq and the cruxes are safe and easy to pull through.  well worth ones while if at the cliff Apr 2, 2019
The anchor has good tat and fixed biners to lower. Fantastic climbing and everything needed is clean. Sep 21, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Crux off the deck. Fun easy climbing. Cruxie and wet up top! Maybe for very delicate movement to slap finish slope sopping wet · Lead / Fell/Hung. so fun, at both cruxes go slightly left for high right feet · Lead / Redpoint. Just missed flash because of weird balancey first move. Cool but covered in aggressive black lichen · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell at wet ledge at top. if dry, would've been an onsight, but that's how it goes · TR. TR solo Etch a Sketch. not in MP. right of this route. 2 laps. great route! go back for the rp

area_description: Narrow Arrow is a tower feature right of Godzilla. It has a small notch in the back, but blends into the wall below. From here and right, the wall curves back up towards the hillside, creating regions that get shaded earlier in the day. This region is generally steeper than the rest of the Lower Wall.
area_getting_there: Same approach as for the Lower Wall, but one can also approach by walking NE along the railroad tracks until reaching the boulder field, and then taking a short trail down and across to the wall.

routes.route_fa: Terry Lien, Jon Nelson, Greg Olsen
routes.route_description: This great route starts off with a powerful lieback move at about 15 feet, with a great stance just above.  Clip the fixed pin, and traverse left, up a little, and then back right to another stance.  The climb finishes by climbing the crux left leaning seam and face to a giant ledge with two bolts for an anchor.
routes.route_location: Starts about 10 feet to the left of thin fingers.
routes.route_protection: Mostly small nuts and tcu's.  One fixed piton.  Be ready to climb well above small gear.

route_comments.comment_text: Did this one a few years ago.  With tiny tech, the R rating no longer applies.  It's a little nerve racking, but not bad. Apr 25, 2011
Link this climb with Thin Fingers variation Big Toes for an spectacular exercise in placing small passive protection, offset stoppers are nice to have. Jan 9, 2013
Easily TR accessed via the first half of Thin Fingers or Shirley. Mar 26, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. TR. First crux: get right hand into the good slot, not left as is tempting. Lieback and get the right toe jam. Middle crux: left foot far left to the seam, left hand directly above it in the horizontal pod, right hand to a crimp above that. Right foot into toe jam below, left foot out. Top crux: ??? · TR. Almost TR(fl)ashed but blew the top. Compress with LH on the blob, RH to good edge, hike LF to notch and reach for jug. Suss gear first · TR. Bottom sequence has LH Gaston block, RH in slot, high LH thumb down, high R toe jam, Huck. Middle is rose with low feet to ledge. Top is high feet, compress, smears r, stem against L side high. Gear is black tote, blue purp offset mastercam above block, purple totem above RH slot, sling horn, backup pin with blue totem, after traverse yellow tote with long sling that you unclip. .4 low on ledge, purple peenut and purple brass in corner with 0 Z4 · 2 pitches. TR. That crux at the top is tough. Used a knee bar, knee bar pad would be nice · Lead / Redpoint. One toprope one lead burn. A fun headpoint with surprisingly bomber gear. Small nuts protect the final crux. · TR. Way hard for 5.11b. Sparse and thin pro. 3 distinct sections. Powerful layback with a particular sequence. Improbable traverse across thin crimps and a shallow finger slot. Stepping on the thin (left leaning?) crack for balance is key. Finally, the dihedral - definitely the crux. Start in the thin crack, reach for high L side pull to layback off of, throw R for another side pull, transition RF over to awkward stem, finish with a couple of desperate arete slaps. · Lead / Redpoint. With Jonah - HP, w/o pin, good protection the whole way (not PG13), short but so fun · TR. Climb clean the bottom. Need to work the upper section... I hung a lot. Dirtbag weekend · TR. I hung so much... use Mira shoes next time... W/ Sapphire and Aaron Schick · Lead / Redpoint. Not R rated. Just bring a Red ball nut and some brassies with gear to.5 and some slings to equalize. Super fun.

routes.route_description: This is a sustained pitch. Thin finger locks to a small roof. Nice position. The rock has a slightly different texture to it if I remember correctly. The only bad thing about this pitch is there is a loose block. I have put a black circle showing the location on the topo. Once that block is gone it could possibly be four stars.
routes.route_location: Climb Let's Barbecue to get to this pitch or one can access it from the top via Tatoosh. The red line in the topo shows were to traverse to the top of the pitch from Tatoosh. 70m rope will work. Naturally one will want to rap straight down via Tai and Randy Memorial  route after climbing Bob and Doris, but that is not recommended due to a very large mess of loose rock. So please rappel via Let's Barbecue. One day  the  Tai and Randy Memorial route will be brought back to life
routes.route_protection: I only tope roped this pitch but I would say a single rack with thin wires. Cams from 000 .75 single set would be more then enough. there may be some small cams that could be doubled but I cant confirm those sizes right now. I added two stainless bolts and hangers with chain on top and at the start. The chain is not stainless. There were two pins on the start for a belay originally, I think I removed those. Brian Ebert helped me with this work.

route_comments.comment_text: I know now a days we call Tatoosh the awesome pitch that forks left before the OW section. I think the OW section is called Free at Last now. Jul 24, 2016

routes.route_fa: D. Cilley, J. Nelson, G. Olsen (1984)
routes.route_description: This route has the same start as Natural Log Cabin (and pre-dates that route). But instead of traversing right into the bottomless corner, continue straight up into the left-facing corner-chimney system. It shares the same anchor as Natural Log Cabin.To start, either face climb straight up to the corner, or traverse in from the start of Godzilla. The start of the corner has an interesting pinch-grip face move (10+), from which you rock over to the main crack. The crux is the flaring hand jams above.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Small wires to 3.5" cams.

route_comments.comment_text: You can also continue up the same major corner system ending in a finger crack on the right, to an anchor atop P2 Godzilla (aka Leapin' Lizards) - and from there you can continue via Slow Children (far left) or P3 of City park (middle) or Park Ranger (above). Climbed to this point, Deal With it Ranger is an excellent 50m 5.11a/b. Mar 9, 2015
Does this get climbed anymore? It is one nice looking chimney up there. Jan 28, 2023

routes.route_fa: Ron Burgner, Mark Weigelt, Mead Hargis, Jim Langdon, Tom Ramier, Craig Rankin
routes.route_description: This version of Free at Last from the new guidebook is a bit of a rework that combines pitches from the original full Tatoosh, Free at Last, and Voyage of the Majestic Glass Eyed Tuna.  This route is packed from top to bottom with varied, thought provoking crack climbing that will force you to pull on your thinking cap.Pitch 1 (5.10b, 35m):Start up the modern version of Tatoosh (well documented here:mountainproject.com/route/1…).  Instead of belaying at the normal anchor for Tatoosh under a large perched block, continue up 10 feet of dirty terrain and belay off a tree.  Alternatively, split off about half way up, climb up the original pitch two of Tatoosh and belay at the anchors of WATWB/Just Say NO2.Pitch 2 (5.9, 35 meters):This pitch is the lowest quality on the route due to some mandatory dirt scrambling, but it still has a good bit of fun crack climbing.  Head up a clean, low angle V-slot, with a thin crack in the back.  Hike up some dirt and climb some creative sequences up cracks in the corner to the next belay.Pitch 3 (5.10b, 35m):This pitch has quite a few cruxes and felt more sustained than pitch 4, but it's all there.  Begin by heading up the corner to the first crux at the obvious roof.  This is definitely harder than 10b if you opt to burl through it, but there are some sneaky tricks to it.  A good stance above the roof separates the next crux, which will require even more creative thinking.  Once at the base of the overhanging ice cream cone feature, head up and left to the third smeary slab crux, protected by a bolt, and finally up and right along an easy ramp to the belay.Pitch 4 (5.10d, 30m):Just when you are getting used to the funky crack movement, this pitch slaps you in the face with some hard face climbing past two bolts.  We were a little confused by the bolt placements here.  Start by mantling into a little boxy ledge and clip the first bolt, then climb straight left to a blocky crack.  I placed a red metolius here to protect against a pendulum as I moved up to the next bolt, then reached down and pulled it out after clipping.  Continue up to a right leaning crack and then to the base of the imposing V-slot.  This slot is the real money climbing of the route, but I would HIGHLY recommend taping up to get the most enjoyment out of it.  At the top of the slot, clip a bolt and make a few last moves up and right to the chains.  Give your thanks to Saint Francis before heading down!Descent:Rappel the route with a 70 meter rope.  It works best to use the anchor of WATWB/Just Say NO2 for the last rappel, which is climber's right of the couple trees at the top of the first pitch.  The rappel getting there is a rope stretcher.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Doubles from blue metolius to #3 C4, and a few small nuts.  You will be climbing parallel cracks of every size on this route.  Bring at least 3 alpine draws to minimize drag and a handful of quickdraws for the occasional bolt.

route_comments.comment_text: IMO, pretty ridiculous to call the final bolted move on pitch 3 10b, but I guess this is Index and that's the way it goes. Maybe I'm soft. Also confused by the bolt placement on P4. Mar 18, 2018
Really enjoyed this adventure to the top of the LTW! I've added an annotated photo for the Pitch 4 start, which confused us a bit at the time. mountainproject.com/photo/1… Oct 2, 2018

Instead of dealing with the grovel directly above Tatoosh and knocking stuff down, I recommend climbing Quarry Crack as the first pitch. Fun climb that does not get climbed as much as it should and leaves you with an easier, cleaner way into the start of the second pitch, Jul 5, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Led the first two pitches, followed the last two. Took the Voyage of Majestic Tuna on the last pitch · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on pitch 4. May or may not have cheated on a draw for pitch 3 slab crux. Powered my way through roof of pitch 3, not sure what the tricks that were mentioned are · Lead / Onsight. Fourth pitch off the belay I’m told you can start from the gully on the left and traverse and not crack that’s easier. If i do use the bolt up and right and then step left, stay very low all the way down to the low Bigfoot and transition to the crack Where you can climb up and get some good cams before the crocs steep moves just above which all go pretty well if you just keep moving. · Lead. Led Tatoosh and P3. Pulled on the draw thru slab crux of p3. P 4 has a weird traverse start, and the topout slab is tricky too. Doubles tips to #3, single #4. Triples .5, .75 camalot. · Lead / Onsight. Dirty but fun deserved to be done once last pitch have some funky bolt placements. Did with no tape shorts and no shirt no blood was spilled · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on last pitch. Popped off crimp by first bolt and nothing but a bunch of bloody knuckles to show for it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Did the leftmost variant on p4. Final splitter corner was fun, but not as epic as the guidebook picture made it look · Lead. Sort of an annoyingly fun route. Fun when the climbing is great and when you overcome some of the tricky wird sections of the route but annoying when your mid way through shitting your pants by the runout and the bad fall potential that you are now faced with. Seriously, half of these bolts are placed so awkwardly with no rhyme or reason at all. 1st pitch (tatoosh) was a blast with some fun crack interspersed with delicate section of insecure climbing. 2nd pitch was ok and got better the further you climbed. 3rd was tricky with a couple distinct crux moves. I fell getting over the roof (1st ever trad fall. Yay!) but managed to work out the slaby crux sequence up above ¯\_(ツ)_/¯. 4th pitch got me annoyed by the bolt placemat and had to hang on the second draw to clip but the rest of the pitch was Fantastic with another weird placed bolt at the top. · Follow. Fell many times, pulled on gear. Clean lead on pitch 2. Questionable to say I ‘climbed’ this but I did get to the top of it · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pitch 2 and 3 are great. Pitch 4 was rough, french freed the crap out of it · Lead / Fell/Hung. 5:10 base-to-base with Waiwai. Waiwai led P1+3, I lead P2+4. Only P2 sent on lead and P1+3+4 followed clean. The roof on P3 and the V-slot on P4 felt so mega. · Lead. Led P1 and P3. Clean P1. Took P3 roof. use the right hand rail and stem. P4 is good. I followed P4 and did it clean. · Lead. (TM) · Lead / Fell/Hung. Led 3 and 4 with Kenn. Next time would belay off the tree below the last pitch and skip the PoR bolted weirdness · Lead / Fell/Hung. hung on last pitch trying to figure out how to get over. hard · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Led P1 and P3. P2 is low quality, bailed on the weird and heady P4. Could have used triples in the small cams to 1 for Tatoosh. · 3 pitches. Follow. Followed Jacob. P3 is burly. We both aided through the first section of P4– difficult! · Lead / Onsight. Had a great time with Jess and kye. Led the 9 and 10d. Fun and funky · 2 pitches. Lead. 2 pitches after Tatoosh and finished via VOTMGET as P4. Led all pitches. · Lead / Onsight. Lead quarry crack to free at last. Lead pitch 3 of FAL. Followed pitches 2 and 4 clean. · Lead / Redpoint. With Dan. Fall at 1st roof of P3. Lowered and sent 2nd go. P3 felt harder than P4. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Follow 1&2, OS P3, Hung on ramp on P4, finishing hand crack is awesome. P3 is dope. W Steve · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. routes.route_description: Freedom Fighter (p1) is the clean looking layback crack directly above Shirley. NAD (p2) is off to the left and Shirley (p2) is the dirty / blocky option a few feet to the right. This pitch is rated .10d in the guidebooks but feels significantly easier. Most likely a typo so I put it in as .10b.Pitch 1 finishes on a ledge below Death to Zeke (.11a). P2 (5.9 ow) is the dirty crack on the right. I haven't climbed P2 but will likely clean it up soon™ and update here if I do.
routes.route_location: The clean looking layback crack directly above Shirley. You could definitely link this with Shirley for a sweet pitch.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2" or w/e you used to get here for P1. P2 will need larger gear and a selection of brushes.Bolted anchor on top of P1. Top of P2 is unknown to me but you should be able to get up the Narrow Arrow (anchors w/ rings) or something.

route_comments.comment_text: Did this the other day not really sure what the route/grade was. Fun route, needs more traffic to stay clean. If you keep jamming the whole way I think it's 10+, easier if you layback second bulge. Singles of .4-2 are more than enough. Oct 12, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Fun route. Only did p1. Needs more traffic to stay clean.

routes.route_description: Start by stepping across to the wall from the Narrow Arrow summit. Clip the bolt, enter a 10a flare, go up a ramp, and continue trending up and right. After doing a 10a roof, go right, crossing Tatoosh to a ramp and belay ledge.For this and other routes in the area, see the two beta images.
routes.route_location: First you must reach the top of Narrow Arrow.
routes.route_protection: 1 bolt, gear to 2".

route_comments.comment_text: Dirty but worth climbing to get to the goods above. To avoid getting lost just keep following the edge of the slab up and to the right until you reach the Tatoosh corner. A little spicy. Jul 5, 2017

routes.route_description: Starts left of With Apologies to Walter B follow bolt line  left of the arete
routes.route_location: right of Tatoosh left of With Apologies to Walter B
routes.route_protection: 7 lead bolts, a few cams from red c3- 0.4 BD or nuts in this range and one #2 BD cam + sling. The bolts on the arete are new although the last one may not be clippable on lead. Choosing not to hang draws on the upper arete first would make this climb pretty dangerous. Finish for Walter B anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: New bolts as of 9/29 Oct 1, 2020

Great route. Felt about the same difficulty as NAD, maybe even a touch harder but with cooler moves IMO. Clipping the bolts on lead on the other hand, pretty vexing. There is really only one clip stance on the arete, so I put a 4x draw on the last bolt and skipped the middle one. This has the rope clipped such that you get a clean fall (as opposed to being clipped to your left which sends you... more Great route. Felt about the same difficulty as NAD, maybe even a touch harder but with cooler moves IMO. Clipping the bolts on lead on the other hand, pretty vexing. There is really only one clip stance on the arete, so I put a 4x draw on the last bolt and skipped the middle one. This has the rope clipped such that you get a clean fall (as opposed to being clipped to your left which sends you sailing into the slabby corner). YMMV, but in general a really worth while route. Thanks for the cleaning Lucas! Jan 23, 2021
sounds like a candidate for rebolting to me. Jan 24, 2021

routes.route_description: From belay at top of Higher Learning, do an exposed traverse out right past 2 bolts (12a), up a groove into a bombay chimney. Traverse back left and then follow bolts up the headwall (12a) to the top. You are now at the highest point on the Lower Town Wall.Topo and overview are shown in images for Higher Learning.
routes.route_location: Start is the same place as Path of Righteousness.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2", 6 bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: No, they have not been repositioned. Dec 28, 2015
FA J. Wyland Nov 12, 2016
Haven't climbed it yet but it looks absolutely nails. Apr 12, 2019

routes.route_description: Nice finger crack with a nice view of the Quarry wall. It's  short pitch but a great test piece for Index finger crack climbing.
routes.route_location: This climb is accessed by climbing Thin Fingers or Tatoosh or With Apologies to Walter B and Quarry Crack. Witch ever pitch is dry will sometimes determine your choice for you. To belay at the start of this pitch it is best to tie off to the big tree on the big ledge since there is not a bolt belay positioned at the start. The closest belay is the Quarry crack belay but it is to far right. One can also make a anchor with gear. A 70m rope is best since you most likely will rap Quarry Crack. You can Rap Thin Fingers or WATWB also but take care.
routes.route_protection: Stoppers work well on this pitch in places as well as cams. Single rack of BD 000 to BD 1 would be more then enough. I cant remember the exact sequence of gear. I replaced the anchor on top with two stainless bolts and hangers with chains, but the chains are not stainless.

routes.route_description: This is a great newer 'variation' that combines the best parts of two older routes, an obscure .12b called Just Say No^2 and the more popular With Apologies to Walter B. Bad rock at the start should be no deterrent. Climb past a bolt to a stance. With difficulty, climb past three more bolts and some thin gear to another stance. Instead of continuing straight up the poorly bolted arete of Just Say No^2, make a bizarre, engaging series of movements to the right around the arete past a bolt to join Walter B for its awesome .10d finger crack.
routes.route_location: Past Thin Fingers and Tatoosh the trail goes uphill towards the quarry (unfortunately the nice trail in this section was obliterated by rockfall). This climb is found on the left and starts with some jumbled scrambling up blocks that soon gives way to steep face climbing in a shallow corner. Fixed lowering hardware on top.
routes.route_protection: Four or five bolts, thin gear for the top of the initial corner feature, then finger to hand sized pieces for the upper crack (doubles useful in the .5 to 1 Camalot range).

route_comments.comment_text: This is a much better entrance to Apologies.  Thanks Chris. Oct 9, 2012
Great climb that is quick to dry out after the rains Jan 5, 2013
Worthy.  The boulder problem at the fourth bolt and the traverse into the Walter B crack both feature fun technical sequences on quality rock. Aug 8, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. TR. Don't go too far right getting over first bulge Use hidden foot shelf to work into upper dihedral Bump feet and use crimp above half moon crimp at crux in upper dihedral? (Need to rehearse a bit more) Bring a wire brush to clean footholds on traverse Wear solutions · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. I got all the moves worked out time to send it. Weird step behind with left leg and cross over left arms for upper crux. High right foot for lower crux followed by a layback moves · Lead / Fell/Hung. Project! Tricky feet under clings and crimps tough around the arete as well · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Got it clean on TR, should send next time. Need high right foot on upper crux · Lead / Redpoint. With Luke and KC. 7 TR laps, 1st lead go. Prehung draws + extended alpine draw on 2nd bolt. Toe hook traverse was wild. · TR. Mid crux - get feet up on good rails w/ underclings, LH gaston crescent, LF small good edge, deep backstep RF into dish, RH smudge gaston. Traverse - swap feet onto shit, RH on crystal, RF stand directly on top of only good foot, RH to crimp, toe hook · 2 pitches. TR. First crux: stem up and then go L to ledge. Use foot nub around corner to mantle. Crux 2: high feet into tooth, key is to get l foot on flat crimp and r foot in dish. R hand gastons on weird nothing bump. Arete crux: toe hook should go but may need more intermediate foot moves · Lead / Redpoint. Hung alpine draw before ledge to make bolting a little safer. Psyched for the unexpected redpoint. · 2 pitches. TR. 1st crux: stem up until I can reach LH crimp, RH in to gaston for stability, readjust feet then move L to lip and mantle using RF kneebar. 2nd crux: tried new beta which I think is higher percentage, clip last bolt before crux then lean out right of LH side pull, RH to side pull, LF heel hook, LH potato chip, RF up to good smear near protrusion, LF up to crescent and knee bar, core up and slap RH around arête and back to crimp in corner, stay calm, RF back step, LH up to good arête crimp. Figure out gear for finger crack - nuts probably bomber. 3rd crux: stay low actually, LH sidepull, RH sidepull then cube around arête, RF orange smear, LH in to closer sidepull, LF closer, LH arête, LF match or smear nearby, RF on seam notch toe down RtoL, pull hips R with RF, RH to deep edge, LF good smear, cross LH 2 hung on TR. Probably ready to lead. 2nd bolt pre clipped long draw was recommended otherwise ledge fall potential on first crux · TR. Did all the moves! Rad. The name makes sense after figuring out the “Shquirm-stem” crux. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Kinda scary 1st crux, hanging a sling would be great. Couldn't do 2nd crux, couldn't latch right hand. Did 3rd crux with some rope assistance, hard bringing the right had in. Crack was fun, climbed it straight in. .75 for start, .3 to aid to 2nd bolt, .2, .1, .4 for thin section, .5 + .75 for top (just run out the hands) · Lead / Redpoint. 3rd try, soo good! Emmerson on belay, and after his send! · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd go, team send with Neil. Such a good route. Perfect way to end our trip · Lead / Fell/Hung. .75 for start. Pre hang draws with sling on 2nd (kinda sketchy to clip otherwise). Black totem with draw , gold dmm offset (pretty optional) yellow totem with draw, 2 .5s (first with draw, .75, 1, 1 · TR. Fun movement. At crux use mini-stem with outside edge of L and R in divot. Toe hook at traverse is sick. · TR. Fell but felt easy enough once I figured out the beta. LH crimp, RH gaston, RF dimple, LF up to edge, drop right knee and RH good crimp/side pull, left foot up again to good triangle. Traverse high-ish with right foot up on big tan smear and left on arête · Lead / Redpoint. 1st time tr last weekend. Lead once and fell today, then sent · TR. much better intro to the walter b layback. didn't get to the top. first day at index of the season. bouldered in the morning so was also worked. · TR. Couldn’t figure out crux but really awesome and felt close to unlocking it. Traverse toe hook is sick! · Lead / Fell/Hung. needto develop more power before taking on the roof and side pull · Lead. headpoint 1tr 1 lead, second 12 at index! rad stem crux and traversing sequences! · TR. figured out the moves below the 4th bolt but didn't finish the rest...entrance to walter

routes.route_description: Good hands in an oatmeal dihedral lead to a spectacular flake that cuts dramatically out left. Perfect hands all the way to the chains.
routes.route_location: Up slope from Apologies.
routes.route_protection: Hand-sized cams.

route_comments.comment_text: Route was pretty caked in dirt. Cleaned out some of the dirt, but I'm sure it'll get full again quickly. It's a great photo op, but not very enjoyable. It's not what I would call a modern day 5.8 my friend and I did some struggling to get up this route. Aug 29, 2017

The entire right side wall on the beginning of this route is rotten. Pretty much anything you put your foot on moves. It would be cool if it was cleaned up a bit but not sure there is any solid rock under all the choss. Jan 20, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. total sandbag. first half is choss but the upper part is cool. hard tho · Lead / Flash. double #2 and .75. #3 for entering roof. couple small pieces for beginning, very dirty.

routes.route_fa: Fa: Ron burgner, Mark Weigelt FFA P2-3: John Stoddard FFA P1: Toprope long ago? Dave Morales?
routes.route_description: Right of Narrow Arrow Overhang, this pitch traditionally starts with a beatdown in a difficult wide stemming corner (.11b). An easier and less cruxy method is to use the start of Shirley. Either way, climb up through varied terrain and mantle up onto a small stance at the base of a corner. Layback a flake up a slab and make an airy step-across move left under the roof. Pull the roof past a pin and establish on the face above. The left facing lieback feature thins out just before a core-intensive reach to a large flake. Follow this past a bolt to an awkward stance on a small ledge. Clip the final bolt and begin the crux, a five or six move boulder problem (V5ish).
routes.route_location: This is the rightmost of the two "Narrow Arrow" routes. The beginning climbs dirty ledges below a bolt. A 60m rope will lower to the ground from the anchor. It is possible to continue for three more pitches (up to .10c), including an airy offwidth (gear to 6"). All pitches are excellent and can also provide access to new pitches above and right of the Narrow Arrow feature.
routes.route_protection: Three bolts and two pins (the first questionable). A selection of gear is needed, very thin to green Camalot size. Include nuts.

route_comments.comment_text: This route continues for 3 more pitches to the narrow arrow summit. p2 is a finger crack in a corner. 5.10b p3 is a very demanding 5.10d pitch with an amazing roof. One of the best 5.10s at Index P4 is a short offwidth and roof. 5.10 Aug 18, 2008

I remember doing the last two pitches to the NA summit in the early 80s. The pitch getting to the summit cleft was fantastic 5.10 crack climbing on the prow. At the time I thought it was the best crack pitch at Index. (I wish I could remember how we got to the start of the 2nd pitch - it wasn't aid and it certainly wasn't 12c. But anyway, there is a way to do the last pitches without doing... more I remember doing the last two pitches to the NA summit in the early 80s. The pitch getting to the summit cleft was fantastic 5.10 crack climbing on the prow. At the time I thought it was the best crack pitch at Index. (I wish I could remember how we got to the start of the 2nd pitch - it wasn't aid and it certainly wasn't 12c. But anyway, there is a way to do the last pitches without doing 12c.) And back then we didn't have any pro that would fit the wide crack in the summit cleft, so that felt incredibly desperate to me. I remember stacking two hexes in the roof at the start and then running it out to the top. Now you have the option of doing a 5.11 finger traverse out right. Jul 5, 2012
I have traversed from Thin Fingers. You can even come from Tatoosh lots of drag if you traverse in one pitch. Best to climb to TF belay and then go from there. Jul 5, 2012

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Thanks to a very patient late night belay from Ruth truck. Triple lh bump, move feet to knobs sooner. · TR. Again felt better but will have a hard time linking both crux’s at the finish · Lead / Redpoint. With Nick and Manny. Index provides! Felt very smooth. Perfect LTW summer evening conditions with surprisingly low humidity. Freshly resoled shoes helped. 10 TR laps and 6th lead go. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. With Nick, George, and Michael. Fell at the very last hard move of the crux on the first attempt, fell off the beginning of the crux sequence on the second attempt. · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Stamati. No falls until the very last hard move of the final crux. Oh well. Several drops of rain on the upper section, then really started raining when lowering off. · TR. This is a approachable project great route lead the second amazing second pitch · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Nick. 2 hangs. Less than optimal condition - bottom was still wet and top was baking in the sun, but went for the lead anyway. Good practice. · TR. Good grief this is hard The lower boulder problem flummoxed me for several attempts (pushing with left hand was what worked for me), but the upper crux with slimpers and a terrible pinch and feet I couldn’t see basically felt impossible. On TR for the love of god. Best wishes to you on your project, Dean · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell midway thru crux on lead. Gear not bad. .2 and purp metolius after bolt · 2 pitches. TR. P1+2. Crux felt hard. Need to be more dialed. See picture for gear beta. Mildly epic. RIP Nalgene :( · TR. At first bolt match lower side pull in seam,RH thumb press, high far right foot, left hand palms arete, keep stemming left foot up, LH to higher seam then get crimp, match and find high right foot. At upper crux. Switch so that right hand is on high part of Gaston/ side pull. Low left tick foot. Rf on tiny knob on arete. Lh block side pull. Bump lf on tick, bump rf on incut foot in corner. Go up for rh pinch and rotate body. Lh Spocks the low seam, rh bumps to crimp, keep lf tension, maybe bump up a tick, bring right foot high to lil knobby foot. Another foot right above it to bump to later. Throw right hand to next crimp then match, try to get feet up (lf in the seam, rf on lil knob on arete), bump to next crimp then get slot jug · Would like to traverse in from the side and do the whole link up again like I did with jack Taylor a half decade ago · Lead / Redpoint. A few top ropes and one lead attempt. Back to back sends with Jesse :-) · Lead / Redpoint. Second Lead attempt, first pitch only. Classic Granite, feels impossible if you do it wrong and feels appropriate for the grade when you do it correctly. · TR. cruised to the crux, hung, then linked it twice! Low gravity high friction thanks to biscuit sending electricity thru the static rope. · 3 pitches. Follow. Climbed pitches 2-4 after coming in from thin fingers. Led pitch 2. Followed 3,4. Great climb. · TR. Laaate night sesh with sawdust. Fun via frittata shenanigans. Boulder problem v v hard but doable. · 3 pitches. TR. TRS. Started at top of P1. Did all upper pitches twice. Really good climbing. · TR. Bottom crux is v3, top v5. Everything in between is pretty cruiser low 11. Couldn’t get top crux but it’s really tiny slopey sidepulls and crimps super close together on almost no feet. · Lead / Redpoint. Flashed the whole top on tr, fell on the bottom but then figured out a closer in but worse foot for the stem. Then lowered and sent, kept it exciting by figuring out all the gear on the fly (not too exciting tho cuz I placed 4 mediocre pieces from the stance after the pin) · 2 pitches. TR. wow, nails. but felt doable. TRonsighted through roof, on second attempt sent up to start of boulder problem but couldn't do crux moves. · TR. with Aaron. moved rope over from Shirley. couldn't do upper crux moves but fun stemming lower crux slab · Lead. Toproped the first pitch and fell a lot and skipped the final boulder problem. Lead and onsighted the next three pitches (done as two). The final offwidth was awesome! · TR. Could not figure out boulder problem at top need more finger strength and core · Lead / Fell/Hung. hung on p1. linked 2/3 on lead. brittany led 1 and 4. ate a cookie.

routes.route_description: This is maybe the easiest/cleanest way to the summit of Narrow Arrow. From the summit of Narrow Arrow it’s reasonable to continue to the last pitch of Free at Last, making for a cleaner and more classic way of approaching its final splitter pitch.Pitch 1 110’ 5.10-Climb the first pitch of Godzilla, from the belay ledge, clip the bolt to the right and make the “Cidiot” traverse as if doing park ranger. After the initial hard moves, stand up on the ledge. There is a critical black totem/blue metolius placement high above the ledge here to protect your follower. Continue past the main corner to the awesome perch atop Natural Log Cabin.Pitch 2 40’ 5.10-Head straight up off the belay, clipping 2 bolts. Then traverse right past one anchor to the anchor at the top of P2 of NAD. It is possible to link with the first pitch if you manage your rope drag well.Note: There are many other ways to reach this point. I’ll describe a couple more recommended variations.Option A: Climb Shirley (5.11) and traverse to the top of P1 NAD then climb P2 NAD (awesome 5.10). This is the most recommended variation as it tags the classic, under-appreciated P2 of NAD.Option B: Climb Thin fingers (or Tatoosh or Quarry Crack) for P1. Then make a moderate traverse clipping strange glue ins to the belay atop P2 of NAD.Pitch 3 80’ 5.10d“P3 NAD”Climb the awesome techy right facing corner up to an athletic roof. Good hand jams take you out the wild roof into a short awkward but easy fist crack. This leads to an hanging belay in the flare above. If you have the energy, it is possible to link into the short next pitch.Pitch 4 40’ 5.10“The Cleft”Head up easy chimney to the roof, then make an awkward transition into the OW on the face above. Solid and friendly splitter 5’s takes you to a sick belay on top of Narrow Arrow. You can get a BD .1 in just before the roof to back up the 5 as you bump it the rest of the pitch. A single 5 allows for TR pro the whole way.It is possible to rap from here with a single 60M rope. One long rappel takes you back to the top of NAD P2, then two more from there to the ground. If descending this way it’s definitely worthwhile to climb P2 of NAD on the way down if you didn’t climb it on the way up.Pitch 5 120’ 5.10aClimb “Higher Learning” to a belay below the last pitch of “Free at Last”. This pitch is a bit mungy but would clean up and likely stay pretty clean if it got some traffic.Pitch 6 80’ 5.10d“Voyage of the Majestic Glass-Eyed Tuna”Head up to near a tree, using a thin crack to head up and right into an obvious left facing corner, follow this amazing splitter to the top of LTW! Alternatively, you can climb the bolted direct start of “The Path of Righteousness” to gain the same corner crack. From here you can rappel or top out and continue up the mid walls Squamish Style.
routes.route_location: Start on Godzilla or Shirley
routes.route_protection: Double rack micro to 3. Single 5. Optional 4. Triples .2ish size if you want to sew it up on pitch 3.

route_comments.comment_text: A few notes: - The traverse from the top of Godzilla to the top of NAD P2 has been referred to as "The Cidiot" (FA Tom Ramier?) and also allows you to access Salad Fingers and other excellent upper pitches. - NAD P4 (OW pitch through roof) is called "The Cleft". The movement and position on this is amazing! - After Higher Learning, the best finish is via Voyage of the Majestic Glass-Eyed... more A few notes: - The traverse from the top of Godzilla to the top of NAD P2 has been referred to as "The Cidiot" (FA Tom Ramier?) and also allows you to access Salad Fingers and other excellent upper pitches. - NAD P4 (OW pitch through roof) is called "The Cleft". The movement and position on this is amazing! - After Higher Learning, the best finish is via Voyage of the Majestic Glass-Eyed Tuna. The original start next to a tree is best (versus the bolted start, "Path of Righteousness"). Awesome link up! Sep 8, 2023

Great climbing. I would suggest the following tactic: P1-climb Godzilla to anchors on the ledge.  P2 head Right past a bolt traversing up to upper Log Cabin anchor, continue up passing 2 bolts, continue right past a2B anchor finishing on the second 2B anchor you encounter. (This puts you one 5.10 pitch above the anchors of NAD and in a good position to easily lower/rap down to TR/Lead the 5.10... more Great climbing. I would suggest the following tactic: P1-climb Godzilla to anchors on the ledge.  P2 head Right past a bolt traversing up to upper Log Cabin anchor, continue up passing 2 bolts, continue right past a2B anchor finishing on the second 2B anchor you encounter. (This puts you one 5.10 pitch above the anchors of NAD and in a good position to easily lower/rap down to TR/Lead the 5.10 corner).  When ready to continue up, linking P3 and short P4 makes sense, no rope drag issues and totally different gear sizes needed. May 16, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Led Godzilla clean, led P3 with a gnarly gear ripper, stopped there · 3 pitches. 2nd two pitches of NAD through the wild OW. Protects well with one #4 and one 5

routes.route_fa: FA(3p): Greg Donaldson, Richard Mathies, 68   FFA(p1 L): Darryl Cramer, Terry Lien FFA(P2 via traverse): Dick Cilley, FFA of full Ben Gilkison 10/2008
routes.route_description: This incredible route has a storied history of free climbing attempts but the first integral redpoint of the full modern pitch was done by Ben Gilkison. Start via some ledgy climbing up to an obvious left facing corner with cracks. Climb up the face and corner above past two bolts to an anchor. Continue through the shallow opposing corners above via spectacular tricky stemming moves with small, finicky gear to another ledge with an anchor. Lieback the arete/corner above past two bolts to the roof. There are a couple methods that work, but either way a very physical sequence of moves leads over the roof to a new anchor about 15 feet above. A little runout in spots and absolutely spectacular.
routes.route_location: Starts between Deal With it Ranger/Natural Log Cabin and Narrow Arrow Direct in a left facing corner with a crack on the face of the corner. Above the top anchors, it looks possible to continue climbing via corners and some broken rock to a higher anchor below the Salad Fingers corner. This appears to have been climbed in the past but I'm uncertain of the difficulty.
routes.route_protection: 2 bolts at the beginning, 3 on the top section (including the anchor below the lieback). Nuts (include a couple of Offsets or RPs) and cams to 1 inch. If you want detailed spoiler beta for gear, read the comments below as some broken rock has changed a critical placement a bit.  The first anchor is on a ledge at the end of the original free pitch and makes for an incredible .11c. Descent from the top anchors is possible via a single 70m rope.

route_comments.comment_text: Ben Gilkison did the FA/FFA - in 2008 rcnw.net/forums/topic/597-n… From above the full 35m P1, the climbing is just a few meters of 5.8 chimneying with hand cracks to a pedestal ledge. It's easy to reach the anchor between P2 and P3 of NAD, or to step left to the anchor below Salad Fingers. more Ben Gilkison did the FA/FFA - in 2008 rcnw.net/forums/topic/597-n… From above the full 35m P1, the climbing is just a few meters of 5.8 chimneying with hand cracks to a pedestal ledge. It's easy to reach the anchor between P2 and P3 of NAD, or to step left to the anchor below Salad Fingers. Oct 23, 2012
How about "two V6 boulder problems, separated by a strenuous & crucial gear placement" - it's accurate, but doesn't quite roll off the tongue. Jan 9, 2015

Stellar FFA by BG!  I'd say better and I think quite a bit harder then 10 % extension. As blake highlighted the two v6 boulder problems are not really "separated" by anything resembling a restful position, but rather are "connected" by a strenuous crucial gear placement in the overhang. My subjective breakdown of difficulty of sections between rest... Stage 1:  Approach pitch to... more Stellar FFA by BG!  I'd say better and I think quite a bit harder then 10 % extension. As blake highlighted the two v6 boulder problems are not really "separated" by anything resembling a restful position, but rather are "connected" by a strenuous crucial gear placement in the overhang. My subjective breakdown of difficulty of sections between rest... Stage 1:  Approach pitch to second anchor = cryptic 5.11 R ---> huge rest Stage 2=  Strenuous V4/5 ---> bad rest in finger lock ---> (V5/6 getting to roof + extremely pumpy gear placement + V6 navigating roof). Last boulder problem is intense. stage 2 could be reduced to v4 ---> bad rest---> v7/8 highball( from finger-lock rest to hand         jam in stance above roof) Still working on my index math mastery but that comes out to at least 5.11 B ++ Jun 21, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Felt amazing the entire bottom section, pulled into the rest alcove with zero pressure or pump. Hung out for a while looking across at mount index, just psyched to be up there. Fired the first bolt, hiked me feet up, fired the second bolt. Hit the right hand pinch and rocked up onto the toe chip. Black totem in the roof, left hand on the side poll, screaming to get my shoulder inside the chimney. Squirmed my way to the chains. LIFETIME RIG · Lead / Fell/Hung. Amazing. Didn’t extend the .5 in the mini roof, bad rope drag. Fell on the top of the layback and fell once pulling the roof, than pulled the roof from the stance to the chains. I think there’s a possibility to do this dream rig!!!!!! AT DAWN, WE RIDE!!!!!!! · Lead / Fell/Hung. First lead go with Stamati.... awesome new friend and excellent experience. real airy section in the middle put me in the right head space to battle on the arete! Fell clipping the second draw, found iron clad beta for the roof. · 3 pitches. TR. 2 tr burns after Oliver from Germany smashed on his second go! · 4 pitches. TR. Met a strong german named oliver who needed a belay on this. Gave it two goes after he put it up and kinda flailed. He sent second go, huge style, ground up, no gear beta. · 1 pitch. TR. Pumped out pulling the roof on TR. Need more gas after that arête! · 7c++ todos los dias. Mucho Mucho mas dificil que NAD, Power Horse, Stern Farmer P2...

routes.route_fa: Darryl Cramer, Nicola Masciandaro, and Terry Lien (1985)
routes.route_description: This rarely done gem is definitely my favorite single pitch climb on the lower wall.  Runout 5.10 climbing leads to a bolt and some fun 5.11 face moves.  Next is a flared hand crack that can be liebacked (hard to place gear this way), which leads to a good rest and a bolt.  Step right into a spectacular corner with bolts.  Stem and lieback your way to the chains.  May be a little reachy, and probably easier for tall people.  Lowering is not recommended due to lots of rope drag.Note:  A standard 70 meter rope will not reach the ground if lowering.
routes.route_location: This is the next route to the right of Godzilla P1.  The orignal pitch called Deal with it ranger goes straight up a chimney where Natural log cabin cuts right into the bolted corner.
routes.route_protection: Mixed

route_comments.comment_text: If you aren't 6'3" and built like a bear as Jesse is this route is going to feel hard for the grade...5.11c is defintanly a sandbag...not as bad as some sandbags at Index, but definantly up there.  And the first 30 feet is 5.10 R/X...though feels more PG-13/R. It also seeps like crazy till it's had a solid week in the sun. Jun 12, 2008

Superb, four-star pitch with several cruxes separated by good rests.  The hanging dihedral is both technical and powerful with surprisingly good feet, but it ain't over til you pull the final layback moves with a solid pump on board. Jul 25, 2013
I rapelled this route 7/29 with a 70 but had to down climb the first move so it can be done with a 70 carefully. Aug 2, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. With Luke. Left exit. Sewed it up, felt pretty safe. 9 TR laps, 3rd lead go. · TR. Cold, dry, sunny, high of 45. Top roped it after Anthony sent. Was great, fell at last traverse. Remember to bring left foot around to nub and stand up, don't try to campus. For first crux, use right hand to grab flake above to stand up. For second mini crux, lie back until you can hand jam with left hand into the crack, then step up. · TR. awesome route. Ran out of gas after reaching the final crimp. Didn’t realize there was a knob on left that Anthony mentioned. Will have to try next time. Legs were gassed as well at the end of this one · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Nick, Ben, Kat, and Carson. Took a rather entertaining fall while trying to sit down on the horn lol. · TR. Did it on TR, high of 55 and clear. Corner was a bit wet. On first mini roof, use left hand, stay right, move left leg over then move up. Lieback the next crack. On bottomless corner, get small crack above the first before moving up. Stem up carefully, then move across and swing left foot around and campus for top. · Lead / Redpoint. Hell yeah! So good!! 2nd go, with preplaced draws and long runners was v nice. With Justin’s rack and draws. Pink pointed first go w one take at roof pull cuz we got the rope stuck, sent second go. Honestly feels on or soft for 11d · Lead / Fell/Hung. .2, .4, .3, .5 (totem), bolt w long sling v nice, 1, 4, .5, .2, .3, bolt, bolt, small nut optional, .2 extended, old bolt, bolt long sling v nice, bolt, bolt anchor · TR. Okay I tried the left exit a few years ago and thought it was ridiculous, right exit is not bad, I should try this more · Lead. TR’d up to before the layback on the gear of a good friend to clean it so he could give it another proper redpoint burn. I took it to the chains after that, such a classic climb omg. He came down because some annoying LA fucker was spraying about absolute nonsense and polluting his mental space and fucking w his psyche. LA dude was aiding Godzilla slow AF w a mega rack n Astro nuts n beaks. Bottom stepping nonstop and placing n leaving pieces every2 feet. · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Clean tr burn again and then an RP. Let’s go · Lead / Redpoint. Such a awesome route put runner on black totem in the cabin will help with drag next time. exited right. Climbed with Brandon 1st time climbing with him and hopefully won’t be the last. Cabin fever is real! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Wow this rig is awesome! Climbed with Simon. Right is easier then left out the cabin. Bring 1 2 double black totem to purple. Single .75 and 1 and bring gold offset 8 draws 4 alpines · TR. Took a bonus lap and went right it was very hard feeling or I was really tired · TR. This thing feels rowdy the bottom of it's okay but as soon as you get into the corner it is just something else. · TR. 80 m rope needed, top rope to the upper roof without directionals. Cracks is climbing out through the top roof. · TR. One of the best pitches I have ever done. Worth getting an 80m for · TR. A couple falls at the exit. Hard! Rope stuck epic saved by Ben and carthik. Thank gawd. · TR. Many hangs trying to exit the corner. Fell at lower crux too and hung a few times from pumping out · Lead / Fell/Hung. K getting to the bolt ain’t bad with a purp and a gold offset. corner: get blue or black totem and extend it. Grab the left arete and stem, there’s a thumb catch for first hold. 7 bolts total, bring lotsa draws 10 not enough · Lead / Redpoint. A couple topropes and one lead go. Amazing. It doesn’t get much better than this. Black totem then some finger sizes get you to the bolt, #2, blue totem with bomber nut above, yellow metolius after transitioning to the hand jam. Bolts. · Do I recommend climbing this 8 months pregnant? No. Did I climb this 8 months pregnant? Heck yes. · Lead / Redpoint. Tr on both exits then lead it doing the right exit, so fun, the right exit is unbelievably good, the layback felt harder in the sun but it didn’t matter since there’s a sit down rest before the ending anyway · Lead / Redpoint. 1st headpoint go, natty light cabana baybeeee. Didn’t think it was possible for me. Was so insanely close to giving up before I happened across the most impossible-seeming beta to get into the top layback. Craziest climbing realization. · Lead / Redpoint. HP - one of the best send trains I'll likely ever get to experience, with good people · TR. With Jonah Matt Cassie Myles - Flash! Let out a full 1.5-second yell when I latched the post-roof jug · 4 pitches. TR. Tr solo to suss out the runout start and gear. Yellow totems are good in a lot of places. Before first bolt, at least 2 yellow totems is good. Maybe a .5 or .75 for last piece before bolt. First bolt grab pinch, lf put on good thing, reach for lh crimp, rf on pinch, stem, maybe some extra hand moves somewhere. Black totem is good between bolts in top corner. Mid corner at totem spot, good rest lf left wall left knee right wall, rf on right wall. Exit corner: clip left bolt, right foot big stem to good pocket. Rh sloper pinch on arete, move lf right, rf smear, lf smear, lh crimp, match rh, lh layback rail. Work rf up onto the crimp you matched on. Then go fast · TR. Crazy features. Good gear before bolt, clipping is committing (R crimp, small feet). Cruxy shifting into lieback and placing gear (flared; move till juggy left flake, place .3) Exiting dihedral - smeary feet, shift w LF heel, slopey to jugs around and up · Lead / Fell/Hung. The climbing to the first bolt is protectable and PG-13. Didn’t feel sandbagged at all. Spoiler: If taking the right exit, you climb the arete. Don’t do like me and try to exit right from the top of the stem box. · TR. Strenuous layback section in the sun was very difficult. Layback move past the bolt. · Lead / Onsight. Likely my favorite single pitch to date. Had an epic cleaning this thing... took what felt like 30+ minutes to retrieve my red C3 between bolts, rapped passed my stashed gear before the corner, climbed to gear and tried to lower but rope got stuck. · TR. holy shit. epic. topdawged the heck out of this rig up to the roof then gave up. so good. · Lead / Redpoint. Found good gear below the first bolt. Almost puked once reaching the anchor!

routes.route_description: traverse 3 bolts from the base anchors of Kunselman's Physics to the hanging belay start.climb the detached flake, clipping bolts to the bombay chimney above.  Pull jugs through a wildly exposed roof to easier climbing above.
routes.route_location: Climb Free at Last to reach the start.  The pitch tops out on St. Francis Ledge.
routes.route_protection: gear to 3"

route_comments.comment_text: This climb is awesome. The only downside was a couple hollow sounding flakes at the start a d a loose looking chockstone. However with a little cleaning this route would be insane. For those who have the Kalman/Van Beiene guidebook, this route is mislabeled in the topos. It's actually #84 on their maps - coming straight down the right side from the top of St Francis ledge. The crux to me... more This climb is awesome. The only downside was a couple hollow sounding flakes at the start a d a loose looking chockstone. However with a little cleaning this route would be insane. For those who have the Kalman/Van Beiene guidebook, this route is mislabeled in the topos. It's actually #84 on their maps - coming straight down the right side from the top of St Francis ledge. The crux to me felt more like 10+ than 5.9 but it was dirty a d wet when I climbed it. Either way, great climb. Get on it. May 23, 2024

I don’t understand this route at all. I made an attempt at it and didn’t realize at first that you had to aid climb across the bolts. Then once I barely reached/got across the bolts, I felt like the stem chimney was dangerous and loose, and needed another bolt, so I bailed after a few bolts. Oct 10, 2024

routes.route_description: Start where Higher Learning ends. Begin with an awkward mantle to a ramp (10b, two bolts), then traverse right on a handcrack below the headwall and go up to a ledge. Go around right for easier climbing to the top.See topo and overview in the images for Higher Learning.
routes.route_location: Starts near the Narrow Arrow summit. To get to the base, one needs to do either Higher Learning or part of the last pitch of Tatoosh.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 1", 3 bolts.

routes.route_description: Shares the same start as Apologies, but continues straight up the overhanging offwidth. Though it looks intimidating, there is an edge inside, allowing one to layback instead of using offwidth methods.From the Carlstad & Brooks (1976) guidebook: "5.9 or 5.10...The difficulty depends on the manner in which the off size is done."
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Double rack 0.3-3.There are no chains or bolts at the top; you'll have to build your own anchor to top rope and rappel down Like Honey/With Apologies to Walter B.

route_comments.comment_text: This is a really good climb, ignored by most for the dirty start? Sep 9, 2014
Maybe people are put off by its supposed offwidthness? At least you don't need any huge gear.. Up to #3 is sufficient. Sep 10, 2014
Fun climb that should get more traffic. fun moves through the lower roof, and then a great handcrack/lieback through the 'wide' section. Sep 13, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Also prussiked up the rope to get it unstuck. It got pinched between the flat part of the lobe on a #2 cam and the rock on the second bulge. · TR. Really fun climb. Would get 4 stars if not for the bushy start. No need for wide gear, #2 hand crack next to the wide section · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung at the first thin hand crack. Very good hold (edge/jug) is high, but reachable. · Lead / Onsight. Grunting up that off width per usual, me and Dylan both ran out the last bit a little. · Lead / Onsight. Burly at the top and my hand got stuck but totally classic. · Lead / Flash. didn't do any offwidth climbing. could be fun to try again as an offwidth · Lead / Onsight. Fun route. Cool roofs, cool wide bit, cool hand crack (EM) · Lead / Onsight. Fun route. Dirty down low. overhang hand crack to jug then mantel, X3. · Lead / Fell/Hung. a super fun line I dont know why people say its dirty. fun over hang pulls with perfect hands thin hand crack is a touch tricky but found away around it. · Lead. Grest route that seems to be rarely climbed. The hand cracks through the roofs down low were excellent, and the OW with thinner cracks up high was really fun to figure out!

routes.route_fa: FFA: Tom Ramier, Tom Coe '05 Previous aid ascents: ???
routes.route_description: Above Natural Log Cabin/Deal with it Ranger is this arching corner. Begin via ledgy climbing (some loose blocks exist) and an easy chimney with a pin to the base of a thin groove reminiscent of initial Slow Children corner (but with a much thinner crack). Climb the groove using some small nuts and a pin and transfer into the upper corner (.11). Physical flared crack climbing with surprisingly good gear leads past a bolt (.11). Clip a flimsy looking pin and pull the roof with some trickery (.10+). Stop at the anchor here or continue past 3 or 4 bolts on the arete (.10) to another anchor at the very top of the Narrow Arrow.
routes.route_location: The easiest way to approach this pitch is via Godzilla P1 and second pitch of Godzilla/The Cidiot (5.9, 5.10). The Cidiot continues to the right while the (overgrown) second pitch of Godzilla continues straight above. Some inconvenient downclimbing is involved (watch out for loose blocks). Alternate approaches are via Natural Log Cabin/Deal with it Ranger (fairly direct but may involve 20 feet of 5.10- runout), Narrow Arrow Overhang, or from the upper anchors on Narrow Arrow Direct via rappel.60m or 70m ropes are needed to rappel.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3 inches with extra small nuts and cams. One bolt on the first section; 3 or 4 on the arete. Fixed anchors for both options.This corner may have been aided in the past; this entry is for the FFA.

route_comments.comment_text: There are 4 bolts on this pitch. Two after the chimney section and two at the top of the flare before the roof. They are basically in the same places as the old pitons. Jun 22, 2018
An excellent pitch that likely see less traffic than it should. I remember thin wires and compact rock at the crux before the flare. Engaging. Dec 23, 2022

routes.route_fa: FFA: Greg Olsen, Dick Cilley, Jon Nelson
routes.route_description: A classic pitch with a somewhat feared reputation.  Fear not though as the gear is good and the climbing soft for the grade.  Starts on juggy holds and liebacks left of thin fingers before tackling the meat of the climb, a stemming section with few to no small hand holds.There is a second 10d pitch above that will put you at the base of Death to Zeke, that I haven't done.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: standard rack

route_comments.comment_text: Named after Dick Cilley's mother. Dec 31, 2008
I was glad to have an orange Metolius TCU before starting up the crux stemming section. Jan 30, 2014
Some small offset nuts would be really nice at the crux. The gear there gets very thin and tricky which can be a bit of a surprise if you don't know what you're getting into. Aug 17, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Yes if you walk past thin fingers you will get to a via Ferrata- which gets you to the anchors of thin fingers. If you rap from there (L side while in Rappel) you can sort of climb towards the anchor. If doing this extend belay device and use hollow block (your other prusik was too long) a piece of gear in crux of thin fingers (.75) could help you traverse and gain the handhold (.5 or .4). The actual climb is really fun, crux is at the top for sure, I fell both times but then got it each time. I think i could get the movement dialed down, would be curious to try again and assess gear placements. Also notably, two anchors directly to the left from here. What are they above? TR? · TR. Not to hard until final stem plan on placing a couple smaller cams and firing to top. Best stemmed direct with left foot going high first when it gets really hard. And don’t forget to not be a pussy. · TR. TR with Andrew after lead burn. Got it clean pretty easily haha. It’s all in the head. Just keep stemming slowly and surely. Trusting the feet. It’s even kind of restful just really insecure feeling but trust the sticky rubber and you will send! Leaning far right and palming right hand far right and left hand leaning on the arete in your face to get high left foot. Right foot along the bottoms edge of the seem. Slowly but SURELY. it will go. · Lead. Semi-blind blue/yellow metolius to sew up the crux. Standard rack tips to twos. · TR. Bring a 3 to place before roof. At the undercling roof and good stance, place a blue totem in top of left crack AND a .1 a few feet higher. You need the bottom of the blue totem crack for your left foot. Run it out to the last jug hold. There’s a good .2 placement at the left hand pinky jam, but cannot find a good stance. Wide wide stemming works best. Don’t forget decent rh crimp just before the end of the crux · Lead / Redpoint. First time back on this route this season, felt desperate but I just kept stemming and somehow got through the top crux. Might be my proudest red point this summer! · Per hard climber, can set up TR on this from thing fingers. Other TR on this wall from Warren B, maybe a cia Ferrata? Walk past thing fingers hike up and eventually take a left to go up above…? · Lead / Redpoint. Wrong date. Finally got clean after far more attempts than expected. .2 protects the crux much better than purple metolius. Black totem does not fit · Lead / Redpoint. Felt dialed! With Simon Connor and Jonathan skipped the last black totem placement · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Second go of the day, broke my red dragonfly on my first RIP. Two purple metoliouses put it down the next time around though · 2 pitches. TR. Struggle bus - couldn't do crux stem moves. Narrow stem traps, wide stem too wide. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bring a 3 for just before Crux sequence. Crux gear: black totem, then lots of small gear: .1, 0, etc. try a .5 in flaring thing? Another black totem on far left after crux? Red ball nut? Nuts not great · TR. Got a TR set up and managed to place gear clean on TR solo will have to lead when I can get a catch · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped big on a purple metolius, coming back for the redpoint · Lead / Fell/Hung. Wow whipped a good bit at the crux yellow alien at the crux and smaller · TR. About 2-3 moves away. Can’t figure out how to get left foot above roof · Lead / Fell/Hung. Was the strongest climber in all of index before the crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. took the whip on a real onsight attempt. doubles to 1 with nuts was good. liberally placing 1 / .75 since there are not so many useful placements for them. Blue totem and largest offset brassie are very good back up gear for crux. High purple metolius (.2 better? black totem does not fit) protects the actual moves. Beta: bump feet up for high right hand lock (not great). Bump left foot into crack to get right foot onto ledge. Left foot onto next bump and then stand up tall for right hand lock. Chimney / shuffle here until reaching crimp out right. Maybe another placement here before topping out, but I'm not sure. · Lead / Redpoint. Finally sent it this time! Third time's the charm. w/ Marius · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard right after the little roof in the stem. Really get that right palm press and right foot out. Move weight back and forth to bump feet and hand · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. one fall, same spot as last time-ish. + 1 TR lap. · Lead / Fell/Hung. slipped! rad, whole body pump. fiddly and not %1000 gear. but it hold. · TR. crux is really hard, didn't have enough hip flexibility and had to get a power belay for a couple moves. Great route though, no falls till stem crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. w/giacomo+roman. only one fall! ballnuts were clutch, placed red & gold ahead of crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped onto my brass nuts. Gotta have more juice in the calves to get through stem · TR. Clean 1st try, fell at crux on 2nd lap, took short break and got it clean again on 3rd lap · Lead / Redpoint. With Mallorie. 5 TR laps, 3rd lead go. Climbing through the crux when the train was passing made for the quintessential Index experience. · TR. fun and chill until crux. good gear to be had in left crack, stem lots · 2 pitches. TR. With Brandon. Mock led x 2, 1 hang 1st go, clean 2nd go. · Lead / Redpoint. Black x2 Blue x2 Yellow x2 Purple x2 Green Red RP Draws x9 · Lead / Redpoint. Stiff shoes help. Happy to not slip off the top! 5.11 mileage day: Apologies to Shirley and her Natural Dik Garden. · Lead / Redpoint. day flash two years later. glad I didn't take the big whip. placed a .1 and a peanut (mega bomber gear below them too), then yellow totem (pretty bomber) at the bulge and a grey metolious for good measure(pretty decent) and then ran to the chains. just keep climbing · TR. First part, I thought I could lead, then got to stem and say nevermind! I will get better at stem · Lead / Redpoint. With Matt - w/ helium birthday balloon assist [BH: orange trango lobes, next morning] · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Matt - so much fun, cleanly whipped on blue offnut and lil purp BD [BH recon] · TR. with Aaron. did all the moves! keep wide stem..press with left at crux to move left foot over bulge. moved rope over from thin fingers · Lead / Redpoint. Crux crack takes microcams well (#0 or .1 Z4, purple/grey Metolius). Do yourself a favor and leave the ballnuts at home. · TR. with Adam Jackie and James. stemming and pressing. good did all the moves · TR. Slipped at the crux, which the crux is very strenuous. I can't imagine having to lead this and place gear · Lead / Fell/Hung. Aw man the ol one hang! So so fun. Better gear than expected · TR. Really fun!!! Super tricky dihedral moves near the top rest was pretty chill · TR. my first ever top rope solo. hard friction stemming section at the end · Lead / Redpoint. Fiddled way too much with gear - just go for it · Lead / Fell/Hung. On that purple C3 at the crux. Only one fall though · Lead / Redpoint. Takes a perfect brassy and offset right below the crux. routes.route_description: This route adds an easier start and a hard variation finish to the classic pitch "Shirley" at the LTW.First clip a bolt and climb up into the corner system right of Shirley.  When that corner ends place a thin piece or two and step left to rejoin Shirley.  This start is approximately 10+.Next climb Shirley into the hand-jam pod below the crux stemming on that route.  Reach left and clip a bolt out on the arete, then down-climb until both hands are on the jug flake on the left side of the Shirley pillar.  From here, climb up and left into the oblique dihedral past two more bolts, encountering two distinct boulder problems on the way to the NAD ledge.I found this route to be a bit harder than its neighbor, Narrow Arrow Direct, but not as hard as the Narrow Arrow Overhang.  While the crux section is short the climbing is powerful and sustained with good movement and the rig makes a nice addition to the hard climbing at the wall.
routes.route_location: Start in the corner system right of Shirley, finish on the NAD ledge.
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts plus gear for Shirley.  2-bolt anchor with chain on top.

route_comments.comment_text: pretty hard crux off of a tiny crimp. it’s def possible to do this route without downclimbing back to the flake thing. just clip the bolt and head left with foot on the flake. Sep 25, 2021
I couldn't figure this one out the only time I TR'd on it a few years ago.  Have 5' folks sent it? Dec 23, 2022

Ben, I'm 5'6" and the crux moves had me pretty stretched out. Mike Patz tried it several times before he left town and also had some difficulty with the crux. I did watch Nathan Hadley and Brittany Goris hike the moves though. Probably a bit harder the shorter you are. Jan 4, 2023

routes.route_description: Good gear the whole way, bring a good sized rack with a full set of stoppers and doubles in the finger sized pieces. Lots of finger-locking up corners. Finishes on steep holds just above a recently cut stump. Great climb!update:7/31/2011- The stump has been removed thanks to the valiant efforts of Chris Henson. This route used to be called Free at Last, now it's just Tatoosh. If instead of going up the dihedral, you break right half way up and head up the offwidth, it links into P2 of the original Tatoosh route(4 pitches long, goes all way the to the top of the wall). There's fun climbing on the original Tatoosh, really fun actually. I tried to clean it up a few years ago, but it was a FUNNEL of debris. I dug out the cracks on the upper pitches and loosed tons of blocks, but I imagine the 5.2 section getting to them is still packed with dirt.
routes.route_location: Starts 3 feet right of Thin Fingers on the recently brushed dihedral.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack up to 2" inches, doubles in finger sized gear.

route_comments.comment_text: You need a 70m rope to rap/lower/TR this one. You can swing over to intermediate anchors on Thin fingers to get back to the ground if you only have a 60m. Dec 21, 2008
Although this route may have been 10b before it was cleaned; with the bolt and the removal of the stump/major cleaning it feels like the easiest 10 at index... Apr 19, 2009

The description and name of this route seem to agree with Darryl Cramer's Sky Valley Rock, although it is now nice and clean. stanford.edu/~clint/index/l… This route seems to be what the Cummins Guide calls "Free at Last, 5.10b R". Either way, a fun route! more The description and name of this route seem to agree with Darryl Cramer's Sky Valley Rock, although it is now nice and clean. stanford.edu/~clint/index/l… This route seems to be what the Cummins Guide calls "Free at Last, 5.10b R". Either way, a fun route! Jul 17, 2009

Good ring lock in the .75 crack before the finish, and great hand jam right above anchor · Lead / Onsight. Superb climbing. Varied, mostly fingers. Good rests, series of short fun cruxes. · Lead / Fell/Hung. took on the upper crux section to manage pump. few things i did better: -instead of laybacking the start, crack climb it to good crimps - upper section has really good stemming rest, and the jug is trustable. with those two rests the upper section is actually pretty straightforward if you go out and left to hand holds— my first fall i believe i tried to stay right · Follow. Post rain in the morning, felt a bit slick even though dry. Humid out. · Lead / Redpoint. Brought trips of .2 and .3, doubles of .4-1, one 2. Three double slings, three singles, a couple of draws. Didn’t use nuts. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Felt hard! Chimney section too thin, lean right to get to bigger section. Save a single rack 0.3-0.6 for the top. Leave the 2s on the ground. · Lead / Redpoint. Upper part walk feet up flake on right before bumping to high left hand jug. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Led and did a second lap on TR. Used trips of .2s, .3s, doubles of .5, .75, one .4, 1, 2 and gold offset. · Lead / Onsight. Felt slightly harder than Thin Fingers the way I did it · Lead / Onsight. Stick clipped the first bolt. Nice climbing but a little nervous with placing gear through the thinner areas · Lead / Fell/Hung. Climbed with Kat. Fell to the first bolt sent the rest of the pitch. Excited to get to come back this route is so fun! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Been wanting to climb this for ages. Fell halfway up on top finger crack. Stick clip for bottom bolt was nice to have, avoided a blind/shallow gear placement at start · Follow. Got shut down at the bolt at the start. Felt so hard. Pumpy bro fest, not particularly interesting or inspiring. Some cool finger moves · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once at top after lieback. Pumped. Fun. Fingers corners. Chimney and stemming moves too. Some ledgeds along the way. Heavy on .2 to .5. Felt fun to be near my max and take a fall. Though I sort of gave up after having the thoguht that I wouldnt have the strength to finish. · TR. Send! Fallon put it up, she thought it was hard and long for 10a. · Lead. popped out of the corner at the start and grunted my way up the rest. easier than it looks from the ground but not exactly great for first climb out of the car · Lead / Redpoint. first 10 in index lets goooo!! couldn’t remember shit from my TR last summer, did in full sun feeling like shit and anxious as hell about all the things going on in life. routes.route_description: This great long pitch begins with easier climbing and a smeary corner.  You can get a full-on no-hands rest at the first set of anchors, but don't stop there, the best is yet to come.  Go straight up the seam (crux) to a good hand crack and more superb liebacking.  Most people skip the crux by going right at the first set of anchors, making it not as good at about 5.10.  Warning, a 70 meter rope is needed to reach the ground on this one.
routes.route_location: Far right side of the lower wall, the splitter upper crack is easily seen from below.
routes.route_protection: Fixed clips are at the anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: This is a great climb that requires a nice variety of techniques.  If I recall, you might want to bring some small gear for the crux moving up off the first belay. Mar 30, 2006

A cool variation called Big Toes (5.11) traverses right at the upper roof to another thin crack about 10 feet to the right of the regular route.  Rejoin thin fingers about 10 feet below the anchor. Oct 24, 2006

This one really should be called "thin hands".  The splitter upper crack is primarily  #1 camalots.  I'd bring at least three #1 camalots next time - I only had two and had to back clean. A good rack would be doubles thin to #2 camalots, with some extra #1 and #0.75 camalots.   Small nuts are useful as well. The 11a crux is hard and balancy.  I cheated.  I'm blaming the ... err..... more This one really should be called "thin hands".  The splitter upper crack is primarily  #1 camalots.  I'd bring at least three #1 camalots next time - I only had two and had to back clean. A good rack would be doubles thin to #2 camalots, with some extra #1 and #0.75 camalots.   Small nuts are useful as well. The 11a crux is hard and balancy.  I cheated.  I'm blaming the ... err.. humidity.  The upper crack is sweetness and worth the cheat. 70m gets you down perfectly. routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the top lieback crack. Too pumped to commit up · TR. Fell on the slab crux 4 times and once transitioning into the layback after, amazing full value pitch · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell once on seam move and once on layback bc of pump / gas. exhausting though, took a long time in general. · TR. And during that part.. soooooo pumped.. only got to the top by bribing myself with a Zekes milkshake. Great climb · TR. My short person beta for the slab crux: right hand get 2 fingers (half pads?) on the little side crimp. Left foot on lower crimp. Jump up to get high enough to desperately get fingers into the crack. Right foot up to nipple crimp. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Another classic index trickiness. Superb hand crack up there but the cruxes above ledges didn't inspire much confidence in me. Took several times. · TR. Super cool pitch. At weird thing crack, go right, left foot out wide to knub, left hand on crimp edge, pull around into left foot matching right hand. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on top of lower pitch again tricky slab move off yellow totem For crux place small bras nut. found a way to step from right onto big foot using left crimp and then up right hand to sloper. Once positioned can reach edges. Didn’t pull it clean but lighter and more fit could. · Lead. Practice Letty’s slab beta next time- use further right side pull (?) hold, left foot to slab edge · TR. Tried far left of slab don’t think it goes. Couldn’t get feet to stick going straight up. Almost lost tension lay backing in from the right, get that tight. P.86 rock warriors way · Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided through the crux, & fell once in the lower crux because of slipping on sand. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell twice on slab. Once on layback. Another take up high. · Lead / Fell/Hung. really amazing climbing throughout with a typical one move wonder index trickery slab crux. bailed right and still couldn’t free the slab. fought hard in the upper half to such an exciting finish! · TR. Managed to pull off the slab crux on Tr! High rf to good foot. Bump rh up arete and lh up thin crack to balance. Stand and reach for rh crimp · TR. Fell once at the lie back. Beta for crux: Left hand low crimp on face, right hand around arete, left foot low crimp. Move right foot up to higher low crimp, move left foot up to big crimp on right side of face, left fingers in teeny tiny crack and move up · Follow. 11/10 maybe best pitch of climbing ive ever touched?? cruxes for me were the bouldery seam section, pulling the overhang into handcrack, and managing fatigue through the handcrack and upper layback crux · Lead / Redpoint. Did the slab crux today yay!! TC Pros ftw. Such a good pitch, the hand crack is so sick! · TR. For the crux: right hand arete and thumb catch. Left hand on small sidepull down and left of anchor. Step up right foot. Tension, move up left foot to chip. Trust your feet. Stand up, move left hand into crack, and move right foot up to better spot. Stand on that and get your hands in the crack. Crank bad finger locks, and reach for the jug. · Lead. Evening send w ruthtruck. Almost slipped off down low hehe. Rh undercling, lh on some bullshit, lf low, rf high, lf match nearby, stand tall to some holds. Foot sequence might be reversed. · Lead / Onsight. Slab/seam crux took a few attempts to figure out, but easy to step back down to the ledge without weighting the rope. Doubles to #2, plus nuts was plenty. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Does it still count as a fall if you just drop back down to the ledge and your belayer doesn’t catch you? Got some beta for the crux and took 2-3 tries to work it out. Everything else was onsight · Lead / Fell/Hung. Gahhh so good! Felt way stronger on lead than the first try. I climbed through the 5.9 slab and felt very good.
