Aided through 11a slab and into the 10a crack, the crack felt great compared to last season. But I need to rest in it more. Good rest stance before the lie back. The lie back continues to feel hard and strenuous, though the bottom felt better than last year. There are also small feet on the left, and also could consider keeping right hip in and smearing right foot outside of the crack. Stopped right before topping out on the lie back, came down after falling. Clean fall. Wanna try to just climb through it next time. The bottom finger crack protects with two .3 totems, then yellow TCU, then a gold RPM (not sure which size?), then .3 BD and then .4 totem. Might add a few extra items onto future rack in case I’m missing something. The 5.9 slab protects with two ball nuts (bomber). The 5.11a protects with a gray TCU but I might need to place more pro before that, maybe RPM. I think to climb it clean id have to get the slab (going out to climbers right and back into the crack is too scary of a fall). But getting the 5.11 slab is hard, bring a brush like a dooche bag and try to clean the feet next time. Also getting into the crack from the position feels really hard (protects with .5 and .75). The 5.10a hands protects with 1s and 2s. The lieback protects with a 1 BD and a .75 BD (x2). The very top might take a 3 BD. Need to work the slab and the lie back. Suchhhh an amazing and varied climb. Also for pro- might consider small stuff pre-hung with alpine draws on the front two loops with bigger stuff in back, can re-arrange after 5.9 slab and bring bigger pro to the front. · TR. Climbed with Aaron - figured out the slab section and feels repeatable - ready to lead this bad boy! · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 hang on first lead attempt! Gear: .1, black totem+blue metolius, 3x .3-.75, 2x #1, 1-2x #2. P1: .3, nut or .5, nut, .4 near good lock. Ledge: .3+ yellow dmm offset, black totem couple moves up. R hand reachy lock, L hand pinky down to place black totem. Get L hand to diagonal hold, work feet, R hand cross to slopey hold, R foot in corner and stand up. P2: .1, L foot up slab working into second R hand side pull. Kick R foot into wall, reach up to good left hold. Stand up and reach to place .4. Big move from R hand on upper crimp with R foot on small slopey chip out right, reach L hand pinky down great lock. Place .75 in main crack or .3 ish in R crack. Get to good jam and place #1. Bump #2 or place 2 in the hand crack. Rest. #1, then .75 before good feet run out. Lieback out till L foot chip out left, convert R hand to rattly thumbs down lock, L foot toe jam in flake, then up to jug. Place .4, endure one more sequence. Rest, place blue metolius, up to ledge, then high .75 and finish. · TR. Decent down low to first ledge, use finger jams to next step, couldn't figure out slab Crux, layback to hand jams, more lay back and crimps up high · TR. first crux is finger section 30ft up, good feet just left of the crack. don’t go too high when bypassing the crux (don’t go into ledge), after hand crack, mostly a lie back at 0.5/0.75 size. · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Onsight first half of p1 to middle anchors !!! Then TRed again for fun · Lead / Fell/Hung. Slab took four attempts, even with pointy shoes. Bring brush next time · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to pull on ball nut to set feet on high left foot · Lead. I sent? maybe? had a false start on the slab move and slid down onto my rope but also just sort of stepped down. climbing is stupid. this route is awesome and so fun and not really that hard and I will come back and do it again · TR. Couldn’t pull the 11a slab moves. Had to move out right and back left · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Erik and Ryan. Fell at the crux a bunch, but finally figured it out! · TR. TRS. Bottom felt good. Had to ascend through slab. Got it clean on tr yesterday. Trs tension made it harder? Biggest question mark remaining for sure. Upper is just endurance. Roger strong says #3 stopper protects crux · TR. Clean! Slab via the right. Leading still seems wild work the gear see how it feels. · TR. With Bridget and Aaron. On TR it felt similar in grade to Tatoosh. But on lead it’d be a lot harder bc of the second section that’s hard to protect above a ledge. One hung at the top before the anchor. One of the best trad 11’s I’ve gotten on · Lead / Flash. Super fun route with lots on thin moves down low and jams up high. Gear: Small nuts, 3 black totem, 2 blue totem, 0.4, 3x 0.5, 0.75, 3x 1, 2 · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very varied. Wanted my sport shoes over my trad shoes for this crux. · TR. Crux is hard, don't feel like I really figured it out. Ended up going to the big edge around the corner and then balancing my way back on-route, but it felt suspect · Lead / Fell/Hung. Feel twice at the lower half, popped a piece right before the crux. Don't climb if it looks wet · Lead / Redpoint. +2 back to back TR laps. W/ Kaz and Emma partially after dark. · TR. Followed David's gear up. The bottom part was engaging, but I stayed on! The crux above the first chains is really tricky and hard! I tried it several times but eventually resorted to tugging on the draw and stepping on the bolt. The rest of it was awesome!! Remember: once the #1 narrows to #.75, better to layback than jam. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got to above the slab crux then fell, bailed from there after losing my head :(. Save a .2 for the top of the crux, spent wayyyy too long trying to get pro in there and pumped out after getting a solid .5 above. · TR. So hard. The lie back! There is a good finger lock with the right hand after the crux to get to the standing position. The 5.9 slab, do-able, but not a lot of pro. Wondering about a ball nut as a second piece. And also transitioning into the crack if you don’t go up the slab, might feel scary on lead. Could I just stick in a .75 blindly before getting in the crack? I think I could get those moves if I rehearsed it. So sustained and pumpy. Tried the slab, I almost was having more luck out left but then it thins out. There is an undercling on the right arete with a foot to stand up on but this go I wasn’t able to reach the crack. Higher foot? Bump up the hand? Some pro I placed on TR RP Gold nut .3 black totems x2 .4 yellow totem x1 .75 green BD x3 2 yellow BD x 3 1 red BD x1 .5 purple · TR. Got pumped out at the bulge and fell. Had to take the.10a variation to slab hell. · TR. fell many many times. needed to rest more between sections. did 10a variation · Lead. First p at index, wet and only to the first anchor. Great rock · TR. Micah led then TR’d after him. Low crux was hard layback, then next crux was slabby super thin crack. Figured it out but fell trying to figure out how to get into the hand crack. Hand crack was amazing. Then pumped out at upper layback crack. Need to work on the feet through this section to make it less strenuous. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Felt way better than I expected it to. Beautiful movement. The lie back is strenuous to move through with gear- get a couple of ..75/ .5 totems to just plug and chug on the way up? Climbed around the slab for today but would like to work it. Hand crack is soooo good · TR. TRedpoint. Didn’t cheat far out right this time. Should definitely lead it next time

routes.route_name: Voyage of the Majestic Glass-eyed Tuna
routes.route_description: From the Narrow Arrow summit area, go partway up Tatoosh, then exit right onto a ledge. Go right on the ledge to an obvious corner (10b) left of the headwall. Another bolt protects the moves to the top, the highest point on the Lower Wall.For other details, see the beta images for "Higher Learning".
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3.5", one bolt.

route_comments.comment_text: What's with the Tuna theme at Index? Is there some history here? Missing the boat. In the Cummins book the crack is called the A2 variation of Tatoosh. How did a A2 crack become 10b? Feb 11, 2014

About the tuna, do you mean this one and Dr Sniff? I don't know if the similarity is a coincidence or not. I had nothing to do with either name. Bobcats, on the other hand, is definitely an Index theme... Feb 11, 2014
I was wondering about the bobcats as well. It was fun seeing the history behind the Strange Boar and associated friends. May 28, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. amazing! below at the tree below for an easier start - if belaying at the anchor, it's a cruxy face climbing / crack climbing to enter the slot · Sketch going right in at first bolt. Try goin left by tree the. Return to second bolt

routes.route_description: A beautiful route on great rock with a well-protected face crux followed by a perfect splitter 10+ finger lieback to thin hands crack.  Not to be missed, especially because the scary old 1/4" bolt protecting the face crux was recently replaced with a bomber Petzl bolt courtesy of the Washington Climbers Coalition during the annual Index cleanup they sponsor.Now that the entrance to this route is protected by a good bolt, this thing should become a popular alternative to Thin Fingers and other similar routes in the area.
routes.route_location: Uphill to the right from Thin Fingers about 40 feet.  Follow the nicely maintained trail (again, thanks WCC volunteers) to a ledge below a blocky chimney (DO NOT CLIMB THIS CHIMNEY!). Traverse left from the ledge, reach out and clip the bolt, and it's on.
routes.route_protection: Gear to #2 Camalot and a handful of draws

route_comments.comment_text: I'd like to thank whoever placed those two bomber sport snap anchors up there. Not only are they shiny and new, but they make it simple to clip the rope in and rap off. The lieback is strenuous and fun. Aug 9, 2009

It's also possible to approach the traverse more directly from below now, which is still kind of dirty, but reasonably enjoyable climbing.  It probably adds about 30' to the route which makes it a bit fuller value.  Not quite up to the quality of the rest of the LTW routes, although it may clean up in time. Oct 9, 2012

Nice route that deserves a lot more traffic.  The easiest Lower Wall 1st  pitch that you haven't already done?  3 very distinct sections: grotty old-school 5.9, crazy-fun 11- bolted crux, then textbook off-fingers 5.10 laybacking to better jams near the top.  Very safe, but pay attention to the the way your rope runs on the edge as you pucker up and commit to the final dihedral. We used a... more Nice route that deserves a lot more traffic.  The easiest Lower Wall 1st  pitch that you haven't already done?  3 very distinct sections: grotty old-school 5.9, crazy-fun 11- bolted crux, then textbook off-fingers 5.10 laybacking to better jams near the top.  Very safe, but pay attention to the the way your rope runs on the edge as you pucker up and commit to the final dihedral. We used a single 70m but had a fair bit of rope left over. A single 60m would probably work as well. Jan 22, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Fun! Face crux protects very well, layback is strenuous but has a couple good foot chips to place gear from. Lead next time · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once at crux. Top lie back crack kicked my butt though. Was struggling to commit and got pumped out multiple times. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Layback was fun with Hasib. Didn’t have confidence. Saw someone else go straight in - interesting! · Lead / Fell/Hung. W Andrew. Was being scaredy pants and pulled on .75 because I was getting pumped and didn’t want to whip. Didn’t have the ideal rack either. Next time: double #1-3 for bottom half, extending every piece fully. Save 1 .5 and all the .75s for the top crack, and maybe a hand piece. AND RUN THROUGH THE CRUX SO YOU DONT GET PUMPED. not hard. Good hand crack higher up. Just send it. · TR. Fell at the face crux a few times. Just gotta commit to the jug. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell trying to place after the crux. You can jam the layback, it’s mostly .75. Bring 3x.5-.75 · Lead / Onsight. Last pitch with Aaron. Nearly pumped out of the crack. I was psyched after. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 0.5 with dl sling, 1 sling, blue sl, 0.5/0.75, 3, bolt, 0.4/0.5, 0.5, 0.75, 1, 2. Next time try crossing hands over at crux with right hand furthest left crimp?. Grab crimp with left thumb (Gaston with slight underlying) Need to move r foot before going for sloper jug · Lead / Flash. Great route! A bit soft for the grade, the traverse is quite powerful, but the upper crack was pumpier (laybacked). · Lead / Fell/Hung. 0.75, 1, 3, 0.5 (could do p/g offset or 0.4 instead), 3, bolt. For crack, 0.5 x 2, 0.75, red, yellow. Slings on everything up to traverse. so: 0.4, 0.5x2, 0.75x2, 1x2, 2x2,3x2, 0.4/0.5, 0.5/0.75. · TR. One fall on TR bc I tried to jam the upper crack instead of laybacking. Feels like it would be doable on lead, I'm tall enough that the traverse isn't too bad. Upper layback is definitely the scary part, but I think doable if I can get away with no gear between the ledge and the hand pod. · TR. crux traverse is hard. layback isn't too dramatic. down low is cool. potential project? · Lead / Redpoint. Had to style it again on 1st index day of the year · Lead / Fell/Hung. Broke a hold near the start and fell but other than that pretty good go. Just need to gun it on the lay back · Follow. Holy heck the last 25 feet are pumpy!! ew liebacking. Bolt section traverse is fun! Just a bit reachy but not bad if you know where youre going. · Lead / Redpoint. First try of the day. Almost messed up the traverse which has never happened before - tough piano match saved the day. Loses a star for how dirty the intro is, but otherwise great · Lead / Fell/Hung. hung twice in lieback. triple.75 would be nice. lots of slings · Lead / Onsight. really fun route. the traverse wasn't as bad as it looked. · Lead / Fell/Hung. One take in the layback. Just couldn’t quite make it to the hand jams. Next time, remember to just push a bit further and it eases up. Move fast, place 0.75, move fast, hand jams. · TR. Flailed on this. Face part wasn’t too bad. Upper crack felt pretty unachievable. · TR. Clean! Would still be hard to lead that lieback part, but I actually did it with a bit of juice left, so maybe it would go. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Best attempt. Fell on slab but very clean fall. Got back up and redid the slab + layback. Layback lead went well. Found a bit of rest with .75 thin hand lower than previously · TR. bottom is bouldery old school climbing. felt 10-. would use a bunch of hand sized pieces there. could not figure out the foot traverse. may be worth trying again with fresh forearms. splitter crack was awesome. · TR. Clean TR. time to go back and lead it now roofs felt good this time can clip bolt from top of right side and then go down and rest before traversing traverse felt okay too, just have to trust feet and throw for that left hand (get deeper left hand) need .4 or orange metolius for base of lieback Then .5, .75 and the rest is halfway up, with a hand jam jambacked inner foot felt pretty secure, lieback is definitely strenuous, consider pre-attaching alpine draw to gear to save time · TR. Hung twice: once b/c I didn’t see a good foot on the finger traverse (but the traverse felt pretty solid after) and second on the layback when my foot slipped · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Gear beta .75 low, extend like crazy bring some #2's for the first buldges a #3 is useful for the final bit before the traverse you know the traverse well .4 is good first part of lieback .5s the rest of the lieback #1 for final handcrack (thank god) · TR. Couldn’t step of the slab. Climbed the lie back better the second go. · TR. At crux use low feet, high R on good edge, match crimps, L out on edge, and wrench left shoulder to get to ledge. Layback is pumpy, keep going to handjams. · Lead / Fell/Hung. made it past the first crux on the slab move in the first go. bring lots of green cams 4 I believe in 5 the top which is the hardest part takes the most of them currently the best beta for the feet in the corner is a left foot toe jam and working the right on the smears. The first placement right off the face move is 0.3 cam and it's very helpful to keep your right foot on the facehold that you just left. Left side there's a good nub for your left foot. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 5 .75 3 .5 3 1 plus rack to to 3 · Lead / Redpoint. First try this season, didn’t remember any beta. Fun!! With kaj and quincy. · TR. had some help getting through slab crux, was super hot, rubber melting, and I'm fat and weak. hung once on upper crack. cool route, slap after slab isn't super positive. lower crack had a couple powerful steep bulges to pull · Lead / Redpoint. Forgot a .75 for the top so I did a good run out to the 2 · Lead / Fell/Hung. No problem through the traverse. Fell while pulling up rope to clip fairly low on the crack. Next time keep moving! · Lead / Fell/Hung. aided crux then fewhang through upper dihedral (lieback, don't jam!). 2s and a 3 for the bottom, then .4, .5, .75x2, 1, 2 for the top). try LH gaston crack as an intermediate for the crux next time. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Could redpoint! Reach for bad hold after bolt and trust it. Layback crack. · Lead / Flash. first day back at index for the spring. it was desperate through the bolt and in the layback, but managed to keep it together. climbed pretty tense and scared. · Lead / Flash. Got scared on the 5.9 down climbed it to come back another day and flashed the whole thing freaking stoked!! · Lead / Redpoint. Redpoint. TR'd it a while back. First go. Super fun route · Lead / Redpoint. Redpoint on first lead attempt! Far left feet on traverse. Extended .4, .5, 2 .75s, 1 on layback. · TR. Boulder problem moves very small box, still not sure how to do them right. Upper corner lieback until a bit before the other crack appears. Then, straight in ringlocks for a few moves before transitioning to hand jams.

area_description: This lower-angle slab features a number of friction climbs, and some other attractions.
area_getting_there: Directly above Princely Ambitions, to the right of the Dihedral Wall and separated from it by a brushy gully.

routes.route_description: This right-facing corner features a hard, overhanging, flaring start with a thin-hands crack at the back. Once past this the climbing eases.One can do the original finish by staying left or instead finish to the right on the fun upper part of Newest Industry.
routes.route_location: The prominent right-facing corner visible when looking at The Shield from the Dr. Sniff or Princely anchors.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2", emphasis on thin-hands gear.

route_comments.comment_text: there is a pretty scary block/flake about mid way up this route that at first glance I wanted to use for gear, and then shuddered to think of it falling directly down over Japanese Gardens. After the layback start, there is a low angle section, then it starts traversing right, with the bolted slab out to your right, while you are following a slanting corner, the block is hollow behind and... more there is a pretty scary block/flake about mid way up this route that at first glance I wanted to use for gear, and then shuddered to think of it falling directly down over Japanese Gardens. After the layback start, there is a low angle section, then it starts traversing right, with the bolted slab out to your right, while you are following a slanting corner, the block is hollow behind and makes a great undercling until you look closer and it is detached but hopefully wedged there.Best to avoid it. Great route otherwise. Jul 26, 2013

This is probably the most neglected and under appreciated 5.9 at index. Especially given its proximity on the Lower town wall. I’ve climbed it twice and IS NOT choked with black berry bushes as the 2012 description suggests.    Given the millions of people climbing princely ambition they should just continue up this climb and add another 5.9 pitch. Jun 26, 2019
The large block (2'x5') right before the roof traverse moved on me, had to stem around it. Seems like a hard pull away from the face would make it a meteor, so use caution. Aug 23, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Difficult and dirty start. Takes larger gear inside the flake, but it seems like the best way to climb the upper part of the flake is liebacking. Cleans up after the crack and is a pleasant climb · Follow. backed off. Ryan sieged it and the struggle was worth it. hard transition from crack to layback. fun work. · Lead / Onsight. After Princely. Burl start to no hands slab traverse - pretty cool, a bit dirty / spiders. Block seemed solid enough but didn’t really pull on it. · Lead. dirty and covered in spider webs when I got there. now a bit cleaner. would benefit from more traffic. burly start then lots of undercling smeary roofs. watch for rope drag. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell a couple times at crux on lead, then got on TR after Kyle sent. “Normal” finish is full of bushes and you finish out right under and over roof. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once out of the initial flaring chimney, and hung a couple times at the roof. · struggled with dirty flaring crack, sketched out by huge loose block, fun bite-size roof

routes.route_description: Might be a bit scruffy and the bolts might still be 1/4"  This route and the following pitch that goes to the top of the wall contain really fun climbing and are atypical for Index.  Perhaps someone will be inspired to brush them off and upgrade the hardware.Climb crack/corner just to the left of Beak! Beak! Beak! (5.9) This feature soon ends at a smooth and exciting slab. Pad your way past three bolts to a bolted anchor. It is possible to avoid this anchor by climbing right to the anchor on top of Beak! Beak! Beak! It is also possible to traverse from the top of Lamar’s Trust directly to the top of Beak! Beak! Beak!From the Beak! Beak! Beak! anchor it is possible to continue up via 10% to the top of the wall. (Several variations ranging from 5.7+ to 5.9 are possible) You can also TR Newest Industry and the excellent 10% slab from here..
routes.route_location: Start just to the left of Beak! Beak! Beak!
routes.route_protection: Small rack and quickdraws

routes.route_fa: Greg Olsen, Max Dufford, Darryl Cramer
routes.route_description: A really enjoyable slab climb located on The Shield, which is essentially the large slab on the upper left portion of the Lower Wall. Well-bolted slab climbing grows in difficulty until a distinct, thin crux section. After the crux, there is a much easier runout either right to an anchor on TPMV below its 10d mantle pitch or to a higher anchor via a dike and easy roof. Natural gear protects the dike and the moves over the roof. The crux of the route is infamous for being rather thin for the grade, especially during the warm season. Descend from the anchor above the roof or better yet continue to the anchor at the top of the TPMV/Japanese Gardens routes via 5.7-5.8 slab climbing for a full size pitch.
routes.route_location: The best approach is probably via Princely Ambitions (.9) and Dr. Sniff and the Tuna Boaters (.10+). From the anchor at the top of the latter climb, scramble up and right across a grassy ledge to an anchor below the slab. Beware of loose debris on the ledge: anything that falls could easily land on someone below! One 70m rope will get you down the wall, with a variety of anchor choices available.
routes.route_protection: Bolts and gear to 1 inch. Bolted anchors.

route_comments.comment_text: Husker Du, "Newest Industry," from Zen Arcade (1984) Been through mass destruction once, but once was not enough. Said we want a second chance and all they say is "Tough." A world where science went too far, there's no way to survive. Why can't we get this thing straightened out, I want to stay alive. They burned and bombed the East and North, and there's no place left to go. ... more Husker Du, "Newest Industry," from Zen Arcade (1984) Been through mass destruction once, but once was not enough. Said we want a second chance and all they say is "Tough." A world where science went too far, there's no way to survive. Why can't we get this thing straightened out, I want to stay alive. They burned and bombed the East and North, and there's no place left to go. The Sun Belt's overcrowded, so let's annex Mexico. The Peso's only worth a dime, but they've got all that land. No need for civil war, we know they'll understand, right? Is that how you like it? Factories left unattended, crumbling to the ground. We tried to keep them running, but there's no more oil around. We used it all to fight a war that neither side could win. Vietnam is little league compared to where we've been. Now we live in caves and huts and we don't have pay TV. And everyone is signing up for the newest industry. Standard Oil goes solar power, all try to make a buck. So I'll sit and smoke cigarettes and babble "What the F__k?" Jan 1, 2009

This is one of the hardest 11a Slab Climbs I have ever done.  And I have climbed a lot of slab! I would put this around a 11b/c. The crux is at the 4th bolt. The PG rating is for the top part of the climb, but its easy 5.8 slab climbing with "iffy" gear for 15 feet. Mar 25, 2013
Definitely a very short, hard section that peeled off the toe from my shoes (I ended up frenching it). I dont think this warrants a PG13 rating May 23, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. At crux with right foot in pocket don’t miss the knob by bolt for left foot · Follow. followed the full pitch. Quite hard for the grade. I fell a number of times · TR. Hard. Did all the moves but fell a number of times. W/ Ben · Lead / Fell/Hung. with jay. didnt know what it was. got worked on a short hard section. it was hot, melted my shoes · Hardest 11a on planet if done in sun. Easy if done in 35 degree weather.

area_description: The Dihedral Wall is located directly above Princely Ambitions, Dr. Sniff and the final pitch of Snow White. Years ago the Dihedral Wall was free of obscuring vegetation and the “dihedral” routes were strikingly obvious from the parking lot. Now several trees shade the routes and they seem to have become largely forgotten and most certainly dirty. Too bad as they are excellent routes. Julie’s Roof and Gogum being thin cracks and C&S a stemming problem.
area_getting_there: The Dihedral Wall can be reached via walking from the top of Princely Ambitions, Tadpole or Snow White. It can also be reached by walking over from the top of the Great Northern slab. The trail from GNS takes you directly under the Terminator route. As always take care not to knock anything off as there will most likely be people down below.The old school descent from the top was to climb up to where it is possible to scramble down to GNS or simply rappel to the base. I believe bolts were added to simplify the descent. They might be old and manky now or they might not exist so plan accordingly.

routes.route_description: Climb up a short steep section past a bolt (1/4”?) and then pull into the wide dihedral. There should be good protection for this move. Start stemming up the corner. (5.11)  The crack occasional widens out locally as you ascend but mostly it’s too small for fingers until you’re past the halfway mark. Originally protected with several pins that were removed at some point. Modern gear should make the route protect-able without them but that’s just a guess. The stemming is sustained but the corner is short and the route joins Julie’s Roof at the top of the corner.  At one point this was a classic Index stemming problem.
routes.route_location: Start just left of Julie's Roof
routes.route_protection: Small rack to 3"

routes.route_fa: Doug Weaver, Jeff Wright & Scott Prueter
routes.route_description: Easy climbing leads to a corner. Climb the corner (5.7) to the Terminator anchor. The Instigator variation (5.8) starts just to right.
routes.route_location: Start just right of the Terminator.
routes.route_protection: Small rack

routes.route_description: This gem is now hidden behind foliage but it once was a sought after test piece. It climbs the leaning dihedral on the right side of the Dihedral Wall.  With the advent of placing protection became far less strenuous than on the FA. If this was at the Smoke Bluffs there would be a lineup every weekend. The route's name is derived from the FA team initials.The route has the feeling of being simultaneously low angle and overhanging at the same time!At the top of the corner there should be a ledge with an anchor.
routes.route_location: The right most corner on the Dihedral Wall.
routes.route_protection: Small rack

routes.route_description: Climb the crack just left of Gogum up to a roof. (5.11-)  At the roof it is possible to continue up - at least on TR I can't remember if its been done from the ground up.  In any event it will be dirty.  Julie's Roof proper traverses left under the roof and climbs an easier crack to a ledge.
routes.route_location: The second dihedral from the right side of the dihedral wall.
routes.route_protection: Gear up to #3 camalot

route_comments.comment_text: I remember one autumn many years ago in Yosemite. I was there with a friend and we were discussing what we should climb when my friend spotted Julie cooking dinner in a van.  I didn’t know her at all but we walked over and my partner asked her if she knew about a certain route.  I think the route was Orangutan Arch.  She not only knew about the route but offered detailed protection info and... more I remember one autumn many years ago in Yosemite. I was there with a friend and we were discussing what we should climb when my friend spotted Julie cooking dinner in a van.  I didn’t know her at all but we walked over and my partner asked her if she knew about a certain route.  I think the route was Orangutan Arch.  She not only knew about the route but offered detailed protection info and even pantomimed the crux move.  Turned out she was spot on.  The next time we saw her we asked about more routes and again she remembered lots of important details especially with regard to protection.    For the remainder of the trip we’d say to each other –“We gotta ask Julie about this or that route.”  She must have groaned every time she saw us because we were total pests for the remainder of our stay.  Julie was truly an encyclopedia about the popular and the obscure as well. Dec 6, 2019

routes.route_description: The original Dihedral Wall routes faced south and when first climbed were very visible from the parking lot. Doug and Jeff discovered that just around the corner facing west was a short featured wall. This route climbs past two bolts through a knobby section of rock. The crux is short lived and a bit reachy. Easier climbing leads to an anchor.
routes.route_location: Just left of the Dihedral routes.
routes.route_protection: Small rack

area_description: Probably the most crowded area at the Lower Wall on nice summer days, the Main Wall also has the highest route density and many awesome high-quality routes.
area_getting_there: Approach as for the Great Northern Slab, but follow the trail right along the base of the cliff.

routes.route_description: Named for the onetime street address of local climber/steward/first ascentionist Chris Henson, this is a good sport climb up an arete at the far left end of the lower wall. It tackles a series of interesting and powerful boulder problems, with the last 2 (~v5, v3) being really great. The middle section features some marginal rock and a big resting ledge, which both detract a bit.
routes.route_location: Left side of the lower wall. Ends on the very left end of the narrow ledge which also has the anchor for Dwarf Tossing and Princely Ambitions P1.
routes.route_protection: QDs

route_comments.comment_text: Excellent route and lots of variety. Physical at the crux. bring 3-4 shoulder length draws to better manage drag. Sep 9, 2018

Some tricky boulder problems separated by really good rests. The top is fairly “sustained” by index standards. The rock in the middle is a bit friable, but it’s still fun climbing. Felt super hard initially, but like all things it came together and felt reasonable for the grade. I don’t think there’s too much sand in this bag, just some cool rock climbing. Permas at the crux and anchors,... more Some tricky boulder problems separated by really good rests. The top is fairly “sustained” by index standards. The rock in the middle is a bit friable, but it’s still fun climbing. Felt super hard initially, but like all things it came together and felt reasonable for the grade. I don’t think there’s too much sand in this bag, just some cool rock climbing. Permas at the crux and anchors, which should incentivize some suitors! I’ve also never seen anyone on this, which is a nice consideration for LTW projecting. Oct 28, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. hard! lower sequence requires going up with left hand straight to bread loaf with left hand. second sequence is right hand at bottom of the v slot, bring right foot up and put left hand on the left wall crimp, smear left foot, then jump to right hand jug. next part is pretty hard, get right hand over and then bump out, get knee in slot, and work your way up. then match feet, move left foot up. from there, the mantel is super hard. · 2 pitches. Fantastic. Bolt to bolt finding, cleaning and chalking the holds then a tr lap · TR. w/ Tavish. Fun, got shut down on last crux but could def come back to work it out

routes.route_fa: FFA James Wyland (2001), Equipped by Ramier/Wyland
routes.route_description: Dwarf Tossing is just another 4 star lower wall classic free climb. This is essentially the free variation of Snow White. The original snow white takes the thin crack from the start of princely ambitions directly to the mini roof at the 3rd bolt.This route has at least 4 different 5.11 sections in addition to the all points off 7 ft sideways dyno at the crux. If you are taller than 6'6", you may be able to reach past the dyno. Shorter people might find the dyno to be impossibly long.If the dyno isn't your style, this route makes an almost as good 5.11d, A0. Highly recommended.
routes.route_location: Take the trail up towards Rogers corner, but break right just before you reach that route. This will deposit you on a nice little shelf approximately 30 feet up and left of the start of princely ambitions.  This route shares anchors with princely ambitions.  Rappel to the starting shelf is possible with a 70m rope, but you cannot rappel all the way to the ground.
routes.route_protection: Mostly bolted, but some gear is needed before the final bolt.  Most will want to stick clip the first bolt.

route_comments.comment_text: I see where this thing starts but how does it end? Does it join up with Princely of just keep going straight up? Aug 1, 2011

Greg, after the dyno head up and left on easy (runout-ish) ground to a bolt below a left facing corner. Go up the corner, which is rather tenuous and tricky. Bring a #1 for the pod. I feel that this is the most difficult part of the route despite the fact that I'm 5'8".  It is quite different in character than the rest of the climb. Also, I took a big whip on a #5 Micronut and am planning... more Greg, after the dyno head up and left on easy (runout-ish) ground to a bolt below a left facing corner. Go up the corner, which is rather tenuous and tricky. Bring a #1 for the pod. I feel that this is the most difficult part of the route despite the fact that I'm 5'8".  It is quite different in character than the rest of the climb. Also, I took a big whip on a #5 Micronut and am planning on going back for it, so please don't booty it anyone! Mar 13, 2016

FYI: there is a spooky flake just below the top L facing corner on this route that wiggles and feels like it wouldn't take much to rip off. I think it is still safe to climb but just don't yard on it. Jun 21, 2018

routes.route_description: This route has been obscured and neglected but it actually has really fun climbing and has some wild moves. Essentially it is a couple of unnamed variations to Snow White that are cobbled together and given a name.Starting slightly uphill from the regular Snow White start climb up scruffy rock and traverse right to a bolt (probably worthless unless it has been replaced) on an arête. (In picture bolt should be below the bolt notation) Traverse right along a horizontal break and join Snow White. The crux (11c) comes next and is a big crank to a jug. Continue up a couple of moves until it is possible to follow a right trending crack to join p2 of Princely Ambitions. The crack turns into an arching corner and the moves here are really fun lay backing the edge of the corner stepping into p2 of Princely Ambitions which is followed to the belay.
routes.route_location: See above
routes.route_protection: Standard Rack

route_comments.comment_text: I think this climb would be better done by starting on Dwarf Tossing, then exiting to Princely via the layback. A new bolt there would be welcome. Jun 11, 2019
I agree but aren't the opening moves of Dwarf Tossing harder than .11c? Jun 11, 2019
A bit, yeah. It's like a V4 boulder problem. Jun 11, 2019

routes.route_description: This brilliant route leaves Numbah Ten after several bolts (original locations have been altered) and heads right through a roof and up onto a technical arete that is just under vertical. It's possible that some ascents have climbed to the right after the roof to take advantage of a full rest on Iron Horse before moving back left to establish on the arete; although not totally straightforward, this reduces the difficulty as it allows one to start the easier Powerhorse sequence fully rested and chalked. If climbed directly without the jaunt right into the rest, the moves are harder and the route feels far more sustained. In any case, the climbing is a remarkable mixture of power and finesse, difficult nearly the whole way through. Temperature and humidity are both important considerations when attempting the route even if your granite technique is absolutely flawless.The extension to the original route continues above the anchor over the roof past one bolt to a more logical finish at an anchor on a large ledge. The original anchor has now been moved higher to just under the upper roof, making what was originally a crux section of the extension part of the shorter version. This section is height dependent as it is much easier if one can simply stem across the corner. A small stopper and a finger-size cam protect the final section above the roof.
routes.route_location: One 70m rope reaches the ground from the top anchor; otherwise a 60m is sufficient. Route starts as for Numbah Ten in an obvious groove left of Iron Horse.
routes.route_protection: Originally 13 quickdraws plus anchor, there's now at least one extra bolt on the lower section. You'll need one more quickdraw plus a small nuts and TCU for the extension over the roof.

route_comments.comment_text: This pitch is amazing - it has to be one of the best single pitches of granite climbing anywhere. Definitely end this by climbing up and over the roof (either rightward or leftward), it provides a final redpoint crux just after anchor #1, and seems like the only logical finish. The original anchor spot doesn't make any sense. As to the 13a vs 13c question (depending on if you step right into... more This pitch is amazing - it has to be one of the best single pitches of granite climbing anywhere. Definitely end this by climbing up and over the roof (either rightward or leftward), it provides a final redpoint crux just after anchor #1, and seems like the only logical finish. The original anchor spot doesn't make any sense. As to the 13a vs 13c question (depending on if you step right into Iron horse) There isn't an easy or obvious way to escape over into the Iron Horse flare. It may be possible, but sticking to the arete doesn't feel forced. Jan 10, 2015
I'm not sure that it is a sandbag for the folks that stay in the flare.  I've witnessed three successful non-knee baring ascents of Numba Ten since I moved them and no complaints. Feb 27, 2016

A few of the bolts could use some wrenching, especially the one underneath the roof (the hanger was barely hanging on by a thread.)  I'd also really recommend using some Loctite on stainless steel wedge bolts as they have a tendency to loosen up easily.  I would of been happy to do the maintenance but I was just passing through without my normal kit. Dec 16, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. After falling off Powerhorse. Smear in dimples and work out right on underclings, get RH far R where a bit worse, LH side pulling next to rail, RF high to edge at lip, perch, LH match, swap feet and RF out to knob, RH side pull, LH match above, then far RF to arête (tick it), then compress with LH, feet reset, LF in crack at edge, RF heel, RH above edge, bump LH high as possible then start smearing. At the chains, fat pinches and rock onto knobs · TR. Really hard! Oliver from Germany could make it through the roof, really impressive. Really hard to integrate this with the arete. So pumpy. · Lead / Redpoint. Amazing climbing start to finish (I used the hand jam in the iron horse flare to clip and shake out, though I didn’t move/step right into the corner)

routes.route_description: Yes it seeps and can be dirty, but this should definitely get climbed more during the summer and fall when its dry.  It climbs quite nicely and feels more like something from Yosemite than other ltw routes.  Pumpy and burly!Start up Sagittarius but head left along the roof with thin underclings in the crack.  Turn the corner and punch it up to meet back with Sagittarius.  A stylin' way to climb this would be stepping left from here to finish on Iron Horse.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Seems like it would protect no problem with modern small cams.  Can easily be toproped off of the first or second Sagittarius/Iron Horse anchors.

route_comments.comment_text: has anyone red pointed this thing in modern style? To what anchor did it go?  was Jeff smoot's ascent a modern redpoint? stories?...Anybody? Oct 6, 2023

routes.route_description: This is an old A4 aid line, the bottom 45 feet goes free at 10b and has some spectacular, well protected climbing. Great climb at the LTW for those starting to lead 5.10s at Index. Cool sections of finger crack punctuated by good rests.A final move onto the face left of the thin crack brings you to the anchor.Continuing past this point is the original aid line, Artifice, which has never seen a free ascent.
routes.route_location: Start as for Batskins and go straight up the finger crack above the small roof from where Batskins traverses hard right
routes.route_protection: small cams to .75 Save the .75 for the horizontal placement before making moves to the anchors, .2 or similar sized cam is also helpful. slings necessary to extend pieces placed before roof
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. I’m gonna say I sent it. But I did grab onto the chains to clip because I felt super insecure being an inch too short. I would love to do it again. Such a sick climb. · Lead / Onsight. Nice, .1/.2 would be nice for top but brassie wasn’t bad · Lead / Fell/Hung. Spent too long messing with gear at the start of the crux and pumped out on the next moves. Doubles 0.2-0.75 is more than sufficient. · Lead / Onsight. Totems, .1, .4-1, gold offset for the top, take 7 draws if top roping. Maybe the best way to warm up at LTW - never seen anyone on it · Lead / Onsight. Fun climbing, lots of rests. Last part was a bit cruxy but also delicate. Fiddly mental gear before the last few moves, that .75 a few feet below is bomber though! · TR. Nathan lead and Dylan and I followed. Crux for me was last moves along the crack and gaining the face · TR. tronsight. Might lead, heavy on .3 .4. A fixed head and maybe a marginal nut protect the final burly crux clipping the chains · Lead / Onsight. I didn't place anything past the 0.75 in the horizontal, made the moves to the chains a bit heady but the fall would be safe · Lead / Fell/Hung. sweaty day and mental crux going into the last bit. it will go next time. · Lead / Onsight. More faffing than climbing lol. Fun route that’s mostly just easy liebacking and p interesting features. Q short. One really cool move at the top · TR. Followed Nick to end the day. Felt harder than I remembered, but was also pretty pumped. :) · Lead / Onsight. Super fun! Very approachable for steep finger crack route at Index. · Lead / Fell/Hung. crux traverse to the anchor way above your last good piece isnt super fun. why is the anchor over there?

routes.route_fa: FA P1 full: Bob Crawford, Pat Timson FFA P1 short: Terry Lien P1 full: Darryl Cramer, Max Dufford P2: Cramer, Nicola Masciandaro
routes.route_description: This climb has some really interesting knobs and a good variety of features and climbing styles. The short version of the first pitch climbs an arch feature with natural gear (some tricky placements) to a ledge with an anchor (.11a) This is a worthwhile pitch on its own. The full pitch continues past bolts in a shallow groove with some tricky stemming and a cruxy section on knobs, moving left to an anchor (.12b).The second pitch is also excellent providing it has been brushed recently. It follows a thin ramp and then a stemming corner with knobs to a testy balance crux up high. 3 bolts; some small gear is needed to protect the crux moves (.11d).
routes.route_location: Climbs the right facing arch to the left of Godzilla. A toprope variation climbs the face under the arch and joins the arch midway through.
routes.route_protection: Natural gear to 3 inches for the first part, especially small; Bolts (4 or 5) plus an anchor for the second part.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Beginning of upper crux: high L foot, palm R to get foot up to smear. Palm L, crimp R and dynamic R foot bump · TR. Tried batskins variation 1st, swung over to ratkins after failing at the basketball. · TR. At first crux above 11 chains: putting LEFT foot on righthand wall/nub was key, right hand on dihedral crimp/sidepull. Could not get thorough top basketball crux · TR. 45 and sunny! Very dry. Did this as a warm up. Took twice at the stemming spot, but think I can send this on TR next cold dry day! With left hand on basketball, levitate feet up and reach for great knob with right hand. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Practice falls to first chains. .5 and. 4 protect under roof, place black totem before crux foot swap · 2 pitches. TR. Got it basically clean the second time. Should lead it next time, use a combination of stemming and lay backing for the crux · TR. 2 attempts. Took some time to figure out the beta, but not too bad once you get the moves. Definitely easier to be tall here. · Lead / Redpoint. *********TR to low chains. Lead to the top with pre-hung draws · TR. Short crux: layback to get LF on jug, step left to get RF up high and RH into juggy side pull. LF to good knob, RF toe into lieback pod, place black totem in slot, LH slot, RH pinch undercling, Swap feet, LF good knob, flip LH to under cling, bring RF to another knob · Follow. Got clean today with Nate redon. To first anchor 11.a very hard and a long whip potential at top. Took his whip in 2015 · Lead. Went up and sorted the beta at the top and it made way more sense to got left to the jug earlier with right hand on the basketball, the way climbing up to clip the bolt feels henious and haughty dependent and reaching left feels super natural and in sequence. Ends with a dyno to a jug, pretty sweet. 2 tries this year toproped once a few years ago I think · TR. TRed clean until the crux pull on the slab. Would be a heady lead. · Lead / Redpoint. Two lead goes after some toprope work. Double send day with Numbah 10. First 5.12 post surgery · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard. At 3rd bolt, step rf on good knob, lf stemming. Grab football hold lh and bad knob right hand. Work left foot up on to bad knob then stand on football. I think. I dunno can’t remember quite right · TR. start knob sequence with left foot, get right foot on smear, pull on small crimp, bring left foot up. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a *big* whip at the crux (rope behind the leg, flipped upside down and all). Proud that I finished it after that. :) · Follow. Near TRonsite of the short version of the first pitch. After climbing through the crux, there's a high left finger slot. The key for me was a right hand middle finger pocket under the rail. · Lead / Redpoint. Just to the low anchors (11a variation). Proud of the lead on this one. Should def come back for the whole thing. Gear beta for crux: double up at the last roof (blue totem and either purple metolius or a blue z4, be sure to put a draw on); don't bother trying to place in the side pull (seriously, it's garbage); black totem at next pocket is bomber. · TR. Really fun! The roof moves are great and then a tricky cross over · TR. DNS.Projected first pitch on top rope; climbed three times to under cling. Felt good to get under cling move eventually. Pumpy-biceps are so sore! Felt good knowing last time I was here I was buckled in fear, but today I jumped right on and gave it a try. · Lead / Redpoint. headpoint no lead falls, kinda botched the lower 11 slab section and got flash pumped but kept it together and styled the 12! · TR. Got the first pitch clean, but couldn't even do the first hard move on the second pitch · 1st p tr. Clean to crux. Fun face moves out left. Need to stay in crack though · TR, def not clean, but it will go one day. Lead will be SCARY

routes.route_description: This is the second pitch of Roger's Corner.  Take the obvious handcrack next to the tree.  Straightforward, fun jams.  You'll wish this went on for another 150 feet.  A bonus is that it stays dry in the rain.  There is an anchor on the ledge above, and you can toprope Marginal Karma, the 11b immediately to the right, from those bolts.  You can also approach this from the top of GNS if you don't want to go up Roger's.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: A few hand size pieces.  You'll have enough from whatever you brought up Roger's.

route_comments.comment_text: Awesome route! Pumpy with stunning exposure.  Goes from #0.75 Camalots to #3 Camalot.  Two of each is more than enough.  Warning: The crack has 'hollow' sounding sections which is a little creepy!  We rappelled with a single 70m rope to the chains midway on Roger's Corner, and then another rappel to the ground.  I don't think a 60m rope would have made the chains, but you could easily rappel... more Awesome route! Pumpy with stunning exposure.  Goes from #0.75 Camalots to #3 Camalot.  Two of each is more than enough.  Warning: The crack has 'hollow' sounding sections which is a little creepy!  We rappelled with a single 70m rope to the chains midway on Roger's Corner, and then another rappel to the ground.  I don't think a 60m rope would have made the chains, but you could easily rappel to the belay tree, then to the chains, and then to the ground.  Or just bring two ropes! Jul 3, 2006
A 60m does barely make it to the chains midway up Roger's Corner, but be careful. Aug 13, 2007
With good use of slings and a bunch of gear you can go from the ground up Roger's Corner and finish on Breakfast in one full 70m pitch. Apr 3, 2008

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. The moves felt easier than last time, but still strenuous since the crack slants left and slightly overhung. Didn't need to place any #.75; moves to get into the crack were straightforward. · Lead / Fell/Hung. One fall. Was pooped after leading Sagittarius and TR iron horse. Think this would go otherqise · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took. Super out of shape but a fun route. Felt much harder than it looked · TR. Big jam past tight red hands, start lower and traverse rigjt and use start of marginal karma. Green cam protects start. Move fast past crux · Lead / Redpoint. Tried to avoid going out right too much at the start, used some face holds but' no side pulling MK crack. Also went straight up at the end with a high step and finger lock. 0.4/0.5 Offset, 0.75, 1x2, 2x3, skipped the #3 (had it tho), 0.75 out right (wc or tot better than z4) & 3rd #1 next to it. 0.5x2 in flaring crack above cave, idk why but yel tot was shit and/or blocked my finger jam. · 2 pitches. TR. TRS 2 laps + Rogers crux, no mock lead just directionals. Went pretty straight up off belay both times, hard but doable. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung once after feeling pumped going from thin hands section to hands. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Needed help getting thru the bottom section of thin hands / sooo good and splitter · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Brian Rajdl. Linked from 5.9 Roger's Corner. This pitch is a bit short, but the position is fantastic 120' off the deck! · Dropped in from the top after going up GNS as a party was lapping Roger’s. Make sure to bring a few cams with you if you want to top it from dropping in so you don’t end up floating in space… · Lead / Onsight. Tight hands at the start was tough but short. Rest was cruiser. Thought this was easier than Roger’s because of the easy gear and short line. Lots of feet on face until crack widens for easy foot jams. Overall Way easier than Libra. · Lead / Onsight. Steep for a 10a. Super burley. Crux at the bottom and top. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung once after struggling to find a place to place a #1 when I only had 1 #2. Definitely bring 2x #2s! Pumpy but is all there. · Follow. Andrew led and took a few times down low. But pushed on and made it to the top. Fun and harder than it looks · Lead / Redpoint. W chad, finally got to get on lead for this one still steep and burly but much more fun now that I know how to jam. · Lead / Onsight. Proud send. A bit heady and challenging. Some face holds and feet at the bottom help with getting sufficient lieback moves to get to the thin hands bit to get a good foot pod. Finger lock out right while standing on the low/first (only?) foot rail helps to rest long enough to launch into the route. Was helpful to have been practicing swimming technique up and down and up and down VW hand crack for endurance. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lowered and had Wren lead the last bit at the top. Followed her up there before rappelling · Lead. Alright Kristina and I split this lead and honestly probably the hardest thing I have led at index. Consistent hand crack to some blocky crack climbing. A couple big moves — don’t be scared of falling into the tree behind you · Lead / Fell/Hung. I am so weak! The crack is lovely but the overhung angle did me in. Took a lot and backcleaned a bit. The big upper move is almost harder. · TR. W/ Gus. Thankfully someone had come over from GNS and followed with our rope so we could top rope. Come back and take no falls and practice hand jams. Very yummy for 10a. Got lowered to the first pitch of Roger’s Corner. Absolutely terrifying, exposure definitely got to me waiting at the anchor and rappelling in the void. · Lead / Onsight. Thought we were on rogers corner but we took the wrong route up to this. Also tried free range chook and whipped on the piton · Lead. Lots of takes, but did the moves cleanly and didn't pull on gear. First few 0.75 moves are hard and overhung. Brought singles 0.3-0.5, triples of 0.75-2, and doubles of #3 · Lead / Onsight. Super fun crack, gets easier the further you go! Doubles 0.75-3. Clean and simple. · Follow. had to aid climb the second half as my fore arms were fried from the lower pitch but fun · Lead / Onsight. fun, committing move off the start of the pitch to a nice stance · Follow. Crux getting off the anchor. Takes a 0.5, then gets wider and wider to a 3. Stay right and walkup to the anchor.

routes.route_description: This short but fun climb has two cruxes: one passing a bolt low on the route and another reaching and clipping the anchor at the top. Some think that clipping the chains is the hardest "move" on the route! This route includes knobs, face and crack climbing in its 40 feet and is very worthwhile. The gear for the top section, although a bit tricky to see, is quite good. The "sort of serious" rating is due to the fact that the beginning 10-15 feet is unprotected and has some slightly questionable rock. The climbing in this section is easier than the rest of the route, however. Additionally, the shorter you are, the more difficult the bolt is to clip.
routes.route_location: Right of Japanese Gardens, this route shares the same start as Bat Skins, but instead of traversing right continues straight up past a bolt and gear to an anchor with chains.
routes.route_protection: One bolt and gear to one or two inches. While the top crux used to be hard to protect, modern cams make it quit safe although placing them is still a challenge. Don't bother with the old circlehead nearby (except for nostalgic purposes): a much more trustworthy Alien, TCU, or C3 (depending on brand preference) is available nearby.

route_comments.comment_text: Bolt is straightforward to clip.  Although I haven’t done them all, this is quite possibly the best route at the lower town wall. Highly underappreciated cerebral and poetic movement-a true reflection of the index style of climbing! Nov 17, 2018
I came to write a comment about how good this route is after doing it for the xth time this weekend, but I already spewed about it once! Still as good as i remember it.. Apr 2, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Fun to refigure. Remember R heel hook to stand up at crux, then switch to R layback after jug to stand onto ledge. · Lead / Redpoint. With Brandon. 7 TR laps, 1st lead go. Sideways dyno at first crux if you are short. · Lead / Fell/Hung. .5 off ground, .75 to back up bolt. black totem after bolt (maybe extended in case it pops?). .4, .75 on undercling, blue totem, blue tcu / black totem. · Lead / Redpoint. 2 trs to suss gear, sent 1st lead go. chains are dumb. wtf is happening. doubles to 0.4, gold dmm, 0.75, .5. see rack photo · TR. tossing the heel hook in and just stand up grabbing the under belly. lay left on the next section the finally getting a high right foot going to the anchor feels good. · TR. fell on first trip up. make sure to grab the right top sloper hold when leading next to the chains. · TR. It’s not about how long it is, it’s about how you use it. Definitely gotta come back to put this down. · Lead / Redpoint. 7 tries total. I had resisted this one for being short and ending with the weird clip but the 2 cruxes on this are as classic as any other. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Next time remember the good foot hold a step down in the crux. Gear: BD 0.75, locking carabiner, yellow DMM nut or black totem, BD 0.3 (left crack), yellow totem (right crack), BD 0.4 (right slot), and blue totem (bottom of pod--tight, but goes in well). · Lead / Redpoint. Finally got it! Should try Nick's RH palm press at the low crux next time. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Real close to getting it this time. 1 fall at low crux and grabbed the chains to clip. Really liked my new crux beta (RF on slopey ledge, LF to the cutout jug). Remember to clip chains from low LH. Next time for sure! Used black totem at the top this time (slot it up high), and it seemed much better. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Two falls at low crux, one fall at top. Gear felt bomber. Will get the RP next go. So glad I mustered the courage to lead this one. So worth it! Gear Beta: https://photos.google.com/u/1/photo/AF1QipMAL-n3GjDiRka-VfJ3ZJ4twWPAIY7vf1D3K1LA · TR. TR'd and placed gear. I've got all the moves down. I'm ready for the lead. · TR. Got it clean on TR. So fun! Nearly blew it when I got distracted by train and got sloppy with foot at second crux. :) · TR. Fell 3x at low crux before figuring out beta (right foot on the big hold, focus on getting knee turned left so that you're almost pushing out to the right on it). Think I also fell 1x at higher crux.

routes.route_fa: Greg Olsen, Darryl Cramer, Terry Lien
routes.route_description: Having MiniTraxioned this route a couple of times in the (increasingly distant) past, I thought it might be worth adding in case anyone else has experience with it. It was a little scruffy when I climbed it, but someone had cleaned it somewhat recently and it was still possible to at least toprope it clean. From the anchor atop Japanese Gardens P2 move left and up to a short, thin crack. Even though I remember thinking some gear might go in before you commit, the business starts without any fanfare and on lead the crack would be a scary, desperate lieback above a ledge with a hard-to-clip bolt near its top. The route then climbs over to and up onto the face of the Stiff Kittens Flake and follows a seam/crack to the top of the flake. I remember this section being low-to-mid-5.10 face climbing and it appeared quite runout. Another option would be to just finish Stiff Kittens, which would omit the worst of the runout. I know that at the top of the flake I stepped left and down and finished on the Stiff Kittens slab, so I don't know if there is an independent finish directly above. I believe if it were scrubbed the route would at the very least be a fun toprope option, say after doing Japanese Gardens to the top, Stiff Kittens or maybe even from the top of TPMV P3 if the final bolt works as a directional.
routes.route_location: Above the anchor of Japanese Gardens P2, the beginning of this route is an obvious short thin crack up and left with a bolt next to it near its top.
routes.route_protection: As stated I haven't led the route, but the lower crux finger crack/lieback is thrutchy and desperate from the get go and it was obvious to me that gear would probably be really hard to place once underway. The bolt would similarly be hard to clip and its status is unknown at this juncture. The upper part of the route is pretty runout; I don't remember seeing much potential for gear but it does follow a seam or crack of sorts so there might be something. Another option as stated above would be to climb the rest of Stiff Kittens which has good gear. There may or may not be an independent anchor for Cheeseburgers, but I remember stepping left--again on MiniTraxion so take with a grain of salt--to finish on the upper Stiff Kittens slab. In any case this route would probably need a mandatory scrubbing and inspection, including the bolt, before attempting a lead.

routes.route_fa: Roger Johnson, Richard Mathies, 1966 FFA: Todd Skinner, 1986
routes.route_description: P1: (.13+ or C1) Next to Godzilla is this obvious pin-scarred splitter seam. This classic easy aid crack at one time had the distinction as the hardest crack in America when Todd Skinner freed it in 1986. It has a storied history of free ascents and attempts. Hugh Herr, a double amputee who used prosthetics that he designed and fabricated, completed a free ascent. Chris Schlotfeldt completed a pinkpoint ascent (pre-placed gear) in the late 1990s. Mikey Schaeffer made the first redpoint ascent in the contemporary accepted style in 2006, meaning he placed ALL his gear on lead from the ground. Start via a bolt ladder that leads to the base of the crack. The crack is consistently difficult until it relents at the top, although a left-jogging section above an undercling is particularly challenging.P2: (.10b) The oft-climbed approach pitch to Slow Children can also be accessed via Godzilla. Thin stemming leads to crack and ledgy face climbing and an anchor on a ledge below the initial corner of Slow Children.P3 and P4: Apparently, pitches 3 and 4 of City Park can be free climbed at moderate grades (.10, 5.9+). The belay for pitch 3 would be to the right of the belay for Slow Children, but I'm not sure. Another option above Slow Children is the excellent Tommy's Sandbox, a fine .11a outing with nicely varied climbing.
routes.route_location: Start on the bolt ladder left of Godzilla that leads into the obvious thin crack.
routes.route_protection: Lots of nuts for the pin scars, plus cams. Anchors on the first two pitches are fixed; the others are unknown but there is probably a bolted anchor at the top of P4.

route_comments.comment_text: Todd Skinner didn't have small fingers; but, he did have an exceptional work ethic. Jun 11, 2011
Good observation Ben, Skinner was in it to win it. Jun 15, 2011

Did P2 while doing the Godzilla -> City Park -> Sloe Children linkup.   Fun pitch.  Thin and balancey off the belay to the mantel, and then into crusing hands.  Make sure you bring some small nuts (big brass HB offsets or small BDs) for this pitch. Jun 18, 2011

routes.route_tick_comments: · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Pitch 2 linked with Godzilla and slow children. Had to aid crux · 1 pitch. Lead. Aid. First aid pitch! Had just enough small gear. Some strategic backcleaning. · 1 pitch. Lead. first aid pitch! grace said it took an hour but I swear it felt like 10 minutes. scarier than I thought it would feel · 1 pitch. Lead. Climbed with Zach. Aid in 1hr 20min shooting to get this under an hr. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided twice on TR Solo: 2 hours and then 44 minutes. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Aid 40 min. Took a fall on a red yellow offset bd? · 1 pitch. TR. Free climbed with maybe a dozen rests. I did WAAAY better than I could have imagined. I actually got to the top doing all the moves. I thought the Pirate was harder lol · 1 pitch. Lead. Aid practice, short fixing, 1st pitch to 1/2 way anchors, 20 min · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Lol I aided this so I guess I fell/hung the whole way up With Andrew Good first aid learning · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. First aid lead at C1+ (Says Sam Boyd)<-- Really good climber. only had 1 piece blow out below after just placing a piece just higher and clipping in. · TR. Follow bolt ladder with mock lead. Times: 1) 16 min 2) 9 min Lead bolt ladder: 3) 9:40 Jugging: 1) 10:30 w/o lowering · 2 pitches. Lead. Just did first two pitches because it started to rain, clean aid · 1 pitch. TR. Aid. No falls. Gear: BD stoppers 3-9 (mostly 5-7), micro cams, and maybe 2 #2s · Lead / Redpoint. Amazing rock climb, very enjoyable climbing not even that painful, should see more attempts · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. C1. First aid lead. Takes narrow cam hooks and black totems well. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Aid lap, what a cool crack. Ate offset nuts like crazy. 1h 4m with 10m spent on · 1 pitch. Lead. Aided. Dmm offset 2*7,8,9 Purple totem 4 cam hook moves, Bd offset: 2/3,3/4,4/5,5/.75 BD:.1,.2,.3,.4,.5,.75,1,#3 20+ draws · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Only did P2 to Access Slow Children: fell@ beginning, red offset peanut after bolt (popped twice) then mantle into small alcove thing. Delicate feet with fingertip side pull to left hand mono crack thug move to mantle ledge · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Led p 2 btwn Godzilla and Sl. Childrn w/ Matt B. Clip bolt, bridge with left palm/right thumb, place the DMM #5 brass offset nut in pin scar just below shelf, stem up to corner, green c3 in crack, followed by blue Metolius, etc. Tricky, technical and fun. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Failed to do p2 of city park (on way to slow children). That crux finger lock move off the bolt... ah who am I kidding, finger cracks in general. · 1 pitch. Follow. 2nd pitch only. Ben aided. I stepped on the first bolt. sue me. · Follow. Attempt P1 free. Hangdogged up to the end of the lower crack (free to there) but couldn’t figure out feet to move off that slopey pod and into the upper crack. Aided pretty much everything from there onwards because we were running out of daylight · Lead. Aid. like 30 fuckin pieces. up to #1BD. DMM offset stoppers and a crap load of them. peanuts and tons of QDs · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. pitch 2. #5 brass offset for high blind placement, then .3 x4 to keep the next finger pod open, blue metolius tcu might be even better. · 1 pitch. Follow. P2 w/ Godzilla as super pitch to base of slow children. W/ Ben and Devon · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Pitch 2 of course Red ballnut and #5 brassie at the crux Then blue alien. Green blocks the finger slot. · Aided the route. Maybe one day I’ll do this monster free. Who says you can’t dream big! · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. First aid route! First whip! First zipper! Sending! (First pitch only) · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided ~2/3, ran out of time. Only nuts, much faster than before. · 1 pitch. Lead. Aided Pitch 1. Very Slow. Lots of small offset nuts & cams. · 1 pitch. TR. did all the moves. not too bad on TR, insane to lead?? · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided, really only half a pitch before lowering on anchors to left. Took a fall when cam popped. · 1 pitch. Follow. Did second pitch to slow children. Established feet high on left side and then use the slopey ledge · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Only climbed 2nd pitch. Quite tricky right off the belay and above the bolt. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Lead p2 only (10b), approached via Godzilla, finished on Slow Children · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Almost got P2. I have the moves now just need to link them. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Lead the second pitch, took a good whip on a .4 (5.10b) · 1 pitch. Lead. P2 Real scared on that thin start with a party on the Godzilla ledge to cheer me on :) couldn't help it- pulled on the first draw and next cam. The rest was jam · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Aided pitch 1 and lead second pitch as approach to slow children. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. First aid lead with Braydon. Wish I had more micro stoppers · took me 3 hours to aid solo the first pitch, bring like 4 bd 5 nuts and backclean every other one

routes.route_fa: Roger Johnson, Richard Mathies (1966); FFA John Stoddard (~1979)
routes.route_description: If the bolt ladder get's one, I think this pitch deserves it's own listing. It always feels a bit weird ticking City Park after just climbing the second pitch to get to Slow Children.Move left from the belay and climb up to a thin stem-box with a bolt. A med/small nut protects the mantle into the flare. Follow fun cracks and flakes up to the ledge below Slow Children.
routes.route_location: Above City Park
routes.route_protection: Standard rack
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Foot fell once at crux move. Repeated the same move and got it right after · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tried to dyno to good hold, didn’t quite work. Finally figured out the sequence and beta but man is it technical and reachy for me. Classic techy scary index · Lead / Fell/Hung. Felt sketched out a little today, took on the opening moves and once higher up because I botched the beta. · Lead / Flash. golden dmm offset massively helps low crux protection in seam ~10” below the mini ledge. black totem above ledge to protect pulling it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Too nervous to commit to the big reach with my hamstring injury · Follow. Tough techy crux right off the belay then eases a lot. Followed Conor, kinda spicy lead I bet · Follow. Didn’t feel like leading this onsight, and Haigh and Brielle showed up so Chase and I followed them up. Bring a gold offset for the crack after the bolt. It’s not too bad once you’re in there. · Follow. Thumb press right and palm arete left to stand up onto balancey left foot. Black totem in first slot, use the next slots for fingers to mantel. Both feet up to decent edge, R foot up to slopey bump, hop L foot up to ledge · Lead / Redpoint. Have got it clean in the past also. This time learned not to try for nut until higher up and then use larger small nut and then just reach for ledge I can reach from stance and easily pull up get a stance and place black totem in the crack. · Lead / Redpoint. Redpoint cause I fell at the stem crux and had to re-try. Got clean afterward · Lead. Forgot how tough this was off the start, kinda scary but fun. Bring a 3 for up higher, there is a horizontal slot you can place it in out left. · Lead / Redpoint. Had a couple falls onto a brassy at the start, if tall can reach the ledge, if short need to get right finger lock, left foot to rail, right hand up, pull - bump right foot to stem, bump left foot up to small chip, then can reach the rail. After 3rd fall lowered to the belay ledge and led clean. · Lead / Onsight. Good pitch! Climbed with Brian Rajdl. Linked from 5.9 Godzilla to get to 5.10d Slow Children. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Greased out of a finger lock and my black totem broke a piece of rock but still held · Lead / Fell/Hung. 2 nuts micro and small nut silver bd Yellow .2 don’t place a .3 Used finger and step up. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hang at the mantle. Gear notes (mostly for myself): DMM brass offset #3 above the bolt optional black totem in a crack right above the mantle bomber BD X4 offset #3-4 when standing on a mantle BD C3 #1 in a flaring crack the rest is easy · Follow. Did as second pitch to Godzilla. Felt easier than Godzilla and Japanese Garden Short. · Lead. mantle right hand and get right knee on ledge. left hand and foot stemming to left face. after crux, red, yellow and finger piece. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell and ripped the first nut, bolt caught me. could not get the start and lowered, then followed. · Follow. Tough but off the belay! Fell on first move lol. But fun moves above. · Lead. did it as one long 70m from the ground, linked with Godzilla. sunny and warm for 35 degrees. didnt need a jacket, belayed with shoes off. · Lead / Fell/Hung. dmm offset #1 nut, then optional small offset cam above ledge to protect crux. · Follow. 1 hang, don't go right hand into the crack first above the mantle. small brass nuts or micro offset cams, then fingers up to #3 or Wc #2 near top. scary and hardstart · Lead / Fell/Hung. didn't bring small enough nuts or ballnuts to protect part after the bolt, bailed. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a while to figure out the start sequence through the mantle. The rest was peachy. · Lead / Onsight. Small gear before the bolt. had to crank up for finger lock but its great after that!

routes.route_description: A pocketed face climb, generally done as a variation start to Godzilla. The crux is moving off the large blocky knob near the bottom. The rating applies to moving right from this stance and staying right of the bolts. The route is quite short, but it has some nice pulling on pockets.For a slight bit more challenge, closely follow the bolt line all the way (without moving right) to the start of the City Park crack, about 10c/d.There is often some slings at the large flake where the route joins Godzilla. Lower off from here, or continue up Godzilla to the anchors on Godzilla. For the latter, bring the gear recommended for that route.
routes.route_location: Just left of the Godzilla start.
routes.route_protection: 6 bolts. May need a sling to leave on the flake at the top, but you can look to see before starting.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. free climb. direct is hard, zigzagging around makes it a hard but doable 10b. fell/hung.

routes.route_description: Textbook Index face climbing leads to some trickery before a good stance at the entrance of the knee bar/flare on Numbah 10.This short variation offers a more straight forward start to both Numbah 10 as well as Amandla, avoiding the dreaded shoulder wrenching pterodactyl move on Numbah 10 as well as all the associated ambiguity over the grade.
routes.route_location: Leave the ground on the Iron Horse flake then follow bolts left to join Numbah 10 at the 5th bolt where it's possible to enter the flare on that route.  Continue following bolts as for Numbah 10.
routes.route_protection: 12 QD's
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fist time the beta made sense. Found nearly passive arm bar when shuffling in that makes things much easier. Slightly unsure how to move up from crimp to above roof. Currently chimney with left fort back step, but slightly awkward. · TR. High step crux: R hand pinch/undercling far R, L hand on arete, L foot smears lower than obvious foot, R foot steps through. Flare crux: L foot knee bar, crimp in back of flare L hand, L foot to square chip, R hand chickenwing, shuffle up until can get R foot onto edge in back and stand up to crimp below roof · TR. Sent it on TR. Cold,dry, sunny day, 45 degrees. Getting into the slot and levitating upwards felt great, simple. · Lead / Redpoint. Woohooo! I love this climb. 6 or 7 tries total. Fell at the 3rd bolt on my 3rd try today then just lowered and got the send! Now gotta do the OG. · Lead / Redpoint. Second go of the day. As sad as it makes me, the kneepad helped a lot. Incredible climb · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pretty tough, at least the top is chill. Beginning use toehooks to get mantle. Next part cross rh to crimp sidepull and get high feet. Then layback the bad slopers before getting knee bar, otherwise I can’t move off them · Everything up to the foot entry sequence was great, just kept falling after that. I think the right thing is getting the right foot higher when you scum it · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couldn't figure out the foot entry sequence on the flare. Just kept falling. · TR. Flare crux: layback using high L feet and R on face low knob and high chip. Then move L foot into rand smear to transition to other side. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard crux @ 3.5: possible w L crimp, LF dish, RF smear, R high sp for balance, move RF out, R fall into lower sp, LF out for L to arete. Then go up corner w R chickenwing and L gaston crimps, bumping up RF jam to aim for meh R crimp above · Lead / Redpoint. Nice one. Really only adds two short sequences, but the top of numba ten would probably make anything 4 stars. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Kinda stressful belay from dad. Fun! Hard. Need more burns to suss beta. And kneebar pads or pants. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Low crux felt harder than before somehow, maybe because it was in the sun · TR. TR in the shade after went much better. Stiff shoe / TC Pro might be the move. Big triangle hold - LF smear in scoop, RF up to jug and rock over / pistol. Cross LF behind then RF to top. LH on diagonal crimp LF kinda high and out to edge, LH arête, RH still squeezing sidepull to stand up, smear RF, LF to good black crystal, stay kinda low to swap feet, then LF really high into corner to find knee bar. Middle bit - LH on good corner hold and keep tension to reach up with RH to sidepull arête at obvious hold, then LH crimp/press to bring up LF to good edge Upper crux - RF good arête smear, RH good corner edge, LF good smear out a bit, LH crimp, RH to corner thumb on crimp, RF high to corner edge and rock over. RF on corner thumb crimp is key to getting RH up a couple moves later. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Maybe don’t try it in the sun. Didn’t go too well, although I finally figured out the transition so now I’ve done all the moves. · TR. Cruxes felt like getting into and out of knee bar (stem out?) and up high before small roof, where I used shouldery lockoff. 2 hangs on second go. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Good climbing! 3: slopey L arete, up LF to scoop, RF to hold, standup into faint ripple crimps, switch feet RF to point to reach clip Joining #10: R cross arete to L crimp in dihedral, R cross lean into seam pod, L bump sp up to sloper knob? R other seam pod to roof Corner above: up crimps to R palm knob, LF HIDDEN FOOT OUT LEFT! RF near R, L to crack Last 2: up crimps, L crimp near arete, R fall into faint diag crimp next to it. Insecure above around block - L crack left side, R right arete to slopey! ledge, L pocket crack · Lead / Redpoint. really good alternative for those that aren't in tune with the crux of Numbah 10 · TR. 2 hung it.
