Knee bar is feeling good and the first bludge feels better with the palm press. · TR. quick morning TR lap. cool temperature of 63, a very light rain, new resoled shoes, Mick Pearson's alpine harness that I borrowed, and not having climbed outside in 4 weeks. end result was the smoothest send I've ever had, where each crux just felt doable and easy without strenuous effort, just focus. wanted to immediately get on power horse but didn't have time. · TR. worked out some new beta for the bottom. Good movements off the first horn with some good feet. The knee bar beta turns out to be the best for the flare for me. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Blue totem / .4 if no stick clip to protect the start. Pulled through on the transition left - quite hot so sloper pinch didn’t work. Looking at photo, maybe transition even higher up · Lead / Redpoint. 3rd go, first index 5.12 in a day. For index, probably 12a (at least for taller folks IMO) · TR. quick lap in the morning. for the flare, press shoulder into the wall, move left hand into the crescent, right hand up above on thin crack, and just bring the right foot up to that little ledge. use shoulder to stabilize when bringing the foot up, don't try to scum and move up off the right foot until it's onto the ledge. then you can stand up. · TR. work through the bottom sequence up until the crossover still feels hard getting the left foot on the bad smear doesn't feel secure moving into the arete feels bad working on knee bar beta. made all the moves above that doesn't feel easy but it will go. · TR. aided through the bottom. felt very hard but it was after I projected japanese gardens · Lead / Fell/Hung. keep falling on the scumming right foot high enough. everything else is wired. I've sent it before, can't seem to remember the right moves · TR. fell getting into flare, shoes felt really slick all of a sudden. got top crux easily · Lead / Fell/Hung. cold, did on a sunny 35 degree day,but sun had just gone behind the mtns. got all moves, needed to take to warm up numb hands. did mix up last crux: remember to bring left hand up to get hidden side crimp. · Lead / Redpoint. 7 days of projecting during a summer heat wave. 6am conditions allowed the send. Fantastic line. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Managed every move except the crossover into the layback around the 6th bolt. I love this route · Lead / Redpoint. Sent it! scum right foot in flare, don't twist it. stand up. 2and crux: left hand up to right side crimp, skip left side crimps completely

routes.route_name: Dr. Sniff and the Tuna Boaters
routes.route_description: Climb the splitter cracks from the top of Pitch 1 on princely ambitions.  The crux comes at about 50 feet just before a ledge at the base of a corner/chimney.  This feature can be either climbed directly or liebacked.  It is a little bit friskier to lie it back, you can't really reach the crack to place gear.  Near the end of the lieback as it starts to get slopey, you may either discover a really cool trick to make the final move easy, or you may go for a good ride.
routes.route_location: Just right of pitch 2 on princely ambitions
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2 inches

route_comments.comment_text: EXCELLENT ROUTE and Great description of the last section of the climb:) Apr 12, 2010

Did this one on TR for the first time last weekend.  Very enjoyable finger crack to start with followed by a fun sequence into the chimney. Instead of doing the layback, I stayed inside the flare and found it suprisingly secure to chimney, but my partner, who is several inches taller, got spat out pretty quickly so maybe not the best strategy for taller folks. The gear I used inside the... more Did this one on TR for the first time last weekend.  Very enjoyable finger crack to start with followed by a fun sequence into the chimney. Instead of doing the layback, I stayed inside the flare and found it suprisingly secure to chimney, but my partner, who is several inches taller, got spat out pretty quickly so maybe not the best strategy for taller folks. The gear I used inside the chimney was a .5 at the base of the flare, then a blue alien and medium-size nut.  Other combinations of smaller gear are possible in there. Aug 2, 2010

Great stemming and liebacking at the beginning with great locks. Green Alien/red C3 is perfect for the crux and a bomber nut can be had right before starting the lieback at the top. I agree that the description of the last section is spot on. Spicy but safe! Mar 29, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Dumb fall at pre-shelf crux - stepped up w/ left instead of right. Discovered that a piece can be placed mid knee bar section. Good full warm up with Princely. · Follow. Kevin H. Clean. Continued up Beak Beak Beak & TPMV P5. Kevin led BBB, I led p5 TPMV. · TR. Tough route! Wouldn't even know how to place gear on the upper section if laybacking it · Lead. Chimney felt off widthy but got through it. Would like to get on it again. · Lead / Onsight. 0.2 to 0.75, single 1 and 2 + offsets. Purple and med nut at rest, 0.2 in chimney. I had left back on arete and both feet on slab with some arm bars and knee bar. · TR. From the top of princely ambitions, you can traverse to the right, and set up a top rope for this pitch · TR. crux moving out of crack: left hand thumbs up pinky lock in crack, L foot smear where crack turns, R foot jam just above, R hand side pull above crack bump to side pull up and right. L foot jam, R foot to knob, stand up into L foot jam top of crack, stand up and done · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tried to chimney the flaring top section and oozed out right before it got easy · Follow. Bjorn led and chimneyed the flare at the top. I did too and it was hard. Probably easier to lie back it · TR. TR clean, so fun. Still a bit intimidated to lead, need to figure out second gear placement in v-slot to make it feel more chill. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Right handed under kling crimp to finish out the lapyback. Trust the feet even when it gets slopey. Black totem before the mantle move into flare. Perfect Small silver nut after mantel. Then .1/.2 offset before laybackinf. · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell, then fell again, then fell SIDEWAYS then ran away out left. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a couple falls trying to get into the flaring layback, wasn't loving my gear and bailed for time sake but would be worth coming back for · TR. very fun. Lay back mid crux and knee bar flare to get good gear. · TR. Clean! Corner switch is the physical crux, get right hand on sidepull, right foot really high on face dish and layback up to skip the shitty holds. Only really get 2 pieces in the flare, purple totem and then maybe another or 0.75 or purple BD offset nut. Another higher spot for blue or yellow totem, you could maybe wedge yourself in to place then step back down. Gun it until layback hands disappear, then right knee bar, reach left hand to 2 finger pocket, shimmy knee jam higher, then loooong reach with right hand to the jug! Horrifying lead prospect. Awesome TR · Lead / Flash. Holy crap this thing is good! Lowered over it and decided to give it a lead go. Soooo fun!! · Lead / Onsight. w RB. Managed to hold on for the OS - don't miss the secret jug! Place some gear and then fire to the top. · TR. Clean, lowered after topping out princely. Super rad, crux still the thin crack and moving up through the corner into the flare. Flare felt tamer than before, gun it to the end of the layback, double knee bar (place a piece??) then reach to deep 2 finger rail from knee bars, then home free! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard boulder problem then hard flare. Would be fun to project more · TR. TRS at end of day. 1st lap hung at thin crack cuz I wussed out but got layback clean. 2nd lap clean to layback but blew a foot starting it, 2nd tho clean. Otakis are great for this! BD red offset nut from R knee bar high on layback, no hands rest! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Didn't have enough small gear so bailed left to PA at ledge. · TR. 2x did as lieback..think you could place gear. did all the moves felt easier than slow children · TR. TRS. 3 laps, 2 & 3 clean, even with some gear faffeing for redirects! 2 falls on lap one at step right out of thin crack and slipped halfway through layback. Left knee jam only once where layback feature changes to get a piece, purple BD offset nut & 0.5 cam at start, sling a block near finish! Gun it, keep feet high! · TR. Fell twice at the the move right, foot sequence get left toe jam in flaring crack, right foot wide right to chicken head, left hand side pull, right hand grope up. layback start similar to velvet pedestal, final section can get knee bar to place pro. · Lead / Onsight. super fun blasted through the finger crack and lieback section, as little run out but that was my choice haha · Follow. anthony led. fell off on the Crux this time. man I love those arm knee bars on this one. · Lead / Onsight. never arm barred between my leg and the wall before...that was cool. · Lead / Onsight. Felt pretty easy. Super fun climb. Could have used another .2 or .1 · Lead / Fell/Hung. Improved from my one try leading this last year. Hung once. Fun. Felt way easier · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very hot out and I was really nervous. Hung several times. Lots of small gear on the initial crack. .3-.4. Also placed a 2 in the beginning. Lots of feet as you go up into the finger crack. Would have liked a metolius 0 and x4 red. Maybe alien black for t · Lead / Onsight. Super fun! Crux move is a high right hand that's hard to find. Look higher and use the right foot nub · Lead / Fell/Hung. Difficult, pumpy lieback. 1 opportunity for gear placement low inside corner. Small nuts/cams high up. · Follow. jay got this one, i did newest industry next (which has a hard move!) · Lead. Flailed because I didn't lieback. Lie it back when you need to place gear! · Climbed halfway without enough small gear. Down aided. Bring 3x .3 all the mini shit. ð

routes.route_description: Balancy steep face moves to a thin crack (crux), then a 10c crack, followed by 5.9 climbing up around the flake.One can continue up the finish to Model Worker, or follow the original aid line (A3) out left for pitch two.
routes.route_location: Just left of the Numbah Ten dihedral.
routes.route_protection: Stick clip the first bolt, then thin gear to fist-sized cams.

routes.route_description: Start on P1 of Princely. Where Princely goes left on the hand traverse, instead continue up and right.Several 11-ish moves, though the hardest may be at the second bolt, where you must do a long reach or dyno. Ends at the base of Tadpole.
routes.route_location: Shares the same start as Princely Ambitions.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3". Four quickdraws.

routes.route_description: Another Index classic.Godzilla is the crack/corner system immediately right of City Park (5.13c), a fairly obvious landmark.P1: (5.9) Start in a shallow right-facing groove/face, just right of being directly below the obvious City Park crack. Climb up and trend left to the big flake at the start of the main crack/corner system. Continue up the obvious right-facing corner-crack system and then traverse left along some ledges up to a bolted belay/rap station.There are several variations to this pitch.Bottom: (10b) Start further left, climb the City Park bolt ladder.Middle: (10a) Right after the flake, go straight up into the corner instead of laybacking out right.Top: Move left early. There are several points to do this.You need a 70m rope to rap down from the belay.P2: (10b) (AKA "Leaping Lizards") - Move right from the anchor, clip a bolt, right again, then head up a crack to a v-slot with a pin and another bolt. Step right (3rd bolt) and stem/mantle to the chains.From here, there are also pitches that go further right to the top of Natural Log Cabin and the base of Salad Fingers.P3: There is a third pitch. Please tell if you've done it, and we'll update this info.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Standard trad rack to 3", bolted belay/rap station

route_comments.comment_text: A really fun variation called "Bambi" steps left via a long reach and a mantle about 15 feet before the regular leftward traverse.  This probably makes it 5.10-, and is a more direct line.  Even better than the original godzilla, which is already ultra classic. Apr 15, 2006

A great pitch! You can rap/lower is a single 70m rope. Nuts and two sets of cams from TCUs to #3.  Long slings helpful.  If you're not comfortable jamming, the flake section may seem harder than 5.9! Jul 2, 2006

Stellar line on impeccable rock.  It is possible to rap this route with one 60m rope.  I did it today.  We used an intermediate anchor (the anchor for Batskins) about 60 feet off the deck and to the climbers left when facing Godzilla.  Note: The anchor I am talking about, however, is NOT the anchor roughly 30 feet below and also to the left of the top of Godzilla. Jul 29, 2008

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. super fun, starts kind of scary, have to get pretty high before first pro which was a .1 :P glad i brought lost of gear, its a long route and I used it up:-) took like a 15 foot whipper on the lay back, the lay back is just long and sustained, i tried to put my foot on the outside and lost my balance. you can also crack climb this apparently seems less strenuous but more awk. struggled in the top twin cracks as well, its just a very sustained long route as a whole but does have lots of good rest. the step around to the second ledge was pretty secure, next time i do it i'd consider skipping the pro on the first ledge, makes for a hard clean · Lead / Flash. Took the hand crack (right). Mantle after 3” section, then stepped to the left to do the final mantle. Protect the follower with an extra piece up high before stepping over, but it is possible to stay low and go left to avoid the potential pendulum · Lead / Redpoint. Got it clean, better gear placements and decision to move through crux · Lead / Redpoint. Led with Billy and Vadim following, went on to City Park and Slow Children · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to grab a draw to clip at the flake. Going from layback to jamming. Good jams above a #3 · Lead / Fell/Hung. .4 20 ft up. Get good piece and lay back middle. Get deep arm up high, climb through. Got pumped from too much gear at layback, tried to jam. · Lead / Redpoint. Led this for the first time since my bail and finish a few months ago. Felt super chill and actually crack climbed it this time! · Lead / Fell/Hung. bb's first trad whip on a #3. Start gear: protect with nut, and .4 in horizontal pod (after initial moves - some juggy pockets out left below horizontal) when layback flake gets wide make sure to jam feet to get to top of flake · Lead / Fell/Hung. Accidentally did the 10a variation in the middle, that part went great! Foot slipped right at the end of the climb and took a whipper; aggghhhhh! · Lead / Fell/Hung. had absolutely horrendous head game on this. took a few times, pulled on gear, and took a practice fall which overall was good exposure to this style of climbing. however this mightve set me back mentally on trad. gotta take more practice falls on easier climbs. · Follow. Super hard. Off the ground even slick and hard. Very too on ledge for final moves was sketch. Jillian lead. · Lead / Onsight. 2 nuts right off the deck through blocky terrain...excellent crack after that. crux is for sure the mantle · Follow. Right after rapping with Chase Haigh and B showed up so we followed them back up Godzilla and went to Slow Children · Lead / Flash. I finally psyched myself up to lead this. It really wasn’t too bad. There’s a good .4 placement in a horizontal crack in the left side after standing up from the boulder start moves. I think I used some triples of finger sized pieces. I brought gear .1-3. I also used 2x#3 · Lead / Onsight. Extend draws before changing cracks 2x. Marginal pro first few moves · Lead / Redpoint. Felt quite good. This climb is 10a minimum. Don’t really need the #4. Optional. Didn’t place nuts. Don’t bring them. Double length sling is nice. Long pitch. · Lead / Fell/Hung. no gear for first 15 ft?!?! used another party's TR to place small cams and then continued up. Save a #2 and runner to protect crack before traverse. brought 3 5.s and would have used 4. · TR. Awesome climb. No good places to protect until 15-20ft off the ground. Can do the big flake section as a layback, with decent transitions to still place protection. However, its possible to somewhat stay in the crack, but we ended up partially face-climbing. · TR. Super fun climb but it was very hard for me! Really enjoyed it. · TR. Max lead. I TRd again. Need to get the courage up to lead next time · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took on the flake and had a second rest further up, pumpy but another great climb · Lead. First time leading it in two years, felt so much more casual that my first time climbing at Index · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung once, got pumped/scared on the flake! W/ Alex, bring doubles and took lots of small stuff. I used a 4, probably could have used some medium to large nuts to save cams. Extend rope to move leftward to reduce drag. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Apparently, I hit the mountain project word count limit trying to be detailed about the beta, so I have saved personal notes under 2024 athletic section. Tripples upto .5 and doubles upto #3 with a set of stoppers and lots of slings (cant have enough because I needed to extend most placements, sometimes to prevent the deeper walk) for zero rope drag. · Lead / Pinkpoint. Climbed on Sandy's gear. A ~red ballnut would be nice to not have a ground fall after the direct start's black totem. · Lead / Flash. First 5.9 trad Index flash. Beta: Small nut near the first hold to protect the first couple of moves. Then there is a big run out unless you can find a .3 in a small pod to the right before a layback move, or a .4 in a horizontal crack to the left. Gotta look hard for this. Then chill climbing up to a big horn that you can sling with double length sling, seems pretty bomber. Then a bit more climbing, I think I placed a green or purple. Then you have to decide whether to go left or right around the flake. I placed a #1 at the bottom of the right side, extended, and then stepped over to the left. Supposedly the right is more fun with good jamming technique. Be sure to save a 0.4 for the final moves. You gotta do a couple of ring locks and place left foot on a marginal foothold, and then reach up to a good jug, rail, and then work over left. · Lead / Redpoint. Good breaks when you need them. Would like to continue to repeat and try more jamming, better technique. Feels good to finally send! · TR. Followed Ryan’s lead. Such a good pitch. For sure 10a. And that fucking start is always unnerving. A #4 could be used to protect down low, or other .4-.75 pieces. · Lead / Flash. With Tbird and Rich! Rainy and ominous. Surprisingly comfortable with unprotected start. Felt very secure.

routes.route_fa: FA P1 short: Roger Johnson, Doug Leen. P1 full: Kit Hanes, Bob Lagenbach. FFA P1 short: Peter Croft. P1 Full: Dick Cilley, Dante Leonardi
routes.route_description: Killer line.  Crux is getting out of the thin crack and above on the slab. I think the line goes up into the (gut wrenching) shallow corner above. But you can cross over to sag and top out that way.
routes.route_location: Thin crack 20'left of sag start.
routes.route_protection: Small nuts plus cams. a #6 HB brass works great above the crux. some tat on a pin in lower crack.

route_comments.comment_text: The tat looks unsightly, but both pins are driven so deeply into the crack that they are impossible to clip with a carabiner, and it requires some effort to even get webbing or cord through the eyes. Changing this out every year or so seems like a good decision, the old stuff was faded and crusty. If the pins were gone, I don't think they would need to be replaced, but since they are still... more The tat looks unsightly, but both pins are driven so deeply into the crack that they are impossible to clip with a carabiner, and it requires some effort to even get webbing or cord through the eyes. Changing this out every year or so seems like a good decision, the old stuff was faded and crusty. If the pins were gone, I don't think they would need to be replaced, but since they are still there, and still BOMBER, they may as well offer something you can clip, not just get tetanus from. Despite the description above, most folks find the crux to be getting OFF the slab stance, or pulling into the chimney just below the first anchor. There's nothing in the flare or the roof above which is nearly as hard as several of the lower moves below anchor #1. The blocky roof after anchor #2, rated .11c or .12a in the two guidebooks, is more like 5.10+. It must be a misprint or maybe even Index has a token over-graded pitch. You can lower back to the ground from anchor #3 with a 70m. Apr 14, 2014

I found the pro in the roof to be much smaller and further apart than I would have preferred. 2 of the 3 pieces (both brass) I placed after the Sag chains zippered when I took tension on the anchor. Really cool 3D climbing worth doing at least once! Maybe consider pre-inspecting the gear. Oct 8, 2020
Finger crack to slab Pull crux then into chimney Exit to the right Nov 22, 2020

routes.route_description: Climb out right past a flake (5.8) or directly up past 3 bolts (5.11-) to a ledge, which can be reached via a long rightward traverse from Princely Ambitions. (if you've approached this way, it's easy to build a gear belay on the ledge). Stem up the white overhanging corner, placing gear and clipping a bolt before a stem and mantle out left (crux). Trend up and left of the quartz intrusion, using bomber small cams and wires (bring runners) and generally looking around for side-to-side options on knobs and flakes. Clip one (replaced) bolt and move up to the anchor on face holds.From the anchor atop full Iron Horse (also reached via many other routes)
routes.route_location: Begin from atop Full Iron Horse/Full Amandla. It's easy to get here also via Sag. (climbed through the Iron Horse roof). If you don't mind missing the first 20' of the pitch, you can reach this by traversing right from Princeley Ambitions, and making a gear belay on the ledge just above the bolted anchors.
routes.route_protection: Rack to #1 or #2, doubles in tips and finger cams. Wires and runners.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Swung in after working JG. Fun moderate pitch in need of some love.

routes.route_name: It's a Dog's Life, but You Can Picnic with Us
routes.route_description: The leftmost of the 3 pitches above P1 of Japanese Gardens. Traverse left to the shallow right facing corner. With difficulty work up on tips in the crack, arête pinches, and knobs. About halfway up, the crack on the right gives some options and a nice moves finishes to a mantle onto the ledge.
routes.route_location: Above pitch 1 of "Japanese Gardens". The leftmost of the 3 cracks. Finishes on the ledge with chain anchors above pitch 2 of "Japanese Gardens"  rappel to the P1 anchor of JG. 70m single rope reaches the ground from P1 of JG.
routes.route_protection: LA's on FA. All pins are now gone. Easily top-roped from chains atop P2 of "Japanese Gardens"UPDATE2 new pins have been added as of 4/10/14UPDATE 11/19/14 new pins have since fallen out or been removed.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. WOW! Stimulating. Stoked to take the sharp end. w/ Jeremy Date Approx

routes.route_fa: Lowell Anderson, Dave Page, Jim Stoddard. FFA: Terry Lien, Jon Nelson
routes.route_description: A central, classic full-wall route.P1 (short): Starts with a fun 10a section in a short left-facing dihedral. Trends right then back left and up a wide crack (protects great with a #3 Camalot). This "pitch" ends at the first chains.P1 (full): Past the first chains, the wide section continues, with high steps and laybacking protected by a #4 Camalot. Two cruxes remain where the crack peters down to fingers then hands. Finish on a finger crack with big moves off edges and locks by stemming and traversing to the right (11b).P2: A short jam/lieback that gets progressively harder until the last move (11b). Ledgy climbing leads to an anchor up and right.P3: Step left and enter a flare with a fingercrack (11a). Physical jamming leads up around the left side of a roof and up a slab to a belay.P4: A slab leads to steeper slab climbing through left-facing corners and arches (11c). Easier slabs then lead to a belay at the top of the wall (9).(Jonah's description for P1, Drewsky's for P2-4.)
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Doubles through #2 Camalots, single #3 and #4, some small nuts.  Some people (Tripplet) lead the first pitch on about 6 pieces.  Whatever.  You can run TR laps if you hang a 70m rope, but make SURE you place a directional (#1 Metolius) to the left of the anchor or the rope will get completely jammed in the crack and you won't be able to move it at all.

route_comments.comment_text: You can do just the first section at 5.9+ and stop at the chains.  A small TCU is useful to protect the last move before the chains.  This is a fine, short outing requiring a bunch of different techniques.   For protection bring one set of cams TCUs-#4 Camalot and some nuts. Jul 2, 2006
We were able to rap from the top of P3 using a 70m rope (one 60m may work too). Jul 12, 2009
A 60m will only work if you stop at the hanging belay half way up pitch 1. Mar 6, 2010

Probably whipped 10+ times and took another 40. Second crux was a challenge · 5 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. With Rio. Finally checked out all 4 pitches. Led P2. TR'ed P2 again on the way down. Feels like P2>4>1>3 in terms of difficulties. · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Finally, totally improvised at first Crux but fought through. · 1 pitch. TR. Fell multiple times, amazing route. Do it later when I’m stronger · 1 pitch. TR. Really struggled in 2nd crux. Want to go back and try leading now · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. .5, .4 ext, red nut, 3 ext, 3 ext, .2 ext, bolt, 4, .5, .3, 2, .3, 4 HB, .5 · Lead / Fell/Hung. w/ lucas. flailed and aided my way up all four pitches. begged the question of whether i've ever actually climbed a 5.11 before this. psyched to come back. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Great conditions; fraught footwork. Bury me with a blue totem when I go. · Lead / Redpoint. Full first pitch. RP fourth try of the night with Shane · 1 pitch. TR. First crux went easily: L hand in higher good lock, R hand reach to marginal, L foot in shallow toe jam under roof, reach through · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. tried the straight-in method for the #4 wide section today, felt more tiring than the lieback method... work on finding the rests. First crux felt easier today with high smearing feet... just don’t use the crack for feet on first crux · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Cruised pretty good up to the roof crux. Messed up beta en whipped just before good lock. Roof beta is to get high thumbs down right and pinky down left, bump up right to next lock and left to the old right lock. Move left foot up to highest jam, keep torso facing crack. Bump right to good jam and left to hand jam. Aided up a bit of the stemming, psyche lost. Oh well next time · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Led P3 clean. Did a TR lap as well. · TR. Trs p2 1x & p3 2x. Did climb to right of p3 as well. Hot · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. I was SLIPPING out of this thing cause I was so sweaty. Jeeeeeeez. Miss those Index summa condis · TR. Climbed with a couple of German visitors Paul and Sophie. Need to work that first crux out again that still feels desperate. Second crux feels significantly easier for me and repeatable · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Tough burn with the bois quince and salmon. Really amazinf · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on P1. Led p2-3 clean. TR ed p1 clean on the way down. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Led p1 and p2 clean on 7/24 and Stamati took it to the top. · Lead. Did JG full with Matt Michie, lead p2&4 Multi fell on p2 but sent everything else. My gold DMM offset that I bootied off JGp1 a week or so ago is now fused in p2. Just gotta comeback for p2 now · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. 5.11b my ass. The 4s section is super challenging, fingers section is chill. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to pull through finger lock crux, skin was shredded. · 1 pitch. Lead / Flash. Easier than Freeway and Butterballs. Similar difficulty to Shirly · Lead / Fell/Hung. Full with Simon fell once on two make sure to get left in the last good finger jam. And fell twice on last pitch bring two yellow totems two black totems and two blue totems. · 10 pitches. TR. Pitched 1-3 TRS plus another 10 pitches of other stuff on the upper part of the wall. Long hot day. · TR. Jack put it up, got all the moves with a couple hangs at the crux. Layback the wide, forget about the butterfly · 2 pitches. Lead. This is the greatest and best climb in the world :) and sushi farmer wooooow :) .5ext, graylienext, reddmmext, 2or3, 3or4, golddmm, draw, 4ext, .4or.5, .3, 2, .3 · 1 pitch. Lead. First crux more wet. Second crux felt easier. Felt good to finally get the full lead. · 2 pitches. TR. Two burns, one hang, both cruxes were wet, fired cruxes several times. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to aid second and forth pitch. But both should go at some point. · 1 pitch. TR. Followed paddy who crushed it and sent today. Nice job paddy · 1 pitch. TR. Burn of pitch 1 Japanese Gardens, got better finger beta for first crux. Would like to come back and figure out my feet. Thinking a different shoe on my right foot. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Frick, bring triples in black and blue totems if linking first two pitches · 1 pitch. TR. Just the first pitch and holy hell i mean it was in the sun but wow was that hard · Lead / Fell/Hung. .4, .3, 2, 4, .2, anchor, 4, 1, gold nut, 2, .3, .1/.2, .5 · Follow. Followed up Kevin the whole thing, so damn hard. He did great, I’m psyched. · Lead / Fell/Hung. The full four this time! Lead 2 & 4, all clean except for the cruxy (and wet) move left on p4, which took a few tries to do a spanny move bypassing the wet slopers. Nice for P1 to feel smooth (even if just following). w Bill · 1 pitch. TR. I'd love to work on this as a project to lead. Pitch 1! · 2 pitches. TR. TRd P1 got the short version of P1 clean then fell a lot haha · 1 pitch. 1 pitch. Did 3rd pitch 1x TRS. Exited right at top roof. · 1 pitch. TR. First pitch. Would need gear to 4 and extra in fingers for finger lock section at top. Cool route. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Feel at finger crack but found new way. Get left fingers in good pod and right hand higher. Lay back and get a foot smear just under the .3 cam. Right foot still goes to foot chip. The layback should allow an easy move to the sinker fingers. Turn to face the wall as fingers sink in to help torque them. Ethan says a nut goes above the last .3 cam · Lead / Fell/Hung. Felt hard. Finger crux. Left hand high in second pod. Lean into wall. Right hand above. Left foot smear on edge of slab. Right foot kick up far right edge. Bump left foot higher. · 1 pitch. TR. Tried pulling out he first crux several times but eventually gave it up. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Save blue, black totem, .1/.2 for top. .5,.4, .3 or big grey nut, 2, 3 (or4), .3, anchor, 4, 2?, .5, black totem, 2, .3,.2, .1/.2, .75 · 1 pitch. TR. Once again first crux feels worse - can't do move in iso. · 3 pitches. Follow. Lap 1 to mid anchor Lap 2 to chains, 5 falls Lap 3 to chains, 2 falls · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. First crux now a problem, couldn't pull. Second crux goes easily with layback/foot match beta. · 1 pitch. TR. clean. for top crux use layback foot plus hand foot match beta · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. With Vivian and Long. Unsent :( Turns out warming up on JG might not be the brightest idea lol · 1 pitch. TR. crux 1: left hand in last good finger lock thumbs up, long lock off right hand all the way up to good lock where it widens (bump if needed). then work feet up. crux 2: kick right to knob, stem left foot. left hand on highest juggy side pull, work feet up, right hand sloper (right side of ledge). then left foot jam, left hand as high as possible to finger lock. left foot on nub, right foot on slabby foot right of crack, reach up right hand to good finger lock, then done · 3 pitches. TR. tape r index, l pinky. first crux goes with right lock above good lock, bring l into good lock, bump right. l foot toejam. upper crux use r foot knob smear, l lock to bump foot. 2 good whips · 1 pitch. Lead. Crux: L fingerlock in second pod, R to marginal one, smear RF, then bump to good. Pull-up feet after Top: gear in left crack: yellow offset nut, .2 cam in good pod, stem to right crack, gaston cam pod to bring up LF, R goodish hold (opt .2/.3 behind? Or small nut in non-pod part of left crack - last gear before runout!) R Gaston above, work feet up left then right, L to pod, aim R for crimp. L to corner, RF match R. · 1 pitch. Lead. crack was wet, so I aided through the Boulder problem section. didn't have a number four, so just ran out the section after the chains for about 15 ft. heady but straightforward . · Lead / Redpoint. Finally got this classic! First attempt of the year. Switched beta to use the crimp and it felt smooth. Dunno why I didn’t revisit that last year. · 1 pitch. TR. at low crux, keep l hand thumbs down in layback below roof and reach up to R locks. bump L to pinky down lock, bump R to good lock. L foot below roof and huck · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Finally! I think this was my sixth try total. Got the send train with Ahad and Sergey who did it in a day. · Lead. Two 4s would feel comfy for the layback, but doable with 1. 3x .3 · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. went to the second anchor, fell because i was scared. · 1 pitch. Did 3rd pitch 1x TRS. Exited right at top roof. Cool variation. · 2 pitches. TR. Trs p2 & p3. Great pitches. Did another 1/2 pitch of something up and slightly right of anchors (below tommy sandbox rood) · Lead / Fell/Hung. Grp of 3 with Reid and Mike. Led p1 which may have been one of my favourite gear pitches anywhere. P4 slab BP was wicked fun. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 0.5,.4,.4 add alpine sling for first part. #3, .3 Extend second sling on chains 4 alpine slings First crux has a low right foot on the lip of the overhang. Left foot small knob commit and reach right for sinker fingers. Second crux, add sling to #2 then I move right, place .3, then stem back over. Use right hand to bump right foot higher. Push up on right foot and pull left fingers. Then lean back right and palm it. High right foot · TR. New top crux beta: Go out right. Get left toe in right crack then get right foot above it · 1 pitch. TR. Wide part takes two 4s, transition to pulling into and over the face to really big crack, stem up to anchor. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Got down to 1 hang. Didn’t have the gas for the last move. Kind of just let go. Really nice night though. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. fell at first crux, tried laybacking. fell again/took at next crux · 1 pitch. TR. Gear to 1st Anchor: 1, 0.4 + sling, 0.2 + sling, 2, 4 + sling, 0.1 Gear to Finish: 4 + sling, 0.5, 0.3, 0.1 optional at crux, 2/3 at rest, 0.2 + sling right crack, 0.1/0.2 offset above, 0.5, 0.2/0.1 to left to keep rope out of crack., anchor, 2nd #4, · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Same as last time basically but fewer falls. This was the early am session where Jess left a knot in the rope!!! Oops lol so had to go back up for it leading on the other end. Meant I got another lead in. But boy it got sunny fast. Evening is better :) · 1 pitch. TR. Pulled on one cam mid fingers crux due to collateral ligament. Otherwise felt very chill :) love that upper boulder problem. And surfed stern stem crux on the way down :> · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Couple hangs at both cruxes. Really cool lived up to the hype · TR. Crux was harrd. Lots of figuring it out. I think using high left hold, right crimp doing a big power layback into the jam is the move. Definitely gotta do some laps on it and get it down · 1 pitch. TR. Tr first pitch! Forced me to crack climb lol fun and engaging · Lead / Fell/Hung. Full 1st pitch, these fat sausage fingers struggled on the thin finger locks at the crux’s · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Finally sent it! First go of day, just barely held it together, thanks Viv! · 2 pitches. TR. 5.9/10a start pitch felt hardest beta-wise. Still find wide stuff hard. Mostly lie-backed it. The thin fingery part of JG was straightforward but ofc still strenuous. Felt easier than Even Steven though (perhaps more sustained with easier individual moves?). · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. down to 2 falls on lead for full P1, then did a TR lap to work the cruxes some · 1 pitch. Lead. good warm up for powerhorse, sent it. top ropes to first chains, then led the rest. that put me in a great headspace, the route felt pretty easy to execute. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. first go on lead, bitched out after placing the 4 on the lay back. went down and did it again on tr. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. probably 5 or 6 total falls/takes, iwith a proper ride on the last part. thanks karissa for the catches! will continue to work maybe with shade and actual warmups · 1 pitch. TR. Full first pitch. Hung once at lower crux and twice at upper crux · 1 pitch. TR. 2 falls on a TR go (next time go for finger not fist; and reach higher into crack from the right edge). need to lead it next time · 1 pitch. Lead. felt tired , 2nd route of the day, sent it though. · 1 pitch. TR. warmed up on the bottom, then went ground up on the second one all the way to the finger lock crocs. from there I passed that and worked out the top sequence. top sequence starts off with right foot on large nub right hand inside pull left hand inside pull, next smear left foot up 4 in on front face, then step right foot up on small nub, place left foot in the Right face lobe and then reach right hand up to crimp rail left hand goes out to the left finger locks high then right foot comes up very high into the top node from there Cam the right foot in and reach right hand up to the bottom of the flare left foot goes out to smear against the side rail. lay back the top by working the feet up The left side get the right hand down on the crimp rail and then work your right foot up to the crimp, from there stand up on the crimp while laying back the flare I got a handjam and the top of the flare which helps a lot. stand up reach right hand high to the finger lock and that's the end of the route. · 1 pitch. Lead. great. did it clean, top felt easy. right ft in crack, left foot, then right hand on rail, move right foot high up in crack, then left foot out, then left hand lieback into flare, bring right foot up onto right ledge rail . · 1 pitch. TR. first pitch is dialed. gear for the first could be 2 4s? a .4 for the second placement works great. figured out going to the chains a heal toe cam works better than standing on the rail with the left. the second pitch crux one ) move through the wide crack laying it back fast. crux2) after milking the rest, the finger sequence is left, right then work feet up on the left face stand on nub then bump hands up a little the get right hand hight and kick the index finger with a thumb pitching the bottom. smear the right foot way right then left foot on the sloper and get the left hand into the bottom of the crack then pull hard and slam a good jam up hight with the right. current idea for the top r , l foot in bottom then move left hand out left then move right foot in and lock then stand up and reach the jug? new high point. was the top crux · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. With Lukasz. P1 full. Finally sent!!! 7 TR laps, 10th lead go. Came full circle since my first time on JG was with Lukasz. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. With Brandon. First go: 1 fall - peeled off the very last move before the good hand jam on the second crux lmao. Second go: too worked for a proper redpoint attempt. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. With Niki. 2 falls one at each crux on first go. 1 fall on the second crux on second go.

routes.route_fa: Lowell Anderson, Dave Page, Jim Stoddard. FFA: Terry Lien, Jon Nelson
routes.route_description: An abridged version of the first pitch of Japanese Gardens, this first part (to the lower anchors) offers great moderate climbing and is a good warm-up or fun lead on its own for 5.9+/5.10- climbers. It follows a shallow right-facing corner at the start, which becomes a wide flake.Please be considerate of faster parties hoping to blitz to the harder stuff above as this short pitch is the access to super-classic 4-star 5.11+ climbing.
routes.route_location: Starts on Japanese Gardens. About mid-way between Princely Ambition and Godzilla.
routes.route_protection: single rack to 4"
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took at entrance to left ramp. Took at wide crack, needed better jams. Save .3 or have 5 for move to chains · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. 1 very cold TR lap and then sent first lead try. Could be nice to have 2 #3's for the wide section, ran it out a little but would have been a clean fall. · Lead / Onsight. Was going for the whole p1 but fell out of OW and whipped immediately onto #4 after the first chains lol. Then was getting late and Andrew wanted to go. Must come back for full send next time. 4 pieces to anchor. · TR. Kurt H on belay! free climbed first 1/3 til the thin seam and crack splits. Aided the rest of the way up. Climbers Fest clinic - improvised aid & french free with Adam B · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got stumped in the wide section up top, overall super fun also. · Lead. One hang. Fell going into #3 crack with first. Needed to layback with left foot on edge then in crack. · Lead / Redpoint. not sure if I onsighted but I did this a few times while trying full P1 of JG. approximate date · Lead / Onsight. A little spicy off the 2nd piece of gear. Did with Jakob. Clipping the chains is a tricky cunt too · Follow. Erron led, felt hard, fell twice. Again with the pumpy bro feel. Lots of hard laybacks and pulling up hard/mantling in lower town walls. #4 section was hard, wear long sleeves next time. Last move to the chains was also tenuous. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fun climb. A nice wide hands crack. Felt pumped from the get go from previous days climbing. #4 towards top · Lead / Fell/Hung. Did much worse this time. Multiple takes, way more pumped from the previous two climbs · TR. Max lead and flashed. Haley trd and had a take in the middle of the crux section. That section would be a scary lead for me. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung once right below the wide section. Need to find a better stance while plugging the 1. Great 3 to bumping 4 on loose fists. Eventually use the outside of the flake outside the crack, I lay backed a piece of this while bumping 4. Burly, But excellent. · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd try, bailed 1st try. wide at the top and strenuous! 3rd 10 ever and a proud lead for me :) · Lead / Fell/Hung. Almost had it clean, had to take once right before the ledge · Lead / Fell/Hung. Climbed with Rachel as first climb back was pumpy amd didn’t bring a 4 · Lead / Fell/Hung. David gave me lots of awesome gear beta... David and Joe coached and encouraged me thru the crux of pulling that linebacker onto a right foot. Sadly, after pulling that move my right calf was Elvis legging like crazy and shortly after I got the #.4 in, I grabbed the webbing before clipping the rope. I continued up snd got super scared on the handle traversal and took so long on it haha. David and Joe encouraged me to stick with it again and I'm so glad I did. However, once I got to the handjam it wasn't quite as restful as I'd hoped, so I hung. Gear: #.5, #.3, (possible #.1 before crux move?), #.4, #2, #3, #4, #.3, and finally can add a black totem for extra security for the last move. The last move is not bad at all to that jug :) Just inch up on left hip/ back as far as possible till layback + left foot/leg in wide crack then throw to great right foot and grab the jug. Send it next time... · TR. TRd it after leading it to dial in the feeling of all the moves, especially the traversal crux at the bottom and getting up into the #2/#3 crack. It feels really solid, especially the top part to clip the chains, so I'm hoping I get it clean next time. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bailed before the wide section because was too scared. Dialed in the sequence on TR after Anthony got the rope up. · Lead / Onsight. Great climb. Fairly pumpy (I liebacked the 4s section). Also tired from the day before. .2 in the thin seam, then .4. Once on the flake rail I plugged a #1 then in the hand crack #2, #3, #4. And at the last move a .3 and .1 in right flake. Maybe next season I’ll try the first full pitch. After I climbed, this guy attempted to lead rope solo the thing. Was super inexperienced and sketch and took a fall from the jug horn after the thin section. Ripped a .2 (from a spot where I placed a .4) fell ~30 ft. And stopped 1ft from the ledge. No helmet. Would have been gravely injured if the crux .2 cam blew or if he had any more slack in the system. Scary. We offered to belay a regular lead, he pumped out and took a huge whip, then came down and Bjorn climbed the thing again to get the gear. Yowza · Climbed it with Cam, only the first 5.9 section and it kicked our ass. Clearly I need to get in better shape cause I bailed like a whiny little baby on the upper hand crack Bring a #4 and nuts · Follow. Excellent but found the off width at the chains to be the crux · Alright so Joey and I split this lead. I did the first part and there is this sketchy face traverse section that scared me and then you have to pull over this little ledge where the crack widens A LOT. Joey led that section, and I liebacked the whole thing when I followed · Lead. Jam slipped and i took a 20 footer about 2 moves from topping out the flake and hurt my ankle pretty badly. Managed to finish the climb, gotta get it clean next time! Used a .1-.3, 2, 3, 1 alpine. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took my way up to the base of the wide crack and called it a day. Mentally very spooky! · Lead / Fell/Hung. With grant — whipper into the first slab pocket and unable to reach the anchors · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took when it widened to #4. found the top out slippery and scary. · TR. Followed Aivy. Beware of rope drag and we found the top to feel very wide. She wished she had 2 4s. · Lead. Definitely was not pretty. Rope drag was bad. Bring two #4's for upper. Had to actually aid to get to chains. Maybe #6 would fit??? Wished I had bigger hands and wasn't short overall. · Lead / Onsight. First pitch in Index. Crux was clipping the chains, strange anchor. · Lead / Fell/Hung. took a nasty whipper trying to clip the chains : ( · 4 pitches. TR. Led it almost to the top and then just kept taking big whippers - witnessed the fitness. Ran laps on TR w/Chris. · Lead / Flash. Hard, but got it clean. Wide corner crack, and tricky move to the anchor but protected with a nut, brought 0.3-4 with some doubles · Follow. Fun! Learned some great crack technique. Feeling strong and more confident on granite. With Josh · Lead / Redpoint. 0.75z4, orange totem, 0.2/0.3 Offset and yellow alien out left, 0.1/0.2 Offset (decent), blk tot (mehh) in crux, 0.3 &0.4 z4, blue totem (careful, get eyes on it) start of rail, 0.3/0.4 Offset end of rail, WC #1,2,3 then bump 4 up fist. 0.2 & blue tot at end, leave the big cams behind! · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. face the wall at the top chimney, tool twice om the fist crack, use the chock stones in the crack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took too long in finger rail before hand crack, got spooked by flaring crack and placing blind gear, hung on a cam. Blk tot at bottom then blue totem at top, then step up and layback into the hand crack & rest. 0.75 & orange totem low, blk & blue totem left before slab step right, 0.1/0.2 & 0.2/0.3 cams high reach before slab, then 0.3 & 0.4 after. hand crack 1,2,3,4 then #6 & 0.2-0.3 great for top out. could skip the 6 (which was really good, better than the 5, but in the way a lot trying to left side chimney) and place 2 small pieces at top. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had a lot of trouble on the layback. Can’t figure out the balance. 2-3 falls.

routes.route_description: Start as for the last pitch of TPMV, clipping the first bolt on that pitch, but then breaking right past 3 more bolts on hard, knobby, sometimes runout slab. Eventually join up with the top part of Japanese Gardens P4 to reach the chains.
routes.route_location: Start from the belay on Stiff Kittens, trending up and right till joining with P4 of Japanese Gardens.
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts + some small/finger sized gear for the top of JG.

routes.route_name: Klaus Von Bulow and the Algorithm of Love
routes.route_description: Crux is right off the second set of chains above Japanese Gardens
routes.route_location: I get there by doing Princely, Dr. Sniff then traversing ledges for 30m to the end of the ledges. From there one can see the 2 roofs that you split on KVBulow. You can also make it a finish pitch to full Japanese Gardens.
routes.route_protection: micro cams to #1 camalot. Bolts at top

route_comments.comment_text: Easier approach is to climb to the base of Slow Children and walk 5m left. The real Claus Von Bulow en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claus… is spelled with a C, and has quite a story behind his infamy. May 26, 2015

Another pitch that deserves more traffic.. As Blake mentioned, the route starts at the exact height as the start of Slow Children.  Walk 5m to the left of Slow (very safe, but stay roped in - there is a small ledge to walk across.  A big tree is even growing on this ledge - walk behind it and you have a bomber piece of pro in case you were to fall).  There is a 2 bolt anchor at the base of the... more Another pitch that deserves more traffic.. As Blake mentioned, the route starts at the exact height as the start of Slow Children.  Walk 5m to the left of Slow (very safe, but stay roped in - there is a small ledge to walk across.  A big tree is even growing on this ledge - walk behind it and you have a bomber piece of pro in case you were to fall).  There is a 2 bolt anchor at the base of the route. The crux is no doubt immediately off the chains.  The first few moves are committing because you can't place any pro until a few feet higher.  Once through this crux, its a really fun finger crack to thin hands crack to a roof.  Klaus goes through the center of the roof.  Trapped by a Hamster goes to the right in an amazing, tricky bottomless corner.  The gear is very good for Klaus.  But if you decide to do the Hamster variation, make sure you have several small nuts and be ready to climb above tiny trinkets. Jun 18, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Pulled a bunch of shrubs out. Needs a brush job & bolt replacement at R facing corner near top.

routes.route_description: Climb Model worker then move left into Frog Prince when it is possible to do so.  Finish on Frog Prince.
routes.route_location: Starts on Model Worker
routes.route_protection: a few draws and runners and a handful of trinkets

routes.route_description: Despite being in theGodzilla descriptionI think this route deserves it's own page.From the Godzilla/City Park anchor, move right, clip a bolt, right again, then head up a crack to a v-slot with a pin and another bolt. Step right (3rd bolt) and stem/mantle to the chains.The route gets it's name from the wide stem/step at the last bolt...you'll see when you climb it.It can be linked with p1 ofGodzillafor a fun long pitch.
routes.route_location: Accessed from the anchor atop Godzilla/City Park.
routes.route_protection: 3 draws for bolts and some small/offset nuts in between.

route_comments.comment_text: Indeed, if it has its own name, then it can get its own page. Also, I think one can get to this pitch with little overlap of Godzilla, pitch 1. This involves doing the bottom half of Deal with it Ranger, and then doing a traverse left. Aug 23, 2018
This climb has one of the most interesting moves one can find at the grade at Index.  The move into the stem is so unique and fun. Aug 23, 2018
One of the craziest (and fun) pitches I’ve led anywhere. Apr 23, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. Black totem at base of v slot. Then considerable runout to another .2 or black totem placement. Can plug another piece above and then pin and bolts. Seems strange that another bolt wasn't added between the two small placements given it's a mixed pitch already, and the second half of the pitch you're basically on TR thru the cruxes · Lead / Onsight. Definitely a challenging and balance route. The step out before the chains was freaky and the traverse off the start was kinda scary. Not many gear options and not much of a crack but a very unique climb · Lead / Onsight. stemmy, traversy in a gunksy sorta way, and how about that karate kick · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell on first moves into crack... oh well, was my second pitch at index, give me a break · Lead / Flash. A little spicy due to limited pro and tenuous moves. Fun though (MBk) · Lead. 3 bolts, 1 piton. red cam, offset 0.2/0.3. from city park anchor, traverse right past bolt

routes.route_description: A fun thin crack just right of Breakfast of Champions.  Long pulls on little locks takes you to the top.  The spooky part is stepping off the belay ledge and having to yard on the somewhat loose, hollow undercling flake.  This thing is sketchy and is going to blow sometime, maybe taking out somebody down below.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Small nuts and cams.  You can also TR it from the BOC anchors above.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. TRS solid try at getting it clean and if I was in better shape I think I could do it. Surprisingly good feet for an 11b. · TR. top roped from anchors of BoC. Amazing movement, i thought it wasnt super hard, more technical face climbing with superb finger locks. But doing it on lead with that exposure? Would be a mental crux more than anything. I was getting a bit freaked out swinging in space on TR! · Follow. Lack of bouldering and sport climbing this season showing. Did a lot of pull ups and pulling on gear. Great route though! · TR. Should’ve led this. Great gear between insecure cruxes. Just gotta reach further than you think. · TR. Felt pretty doable after a few hangs to figure out the right beta. · TR. 1 hung at thin .2/.3 crux, will grab the inobvious side cling jug next time and go left hand high. Some spooky holds and blocks in this one, chalked up flake edge low down flexes, fridge size block at top is detached/hollow sounding. · TR. Fun tr from boc. routes.route_fa: P1 short: Greg Olsen, Jon Nelson. P1 full: Terry Lien, Max Dufford, Greg Olsen
routes.route_description: This terrific pitch is best done as one long pitch, skip the first anchors where there used to be a stump (thanks for removing this!!!) The crux is just before the first bolt on the upper section, and is protected by small cams or nuts. Although, I think the lower part is just as hard. This climb is probably damn near impossible for short people, unless you are good at sideways shoulder wrenching dynos.As of 2018, there is now a lower-off anchor at a no-hands rest at 35 m, allowing one to lower off with a 70-m rope.Otherwise, the descent requires two raps to the ground, stopping at the first anchor, or a lower one on the neighboring route.
routes.route_location: Just right ofPrincely Ambitions.
routes.route_protection: You can slot an inverted small carabiner in the hole before the first bolt, but may cause rope drag problems.  You will want some gear to fill in the gaps between the bolts on the upper section.

route_comments.comment_text: If you are short, it may take a little magical levitation. It took me SO long to get this move by getting my feet up really high and reaching for the crimp. I tried this move many many times with the same beta, but somehow i just magically levitated this last time. Jun 21, 2008
There are only two bolts (about 6' apart) on the section above the first anchor and the climbing above them is non-trivial. Jul 14, 2008
Yeah the stemming move is the way if you are under 5'3... Jul 19, 2008

routes.route_description: Roughly half of this route comprises terrain from the original 2nd pitch of Snow White (aid). Like everything else on the Lower Wall, the rock is impeccable and the moves technical. However, this pitch really stands out because of its incredible variety. First 30 feet is cruiser 5.10ish, then you can literally sit down and gather your wits for the boulder crux; and of course, ogle the panorama of Merchant and Mt. Index. The BP will be vastly different depending on height. I'm barely 5' and used a mono under-cling to access to start holds. Taller climbers 6'+ might utilize an enormous reach. Either way, it is challenging. --- more 5.10 follows to a slabby rest position. Once at the roof, rev up the biceps & dance on across to an exposed perch. Once rested, pop the clutch and switch into crack mode. Punch it high before placing a piece, then hang on till the anchor. ***  Originally thought this was 5.12. But...since a few strong folks have climbed it with no repeats I'm thinking it is probably harder.
routes.route_location: NTAD lies mostly between Tuna Boaters and Tad pole.  It shares the same finish anchor with the latter route.  The start (bolted anchor with chain) is accessed via the first pitch of Princely Ambitions (to the right) at approximately 2/3 height.
routes.route_protection: This route is mostly bolted, but the final 30 feet follows a flared crack and requires a few finger size pieces.  I'd also recommend a couple small wires at the finish.  Use long runners just before after during the roof traverse to mitigate drag.

route_comments.comment_text: Great job Ben! For decades, I have looked over at the upper part of this route and imagined doing the moves. But hearing about Greg Olsen working on it a long time ago make me think it was way too hard, so I never ventured.  Still is probably too hard for me, but it helps to know it now goes. I never thought about the lower half. That part looks fun too. Jan 30, 2014

Thanks Jon.  Last month I ran into Greg on holiday from work in Israel.  It was really cool to hear all about his experience on the route back in the day.  From Tuna Boaters anchor it is quite easy to TR most of the roof and lower sections.  Though it will probably never achieve "popular" status, it is nonetheless a remarkable climb, and worth doing for those who can. Jan 30, 2014

I've changed the route name back to its original. Hopefully the drama of route "redaction" is behind us. Half of the route contains terrain per P2 of Snow White.  Still no second ascent to my knowledge.  I'll probably come back myself this summer to do the 2nd ascent LOL...cause the climbing is great! Dec 23, 2022

routes.route_fa: Dave Anderson, Donn Heller. FFA P1: Larry Kemp, Max Dufford, Jim Purdy
routes.route_description: The bolted dihedral left of Sagitarius and Iron Horse.  Starts out with a SUPER technical crux using horribly small gastons, pinscars and smears for opposition.  All the campusing power in the world won't get you off the ground on this thing.  The body tension/insecurity fest continues to another crux pulling the first roof, then eases for a bit of very fun 10/11ish face climbing until the final crux, involving shallow locks and high steps through a small roof.  Amazing!Amandla, the 13b/c arete climb, follows Numbah 10 for the first 5 bolts, then breaks right.I gave this a generic "5.12."  The books give it 12b, which is a laughable sandbag; Index is burly, for sure.  I'm not suggesting a rating change above because: a) I haven't redpointed it and b) who cares?  But if your ego hurts after this one, just remember how much fun the route is and that it would be a 5.12c or d anywhere else.

routes.route_description: Climb out right through an alcove/arch in white rock, and then follow two stepped flakes past 1 bomber pin (shallow right-facing corners with finger cracks) up to a belay shared with the top of Tadpole (or easily scramble a few more meters to the belay at the base of Beak! Beak! Beak! / Newest Industry.1/2way through the pitch it's possible to move right (1 bolt) up onto the top half of P2 Iron Horse. The grad would stay the same.This needs more traffic!
routes.route_location: Begins atop the P1 (full pitch) of Model Worker. Easiest approach: climb Princely Ambitions, and walk/traverse right on the ledge for 15m to an anchor.
routes.route_protection: Doubles in fingers, singles in hands.

routes.route_description: Pitch 1: (5.9) GodzillaPitch 2: (5.9) From the anchor, traverse right (one bolt) to the major corner with a large flake. (optional belay from chain anchor on a ledge off right after the large flake to reduce rope drag) Above the flake, traverse left (reach) into a finger crack then pull steep jugs to see the anchor on a nice ledge.Pitch 3: (5.9) Start climbing right of the belay traveling back left above the belay. Up cracks to a slabby traverse left (bolt) with good feet. Follow crack up to a flare. Can climb flare or stem right of flare. Belay from chains by a tree.Pitch 4: (5.9) Follow handcrack in left facing corner up to a bolt on a dark pillar. Stem through blocky bulge to low angle finger crack.From there, go right to a chain anchor. (This last part is vegetated)Descent: Rap the route with a 70m rope
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Double rack to #3, long slings and draws, 70m rope.

route_comments.comment_text: Has anyone climbed this recently? I looked at it yesterday and it looked pretty dirty. Pretty awesome to have a 4 pitch 5.9 at the LTW, and I am bummed I wasn't prepared to do some cleaning. Jul 25, 2016

If that third pitch is a 5.9, it's the hardest 5.9 at Index. A full value pitch for sure, likely easier if cleaner, but 5.9? It was noticeably harder than the two pitches that preceded it. Aug 1, 2016

First 3 pitches were amazing, 4th pitch was a dirty, dirty bush grovel which I wouldn't do again until someone cleaned it. However, I would happily re-do the first 3 pitches again and again, they were that amazing! Pitch 1: See Godzilla for info. Pitch 2: Easiest pitch in terms of technique, but had a few power moves with poor feet. Gear protected pretty well though, so didn't feel... more First 3 pitches were amazing, 4th pitch was a dirty, dirty bush grovel which I wouldn't do again until someone cleaned it. However, I would happily re-do the first 3 pitches again and again, they were that amazing! Pitch 1: See Godzilla for info. Pitch 2: Easiest pitch in terms of technique, but had a few power moves with poor feet. Gear protected pretty well though, so didn't feel dangerous! Super fun for sure! Pitch 3: The money pitch in my opinion! If you're not used to wider, slightly flaring cracks, it can seem a lot harder than 5.9. First half was some absolutely amazing hands/fists, but the second half is where the grunt work came into play! Definitely got some good thigh jams in, and did a good amount of sweating to squeeze my way up through the flaring crack. Did it on a typical double rack, didn't feel like I was low on gear. Pitch 4: Dirty, dirty grovelling mess with tons of spiderwebs when I did it in July 2016. I would not recommend it until someone goes up to clean it. It had some cool movements, but was so dirty, it was not particularly enjoyable. The last bit to the anchors was especially awful, requiring you to pull through vegetation. Sep 27, 2016

routes.route_description: Super fun and often overlooked way to climb the incredible upper arete of Amandla.  Climb to the first chains of Iron Horse but lean out left and clip the first of four remaining bolts on Amandla.  Rest as best you can before pulling out to compress, slap, layback and pinch your way up the classic hanging arete to the anchor below the roof.Since Blake's writing of his description of Full Horse Power, it seems as though the original anchor of Amandla was moved to right below the roof from lower on the arete.  This makes the current Power Horse a step harder and much more full value than it would have previously been stopping lower, but taking the Full Horse Power extension out over the roof looks like it still packs some extra punch.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Lots of small gear for Iron Horse, four bolts on the arete.
