routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Sent on TR. Single best try I've ever had. 45, very dry, and sunny. Hadn't climbed in one week, but felt incredible. I didn't overthink anything, and just focused on climbing, no success or failure in mind. Flew up iron horse really smoothly, and just perfectly executed the amandla arete. Might be the finger training and the squats I've been doing. Opted for the lay back version at the top, but came down and did the other version as well. · TR. Mid 40s and sunny. Fell twice, one on moving up after the span, second at top. · TR. 2nd TR. 2-3 falls. Got from entry to two hands on the arete before Falling. · TR. 43 degrees, cloudy. 3-5 pm. Fell on first entry move, got next section clean. Good warm up · Lead / Redpoint. Through the roof to the ledge, few tries this year, with some tries going back to 2020 ish! · TR. High of 71, humidity of 50%. Started at 1030,was way too slick. I fell a bunch at every move, first time on since October. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on this. Finished this up then went into the parking lot and saw the fire trucks for Michal's accident.will never forget this day. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 92 percent humidity. fell at 2nd bolt.slipped off. for Crux at top, get right hand in the slot right below crack. bring left foot up to left foot chip, then left hand stabilize along arete, then right hand into bottom slot. left hand above it grabbing arete. transition right hand to a side pull as you move left foot around to the nub. · TR. sent on top rope for fifth time in a row. hadn't climbed in a week, didn't feel strong, but was able to send it with the final lieback beta. non lieback approach is now solved, so much easier than I was making it. lieback is definitely a grade harder. at top, bring right hand up into lower flare, left foot onto lower left arete foot chip. left hand spans out to hold lower flare, left foot comes around onto nub. right foot onto upper right nub. right hand goes to arete just above flare, left hand into flare like lieback, then span right hand out right. bring left foot up to nub, tighten core, move left hand out up arete, bump it once more, then lieback on the left hand. · TR. sent it on TR (4th straight time). clearly the issue is lead head due to the bad fall potential on the last bolt, pressure of "needing" to send, plus the weird rope positions created when leading where it could get behind your feet. on TR it feels pretty wired. · Lead. high of 70, partly sunny, 5 pm. very humid. fell at 3rd bolt, just felt super weak from lack of sleep and inconsistent diet. was hard to give a strong lead attempt. · Lead / Fell/Hung. took a 40 min rest after first burn. slipped getting into the nub. may want to consider the finish most people do to avoid pump and last boulder problem. got pumped out after working it and moving the rope over the comfortably numbah ten. probably would have been okay if I didn't do the additional comfortably rope work. · Lead / Fell/Hung. perfect temps, high of 64. got up to last move onto the nub, got right foot caught in the rope and fell. · TR. sent for 3rd time on TR. without rope issues behind the legs, it's straight forward · Lead. high of 79. 5:15 pm. fell at 3rd bolt transferring before I got onto major foot nub. major issue was it's hard to get foot up once the draw has the rope running through it. may need to bring left foot up slightly prior to make this easier. then had issues on the lieback, out of gas. need to rest more at rest spot. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 80% humidity, cloudy, temperature of 70°. everything went smoothly until clipping. the Alpine draw on the fourth bolt. got the foot match at the first bolt by keeping arms level and not reaching up until the foot match was complete. got the right foot onto the big nub by bringing the right hand over directly below the arete foot dish and pulling directly sideways, not up. this is critical to only pull sideways. when clipping the last Alpine draw, pull out the slack before standing up on the left foot. then come down and take another rest. focus on getting the feet in the right spot so you don't get the foot stuck behind the rope. · Lead / Redpoint. Did this variation after being thwarted by Amandla many times. Such fantastic climbing · TR. high of 72, did it in the evening about 7 pm. got the foot transfer beta right: don't move left hand up the arete before foot match. complete foot match, then move both hands up, shift weight to the left and move up. simple this way · TR. sent it on TR!!! got the foot match correct using tc pros (first try was in pinks but TCs feel a bit better). make sure to move hands up the arete and the left foot up before trying to get up onto the big knob. liebwcking the arete was straight forward. · Lead / Fell/Hung. started at 910, sunny, high of 76. arete felt very warm and slick. the past week of 90+ must have warmed the rock up a lot. felt super greasy, fell on foot transfer 3-4 times. make sure right toe is above left foot and pushes down to get clean transfer. needs cool day so right hand is good. also, but long double sling on iron horse chains to keep rope out of your foot space. bring up an extra 0.75 if you need to go up to Sagittarius chains. everything felt slick, I felt weak. need better sleep and more training in the week leading up to trying it. · TR. high of 80, started around 10 am, no cloud cover. too hot to lead. one fall on the lieback up to the good nub. sent the top section. tried Jeremy's beta of moving right, just doesn't work for me. liebacked the arete 4 times in a row, no problem never fell. the key is to bring right foot up on arete high, almost at the base of the crack, the bring left foot onto nub on the left arete. makes the right foot transfer and the hand transfer in the pocket much smoother. sinking the right foot, getting the knee over, standing up with right hand up to bread loaf worked perfectly. · TR. high of 80, no cloud cover. did 2nd try at 1130 or so. arete was very hot, slipped off lots of places. but even in the heat sent everything above the last bolt!!! · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell at last move. need to remember, grab final bread loaf with right hand. left hand doesn't work. stand up after right hand on bread loaf, with left leg and hand splayed out to the left. · Lead / Fell/Hung. started at 9:15, high of 76. cloudy, arete fully shaded. took 30 ft whipper on last move. need to remember to get knee fully over foot and really sink into it. · TR. sent it all the way from the bottom of arete (after foot match!). stayed focused and fought for it the whole way. · TR. started at 945 am. high of 78 degrees. moderate cloud cover, was in the sun but somewhat covered when I got on. fell on entry sequence, but after that was smooth up until the final move to the bolt. fell about a half second after I started thinking I would send it. need to stay in the mental headspace of really wanting it and being 100% focused on executing each move. on foot match moving into the arete, make sure right big toe is down and making contact. · TR. Tried it in the morning sun, 11 AM, 70+% humidity. Couldn't get the first move, as the right hand relies on friction to keep you stable while you move up the arete with the left. Got the sequence from bolt 1 to bolt 2 clean, fell on the right foot up to the big knob. The beta here is to bring the right hand up sideways onto the foot chip, which has enough roughness to give good friction. Add body tension, Then move left foot up 2-3 inches,and throw right foot up and lean down on it. Upper last move was ok, but quite slick due to heat. Probably will need to try later in the year when it is cooler. · TR. got all moves pretty easily. on entry to arete, grab side arete before swapping feet. then move left foot up, bump left hand up, shift weight over left foot, lift right hand up to side pull, then move up. was 80% humidity, felt really slick. 5.10 pinks felt better than tc pros. for moving onto big nub at 3rd bolt, place left foot low, bring right hand over and lean back to create tension, move left foot up 6 inches, then move right foot up and pistol squat on the right foot. · TR. TR, got all the moves pretty easily. on the third bolt, when getting the right foot turned towards the left, move left hand up as far as you can. position left foot with ankle out and toe pushing into the arete which gives a good counter balance to prevent the barn door. bring right hand above left onto the arete and layback the right foot up onto the good foothold. rest. clip. do move out and around. added an additional draw to make the clipping stance safer from right foot on chip. follow same lieback beta as before. · TR. got all the moves. for entry onto arete, match feet in slot before moving left hand out from side pull to arete. the pull up onto left foot is fine. bump right hand up. move left foot up to nub, right foot into near small crystal pocket. bump right hand again. get solid left hand on arete, find good hold, then put right foot facing left as you pull on it. then lieback and move left foot up, bringing right foot up again to major knob. swing around arete is fairly easy. clip from over there is difficult. move left foot up, right foot onto nub. reach left hand into slot, then bring right hand to grab it as a pinch. lieback up the arete, then move right foot over and sink it into foot. left leg around arete for balance, stand up slowly and grab horn. · Lead / Fell/Hung. got the first two bolts just fine. best way for getting to 3rd bolt still isn't clear. clipping 4th bolt is scary because you're in a lieback and pumped with no feet. not sure how to do it yet. took a few whips, linebacking after 4th bolt is also tenuous and the fall is a bit uncertain, I flipped over slightly coming down and hit my back on the arete but no damage. · TR. got all moves before transferring back onto the arete from left side. put left toe onto dish on left side just above the mini roof, then transfer right foot over to nub and weight it. sink body down to get weight then pull up. wrap left leg around arete to keep balance as you stand. did it in 67 degrees and 60%+ humidity. need to try it when it's 55 or 60 and less humid. feels 100% doable to send! · TR. for the last big nub before getting to the arete, lieback arete facing the arete and bring right foot up · Lead / Fell/Hung. very hot day, slick holds. it's easy to clip the first bolt for me from the corner. the second seems doable from the right foot on the crystal and left leg heel hooking the arete if draws are already there. couldn't get past bolt 2, was just crazy hot and I slid right off. felt completely different than last try where it was hard but doable. ideal temps are probably sunny and 50. · TR. incredible. can't wait to get on it again. top ropes it from comfortably numbah ten.

routes.route_description: Somewhat of an Index classic, Princely can be pretty popular. The first pitch is the best part. The Princely Ambitions area is basically the first part of the Main Wall you pass directly by on the main trail. Princely starts up an easy flake to the left of some shorter bolted routes whose anchors are pretty clearly visible from the ground.P1 (5.9) Head left up the easy flake/ramp, then out onto the face past one bolt (used to be two bolts...), then up more flakes. At the top of the flakes, follow a chalked-up ledge traversing left and then straight up the corner all the way to the belay (bolts). The pitch is long, so don't give up on the anchor, it is there.Avoid the temptation to finish at the "Nobody tosses a dwarf" anchors, which are partway up the final corner, just a little to the right. If you do this early exit, you miss some fun, relatively easy corner climbing. Instead, continue until the corner ends at a large comfy ledge.P2 (5.8) Continue up the left crack to a rap station.From the top of P2, you can continue up and left through the trees to the Winky Dinky cliff.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Standard trad rack to 3-4". A small cam is very nice for the traverse (e.g. purple Alien). Larger cams are nice for the second pitch. There are anchors/rap stations at the top of both pitches. You need 2 60-m ropes to rap the route.There is one bolt at the start of the rightward traverse.

route_comments.comment_text: This is a VERY long pitch that wanders, so bring lots of long slings!  Some committing moves will be encountered, so I recommend being comfortable at the grade.  A little bit of everything here including slab, liebacks, steep hand traverses, etc.  Bring a big assortment of gear up to #3 Camalot.  A 70m rope just barely makes the big ledge, but some downclimbing from the ledge would be required. Jul 2, 2006
I start this climb from off the trail to Rodger's Corner and routinely lower off and do laps on the first pitch with a 70 meter rope. One of my favorite pitches anywhere! Jan 29, 2007
A 60m rope will get you off if you angle down and to the climber's left. Jul 3, 2007

routes.route_tick_comments: · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. 4x runners. standard rack minus #1, #2 and 2x #.5 · TR. tr’ed twice, crux is right traverse after bolt when feet disappear, trust left finger lock, sent on second go · Follow. One of the best climbing routes I’ve done. Awesome flakes the whole way up · 1 pitch. Lead / Flash. Only one pitch, finished at the bolted anchor at top of Nobody Tosses a Dwarf. Backcleaned a piece at the traverse to reduce drag. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. First pitch only. So close to an onsight, took a 15-20 foot fall on an extended purple totem · Lead / Flash. Haley led pitch 1. Brought doubles .1-3. Triples .3-.5. Lots of alpine draws. Max led the second pitch. Pretty cool climb! · Follow. Julian P1 (extend the first piece or back clean after the bolt, same with the hairpin) sg p2. Cont to beak beak beak · Lead / Onsight. W Andrew. Soo fun. Would like to link both pitches next time. · Follow. Pitch 2 was WORTH. Got some solid jams in a beautiful hand crack · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. With tj! Rapped with 70 and downclimbed the last little bit. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Pretty speedy climb, felt solid the whole way, got dark belaying second, and on descent · TR. Such a fun climb! Very exposed and airy. I guess it’s 5.9…? But like… also what the hell in no world is that a 5.9 anywhere but index · Lead / Flash. Remember not to plug a 3 behind the huge flake. Low traverse right to V slot before horizontal hand rail traverse out left. Plug black totem and commit, then mantle. Bring long slings. Sustained, fun corner moves to finish. 70m rap from top of p1 requires down climbing big ledge · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. New fav. Surreal. Got to the top with mount index peaking through a cloud scarf with the moon above. Felt like a breezy fairytale. · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Better than last time. Can’t tr from top oop had to downclimb to lower anchors · Lead. With Ethan, I feel like I placed well and had a nice time. · 1 pitch. TR. Top roped. Strength wise could potentially lead it with takes. Very long. 70m only works if you belay from the ledge above. · 1 pitch. TR. Asked another group to trail a rope up for us to TR. Belayed from upper ledge with 70m, barely long enough. V glad I did not lead it, hard! Really fun and great movement, awesome climb. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Stopped at first anchor, from there it's 35m to ground · Follow. Climbed with Will and Kevin. First pitch is hard and a lil reachy/physical for "5.9"! · Lead / Onsight. Lead first, TR second. Stellar first pitch!! Deserves all the stars for varied movement, and just enough spice to keep it real. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. first climb in Index ! properly put in my place · 1 pitch. Lead / Flash. Little tricky but super fun. Peter mantled the finger traverse on top rope! · Lead / Redpoint. Engaging courageous memorable climb with several cruxy/emotionally engaging sections. Would recommend. 2nd pitch sketch loose rock and questionable anchor. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Just the first pitch. Rope drag bad. Bolt at end of ledge traverse bad. · Follow. Erron led. SO scary! Neither of us fell...felt like I was going to many times. Would be awesome to lead one day, felt at my limit on TR. The traverse left was the scariest. Then finger crack was pretty solid. · Lead / Onsight. Love that first pitch. Reminder not to put gear in on the right side of the traverse. Too much drag and hard for the follower. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Just to p1 and lowered for the end of the day, very scary hollow flakes but a full on fun trad route · 1 pitch. Follow. Still scary. Gotta come back to lead this one. Beta for the part before the traverse. Stay left. Stand on very top of flake. Step down right to foot ledge both feet. Reach far right and up for jug · Lead / Onsight. best pitch of 5.9 i’ve ever done! feels like an alpine or big wall pitch, very exciting! ran out of slings at the end but rope drag was not bad. swapped leads with Alice and she cruised p2. gonna come back for the 10d crack variation and the 10d slab pitch above. · Follow. Keep your damn feet on the wall after the first bolt going right onto the rail. Or maybe do something completely different than dangling your legs and doing a pull-up. Then comes the lie back right. Pull onto 2x2 flake. Careful feet get you to the top right of the 7. Again keep feet on the wall and ledge / finger crack trav until in reach of vertical crack for after the right foot mantle. Does not let up here!!! Compose and protect and find the best holds and feet. Big ledge at the top on the right. Followed Eric today but will lead one day. Index=gnar · Lead / Redpoint. Lead p1 could do 2x bt-3 plus offset cams and nuts (one mid & big), only 1x#1. Revolver before traverse and on bolt (but locker on bolt would feel better). Use 2x #3 early and 2x #2 before big flake mantle. follow Deanna on p2. Rap to starting ledge and downclimb · Lead / Onsight. w/ Keira. Led Pitch 2. Pitch 1, some reachy, scary moves on the slab. · Lead / Flash. Kinda tough! The holds and moves are all there but a number of committing stuff. #0.2-3 with double 0.3-2, mostly 0.3-0.5, placed the 0.2 above the first bolt. One double alpine at the very right before left hand rail traverse, otherwise single alpines and draws, no nuts. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. P1 only as a warmup. Fun n chill. Still wanna do the full linkup with Beak Beak Beak

routes.route_fa: Greg Donaldson, Roger Johnson, Richard Mathies, 4/1967.  FFA: Bob Crawford, Don Harder, 9/1974
routes.route_description: This is a fun route and a nice way to approachBreakfast of Champions. An initial wide layback crack leads to some broken block climbing. There are chains about 60 feet up that I just clipped and continued on up all in one pitch. The upper corner involves really fun stemming and great exposure. The pitch ends at the obvious tree.For a belay anchor and rappel point, use the chain anchor with rap rings on the wall next to the tree.  A 70m will get you to the ground.  It's recommended to rap to the first set of chains if you have a 60m and do it in two raps.
routes.route_location: I approached this by walking towardsPrincely Ambitions(which is found by heading right on the approach trail when it forks).  Right before the Lower Wall is reached you can scramble up a well-traveled path (class 3) to a large, dirty ledge.  Roger's Corner is directly above and can be identified by the wide layback corner.
routes.route_protection: Double TCUs-#3 Camalot and nuts. Long slings helpful if you do it all in one pitch.Fixed biner lower-offs on both the mid-way anchor (~20 m) and the top anchor (~35 m). (A big thanks to S. Richards for adding these, summer 2022.)

route_comments.comment_text: FA:  Greg Donaldson, Roger Johnson, Richard Mathies, April 1967. FFA : Bob Crawford, Don Harder, Sept. 1974.- which means they did it free with hex's and nuts. A fun challenge is to do this and Breakfast of Champions as one pitch, place 5 pieces in this and save cams needed for BOC. Aug 5, 2014

Easy to do in one pitch - I used a double runner to clip a bolt on the intermediate belay station and then back-cleaned the last piece I put in before the intermediate bealy and finished without noticeable rope drag. Aug 24, 2015

We rapped the whole route from the tree belay with a 60 m yesterday. Rope stretch and a swing off to climbers left got our feet on the ground, but just barely. Knot your ends and use your head! May 13, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Still spicy but not as bad as I remembered from my first time trying to lead it · Lead / Onsight. Felt super pumped at the top after not having climbed for a couple weeks but good route ignoring the seemingly bad rock in the middle. No need to layback the wide start, jams perfectly well · Lead. Very scary when out of shape lol. Very hot and sweaty but bomber sheesh · Lead. W Stephen, Ben. Fun! Got tunnel vision on the finger crack and made it harder. Lol · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Brian Rajdl. Linked into 5.10a Breakfast of Champions, awesome link-up! · Lead / Flash. Aleah led to the first anchors, and then I led the top. Def not 5.9 · Lead / Fell/Hung. was a little wet in some of the cracks. took multiple times. gave a couple attempts at starting the crux at the end but ultimately decided to bail before the overhung hand crack/last stemmy bit. should be able to finish next time! needed lots of extensions · Lead / Redpoint. Finished off the lead for Theresa through the crux. Fairly cruiser-ish until stemming. Middle section is more engaging though than I ever remember it to be. Probably want to encourage new leaders to save a 1 and/or 0.75 for the top. · Lead / Onsight. Fun route, kinda tricky to project without crazy drag. Lots of ledges so running it out not advised. Placed two cams at crux and had to back clean before belaying up Anna due to drag. To first chains is just ok, crus has fun movement. Would be tough to link with BOC unless you run it out, bring triples in hands. · Follow. Got the TRonsight. Fists/butterfly didn’t last long because you could get high feet. · Lead. This was my pre-injury goal for the year. I am so proud of myself. · Lead / Flash. Haley lead, max followed to get to BOC. Felt like a great lead for me. Pretty sporty but also somewhat physical. Couple spots you have to trust feet. · Lead / Onsight. Pretty fun imo. Linked the pitches to base of breakfast of champions. Spaced out pro and had no rope drag. Some loose stuff but not bad. I found it really enjoyable. · Lead / Redpoint. Felt hard after a day of doing lots of climbing. Fuel up & bring enough food for doing sustained powerful climbing. · Lead / Fell/Hung. would definitely carry a 4 inch cam next time. took 20ft whip while clipping, oof · Lead / Redpoint. Fun on top half, being extra hand size piece and alpine draws · Follow. Possibly just as hard with a heavy backpack to head up to mid wall on as on lead. ~Pumpy~ was almost feeling to gassed to fire up BOC. · Lead. Well not quite as easy on lead but still ok. A few awkward body positions, especially getting into the upper corner. Used singles 0.3-4 plus an extra 0.75 and a 0.4/0.5 offset but there are options. · Follow. Followed Roger up Roger’s Corner. He was scared leading it. I was scared following · Lead / Flash. So I LOVE this climb. Did it 3 times this summer :) a little pumpy at the end tho! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Freaked out at upper bulge. It’s all there, just stay left, get a high 2, and move quickly. · Lead / Onsight. fun. spicy move off the mid anchors. felt on the harder side of 9. · Follow. Jillian’s lead. Felt good to follow. Stayed fully in the corner on upper crux and it was pretty chill. · Follow. W/ Gus. Very fun follow. No way I could lead. Linked with Breakfast of Champions. Stopped at the first anchor to ensure we had enough gear. · Lead. One take 10 ft from the anchor, not a super hard climb at all · Lead. felt easier than in 2020, however had a really heavy rope which made drag bad at the time

routes.route_fa: To ringing flake: Pat Timson, Don Harder. FFA to roof: Mark Moore. FFA P1 full: Terry Lien, Jon Nelson. P2: Terry Lien, Darryl Cramer
routes.route_description: Just to the left of Japanese Gardens is this obvious line of hand cracks and traversing roofs.  Start on the ledges above the big stump on the trail and lieback a wide flare for about 10 feet to a short finger crack.  Move right into a sweet steep handcrack, up into a wide (6"?) crack that traverses left.  Clip the fixed chock before the traverse, and walk a # 5 Camalot to the end if you want to protect this section, or drag will become an issue.  At the end of the traverse there is a set of anchors. Skip this and get into the chimney above it.  Walk your #5 up this section again until the chimney narrows and you step out onto the face to commit to the perfect handcrack above.  You'll hit the "ringing flake" here.  Spooky.  The handcrack cruises through it to the anchor up above (from which you can TR Iron Horse, too).  A 5.11 variation goes through the roof above this anchor.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Several hand-size pieces (at least double #2 Camalots and maybe double #3s to sew it), a few smaller cams, and a healthy selection of large cams.  A #5, while not necessary, would ease the mind a bit.

route_comments.comment_text: The full first pitch (5.11b) is one of the best on the lower wall.  This pitch has everything you could ever want on a climb.  It's the only climb I have ever enjoyed that I place a #3, #3.5, #4, and a #4.5 camalot on. Mar 13, 2006

A fellow climber aptly described this amazing route as "a voyage."  It takes you through so many big, improbable features that by the time you reach the final stretch of steep handcrack, you'll feel as though it was twice as long.  Shorter folk will get an extra thrill on the traverse under the roof, as you may not reach the undercling to use for balance. Gearwise, I find that placing a... more A fellow climber aptly described this amazing route as "a voyage."  It takes you through so many big, improbable features that by the time you reach the final stretch of steep handcrack, you'll feel as though it was twice as long.  Shorter folk will get an extra thrill on the traverse under the roof, as you may not reach the undercling to use for balance. Gearwise, I find that placing a #3.5 in lieu of clipping the chockstone inspires a bit more confidence for the wide section til you can get a #4 at the roof.  A #5 is bomber for the chimney and a few .75's and #1's are nice in the upper handcrack.  A single #3 was sufficient but you could probably place another if you bring more. Jul 28, 2012
Don't listen to Aaron's gear beta. Place a 3.5 or a 4 slightly to the right of the middle of the traverse and run the rope behind the flake, it won't bind. Aug 29, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Sustained liebacking for me. Need to get better endurance. 5 takes · TR. Roof beta: set up in vert crack, RH to side pull, RF to arete black crystal, bump LH to Gaston on way to tooth · Follow. hung at overhanging wide hands and start of layback. didnt like this as much as other index classics, lots of groveling. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell out early due to foot slip. Big, strange fall but got caught safely. Then got pumped quite frequently. Worse than on the previous attempt. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Cruxed out low establishing into the crack. Went back down & taped, did again from ground, took just a bit before chains due to pump. Super fun, protects great. · Lead. .2, 1x .4-.75 (+graylien), 2x 1-4. All the slings. Place 4 right side of roof. Extension seems to take finger to medium. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Save .75s and .5s and a few 1s for top. Didn’t use the 3s at the top- could use both at the bottom. Two or three 4s and a 5 for sure. Extend everything at the bottom and after the traverse make sure to put the rope around the horn/ flake to reduce drag · TR. Woof - lots of fun varied climbing, look around for jugs / feet · Lead / Pinkpoint. Cleaned first half for Ben. Led to the top chains to TR · Lead / Pinkpoint. Half pink, half red. Sent it after Brandon couldn't finish it after getting in his head. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to take at the start of the traverse. Got to the offwidth ok but didn’t have enough gear and got in my head. Also had the rope running over the flake. Bailed off a loose flake. Feels bad man. Save a 4 or 5 for after the traverse. Run the rope under the flake. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Wimped out didn’t finish! Used right lower flake due to greasy feat on left flake · Lead / Fell/Hung. Didn't manage effort well and had to hang up top in the paddles/fstacks · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell hung before first crux and getting in to hand crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. Spectacular climbing, would like to come back and send, it was a hard warm up, but I had to hang a rope on iron horse · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped at start of traverse then just epiced the whole way. Need to work on size 4 technique. · Lead / Onsight. Mostly just intimidating, good climbing! Don’t stop at the first anchor - nice layback for another 15 ft · Lead / Fell/Hung. First lead attempt. Did it 99% clean, then grabbed the chains at the very end :'( Definitely more type 2 fun on lead (still great). Need to figure out a better plan for the layback, not enough of a brave boy to just run it out · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 (real) fall at bulge coming out of squeeze after committing to the lie back from the face hold, 2 takes in the upper liebacks. 0.5 in the flaring layback at bottom (extend this piece with full single+mini extend next 0.3 when finger crack first accepts this, only one #3 necessary #3 BD pulling into hand crack, bump this up to slung chock At slung chock, reach far back to use it as good hold to rest on Get up higher to chalked jug block, place #4, then can rest by jamming upper arm between the big undercling roof and the jug block, bump #4 over, find the feet, then make handless traverse to transfer to other side of roof Gooood rest in the upper squeeze after it flared out, find the good foot to depump calf with a left frog leg (hands free, relaxed), a couple hand fist stacks to pull over the weird #5 section and place/shove the #4 into ringing flake before pulling face move. #1 at bottom after squeeze/#4 Commit to balance-y lieback can’t sneak thumb jammed in on bottom hand, too narrow, then don’t forget about foot rail out left after a couple moves plus finger jam in flake, eventually getting to hand jams above flake #2 BD midway through in hands section, rest with feet in flake and rail #1 up high before bulge right before committing to the last section #0.75 midway up final layback, continue on, then another #0.75, can get foot over to left side to clip chains Final gear (in order): 0.2, 0.5ext (totem), 0.3exthalf, 3BD, chock+single, 4, 5, 4, 1, 2BD, 1, 2*0.75 (maybe extra #1 for this section?) · TR. Amazing route. Every kind of bullshit I love in one climb. Can't wait to go back and lead it · Lead / Fell/Hung. Black totem to pull over first blocky terrain, 0.5 or 0.75 (if so bring triples) in flaring layback, extended (did on sliding x because wet) 0.3 in finger up top 2 friend (almost tipped out) or 3 BD pulling into baggy hand crack 3 up higher in this? 4 midway through traverse at the tooth hanging down bit of the roof Can reach across to gaston just barely 5 pulling into squeeze, take it all the way up 4 in ringing flake before reaching outside to key hold with right hand 0.75-2 multiple in the upper for the hand cracks (wider crack below, baggy 0.75s splitter up top), all layback ish. · Lead / Redpoint. Lead to first anchor to set up TR on IH. Start with .5 in flare · Lead / Redpoint. perfectly 3 years ago. finally got the repoint. remember to face out on the chimney. 1 #5 and 1 #4 is enough. not sure how to place the first #3 so the rope doesn't get caught. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped on a 4 right below the blue tat. Took 1 other time · TR. Partner didn’t want to follow, so I had to clean it somehow and sure as hell wasn’t gonna do it as I was getting lowered · Lead / Fell/Hung. Great climb but very physical and hard for me. Whipped on the lower finger crack, fell on the wide stuff, was pumped for the final layback Double rack, 2 #4, 1 #5, save your .75s till the very end · Follow. With marius. Someone go put the cleaning biner back on the sling, i grabbed it thinking it was my partner's, put it down at the base of the climb · Lead / Fell/Hung. Intimidating from the ground considering the whipperfest 3 years ago but I made it nearly to the chain until I slipped at the final layback. My body felt like I was HIIT training, full body pump. Got a lot of spray on gear placement from the ground. Thankful but a lot of faff. Bit improvement from 2020. Single .3-.5, 4-5. Double .75- 2. · Lead / Onsight. So stoked to get the onsight of this! At the top plugged a #1 (2nd #1 at top section would be nice) liebacked the 1 section and barely made it to the chains before pumping out! Would have been an exciting fall. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung at lieback. Had the strength to do it, purely a wimp. Rest a cruise. · Lead / Redpoint. Finally sent 11b variation. No 5, but .4 to .75 fits in back of offwidth just fine · Follow. fcking hard, didnt help that multiple cams stuck. Wicked hard for 5.10, but I’m just bad at sustained offwidth jam crack. Pulled back on and sent next go. .75 and black totem (optional but nice). Prep text the top. .75 slots all the way in on the top of the good hold out right · Lead / Onsight. neat. looked at going out the roof, looked a bit dirty and cruxy on an upside down pin · Lead / Fell/Hung. w yev. fell several times at the first fist crack. layback the top crack before the anchors, don't try to jam · Lead / Onsight. So sick!!! Stopped at anchors bellow roof but it was a blast. · TR. I fell a bunch of times, definitely something I want to work up to · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a sec to figure out the middle and top crux · Lead. Another burn on this to hang iron horse but bailed at the first anchors cuz wet up high. The bottom 3 crack is hard · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 big fall, several hangs. start w/black and blue totems followed by .5 soon after. extended #3 under small roof to the left. #4 and #3 up to chockstone. 2x #4 to traverse under roof, extend second over flake. #5 up chimney to leave at top with yellow alien. 2x #1 after exit, then 2x #2, then 2-3x .75. · TR. Possibly bring triples of hand sizes and no nuts. · Lead / Fell/Hung. took on the last 0.75 crack. Gosh, the layback is so good what was I thinking. It was also my first time taking the finger crack up, much better than the flare. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell attempting 11b extension. I placed #4 too far to left on roof traverse, which caused drag. optional #5 for chimney. · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Jess and hung a top rope?? Date is wrong · Lead / Redpoint. Got it. routes.route_fa: FFA: Terry Lien, Jon Carpenter, Pat McNerthney, Jon Nelson
routes.route_description: Named for the "Slow, Children at Play" traffic signs that are typically found near a "City Park".This splitter finger crack has its hardest moves at the very start and the very end, though is pretty continuous throughout. It follows a shallow corner that switches sides a few times.Start by traversing or directly mounting a flake in the left-facing corner. You can place a good piece here(.4 camalot), then make a strenuous move to get to good finger locks in a right facing corner. A short stemming section is encountered before the final splitter crack in a left facing corner.There are two finishing pitches to choose from. the left one, Tommy's Sandbox, is around 5.11-, and the right one may be 5.10.
routes.route_location: The most popular way to get to this pitch is by taking godzilla, then Pitch 2 of city park.  This dumps you right at the base.
routes.route_protection: LOTS of small cams!!!  Nuts don't work in this crack very well.I think I may have used 4 yellow aliens.

route_comments.comment_text: one of the funnest pitches i've ever done!  go do it! Sep 17, 2006

The freight train crux makes the experience complete! I can not remember topping out without the train, you might want to hang out in the upper dihedral and wait for one to come so you may have the pleasure of doing the upper crux ...properly. Jan 31, 2007
Not a typo, but as for the significance ... I'm not sure. May 15, 2008

routes.route_fa: FFA P1: Terry Lien, Tom Michael. P2: Mike Schaeffer (as one long pitch from the ground)
routes.route_description: Climb the initial section of Japanese Gardens until you can protect the rightward entry moves with a bolt (at the chalkstone chockstone halfway up the hands section ). At this point the climb turns strenuous and technical. Once established in the corner climb through hard moves up to an obvious pin scar, from here another challenging section leads to a purely fun .11 finger crack to the chains. The second pitch has now been freed at .12d (I think), though I have never tried, so don't hold me to that.
routes.route_location: Start as for Japanese Gardens. From the ground it is the obviously difficult looking right facing corner that trends rightward off of Japanese Gardens.
routes.route_protection: Protection is thin, but there. Everyone that I know seems to protect this testpiece a bit different. It is all there, just not the most obvious. Use a draw with two lockers to protect the moves transitioning into the flare, there has been multiple close calls and an injury.

route_comments.comment_text: In Index the locals spell sandbag s-t-e-r-n Feb 4, 2012

Yet another variation on p1 is to move left after the anchor and reach the 2nd crux of Japanese gardens from directly below, climbing out the flake. I've heard this variation called "Sushi Farmer" and you'll want whatever gear you like on P1 Stern, plus a hand and finger cam and a few long slings. If both of these climbs were already 4-stars, this variation is off the end of the quality scale.... more Yet another variation on p1 is to move left after the anchor and reach the 2nd crux of Japanese gardens from directly below, climbing out the flake. I've heard this variation called "Sushi Farmer" and you'll want whatever gear you like on P1 Stern, plus a hand and finger cam and a few long slings. If both of these climbs were already 4-stars, this variation is off the end of the quality scale. P2 Stern Farmer ~5.12a - A mellow finger lock and a compression move or two lead to a powerful pull establishing up into the chimney/stem. There's a good-looking fixed head you can clip before the crux unless your're short. Since this crux might result in fall to the p2 belay stance, consider linking p1+p2 or lowering the belayer to a nice no-hand stance a few meters beneath the anchor. After getting into the chimney, a good fixed wire ( and later 2 fixed pins) protect tenuous flare chimney work, using knobs for feet, the hardest move is at mid height where there are no knobs for a second and your chicken wing skills get a test. Pull out of the chimney on a jug rail ( small cam) and face climb straight left past a bolt to the anchors atop p1 J. Gardens (VAR) or mantle up and right, joining P2 of batskins below the .11d crux move, (the 'fixed' heads all fell out in 2014) and finish via that pitch, which ends 10-15m directly above the anchors of p1 J gardens. Gear P2- single set from purple c3 / grey TCU to purple camalot, and a few runners. Feb 9, 2013
Specific gear for the sushi farmer ending is one #2 C4, and one green alien, and one red alien for after the crimp move at the top of JG if you like to place a piece up there. Oct 7, 2013

routes.route_description: An all-time, full value pitch with a good amount of both technical and burly movement, often at the same time. Enter the upper flare with effort, enjoy the mild and exposed chimneying, traverse right out of the roof and struggle-float through the final crux at 40m.
routes.route_location: Continue past the intermediate anchor on Stern Farmer.
routes.route_protection: Doubles in small cams, slings, 2x quickdraws.

routes.route_fa: Darryl Cramer, Greg Olsen, Larry Kemp
routes.route_description: Perhaps this route sees more traffic these days, but around 10 years ago it was a bit mysterious despite being a nice option above the initial pitches of Japanese Gardens. Wander up ledgy climbing above Japanese Gardens P2 towards the roofed base of the large, obvious curving flake. The climbing up to the roof gets progressively more difficult and the crux is moving left around the roof to where the flake curves upwards vertically and the crack behind it opens up more. This sequence is somewhat inobvious and powerful and the former fixed pin above the roof is gone now, although small gear protects adequately. The flake itself is fun, easier liebacking and crack climbing. From the top of the flake, a short "sting in the tail" slab section leads up and left past one bolt to the anchor atop P3 of TPMV.
routes.route_location: From the anchor atop P2 of Japanese Gardens, Stiff Kittens is visible above as a large curving flake with its bottom forming a roof feature. For reference purposes, the obvious thin crack/lieback Cheeseburgers on Trial is to the left. The true third pitch of JG is a crack in a groove to the right.
routes.route_protection: 12 years ago, the route had one bolt on the upper slab and no other fixed gear. It was clear that there used to be a fixed piton at the crux, but it was gone at that time. Luckily small cams and maybe some small nuts are totally adequate protection. It might be good to have some small nuts or RPs as well, although I can't recall using them. The upper flake takes some larger gear. The rack required for Japanese Gardens with the addition of a couple of smaller widgets if you didn't already bring them should be perfect. Since it's been awhile, take my recommendation with a grain of salt.

route_comments.comment_text: This route does not see any more traffic than a decade ago. Everything was awesomely crumbly and licheny when I climbed on it today. I saw the pin hole, looked like some small gear for sure! Might see traffic with a bolt for the traverse as the gear is undoubtedly small. Sweet route name. Dec 28, 2020

Seems to me the ticket is to go up and over the overlap that jogs left. There is a nice pocket that takes some gear, then preform a cool leftward move on knobs to regain the corner. I doubt this gets climbed often, but it is very very fun. Jan 20, 2021

This seems like mid 5.12 pulling over the roof then moving left as per Matt, and borderline impossible moving left below the roof. Matt, Jack, or others - did any remember beta or have other impressions? Jul 24, 2021

routes.route_description: This fun climb follows a thin corner crack.  A committing but easy balancy move takes you out of Roger's corner and into the next corner immediately right.  Thin fingerlocks and delicate stemming continue up, over two bulges, to easier terrain and the anchors.
routes.route_location: Immediately right of Roger's Corner.
routes.route_protection: Gear is adequate but thin.  Mostly small nuts and small cams.  Most of the rock is solid but some is crumbly, especially near the top.

route_comments.comment_text: pretty tricky to protect this. plenty of big fall potential. May 8, 2014

Just did this yesterday.  I thought this route was quite fun despite the cob webs. It feels pretty protectable to me but a fall might be interesting given the bulges. Bring several small cams and nuts, no big gear needed. There is also a nice tuft of grass growing in the last crack where you will likely want a jam. Definitely worth doing while waiting for the other nearby stuff to free... more Just did this yesterday.  I thought this route was quite fun despite the cob webs. It feels pretty protectable to me but a fall might be interesting given the bulges. Bring several small cams and nuts, no big gear needed. There is also a nice tuft of grass growing in the last crack where you will likely want a jam. Definitely worth doing while waiting for the other nearby stuff to free up. May 5, 2015
Easily Top Rope-able by climbing the easy first section of Roger's corner to it's first anchor. Jun 27, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Fell a bunch, but eventually made all the moves. Book says 10a, this feels harder. Pooped after. · trd this off the Rodgers corner. made a good try of it making it to the middle ledge where I had to do a right hand left foot stem to reach the finger lock, pulled hard for a few moves but didn't quite make it out of the dihedral. wore myself out pretty good · Follow. Jean crushed this thinking it was a 5.9. I fell once and struggled up this one on second. · TR. Would be a scary lead. Also climbed the next corner over. Featureless acrobatic stemming. Fun!

routes.route_fa: FA: Ben Gilkison, Stamati Anagnostou. FFA: Benny G 9.3.21
routes.route_description: Little people rejoice!Supermodelis the new direct start to Model Worker which completely avoids the original shoulder wrecking span which has left most sub 5 foot climbers scratching their heads...well before the 5.11b crux. What at first appears blank from the ground...upon closer inspection yields small sets of curious holds that require precision, high steps, insane balance, and single leg squat power leading up to the huge rail, and finishing at the short anchor; but of course would be even better linking up and through Tadpole.Some history: TR'd in all or part by Andrew Philbin in the very early 21st century (best recollection). I recall doing the direct moves back in 07' after futile efforts to do the Lynn Hill stem solution on MW (most likely due to my lack of frontal plane hip flexibility).  At the time, I gave the direct a lead by climbing up to the eye bolt on MW, back down to the ground, and then climbing over right to the direct start...eventually falling and swinging way left to slam hard into the wall. I recall the climbing being brilliant but the fall absolutely terrible.I'm certainly not a fan of squeeze jobs and unnecessary bolting, but do believe the distance between the original MW line and Supermodel allows adequate breathing room. Moreover, the climbing is just SO awesome!!  I would imagine the grade is all over the place depending on body composition, skill, flexibility, height etc.  Felt like Index 5.12c to me.  The direct now has 2 bolts. My girls wanted me to name the next FA I did after them, so AKA Sierra-Rose.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts, and an optional thin hand sized cam up to the short anchor

route_comments.comment_text: Thanks Jon!  It would be curious to examine that face for holds. Of course, from the ground it looks blank. The beauty of index is the fact that often the most subtle and almost imperceptible feature can make a route climbable. INDEX!!!!! Sep 5, 2021

Lead / Redpoint. 4 or 5 lead burns before my foot finally didn’t pop. + 2 previous sessions of toprope sussing · TR. Made it up model worker left start until dyno. Tried direct start that Anthony had just sent. Couldn’t pull any of the moves. · Lead / Redpoint. With Jacob. Almost gave up on this but finally all the stars aligned and sent!! Took 30+ attempts which is more than Stern Farmer and Like Honey combined, so probably Index 11d right lol? · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Nick. Got through the Supermodel section without falling but blew the 2nd MW crux lmao. · TR. pulled on draw for the crux. Upper model worker crux still felt impossible. or wear stiff shoes · Lead / Redpoint. Couple tries to find the right beta! A very fun climb. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. With Casey. 3 rp attempts, topping out 2 times. This is getting comical... · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. With George, Vadim, and Becca. ~8 rp attempts, topping out 3 times. · 3 pitches. routes.route_description: After the beautiful, stupendous, in-your-face Stern Farmer, step left to undercling the flake that forms the final crux of Japanese Gardens and head straight up, out of the dark corner system and onto the open, airy face. The transition is just breathtaking.If your face doesn't hurt from smiling by the time you clip the chains, seek help.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Bring a #2 Camalot for the undercling and a piece of pro for the JG crux. Beware of rope drag from whatever piece you place before the traverse.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. So hyped. Long time goal complete. It’s as good as they say, maybe better. JG crux probably doesn’t change grade cause of the rest but 12b is already stiff as it is… · Lead / Redpoint. Wooooooo let’s fucking go!! Clipped chains of stern, I clipped them sent it up to this rig. This thing is really forever · Lead / Fell/Hung. This thing is going as soon as the condis are firing. Almost went in the rain last night, almost went in direct sunlight this morning… · Lead / Redpoint. With Vivian and Long. Delectable! Felt really smooth on Stern but almost blew the second JG crux. · TR. did it with two falls. got the bottom part without falling until the last good pocket where you move your right hand outright. in that pocket, remember to let your left hand go up first, so your right hand does not block it. It feels counterintuitive. to enter the slot, go in at the lowest point with the right foot, bring the left foot in match feet. get hands into the two poor slots to stabilize, scum right foot, and move left foot up three to four inches onto the small nub in the crack. from there, it is just a series of stabilizing and moving the left foot up in the corner. · Lead / Redpoint. Third lead attempt took a few tries to get through stern! · Definitely the way to finish stern. No harder than to the first chains. Double kneebar in the roof is rad! · TR. on traverse into flare, match feet get right hand in flare, move feet up, then right foot out. rest is doable · Lead / Redpoint. A couple top ropes and one lead burn. No knee pad. Blue metolius before the “palm crux”, black totem after, .4 protects the run to the chains, #2, .3. · Lead / Redpoint. Soooo good inverted double kneebar “rest” feels super fun on lead, stern felt so nails and then it just went. Super cool route one of the best ever. · TR. felt pretty good! keep walking feet up, make sure to get the right hands in the correct spot. · Lead / Fell/Hung. classic index beatdown. PR whipper? stem harder. work the layback at top of crack to get to jug. .2 goes in pod below top pod. · TR. belayed by a new friend, michael! got it clean up to the thumb/palm press! need to press on the higher, more positive part. fingerlock in undercling. coming together! · TR. trolo boi stern spanking edition. less fatigue would help... some. still need to understand entrance sequence. got the easier part first try at least!

routes.route_fa: Dave Anderson, John Teasdale. FFA P1: Terry Lien, Greg Olsen
routes.route_description: Awesome tight fingers to start, boulder move crux with a pin.  Finish up an 11a offwidth/chimey/flaring corner, FUN.  Aside from the boulder move the route is consistent and really fun.
routes.route_location: This route is directly above Model Worker and can be reached as such.  Or do an easier route and rappel down into it via the Newest Industry slab anchors.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3/4", double small stuff...maybe tripples in small stuff and really light on the .5-.75 inch gear.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ground up via model worker with will and Jake. Whipped on fixed pin, then sent the rest of the pitch after a hang on the pin. Excellent climb, need to go back for the send. · Via model worker w Akash. Wasn’t in a stemmy mood and epiced on this thing after some small pieces ripped while aiding. Save the .1s for the upper flare

routes.route_description: Start via Sagittarius, but continue straight up through into thin flake, where Sagittarius cuts hard left. After a great rest, some strenuous layback moves and a few bolts lead to and under-cling mini roof, from here cut right to join P1 of TPMV via a few reachy moves.Note the under-cling above the thin flake stays damp for a long time after rain, this is where you place your piece to protect the moves to rejoin TPMV. Worth taking a look from the ground before embarking.
routes.route_location: Starts on Sagittarius, look for the huge flake system in the middle of the wall, bordered by the thin crack of Iron Horse to the left and the iconic corner of Japanese Gardens to the right.
routes.route_protection: Doubles of #0.3-#0.5, singles #0.75-#3, plus 3-4 draws for the bolts and fixed gear on route. Save at least one finger size piece for the last bit before anchor(0.3 or 0.4). If wide handcracks are not your thing, bring one extra big hands piece for the start on Sag (#3).Be sure to extend your pieces properly at the start, under the roof and once you rejoin TPMV or you can get some pretty heinous rope drag.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. did it in morning heat. quite hard, the move up to placing the 1 under the roof is hard. the reach across is also challenging, but it's solid 12 after it joins. nuts felt much better than cams, had to see it up to move up. was quite harder than iron horse or maybe even power horse, albeit different movement

routes.route_description: Blake Herrington originally pointed me to the undone direct start of Ten Percent Meteorological Vinculation. “Ten Percent” is a 5 pitch climb in the center of Index’s Lower Town Wall, first aided in 1972 by aid climbing legends, Bruce Carson and Dave Anderson (Carson and Yvon Chouinard were the first to climb the Nose clean, without a hammer). The first 50 feet of true start still had not been freed and was one of the most obvious remaining challenges at the Lower Wall.When I got on it for the first time, I couldn’t do all the moves but I could see that it would go, and was surprised that no one had done it yet. The holds and the sequences are quite beautiful...pure Index, but on another level from what I had been on before.It took about a year of getting on it here and there till I saw how it went and could link large sections. After an easy intro, the main part of the climb is only 25 moves, but 25 moves of tricky and hard vertical granite bouldering, with some classic Index funk and consistent bad feet. I linked the crux 3-move boulder for the first time this winter and knew then that it could go at any point.I decided to add 2 bolts to be consistent with how the rest of Ten Percent is bolted, and started to make attempts on lead. After 15 or so attempts over a few months, including a couple falls above the crux, I sent on a cool and dry spring evening, likely one of the last good days before the summer heat.This route could go gear only, but it seemed way more fun to not have to wiggle in stoppers, take massive, awkward, and possibly dangerous falls on them, and then wiggle them out to make another “clean” attempt. Somebody could surely do it...they will be way more badass than me. But now people can go free ground up safely and focus on enjoying the moves on one of Index’s best routes.After a few difficult boulders, the route breaks hard right on a line of crimps with bad feet to the ledge below the low anchors on Japanese Gardens. You could probably go straight up and avoid the ledge, but this seemed contrived. And instead of continuing up the 5.11+ climbing on Ten Percent I decided to end it short. It didn’t seem to fit the nature of the free variation to lengthen the pitch.I’m suggesting another name for the direct free variation, “En Passant,” French for “In Passing,” because it resonates with “Ten Percent,” and because I think the reintegration of the direct start deserves a more interesting name than “10% Direct.” The crux clocks in around V10/11, and you can fall in other places as well. I think it’s a solid step up from Amandla (5.13+) in difficulty and is likely Index’s first 5.14.
routes.route_location: Between Sagittarius and Japanese Gardens.
routes.route_protection: Start as for Sagittarius and break right at the finger crack (place a yellow C3) and up to the rooflet (#2 BD) below the dual thin cracks. I climbed the rest of the route with just the two bolts I put in, skipping the aid bolt (the third/last bolt). Finish at the low fixed anchors of Japanese Gardens.

route_comments.comment_text: Nice work Nathan! Glad I was there to watch. Great name. May 20, 2019

I remember thinking it would for sure go and probably be 14-.  I could do all the moves but struggled to make any real links.  I know Cole Allen also spent some time on it and thought the hardest move was a double digit boulder problem.  So pretty safe... more Way to get this thing done!  Pretty darn interesting climbing.  I may of been the first person to put work into this rig almost 10 years ago.  I remember thinking it would for sure go and probably be 14-.  I could do all the moves but struggled to make any real links.  I know Cole Allen also spent some time on it and thought the hardest move was a double digit boulder problem.  So pretty safe to say this thing is 5.14.... May 20, 2019

That’s awesome!  I think that 10% is the best line at the Lower Wall.  It’s a full length route and it’s a distinct line to the top.  Everytime I walked by that lower section of rock – and I mean EVERY time – I imagined myself freeing it because it is so in your face and the perfect Index rock.  I tried it once imaging it was a 5.11 slab and failed miserably. Everyone in the usual Index crowd... more That’s awesome!  I think that 10% is the best line at the Lower Wall.  It’s a full length route and it’s a distinct line to the top.  Everytime I walked by that lower section of rock – and I mean EVERY time – I imagined myself freeing it because it is so in your face and the perfect Index rock.  I tried it once imaging it was a 5.11 slab and failed miserably. Everyone in the usual Index crowd back in the 80s-90s tried it at least once.  Some gave it a concerted go.  I think Max said he TR’d all but a body length free.    Some controversial tactics were tried on occasion as well.  Not sure I understand giving it a new name – it’s 10%.  If every section was renamed when it was freed, the route would have a half dozen names.  And after all City Park remains City Park.  Renaming routes at Index seems to be a Mountain Project thing. May 20, 2019

routes.route_description: A lesser-done Index classic with lots of variety. There are multiple 5.10 sections, with stemming, slabbing, and crack climbing, all separated by rests. From the anchor atop Slow Children, step left and stem up toward a bolt, roof, and slab. Atop the slab, a hard v-slot move gains a large left-facing corner and more stemming, leading left (with gear) to a stance beneath the large roof. Pull the bolted roof (crux?) and follow a finger and hand crack to anchors atop the lower town wall.Adding this to the 3 pitches below makes for a great stretch of climbing with each pitch ~ 2 letter grades harder than the one before.This pitch should get done a lot more, and it needs the traffic to keep it clean.From the anchor of Tommy’s Sandbox, traverse skiers left to the anchor for Park Ranger. A 70m easily gets you back to the Slow Children anchor. Rappelling from the Tommy’s anchor is a rope stretcher and not recommended. Multiple people have come up short with 70s from the Tommy’s anchor to the Slow Children anchor.
routes.route_location: This takes the line above/left of the anchor atop Slow Children, and pulls a roof obviously visible from the railroad tracks.
routes.route_protection: 9 bolts plus several sections that require natural protection. Microcams/nuts recommended, the rack to get you up there plus some extra micro gear should be fine. I'd recommend doubles in .1 to .5, singles .75 to 2, and nuts including some micro. At least a few alpines on top of the 9 draws because it wonders a bit. 70m rope to rap (from Park Ranger anchor, 70 might come up short if you rap from Tommy's anchor).

route_comments.comment_text: Awesome pitch, definitely deserves more traffic! Jun 4, 2014
I did the FA of this with Chris Henson some time ago.  dont really remember the exact year.  And the name should be Tommy's Sandbox. Jul 4, 2014

Spot on rack beta and info on runners. Climbed at end of March 2015 after 3 or 4 dry days.  There were some sections of the slab which were wet after the left facing corner.  There is also a significant amount of moss/mud on the ledge below the v-slot at the start of this corner.  All of this seems to be avoidable without making the pitch much harder. The slab moves felt like the crux to... more Spot on rack beta and info on runners. Climbed at end of March 2015 after 3 or 4 dry days.  There were some sections of the slab which were wet after the left facing corner.  There is also a significant amount of moss/mud on the ledge below the v-slot at the start of this corner.  All of this seems to be avoidable without making the pitch much harder. The slab moves felt like the crux to me, felt similar to spineless at Private Idaho (e.g. 11a). Has a cool alpine feeling given how you need to run the gear, you are at the top of wall, and the general decrease in steepness compared to lower pitches.  Very psyched. Mar 31, 2016

Fell once on traverse below upper roof and once pulling upper roof. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Climbed cleanly save for a false start in the corner off the mid-pitch ledge. I hopped down w/o weighting the rope but grabbed it to maintain balance · Lead / Onsight. Crazy pitch! W Conor. Very varied, a little spicy. No falls! · Follow. Clean until the roof, swinging right to try and regain the bolt cause rope tearing and a scary time. Varied, don’t forgot how hard the slab is!
