Insane pitch! A complete 7 chapter masterpiece of index shenanigans! The top roof is both chess game and bar fight in one. Please keep the thing clean by climbing it!!! · Lead / Onsight. Wooooo! Slightly rainy headlamp ascent. Such a fun lap up the LTW · Lead / Fell/Hung. run out at the start. fell from the underclings instead of clipping from the massive jug at the roof

routes.route_fa: Dave Anderson, Bruce Carson, 1/73 FFA  (See description for full FFA details - too many characters to fit here))
routes.route_description: 10% Meteorological Vinculation (or TPMV for shot) is a classic 4 pitch excursion up the entirety of the Lower Wall.  Most often only the spectacular short version of p1 (via Japanese Gardens, .11+) is climbed. The original aid version of this route had 5 pitches (5.8 A4). The free version really only has 4, as the original second pitch is best combined with p1.P1 (Original): Formerly the last remaining bit of aid on the original TPMV, this section was free climbed recently at 5.14-. See neighboring entry "10% Direct (En Passant)". This is also an excellent C1/2 climb and in years past was often used as a place to practice hanging belays and setting up hammocks/portaledges.  For many years there was a two bolt anchor about 40’ up to facilitate aid practice.P1 (Japanese Gardens to TPMV):  This pitch is most often done as a standalone climb by beginning on P1 of Japanese Gardens and then stepping left at the first (short) anchor. The rest of the pitch follows shallow corners and cracks past 3 bolts and gear to another anchor (.11+).P1 (Extended): Climb the Japanese Gardens P1/TPMV linkup as described above but keep continue past the anchor. The section above consists of a difficult height dependent bouldery section protected by good but small gear (.12c-.13a). The gear must be placed well, otherwise the fall onto the P1 anchor is fairly substantial. As such, it is a mandatory strategy if free climbing to climb this as one pitch from the ground. This extension is basically the old "Chopper Flake" pitch 2 of TPMV; see "History" for more information about the flake.P2: This was actually P3 of the original aid climb. Climb cracks up a RFC to a comfortable ledge.  From there face climbing angles left to an anchor below the obvious corner start of the slab pitch (fun 5.10-, slightly runout).P3: Fantastic, challenging pitch of slab and corner. Traverse left and up from the anchor and do a committing and slightly scary move back right to clip the first bolt. Continue up the difficult corner via bolts and gear, then follow the left-trending dike until you can step right to a ledge with an anchor via runout 5.9 climbing. Alternately, continue up the dike and over the roof to join Newest Industry. This pitch can also be approached via P1-2 of Japanese Gardens and is well worth the trip either way (.11b/c).P4: This pitch climbs a slab past a bolt and some gear to a tough little mantle past a bolt. (5.10d) Cracks then lead near the anchor on top of Newest Industry, but 10% continues on via three slab options: a) climb out right and then up over some overlaps to the anchor (5.8). At one point there was a bolt and a pin on this variation. b) continue straight up past 2 bolts to the anchor. This variation has the best protection (5.9). c) an easier variation with less protection climbs to the left before arching back to the right to the anchor. It should be noted that a fun alternate finish that joins Japanese Gardens can be climbed by following a ramp up and right to join JG on its last pitch (5.11).
routes.route_location: Starts via thin cracks just to the right of Sagittarius.
routes.route_protection: Nuts and cams to #4 Camalot (for the section on Japanese Gardens) with emphasis on finger size cams; word on the street is that a micronut or small cam can be used to protect the crux on the extended P1.Descent is usually possible with one 70m rope in this section of the wall, but for peace of mind bring two that are at least 60m. All anchors mentioned above are bolted and currently have chains.

route_comments.comment_text: For the Full 10% (i.e. the extension), it is mandatory to link the first and second pitches together.  I fell off like 10 times while attempting the redpoint, and each of those falls from the crux took me past the first anchor.  The trajectory of fall precludes belaying at the first 10% anchor. Please Note: there is 3" ledge just below the first anchor that is possible to tag with a heel or... more For the Full 10% (i.e. the extension), it is mandatory to link the first and second pitches together.  I fell off like 10 times while attempting the redpoint, and each of those falls from the crux took me past the first anchor.  The trajectory of fall precludes belaying at the first 10% anchor. Please Note: there is 3" ledge just below the first anchor that is possible to tag with a heel or toe if one whips from the crux.  On one of my falls I didn't have quite the clearance, and smashed my heel smack into the small ledge, which didn't feel that awesome after sailing through the air for 15'.  Beware. That said, I didn't use any small cams.  I believe I protected the crux with a micronut.  If you decide to place a cam instead (which will definitely work), there is less room to use the crack pocket for your fingers. Yesterday I was up there and noticed the extension bush and greenery have really grown back.  Fortunately, this area is small.  Perhaps I'll head back up and do some cleaning soon. Also, don't let the grade intimidate.  It was one of those really hard to gauge routes.  While the crux is potent, it is relatively short lived and balancy to boot.  If you're taller than 5'6" I think that it would be perhaps only 5.12.  Though, the only other ascent was by my buddy Tobias who is 5'4". Jan 6, 2014

P2 isn't "R" for the 5.13- crux, which protects well with a BOMBER blue alien. It's a crux done above your gear, but most falls should be fine, though it's a bit runout above there on fun jugs. --------- P3 is a nice pitch that deserves traffic as an LTW moderate. ~.10- From the anchor atop P2 (which are also atop " It's a Dog's Life mountainproject.com/v/its-a… ...") and which is... more P2 isn't "R" for the 5.13- crux, which protects well with a BOMBER blue alien. It's a crux done above your gear, but most falls should be fine, though it's a bit runout above there on fun jugs. --------- P3 is a nice pitch that deserves traffic as an LTW moderate. ~.10- From the anchor atop P2 (which are also atop " It's a Dog's Life mountainproject.com/v/its-a… ...") and which is located 15' left of the top of J. Gardens P2: Climb the overhanging and leaning finger crack (crux) then mantle up and left. Move up and left again around the left side of a major flake system. Face climb up and slightly right on a flake and knobs, and then work out left up the left edge of the flake until it ends, and you can face climb shortly to the anchor. 5.10b - Single set of cams and include some slings. Aug 18, 2014

For taller folks (I am 6') reaching the good holds at the end of the boulder problem on P2 is easier, but getting the feet up into a super scrunched position and not peeling off the tiny holds still feels difficult(I thought v6/7). Go try it out! May 4, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell pumping out R clipping last! Tenuous R crimp knob w LF smear First crux: small R sp crack to hard L crimp clip, shuffle feet and hands for pods. L in upper better, hop up RF to smear black bump near belly. Reach R up Biggest brassie at top of corner after. Stand into Rs for good .4 at top (.4/.5? + smaller options). Traverse left w L ok, R better pod. (opt .1?) up L, push down R to keep bumping up RF. Up to crimp knob Crux: crack up good 2/3F pods? W feet stemming LF knobs R+RF handholds. Two .3s in pods above, one last tenuous lean off R gaston to bring up RF to clip anchor · 1 pitch. Warm up, lap, fell once at finger crack entry. Bring left foot up a bit higher to start. · 1 pitch. TR. Sent 1st pitch on TR. On first crux, bring right hand on small side pull, step up left foot, bring right foot up. Left hand goes onto thin upper crimp. Reposition left foot onto small ledge, bring right hand onto two finger pocket. Left foot up to bump split by crack, right foot onto bump, grab rail with left hand. 2nd crux, right hand into two finger slot, make sure to get left foot on far left nubs as you move up. · 1 pitch. TR. Crux 1: with both scars, bump l foot up to get high R foot. Crux 2: l hand in shitty scar, r hand pulling down on croissant, l foot on crack knob, r hand to high good lock (tension), r foot to basketball · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Second try of the night but have tried to extension before a couple years ago. Yo-yoed to the first anchor and led out. · 1 pitch. TR. Got all the moves, only fell a few times. Moving off the mini ledge, get right hand in upper pocket, stabilize with left hand, b ring right foot onto nub, rock over, smear left and pull. For second traverse Crux, get fingers in good pocket, move right foot slightly over to nub, smear left foot, and go up to nice pocket. Home free from there. · 1 pitch. TR. p1 crux move: L lock, high R foot. need to suss gear, totems didn't fit great in rest pod. offsets? avoid bats in holds · 1 pitch. TR. To first chains, skipped the first bolt past a sleeping bat. Didn't want to get rabies! · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. P1 only. Repeated clipping stance a few times for 2nd bolt · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once at crux. Sloper felt a lot better in condis! From knob: L gaston? Up feet, R sloper, LF out to surprisingly slippery knob. L sneaky good B2 lock in crack, hard smeary feet up into L undercling crack? To R better. Only need .2-.4 after JG · 1 pitch. Lead. Linking w JG. 1st pitch of the season. Nice, increasingly hard sequences culminating to the crux: L finger pods, R slopey holds. SMEARY LF in pods. Stand up RF on ball. Leeean left, Better fingerlocks higher · 3 pitches. TR. TR solo p2-4. The 5.11 slab pitch is hard as nails! · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. With some fancy heel hook beta for taller folks, the crux dumbs down quite a bit. I would say all 3 cruxes are similarly graded and in the 11+/12- range. Also feels quite safe with x4 offsets and a back up stopper. · 1 pitch. TR. First pitch. Extension is very hard. Feeling weak, couldn’t touch it. · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Full P1. At 6’2” with the “heel hook pistol squat” beta it was really not that hard. Whipped off the crux a couple times, very safe. · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. To the .11d anchor. Cool temps helped me a lot. Techy goodness! · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. RP of the full first pitch. Techy boulder problem. .2 X4 seems to be the best cam! · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. 11+ to first anchor. OS TR, then sent on lead · TR. made all the moves! saw a yellow alien and probly bring a few other small widgets · 1 pitch. TR. Good practice lap. High of 55, cloudy but dry week. Cold initially, fine on second lap · 1 pitch. TR. Make sure to warm up your three middle fingers before to avoid straining them.

routes.route_description: Bolted in 2019 by Stiggles, Tricksy was freed on August 17, 2021 by the Hobbit of Rock, none other than the illustrious Ben Gilkison. Start on Numbah Ten, veer left under the roof near the top, passing 3 bolts and continue up a lovely, airy arete. The arete was toproped back in the glory days, and to my knowledge was first led by either me or Florian Assman, stepping left from Numbah Ten anchor.The climbing is technical, with strange contortions on small holds all round. The arete is moderate but quite exciting. A worthy addition to the Lower Town Wall.
routes.route_location: Start on the cool dihedral of #10
routes.route_protection: The gear is whatever on Numbah Ten and 3 bolts (2 long draws) and a couple of finger cams and small nuts for the arete
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. That upper arete is superb. The crux is certainly tricksy, but not too far out.

routes.route_description: Start up p2 of Japanese Gardens and step right out onto the face. Engaging moves lead you up a steep flared hands and finger crack. Layback, jam, compress and dance your feet up this classic pitch. Stop at the chains on the ledge or continue to the base of p3 of Japanese Gardens (another 50’ or so).
routes.route_location: Climb Japanese Gardens p1 (full). Trout Farm is the steep face directly above the chains.
routes.route_protection: Green c3 - .75 BD size cams (doubles from .2 - .5) + small nuts. Bring a more comprehensive rack to BD #2 if continuing to the base of JG p3.

routes.route_description: Add an interesting traverse sequence above gear to gain Numbah Ten from Frog Pond, then finish up on That Arete (E5 6a)Waq̓waq̓us is the Lushootseed word for March, the time when frogs sing.
routes.route_location: Begin on Frog Pond.
routes.route_protection: Quickdraws, doubles from the smallest cam to tips size, a couple of offsets and some small stoppers.

area_description: A smoother slab area that sits a little higher than the base of the Great Northern (GN). This region extends to Roger's Corner. It has harder climbs than GN and less crack climbing.
area_getting_there: Walk along the base towards the lower wall. Near the start of Princely Ambitions, go up and left to the obvious slab.

routes.route_description: A nice but rarely climbed crack above the Terminal Preppie anchors. The top is often dirty, so consider rapping in from the top of the GNS to give it a quick cleaning first.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3".

routes.route_description: Thin edging, similar to that on Sonic Reducer and Terminal Preppie. Perplexing start - you might want to stick-clip the first bolt.After the roof, continue up, then either move right to finish on Terminal Preppie, or move left to the chains on Sonic Reducer.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 10 bolts and a microcam or small nut to protect the finishing roof of Terminal Preppie.Bring slings for the last bolt and the piece in the roof of TP.Rap rings to lower off.

route_comments.comment_text: Has this been cleaned recently? When I lived there I never saw anyone on it and it was always dirty. Never heard of anyone doing it either, though I'm not suggesting it hasn't been repeated.  Can anyone comment on the grade? I always thought this had a very high probability of being a classic index sandbag given the FA party. Jul 29, 2013

No cleaning yet, but I hope to clean it soon and try it. When we did Sonic Reducer and Terminal years ago, I thought this center line would be the best of them all, but never got around to doing it. Yes, it might be a classic sandbag, but certainly worthy of the effort. Jul 29, 2013

I've done it, clean enough scrubbed little early this yearlast bolt is missing  hanger two ways to do start go in from sonic reducer on underclings or do dyno to crimp from terminal. Its hard took me longer to redpoint than sonic reducer. 11d seams fair Jul 29, 2013

routes.route_fa: Jon Nelson, Greg Olsen, Russell Erickson
routes.route_description: Left of Terminal Preppie and Pretty Vacant is this line of 7 bolts. The crux is encountered amongst the first three bolts. Despite the low angle, expect to pull hard on small holds. The author of the most recent guidebook, Darryl Cramer, calls it "...an example of truly difficult low angle slab climbing." (Sky Valley Rock, 1999) That pretty much sums it up. The rest of the climb is 5.10 and is very enjoyable.
routes.route_location: The slab left of Roger's Corner contains three classy slab climbs: Terminal Preppie, Pretty Vacant, and Sonic Reducer; they are encountered in that order.
routes.route_protection: 7 bolts and a bolted anchor. Probably old webbing at the anchor; I don't recall whether or not there were chains. One 60m rope will suffice for the rappel.

route_comments.comment_text: Historically, the first 12 at Index. May 14, 2013
Bolts have been modernized including anchor. Location Update to avoid confusion. Left From Rogers Corner:  Strength Through Bowling, Terminal Preppie, Pretty Vacant, and Sonic Reducer. Aug 26, 2013
youtube.com/watch?v=ohZnOae… May 11, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. A couple falls in the bottom and at the roof. Rainy lightly lol

routes.route_fa: Greg Olsen, Bryan Trott, Jon Nelson
routes.route_description: A decent start leads to a bolt with sweet underclings through the reachy roof. Easier but still thin climbing leads past another bolt and some gear placements to another bolt and a traverse left and then back right to the anchors.
routes.route_location: Great Northern Slab. Between Terminal Preppy and Roger's Corner.
routes.route_protection: A few QD. Thin gear to green alien. A number 3 camalot was helpful. Also .75 is supposed to be good but I personally didn't need it.

route_comments.comment_text: 4 stars seriously? Aug 13, 2010
So you hate life, no? Aug 15, 2010

no, just don't like crumbly rock and poor dynamic 1 move wonders.  Of all the 5.11 routes I have done at index this is EASILY the worst one.  Terminal preppie just to the left for example has no crumby rock and excellent movement.  That is a four star route.... Aug 16, 2010

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Sent on TR afterwards - there's a couple key holds on sloping ledge above underclings to get to big jug. In the future either climb with double ropes or back clean gear before the first bolt so a fall at the crux is cleaner. · Lead / Onsight. insight with Doug's beta. small nut, 2 microcams, red camalot. Came in from right side. Key undercling at crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. I bailed after the low roof, that was a powerful move and felt good to figure out, but the next bolt after the roof is about 15-20 feet. I brought a single rack of cams down to .3 but couldn’t get any good gear, a black totem would probly work. Can bail to the anchors on right. Kinda meh route. · Lead. Started up but bailed right to Rogers corner anchor bc it started to rain. · Lead / Fell/Hung. black totem and bd #1 between first and second bolt. #2 and blue totem for finish. · Lead / Flash. A few years since last running this line. Traversed low to leave Terminal P, protecting the thin seam with a red C3 and struggling to wrap up the traverse. The remainder of the line went smooth, with a few position changes to reach the roof crux hold. · Follow. Followed Jacobs line to the first anchor on Roger's Corner. Will come back with more thin gear. · TR. TR after Roger's Corner. Really fun, especially getting over 1st roof. Should come back for the lead · Lead / Redpoint. Hella fun! Bring small gear 2x metolious blue and purple) to protect. Also a 2 to protect the top.

routes.route_description: I absolutely love this route!!!  Terminal Preppie offers multiple 5.11 cruxes with a great blend of power and finesse.Climb easily to the first bolt, then ponder the first crux:  an insecure friction sequence to nab a good jug below the roof.  Undercling right and power over the bolt-protected roof (5.10 if you do it right), then balance up to a short crack/flake.  Place a small wired if you want, or run it out to clip the first bolt of a fantastic three-bolt crimping sequence on matchstick to half-inch edges.  The highly technical ultimate crux comes at the last bolt, starting off a good stance, which is good because it might take awhile to decipher.Ah, but it's not over!  After a moderate runout (good holds will appear), sidle up on a flake below the final roof and place a small wired (good placements).  The final 5.11 crux pulls the roof on thin jams to a bomber rail, with a welcome horizontal hand crack at the back.
routes.route_location: Approach as for Roger's Corner.  Terminal Preppie is the first obvious route on the slab left of Roger's Corner.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts (old bolts replaced in 2007), plus a few supplemental pieces.  Definitely bring small wireds for the upper roof and for protecting the small crack/flake above the first roof.  A #1 Camalot works well in the flake getting to the first bolt.  A #3 Wild Country Rock is perfect for the upper roof.  You can place a #2 Camalot in the final horizontal hand crack.

route_comments.comment_text: The name Terminal Preppie lyricsdepot.com/dead-kenned… comes from a Dead Kennedys song of the same name. Jul 17, 2007
Classic index slab.  Hard levitation moves to good stances...and one crux after another till the chains.  I think this route sports 4 5.11 cruxs.  Beautiful. Apr 25, 2011
Safe but exciting runout after the last bolt on non-trivial climbing. Spectacular route that requires some creativity to decipher. Go do it! Oct 26, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd try. #1 at start. black totem and green alien for end. · TR. tr solo. first roof: left in jug, high right foot, crimps out right, pistol squat. crux above crescent is very thin edges · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the final hard move :( one of my favorite climbs at Index · Lead / Redpoint. Turns out low 40s and wind makes this feel easy rather than slippery! · Lead / Redpoint. -1st Roof RH up, Heel hook RH up, Heel to toe -1st Slab Crux -pull and balance -The Crux LF stays on ledge, RF step thru LF to far upward angled black hold RH to sidepull LH to slot RH seam high RF white smear Stabilize, balance, and pull up to better holds Final Crux 1. RH jam 2. LH high jam 3. Rh knee to foot Open up the shoulders & hips and stem and 4. Grab the jug · Lead / Redpoint. One top rope two leads to send. One of my favorite pitches out there · TR. the last bolt Crux took me awhile to figure out. then the last Crux is just brutal. didn't get today but it will go soon. · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell at crux, go for very high right foot with far left hand slot, then pull up and high left foot · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell after first roof and at crux. black totem for second roof · TR. ezpz now. For slab crux, get right foot on left side of good ledge. Left foot goes down and over to a good hold. Move left on whatever holds ya got then get left foot on a good foot chip further left on the vertical corner/rail thingy. · Lead / Redpoint. The last bolt was missing a nut. All the bolts were severely under torqued. I added a nut and tightened all the bolts. .5 protects the start, .1 (or brass nut) protects the end. · TR. doug and gabe! shut down at the crux but did the rest of the moves! so fun! · TR. Incredibly cool friction slab climbing on this. Would be rather "thrilling" on lead. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on finishing move. Need to focus on getting left foot on the spot just below and to the left of the jug. black totem protects great · TR. Did twice. Fell on last crux first time, fell on slab second time.

routes.route_fa: FA: Don Brooks 80' FFA Lucas DeBari
routes.route_description: This route is essentially two boulder problems followed by a fun 5.10 finger crack. Stand on the ground and touch 12 different holds 5 different ways before you commit to the slab boulder. Once through this section, encounter some fun face climbing to a no hands rest. The second boulder is steeper, more powerful, and allows access to the splitter finger crack on the hanging slab above.
routes.route_location: 10 ft left of Sonic Reducer
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts, couple Green or yellow aliens

route_comments.comment_text: Walkin The Dog?  Picked a nice plum here!  With so many routes to be done tho  I don't understand the name change. Jun 25, 2019
Nice work! Really cool climbing. Jun 25, 2019
I changed the name back to Walkin the Dog. My thought had been to keep it consistent with the old school punk rock songs of the era…maybe not my best thought to date Jun 25, 2019

area_description: The Great Northern Slab is where many climb their first time at Index. There are a lot of fun, moderate trad routes, mostly 2-3 pitches in length. When the sun is out, the routes are all in the sun.If it is too hot, the relatively cool Inner & Side Walls, as well as Lookout Point, also have great moderate (5.9 and below) routes.
area_getting_there: The trail from the parking lot leads straight to the Great Northern Slab (i.e. don't turn left or right, just go straight).

area_comments.comment_text: Does anyone know what the finger crack to the right of the start of the great northern slab is rated/called? Jan 3, 2017
Found a blue rope coiled at the base of Sandy Corner on 12/11/2017. We were the last ones to leave so I picked it up. Let me know if it's yours and we'll figure out how to get it to you. Dec 12, 2017
found some car keys on a small ledge at the top of sickle crack by the blockbuster block on 1/15/18. Probably dropped from somewhere on GNS. Left them on the sign by the porta-potty Jan 16, 2018

routes.route_description: A thin friction climb on the slab above the traversing 3rd pitch of Aries.
routes.route_location: Can be accessed by heading 20 ft right of the top of the Butt Lips Chimney or from the Sonic Slab anchors.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts

routes.route_description: This is a high-quality climb up Index's Great Northern Slab area, with a wide variety of climbing styles, perfect protection, and gorgeous Index granite. Though it is commonly done in 5 pitches, all of the pitches are very short (some less than 30 feet). The original rating on this route was 5.8, but is now an Index 8+. In Leavenworth, this route would easily be rated 5.9+ or 5.10A.To approach, just cross the tracks, go slightly uphill, and trend diagonally right to the closest wall. Look for the obvious fist-crack and start here.Pitch #1 - 5.8 - Jam up the hand-crack which turns into tough flared fists at the crux. Belay on the ledge. 25 feetMove your belay over to the base of the finger-crack on the climber's right.Pitch #2 - 5.8 - Jam or lieback up the thin fingers to tips crack in the left facing corner. Scramble up to the base of the squeeze and belay at the fixed bong. 70 feetPitch #3 - 5.8+ - Wrestle and grunt your way up the vertical featureless superslick flared squeeze chimney. This pitch is often wet. Remember to remind yourself that it's only "5.8". Belay on the ledge above. 40 feetPitch #4 - 5.8 - Climb the crack up to the roof, then hand traverse to the left with beautiful exposure. Turn the corner then jam the hand and fingercrack to the big anchor. 70 feetPitch #5 - 5.7 - There are 2 options for this pitch. Consider the left one, which is much better. Scramble up to the tree, then angle up and to the left towards the arete. Look for 2 bolts above you. Fun balancy slab moves bring you to the anchor at the top of the wall. 90 feetDescent: Rap the Great Northern Slab route. Only 1 rope needed.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 1 each cams smallest Alien to a 3 CamalotExtras in thin hands to hands are nice for pitch #41 each small nuts60 meter rope

route_comments.comment_text: A fun climb. Sep 13, 2006
The buttlips chimney is pretty burley for 5.8.  I'd sure like to know the sequence to keep it under 5.10. Jul 9, 2007

Climbed the 2nd, 3rd and 4th pitches of this route today, and had a blast.  We combined the 2nd and 3rd pitch into one pitch, and rapped from the anchors at the end of pitch 4.  Our 1st pitch was the short 10c tips corner around to the left, which added a nice wake-up call for an end of day climb.  Taken individually, each pitch was gem. Jul 9, 2008

routes.route_description: A fun outing, this route tends to be pretty popular.P1 (5.2) Start in the corner to the left of the flat ledge with the 10c toprope problem. Climb rightward up a ramp and through some bushes, then straight up an easy ramp to two very large (i.e. 1-inch diameter) bolts.P2 (5.7) Climb up the corner. The 5.7 move is the somewhat awkward move to gain a sloping ledge. Continue up the crack system on the left or the right (technically Pisces), both 5.6, to a belay/rappel station with an overcomplicated set of chains.P3 (5.7+) Either climb up a ramp left and continue up to the top, or go right up another ramp and climb a slabby face to the top. Descent: Rap the route. With 2 60-m ropes, you can reach the ground from the rap station at the top of the second pitch.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: A standard trad rack to 3" will suffice, with lots of runners to help reduce rope drag. All the belays are bolted.

route_comments.comment_text: Seemed a lot easier than 5.7+ to me. Eats up stoppers. Gets really crowded!!! Feb 9, 2006
A good climb. Sep 13, 2006

Anyone know the details of the bolted line that runs up the arete on the far (climbers) left of the 3rd pitch? Climbed it today instead of the crack to the right that i've done in the past. Felt a bit harder and was really fun. Sep 1, 2013

route_comments.comment_text: The three 1/4” bolts on this have been replaced. This route is now safe to lead! Get on it! Sep 25, 2023

routes.route_description: The obvious handcrack going straight up to the right of the huge eyebolt.  Approach as for GNS, Pisces, etc.  Goes from tight hands to perfect hands to fists all in the course of 20 feet, then finishes up the beautiful easy crack above.  Many people think this is tough for the grade - I've known people who onsight 11 crack to get spanked on this short pitch.  Maybe handsize dependent?
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: One set of camalots

route_comments.comment_text: If you have big hands, getting established in the tight hands section will probably seem hard, luckily it widens up quickly. Mar 21, 2006
Definitely a sandbag.  It helps to be tall.  Stemming as high as possible at the start will allow you to get your hands past some of the tight jams. Dec 5, 2009
Apparently it helps to be short also. Oct 20, 2014

A lot of work to do! · Lead. Lowered down and eventually got it straight through clean. Rough · TR. Hard. Very hand size dependent and worthy of an Indian Creek style flat grade of 5.10. · Lead. Thin seems leadable once I’m in better shape · TR. mock lead, gear beta: .75 1 2 3 :) bring more 1s and 2s for Pisces after. · TR. followed this pitch after leading the first, only uncomfortable for a short section, very easy to protect · TR. TR. 3 laps clean. 1st no gear, 2nd placed gear and left it, 3rd cleaned gear while climbing. 2x 0.75 from ground, reach up above both, left foot jam under roof, layback R hand, bump left hand, right foot layback crack edge, repeat. 1,1,2,2,3 w/ draw · TR. Pulled on gear for the start.... oooof, not good at thin hands. Great hands and fists after · TR. lowered again from P2 GNS, another clean send plus Picses. Same beta, stem, high gear, reach 2x thin hands, kinda layback left and get a foot high, step up to good hand! Don't blow the funky exit. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung after getting up to a decent #1 jam. routes.route_description: Difficult climbing up the arete to the right of the Butt Lips Chimney.

route_comments.comment_text: After a little scrubbing each summer, this route is worth the try. BETA Warning*****Stay to the right of the corner and look for small feet on the face. Super strenuous and balancy.  Bring stiff shoes!  I would not use this as an intro climb into the 11's at index. You can top rope the route by climbing one of the 5.8's to the left of it. Mar 25, 2013

routes.route_description: This perfect splitter handcrack is really a continuation of Libra Crack but is often climbed by itself. To climb the crack w/o climbing Libra there is now only a single commonly climbed option:Climb the 5.0 gully past the giant rings and follow the corner (part of GNS) before traversing right to the base of the 5.6 hand crack. The crack starts just above Libra Crack. It is important to note that the Index Town Walls guide book by Kalman and Van Biene include Libra crack (5.10a) as part of the original Pisces route and therefore rates Pisces a 5.10a.It used to be possible to climb the 5.4 corner above, and just left, of Blockbuster before traversing left past an arete to the base of the crack. However the blockbuster boulder was pushed off the wall with a hydraulic jack presumably for safety reasons. The remaining wall is no longer commonly climbed and the Blockbuster route is gone forever.
routes.route_location: Right of the twin cracks above the giant ring anchors.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2.5".

route_comments.comment_text: I found the hardest move on this route to actually be the traverse left from the top of the 5.4 gully to reach the base of the handcrack. May 31, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Pure fun and easy jamming. Starting Corner left of the eye bolts is definitely the crux · Attempted multiple times with great success, some of the best jams on this wall. · TR. Led up Great Northern Slab, finger crack (left) variation. At P2 anchor I did a quick rap down and TR solo lap of Pisces hand crack. Such an amazing hand crack · Lead / Onsight. Did 3 pitches total started on Aries (5.8), then this, ended on Pisces(5.6) with Daniel following. Great pitch · Lead. Ran p1 of GNS into this. Rope drag wasn’t to bad with long runners and minimal placements · Lead. First trad lead attempt. Crack to the right right size for girls and petite men · Follow. omg I loved this so so much. climbed the gully to the giant rings, Jarrett led up the 5.7 and then connected to this. · Lead / Redpoint. Traversed in from Aries first 2 pitches for a long pitch. Good fun

routes.route_description: Now that "Blockbuster" fell off, there is no longer an easy way to access the trough to the right of Libra Crack which leads directly into Pisces or out right towards Taurus. Instead you can now pull a wild dynamic move off of a good stance followed by a short steep hand crack to gain the original route. From there, either finish directly up Pisces or head out right towards Taurus.The new dynamic sequence is pretty unique and fun. I'm entering it as it's own route in the hope that more people try this as an alternative to Libra.
routes.route_location: Directly to the right of Libra Crack. You can use the same new anchors as for Libra.
routes.route_protection: Small nuts / small cam to protect the crux, hand sized gear above.

routes.route_description: Short stemming corner used as an alternate start to GNS or Pisces/ Libra Crack.
routes.route_location: Obvious short corner directly to the right of the GNS start.

route_comments.comment_text: FA Mike Berman Mark Weigelt 1969 Jan 15, 2019
This into Libra, then up the crack then slab (Pisces?) to the trees makes for a nice link up. Aug 23, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 hung, couldn't commit to the dead point first go. Sews up great with nuts, used WC 1, 2, and 3. Great way to start GNS! · TR. Following Sophie up GNS. Figured this would make the first pitch more fun. Tough! Almost fell. Went feet in the corner. · 2 pitches. TR. Hopped on this while waiting for friends since a party had a TR on it and offered a belay. Fun into to Index! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Guaranteed to deck if you fall at the crux. Got scared and hung before going for it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a few rests before committing to the topout. Small finicky gear made for a challenging second placement while holding in with a small left foot ledge, a smearing right foot and a decent, but pumpy right hand. · Lead / Redpoint. Blue #8 offset nut, #0 Z4, and grey #2 peenut made this feel nice and safe · TR. On TR solo Rig: ascender (2 slings - bunjee cord would work better) + microtraxion · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Floyd, he was psyched, got my psyched, it was hard but funGear: .2 x4, 2 offset peanuts. Super slick thin fingers/tips with crux of a series of bumping up to crimps on the right and reaching for the top with the left. Had to aid off second placement · 6 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. #1 ball nut up high. Lead and followed many times, best to lead since getting gear out in the stance is challenging · 2 pitches. TR. Should really come back and try to lead this. Would be fun to place some small nuts. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lack of warmup crushed my fingers and onsight attempt. Otherwise manageable. · TR. Bonus 10pm lap. Lots of slugs. Finished the dihedral by pulling off the sloper rail on the left. Does the entire crack go at 10d? · Lead / Pinkpoint. Got it with a rest in the middle.Placed purple nut too well,stuck.Easier 2nd go.Match high crimp · Lead / Fell/Hung. First trad whip/piece blowing out. Tiny nuts. REALLY hard, but good.Alex led most, i just mooched · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 walnut protects crux. Smear high and lunge for left lip. DNF · Attempt. top rope from the monolithic rungs on Great Northern Slab. Fell on the last move... which is crux.

routes.route_description: The traversing lower half of the crack can be climbed either high (by shuffling your feet along the crack using your hands for balance) or low (with your hands in the crack while smearing).  The upper half of the climb is easier.
routes.route_location: From the ledge this climb heads up the sickle shaped crack between P1 of the Grat Northern Slab and the Aries diehedral.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3".  Smaller gear for the crack, larger for the anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: Interesting feature. Link to Blockbuster and Pisces for a pretty rad long pitch. Jul 12, 2015
Hand traversing at the start was rather strenuous (feeling more like 5.8) and tricky to protect. I imagine tip-toeing across would be easier, but it might be harder to place protection. Sep 1, 2020
Literally walk up the crack. Sep 8, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Felt very hard with hand traverse not good gear due to dirt in crack · Lead / Flash. First cleanly led 5.7 at index! Beginning is balancey with small but good gear and second half is easy · Lead / Onsight. Did 3 pitches total started on Aries (5.8), then this, ended on Pisces(5.6) with Daniel following · Lead / Onsight. Hung from the crack rather than walking it. Walking it looks rad but protection in the mid section is marginal and a bounce / slide on the 45°slab down to the ledge would be a bummer. Next time? · Lead / Onsight. Single pitch from the start of Aries into single crack then libra crack · Follow. Sent on Follow but felt tricky. We tried smearing but it didn't work well. Walked across the ledge. It was dirty. Basically just balancing. Rapped from pitch 2 anchor for Aries / with Aaron · Lead. Actually really tricky with hands on, backed off then way easier feet on. Totally covered in dirt and pine needles. Approach on Aires p1 · Lead / Onsight. Walking the crack is easy, but committing and a bit scary as you'll almost for sure hit the ledge if you pop a foot. · Lead / Onsight. routes.route_description: A two pitch route with an excellent upper hand crack.P1. From the top of Blockbuster climb the easy corner just to the left left. Consider belaying here to reduce rope drag). Traverse right passing the top of the Butt Lips Chimney and the start to Air Over Aries to a angular looking hand crack.P2. Head straight up the hand crack until it joins with the final pitch of theGNS.

route_comments.comment_text: This route has a lot of mediocre climbing for a stellar 30' crack. Although pitch 1 is easy, don't forget to place gear for protecting your follower and use long slings to reduce rope drag. At the end of pitch 1, belay under a big roof; just below and to the right you will see the bolted anchor at the top of Walkin' the Dog. You won't be able to see the hand crack of pitch 2 until you traverse... more This route has a lot of mediocre climbing for a stellar 30' crack. Although pitch 1 is easy, don't forget to place gear for protecting your follower and use long slings to reduce rope drag. At the end of pitch 1, belay under a big roof; just below and to the right you will see the bolted anchor at the top of Walkin' the Dog. You won't be able to see the hand crack of pitch 2 until you traverse right and then up over a bush. Sep 1, 2020

route_comments.comment_text: This route is not an X/R route.  It has been re-bolted and the protection at the top is excellent.  A #1 fits in the back of the crack and a #2 fits in the center if you want to double your pleasure.  That would be overkill tho! I would put it an 11a.  Start on the roght side of the corner and work your way up to the left side.  Finish with a long reach.  Scary, but fun. Mar 25, 2013
The name was Russell's idea. Thank goodness he suggested it, as our original name was really bad. Sep 28, 2015
As of May 2016, this route needs some cleaning. Totally overgrown with black lichen. Too bad cause it looks like some cool techy arete climbing. May 8, 2016

area_comments.comment_text: I will follow up with better descriptions Sep 2, 2021

Very cool wall, thanks Marty and Doug for all your work up there. Really excited to see what's to come. Heads up for anyone venturing up there, this wall is still a work in progress. Expect some dirty/loose holds, I broke a few holds while I was up there. And definitely don't bring dogs or kids, the belay ledge is sketchier than WWI. That being said the lower 5.7-5.8 pitches are all clean... more Very cool wall, thanks Marty and Doug for all your work up there. Really excited to see what's to come. Heads up for anyone venturing up there, this wall is still a work in progress. Expect some dirty/loose holds, I broke a few holds while I was up there. And definitely don't bring dogs or kids, the belay ledge is sketchier than WWI. That being said the lower 5.7-5.8 pitches are all clean and solid and make a great addition to the growing collection of moderate sport climbs at Index. Oct 5, 2021

Huge thanks to the developers for another spectacular sport crag! Great routes and stunning views (even from pitch 1). As of mid-Aug 2022, the crag was open but still under development. Be sure to give a shout to the developers, if they're cleaning while you're there. Check the plastic info box on the tree just after the turn into the crag and wear your helmets. Aug 28, 2022

route_comments.comment_text: We got a bit lost on this and weren’t sure we were going the right way due to the criss-crossing bolt lines and eventually bailed. My partner also pulled a block off so watch out for loose rock although maybe he got the last of it. Seems to take 13+ draws unless we did the wrong thing. Jul 10, 2022

Lots of fun, one of the better routes on the wall. From what I remember it meanders up and left towards a roof, finishing up and left through the roof. Took a lot of draws. Easier to clean on tr, but is manageable on lower with some fun swinging. Jul 10, 2022

I believe this route is 95 feet long... from somewhere. I'm not sure where that is though, certainly not the ground. Our 70m rope ended with both my belayer and I dangling 5ft off the ground furiously converting meters to feet trying to figure out what happened. That said, the movement around the left of the roof was absolutely amazing. Sep 2, 2022

Super fun first pitch. Nov 27, 2023

route_comments.comment_text: Super fun crux! You head out onto a floating fin feature and squeeze up it with excitement. Very nice! Oct 1, 2021

Awesome route that I am not the close to sending. Heads up that there’s a seam on the upper fin that has some small foliage growing out of it. Not sure if the seam is even useful but you might want to bring a wire brush to clean it out. The route is otherwise in great condition. Apr 13, 2024

This climb starts with intriguing crimps and odd movements off the deck. This section is very closely bolted, basically an aid ladder. This is followed by more relaxing but still attentive climbing to the fin. Clip the fin and voyage onward into the crux. Jun 29, 2024

routes.route_description: Face climb past bolts blocky overhang, when your head hits overhang move left, continue up face. At top you can do the direct finish over bolts or bail to the gully.70m rope is REQUIRED
routes.route_location: Far right side of cliff.3rd class up to anchor 40' or start onSauna Time and traverse over
routes.route_protection: 14 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: 70m rope is EXACTLY the length needed from bottom anchor (reached after the scramble) to top anchor. Stopper knot touched my grigri once I lowered my partner all the way. I highly recommend climbing the face at the end of the route rather than taking the gully - feels exposed and epic. A few large, disconnected rocks near the top could dislodge so avoid touching them. Jul 10, 2023

Found the description here a bit confusing and found out quickly the route is 35m from the intermediate station. NOT from the ground. Route was overall fun, you'd pull some crimpy moves, then get a nice stance, then do it all over again. What kind of ruined it was the last 5m, feels like the climb could end naturally at the first major ledge you come to and it would be much more fun than doing... more Found the description here a bit confusing and found out quickly the route is 35m from the intermediate station. NOT from the ground. Route was overall fun, you'd pull some crimpy moves, then get a nice stance, then do it all over again. What kind of ruined it was the last 5m, feels like the climb could end naturally at the first major ledge you come to and it would be much more fun than doing bellyflop mantling onto a super dirty ledge then having your rope run over a loose gully to top rope. Just my two cents, would be a 3 star climb if it was cleaner and ended earlier. Aug 3, 2023

Attention!! At the top near the last two bolts there is a tree stump and above the tree stump there is what looks like a rock tower that stands 3-3.5 ft and is to the right of the last bolt. The rock sitting above is about 250-300lb and is VERY loose resting on top. This rock could kill or cut a rope and climbers should take EXTREME caution when climbing near it. Be advised as little as a rope... more Attention!! At the top near the last two bolts there is a tree stump and above the tree stump there is what looks like a rock tower that stands 3-3.5 ft and is to the right of the last bolt. The rock sitting above is about 250-300lb and is VERY loose resting on top. This rock could kill or cut a rope and climbers should take EXTREME caution when climbing near it. Be advised as little as a rope brushing it could very well knock it down. Aug 11, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Almost onsight but fell on the last move cause I was committing to the face instead of going up the fully and the intermediate face is so slope-y :( Fun problem and not that hard though. Defs 70m. Relatively easy scramble to the anchor · Lead / Fell/Hung. Sent. Fell at very top of route. It's pretty messy up there · Lead. Via face variation at top (probably 10c/d and definitely harder than anything else on the route) · Lead / Onsight. Good route. Stepped into gulley near 5th bolt. Felt pretty full on. Face finish at the top. Most ledges have dirt and pine needles all over them. · Lead / Onsight. not often that you find exit 38 quality rock at index! · Lead / Flash. Great climb. Committing face climb at the end I will have to come back for. · TR. There’s some extremely loose boulders up in the gully near the top, frankly seems like a bad idea to climb this right now with how ready to fall they are

routes.route_description: 5.7 climbing through first 3 bolts to a ledge. Climb up corner for some fun 5.10 climbing and follow line up past several bolts. Finish the climb with a committing mantle move from a good crimp to a goodish sloperhold moving to the right, the jugs back left to anchors.70m rope REQUIRED
routes.route_location: Starts behind fir tree following bolts to the right of perma-draw.
routes.route_protection: 10 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: After the 3 bolts to the ledge, the 2nd bolt after the ledge has some difficult arete moves and there is good decking potential if you blow it. Rest of the climb is more technical and interesting than Project Petzl. Oct 1, 2023

I recommend extending the second bold above the ledge with an alpine draw and a normal one to avoid ledge falls. Folks at the base of the climb mentioned someone ledge-falling pretty hard recently. Without this, the climb warrants a PG rating IMHO. Jun 29, 2024
The shallow corner (bolts 4 and 5?) is brutal. Most I've fallen on a single lead, including a deck on the ledge. Aug 17, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. The corner is extremely hard. First third is hard esp if you’re short. Once you reach the good hand hold, the rest is more enjoyable · Lead / Fell/Hung. One hanged arete at start of 5.10 climbing. Committing moves off ledge with deck potential before climbing 2nd bolt. · Lead / Fell/Hung. had to stick clip second draw on the second ledge to avoid decking it · Lead. Def an Index 10. Corner was really fun but above a ledge and tough for a shorty. Do not go left around the corner at the last bolt- very scary rope drag.

routes.route_description: Farthest route on the left side wall. First pitch ends at hanging chains. Second pitch wild moves though to start and fun climbing to finish,
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: A super spooky and bouldery start on the second pitch (but very fun), as a short person (5’1”) I found this route a little extra challenging. Jul 10, 2022

Very fun, gym like climbing with massive holds. If someone goes up, could be a good idea to manicure the bushes near the top. Either extend draws or skip a couple bolts down low to reduce rope drag if linking pitches. Jul 10, 2022
Linked pitches from ground to second anchor but bolts continue above, so is it three pitches or two? May 1, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. One take at the crux, told me a second to figure it out, was nice and juggy once I found it · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Easy af Only first pitch. Move to get to start of second pitch hard but seems doable Want to come back and do it · TR. First pitch is solid, second pitch is challenging but super fun! The overhang moves are sick. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Belay stance is odd; make sure belayer is anchored to first bolt. Pizza box sized hollow flake 3/4 of the way up made me nervous; I x’d and avoided entirely. Otherwise fun climbing, very chill for 10b. · Lead / Onsight. Spooky loose blocks all around the edges of the line and some questionable rock directly in line significantly detract from this otherwise fun climb · TR. On crux, bring left foot up to left, left hand on top of flake, right under.... then bring right foot far to right to smear. Lean to right and grab pinch. Then as leaning to right take left hand and switch 180 to make it a pinch on the arete. Then stand up..... 3rd clip there os a massive jug way high up in the crack · TR. Need to stick right foot out further on crux, use sode pull and move to right not up to left. 3rd bolt there is a jug up to left in crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. Linked P1 and P2. Clean lead on P1 but a few takes on P2 as I figured it out. Experienced rope drag near the top of P2. · Lead / Onsight. North group, lead first pitch, too on second, rolled ogg ceiling, lost cell phone · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pulled one draw to get clipped above the first pitch anchors. Better to be safe than proud. Linked both pitches as a single lead. 70m barely reached back to the ground level belay ledge from the top of pitch two. · Follow. Following on the first two pitches linked. Didn’t climb the third. Linking the first two pitches is recommended to avoid a hard catch since the crux is right after the anchors. Used a 70m rope. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped around 3rd bolt on 2nd pitch. Went out too far to left instead of staying in line with bolts. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Lead first pitch, Vince took second pitch. One hang on second pitch. · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Followed on the first pitch, lead the second one. fun route, would've been easier with more light (climbing after sunset) · TR. Second pitch is mean and hard cause of short, probably 5.10d/11a moves down low, especially the start which I couldn’t do the rock over for

routes.route_fa: FA- Don Brooks, FFA-Jim Yoder, Matt Kerns, Bill Crawford
routes.route_description: A crack in the middle of a sea of bolts. It needs a little cleaning.
routes.route_location: The crack just right of Billy’s Corner. Start is at two bolts 3/4 the way up Stolen. Or combine with Stolen for one awesome long pitch.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3”

route_comments.comment_text: Still dirty but has potential Nov 27, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. Maybe it’s the moss but that’s not 10a to me. Makes sensation station or ride the lightning feel easy by comparison Lead 3/4 of the way up and was too pumped to finish. Will return. · Lead / Onsight. Definitely mossy and wet when I did it… the transition to stemming was sweet! Definitely a bit scary down low where there is some ledge swing potential depending on gear. Someone should bring a wire brush up to clean the moss. I will if I climb it again. A 70 doesn’t reach the ground, lower to intermediate then rap or do 2 raps · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tried to lead from the top of Stumps but it was quite hard to get right into the crack. Very dirty climb and I gave up and eventually rejoined the bolts of Billy's Corner.

routes.route_description: Stick clip the first bolt and go!
routes.route_location: It starts just left of Sauna Time . First clip is the perma- draw and then you head straight up for 2 pitches. You know you are on route if you clip the stump.
routes.route_protection: Bolts many

route_comments.comment_text: Bottom pitch is quite dirty and not really worth it as a single pitch. Aug 17, 2024

Very fun multi pitch definitely high up for the first bolt on P1 and i found it a tad hard to route find for P2 as there is alot of work being done up there. but you just continue straight up the bolt line you dont venture left or right i ended up needing around 15 quickdraws for P2 i had brought 12 and had to backclean a few Sep 18, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Fun long route, exciting first bolt without a stick clip, but doable if you’re very comfortable at the grade

routes.route_description: I would say it is a classic but it was stolen from me.
routes.route_location: Start just right of Stumps in the corner. Then head straight up the arete.
routes.route_protection: 10 bolts and chains. Anchor shared with Stumps Out.

route_comments.comment_text: Great climb with a mix of climbing styles. Fun exposed face climbing at the end. Bring an alpine to reduce drag as the route goes right. Aug 28, 2022
There is an optional anchor under the #BigScaryBlock that you can use to TR this climb if people are utilizing the Stump/Stolen anchor. Oct 30, 2023
Last hanger (that's been missing for about a month) was replaced 8/3/24. Aug 4, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Z clipped on the ~5th anchor at the beginning of the second slab. Nearly took a hell of a whip · Lead / Onsight. Awesome climb! A little spookier on lead than Big Scary Block as it has slightly harder moves. Climbing the arete and the exposure both make this a fun solid route. · First multi-pitch! We used the TR anchor as the first anchor, then climbed up to the top as a second. Has a bolt missing near the top I believe. · Lead / Flash. Crux possibly at start good 7 following the arete to nice platform anchor · TR. Best one today. Super fun movements on the arete. Felt harder than a 5.7 at the base but mellowed to the top. Typical index grading. · Lead. Repeat. Brandon on belay. I still hate the start. Full value 5.7 though. · Lead / Onsight. Fun climbing for a 7, better than most other low grades here. · Lead / Flash. Quena on belay. Up to first 2 bolts, moving onto the slab face a bit committing, as is moving around the arete eventually (wee bit of exposure). Also very windy and cold morning, and sun was directly in my eyes, hard to see the arete at times · Follow. Steven lead first of day. Anchor at top of this climb was a total clusterfuck most of midday and don’t see why there isn’t another set of anchors to the left for stumps out as well as providing anchor to belay the two extensions above. · Lead / Onsight. Great route! A little trick, great position, good stone. Well bolted · Lead. Started on the climb to the right and crossed over to the face. Doable with an alpine · Lead / Flash. Spooked but really good holds on everything. Way too skidish the first time for how easy this climb was. Can definitely lead it first next. · Lead / Onsight. Realized after that I could've gone up 3 additional bolts to the upper anchor with chains · TR. Arete is cool. Crux is towards the bottom of the route moving over to the right before heading up. · Lead / Onsight. Great climb, so long, but really well bolted. Kinda slopey & smeary but never both; and the friction is so good you never notice Azeem followed

routes.route_description: Fun climb through great rock
routes.route_location: Second route, when starting at the left of the belay ledge. Same start as Stolen. Follow bolts to the left of the stump (located a few bolts up). Go up the crack and finish at the anchors shared with Stolen.
routes.route_protection: 10 Bolts. Shares an anchor with Stolen.

route_comments.comment_text: Fantastic climb with an option to crack climb or layback your way up. Aug 28, 2022
Super fun route. Better than it looks from the ground. Continuous engaging movement with fun exposure. Apr 26, 2023
Waaaay better than it looks. Amazing movement for a 5.8. Oct 28, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Really sick route, loved the exposure, stemming and of course the crack · Lead / Onsight. Super fun! Heady crux, but generally easier than the other 5.8s we’ve done this trip. · Lead / Onsight. Could be mixed. Nice crack for pro or hand jams. Exposed at top! Awkward cleaning. · Lead / Onsight. 5 stars! So cool varied styles and slopes! Rad jams and jugs and crimps and slab. Good exposure. Rad! Gunned for Nastassia · Lead / Flash. Fun route. Crux right before anchor moving over exposed arete on right · TR. So fun! But dirty at the top though! Anchors aren’t great for TR but it’s sufficient. Shares an anchor with the Arete climb next to it · Lead / Fell/Hung. Onsight except for one take a few moves from the finish · Lead / Onsight. Lovely hand crack and fist crack. Climbing with Ri. Lots of exposure. Beautiful views · Lead / Flash. Fun engaging climbing with lots of variety! Moves up and over the roof were my crux. Careful what you grab here with some loose blocks. · TR. W/ Quena. Very 3D climbing, some handjams up an overhung crack was a first for me. · Lead. Super fun 5.8. Great movement and holds. Final move to pull onto the anchor ledge could be harder for shorter climbers; I used a pretty wide compression to get over. · Lead / Onsight. Seems like bolts are off and we went to intermediate anchors of the 5.7 next to it. ~10 bolts and I would guess longer than 75 feet listed. Moves above the anchors in the picture were the crux but overall not the craziest sandbag in the world. Probably fave 5.8 I’ve done. · Lead. Psa, watch your head when you pass the bush that’s halfway up the climb. Otherwise you might get a face-full of dried plant bits… · Lead / Redpoint. I think I've been on this route before. Pretty good route. · TR. Fell twice. Turns out climbing a 5.8 in sandals on a 90 degree day is not the move · Lead. quite a bit harder than the other 2 - very fun as well · Lead / Onsight. First onsight of the year! Fun and a little spooky. I have no shame in admitting that I grabbed the stump, it came in handy! All’s fair outdoors! · TR. Love it. Exposure, good views. Hard moves towards the end. Chimneys. Stemming! Project lead for someday… · Lead / Onsight. VERY fun, felt quite exposed for the last 3 moves but Kat was waiting at the top and encouraging me · TR. Stay to the right of the tree for an easy lead then lower on the left for a fun challenging toprope. · Lead / Onsight. Interesting and fun. Take stiff draw for a few reachy clips. · TR. TR, no falls. Fantastic climb. Good crimps on the face into a very steep section with jugs and jams. If I’m ever back I should lead this Probably got sunburned climbing this. Climbed with Azeem.

routes.route_description: Pitch 1- 5.8 follow bolts up past tree root then head right to anchor. Nice pitch on it own. chains at anchor.Pitch 2- 5.10b follow corners out left passing an anchor on right continue to top. superb pitch!!Rappel is 34 meters to tree root anchor!!
routes.route_location: Start on ledge at 2nd 4x. Follow bolts trending right.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: This route is fun! It didn't feel super clear from the ground if we were starting up the correct route but once we started up it felt a lot more clear. The second pitch felt sustained, long, and very enjoyable! Surprised more people aren't on these accessible sport moderates. Seems like there are a lot more routes/projects on the wall than what are on MP, would love to know more details! Nov 20, 2022
There is a midway anchor halfway through pitch two that you could use to beak this into three pitches if you don't bring enough draws with you. Jul 24, 2023

Lots of exposure climbing through the 2nd pitch made this a headier pitch for me than some of the higher graded routes at Field of Dreams. I believe it took about 16 draws to get from pitch 1 anchors to the top of pitch 2 (12 draws to the intermediate anchor and then another 4 or 5 to the top) Nov 20, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · 1 pitch. Follow. did p1, was a fun intro pitch for a warmup, route sees lots of traffic these days · Lead / Fell/Hung. P2 bailed on 3rd to last draw b/c didn’t find any handholds. Need to work on trusting small features & slabby friction. · Follow. Did 2nd pitch. Very cool and a little heady (even though I was on TR) · Lead / Fell/Hung. One take early, one whip later on layback/smear section. James lead P1. Heady. Didn’t encounter any hornets at p1 anchors. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Wasp nest right above the p1 anchor. Watch out! Bailed bc fuck that · Lead / Onsight. More draws for the second pitch than I thought. Turned it into 3 pitches · Lead / Fell/Hung. First pitch Kayla led, second pitch Jeannie led fell at last bolt due to flake breaking off. Leave draws in due to route taking such a big turn. Kayla fell on top and swung way left of route and way off route. Sketchy sketchy. First multi pitch tho! · Lead. Led first pitch-really fun! Hayden led 2nd. 2nd felt tough and reachy for short people · Lead / Onsight. Pulled a head sized block off the second pitch. Take care · Follow. Followed Ben, fell twice and used a hangar for a foot through the crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung at 4th or 5th bolt of the second pitch. First pitch was pretty easy maybe 5.7 or 5.8, just follow the bolts through the easiest terrain. · Lead / Fell/Hung. w/ Allison. Fun! She was scared and didn't want to second P2 which scared me and involved lots of shenanigans and a moment of weakness take halfway up P2. But really enjoyed, would climb again. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. First pitch. excellent view from the belay station of pitch 2 · Lead. Confusing route. 1st pitch wanders right, 8 bolts. 2nd pitch feels significantly harder than a 10b- moves back and forth. Didn’t realize that you passed a set of anchors so stopped at them. · Lead / Onsight. Led p1 clean follow p2 until hold broke right before anchors · Lead / Onsight. This route is fun! It didn't feel super clear from the ground if we were starting up the correct route but once we started up it felt a lot more clear. The second pitch felt sustained, long, and very enjoyable! Surprised more people aren't on these accessible sport moderates. Seems like there are a lot more routes/projects on the wall than what are on MP, would love to know more details! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Stopped at the anchor in the right a couple bolts below the top of the second pitch due to timing. Fun route, but the first pitch was a bit complicated to route find due to the cluster of bolting going on around that area (Multiple sets of anchors everywhere you look and different bolt lines basically on top of each other.) don't get drawn right until you reach the massive tree root, the line is basically straight up until that.

routes.route_description: Crux is at the perm-a-draw. This route also passes an anchor on your way to the top of "Finding your Roots". On a side note you can do the first pitch of "Summer Begins" and that will put you on a ledge above the cruxes of both "Finding your Roots" and "Toes". It is a great place.
routes.route_location: This is the same start as Finding your Roots but at first anchor go straight up.
routes.route_protection: Bolts 16

route_comments.comment_text: Both pitches can be top roped from the ground with an 80m rope if the belayer stands on their tiptoes Jul 15, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Last time I think I only did p1. Actually this time I think I only did p1. There’s an intermediate p1 anchor that I think I did last time. · 1 pitch. Follow. Only did first pitch. Felt like a 9 or light 10. · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Covered in spider webs. But awesome route, start is scary without pre clipping permadraw. Cool push move. Then lay back higher up

routes.route_description: Pitch one is 35 m, its anchor is in white rock. Just below the anchor you can go to the left or right. Just depends on whether you want to do a layback or face climb. This is a good pitch on its own 5.9.Pitch two is 30 m, the crux is at the perm-a-draw. (I had set the bolt too high.)
routes.route_location: This route starts at "Finding your Roots" but follows line of bolts to the right.
routes.route_protection: Bolts 16

route_comments.comment_text: Wonderful stemming and clean movements with some spooky holds promoting intimacy with the spiders. Trees above have dropped pine needles on every semi-flat portion so be prepared for some in your eyes. Jul 24, 2023
I would describe the start as "route starts on bolts 3m right of Finding your Roots." Don't be dumb like me and link both pitches, the P2 anchor is a pure hanging belay. Aug 2, 2023
Awesome route, many bolts! Grading feels more like 5.8 for the first pitch and 10a on the second on the index decimal system. Mar 18, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Only the 5.9 pitch since folks wanted to stay on the ground · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Just did first pitch, but super sick! Layback at top was scary to clip from, so grabbed the draws to clip both times. · Lead / Flash. Tough 5.9+ for the single pitch truly 16 bolts to anchors · TR. Would have been a crazy lead!!!! Fun lead though. Need 16 carabiners and 70 m rope · Lead / Onsight. Just the first pitch. Not sure if this is the route we climbed though. · Lead. Fun but still lots of loose rock. Went right on the split in the first- ended up on sketchy rock. Also went R on 2nd pitch- sketchy rock on both sides. Look for a high left crimp on the crux. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Lead first pitch, great upper section of stemming movement

routes.route_description: This route is on the topo map of field of dreams  that Marty Gunderson posted. We can assume they also set it. On the topo map it says it's a 5.8, but I would say more like a 5.6, especially compared to Big Scary Block and Stolen next door! Rating it the way I assume the setters rated it though!
routes.route_location: On the Main Ledge, in-between Big Scary Block and Summer Begins, it's easy to confuse for the start of Summer Begins. The anchors are indeed under some moss and you can see them from the ground.
routes.route_protection: Bolts and chains.

route_comments.comment_text: Agree that it doesn't feel like a 5.8, maybe 5.6+ or 5.7 (by Exit 38 comparison). The start and the final couple moves around the last bolt is where a shorty climber (like me) might take a second to calibrate but everything else is pretty straightforward. Mar 10, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. w/ Quena. Hardest moves are to the first bolt, and last bolt (before the chains). Bolts felt high for a 5’3” leader. Easier than Stolen (5.7), and much easier than Stumps Out.

routes.route_description: Pull hard on small holds
routes.route_location: This route starts at the top of Stolen or Stumps. It is the left bolt line.
routes.route_protection: 10 bolts and chains

route_comments.comment_text: Gorgeous climb which required biceps for the lower part, strong fingers for the upper part, and flexibility for the crux (at least for someone who is 5'3"). The start is made a bit spicier by needing to traverse over/under/through a bush. Did some cleaning on the way up as the lower holds were pretty dirty. Aug 28, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. 4 tries total. Fell twice at lower crux then Sage sent and left draws. Got on next go. 4th bolt crux right hand crimp, left foot high and rock over bump left hand onto arete jug. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux around 3 or 4th bolt pulling on crimp on right side of arete and then layback body right to get feet up. · Lead / Onsight. Really cool moves at the overhang, Feels super soft for Index 11a, but I also felt like my height and flexibility helped a lot with this one. The bush you have to climb through at the start was annoying · Lead / Onsight. Thought it felt soft for index 11a, but would be accurate other places. Very closely bolted, a bit dirty, and a bit of questionable rock, but pretty fun

area_description: Tall wall just right of the Wart. Forested at the base. The climbs here are steeper than those at the Beetle Bailey Slab.
area_getting_there: Can approach from the road, or from the LTW.

area_comments.comment_text: Not sure how long the fixed line running over walking legend has been there, but it might be time for it to go. i climbed all of walking legend last week and while at the top of pitch 2 i noticed a questionable spot in the rope, about 15 feet below the anchor. it was frayed pretty good and the spot felt kinda flat. im no expert but if someone with more knowledge than me wants to check it out... more Not sure how long the fixed line running over walking legend has been there, but it might be time for it to go. i climbed all of walking legend last week and while at the top of pitch 2 i noticed a questionable spot in the rope, about 15 feet below the anchor. it was frayed pretty good and the spot felt kinda flat. im no expert but if someone with more knowledge than me wants to check it out and maybe remove it, that would be cool. Jul 8, 2016
Don't touch my fixed line! Jul 26, 2016

Anyone check out Walking Back to Happiness?  It is a Gregs Child and Collum route.  Looked awesome years ago but a runout section below the crux got dirty and as a result the route was never done much.  Not sure if it had more than an ascent or two. Jun 15, 2020

routes.route_description: Follow the right-trending bolt line. Stay directly between the bolts for the most interesting climbing. Try to avoid getting sucked into the cave where it is wet and dirty. Shares an anchor with Huberts Revenge.
routes.route_location: Right of Huberts Revenge.
routes.route_protection: A few draws, and a small cam or two.

route_comments.comment_text: Worth doing if you are over there for Huberts Revenge. Sep 6, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Couldn't finish the trad 10a with weird crack. Lead this again to recover the gear. · Follow. Not as good as Huberts Revenge, although it climbed better than it looked. · TR. Fun but tough moves if staying under the bolts, would be several grades easier if in the chimney · Lead. I believe I did this route wrong it felt 5.9 but very fun · Lead / Redpoint. more like 10a, beware of ground fall potential at 2nd bolt. · Can be made into a 5.9+ by weaving up following the cracks. True grade is staying on the face

routes.route_fa: Dave Repnik, Darby Summers, Jesse Cirillo
routes.route_description: Begin in a left facing corner past 2 bolts. climb over blocky terrain to a left facing flaring corner with crack in the back. Climb up corner to alcove. Climb dihedral past 2 bolts by chimneying with foot on rail. pull onto ledge in a great position. 70 meter will get you down in 1 rap. 60 meter will require use of intermediate rap station.
routes.route_location: Right of the Wart. Right of Walking Back to Happiness.
routes.route_protection: Single rack with slings. doubles in .5"-.75"

route_comments.comment_text: This is a neat route which will be especially appreciated by those looking for less intimidating routes to lead at Index.  Probably a tad easier than Roger's Corner.  The dihedral at the top can be stemmed or climbed as a chimney--fun either way! Sep 3, 2013

I had the pleasure of climbing this not long after it was first put up.  Most of the climb is pretty casual with the crux near the end.  The last 20 feet is a really fun puzzle to solve.  It's a good line for the climber that's new to trad climbing. It's 5.9 climbing at the end. Sep 10, 2014
Fun climb. Climbing through the dihedral at the top is fantastic. Oct 22, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. Would climb again. Try leading next time. I think I may have climbed in the past, but not sure. · Lead / Onsight. First 5.8 trad climb, belayed ben up from above to check my placements · Lead. Bottom half is super chill. Upper section takes a little more commitment but is much easier dry! 5 bolts (one extended with double) and single rack to 2. Liked the black totem and 0.75 at the end! · Lead / Onsight. cleaned up nicely. the dihedral is fun and well protected. this thing eats ropes when you pull them. · Lead / Onsight. super fun, easy climbing. the chimney is a bit harder, but still not too hard and with good pro, it has bolts. I used a golden nut, a .4, a .75, a .5, and could've placed another .3 or .4 at the top of the chimney · Lead / Fell/Hung. One hang at 2nd corner where it got pretty wet. Awesome route! · Lead / Fell/Hung. thought i was gonna die. thought i was gonna quit climbing. but we’re here. · TR. Clean. Would be great option to lead as one of first Trad leads before season is out. · Lead / Flash. Haley and max lead. Very fun and some great movement. I used .3-1. Bring lots of alpine draws · Follow. Sam lead, varied climbing with blocks and dihedrals, mostly easier climbing, the dihedral at the end is sporty but the holds are all there · Lead / Onsight. Fun, extremely slimy before second set of bolts (May 22). Stiff for an 8 but stem stem stem and it goes. · Lead / Flash. with matthew an mike. lots of fun. take it slow and dont be afraid to throw a foot behind you at the crux · Lead. Dirty down low, but fun climb and spicy stem/chimney moves to finish it out! · TR. Tr was up so may as well, lucky it was cause it was seeping and slick at the top. Fun route · Lead / Onsight. Wet and covered in slime. Woulda been an awesome route otherwise. Stoked on the lead. · Lead. Wet cracks made the upper crux a little slippery, but definitely worth climbing again. Finish with a 0.75 then 2. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took coming to top of second dihedral. Fully stretched out and still had to swing · Lead / Onsight. Surprisingly fun! Last bolt flexed when pulled but can protect before and after! · Lead / Onsight. Max and Haley lead. Super fun and amazing views at the top! · Lead / Onsight. Single rapped off to bring G + Jordan up. Go outside first flake. Stem dihedral, don't go left. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at Chimney. Steady dripping waterfall led to the wall being algae filled, one take and I worked around lower chimney on face climb and stepped back in midway up. · TR. Wet up top- ended up using chimney technique but awkward to top out- PG finished. 0.4 for top. · Lead / Onsight. Easy at bottom but dirty...exciting and fun for the grade when exiting the chimney at top · Top roped this long, fun, straightforward route which gets progressively more difficult towards the top ending in a great stemming corner for the final moves to the anchors. Probably the most sustained route I've climbed to date. 3 bolts and a fat rap rin

routes.route_description: Climb the first 2/3 of Exponential Excavation and enter onto the obvious protruding prow to the right. Follow three bolts through some beta intensive climbing to a couple TCU placements and some easy moves to the finish. Symptom of the Universe.
routes.route_location: Shares start of Exponential Excavation. Breaks right 2/3 of the way up.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to .75 and some draws.

route_comments.comment_text: Very cool moves, very not 10+. The arete feels way more exposed than it is. A .5 works great after the bolts. If you plan to TR this you may want to block the finger crack with something (we used a small cam) as it eats ropes. Aug 6, 2023

routes.route_description: An exciting deviation from your typical slab line.  Look for the critical two finger pocket below the flake. Start 30 left of Exponential Excavation.
routes.route_location: Start 30 left of Exponential Excavation.
routes.route_protection: 7 Draws

route_comments.comment_text: Fun if somewhat contrived.  If you follow the natural line, you'll have to go a bit out of your way to clip the bolts.  Whatever, it's fun and safe climbing. Sep 12, 2017

I really liked this pitch, interesting movement. Pretty long runout to the 5th clip: placing the bolt on the slab to the right of the layback flake would've been safer, more direct and less contrived. Oct 21, 2018

Pawel, its been a few years since I bolted this section.  Please tap around up there (with a hammer) and see if your suggested bolt location is hollow.   There is a lot of hollow rock up there that looks solid. Oct 26, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Went well but I had to cheat the hard slab crux. Next time go right and press up, match the high crimp, pull up, and rest is ez. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bad beta exiting Crux to rail. Super reasonable 11a for index. · TR. Running out of juice for crux section, had to treat with hanging draw and stepping on the bolt to get over it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had a fall on the traverse trying to gaston on the left · Lead / Redpoint. Clipping beta for the 5th bolt (mid crux) made this possible: high opposing smearing feet and a low right crimpy sidepull allowed me to (barely) clip the draw and keep it moving. Happy to start breaking into 5.11 at this crag :) · Lead / Onsight. Can place a .2 or .3 in flake between the more spaced out bolt 5 to 6 · TR. Pretty sure I’ve climbed this before. Sustained slab and crimps. Would not lead. · TR. Fell at crux. Keep feet centered and match hands on middle crimp before bumping left foot to rail and left hand to pocket. So fun! Will be back. · Lead / Fell/Hung. After the third bolt step down and math rail, left foot out, then get the slot · Lead / Fell/Hung. Did first 4 bolts of this climb thinking it was the 5.8 next door…. So hard · TR. 90* out, overheating for top 1/3 of route. For crux, I think what worked best for me is climb up a bit higher on little crimps & smears, before traversing and throwing left hand to the crack. Haven’t found good clipping stance for the clip right before the flake (clip #6?) · TR. Middle section has a lot of tenuous holds that felt hard on my fingers, need to build up some strength so I’m not full crimping to pieces. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard figuring out the Gaston move and then struggle bus thru the upper crux. Didn’t quite pull the move. Wild, never climbed hard slab before and trusting the feet is hard.
