Wouldn’t want to fall on the layback flake cos it’s a bit runout to the next bolt · TR. Lead next time. Crux for me was transitioning from the good stance to the 'slot'. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Max lead this as first pitch of the 3 pitch climb. By accident. But he almost flashed it. Had one take on last 1/3 of the climb. Haley TRd. This climb shares the first two bolts with 3 pitch climb and then goes left. 5.9 route go right. · Lead / Fell/Hung. W/ Kyle. Not too much of a struggle need to go back for rp · Lead / Redpoint. fell a bunch trying to traverse left between bolt 3 & 4, first 11 outdoors · Lead / Fell/Hung. Go up on traverse (trust high foot). Hard sequence up to the large flake

routes.route_description: Marty Gunderson posted his hand written descriptions of the route Feb 25, 2024. This was soon after he took down the fixed ropes for the bolting effort.  He named the route for his grandson Patrick.Pitch 1: 5.7  -30m- gear to 1” with 5 bolts.Pitch 2: 5.9 -30m- gear to 2” with 8 bolts.Pitch 3: 5.10a -30m- 9 bolts can be easily linked with pitch 4Pitch 4: 5.10b -20m- 8 boltsPitch 5: 5.10+ -30m- gear to 2” with 3 bolts near the end.  The cracks will lead you up towards the bolts.  At the third bolt, and the trees, look hard to your right for the chains.  Committing slab step across to the chains.
routes.route_location: Right side of walking Legend Wall.  Walk to the right from walking legend itself 60-100ft and look for the cleaned route above a large stump.
routes.route_protection: First four pitches are mostly bolts with supplemental gear to 2”. Last pitch is mostly gear with 3 bolts to protect the crux. 9 bolts max.All belay stations are bolted with chains.

route_comments.comment_text: There appear to be two anchor options between pitch 3 and 4.  I’d recommend clipping the left if you are linking but the second may be a nicer spot if you want your belayer to watch you on the 4th pitch. Apr 23, 2024

Danielle and I climbed pitches 1-4.  If 5.10+ is intimidating or beyond your skill set, you can skip the last pitch and rap off after the first 4.  Pitches 3 and 4 are High Quality. HIGHLY recommended. Apr 25, 2024
Nice route! There is a lot of slabby and ledgy terrain that lends itself to loose dirt and rock coming off during rappels. avoid this route if someone is already on it. May 2, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · 4 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Climbed first 4 pitches with Brian. Linked P1 + P2 and P3 + P4. P1 + P2 = lots of rope drag, would not do again. P3 + P4 worked well. P5 starts of 100% trad with a slight lie-back crack up to ok undercling / sloper holds. Did not feel comfortable leading P5 so just rapped after p4. · Follow. Led 5.7, followed rest Slid at 10. a .10a felt harder than 10b Swing a little at.10+ Pulled myself quickdraws · Very fun, last pitch is mostly gear, could use doubles in some sizes. The rest is pretty soft touch for index. Rapped w/ 70, might be tight with a 60? · Lead / Onsight. W/Tia. First two pitches, didn’t have time for whole thing and it was a bit hot! · Lead / Onsight. Lead p2-4… fantastic climbing, really fun mixed feel—bolts where necessary, gear pretty obvious. Only need a single rack. “Alpine” feel for sure given recently established. Do it!! · Lead / Onsight. Led everything. Will Julia and Nicole. A bit heads up on P2 and 5 but a very fun route. · Lead / Onsight. I led pitches 1, 3, and 5 while Ethan led 2 and 4 · 3 pitches. Lead / Onsight. I lead P1 and P3, Matt lead P2 and we were pretty done after just having finished walking legend so we rapped after P3. Per Matt it gets substantially harder and less fun P4-P5 · 3 pitches. Lead. Went up three pitches. Lead on the second. Followed on one and three. Didn’t feel like finishing the route today after doing walking legend too. Found a crow-bar sticking into the pine needles above the 2nd pitch anchor. Couldn’t tell if it was intentionally left there, or lawn darted from up higher, so I brought it down to the ground rather than risk it falling once the rains start. I assume it’s Marty’s. Hope he isn’t missing it being up higher. Left it leaning on a log down on the ground. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Only pitch 1. A fun move getting to bolt 3. Pro is weak bw bolt 3 and 4 - assess your holds · 1 pitch. Lead / Flash. Only Pitch 1. Crux after 2nd bolt. Go right to get to third bolt. · Lead / Onsight. Went well. Followed on pitch one and two since they were easier then led the final three. Pitch two to four seemed reasonably easy for the grade but the 5th pitch made up for it by being a quite stiff 10 compared to others on the lump, better beta may improve that.

routes.route_description: A fun juggy route that climbs unique holds up a steep face. Knobs, crystal pockets, sloper rails, heel hooks and a memorable slab make this a fun climb. Hail Sabbath.
routes.route_location: 20 feet left of finger my slot. It starts in a corner at the base of a low angle ramp.
routes.route_protection: 15 bolts, chain anchor. 70 meter rope is recommended, but you could likely swing into the anchors for Walking Legend or left to higher ground if you have a 60.

route_comments.comment_text: Even with the easy middle section, this route was super fun. Definitely has movement in it that will keep me coming back like cunning stunt. Apr 11, 2016
TRd this yesterday.  Super fun, has some really incredible movement. The lower slab is weird, just get past it and get to the fun stuff. Jun 10, 2016
Great Route! challenging slab move on the lower half, then interesting moves through the full top half of the climb. The middle bit is a good rest to get ready for that top half! May 10, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ooooph 80 degree weather may not have been the right choice, the slab crux felt impossible. The rest of the club was super fun, challenged my bravery a bit at the upper crux, but the falls are safe and it’s generously bolted, I just need to be braver. Fell a lot. Will come back and do better · TR. Feels more than 1 grade harder than the 11a next door. Did not figure out the mossy crux. Really fun short person beta at top and in mid · Follow. Couldn't figure out the slab traverse crux - took ramp to the left. Was able to do the rest no hangs. Still some spinning hangers. · TR. Didn't get lower crux... or just before the chains. Was super fun though! w/ Dale and Mike · Lead / Fell/Hung. 4th bolt was hard. Clumsily skated my way through it and had fun on the rest. felt hard, but I suck at slab. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bailed near top in the dark. Covered in lichen. Spinning hanger midway. · Lead / Fell/Hung. The feet at the lower crux were not possible with loose finales and socks but besides that I didn’t fall. Pretty dirty climbing too · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard… eventually made it through 4th/5th bolt crux but stumped at the top. Blew the toe in my shoe on it :( · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very tricky slab crux at the bottom. Need to go back to try to figure it out. The rest of the climbing is stellar. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very slabby and reachy. Slab moves after bolt 4 were too tricky for me and very difficult movement on the upper slab. Much more difficult than most 11s I’ve climbed · Lead / Fell/Hung. awesome. route and some really unique movement. would be a hard onsight i think · TR. Move left at end of lower slab so thin, pulled on draw. Upper section also SO THIN and only feet tiny crystals & knobs in places. Dirty, blew mantle/heel hook 3 times, gardened, then got it as toe hook. Razor sharp pockets good but ouch. Not jugs, slopers · Lead / Fell/Hung. No idea how to traverse left at 4th bolt. Pull on draw. On upper part, go on toes and pull up on ramp on left. On the crystal hole bolt, go left. Work up tenuous ramp.After last bolt, get foot up and use 3 intermediate R hands, L hand in fingernail crack · TR. Still couldn't do lower slab crux on TR, got upper wall OK. Great upper part! 11+ slab down low? · Lead / Fell/Hung. Could not get past lower slab crux (4th bolt?); pumped out on upper wall, Dean finished · Lead / Fell/Hung. WOW so good! That low crux is super low percentage for me · TR. Didn’t make it to the top. Struggle fest on 2nd rail- need to step in

routes.route_description: Follow the 3 bolts to the right trending crack. Follow the crack with good footholds to the chains on top.
routes.route_location: Right of Exponential Excavation.
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts.Small cams and a #3 Camalot.

route_comments.comment_text: Fun, some loose stuff near where the crack starts. Nov 17, 2013
It passed the 6' prybar test. Also why we added the bolt left of the crack. Jan 24, 2014

Why doesn't this keep going forever!  Fun route real "sporty"  gear was a little tough to figure out.  It looked like a hand crack from the ground but i was sure wrong, Gear beta spoiler:  there is a nice spot for a red c3 or a .3, then i deep pocket that fits a bomber .75 then above where you think a 2 should go but its way to flaring a 3 is great.  other gear could probably fit as well, but... more Why doesn't this keep going forever!  Fun route real "sporty"  gear was a little tough to figure out.  It looked like a hand crack from the ground but i was sure wrong, Gear beta spoiler:  there is a nice spot for a red c3 or a .3, then i deep pocket that fits a bomber .75 then above where you think a 2 should go but its way to flaring a 3 is great.  other gear could probably fit as well, but when i do it again i'm just taking those 3 pieces lol.  (after you pull the lip its like 3rd class) Jun 27, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. I'm new to Index and can understand why people call it 5.9. Very fun. · Lead / Onsight. First trad 10, although the hardest part imo was the first bolt · TR. Tried and fell a couple times at the start. Lowered and redid it. Got up to the right trending flaring crack but fell/took a couple times. Super greasy. Still super fun! · Follow. First use of trad gear. Used 4 cams, could have just used 2

routes.route_description: This is a fun and short gear route on a wall populated with sport climbs. The climbing is straight-forward on jugs with a couple of exciting runouts.
routes.route_location: Start in the  middle of the cave feature, on the tip of a little boulder. Do a bouldery sequence and trend right to an indentation in the rock, heading straight up from there to the chains, which it shares with Drunken Saharenity and Hubert's Revenge.
routes.route_protection: Not yet clear, but scope out the route beforehand and see comments below.

route_comments.comment_text: Sounds intriguing and fun. But I'm wondering if you could double-check or clarify two things: 1) The location and direction. This is given as being the furthest right of all the routes on the wall. Yet it 'trends right' and nevertheless reaches the same anchor as routes to its left? If instead it is the routes to the left that need more description (e.g., "traverse 50' right at... more Sounds intriguing and fun. But I'm wondering if you could double-check or clarify two things: 1) The location and direction. This is given as being the furthest right of all the routes on the wall. Yet it 'trends right' and nevertheless reaches the same anchor as routes to its left? If instead it is the routes to the left that need more description (e.g., "traverse 50' right at the top"), let me know and I'll fix them. 2) Protection. Can you add some suggestions? Nov 1, 2016

Hubert's Revenge and Drunken Sarahenity both trend right. Long for Rand does as well, but not as much and indeed finishes at the same anchor. As for the gear, fingers to a .5 camalot I think. Nov 1, 2016
Thanks Stamati- Nov 2, 2016

routes.route_description: Named after a local legend that against all odds is still on the sunny side of the grass. This is an AWESOME sport climb that follows a left leaning fault system all the way up the wall with killer views and great exposure.-Pitch 1 5.8+ (65) Shares the same first bolt as Finger My Slot as it traverses right to the sloping ledge. From the slopey ledge head straight up to the anchors.-Pitch 2 5.10 (60) Starts with a technical sequence before transitioning to juggey fun.-Pitch 3 5.10 (115) This is the pitch that just keeps on giving.  (Missing hanger on bolt at crux was replaced on 7/26/21).
routes.route_location: 30ft left of Exponential Excavation
routes.route_protection: 12 draws

route_comments.comment_text: Great route with sustained climbing on mostly bomber rock. Second and Third pitch are steep and varied with excellent climbing. Unfortunately a hold blew on me just below the 10th(?) bolt sending me for a pretty good whipper and I busted my ankle. That section was already thin and is now even thinner. The hold was an obvious right hand side pull next to the small tree near the top. The grade... more Great route with sustained climbing on mostly bomber rock. Second and Third pitch are steep and varied with excellent climbing. Unfortunately a hold blew on me just below the 10th(?) bolt sending me for a pretty good whipper and I busted my ankle. That section was already thin and is now even thinner. The hold was an obvious right hand side pull next to the small tree near the top. The grade probably remains intact though. Nice route. Recommended. Oct 22, 2015
Dang, sorry to hear about the ankle Casey. If another person were to blow off in the same spot, would the same fate await? Or can one place more gear? Oct 22, 2015

Jon, I think it was just circumstance that I was injured. I was pulling the last hard move before clipping the 10th bolt (if my memory serves me correctly) when a key hold blew. I think that normally a fall from that point would be clean, but because it was a hold blowing I was spun sideways in the air before hitting the wall 25+ feet below. I'm pretty sure the climbing just below this point... more Jon, I think it was just circumstance that I was injured. I was pulling the last hard move before clipping the 10th bolt (if my memory serves me correctly) when a key hold blew. I think that normally a fall from that point would be clean, but because it was a hold blowing I was spun sideways in the air before hitting the wall 25+ feet below. I'm pretty sure the climbing just below this point is fairly easy so there is a longer space between these bolts then most bolts on the route.Perhaps 15 feet or so. Once you pass the easier climbing you have to pull one more tough move before clipping the bolt. A fall from here while clean, will probably send someone for quite a ride. As I learned the hard way. There's nowhere to put natural protection in at that point. I'm not sure if this changes the grade of the climb or not, as I was simply climbing the most obvious line and the funnest looking move. Although I am fairly certain that this section is probably more difficult now. Either that or there's a nice incut now. The place where the hold came off is visible in the photo taken from the top of the 3rd pitch. Climbers right of the bush. Probably wouldn't hurt for someone to head up and assess the pitch at some point. I'd be happy to do it but unfortunately I'm going to be outta commission for quite a while now. Anyway, it's a great route and could use (and deserves) more traffic. Oct 23, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Sent p1 clean, be cautious of low ledge. Took on p2, ended up going low/left then up at low crux. Rap w 80m gets you from 2nd anchors to dirt · 2 pitches. Follow. Pitch 1 - 10b, Pitch 2 - 10c /+ Single rap down from end of P2 w/ 80m rope Transverse above first bolt is the crux · Follow. 1- fix and follow, fun 2- fix and follow, had rope fall on me while trying to reach left hand over during ledge… could not put glasses back on and unwrap rope from around me without letting go:( 3- tr belay from above, all good holds felt about 4-6in too far, intermediates felt not so good with no chalk, the end slab was spooky- even on tr. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lead p1 followed adarsh p2/3, fell once on p2 barndooring after the dyno to the jug off the pocket and once on p3 at the undercling near the top · 2 pitches. Follow. RGC Followed Claire up it with Mike and Nick S. Bailed off 3rd pitch. · Lead. On sighted p1 and p2 whipped like 20 ft on p3. RGC lead · Lead / Redpoint. 1st pitch only. Really ought to project the rest of this route. · 1 pitch. TR. Footholds in the traverse are good but sparse, so make some room for left foot when landing right foot, otherwise be comfortable with foot crossing. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lead rope solo, linked all three with an 80m which was something. On the p3 crux I greased off due to extra mega pump and with how ever many bajjiollion meters of rope under me I under getting a really soft like 30 foot whipper. Stellar climb, good movement essentially the entire way up. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Zach leads p1. I lead p2 clean and confident. I lead p3 but grabbed 2nd to last beaner, was not vibing as it got dark mid way through. · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. P1 clean. Will had a bit of a fall and I recovered the gear · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Lead p1 in the dark (11pm), felt good. Shea leads p2 and I TR. Weirdly less confident on the tr... · Lead / Onsight. Heck. Yeah. Did it with Nathan Johnson. Led all 3 pitches clean · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on P3? follow just moving fast and sloppy but fun! No lead falls leading P2, Matt leading 1 and 3. Great rock, bolting, jugs, and position. Not a sandbag at all solid pump. · Lead / Redpoint. Team send? Sean lead P1 and most of p3, I led p2 and top half of p3. Last two bolts through the flakes were sopping wet. · Lead / Onsight. Extremely wet up top. Had to figure out how to navigate through · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bailed on the 2nd pitch after bolt 4 because didn’t want to commit to the move. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tough! Used a #2 on P2 and a #1 on P3 this time. Linked P1-2 with one hang on P2 on the #2 cam. Was exhausted from prev climbs and hung and pulled on a number of bolts on P3, it’s a bit awkward climbing with bolts that are a little out of line. · 2 pitches. Follow. Tough follow, first multi-pitch, stopped due to rope length (had 60m, need 70m). Took a long time to get up as I was panicking at several points due to exposure. · Follow. Led p1, followed David up p2 and p3. The 10s we're not bad except that my fingers were shredded from earlier and my pinky broke up in blood part way thru. Plus I only remembered to bring my skwamas today so feet were hurting pretty bad. Overall feeling like a whiner · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. stick clipped first bolt; other draws prehung. take after first bolt to reposition right foot to accommodate a match. · Lead / Redpoint. Finally got back on this. There were a couple wet spots, but not where it mattered. Used #1 on the 2nd pitch, and a .3 and .2 on the third pitch. Super classic! · Lead / Fell/Hung. started just after sunset. amazing climb, heady in the dark. easily 10c. P1 8+, P2 10a/b, P3 10c BETA/ SPOILER P2 Crux is figuring out how to get away from the belay. lots of features out right, but the way to go is laybacking the farthest left crimps · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. fun romp, didnt love where the first bolt was. lots of pistol squatting. · Lead. Led the second pitch. Felt more solid on the third this time. Pulled on only one QuickDraw. · Lead / Fell/Hung. First climb on WL. Led pitch one and three. Followed on pitch 2. Pulled on a few draws on the third pitch to clip. Will need to climb it cleaner next time. Placed a single .2 cam but wished I didn’t bring any trad gear at all. This climb is well protected enough with just sport draws. You don’t even need to extend any with alpine draws. It’s tempting to link pitches one and two next time (don’t lower that way) Seemed notably easier than “Argentinosaurus” and slightly easier than “Billy’s corner” or “Sensation Station”. Harder or at least more sustained than “Tiny Dancer” or “Flying Salamanders Full”. 70 meter rope needed for the third pitch rappel. · Lead / Flash. pitch 3 outstanding, so much variety. 2 raps with a 70 barely makes it. took .4-.75 but didn't place · Lead / Onsight. Did it in one epic pitch! 80m rope and I think 25 draws. extended everything on p1 and a few bolts on p2. no rope drag, but that much rope is quite heavy towards the top! · Lead / Onsight. On sited all of it except on fall at the final crux of the third pitch. Amazing climb. · Follow. P1 and P2 complete, started P3 and slipped, rope stretched from Joey belaying and hit my ankle on the fall on the only major ledge at the start of P3, unfortunate. Sick route, awesome · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. with Jay. hung at pitch 2 crux. rapped from 2nd pitch since dog appeared missing · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once on the third pitch second bolt crux but I missed the easier beta out left. Great, fun climb. With Tyler S. and Bret. · Lead / Onsight. Designed by the gods, every hold right where you want it. So good. Lead p2, follow p1 & p3 · Lead / Onsight. Led p1 and followed clean on p2, p3 Thanks Karl for the rope gun · Lead. Top roped finger my slot and the last pitch and lead the second without falling. My second multipitch. With Reese and Thomas · Lead / Fell/Hung. lead p1, followed p2, lead half of p3 but couldn't finish. Harold finished and I followed to the top. hot, 85 degrees · 1 pitch. Just did the first pitch, super fun, want to come back and do the whole thing · Lead / Redpoint. Lead P1, first slab lead in a while, had to gather some courage. follow p2 & p3 clean. a few good totems minimize runouts, single rack black-orange party of 3, lowered both from top to ground with an 80 then 2 raps myself

area_description: A rocky knoll at the base of the Lower Lump. 100' high, 40' from the tracks.
area_getting_there: Park and approach as per the Lower Lump.

area_comments.comment_text: The anchors at the top of Smiley Kylee are two large metolius hangers that could use quick links/chains for rappelling  These anchors are the only way to rap down the east side as far as I can tell. Jun 18, 2018

I'm not the biggest fan of those Metolius rap hangers, still a pretty sharp bend on ropes. As of May 2021 there are new chains farther climber's right for topping out Mean Mug/Banana hammock that you can rap to the ground with a 70. There is also an intermediate anchor with cordalette slung around a block with a quicklink or on the ledge just above the wide crack or chimney starts which... more I'm not the biggest fan of those Metolius rap hangers, still a pretty sharp bend on ropes. As of May 2021 there are new chains farther climber's right for topping out Mean Mug/Banana hammock that you can rap to the ground with a 70. There is also an intermediate anchor with cordalette slung around a block with a quicklink or on the ledge just above the wide crack or chimney starts which you can use if you only have a 60 and do 2 raps from the top. Or just walk around the back down to Beetle Bailey. Aug 8, 2021

The intermediate tat anchor has been replaced with fresh ring bolts for those needing to rappel with a 60m. You can find these on top of the large broken blocks on Bannana Hammock. I will note that the tat which had served as the mid anchor was almost completely severed from the sharp edges of the blocks. Slightly terrifying to think what could have happened there. Aug 1, 2022

routes.route_description: Banana Hammock starts at the bottom of a wide, rightward-trending crack. After the crack, the route joins Mean Mug, which ascends the face using a series of blocks and slabs. A single bolt protects the upper slab.
routes.route_location: Between Mean Mug and Smiley Kylee.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack to 3", 4-5" cams optional. A 70 m rope for top rope. A single 60 m rappel will reach ground from Smiley Kylee, but be careful because it is close.

route_comments.comment_text: Between Smiley Kylee and Mean Mug is a short curving crack that can be a variation start to Mean Mug. Aug 18, 2015
Climbed Banana to start, but on the ledge it seemed to make more sense to me to continue up Mean Mug instead of Smiley Kylee. A fun combo. Apr 4, 2016
Climbing this into Mean Mug is great fun May 7, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. TR once and had to lead it to get my rope. It was chill to lead. · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. For RGC, I led Nick S, mike and Claire. · TR. TR bottom half, offwidth is still scary! Top was the same as mean mug. · TR. Joe Lead it. I climbed the crack so differently than him… I pressed my back on left side. And did a lot more lay back moves cause the feet on right side was slippery. · TR. I moved anchor from Smiley Kylee to Banana Hammock while cleaning. Was lowered from top of Smiley to ledge at end of Banana. Set up anchor, PA in, went off belay and then pulled rope from Smiley and tossed ends to ground from Banana anchor. · Lead / Redpoint. I did it cleanly! Didn't do any hand stacks this time. Just better footwork and mostly hand jams. · TR. Mock lead this bb. First fist jams ever let’s gooo. They felt way better than the hand jams so I have work to do. · Lead / Flash. First 5.9 on gear (felt a lil soft though)!! Super fun climbing from bottom to top. W/ Sandro on belay! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Still not great at crack, and the offwidth section shut me down several times, even on the pink. Can imagine placing gear in that. Top is super fun with some nice almost vertical face climbing on great crimp-jugs. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard! Thank goodness Luis left some gear up for us to clip into. Crack is off width and moves are pumpy in lower portion of climb. Top portion was airy and flowy. I got in my head about placing tiny gear under flakes. · Lead / Redpoint. Led this route with a 3.5, 4, 1, and 3. 3.5 worked great down low A 5 might be ideal for the lower wide part vs a 4 A 2 might be better than a 1. Wasn’t super happy about the 1 placement. Or a .4 in the finger slot. 3 is best if set deep in the left crack. Extended all pieces Nothing walked on the lower off. · TR. TR’s cleanly. There’s actually great hand-jams most of the way!! No off-width technique required! Just some big throws to reach the next jam sometimes. I could probably lead this… with a few takes, I imagine. · TR. Fun crack with solid jams. Observed a flaring nature to some of the larger cracks above. Some small pro opportunities. · Follow. Follow Deanna. Dry, but dirty. #4-6 all useful, 6 best in top half of ow. Full no hands rest right knee jam. · Lead / Redpoint. Ow gear 3 2 4 5 6 but could skip the 5 and just do 4 & 6 or 5 &6. Mid tat rap anchor gone, now 2 bolts w rings on face to the left (not clipable) so threaded a pinch w double sling. 0.2 & 0.1/0.2 Offset above ledge then yel alien & 0.3. Higher up lots of horizontals 0.4-1, used red tricam. After bolt 0.2-0.3 and purp offset nut before runout. · TR. Mock lead in the pouring rain, took several rests but got through the crux · Lead. Woot!! Took two BD 5s and used both of them (didn't use a #4)!!! · Lead / Onsight. Didnt know crux was low. I scared myself but, it was a fun onsite tho and just beautiful route. go past the first set of anchors for fun adventure, use anchor right of the tree at the top · Lead / Onsight. Exposed after the ledge and a bit scary. First crack was pretty simple and well protected · TR. Mock lead. Lots of small cams on second half. Used z4s in horizontal and shallow cracks up top so save them. Used .1 and .2 cams as well. · Lead / Onsight. fun and varied. diagonal crack was good and top slabby section was airy and delicate but easy · Lead / Fell/Hung. first offwidth. did some fancy stacks and stemming and fell off a couple times getting into the wide bit · TR. Hard start, need to foot jam and hand jam at the top of the crack · TR. clean. Nice climb with varieties. OW section can hand jam. Overhang left nice jug. Rest easy and fun! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Maybe just me but the crack was amazing! kicked my ass but so fun. First climb where I hung on gear... · Follow. Shoved my body in the crack and learned to be calm on slab · Super fun 1st pitch. Did second pitch but it was dirty with sketchy gear on ez climbing · Lead. Felt pretty cruiser! Doubles to 0.5 and singles above to 4. Nice to have a double runner to extend at the intermediate rap rings. · Lead / Flash. Fun trad lead! Good jams for first half and good slab mini jugs up top · Lead / Onsight. Haley and max lead. Heather and Jeremiah trd. Crux towards the top 1/3 of R angled crack. Upper section, straight forward slab. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fun route that has a little bit of everything! Offwidth, fist and hand jams, finger jams, and slab. Really fun climb; definitely used my C3s · Lead / Fell/Hung. Burly crack start. Do it better without shoulder injury. Top takes 0.1 to protect the crux above the bolt. Bring a ton of draws. · Lead / Onsight. didn't go all the way to the anchor, used rap rings above the crux · TR. took a bunch on the first half. learning crack. hard but fun. need to get better and try again · Lead / Fell/Hung. First trad whip (finally)! Great gear through crux, but moves felt a bit insecure even on TR · Lead / Flash. think carefully about extending pieces, it's easy to get tons of rope drag. don't need a #4/5 but having one or the other could be nice

routes.route_description: An awesome left facing corner with great laybacking and jamming.
routes.route_location: SW corner of the Wart.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 3".

route_comments.comment_text: Fun climb, good combo of laybacking/jamming for the first half, then some interesting moves on the top half. Jul 1, 2015

Fun laybacks off the deck (more sustained than Toxic Shock), then interesting sequence above to reach chains. Cleaned of (most) blackberries, moss, and mud on 7/2/16. Deserves more traffic than it sees. Jul 3, 2016

First half is challenging but clean and well protected.  2nd half is dirty and hard to protect.  Where good protection ends, there is a rap anchor left of the route, which  I should have used.  My attempt to continue (right) resulted in an injury ledge fall.  It's my fault - I knew my placement protecting the move off the ledge was crap.  Moss/dirt may have been a factor - it's possible there... more First half is challenging but clean and well protected.  2nd half is dirty and hard to protect.  Where good protection ends, there is a rap anchor left of the route, which  I should have used.  My attempt to continue (right) resulted in an injury ledge fall.  It's my fault - I knew my placement protecting the move off the ledge was crap.  Moss/dirt may have been a factor - it's possible there is good protection buried somewhere.  Ballnutz might have helped. Update (2017): the 1/4-inch crack in the dihedral going right (below a bolt) has been excavated, revealing good purple BD nut placements (e.g. imgur.com/a/9NnyF ). Nov 8, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Didn't finish. Dirty top couldn't place gear needed a smaller cam. Finished on TR · TR. Hard as shit. Commit to the layback and go for the good right hand thumb down jam to rest. But quite mossy and dirty after the crack to the anchors except where there are a key foot or handhold. · Lead. Climbed with Kat - I struggled getting out of the crack. This one felt harder than 10a to me but there could have been an easier beta I missed · dirty top if you go right - best to go left after the bolt. strenuous layack · Lead / Redpoint. 2x0.4 cams, then 1, then 3 then 4 at the top. · Lead / Onsight. Didn't make it look good, but sent. Don't fuck with nuts in the corner. When laybacking in a a corner just plug a cam and move. (takeaway) · TR. Climbed it much better than last time! (Ditched the stem) Can see a lead in my future. · TR. Already tired, this was so hard! Did I forget how to crack climb? · Lead / Fell/Hung. Gotta layback the whole thing and make sure not to put #2 where you want good foot jam- clip the bolt after topping out and go straight up to closest bolts on the left. I tried going right and it’s tricky at the top and bailed · Lead / Flash. Strenuous lead. Gear felt good but also saw Brayden go first so there’s that. Sort of tricky moves above the layback section gave me pause. Equalized nuts for the first time lol · Lead / Onsight. Was my second ever Trad route and if kicked my butt. I had never really practiced that style that was needed for this climb but had a blast and I think next time I’ll shoot right up. The crux at the top is really fun!

routes.route_description: Thin crack climbing bypasses the hand crack of Compound W. Follow the upper section of Compound W to the anchor.
routes.route_location: 5 feet right of the regular start of Compound W.
routes.route_protection: thin gear

route_comments.comment_text: Cleaned of (most) blackberries, mud, and moss. Deserves more traffic. Jul 2, 2016

This is a fun little route and I agree that it deserves more traffic.  The work put in to keep it clean is appreciated.  It does seem to collect debris pretty quickly.   As of 8/6/16, it is still in good shape. I take a single rack to #2 plus a few nuts for this one.  You can easily get away with leaving the #2 behind, but there are two nice placements for it if you have it with you. Aug 6, 2016

FA by Uros Lukic There is some confusion here between Compound W and the Compound W Variation. The "Variation" is actually a completely separate climb. The original Compound W climbed to a tree anchor that was above the leftward anchor. The anchor on the left is where the good climbing ends and is the closest to the original line. The Variation was led from the ground up from below the... more FA by Uros Lukic There is some confusion here between Compound W and the Compound W Variation. The "Variation" is actually a completely separate climb. The original Compound W climbed to a tree anchor that was above the leftward anchor. The anchor on the left is where the good climbing ends and is the closest to the original line. The Variation was led from the ground up from below the rightward small roof section and the anchor placed decades after the original Compound W was established. Essentially, they are 2 distinct climbs. If you have fun combining them, awesome, but one would be safer climbing them as 2 separate lines. Aug 7, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Super fun warm up. Stout for the grade. Used the anchors out left. Single rack 0.4-4. 1 Alpine. 60m rope. Bolted anchor, chains/quicklink

routes.route_description: Lovely arete climbing on flawless stone. A technical crux down low leads to a fun sporty finish. Hard for the grade.Discovered and worked on over a decade ago by the indefatigable Doug Taylor and the esteemed Gabe Shank, who were and who remain... flat earthers.
routes.route_location: First route you'll see as you approach the Lump.
routes.route_protection: 5 draws

route_comments.comment_text: Come On Stiggles!  If it was 5.11b, it would have been done over a decade ago.  Add at least 3 letter grades so Shank and I can keep some level of dignity. May 29, 2020
Your wish is my command. Feel free to adjust grades in direct relationship to heat and in inverse relationship to skin :) May 29, 2020
What I would like to know is how it compares, difficulty wise, to "I can see your house from here". May 29, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Very cool. Like the engineer but harder. Will come back with stiffer shoes and cooler temps ….. · TR. Second to third bolt is the Crux for me. Unknown how to proceed. after that traverse · TR. With heavy TR assistance, managed to do all the moves. Top is contrived (at least if tall) because I can reach the good crimp and top out from the ledge out left, but sticking to the face is quite fun and not too hard. Bring wire brush next time to scrub the moss and slime. Easy to pull through on bolts I think, and Compound W seemed slimy and not worth climbing · TR. Just after the FA. Did all the moves except the crux cross. Definitely coming back for this one!

routes.route_description: Freight Night starts on Mean Mug (or Banana Hammock for full value) and cuts right where you can traverse on a slabby ramp. Follow the ramp using a broken crack system up to a small roof (crux) and continue up easier terrain to a bolted anchor. You can easily reach the top of the Wart from here.A direct start up the arete has been done on TR. Pretty fun.
routes.route_location: Starts as for Mean Mug (large chimney at the base of the gulley) or as for Banana Hammock for full value. See picture.
routes.route_protection: SR from small nuts to .75". If you're pushing yourself at the grade, a good selection of small nuts / cams will sew it up. Bring bigger stuff if starting on Banana Hammock.

route_comments.comment_text: Not sustained, but keeps you on your toes.  Most of the route is probably 5.7ish slab but the crux [with beta ;)] is roughly 5.9.  Keep your eyes peeled because there are plenty of easily overlooked placements.  Summiting the Wart from the anchor is easy but I would remain tied in/on belay to do so.  Hip/tree/further anchor belay your partner up after.  Fun route; atypical of other ~5.9 climbs... more Not sustained, but keeps you on your toes.  Most of the route is probably 5.7ish slab but the crux [with beta ;)] is roughly 5.9.  Keep your eyes peeled because there are plenty of easily overlooked placements.  Summiting the Wart from the anchor is easy but I would remain tied in/on belay to do so.  Hip/tree/further anchor belay your partner up after.  Fun route; atypical of other ~5.9 climbs at Index that I've done (more face-climbing focused). Sep 24, 2016
Pushing 10a (height-depdendent) at the crux (near the end).  Protection there (nuts / small cams) is probably ok, but one would fall some distance. Nov 9, 2016

Thanks for the input Serge, I graded it based on other routes in the area but maybe I underestimated the crux. In the interest of not sandbagging anyone (BETA ALERT) the crux will definitely feel hard if you don't find a certain hold way out right. Nov 14, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell several times at the crux on small nuts, definitely harder than 5.9 · Lead / Flash. Keep your eyes peeled for placements, there are a lot of solid spots that are easily overlooked.

routes.route_fa: Dawn and Jesse Cirillo. Initial development by Dave Repnik.
routes.route_description: This unassuming route contains fun climbing for the grade. Start up a right facing chimney and continue up and left onto some large square blocks. Once standing on top of the blocks continue up a series of small cracks. A bolt protects the crux of the route on the upper slab.The top anchor is two bolts, just below the tree.
routes.route_location: To the right of Smiley Kylee.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 1".

route_comments.comment_text: Bit of a mental crux a the beginning of the thin crack section, stepping out over the chimney you just climbed up with some very small pro. Might be the physical crux too in my opinion, the face climbing above the bolt was fun but easy with all the mini jugs. The lower section might also be a little height dependent, I know I had a much easier time of it than my partner because I could reach... more Bit of a mental crux a the beginning of the thin crack section, stepping out over the chimney you just climbed up with some very small pro. Might be the physical crux too in my opinion, the face climbing above the bolt was fun but easy with all the mini jugs. The lower section might also be a little height dependent, I know I had a much easier time of it than my partner because I could reach the finger crack better than she could. All in all a surprisingly good route. Jul 26, 2015
I'd recommend approaching via Banana Hammock for some extra fun, great route. May 7, 2016
As of May 2019, the Tat anchor on the tree has been replaced with ASCA SS bolts at the base of the tree. I also agree with Nate about the Banana Hammock as a great alternative start. May 1, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Led banana hammock into it, with Mike, Claire, and Nick S. · Lead. First 5.8 trad lead!!! I def could have onsighted it but TRing it once helped me dial the gear and foot placements in and it felt super secure the entire lead. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Messed up with rope drag so had to lower to remove some pieces · TR. The start is hard for short people. Had to beach whale onto the boulder in the crack with one arm, no feet · Lead / Onsight. Really sick route. No finger crack tech needed. Pretty well protected · Lead / Onsight. Marcos. Ran out of gear I wanted at the top and took a long time to work that out. Blueberry bush was nice · Lead / Onsight. Cool route!! And I’d say a true 5.8! Led with singles #3 to Z4 Zero. The micro cams were very handy, I was glad to have them. · Lead / Onsight. Easy chimney that’s not protectable, top half is slabby. Anchors sitting way back on a ledge so more of a good TR site for a long static rope anchor · Lead / Onsight. Via banana hammock. Struggled a bit with good protection up high on the face · TR. 2 laps. hard to pull rope up. it gets stuck in the chimney. · TR. TRed bottom chimney after leading Banana Hammock. Banana Hammock is the better start. · Lead / Onsight. .1 to .5, double .3, small nuts. Scary slab but just go. Ditto for finger crack above chimney. All easier than it seems. Dirty · TR. Chimney was kind of fun. Middle of route was super chill. Slab at end was pretty straightforward. Lots of dirty holds. · Lead. Nice 5.8 with chimney start! Then small placements, kinda scary stepping off block to small crack. Easy finish, sandy and loose up top.

routes.route_description: Start on the left facing ramp. Climb the right facing corner to the roof. traverse right out the roof to the incredible hand crack with an airy finish to the anchor.
routes.route_location: Right of Compound W. Look for the clean corner and roof.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 3" with micro cams.Bolted anchor at the top.

route_comments.comment_text: Exciting finish out the right side of the roof. 3 stars for 2nd half of the climb. There is one bolt on the route. As of 4/2/16 only one of the bolts at the anchor has a hanger. Apr 3, 2016

The protection prior to the bolt is small and questionable given the rock quality, after the bolt its a pretty sweet well protected climb with an exciting traverse. FYI be very careful getting up the ramp to the start of the climb I pulled off a handhold doing a 4th class move and nearly took a very nasty fall. Jun 3, 2019

With permission from the FA, an additional bolt has been added to the climb next to the "Less Than Ideal" pro.  The potential PG-13 section can now be safely led.  In fact the entire climb can be led safely.  So why aren't you climbing it now? Aug 17, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. Had a great start through the tough moves around the bolts, then got shut down at the “hand crack” which is actually offwidth, slightly bulgy, and leans left · Lead / Onsight. super cool movement on the upper section. upper hand crack was a little wider than I expected! · Lead / Onsight. Really fun adventure route! Single rack 0.3-3, doubles 0.75, nuts! 6 Alpines, 2 sport draws, 60m · Lead / Redpoint. I can’t believe I lead this five years ago! I thought it was hard and scary now haha · Lead / Fell/Hung. bailed halfway up the ramp— one of the rocks feels loose and i cant tell how to avoid it · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. trying to project, got the bottom half but the crack hates me · Follow. With Hank. Fell a couple times. Had to skip the move coming out of the roof/over the buldge.

routes.route_description: Follows the prominent crack system on the east face of the Wart. climb from the ground up to the large ledge and follow the crack with great feet to the top. Look for Metolious Enviro rap hangers at the top. The top of the Wart is a fantastic hangout.
routes.route_location: East face of the Wart. Can walk down the west gulley or rappel the route.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack to 3" include additional small cams and nuts.

route_comments.comment_text: Seeing the orientation, it looks like it would be good for a morning climb in the cooler months and good as an evening climb in the summer. It's hard to beat the easy access. Jan 31, 2014
its pretty fun for the first part, you can belay from the top also Feb 10, 2015

This route is strikes me as a good one for a new leader. It's a jug haul that can be easily protected the entire way by the crack. Very little jamming is required. It also felt significantly easier than any other 5.8 I've climbed at Index. Apr 11, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Had to down climb. And left one section a bit over exposed. · Lead / Flash. Lots of value out of this 5.7 line: crack, edge, balance, overhang jug, rope drag, rope stuck on ledge when pulling it etc. · Lead / Onsight. Fun! Bulge scared me for a hot sec. Placed protection to the bulge then ran it out from there. · TR. Climbed twice. Once on top rope to clean (and move anchor to Banana Hammock) after Jin led. Second time followed Jin and both rapped on 70m rope. · Lead / Onsight. Fun! Used all my pieces bigger than .5, try to use small gear early on · Lead / Onsight. Sarah belay. Pulled the #2 after getting on that first ledge to use higher up. · Lead / Pinkpoint. Luis put up some of the gear. So, a mixed red / pink point. Great views up top! · Lead / Redpoint. Overcammed one cam and had a nut fall out because I didn’t extend it enough · Follow. Felt harder than last year. Jin led. I followed and then we both rapped on 70m rope. · Lead / Onsight. Good warm up/early season. Had to clean the cracks a bit. · Lead / Onsight. Acclimating to Index and Granite. Fun route, kinda damp but good especially for the grade. · Lead / Flash. Doubles of #0.3 to #3. Happy to see someone added quicklinks and steel rap rings to the bolts at the top to facilitate lower-offs; I remember a few years ago the hangers were naked. · Lead. Not much jamming, placements a little odd, placed 5? .3x2; .4; 1; 2 ? · Lead / Onsight. Steep but safe. Pretty fun and varied. Lots of face climbing and jams · Lead / Redpoint. w Isahia and Demarcco. isahia led afterwards for his hardest trad climb to date

area_description: The area includes the slabbier region left of the Wart to the steeper area right behind the wart. Many of the routes are on the Beetle Bailey Slab, but some extend higher up, past the steeper overlap that bounds the slab.Fun area to hang out in, particularly on hotter days as the base is shaded by large maples.
area_getting_there: For the shortest approach, park at turnout past LTW parking lot. Cross the tracks, then follow trail down and left to the wall. The Wart is an obvious big blob of rock on the right.You can also park at the LTW lot or closer to town.

area_comments.comment_text: Checked this place out yesterday, good work with the cleaning Adam! Nice fun little sport crag, and all the first pitches stay shaded all day. Jun 3, 2019
This crag is incredible now, and a great place to hang out. May 30, 2020

This may be the new Lower Town Wall for beginners after the next 5 routes are opened.  Where else can you get 5.6 Trad, 5.7 bolted, and 10a/b multi pitch routes all within 50 feet of each other.  Then work your way into a few hard 5.10 single pitch routes a few feet down further.  June 2020 will be an awesome month to visit the area thanks to the Cleaning Crew AC,DT, and Friends. May 30, 2020

routes.route_fa: p1 A.Wood, G. Shank, D.Taylor p2-3, A. Wood, D. Taylor, M. Rynkiewicz, G. Webster
routes.route_description: Obvious line of bolts and small gear following ramps and ledges through a diagonal crack. If linking p1 and p2 skip hanging Mussy anchor and continue following bolts up a shallow dihedral. P3 ascends a roof system following bolts. A single 0.75 is needed.—((*LINK*  p1 and p2 for a nice 70m TR))— :)
routes.route_location: Just behind the large tree right of Flying Salamander and the Tombstone. Two bolts leading up fun slabbish or juggish climbing depending on the path chosen.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 0.75 mostly bolts.p1 and p2 are best led as one 34 meter pitch. (Makes for a classic Index TR) ....Recommended...P1 can be top roped from obvious mussy hooks with no traverse at only 10cEverything Hertz is a fine alternative starting pitch and is easily linked into p2

route_comments.comment_text: p1 is a thoroughly enjoyable line with an engaging, physical crux.  The bolts are right where you want them for the business up high, though you may opt to stick clip the second bolt if this grade is at your limit.  You can also place a green alien in the diagonal rail ( between bolts 4 and 5, if I remember correctly.)and a .5 or .75 at the exit of the triangular roof feature. Jul 25, 2020
I found a spot for a small yellow Metolius up top on the ramp leading to the right anchors.  The route is a blast.  So many different styles of climbing on it. Jul 25, 2020
"Harder yet easier" is the best description of Index climbing I've ever heard. Jul 27, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Grabbed 2nd to last draw on 2nd pitch with linking p1 and 2. Too much drag! Extend better · Lead / Fell/Hung. Three bolts before the anchor are the trickiest. The traverse left was technical crux, physical crux was the diagonal ramp after it · 1 pitch. Lead. No stick clip - grabbed second draw. Otherwise sent everything above bolt 2. Very difficult. Put in some pieces in diagonal rail, which I found as a crux for me as I was on it with my hands. Viper stood up on the rail - there were great knob crimps for this had I looked around. Thought for sure I was going to whip at the top but somehow pulled through it. Intense. · 1 pitch. Led the first pitch 10c cleanly. Had tried this by accident at one point several years ago · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. With woody he hung the draws Sunny and dry and cool Amazing conditions I wish index was always like this · TR. crux sequence: left hand pinch, right crimp, long reach to left crimp. right foot smear; left foot back step. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Pretty sweet climb, goes right of the amazing looking dihedral, the top of the climb was the most fun part. · 1 pitch. TR. Pitch 1 is a lot of fun. I'm sure the rest is really good too. I'll have to come back to climb the rest of the route. · 1 pitch. Went to second anchor. Fell 3 times. Need slings. TR. long TR. 10c crux is interesting and mantle was pretty easy for me but top crux is weird and really abrasive · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. lead to p2 linked fell at crux of p2. need 16 qd s including anchor. placed .5 at p1 and then .75 on p2 · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Could not get past crux of P1 Brad got a little further then took a big fall Vadim completed · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Tricky traverse crux. Second crux is stepping out of the crack to finish the climb. · Lead. Did P1-3 with an 80. Be careful of drag. 8 bolts on P1 · Lead / Flash. Did first pitch only. Fantastic climb! With rich and Carson and Travis · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lead P1, hung once at last bolt before rail traverse cuz I wussed out. Also started the bottom up ramp to left instead of scary arete. Felt great, nailed the undercling traverse. Tots blk to red -purp + 0.3&0.4 z4, brought 0.2 and 2x0.5 too! Follow robby p2&3 clean! Traverse to RTL P4 start from top, kind of a lower out... not horribly sketch. · Lead / Onsight. use long woody for roof, then .75 in crack on left. Awesome line! · Lead. Just the first pitch, really fun but forgot the cams so scary runout to the mussys · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. very cool movement on p2. well-protected...bolts are right where you want them. I used both of my stiff draws to clip from good stances. · Lead / Onsight. Led the first pitch without gear. Huge scary run out to mussys. Would be really fun with gear for top · Lead / Fell/Hung. Jai led P1, 0.2-0.75 cams for traverse, sketch run out slab fall potential, 1 fall me. skip mussies and go to anchors up and right. I led p2 awesome mantles & heel hooks, 1 fall at crux. p3 clean green & black tot, Rad position but still pretty dirty! · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. lead pitches one, fall at crux, went from last bolt to anchors on the right with no pro bring a .4 and 1 next time · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. First pitch only. Didn't know there weren't bolts at top so had to clip into bolt on other route · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got p1/p2 clean, fell once on p3 trying to be cute in the corner. Pull hard! p1 is amazing! · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. So good! Green alien, blue and yellow metolius, .5 and .75 cam as supplemental pro.

route_comments.comment_text: Deez route descriptions just getting better and better. Aug 31, 2021

I think I top roped this line just for fun before it’s recent scrub and bolting. The new bolts put a bit of a squeeze on Smilodon near the top, but still fun. If you climb true to the bolt line, then it’s 5.10-, if you go way left then it’s probably easier. Sep 3, 2021

The Anthropocene and Smilodon finish at the same anchor but follow separate bolt lines that are several feet apart.  After pulling over the little rooflet in the middle of the route, stay left and your next bolt will appear after the dark, left-facing flake.  From here, stay left for your next bolt (the bolt you see to your right is on Smilodon) and a few more fun moves that will take you to... more The Anthropocene and Smilodon finish at the same anchor but follow separate bolt lines that are several feet apart.  After pulling over the little rooflet in the middle of the route, stay left and your next bolt will appear after the dark, left-facing flake.  From here, stay left for your next bolt (the bolt you see to your right is on Smilodon) and a few more fun moves that will take you to the Smilodon anchor without clipping any of that routes bolts. Since these two routes share a 3-bolt anchor, please be mindful of how you arrange your anchor so as to leave space for climbers to lead or TR both lines simultaneously.  If people are finding this shared station to be a hazard or a hassle,  we may revisit the anchor bolt arrangement in the future.  Establishing an independent anchor on the left for Anthropocene could put the rappel line in the territory of the massive detached flakes, which is why it is where it is now. Also, a quick note regarding the grade: depending on how short or tall you are and whether you stay to the right or left the bolt line at the cruxes,  the route can feel anywhere from 5.8+ to .10a.  Choose your own adventure.  The bolts are placed with the intent to make this an interesting and safe climb (ie-- to avoid ledge falls and discourage folks from using the mossy, semi-detached blocks on the left), so feel free to try hard if this grade range is at your limit or enjoy it as warm-up approach pitch of Argentinosaurus. Sep 3, 2021

route_comments.comment_text: The climb “Congolindination” has a somewhat weird history.  Although it was listed in the early Clint Cummins guide, it was labeled as the wrong climb.  The later Cramer guide showed the correct, but otherwise forgotten line.  The most recent Kalman/VanBiene guide appropriately ignored the line.  As of 2019, there was a scary anchor and plenty of tat to mark the path of terror one would follow... more The climb “Congolindination” has a somewhat weird history.  Although it was listed in the early Clint Cummins guide, it was labeled as the wrong climb.  The later Cramer guide showed the correct, but otherwise forgotten line.  The most recent Kalman/VanBiene guide appropriately ignored the line.  As of 2019, there was a scary anchor and plenty of tat to mark the path of terror one would follow to complete the line. During the winter of 2019, Gabe Webster and I tried to resurrect the line “Congolindination”.  In the process of removing loose rock, we pretty much removed most of the first half of the climb.  We abandoned the efforts for a few months.  We later determined that “Smilodon fatalis” was a worthwhile climb that actually traversed into the base of the meat of “Congolindination”.  Unfortunately, the upper section of Congo’ moved back into loose and scary rock.  After some deliberation, it was determined that if the route merged with Racer X near the top of both routes, the best climbing from the original route could be had, while giving modern climbers the best possible finish. Cheers to Dave Anderson and Bruce Carson for their vision of the original route and Cheers to the modern climbers who get to enjoy what is offered today. Aug 24, 2020
Definitely a worthwhile route to do after you nail Racer X.  The crux is a crazy lieback on slab.  Loads of fun. Bring your 80m rope for a single pitch climb! Aug 25, 2020
youtube.com/watch?v=rgHY4qj… Video of Sherri on Argentinosaurus Aug 25, 2020

Stoked to find a stellar 5.10 index pitch I’d never heard of. · Lead / Fell/Hung. tricky Crux, once you get it it goes just fine. fun ass full strength 10c rope stretcher · Lead / Fell/Hung. Soo close, lots of falls and swearing. Colder temps and send this damn thing · Lead / Onsight. 80m rope gets you to the ground and sets up a rad top-rope. · Lead / Fell/Hung. (Pun yet true) incredible stone, incredible climb, will out live us all · 2 pitches. TR. Crux LFC overlap feels impossible to get into; crank into then big reach to knob out right. TR 2x

routes.route_fa: FA: Bruce Garrett, Don Heller  FFA: D. Cramer, B. Scott
routes.route_description: As several routes go up to the same anchor above this pitch, it is often done as a one-pitch climb, whether just TRed or to set up a TR. Hence, I separated it from its original 3-pitch listing.Face climb up to a ledge, about 15-feet up, clip a bolt, and start laybacking the offset edge (a mini arete), smearing with the feet (crux). Then relatively easy face climbing to the anchor.
routes.route_location: It starts lower-down and left of the obvious right-facing groove-ramp (first pitch of Racer X). Look for the layback offset-edge. Start directly below.
routes.route_protection: Three bolts for the hard climbing. You might be able to place small pieces below the first bolt and after the third.

route_comments.comment_text: YES!  Too many first pitches at Index get missed because the multi-pitch version is too intimidating. There are several ways to get above this line to TR it and dial in your skills to lead it.  Racer X (P1), Index Archaeology, and Smilodon fatalis can all directly go to the anchor.  Behind the Tombstone can be used if you don't mind a little easy/safe traversing to get to the anchor. ... more YES!  Too many first pitches at Index get missed because the multi-pitch version is too intimidating. There are several ways to get above this line to TR it and dial in your skills to lead it.  Racer X (P1), Index Archaeology, and Smilodon fatalis can all directly go to the anchor.  Behind the Tombstone can be used if you don't mind a little easy/safe traversing to get to the anchor. If this pitch is near your limit, use the easy climbs to get the anchor, practice, and lead it.  Once your skills are up, take on the rest of Beetle Bailey. Jun 26, 2020

Just to add a little beta.  If you stay to the far left you can avoid the upper crux making it a 10b.  It does put you at more risk of a swing if you fall.  But it’s an alternate way to climb the route. Jun 27, 2020
Nice to know, Gabe. Does this way involve moving left just after you have done the mantle and stood up? Jun 27, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. Couldn’t really do the laybacking move. Traversing to the left afterwards was also hard. · TR. Got all of the moves with a fall in the middle, the crux is tough but doable · TR. Fell/hung around the third bolt (but on TR cause it was pretty damp out and scary) This climb will haunt me for as long as the giant bruise now forming on my leg from where I slipped and hit the bolt takes to heal. But actually pretty cool climb and would definitely do another lap then go for the lead. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couldn’t get the third clip. Had a stick clip handed to me. 10 or so attempts to get it. · Lead / Onsight. I placed 1 .4 cam after the third bolt but it didn't feel necessary · 2nd go. First go had a couple foot slips at 3rd bolt...blaming the heat. Sent after w some sloppy climbing. Fun tricky slab moves on a sweet feature! Like dancing! · TR. Kai led it, hanging several times trying to figure out the moves. I was able to top rope it hanging a couple times before I fully committed to the slabby lie back on the off set feature on the right. Felt like it was the hardest .10d I’ve been on. Audrey managed to pull her way up; she hung a lot before figuring out how to move up through the crux. Kai TR’d it without falling to clean it. Clean and hard moves through the three bolts. · TR. Fall at top of hard section (right) - two attempts. Got high on right arete/rail and then dyno to left hand crimp. Should look for different beta. · Lead / Redpoint. Get feet as high as possible. LH to crimp, adjust feet (left on small hold), RH good edge, LH finger jam. · Lead. One fall in crux because no friction (hot and muggy). Immediately got back on and finished it · Lead / Fell/Hung. Clean to the second half of the layback. Then I couldn’t make the layback go at all. I couldn’t get my feet to stick. · TR. Wow super committing smear to bolt 3. Took me a few attempts to dial in. Had to find left foot on small nub to desperately move over to presumed clipping position. · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Claire, figured out the method for the crux; feet right of the arete · TR. work up arete with wide pinches (using small features for thumbs). press hard with both feet on face. keep feet high. key is getting good pinches. step left AFTER getting left hand on one of the crimps (can go for either the small, lower crimp or the bigger edge). decent finger jam to clip off of. · TR. Lots of falls on the damp rock. Coming back to it! Needs to be dry to get the feet high lol · TR. Next time, go left after first left foot at upper crux. And use shoes with more grippy rubber, not resoled TC pros · Lead / Fell/Hung. No trad. Almost got it first try and then took awhile · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once in crux unfortunately, but linked into pitch two for an awesome 40 m pitch · Lead / Fell/Hung. Greased off the thin layback just before the jug. Lay it back to the top then go left to the good hold. .75 · TR. took once at upper crux. Lower crux, stand on the triangle. Face right arete foot hold. Squeeze. Slab. Crux 2: right hand jug, up two steps. Then right hand sidepull, foot close to body. Good hand on the left. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 fall, 1 take — same place. Thought I was gonna get it first go! Really cool tricky feet, laybacking on smears is a wild time. Went dynamic at the crux, but worked it on TR on the way down and it goes way easier just trusting feet. Oh yeah, .5 and .4 for the top. Probably could just do one or the other. · TR. Hard one!! Zack was giving some beta as I tried the smear move. Semi figured it out but it was definitely anti style! · TR. Tough crux sections. Fell 2-3 times at the second one but got it. Tough. · Follow. Omfg the feet were so mossy for such an insecure and powerful lie back. Classic index right here. · Lead / Onsight. I never did the left “v4”, instead of following chalk I climbed on some nubs left then a pretty big runout to chains. · TR. Stay a little left on the first bolt, second to third bolt…don’t know yet. · TR. Tricky and still need to put it together. Beta for lower layback. Right shoulder in left hand on side crimp, left foot on smear on arete, right hand on arete, right foot on small foothold in corner. Smear and lift up on left foot and get the rail. Second layback is powerful but out you get jug on left it’s cruiser. Question is how to get there. · Lead / Fell/Hung. beta: use left pinch and black crystal to stand to L crimp · TR. Move feet to face once layback changes angle. Left foot to chip, reach left to crimp. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell a bunch of times, good thing this route is so well protected! The lower section is tough, but if you get the sequence right (left crimp/ right crimp to right side pull to left crimp to ledge mantle) it’s short. The upper sequence is much harder — right juggy side pull with feet on the right, move feet to the left just after the bend, keep pulling with tiny foot progression until you can grab the left jug. Fell A LOT of times to figure this out. Bring some hand sizes for the final section. · Follow. took a few falls on crux. hard lie back. #3 placement up top

routes.route_fa: Bruce Garrett, Don Heller.  FFA p2 Terry Lien,Darryl Cramer,Brian Scott. FA var. p2 Byan Burdo
routes.route_description: Start by following right facing flakes (5.9), using one small cam then four bolts, and trending rightward to the finger crack. The crux is either the thin finger crack or the face climbing just afterwards (11a).If you cut right 15 feet from the belay you'll be climbing Larry’s Gaily Colored Lycra (10c). If you started too far left off the P1 anchor you are climbing Metal.The route also had an aid pitch over the roof, at the very top of the slab (see Clint's topo). Now one can instead follow P3 of Ride the Lightning.Rap the route doing two raps with 60. A 70 doesn't quite reach the bottom.
routes.route_location: P2 goes straight up from the anchor on P1.
routes.route_protection: Four bolts and a blue tcu will get your into the finger crack, no more pitons or brass nuts.  p2 A single rack to 2 is sufficient with doubles of 0 and 00 master cams to sew it up.

route_comments.comment_text: It can also be aided in winter. Nov 16, 2012

Pitch 1 requires a lot of try hard with your right bicep and smearing of your feet. I placed a #3 between the 3rd bolt and the anchors. Another climber used a "finger sized" cam in the same area. Burly and enjoyable. Aug 18, 2019

Regarding the 2nd pitch; all three pitons were pulled today with permission. Three 1/2 inch ASCA bolts now make for very safe climbing off the pedestal belay. I also pulled and replaced the two bolts on the 11a variation. I suggest parties top rope from this variation or use directionals as the line wanders right. Aug 19, 2019

routes.route_description: Exciting moves off the deck with thin feet. A big reach to a pocket jug then follow bolts with a variety of options on moderate enjoyable terrain. High stepping, balance moves and bolts where you need them make this climb a kind index moderate.
routes.route_location: Walk to the beetle bailey slab. This route is the line of bolts right of the first pitch of racer X (5.7 ramp) which can often be dirty.  Look for the "Tomb-Stone" a 4ft tall shield of granite driven into the ground by the force of gravity. The start hides behind the tombstone.
routes.route_protection: Just a bunch of Quick Draws.

route_comments.comment_text: If you dont have gear, the runout between bolt two and three is easy. If you can pull the move off the ground you'll be fine. Jun 3, 2019

Fun route.  I thought it was 5.9 or so but then I was probably doing the bit between the 1st and 2nd bolt wrong. Sep 4, 2019

routes.route_description: Climb the left facing corner to the belay below the roof 5.10c. Pitch 2 Climbs to the right and through the roof using the thin crack below the tree.
routes.route_location: When following the path to the top of the wart. This route is about halfway up the path. Look for the left facing corner leading to a roof. The first set of anchors is below the roof.
routes.route_protection: The usual suspects

route_comments.comment_text: At the moment this sweet looking route needs a good scrubbing and anchor replacement. I would not get on this route until it receives a good dose of community service. Aug 23, 2015

routes.route_description: Ascend a short slab, left of Michal’s 5.5. Follow bolts up a steeper granite face with crimps and a some high footy / hand matchy / battery draining moves. Nothing terrible, but don’t stop too long to think. Aim for an improbable looking blocked roof with a bolt.Yes… your going to climb that lip and it goes!!! Edge and smear fighting gravity into a welcomed rest below the roof. Take some time to recharge and reach up above the lip. Holds will welcome your strain, as you launch out and up to an anchor above.Brilliant, and easier to imagine, if well hydrated. A few of the sequences can be cryptic but the bolting is very generous.If this were at world wall it would see daily ascents.
routes.route_location: Start as for Michals 5.5 then follow bolts left through an obvious overhung block with a bolt. Bolts all trend left at the start above a series of stacked mossy blocks.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Crux sequences are steep on big moves/high feet.  Great rests in between.  Very comfortable bolting.  Pulling the roof at the top is awesome. Jul 1, 2021
Great route! You can also traverse right into full Tommy Dutra to add value / avoid the 5.8 start. May 12, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Some of the beta felt very tricky, but had a blast figuring it out. Redpoint feels within reach · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd go. Pretty dirty and sandbagged but grades aside, awesome route! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Cool route . . . upper roof is exciting yet falls are not really that long with last bolt just below lip. 1st crux felt the hardest. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Made it about 3 bolts up before the falls and hangs began. Too tough for me

routes.route_fa: P1: Jeff Kljaich, Doug Taylor, Adam Wood, Gabe Shank P2: Michal Rynkiewicz, Jeff Kljaich, Adam Wood
routes.route_description: P1 5.10: Start as for 36 Volts.  At the second bolt cut right trending up a rampy slab of increasing difficulty.  Follow the bolts into a mantle sequence on a pedestal.  Enter a crux below a small roof with a hand jam on the right and stemming all around.  Once you have established yourself above the roof head left and do fun laybacking up the feature.  Can either finish at the mussy hooks or finish on the right trending crack for the real deal and finish on a belay ledge.P2 5.9+: Make some slab moves straight up from the belay on the ledge and make fun moves through another roof.  Trend up and right and just follow the bolt line!
routes.route_location: Shares first two bolts with 36 Volts to Anywhere.
routes.route_protection: 12-14 draws (some extendable to reduce rope drag) and a finger sized piece for the crack finish.

route_comments.comment_text: Unlocking the roof sequence is key! Jul 29, 2020
Very cool moves over the roof. Link this with 36v pitch 2 for full value. I think I used a .5. Jul 29, 2020
Great climb. Mostly 10- climbing until the roof, then a powerful move to a jug continues with sustained pulling over the roof. The following layback moves are more heady than hard. Jul 30, 2020
