routes.route_description: Continue past the first anchor on Flying Salamanders heading up a beautiful bolt protected slab. The first couple bolts lead off the ramp ledge and into a rock scar with a couple powerful crimps. (crux) 5.9/10a followed by a series of subtle weathered dishes and knobs.After the second bolt a variation extends right up a ramp to a perma-draw anchor. This is an access for two yet to be published lines.
routes.route_location: Find Flying Salamanders and go to the top (15 bolts) This is an excellent top rope 70 METER REQUIRED. Another bolted climb follows the ramp heading right to a set of permanent draws. This is a different pitch.
routes.route_protection: 15 bolts. 70 meter rope!

route_comments.comment_text: This route delivers when it comes to fun moves on quality rock --  a great addition to the growing selection of new moderate sport routes at Index.   It is well protected, though short-folk might want to take along a stiff draw for one or two of the clips.  Thanks to the developers for the vision and hard work you put into the Lower Lump to bring this gem to life. Jul 27, 2020

Really really good, don’t pass this one up if you’re in the area! Couple crux sections, some delicate edges and good crimps, but also some amazing rests where ya need em! I found one of the clips to be a little strenuous but overall generously and safely bolted. Anyone know which route goes off to the right up the ramp from the first set of anchors instead of straight up for this climb? Jun 23, 2021
Harry it’s an unnamed 5.7 bolted ramp.  You can lead climb it to a sport anchor and toprop the 2 routes below it. Jun 23, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Nice and long, couple tricky moves in the second pitch but really good crimps and friction. With Lukas and Ally · Lead / Fell/Hung. Didn't make it past second bolt. Went right and lowered off adjacent anchor. · Lead / Onsight. Climbing with Ashley, Kai and Sophie following on TR. Upper crux section felt like a stiff 5.10. Well protected steep slab pulling over a small bulge, decent hand holds with mainly friction smears for feet. Another micro crux just below the anchor moving left into a sloping crack. Very fun line! · Lead / Onsight. Did hedge trimmer and linked it to the second half of flying salamander. · Lead / Onsight. Super fun route with an intriguing finish! Would def return for another lap · Lead / Fell/Hung. I continued the lead from the ground. Indeed 15 draws. Crux at the 3rd bolt above the midway anchor, I had to pull on the draw a lot to get through. Also hard between the last bolt & anchor, I went far left off-route to get a crack with good finger-locks to finish those last few feet. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Nearly a (slow) “flash” but I couldn’t figure out the top on the first try. Beta: LH sidepull on nub, throw for RH jam, feet on small obvious ledge and muscle up to pull jugs · TR. Top rope 1st try w rappel 70m rope - sick route and first 10a at index · Lead / Onsight. Really fun!! Did this one third of the day, loooved the slab up top · Lead. Went up the right variation that wasn’t the official route. Felt like there were a couple 5.9 slab moves. · Lead / Onsight. Led the first part then went off-route to the right on the variation for top rope on the 5.10a piece, felt more like a 5.9 · 2 pitches. follow until the first anchor and lead until the top. Climbing buddy: Cody · Lead / Onsight. good balance practice but not really good friction practice... big holds most places. Good flow. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the last bolt. Gotta redo this one was really fun! · Lead / Flash. really fun, technically did a pink point but it was first try · Lead / Fell/Hung. Did two laps, hung on the first lap. On the second lap I fell on the last sequence of moves above the final draw due to a foot slip. · Lead / Redpoint. Super stoked to get on this and send it clean again. Such a fun little slabby techy route! · Lead / Onsight. Easy first half. Much trickier second half. Two cruxes that require some thought and searching for hands/feet. Sidepulls before the anchors were slimy… · TR. Fun but once you suss it out it’s good. The smear on third bolt of upper section is the tricky bit · TR. Follow Mantas. Fell once one a lower move but ended up doing all the moves including the final move-a double side pull into a high foot on a flake. Proud of that one.

routes.route_description: This route was developed for my 9 year old son to be able to begin leading at Index.  It is well protected and will most likely become popular for entry level climbers at Index.The route is about 15 feet to the right of Behind the Tombstone.  It is a right facing corner, with a bulge at the top.  Climb up and over a detached flake at the base of the route.  Step over and onto the wall.  Make several face moves until you clip the first of 8 bolts.  Go back and forth between using face moves and the right facing corner.  If the move seems hard, look around you might be missing a hidden hold (most are on the left side).  Climb up a slab section and move left over onto the bulge.  This is an exposed move, but exciting face climbing with 2 bolts to protect the last moves.
routes.route_location: The route is left of the Wart and 15 feet to the right of Behind the Tombstone.
routes.route_protection: 8 quick draws and 2 slings for anchor.  There is a chain anchor at top.

route_comments.comment_text: Very fun pitch. The last bulge moves are definitely harder for the person under 5'3" or so. Also, it looks like an easier trad line was largely cleaned out just five feet or so to the right (at the start). It might be nice to post this one here too. Great work cleaning up the area, thanks. Jun 26, 2020
This route has an exciting 10a extension off the first anchor. Please don’t miss out on a full 35 meter moderate top rope. Jul 18, 2020
DT and GW removed the block today.  Nothing left to worry about other than getting on the face to finish the route.  Have fun. Jul 21, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. 2x. Second time, no take moving over the bulge! Remember to go high before transitioning onto the face. · TR. 2x. Want to try to climb it without taking next time. Cleaned it! Mussey hooks at the top · TR. Tried to lead. Had to bail. Don’t get lured into the crack. This is a sport climb · TR. Attempted lead got scared bolt 3-4. Top roped the face. Could have lead and gone right on arete · Lead / Flash. Fun lead went right at 6-7 bolt but next time go left and climb face to last bolt. Doable to anchor on face · Lead / Onsight. Felt sketchy but was definitely further on the face than I needed to be. · Lead / Onsight. Fun & easy! Actually 5.7, as opposed to the typical Index sandbag. · TR. Easy top rope with some fun moves. Also did a mock lead of the trad crack to the right of the sport route. · Lead / Flash. nice easy warm up climb. small roof problem at the top can be a little scary but the holds are great. · TR. Got psyched out trying to do the 5.10a section above it and ended up leaving a screw locking carabiner on the bolt above the 5.7 anchor ): · Lead / Onsight. Ben sent it on TR, Matt made it to the crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. hate it when you know what the move is and you just can’t make yourself do it (high foot step up to the last bolt) · Lead / Onsight. Also lead the slab up to the right. Was kinda spicy · Lead. Was climbing this on the way to salamanders full when I found a large loose flake/block. Removed it to save a belayer in the future. I had to pull up my rope and send my belayer back behind a tree to do it safely. This is too much of a starter climb to have such a big block coming down by surprise. It was right where you would pull to grab the anchor hooks. Route seems clean now. No change to grade and the anchor ledge has more room now. The rock clipped the top bolt before the anchors and bent the hanger a bit but the bolt still seems solid and functional. https://youtube.com/shorts/vH-4SkUuYMo · Lead / Onsight. Stayed a bit right of bolt line where the chalk was, very mellow lead on that side. · TR. Top rope after leading and setting up, stayed direct on the bolt line and it was more fun and a little stiffer. Great climb either way. Super well bolted · TR set by Sarah, fun send. Light crux was top 2 bolts to anchor, good ledges.

routes.route_description: Crack climb just right of Flying Salamanders.  Start in a broken rock section,  climb through small hands to finger crack, then up and over the bulging rock. Very easily protected with gear.  1 bolt at bottom of broken rock to protect climber and belayer.  3 distinct crack sections that suck up gear.  Shares anchors with Flying Salamanders short pitch.  This climb can get dirty after rainfall.  Bring a small brush.
routes.route_location: This route is Right of Flying Salamanders and left of Dougs 36 Volts to Anywhere.
routes.route_protection: 1 set of cams from .2 to 2. Slings are useful and there is a medium nut placement 1/3 up.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Followed to check Ari's TR trad placements. Then after she lead her first trad climb!! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Sarah belay. Did the 5.7 start on the left flake. Took once on a questionable #0.5 placement, didn’t fully weight it. · Lead / Onsight. This thing is so much fun. The moves go great. For newer trad leaders who are strong climbers this thing is a blast and a huge confidence boost for learning/dialing gear placement. Type 1 fun to the max. · Lead / Onsight. So fun and got to do a big beached whale at the top · TR. With TR by Victoria, from Salamander. Smaller gear after a lower bolt. Short climb. · Lead / Onsight. Quick after work romp on this climb, careful of some of the loose rock at the beginning at the first bolt. crack to the Anchors had some good placements. wish it was a little longer for a good index Warmup · Lead. lead after owen top roped first awesome blue pocket placement felt very calm compared to hag crack · Lead / Onsight. Nice handjam, can get away with face climbing. Super short, pretty easy. All jugs. Only small gear · Lead. First Index lead!! It was a perfect one for my first lead at Index:) · Lead / Redpoint. Despite recent dry spell and good sun exp., several spots are likely perpetually wet and dirty this time of year from water dripping/seeping down from the top of this cliff. · TR. Practicing placing gear before the lead. Decent nut placement after some gardening w/ nut tool. · Lead / Flash. Nice easy gear placement practice route. TR can get stuck in crack just climbers right of anchor

routes.route_description: Climb rampy jugs with big feet up the middle of a triangular face. Moving right clip a bolt and place a finger size cam in a horizontal cracked feature. Break soft left on face moves past two bolts to a pedestal belay for Racer-X/Metal/Beetle Bailey.Use the 3-bolt anchor at the top of Beetle Bailey p1 after some easy scrambling from the top of the pillar.SHORT CLIMBER NOTICE:  Several shorter climbers have stated that this line has reaches that make for a potential ledge fall in the bottom half of the route.  The “Vertically Challenged” will need their belayer to be ON-POINT and  ready to take up some rope.  Alternatively, have a partner that’s taller than 5’8” and let them take the sharp end for this one.
routes.route_location: Splits the triangular face between Beetle Bailey Pitch 1 (10c) and the 5.7 ramp start for racer X. Look for three bolts.Previously an unnamed solo that was retro-bolted sometime pre-1991. During restoration cleaning in 2019 the original (retrobolted) hardware was upgraded. A bolt was added below to make this climb safe and now offers climbers an alternative moderate start for Racer-X, rather than the often dirty 5.7 ramp.
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts and finger size gear

route_comments.comment_text: Cool climb, didn't use any gear, large runout after the first bolt, but if you're comfortable climbing the grade it is fine. Huge holds to a clipping position. Any 5.8 move is very well protected. Jun 3, 2019
A superior "Easiest Approach" to the upper pitches than Racer-X p1.  Let's face it... You wanna TR "Beetle Bailey" p1 too and this is the best access to the anchor. Aug 17, 2019
Excellent way to TR "Beetle Bailey" p1.  A few smaller cams will keep you off the deck if you fall on easier terrain. Sep 4, 2019

routes.route_fa: Ryan Hoover, Adam Wood, Michal Rynkiewicz
routes.route_description: Dramatic, interesting and obvious. I was intrigued when opening the more moderate terrain of Ride the Lighting. Ryan and Mike saw it and knew it had to be. Ryan and I started efforts between rain storms in 2020 and after much talk on ups and downs of viable passages we settled on something very thought out and special.This is closest your will get to the Cheeks (overhung hard granite) and roadside. Two pitches, the first is improbable, airy, overhung crimps on bolts with no distinct crux. The hardest bit is allowing  your mind to believe that the ascent is happening.The second pitch is a minor traverse up techy slab. The second pitch joins the final bolts of RTL p4.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Lots of different options for starts, here’s my 2 cents! P1 : Climb “Behind the Tomb Stone” 5.9 or P1 of “Beetle Bailey” 10d. If climbing “Beetle Bailey”, belay at the top of the pillar feature, a new anchor has been placed on top to help with traffic. P2: Climb “Tiny Dancer” or “Rope Eating Mice”. Bolts and a couple finger to tight hand size gear placements (optional). 10- P3: Start... more Lots of different options for starts, here’s my 2 cents! P1 : Climb “Behind the Tomb Stone” 5.9 or P1 of “Beetle Bailey” 10d. If climbing “Beetle Bailey”, belay at the top of the pillar feature, a new anchor has been placed on top to help with traffic. P2: Climb “Tiny Dancer” or “Rope Eating Mice”. Bolts and a couple finger to tight hand size gear placements (optional). 10- P3: Start as for P3 of “Ride the Lightning” but take the left of the 2 bolt lines up the overhung face. 11+ P4: Climb slightly right then up. Join “Ride the Lightning” for the last 2 bolts. 11- If you are comfortable with easy run outs on low to mid fifth, this thing can go with all draws and you can skip the rack. Sep 2, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Didn’t do the last pitch because it was dirty. · Lead / Fell/Hung. TR, not lead. Only did P3, since this was after climbing and lowering off P4 of RtL. Super fun, did all the moves both times but this is a powerful route! Basically only three hard or big moves but they add up! The upper section abrades the rope quite a lot when TRing. We left pink fluff all over the rock...

routes.route_fa: FA TR Cramer Lein  FFA Grafton Gerberding
routes.route_description: This is an interesting alternative to Beetle Bailey pitch 2. Start as for BB P2 then cut right early following a right trending crack ramp with nice feet. Small cams are good for this bit. Continue diagonal until a block is reached and a bolt (retro bolted 2019) out right. Then follow directly up to the Beetle Bailey anchor.
routes.route_location: Climb either routes to the first beetle Bailey Anchor. Then directly above the chains heading right at the first opportunity.
routes.route_protection: Some smaller gear including nuts and small cams. Careful to use the bolt rather than the ringing block for pro half way up the route.

route_comments.comment_text: This fantastic moderate now has an ASCA Anchor. This is also the original finish for Beetle Bailey pitch 2. You can traverse from this anchor left to top rope BBp2 via the 11a variation. Aug 20, 2019
Such a great varied route. Juggy face climbing to a fun rightward transition, then awesome slab/knob moves at the end. One of the coolest I've done at Beetle Bailey area. Jun 3, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Awesome climb, did on toprope; might be tough to protect on lead. I believe you're intended to clip one bolt of the Tiny Dancer line near the end...

routes.route_fa: Michal Rynkiewicz, Jeff Wong, Adam Wood
routes.route_description: This short start to Master Wong full is extremely high quality and very approachable for newer climbers.Ascend a beautiful bolted slab. Take the furthest right bolt line through the roof. Pull through a roof on jugs with perfect feet out left. A few big reaches take you to a hanging set of mussy hooks.**The name comes from an incident last year. Jeff was working the route and heard a loud smash. From his high point on the route Jeff could easily see his own car across the tracks with one less window and a few less personal items. Truly a sad day.**
routes.route_location: Right side of the Beetle Bailey massif. Look for an obvious slab to roof. Same start for War/Brain on Dougs. This direct line through the center of the slab and roof.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: This is a SUPER fun climb, that is well protected. I looked up and thought there were too many bolts at first but once I was climbing I did enjoy having them there, as the crux is through the layback roof thing, and there is a slab beneath. I enjoyed this climb a lot and it’s pretty easy up until the little layback roof. I did tell michal it felt harder than “cunning stunt” so I think the... more This is a SUPER fun climb, that is well protected. I looked up and thought there were too many bolts at first but once I was climbing I did enjoy having them there, as the crux is through the layback roof thing, and there is a slab beneath. I enjoyed this climb a lot and it’s pretty easy up until the little layback roof. I did tell michal it felt harder than “cunning stunt” so I think the grade should be 10c or d , but it’s def only one move of it , with the rest being pretty 5.8 ish Jul 9, 2021

This climb is mostly 5.9/10a Index-y slab with a perplexing start and fun gymnastic and unexpectedly sequential roof crux.  I agree with Sara, harder than "Cunning Stunt" through the crux.  Felt about the same as 36V p1 or Everything Hertz.  If you try those, you should try this one too.  It's a super safe modern-style sport climb.  I can't think of any 5.10b's at Index that felt this... more This climb is mostly 5.9/10a Index-y slab with a perplexing start and fun gymnastic and unexpectedly sequential roof crux.  I agree with Sara, harder than "Cunning Stunt" through the crux.  Felt about the same as 36V p1 or Everything Hertz.  If you try those, you should try this one too.  It's a super safe modern-style sport climb.  I can't think of any 5.10b's at Index that felt this difficult but plenty of 5.10d's and a few 5.10c's.  I'm gonna suggest 5.10c/d but don't be surprised if you're solid at the grade and have to try a couple times to send. Be nice to the slug family that lives at the base. Jul 12, 2021
Great short powerful roof route.  Techy slab moves lead into a juggy roof.  Another classic added to the Lower Lump.  Nice job guys! Jul 12, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Surprising start and tough roof exit but amazing (short) climb. Right foot on ledge before clipping and you’re good to go! With Lukas and Ally · Lead / Onsight. Fell at last bolt crux. Need to work on pumpy roofs · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to take figuring out my feet on the roof pull. Great route · Lead / Redpoint. For the start, move right foot up before going to sidepull · Lead / Redpoint. Stiff for the grade. Couldn’t find a good clipping stance exiting the roof but thugged it out anyways · TR. Had no problems on TR but didn’t lead. Do it next time. Very fun · Lead / Onsight. Tried to do war on Doug’s but it was soaked in algae, this one was fun and probably better · Lead / Redpoint. draws only. fell at 2nd bolt. roof is fun and well protected. · Lead / Onsight. w/ patrick and megan. i thought the hardest part was pulling off the ground! roof moves were sweet - great feet and hands. clipped the chains off of a horrible crimp but there’s a good sidepull i missed. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fun and we’ll protected but super hard finish! Like a V3 boulder problem. Funky start too · Lead. Fell trying to get over lip a few times. Very fun route though · TR. no falls until the overhung crux, tried it a few times before finally getting it. I was concerned I wasn't going to finish it! · TR. High point is the jug at crux. Couldn’t match. Best shot is first climb in flash. Fresh. · TR. 3 falls in the roof. Very cool route. Will Be back when the ankle clears up · Lead / Fell/Hung. This felt a lot harder than cunning stunt. 2 move wonder. Maybe come back and try this again in a few months. · Lead / Onsight. God damn shit. OS but felt hard. The upper parts of the routes looked dirty AF. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell a few times on the roof. MAYBE possible to Redpoint but would be limited most likely by power · TR. Got the tronsight!!! Burly finish, but super secure. Interesting moves at the bottom too! I think I could lead it next time. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got the start but whipped at the second to last bolt · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. harder than 10b in my opinion, crux at the start, 1st bolt have to be tall enough to reach when close ground, can't clip when making the moves. roof the second crux, left hand up when going over lip · Lead / Flash. Watching someone else climb first really helped. Sweet climb, somehow has a variety of moves packed into a short distance! Requires more brawn than technique. · Lead / Fell/Hung. w/Jon. 1 hang to clip the bolt over the roof (ridiculous rope drag trying to make the clip), then 1 hang because I didn't know to go out right after.

routes.route_description: Fun climbing on jugs through a roof (10a to intermediate anchor) leads to a beguiling crux that is way harder than it looks. The climbing eases off but remains challenging to the end.
routes.route_location: Start as for the previous two routes but head right.
routes.route_protection: bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Gave the upper pitch a good scrub today, go figure out the devious crux! It's possible to pull on one bolt and enjoy ~10+ to the upper anchors. Aug 27, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to pull through the crux to the next crimp. Pretty dirty after the crux · Lead. Had to pull on the draw for the crux. L hand on lay back, R on tiny crimp under roof. Still dirty · TR. Trolo boi. The most sandbagged warm-up of all time courtesy of Michal: "5.10 to a crux!" Couldn't do a single crux move

routes.route_description: Cryptic and delicate movement past bolts and pins leads onto a slab. This first half goes around 10d with emphasis on reading the rock for smart feet.   Clip a fixed pin in a hole with optional gear then start sneaking up one of Index’s finest slab puzzles. This section has a very “Phone Calls from the Dead” feel.Follow subtle knobs with hand foot matches past bolts. Cut left below a final angled piton (climbing to this piton puts you off route) to a crack taking small cams (was previously a piton) before one bolt and the anchor. The crux can sit in a small lingering wet streak visible from the road. It’s dry if the belay chains are dry.This climb can be top roped by climbing a short 5.9 corner above the Racer X pitch two anchors. This corner may need some cleaning.
routes.route_location: Right of Racer X and left of Beetle Bailey pitch 2. Climb either Racer X pitch 1 (5.7) or Beetle Bailey pitch 1 (10d) from the chains look directly up and slightly left you will see a fixed knife blade followed  by bolts. If you traverse too far left you will be on Racer X.
routes.route_protection: 7 bolts 2 fixed pitons and a couple finger/ tips cams could be helpful.

route_comments.comment_text: All bolts and anchor have been replaced today. Don’t be afraid of what seems like runouts. Gear and pitons appear when you most need it. This climb is as classic as Racer X. This climb was originally bolted 31 years ago and begs a new generation of climbers to enjoy it. Apr 28, 2019

Racer X's big scary brother. The crux (using the seam below the off-route piton and cutting back left onto the minuscule knobs) is both desperate and precise. You can bail left to Racer X's finish on lead if need be. TR access by climbing to the apex of the arch from the left (Racer X) or right (BB P2, Rope Eating Mice). Jul 22, 2020
This slab is terrifying! I tried it in the sun but felt like 11d with bolts a heady distance apart Aug 28, 2021

routes.route_protection: 70M rope, 10 QD's and a handful of runners.  Take extra QD's if you link pitches.2 - 70M rappels get you down to the ground. From thepitch 4ledge, rappel to the RacerX/Argentinosaurus anchor where a rope stretcher rappel gets you to about 6 feet off the ground OR go the Anthropocene anchor and rap again.

route_comments.comment_text: This is an awesome addition to the cliff with several cool steep sequences. Purists need not shy away, you can climb the incongruously hard section with a few 11- moves! Jul 26, 2024

Great new addition! A good multi pitch outing for the 5.10 climber. Would recommend linking first two to racer x anchor. Pitch 3 on its own. Then link pitch 4 and 5 and lower down to top of pitch 4. From there it's two 70 m rope rappels. Jul 26, 2024
Not bad, if a little dirty. The most pitches I’ve done over 200-something feet but it gets you to the top! Fun, if short, cruxes—the 5.8 pitches are thoughtful as well. Aug 6, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · 3 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Alana Linked 1&2, I pitched 3, I linked 4&5. 14 QD, 6 AD plenty. Maybe take 1x #1 for flake moves on p.1. Used fixed rope through 11b section. Try to climb it next time... · 3 pitches. Lead. Top 3 pitches after The Anthropocene & Mesosaurus. Follow 3, lead 4-5 as one pitch. 5.10d without the cheater rope. · Lead / Fell/Hung. James lead 1+2 of Argentiniosuarus, I lead 3+5. Very pumped on overhung start of pitch 3 not trusting shoulder. Pitch 3 felt harder than 4. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Truly incredible route. 2min from the car, beautiful views, and such fun climbing! Huge variety between each pitch, from super slabby with tiny knobs to big mantles and even some fun and interesting crack at the end! · Lead / Onsight. Led 1/2 + 4/5. Followed P3 and freed past the rope at ~11-. Very fun climb. w/ Kuba. · 3 pitches. Lead. did it as a finish to argentiniosaurus, dirty af, could be a good time when it cleans up

routes.route_description: This is a great slab climb with your typical Index knobs.P1: Climb a ramp (5.7) to a bolted belay, or do the first pitch of Beetle Bailey Arch (5.10c).P2: Traverse way left. When you get to a cool pocket with crystals inside, go up the knobby slab. Some people put a 3" cam in the pocket (5.10a).P3: A short pitch up an arch (5.9+).As of 2020, there are 4 options to access the Racer X anchor as your "First Pitch": Smilodon fatalis, Index Archaeology, Village Idiot (Original pitch 1) and Behind the Tombstone (requires a short leftward scramble). The original first pitch is probably the least enjoyable.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: bolts, 3" piece optional. If you do the 5.7 first pitch of this climb instead of that of Beetle Bailey Arch, bring small cams, and nuts.

route_comments.comment_text: The first pitch (5.7) is pretty much unclimbable as far as I could tell. Beetle Bailey is much cleaner but still very mossy. The lower portion of the crag deserves a much needed cleaning. Jul 14, 2018
Is this on anyone’s cleaning list? Perhaps it’s already been cleaned?  My guess is It would be a great readdition to Index. Nov 22, 2018

We've talked about leaving cleaning tools at various lessor-traveled places at Index, and this would indeed be a great section of cliff to reclean. I haven't heard of anyone working on it. Nov 23, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. superb knob slab. heart beating, blood pumping, dawgs barkin. spicy and thoughtful. With Nina! · Lead / Redpoint. #3 for pod. Lead / Onsight. Didn’t do p3 since it’s only like 20 feet. I think we traversed too far over and got on the dino route left of this route bc I did the layback slab crux of that route · Lead / Fell/Hung. spaced out bolts! bring a #3 for the crystal pocket. did BB p1 first on TR · Follow. Fantastic knobs, but I thought the crux was before the knobs · TR. TR only pitch 2, 2x. Crux beta: downward left thumb to push up toward good right hand pocket. Stand up on right foot. Trust foot! Leadable · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. runouts are easy, it's where the bolts are it gets hard. awesome, after 9 months zero granite- still got it! · Only did Pitch one and 3/4 of pitch 2...scary...Never found the 3' cam placement either...

routes.route_fa: P1 A. Wood, D. Taylor   P2 D. Taylor, G. Shank  P3/4 FA A. Wood, J. Mack, S. McAmis
routes.route_description: This is why you started rock climbing.Inspiring roofs, slabs, traverses and exposure rolled into four very different moderate pitches. Everything to test the new 5.10 leader.P1Climb “Behind the Tomb Stone.5.9P2“Rope Eating Mice” Bolts and a couple finger to tight hand size gear placements. Face moves to start into expanding flakes and a high crux. Stop at the first set of anchors NOT the high set of rap rings.10a/bP3“ From the lower belay, make an easy traverse right, up a ramp with optional gear, aiming for an obvious low bolt on an exposed Arete (5.6)  At the bolt match low then make an exposed karate kick to good feet and slap out right to a jug. Follow bolts up exposed terrain minding your feet with a few reachy moves.10cP4This pitch can be seen from the pullout by the river. It’s a fantastic clip up on slabby mantles, high steps and a memorable foot traverse with extraordinary views of Mt Index and the river singing in the background.10aThe FA team completed the route sans headlamp during an end of season lightning storm 2019.
routes.route_location: From the base of Beetle Bailey Slab, you will see a large triangular headstone driven into the duff. Locate “Behind the Tomb Stone” and go for it!Update: StayRIGHTat each belay.At the top ofP1going hard left will send you onto “Tiny Dancer” this is a fantastic fully bolted alternative to “Rope eating Mice” but much better approached from “Index Archeology” From the top ofP2stay hard right out the arete. Going left takes you onto “Kiss the Sky” which does link into the base of P4. (An awesome variation for the 11b climber)Descent:70 M ROPE!!!! Lower from the 4th to 3rd pitch. Make a long free hanging rap from the top of the 3rd pitch to the anchors atop “Behind the Tomb Stone”Gear:12 quick draws single rack to 1inch, 70 meter ropeP1 Bolts 5.9+P2 0.75, 1 and 0.3 Camelot, Bolts 10a/bp3 Bolts 10cp4. Bolts 10a
routes.route_protection: 12 quick draws. Blue TCU and a couple mid sized cams to sew it.

routes.route_fa: Gabe Shank, Doug Taylor, Adam Wood
routes.route_description: A great psychological warm-up for Racer-X as it compares in physical difficulty, but is much more generous with protection.  Originally viewed as a 2nd and slightly harder/longer pitch to Behind the Tombstone, it also became the 2nd pitch of one of Index’s best moderate multi-pitches, Ride The Lightning.From the top of “Behind the Tombstone”, continue up bolts through the inverted-V roof. Follow the super easy ramp with natural gear a few feet until you see a bolt above in a “circular cutout”.  Climb into the cutout and then onto the slab (crux).Climb pastintermediate anchor (the start of p3 of Ride The Lightning) and another bolt.  Move right to the white corner, padding up fun knobs for feet and crimps in the roof to the anchor for the 5.10a/b finish.  The route makes use of a series of expanding flake systems that are safe for climbing but highly suspect for gear.The anchor is shared with “Beetle Bailey P2” and “Larry’s Lycra” and is an easy access to set up a TR for those routes.
routes.route_location: Starts at the Behind The Tombstone anchor.
routes.route_protection: 9 QD's and a single rack to #1

route_comments.comment_text: Bring a #2 BD cam for the start of the right-trending ramp which is easy climbing but it's a ways above your last bolt and a long way to the next one. My biggest piece was a #1 per the gear beta and it was mega tipped and likely would not have held a fall. Protection felt marginal along most of the ramp as the crack is flaring and jagged, with the exception of a decent yellow totem before... more Bring a #2 BD cam for the start of the right-trending ramp which is easy climbing but it's a ways above your last bolt and a long way to the next one. My biggest piece was a #1 per the gear beta and it was mega tipped and likely would not have held a fall. Protection felt marginal along most of the ramp as the crack is flaring and jagged, with the exception of a decent yellow totem before pulling up into the circular cutout and a bolt. Pretty thin and challenging route overall, felt sustained and had several committing moves/mental cruxes. Worth it to get to Ride the Lightning, though! May 16, 2021
You can tr/lower off this from the ground with a 70 (tie knots) Sep 9, 2024

routes.route_fa: Michal Rynkiewicz, Adam Wood, Ryan Hoover, Sherri Lewis
routes.route_description: Tiny Dancer goes up the slab just a few feet to the left of Rope Eating Mice but dances to its own tune.   Break out your best footwork for the thoughtful sequences on thin edges.From the top of Behind the Tombstone, follow the bolt line that trends LEFT above the belay ledge and continue left towards the flake.  From a good stance on the ramp, clip the bolt on the slab and figure out how to gracefully pull yourself onto the slab.  This may be one of the rare occasions that shorter climbers get a leg up.  Glissade up the slab to the anchor(mussy hooks) shared with the start of the 3rd pitch of Ride the Lightning.  (For another 15ft or so of .10a/b climbing, join Rope Eating Mice here by continuing past the RTL anchor, moving right into the white corner --one more bolt -- and following knobs and crimps in the roof to the Rope Eating Mice anchor.)"Dancing On My Grave"(approx 130ft?, .10b) -- start your lead from the ground, combining Behind the Tombstone with Tiny Dancer for one long pitch of Index awesomeness, finishing at the Ride the Lightning anchor. Add a few more draws and slings and a Green Alien or blue TCU to the rack noted below when doing this combo as one pitch.  Can be toproped from the base of BTT with an 80m rope.Note: Tiny Dancer is also the 2nd pitch/approach pitch for "Kiss the Sky."Descent:  an 80m rope gets you back to the ground from the Ride the Lightning anchor.  If lowering with a 70m, it is best to stop at Behind the Tombstone anchor.
routes.route_location: Start at bolted anchor of Behind the Tombstone.
routes.route_protection: 10 - 12 quickdraws, one optional finger-sized piece (ie - yellow Metolius or .4 BD cam) to protect the last 15ft of easy climbing below Ride the Lightning anchor.

routes.route_description: Mind Blowing!Start on the short version, an interesting moderate up expanding flakes that checks every box for new climbers dipping their toes into rainforest granite.From the chains follow bolts up a slab using the left facing corner / face for holds. Similar feel to the “Lithuanian Lip” at WA passPull the roof out right using slopers, side pulls and controlled feet. Expect a dynamic exit for most humans. Most will make an exposed dyno to a meaty jug.Beta on the Dyno: [difficult to grade - sling your weight and skate some smears.] ((Tommy had a devious, dark and impish humor that appreciated a heart breaking finish)) That is why I chose this line in hishonor.** control your swing ****This route honors my friend who died climbing in 2020. Tommy’s spirit for life was infectious. We are often drawn to climbing for the challenge. We make it a life long passion through the people, community and relationships built over time. Tommy was the guy you wanted on your side when it was hard, scary or uncomfortable. He spent his life serving others in medicine and called upon the lessons learned in the hills, to make all our lives a little better.
routes.route_location: Currently, the furthest right line at the crag. Look for a rad platform belay follow bolts up expanding flakes right of “Drunken Master” aim for an obvious yellow/ green roof.
routes.route_protection: Hand sized cams and bolts!!!!!

route_comments.comment_text: Pretty much a sport route. I used a single #3, but this isn't strictly necessary if you're confident with 5.8 handcrack for about 10 feet. This is coming from someone who normally places a lot of gear. The climbing between the first anchor and the roof is a blast and totally worthwhile even if the roof doesn't go. I wasn't able to free the roof but it was easy to pull through on draws and a... more Pretty much a sport route. I used a single #3, but this isn't strictly necessary if you're confident with 5.8 handcrack for about 10 feet. This is coming from someone who normally places a lot of gear. The climbing between the first anchor and the roof is a blast and totally worthwhile even if the roof doesn't go. I wasn't able to free the roof but it was easy to pull through on draws and a lot of fun trying to figure it out anyway. Get it! Aug 3, 2021
Psyched people are getting on this. The roof exit plays well to those with some super hero flight skills. Aug 3, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Took once at the 3rd bolt. Beta: use the right side pull, the top is a jug · Lead / Onsight. Great!! Gear: singles cams #0.4 to #3, and some reasonble number of draws. · Lead / Onsight. Fun crackin, need to come back for the full thing, looks sick! · Lead / Onsight. Clipped the first two or three bolts but only used pro after that. The later bolts really aren’t necessary. Worth doing if in the area but wouldn’t repeat. Kinda short and sweet. Recommend gear to 4” for a new leader sewing it up (can place a #4 below the #3 which should be saved for the top) · Lead / Flash. Placed a #6 hex about halfway and a #2 cam to protect the last fist crack. Do recommend #3 next time · Lead / Flash. Doable on sports lead because of a 5th hidden bolt (bolt 4/5) on top of the ledge in the middle. still a bit sketchy protection without additional trade gear but ok if dry because easy enough. O did it when in bad climbing shape · TR. Left facing crack. Couldn't figure out how to hand jam. Layback most of the time. · Lead / Onsight. Great crack all bolted, a little run out @ the top # 3 might make it feel better for new climber ( it’s a questionable flake for pro) · Lead / Fell/Hung. 5 QD’s. Not sure where the 6th bolt was? Or why it says to bring slings? Crux from bolt 2 through 3ish. Crux well protected. Top section can feel sketchy if not comfortable at the grades. Crack started as wide fingers, ended as thin fists for me.

area_description: The Tiki Heads are the westernmost sector of the Lower Lump.  The Tiki Heads are still very early in development.  It will likely take several years to properly develop this sector, but what is being uncovered is looking quite fun and worthwhile with quality single and two pitch lines being unearthed.
area_getting_there: Continue past the farthest left lines of the Beetle Bailey slab and uphill for the first of the Tiki Head lines.

area_comments.comment_text: Was out at BB on 1/28/25 and captured an epic video of some guys clearing big boulders off the left side of tiki, looks like some super cool stuff is coming soon! Jan 28, 2025

routes.route_fa: Ben Kopsa, Gabe Smith, Doug Taylor, Marilina Kim
routes.route_description: A belayer bolt marks the start of "Hyperbole".   Head up past 4 bolts then pull onto a slab into a rare rock feature at Index, a water runnel on a slab.  Don't let the easy first half of the route make you complacent.  Your slab skills will need to be turned on for the second half.This line is the first to get sun at the Lower Lump, so get on it early.  It's also the first to be in the shade, so get on it later.
routes.route_location: Walk past "Smilodon..." and "Anthropocene" and scamper uphill to an obvious belayer bolt.
routes.route_protection: 9 QD's

routes.route_name: Scariest Most Dangerous Climb in the World!!!, The
routes.route_fa: Gabe Shank, Chase Hughes, Doug Taylor
routes.route_description: Only the most stouthearted and reckless climbers will take the dare and ascend this widowmaker.  With only 12 bolts protecting this 120 foot route, the climber will, at times, feel like the climb is almost slightly run out just a little bit."Scariest..." shares the first 3 bolts with "Hyperbole WILL KILL US ALL". At bolt 3 trend right into a flake crack and follow the bolts to the anchor.Gird your loins, grow a pair, sack up, get focused and be ready to have your name honored in the annals of history when YOU have climbed "The Scariest, Most Dangerous Climb in the World".Descent:With a 70M rope, parties can lower straight down towards "Anthropocene" with 2M to spare.  Otherwise, rap to the "Anthropocene" anchor  and to the ground.
routes.route_location: Walk past "Smilodon..." and "Anthropocene" and scamper uphill to an obvious belayer bolt.
routes.route_protection: All the Quick Draws

route_comments.comment_text: Note: A 70m will get to the ground.  Any rope shorter will require 2 raps to get down or you will have to tag a second rope.  Don’t rap the route, rap straight down.  It’s a killer, soon to be a classic, but let your fear decide. Aug 10, 2024

Likely the most dangerous and terrifying route I have done in my life. By some miracle I survived. The "triceratop-out" is not to be missed. New stretchy 70m rope worked to lower all the way back to the ground. if there are people climbing on anthropocene,  smilodon fatalis or mosasaurus let them know you are attempting such a risky route, as you will have to lower through them. Coordinate... more Likely the most dangerous and terrifying route I have done in my life. By some miracle I survived. The "triceratop-out" is not to be missed. routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Super fun route! Felt like a trad climb with well protected bolts. Would love to try this with trad gear.

routes.route_description: The first multipitch line of the Tiki Heads sector. Twist My Tea, with a short crux and mostly moderate climbing, this is a good entry level 5.10d for Index climbers.Pitch 1 is 5.8 knobby face climbing, followed by low angled slab into a chill corner with a wonderful pinch hold right when you need it.Pitch 2 Trend slightly rightward face climbing on unusual blobby rock.  Crawl into a tightening roof to get your crux on.  A combination of crack climbing and face climbing will get you to a rest ledge.  Hang out for a bit to get the heart rate down, then clip your way up some stacked blocks and boulders.The crux is short but quite thought provoking while most of the route is 5.9 and easy 5.10.A note on the bolts by the crack:  On the first attempts to lead TMT, we learned that the ledgy nature of the line caused the rope to be drawn into the crack making the rope bind on cams and/or get damaged by the tight constriction of the crack.  For safety sake, we decided to bolt the face.You might have seen Chase and Doug sitting at the base after a day of development, drinking a Twisted Tea and discussing their common soul searing hatred of blackberry bushes.Descent:2 raps from the top
routes.route_location: TMT is the farthest left of the Lower Lump climbs.  Walk up to the top of the dirt pile to a ledge adjust past a belay bolt.
routes.route_protection: 11 QD's with optional cams .2 - .4

route_comments.comment_text: Pitch 2 crux is a blast and the last 20 feet of climbing is thought provoking. Aug 10, 2024

It's possible (and fun) to climb this in one pitch with a 70m if you manage rope drag carefully. I back cleaned a good bit. From there, you can lower down to the top of pitch one and belay from there to save a rappel. Overall great route, sure to be popular. Aug 10, 2024

area_description: Mostly steep and usually shady.Zappa is a wall experiencing a renaissance. It had a few routes in the 80s that nobody climbed due to it being off the beaten path, but all the while it was clear to anyone who bushwhacked over there that the wall had excellent potential for numerous classics. Then, after the nearby Halloween was developed during the pandemic of 2020-2022, developers inspired by the late Michal R- made a trail to Zappa from Halloween and started unearthing the long buried gems.Zappa has some excellent cracks, some futuristic roofs, and some slab. A few routes have easy-to-set TRs, but most require a lead and most are trad. And still there is much potential.
area_getting_there: Start by hiking to Halloween. From the east end of Halloween, near the base of Resting Witch Face, look for the trail going down and east. Follow trail for about 5-10 minutes, which should take you close to some steep walls for the last few minutes before going uphill to the base of Zappa. The first cleaned route you'll encounter is Azure Winged Magpie. A minute later you meet the main wall just below Pussamus and Turtles Bong Rip.

area_comments.comment_text: Does anyone have more info about this cliff?  I've looked over at it countless times, but can't find any info more recent than the Cummins guide. Jul 9, 2015

I suspect that nobody has done any routes there since the FAs were done. Hot Curlie and Poop Shute appeared in Darryl Cramer's Sky Valley Rock (2000), but offered no useful info about the routes. When I went back last year, I saw lots of potential for great crack lines, but could not find the ones I had done previously. Hot Curly Wienie was a fantastic thin crack, but where did it go? ... more I suspect that nobody has done any routes there since the FAs were done. routes.route_description: A striking corner finger crack that sat in the woods for decades waiting to be rediscovered. This route appeared in Darryl Cramer's Sky Valley Rock, along with the aptly named Poop Chute, but not the more recent Index Town WallsStart in a corner finger crack atop a flake (or start below for full value) and jam and stem your way up the finger crack until the angle eases and the crack widens. Continue up the crack to an anchor up high, which may be hard to see until you get closer.The top may be a little dirty, but if this route cleans up a little bit its a pretty classic finger crack. Bring a brush and do something nice!Also, there is a handline up the gully just west of Hot Curly that gives easy access to the anchors. So, it is easy to set up a TR on this crack. (As of early July, this gully is a bit clogged with debris from above, but should be cleaned up soon. If you're feeling in a helpful mood, bring up a small handsaw to help remove some of the fallen branches clogging up the gully.)

route_comments.comment_text: Though my memory is foggy here, I think this is a vastly improved and extended version of the ancient "Poop Chute" route "done" by Brian Patrick and I back in the early days of Zappa, right after Hot Curly. I recall clambering between trees and rock to get a few hand jams and stopping at a tree in the corner, giving up on our exploration as the crack looked to peter out and the tree provided a... more Though my memory is foggy here, I think this is a vastly improved and extended version of the ancient "Poop Chute" route "done" by Brian Patrick and I back in the early days of Zappa, right after Hot Curly. I recall clambering between trees and rock to get a few hand jams and stopping at a tree in the corner, giving up on our exploration as the crack looked to peter out and the tree provided a good rap anchor. Now it is unrecognizable for the better. Great job cleaning this up. Edit to add- If the ratings reflected the work to rejuvenate this line, then the star rating would be off the charts. Folks would have to see how this looked before to understand why the FA team considers it four stars. Jul 7, 2024
Ok route but a bit overhyped imo, I would not call it one of the best 10+'s at index. It is long but the actual engaging climbing is pretty limited. Sep 18, 2024

I got back to the ground after the initial cleaning and was taking off my shoes when I see Michal solo up the dirty pitch to retrieve something from the... more I cleaned this on my birthday in 2015. routes.route_name: Something Under the Bed is Drooling
routes.route_description: A long low angle route that steadily traverses right. As long as it's clean, this is probably one of the better 5.6/5.7s in Index.Start with a low angle ramp to a high first bolt then step right into a seam and onto a big ledge. There's currently a large boulder known as the big boi that Jon and I have spent about four days trying to trundle all the way down. It's stable but it's a big boi and hard to move.Once on the ledge, climb a low angle finger crack dihedral to a wide right trending crack in a ramp. You could maybe use big cams to sew it, but only a 4 is really needed.
routes.route_location: Start on a low angle ramp to a high first bolt
routes.route_protection: Standard rack to #4

route_comments.comment_text: Even without the fun climbing, worth it just to see the unique knob at the end. Jul 7, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. w/ Caroline P. 88°f in the shade. Placed 2 black totems, an overcammed 2, solid 4 and a few other smaller sizes.

routes.route_description: A long two-pitch route to the top(ish) of Zappa. This line takes a striking crack and series of golden knobs on the imposing headwall above.P1 (5.10a to 5.10+): The first pitch can be done a variety of ways. The most direct way is to climb Turtle's Bong Rip (Michal 10+ aka not 10+) to the anchor and belay from the good ledge above. An easier alternative (likely more fun if climbing near your grade) is to do Pussamus then move the belay right to the Turtle's Bong Rip anchor. For the easiest approach, climb the first part of Coughing Spider to the first good ledge at about 5.7 then climb the upper half of Pussamus then move the belay right.P2 (5.10c): The money pitch. A full 35m - tie knots in your ends if top roping or rappelling/lowering. Climb a lower-angle ramp with a crack (may need to clean fir needles out of the crack with a nut tool) through a mini-roof then jog left at a good crack and continue up through cracks and a sea of golden knobs protected by three bolts to the top. The top provides a unique perspective of town you won't get anywhere else in Index.
routes.route_location: Start on Pussamus, Turtle's Bong Rip or Coughing Spider on the main wall of Zappa then continue up the headwall to the top.
routes.route_protection: Standard Rack to #4 Camalot

routes.route_description: Start on a 3" right facing corner that leads to a ledge. From ledge undercling and handjam out roof to the right for about ten' past big block that resisted attempts of being pryed off. Once on top of block place small tcu's in right facing corner/groove to reach the bolt. After bolt is short awkward crux getting established into thin right facing corner that goes from tips to #3 camolot toward the chains.
routes.route_location: Obvious right facing corner with roof and block
routes.route_protection: singles up to #1 camalot, x2 #2 camalot, x3 #3 camalot, quickdraw. should be plenty for conservative leader.

route_comments.comment_text: Good shit m8, really fun, kinda hard. Oct 1, 2024

route_comments.comment_text: Fun off-the-beaten path climb. The first half of the route is pretty clean. There's some moss on the face next to the upper corner but it still climbs well. Anchor consists of 2 bolts with cord and biners. I will replace the cord the next time I visit. Apr 5, 2016

area_description: This large, secluded cliff in the forest is named after its first route, which features a classic hand crack in a corner. But it has numerous other classic crack and face climbs as well as plenty of potential for newer lines.
area_getting_there: Approach from the Lookout Point trail.From the initial bridge at the start of the trail, hike up the hill to the crest. From here, if you want to check out the excellent Zelda boulders go left. But for Rattletale (and the rest of Lookout Point), continue on, following the trail right along the crest then bearing left across a flat region to Midnite boulder. Pass the boulder and enter a boulder-talus field. In about 5-10 min, reach a T-intersection, still in the boulder-talus field. Go left. Continue across and up for another 5-10 min to reach Rattletale. The trail hits the wall just right of the Rattletale route.

area_comments.comment_text: Super sweet route. The second pitch is pumpy but has good jams. The setting is really nice, views are good. Sep 29, 2012
Lots of new route activity here. Expect this to become a destination crag. May 14, 2017

In case anyone else notices this conflict, the approach description here is correct, the approach description in the new guidebook is incorrect (takes you to the Zelda boulders instead). Made the mistake of trusting the book over MP and ended up doing an unpleasant bushwhack up to the wall (but noticed a lot of nice looking undeveloped boulders on the way, if anyone was motivated..). ... more In case anyone else notices this conflict, the approach description here is correct, the approach description in the new guidebook is incorrect (takes you to the Zelda boulders instead). Made the mistake of trusting the book over MP and ended up doing an unpleasant bushwhack up to the wall (but noticed a lot of nice looking undeveloped boulders on the way, if anyone was motivated..). Quite a few new routes listed here which aren't in the new book, and I would say with those included it is definitely a destination crag at this point--had a lot of fun here, thanks to whomever is developing it. Jun 27, 2018

routes.route_description: Scramble up gully and pre clip the  2nd bolt. Funky laybacking leads past first bolt to crimpy section at second bolt. Perplexing jugs lead past couple bolts to last bolt where a compression boulder problem guards the chains! Better lead than top roped. You can skip the final crux by going around to left side of arete if going direct is too tricky. Not all climbs need to be over bolted. If you need bolts every 4 feet look elsewhere.
routes.route_location: Left of Chasing the Lizard, on small subbuttress
routes.route_protection: Quickdraws

route_comments.comment_text: High quality. Felt like 5.10+ to a v4. Jun 12, 2017
lmao this is hard af did not expect footwork to be as important as it ended up being Nov 5, 2018
all i gotta say is this is not 11- and I'm not into the Index is so sandbagged bandwagon. May 13, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Ethan put this up for us. It was great to watch him climb this. He had one fall moving between the 2nd and 3rd bolt. Then took a couple tries to move past the last bolt- but he did it and it was awesome. I made it to the last bolt before I had to take on TR. definitely some physical moves to get past the cruxy last moves- took a couple of tries. Definitely right heel hooking and slapping your way up the right side, with some left foot smearing to help you move up. Some fun, crazy movement. · Lead / Onsight. For festival comp. Slightly offbalance climbing to slopey fridge slappin up top. Was actively sliding down at crux, somehow found a nub on R face and kept on. Fun! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped a lot on that last bolt, the compression boulder problem is hard. From the left hand jug get right hand on the nub that’s lower then expected then get left foot up and left hand goes up to slap that slopper then right hand goes up to juggy arete · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couldn’t get past second bolt, and clipped it to start. V hard · Lead / Redpoint. 10/10 so much fun. Tech to more tech to beautiful arete movement up high. Do this thing. · TR. Great route. Many falls. Would love to get it dialed then lead. Also not bad for the skin. · TR. fun layback with thoughtful feet the first half. Got stuck at after the last bolt with jug on left arete. Top of arete is a sloper. went left. · Lead / Flash. w/ Waiwai. 5.10 may or may not be a sandbag, but no harder than Index 5.11- · TR. felt much more reasonable up until the final crux which felt the same. Hard to TR solo because of the way the rope runs. Need to remember a rope protector or lead it · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd go. Awesome and a bit frightening. High left toe at the end was crucial. · TR. Top seems impossible. Alex claims heel hook on the right, smear w/ left foot on the face · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took the whip a few times, then climbed the womb to tr · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got beat down. Top felt impossible on a hot day with little chalk and bad beta. Use a sneaky right crimp and a little foot chip around the right side. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Another failure on Lead. Tr lap with Jonathan beta getting better for crux (rest of route goes well!). Crux beta from good hold: reach right to hidden pocket, left foot to knob on left side, right foot to biggest knob in middle of wall, slap *high*, mantl · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped a bunch, fun to work hard above my grade. Couldn't figure out last problem before chains -, couldn't find holds to get over top. Try again on a colder day. Went around side to access chains. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took some pretty nasty falls. Some bone bruising in the back of my low calf from nailing the r edge of the arete and bloody knees but nothing serious. Was expecting index 10+ and went to battle. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Scary Lead. Super insecure the whole time. Took on the first 2 bolts. Sent the crux at the top · Lead / Redpoint. Not as bad as your typical MR sandbag as soon as you suss out the beta. Not a 10+!!! · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Luke. End of day, superb pitch but very very tricky. · Lad today. Pretty good until the last move to the top. Took multiple whippers. Then used diff beta and cruised it on TR

routes.route_description: P1: Climb the right leaning thin crack to a single bolt then back left along the lower of two left facing flakes. It is expanding. The first section goes clean at C2+ with some ground fall potential, or A2. the expanding flake past the bolt is A3.P2: climb straight up through the roof and traverse left to the obvious flake through bat hooks and 3 bolts; talons work well. Climb the flake traversing left to the small tree and a good anchor in the corner above the tree.  The flake is expanding and VERY hollow, it thins out to a few more hook moves at the end to gain the welcome small cedar tree.  Ball nuts and cam hooks work well.
routes.route_location: Located on the clean face to the right of Rattletale. The first bolt is easily visible with a lower out loop on it.
routes.route_protection: A good selection of hooks including sky hooks, talons, cam hooks, and a bat hook or two are mandatory.KB to #4long LA #4-#6Ball nuts, HB offsets both useful.Double Rack 000 to 0.5 range, small aliens are nice.

routes.route_description: Pitch 1) 10a. Mixed. A bit convoluted but fun climbing. Not sure how they intended the start, I stemmed off tree, but you could approach off the Lizard slab to the right. If you stem off the tree, there is some trad pro near start, then 2 bolt flaring stem box ( crux) fingers- hands- OW ( shared with Lizard), then traverse to single bolt on left slab, balance around corner to bolted belay. Spent some time cleaning this with my friend Bill on 2/24/16.The first ascent team calls this 10a, I would give it a 10bPitch 2) Short 5.9, pass 2 bolts with face climbing into corner ( fingers-hands crack)to big ledge above with good bolted chain anchor. Make 2 single rope raps or double rope rap to ground. This ledge is 40m up.Bill Ayre cleaned this 2/24/16.The first ascent team calls this 5.9, maybe 10a.Pitch 3) 12a, 6 bolts, bolted anchor. Some very small gear might work but it is well bolted. Was a bit spooky and committing for me, still a project for me, but should be pretty easy for a 5.12 climber.Others are calling this pitch 11c.The grade was what the first ascent team gave it, I guess others think it is easier.
routes.route_location: left side of wall, Chasing the Lizard is on the right. The bolted 3rd pitch starts directly above large ledge, with another 12a on the right side of the arete- Non stop Erotic Cabaret.
routes.route_protection: All 3/8" bolts, the 1st 2 bolts are SS, all others rusty plated steel. Standard rack to 4". 2 each .5, .75, #1 camalot. If you are not comfortable on off-width you may want a #5.It is a full 40 meters to top of 2nd pitch ledge. But we have rapped this with a single 70 meter rope by going to top of boulder from the top of the 2nd pitch anchor, and down climbing the big leaning boulder.

route_comments.comment_text: youtube.com/watch?v=peRXpig… Dec 16, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hopped on P3 after doing Chasing the Lizard because there was a bail biner on the fourth bolt. That’s where I bailed, too. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Need to come back- attempted the lead of last pitch after chasin’ the lizard pitch but failed after 3 bolts and gave up cuz I was gassed

routes.route_description: This route seems to get neglected most likely because the grade of the last pitch deters folks from giving it a good look.  Pitches 1 and 2 are really a lot of fun and attainable by the masses. As of August 2020, pitch 1 needs a little scrubbing. Pitch 2 needs some gardening and the bolts on  pitch 2 do need replacing.  Both anchors are SS and replaced within the last 5 years.
routes.route_location: Follow the directions for Avenging the Goddess Kring and just stop at the anchor shared with Chasin' the Lizard.
routes.route_protection: Index Rack

routes.route_description: This line frees the first few meters of Arch Enemy and joins The Orangutan at the second bolt.The Bonobo is a bit spicier than its neighbor, but the crux of both routes immediately follows the second bolt; the sequence is tenuous, powerful, and balance-y.This is an aesthetic line with flowy dynamic and high tension movement on fingerlocks, crimps, knobs and one amazing thumbdercling.
routes.route_location: Start on Arch Enemy with a dynamic unprotected boulder problem (jug to jug) and follow the seam until it begins to veer right. Join The Orangutan at the second bolt.
routes.route_protection: Gear is three pieces (purple mastercam, purple/blue offset mastercam, and blue alien) followed by two bolts.

routes.route_description: This pitch has it all from hands,fingers,stemming, and offwidth.  It deserves to see more traffic. The route starts out in the right hand of two crack systems.  Hand jams lead up to the left facing corner.  Continue up the corner (fingers) to the stem box above.  Continue stemming and grunting up the wide crack and chimney to the shared anchor (2nd pitch of Avenging the Goddess Kring).  2 single 60m raps or one double rap with get you back to the ground.
routes.route_location: Start 50' to the left of Rattletale.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack with gear to 4"-5".

route_comments.comment_text: Isn't this Avenging the Goddess Kring? Jun 5, 2011
Really fun route.  Gear up to a #4 Camalot.  #5 optional.  Anchor just above the ledge.  The second rap station is in need of replacement.  One of the bolts is completely rusted through. May 17, 2012

@Mark - I think this variation is Chasing the Lizard.  I don't have it with me but I believe that's what it says in Sky Valley Rock. The comment in the pic seems to verify it. cascadeclimbers.com/plab/sh… Jun 8, 2012

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. I finally did a lead run on this. Felt great! Pretty strenuous of course. I brought doubles of BD .1, .2, 4 and 5. Triples of in between sizes, but didn’t use any of my #3 cams. · TR. Max lead. Ethan and Haley TRd. I definitely want to lead this next time. Great pro. Max brought triples of medium stuff and 2 each of #4 and #5. · Lead / Onsight. Amazing climb. Feels like a Yosemite pitch with an awesome belay ledge. Used a single rack and #4. · Lead / Onsight. Funky, grovelly, enjoyable Placed a 4 and 5 but could have left the 5 if I didn’t love it so much · Lead / Fell/Hung. Led it in 85* sun after rattletale so felt like a terrible slog. Look forward to another time. I was definitely wishing for .1-00 cams that I didn’t have with so a #5 was required · Follow. Nick Led. I could lead. Bring 2 4s and a 5 and will likely feel alright! · Follow. Sustained, 3x #1, plenty of balancy rests once past the finger crack. Don't forget the #4 · TR. Great climb. Kendra lead. Have to rap left side to top of gully and use the hand line. Full 70 · Lead / Onsight. Max lead. Haley followed. What an amazing climb that really does have it all! OW, jams, fingers, a little bit of chimney and sport! It was very physical and exhausting! But so fun! Especially on TR · Lead / Redpoint. I saved the four and then never placed it. Placed the five to get my knee unstuck lol so that was cool. With Jess, maple stayed home :’( · Follow. Full body workout as always, such a great and varied climb! 2 #4s and a #5 is best. Straight in jamming the pod at the bottom worked well. Bump #5 up wide crack near the top. · Lead. As fun if not more fun then rattle tale. So much different climbing stacked into one route · Lead. hung since I didn't have a second 4. if only bringing one, save for the upper section. fun, long, varied climb with a great ledge at the top. 5.9 in the book · Follow. Bring 4 for near the top. Beautiful .3 finger crack followed by the crux of the flared double crack. Enjoyable and long route · Lead / Redpoint. Slipped on the second move of flash attempt. Sent clean on second attempt · Lead / Fell/Hung. The start was a little awkward with wide hands. once gaining the ledge, the next section is thin fingers in a dihedral that I took on a couple instances. eventually you gain the left wife crack where I'm glad I brought the #5. bumped it for a bit to place a nice but and get into the chimney section. The chimney and upwards was pretty chill and easy climbing. This feels harder than a 10a, but maybe that's because I don't like thin fingers. · Climbed with Karthik - I thought this was a quite technical pitch with many different climbing styles needed. · Follow. Long Sustained tough climbing. Bulge right off the deck, hands up to fingers, switch to left crack system. Tried to lead, fell on start twice. Bring extra gear, maybe trips in fingers to hands · Follow. Starting off width was hard. Need to work on that. Ended up cheating it with a layback · Follow. Start is the crux. Flared down and out makes the feet- or leg- jam difficult. Good hand jams lead into finger cracks and off width cracks. Off width to the left is way too big for my foot and too narrow for a knee or leg jam. Chimney move afterwards. Then lots of manteling to the top. · Lead / Onsight. Long and physical Single .2 to .4,, triple .5 to 2, double #3, 4. Probably can go with just double everything, but I was happy to have extras. I did use a .2 · Follow. Start was the hardest part, felt like grovely climbing most of the way for me. · Follow. Such a long pitch. I’m giving myself the clean follow even though I had to take to clean a 0.4 Adam had wedged. · Lead / Onsight. Sooo good! Definitely need to have your second follow up to clean this properly / easily. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung at the crux down low; didn’t see the nice rest behind me. Didn’t have any issues with the rest. #4 was very nice to have and the #5 was super nice and convenient for bumping. No double #4 needed. Could redpoint. · Lead / Onsight. Super fun. Lots of variety of moves. 70m will reach the rocks off climber's left (TM) · Lead / Onsight. Very stoked on this. Definitely suggest racking two 4s, one 5. Would not feel comfortable on this route without that. · Lead / Redpoint. basically 2x 0.4-#2, triple #1 (could use 4x down low, middle crack switch, then before and after roof but can use bd #2 after if careful), carried 2x #3 to the chains. bumped 4 & 5 though middle leaving some small gear and nuts, left 5 and took 4 then used near top. small 2 offset cams, didn't use blk or blu tot. crux is the start! belay from top, 80m rope for 1rap · Lead / Onsight. Fun. 2x 4s wouldn't go unused....or 1x 4 and 1x 5 · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couple falls at the bottom, don’t put a 3 in or you’ll take up holds and, 1 take at finger..super sweating · Lead / Onsight. Challenging. Felt like 5.10. Gear:double small to 5”, nuts, slings. Did it with a single 4” and 5” and bumped the 5” A LOT!!! · Lead / Flash. Much more awkward than Rattletale, but easier to lead, better rests, got it clean. Used single #0.5, doubles #0.75-3, and single #4 bumping it up till used nuts in small crack instead of #5. Didn't use my #0.3-0.4's. Used lots of draws! Two rappels with 60m were nice. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to yo yo down for the 4, glad to have the 5. Felt more burly than rattletale for sure. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bullshit hang down low when hand crack narrows. Just send it next time. · Lead / Onsight. w/ Cody. This was a long, burley one that took a lot of gear. Glad I pushed through and got it clean - awesome belay ledge up top. #4 and #5 would've been used. · Lead / Onsight. So much better than I was expecting. Beautiful belay ledge at the top. Do this route! · Lead. Such variety. think this would get better with reps as you figure out a flow. would benefit from more traffic, but is worth a go as is. #5 can definitely be placed but isn't necessary. #4 was appreciated. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Cruxy down low- nice to have a 4, 5 up high. Need to rap- bring ATC and down climb from big boulder · Lead / Fell/Hung. LONG, used triple rack 0.4-2, 2x#3, black totem & 0.2/0.3 offset, couple nuts, 4&5 bumped up for wide w/ small gear to right, would have run out otherwise. Took twice getting off ground, crux, rest A FIGHT but clean. 2raps 70m using anchor climber's left. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bring double rack to 4 next time, and a 5 if available · Lead / Onsight. Super good. Crux was the finger crack/layback, but the OW stembox part was very interesting

routes.route_description: Start in the right side of the wall. Pull a couple of 5.9 moves to reach a quick rest at the first bolt. Enter into a short but stout sequence to a knob followed by some good ol' index'ing. Follow the crack and finish up on some easy slab.
routes.route_location: Follow the trail up hill from With Man Gone Will There Be Hope For Gorilla. It is the obvious leaning crack on the bulge at the top of the hill. A top rope can be set from the cricket (5.7 around the corner).
routes.route_protection: 2 bolts and single rack of cams to .5.

route_comments.comment_text: tough moves around the corner and the finger crack after is great. do the cricket and set up the TR! Jul 21, 2018

routes.route_description: The one and only cricket. A fun climb that provides easy access to The Snake and The Shrew. It also provides access to top rope The Claw.(Established as a free solo to access the harder upper pitches. Given the length and easier grade, others may simply "boulder" this entry pitch as well.)
routes.route_location: In the Animal Kingdom on the far right side of Rattle Tale.
routes.route_protection: A few pieces of gear to 2"

route_comments.comment_text: Short little route that gets you up to a ledge that has some fun routes up from it. Really needs a good scrub for the 2017 season. May 22, 2017

cricket got a good cleaning about a week ago. moss and dirt free. Opened up some new/better gear placements. nice little climb for a newer leader. also the access to a few other great climbs above Aug 24, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Not bad climbing but MOSSY and hard to protect bc the cracks are so flaring. I did well but I think it would have been much much easier if it was cleaner and just soloed tbh. Brushed a bunch but there is way more to do. · Follow. Overgrown, including all the routes above it. Buncha thorn bushes at the top that should be removed. Would be easier if it wasn't so dirty for sure · Lead / Onsight. Thoroughly enjoyed this route. Short and not much of a warmup though. · Lead / Onsight. Quite dirty, needs another cleaning. Would recommend cleaning it before taking novice leaders here. · TR. Hornet/wasp/bee nest at base of climb. Crux is trying to not get stung in the butt · TR. funky. note that there are chains on the top and this is definitely not a free solo.

routes.route_description: A technical and odd first pitch (10m, 5.12-) leads to a nice ledge. The second pitch (35m, 5.14a) begins with fun quartzy features to an intermediate anchor below the crux (5.11). Pull the bulge into an extended V10/11 sequence with powerful moves on mostly good holds.When working the crux, it makes sense to leave a fixed rope from the ledge to avoid having to do P1 again.
routes.route_location: Start on a pedestal to the right of The Womb.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Yooo! Mazel tov. Mar 25, 2023

Unfortunately this thing is doomed for obscurity. Lower half P2 will grow over quickly. I sent around a year ago so I'd imagine it's getting pretty green again. P1 is icky. P2 top is rad though. The crux is awesome. Mar 25, 2023
Is this the crack you pass by if you rap from the top p1 of Goddess Kring? Mar 27, 2023

routes.route_fa: Stamati Anagnostou, Ryan Hoover, Michal Rynkiewicz
routes.route_description: "The tree I had in the garden as a child, my beech tree, I used to climb up there and spend hours.I took my homework up there, my books, I went up there if I was sad,and it just felt very good to be up there among the green leaves and the birds and the sky." -J.G.Bring your stem game on this one! Work through the bulge with powerful stemming and crimping- expect the difficulty to vary with height. Take some time to enjoy the beautiful crystals before Jane sics her chimps on you. Truly enjoyable face and feature climbing leads to the anchors.
routes.route_location: Obvious large corner to the right of Rattletale.
routes.route_protection: 8 bolts, chain anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: Fantastic movement Jul 26, 2017
Cool feature to climb with thought-provoking movement. A few awkward bolt placements ... and... 11- eh? Haaa..... Thanks to the FAers though, good fun. May 3, 2019
It's just an awkward feature to climb. I'm not sure the bolts could be in much better locations. May 3, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Crazy stem to undercling, use it once you’re above it, don’t forget the ledge, at the end go up right. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Blew the onsight by grabbing a draw for my 15th Bday pitch. Overall, great route and very approachable at 11-. (Soft) · Lead / Redpoint. With Kat Krohn. 3 goes: lead attempt, top rope beta burn, and send. Crux beta: left hand jug, right hand undercling knob, right foot dark patch, left foot up to rusty knob; move right hand to high undercling two finger pocket, pull in to move right foot up and back into dish, left hand up to rail, left foot up onto blocky stuff, and stem into the right foot higher. · Lead. Turn in R hip on stem. Big hand to slope crimp rail, turned in R foot, L on brown circle. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Left hand out to good hold above roof, right hand on slopey rail, clip, move left foot to brown back, left then right hand up to small edge, shift foot onto big corner. Two more moves- High step right foot to upper ledge

routes.route_name: Kubla Khan and the Fountain of Eternal Stoke
routes.route_fa: Alysse Hotz, MIchal Rynkiewicz, Tuline Kinaci
routes.route_description: 'In Xanadu did Kubla KhanA stately pleasure-dome decree...'-Samuel Taylor ColeridgeThis route got its name from the pure waters that flow at its base from the rainy season until mid-may or so. The waters are filtered through the sacred stone of the diamond area. The stoke will get you warm and fired up for the rest of your Rattletale adventures.Step over the fountain into semi awkward start with a bonus #6 placement for kicks, and lead into an awesome low angle tight #4 crack.Gain the ledge, face-y climbing leads to the crux, finish with stellar jams to the fat double nine links that await you at the top.Squamish sending optional tree beta if desired!
routes.route_location: The route is left of the Wasp and the Amphibian.
routes.route_protection: Single Rack from BD #.1-4Smaller nuts protect the crux nicelyDouble nine link chains on top.

route_comments.comment_text: Wow, looks like a fun climb. Nice job. Jul 19, 2017
Thanks Jon! We're really stoked on trying to get some easier stuff up, for warming up, and so softies like me have stuff to lead! Jul 19, 2017

I'm with you on getting the easier stuff up. They are usually much, much more work to clean off, but way more of us can enjoy them. Am looking forward to seeing more. Thanks for the work- Jul 19, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Fun warmup for rattletale. Lower section was pretty mossy but seemed to clean up around the crux · Lead / Onsight. Max and Haley lead. A little awkward at times but I enjoyed overall. Did not use the tree. Used the #4 BD at the upper section of the wide crack. Then used 2 .2 in a row above the ledge. Felt stiff for a 5.8. · Lead / Fell/Hung. First trad fall on a no. 1 near top “crux”… hung on four or three at bottom offwidthy crack. Should have laybacked that crack. Hated this. Felt really bad. Borrowed another 4 and 3 to finish. · Lead / Onsight. First lead at index ! Very strenuous and mossy , Flake above ledge is very loose and moved when I yarred on it , I don’t know how trundling this block would affect the climb Safe climbing to all · Lead / Onsight. in order, 1,6,3,4,4,dirty mantle, 2,0.1/0.2 Offset,blk tot, 0.2/0.3 Offset, 0.75,1,2 cool climbing, pretty stiff top without the tree, tons of spider webs, mossy slab down low was slick. pretty fun route but funky and the leaning cracks made it tough. the block w X I tested and pulled on it a bit as a layback and it felt solid, wouldn't put gear in it · Lead / Onsight. Glad to have sent this without tree, but perhaps that made it harder. Pretty fun! · Lead / Onsight. Odd route, but it makes you think! Worth your time but definitely harder than a 5.8. you can easily get away with only using gear larger than .5, and youll need atleast 1 #4 for the middle. Also, if the tree is not on, this route would be a lot harder · Lead. swallows gear. used most of a double rack. aided off the tree to set an anchor. bit awkward with the wall there · Lead / Fell/Hung. Mid section was tough for me, but the upper crack was great! My foot slipped off the tree but I was caught by a bomber handjam. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Wow, that was a hard lead. Had to aid up several spots. Definitely having doubles of 0.75-3 was useful! Used a #4 also. Tricky crack technique. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on the top. Didn’t see the good foothold. Used tree

routes.route_description: Splitter highball boulder problem or top rope.
routes.route_location: Right under The Claw
routes.route_protection: Pad or rope for tr

route_comments.comment_text: Nice to have this also listed as a TR. Thanks- For me anyway, a rope from above is better than a pad below because it is usually safer. (Also, easier to carry.) May 5, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Struggled mightily, ended up aiding the first ten feet felt very hard for V2

routes.route_description: Boulder problem off the ground past a bolt to reach the right leaning seam. Place couple tcus and climb good holds to get to first crux. Clip a bolt and climb knobs to good sidepulls out right. Boulder through slopey knobs to second crux. Clip last bolt off huge knob and thumbpress to clip the  chains.
