routes.route_location: To the right of Rattletail on Knob studded wall. The start is off slopers with a bolt.
routes.route_protection: Quickdraws, Tcu's, Small DMM Offsets, Ballnuts.

route_comments.comment_text: Such a badass line. Aug 4, 2016
Best route on the rattle tale wall in my opinion. The boulder problem start is slopey and scary, I ended up stick clipping the first bolt. Jun 1, 2017

**FYI*** An extra bolt was added and ball nuts are no longer required. Stick clipping the first bolt is still a good idea, but a few finger size pieces is all that is required for gear now. Oct 9, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided through to assist on second crux and skipping the final thumbpress, will have to get better for next time! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got smacked by this one! .3/.1, .3, .2. L lock sp, R crimp. RF pivot on knob R hip to wall, piano match crimp? R out? Knob wizardry after, high R gaston after jug? · Lead / Fell/Hung. sent on the tr burn but definitly whipped figuring out the sequences · Lead / Redpoint. felt the exact same difficulty as Message of Love. Both are in the low 5.12 range (in my opinion)

routes.route_fa: Dave Anderson, Cal Folsom, and Phil McCrudden
routes.route_description: This is one of Index's finest hand cracks and well worth the approach hike. Has three short, but athletic, pitches.P1: Start on some broken face cracks trending up and left to a nice right-facing corner. Crux is low in the corner. End at large ledge.P2: Prominent hand crack in a right-leaning, right-facing corner. Crack which starts as perfect hands and finishes as wide hands (or layback).P3: Deep corner slot, also right-facing, with two cracks. You can do a wide stem and jam the thinner, right crack. The crack widens at the top, but you can reach in deep for hand jams. The top is an incut edge, bordering on the forest.Lower from the P3 bolted anchor and have your follower clean the anchor and then lower back to the P2 bolted anchor. A single rap with double 60-m will reach the ground. (Or, walk a short distance up and left to get to the classic Zipper pitch.)
routes.route_location: At Rattletale Wall. All Belay stations are bolted, there is a two bolt anchor with chains on top of P3. Pitches are short and can be linked, one 60m rope is enough for rappelling.
routes.route_protection: A set of nuts and cams, with double or triple hand-size (i.e. #2 and #3 C4 Camalots).

route_comments.comment_text: Just an FYI: the sizes he refers to are for Camelots. Jul 14, 2008
Thanks, good point, I've updated the description. Jul 15, 2008
Someone added belay stations at the top of pitches 1 & 2. Feb 20, 2009

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Led all 3 pitches, fell once and hung once on 2nd pitch, rest clean (w/ Jake) · Follow. Haley led pitch 1. Max led pitch 2. We both led the 3rd pitch. Max flashed pitch 2 this time. He used #2x4, #3x2, and #1x1. I climbed using mostly fists instead of laybacks this time and it killed me. I had a few takes. Would love to practice more. Tape up right wrist next time. 3rd pitch was so fun. We both stemmed until halfway up, then switched to the right crack. Gear .4-3 x2. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. 1st clean second pitch lots of take and bump due to limited gear · Lead / Redpoint. A fine day out with Daniel, stoked to send this thing. 5.10Burly · Lead / Fell/Hung. W/ Esteban. P1: Esteban lead, I followed. Nothing too hard or interesting. P2: I lead. Took a fall half way up. Def hard. Jamming the start felt good but as it got steeper it became difficult. And laybacking it just takes so much energy. Took a big whipper!! Was completely out of breath at the top. P3: Esteban lead first, then I lead. Very fun pitch! Money pitch of the climb for sure. Stem until a nice ledge for feet and start jamming them. Money jug at the top! Overall: great climb to push myself on, pro is bomber, very worthy of its four stars! · Lead / Onsight. Onsighted pitch 1 and took on pitch 3. Followed pitch 2 · Lead. Led P2, followed P1 and P3. P2 felt way harder than the other pitches. Only pieces that fit into P2 that I brought were a Metolius 6, a BD #2, and a WC #3. Ended up hanging a bunch on that pitch and was bumping those cams up HARD until the 2-inch pieces tipped out, then ran it out to the top. Would not recommend, just buy more gear instead. Maybe being one or two WC #2s since the upper crack is too thin at the entrance for a #3 but widens in back. · Lead. Led 2/3 w Jon. Very fun! One stupid take midway P2 bc it was 88° full sun insanely greasy but could send. Shocked by how much I liked the wide hands · Lead / Onsight. Led the first pitch, Sauer led the second and Matt led the third. Jacob followed. · Lead / Onsight. Elliot led the first, I led second, Matt and I both led the third! Jacob climbed the first and hung out on the ledge below the second! · Lead / Redpoint. Led all 3. With Liz. 1 year since failing on p2, felt totally casual this time. · Lead / Onsight. Aaron led p1; we each led p3 P2 was wide for my dainty paws and left me cupping much of the upper section (3’s). Super fun and lovely. Had it to ourselves · Lead. Lead p1 and p3 then got throttled by rain and hail! Jammed thru p2 this time which was hard but fun · Lead / Onsight. Os p1 & 2, Ri did 3, one of my favorite routes of all time! · Lead. 4 #2 (bring WC 2s for the top) and one #3 for p2 crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. Led p 2, hung near the top, whole thing is SO GOOD · Lead / Redpoint. Led pitch 2 for the first time: 2 takes at crux 2/3-3/4 up. Led pitch 3 for the second time: red pointed it. · Lead / Redpoint. Did it all clean! Led 1 & 3. Happy to get back on it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Attempted pitch 2 lead. Jam higher than you think (until a foot hold shows up out right) 3x2, 3x3 and a 4. For last pitch just wide stem to good hand jams · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once on pitch 2 and took a couple times. Hands are too big for jams and too small for fists. And too wide for fists up high, had to layback the entire thing, felt super burly. Pitch 3 was lots of fun · Follow. Fun fun fun. Food for thought solo seems doable maybe check it out first pitch wouldnt be that bad to down solo · Lead. Led pitches 2+3, pitch 2 extremely pumpy but stoked to get the send! · Lead p1, followed 2,3. P2 was too big for me hands—had to lie back and got wrecked · 2 pitches. Lead / Flash. 2x #2, 3x #3, purple metolius. Go back for that last pitch! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Slipped out! It’s hot and sweaty out! Felt good besides that · Lead / Onsight. Super super fun, linked p1&2 then followed p3 off Naomi’s lead. Really fun stuff · Lead / Onsight. Spencer led pitch one, I led pitch two (EPIC SPLITTER), David led pitch three. · Lead. Lead pitch one, followed pitch 2+3. Did have to take on pitch 2 right before roof. · Lead / Fell/Hung. My favorite route evahhhh!!! So good. Needed a take at the crux of p2 and where p3 was wet. Excited to come back and send again and again · Lead / Redpoint. Lead pitch 1 & 3.Ethan lead pitch 2.Austin climbed with us for the lols:) · Lead / Flash. Lead second pitch. So good!! Gear was (2) 2s, 2 1/2, 3 · Lead / Onsight. Led the 5.9, the second pitch was soooo burly and hard for me. The third pitch was wet. Come back for it! Looked so fun! · Lead. Haley lead first pitch. So fun. Max lead the second. He had one fall about 2/3rds of the way up. Definitely could use 3 #2 BD cams for this climb. Max flashed in 2nd go on TR. Haley flashed on TR, but I switched to lay back climbing after crack got too wide for me. Next time just practice true crack technique! We didn’t get to do the 3rd pitch as it was too wet. Next time! · Lead / Onsight. Very classy route. Led all pitches, 3rd was wet. Really enjoyed this one. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Led 2nd pitch. Bailed on 3rd pitch because it was quite wet · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell right as P2 hand crack ended and crack widens just a little. So close! P3 too wet to climb · Lead / Flash. led p2 after a trash!!! so so so so fun— splitter 2s into 2.5s into 3s at the top and STEEP!! My hardest crack lead! · Follow. 1st pitch slimy but fun. Second pitch literally perfect no notes. 3rd pitch slimy stemming VERY fun, tried offwidth/chimney to left and bailed back to stem/jam right · Lead / Redpoint. Crux felt much easier this time around with two functional crack gloves on the crux pitch. Move quickly with your gear planned out and it’ll be fine. Used one red, yellow, and blue C4, one yellow friend. Stay relaxed, breath, keep the bicep relaxed and thumb cammed hard and cruise through the bulge. P3 stem start is the way to do it, even with some partial seepage (rained the previous day/night). Ran it out a bit but it’s secure. P1 had a harder bit that made me feel it’s almost up to the .9 grade. Just not very sustained. Did the OW on the third pitch on TR for a bonus lap. Cheated with a stem a little bit at the start moving through the broken up blocks in the crack, but otherwise sent clean. Felt hard, and was glad to be hitting cardio lately. Expand chest in the bottom to get rests, use rotated body squeeze technique at the top. · 2 pitches. Lead. Pumpy posing for photos for the new guidebook w/ Ben, Q, and Melanie · 2 pitches. TR. First pitch (5.9) was cruiser and fun! Would lead. Second pitch was FUN but I got hauled up it. Struggled with the crack size but after learned to jam my hands deeper and use my forearms. Definitely something to work on and go back for in the future. · Lead / Onsight. Followed 1, lead 2, belayed Freddie on 3 then gave it a lead myself. P2 I used 2 2s then 2 3s, switched to layback just after my first 3. P3 was wet and slimy, stemmed up to just below the first big pod, placed a .75, a 3 and 2 in the pod then a 3 before the top. With a 70 you can lower from the top to the P1 anchors then lower your second from the P2 to P1 anchors then rap P1. · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Led p2. P3 is wet, slimy, rapped down (same as another party) · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Lead 1st pitch clean (easier and less sustained than Senior Citizens) Cruised first half of 2nd pitch on TR with perfect jams then went too fast when it got wider and slipped out. James placed 4 #2s and one #3 on the exit. Worth placing a #1 at the start in order to get first #2 placed higher and it would be perfect. 3rd pitch was wet so we did one rap to bottom. · 2 pitches. Fantastic as always. Skipped p3 due to seeping. We both took turns leading p2, so fun. Placed 2 #2s and 2 #3s on p2. · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. sent pitches 1&2, pitch 3 was soaked so a no go. onsight pitch 1 red point pitch 2 after following. will have to go back for 3 when conditions are better · Lead / Onsight. Led p2 and 3. P3 soaking wet still. P2 softest 10 at index for fat hands · Noah led 1&3. I led 2, hung, rack gear on left side next time · Lead / Fell/Hung. Need 4x #2’s for P2, rack 0.5-4 with double 0.5-2 is prolly perfect plus nuts · 1 pitch. Lead. W/Chad the middle pitch is a lot more mellow then I thought every pitch was good! · 1 pitch. Follow. Only the first pitch, funzies, try more of it next time · Lead / Redpoint. ITS JUST SO GOOD I WANT TO DO THIS EVERYDAY. led all 3 pitches for Alissa but she only did the first. so technically I led all three pitches for myselfffff · Lead / Pinkpoint. Tried to link p1 & p2 - had to hang due to rope drag. Lowered and then did partial pinkpoint of p2. Flashed p3. · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. did pitches 1 and 2 because YES and linked em and oworred with a 76m rope. THAT CRACK IS GOD · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lead P1 and P3. Followed P2. Eats up 2s on P2. Without tape my hands kept slipping and getting cut. Stem P3 · Lead. p2. hung at the last number 2. not enough endurance but that is what you get for being a desk boy. classic climbing, the stuff you dream of. · Lead / Onsight. Hung twice on second pitch. On-sighted one and three. Perfect day. Beautiful climb · 4 pitches. Lead. Followed P1 an P3 clean. Sent P2 on lead. Short but awesome pitches! TR on OW variation on P3 · Lead / Fell/Hung. lead P1 &3 whipped before rest on p3 way good. but hot in the sun · Lead / Onsight. Swap with Garrett, I lead P2. Pitches are short but great!

routes.route_description: Climb either The Cricket Or The Claw to access belay ledge at base of The Shrew. Climb up cool opposing flakes and knobs past bolts to a no hand hands rest on a large ledge. Boulder up the slightly overhung juggy arete to an anchor up on a ledge. This route can be top roped by walking past  The Source and heading up hill.
routes.route_location: Right of The Claw, Above The Cricket, Left of Ze Squid
routes.route_protection: Bolts on The Shrew, Gear to get to the ledge

route_comments.comment_text: This route is pretty hard for a sustained 3 clips, hard enough that I'd argue for a 5.11a grade. We had 4 climbers who all got shut down on toprope. The bolts are super good though and I never felt unsafe on lead. Definitely a cool route! May 22, 2017

I would love to see one more bolt placed on the start of this route. It's a pretty sketchy/start given the location. Also, the bolt could function as a pseudo belay anchor for both starting routes. Unfortunately, as is, the belayer is either protected by the tree or the rap chains from the Cricket, both of which are behind the base of the Shrew. Nov 12, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. bailed off at the start of the arete. that thing is burly. 10ish to the start of that. exciting 5.9 slab too

routes.route_description: Start up knobs and moving left into a mantle past the first bolt. Continue into a thin crack and another mantle to a ledge. Make some catwalk moves out left into a corner. Alternatively, one could finish the crack direct and end at The Shrew/Ze Squid Anchors.
routes.route_location: Access via The Cricket or The Claw, just left of The Shrew. All routes in this area can be top roped via scrambling up and right of the source.
routes.route_protection: Bring doubles to .5 including a handful and some brass offsets! Two new bolts were recently installed.

route_comments.comment_text: Excellent route!  It's challenging, but not too hard, the gear is exciting and small, and the feature that you climb is unique and memorable.  Highly recommended. Aug 31, 2015

Wow, cant say enough about how fun this lead is! Never too difficult, but sustained and tricky climbing the whole way. On thin gear to top it off! I will be repeating this one again often. We did cricket to get to it, and belayed at the chains. This area could use a topo to clarify all the different ways. Oct 5, 2015

I've been calling this zone "the zoo" because you can link up so many different routes together! Example: cricket into the snake (aka the snicket); cricket into ze squid (aka ze cricket); claw into the shrew (aka the clew. Or the shraw. Whatever). Basically 5 short to avenge height climbs all converge at the cricket anchors! Classic index Shena igans Nov 11, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Did the Cricket to get to route. Usually not a fan of adding bolts, but initial gear off the deck did seem super tricky. Rest of route was fun. Consistently small tricky gear. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 0, 00, thee .3, #2 (totem), .4, .5, .,75. offset brassies. maybe small offset cams · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a 30 ft whipper (almost decked) doing the last mantel. Bruised heel. Will be back for the send. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Didn't finish. Bailed at the bolt before the ledge. Felt really hard. With Fang. · TR. Finished straight up the finger crack on the right side of the traverse ledge

routes.route_description: Fun, balancy sport route with 6 bolts.
routes.route_location: to the right of everything.
routes.route_protection: 6draws

routes.route_description: Climb the tree, Squamish style, and work up a seam on an arete to a sting in the tail slab crux. Excellent.
routes.route_location: Around the corner left of The Amphibian
routes.route_protection: Small cams to .5, 2 bolts, chain anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: I only top-roped this route, but wow what a stiff 10c. I think the tree start is a little contrived, and certainly will become harder once that tree's limb breaks off (looks in bad shape). Pro is good after the first bolt as you move into the tricky blank section. Aug 19, 2019
The tree is now gone so you have to climb the overlap. Gear is okay but the beginning moves are a lot more powerful Jul 22, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Whipped at the finish! The balance required to clip the chains is silly. · TR. made it to just before the last bolt. 10b my ass. hard just getting there and moves just got harder · Lead / Onsight. grabbed chains at the end...pretty damn stout for 10- (partial tear of volar plate mid crux)

routes.route_name: With Man Gone Will There Be Hope For Gorilla
routes.route_description: Pitch 1 (C2+) -Clean aid out a prominent, long, left/downward facing arch just right of Arch Enemy and then ascend briefly to a bolted anchor. Expect some excitement with tiny gear right off the ground, followed by some good pieces at the apex of the arch, and then the crux as the crack becomes shallow and flaring.As far as free climbing is concerned, consider this an open project. Be aware that a boulder pad or three is probably better protection than any of the gear you're going to get until the apex of the arch.Pitch 2 (A2) -From the bolted anchor at the top of pitch 1, bat hook right to a series of upward facing flakes, then head up the thin seam from the bolt, many beaks placement but some pods for solid clean gear too, ends at a bolted anchor just before the large treed ledge.This pitch would likely go clean at C3-4.
routes.route_location: Obvious prominent arch just above where the trail to Rattletale Wall splits (left to Rattletale, right to other new routes).
routes.route_protection: Standard clean aid rack for the first pitch, ball nuts and offset cams a must.I strongly suspect that the more ball nuts you have, the easier this climb becomes.For the second pitch, take a small iron rack with an emphasis on beak-type pitons of all sizes, also clean gear to .5 inches.

route_comments.comment_text: Nice route name Jacob, and it looks like a fun, clean route. Aug 3, 2015
you'll want to find a belay slave? :) also, great name Jacob! Aug 25, 2015
I'm assuming you'd be less than stoked on bolts for free climbing.... Nov 19, 2016

routes.route_description: Climb the chimney right of The Amphibian. Stem up and utilize positive face holds. There is only one #4 Camelot and one #1 Camelot in addition to five bolts. Unique warm up and a great way to get a toprope on The Amphibian.
routes.route_location: There is a little fixed line right of amphibian that leada to the belay.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts, # 4,1 Camalot. + 2QD for Anchor

route_comments.comment_text: i can't wait to get on this so i can shamelessly TR amphibian. thanks guys! May 2, 2018
fun climb, awkward chimney interspersed with face climbing. the bolts help alleviate the difficulty of placing gear in a chimney. overall a great addition to the wall. Mar 17, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Lots of moss but completed the route without the use of cams or trad gear. · Lead / Onsight. A lot more fun than it looked from the ground. Would recommend an extra sling to extend the #4 placement · TR. right side in the crack was easier. wow I'm bad at offwidth. don't go in the crack too early · Lead / Flash. Annie started this but got stuck on the squeeze feature, so I finished it clean · Lead / Onsight. Fun! Weird face and chimney climbing the bolts were nice, a single #5 and a #1 plus 4 draws

routes.route_description: The original route starts on the ledge, but a better version starts on "The Cricket" (5.6 twin cracks to the left) and traverses to the ledge. With small gear in the offset crack, climb face features to a 5.9 slab crux. Stand up to clip a bolt, then bust somewhat cryptic moves to a finishing jug at the top of the face. Cross the 5.0R slab, then layback the short splitter .5 crack to a ledge. A final 5.9 move guards the chains. You can also finish the route on the upper half of "The Shrew"(powerful, bouldery layback arete with bolts).
routes.route_location: From the Rattletale route, walk right and uphill 150 yards, following the base of the cliff and a faint climbers trail. The route is around the corner on an eastern facing wall.
routes.route_protection: 2 bolts. single rack, micro cams to .75. Doubles in .5 protects the layback. Chain anchors with rap ring.

route_comments.comment_text: edited due to lack of ascent. Jul 19, 2015
Sorry, but what was edited? Oct 5, 2015

area_description: This 100' high cliff contains high-quality moderate crack climbs, difficult face and crack climbs, and several sport routes.  The rock is excellent and this wall has much fewer people than the Lower Town Wall.  It is surrounded by thick forest and the left side of the wall is shady at the base.
area_getting_there: Park somewhere in town (e.g., next to Dolittle Park), walk to the railroad crossing, then down the railroad tracks (wall-side). Midway through the bend, look on the right for a trail that goes down a little to cross a small wooden bridge. This trail goes to Private Idaho, Rattletale, Lookout Point, Duck Wall, the Diamond, as well as some popular boulders.The trail meanders through deep forest, heading up to a crest. At this crest, the trail left goes to Zelda boulders, but the main trail goes right and remains fairly level until reaching Midnite boulder. Just before this boulder, a trail to Hag goes off right. The main trail passes left of this boulder, then starts ascending through wooded talus. Soon thereafter is a T-junction; the trail to the left goes to Rattletale (and a way to Duck Wall & the Diamond), the trail to the right goes to Private Idaho, Hag Crag, Lookout Point, Duck Wall & the Diamond area. After a few more minutes of ascending overgrown talus, a trail takes off right (just below the 'Brad Driscoll' outcrop). This trail skirts below Private Idaho and provides access to all of the routes.

routes.route_name: 900 Oil-stricken Waterfowl Taken to Ocean Shores
routes.route_description: Steep face climbing, sort of like an easier version of Model Worker.Start to the left of "The prairie fire that wanders" and "Eraserhead", at a slightly elevated region behind an old stump. A few moves on a flake take you to a steep, sustained headwall with bolts. The crux is not a single move, but rather the pumpy sequence to the third bolt. Being flexible can help here. Though originally rated 10c, the route has been known to stop solid 5.11 climbers.A chained anchor lies at the top. One can rap with a single 60-m rope.From the anchor, one can do a short bit of easy climbing to reach the anchor on "Prairie fire" to top-rope the latter. Conversely, one can top-rope "900" from the anchors on "Prairie fire".
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Five bolts. Helpful to bring a hand-to-wide-hands camming unit for the flake above the 4th bolt. Small nuts may be helpful before and after the 5th bolt.

route_comments.comment_text: I cleaned a ton of mud, grass, pine needles and moss off of this line on 3/1/2015, although not squeaky clean, it is very climbable now. Mar 2, 2015
Thanks Kerwin. When clean, it is a fantastic route. Mar 3, 2015
Wow, the bottom half of this climb is truly fantastic!  That crux move is awesome. Jun 1, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. After second bolt, move left foot out, and left hand to side pull · TR. 1 fall at crux, don't get sucked too far left at crux move · TR. hard - dynamic to 2nd bolt, cheat the second half of bolts 2 to 3 · Lead / Redpoint. 1st attempt: got stuck at crux. Then Matt did the crux with beta I didn’t try 2nd attempt: top rope with all moves 3rd: redpoint · Lead / Redpoint. With George, Luke, and Erik. 1 TR lap, 3rd lead go. · Lead / Fell/Hung. I liked having some gear blue totem - .75 for the top · Lead / Onsight. Bringing only draws makes for quite run out! Wonderful day out with Tania · Lead / Fell/Hung. with Matt and Victor. after first bolt, deadpoint left hand hold that's hard to see. second bolt, side pull, gaston, high right foot. · Lead / Redpoint. after first bolt, reach high with left hand and crawl up. after second bolt, rock on to left heel, grab side crimp with left hand and then bump right feet. Used 0.5 and 0.3 · Lead / Fell/Hung. get better left foot and better left side pull. stand up on left foot. right Gaston or crimp · Follow. Lead by committee, the crux is as advertised, minor positioning tweaks helped me get through it · Lead / Onsight. very fun! #1 and some finger sized pieces to supplement draws · Lead / Fell/Hung. first crux big reach with left hand off of smears. second crux high left foot fingers to mantle and left thumb catch overhead · Wow this is such a GREAT route. good movement, fun crux, led with 1 hang. next time!

routes.route_fa: FA E. Gibson, S. Barnett (1970); FFA L. McIlwaine, G. Nelson (1984)
routes.route_description: This nice 5.9 crack climb features some wide cracks then a flared chimney, with good pro the entire way up.
routes.route_location: On the right side of the crag.  It is a left facing corner, with trees growing just to the left of it.  Rappel from the bolts with a single 60.
routes.route_protection: Cams to 5"60 meter rope

route_comments.comment_text: This is a great route with varied climbing.  I didn't use anything bigger than a 3.5" cam.  Definitely save some 0.5-1 sized cams(BD) for the upper section. Nov 7, 2007
How is this route only listed as two and half stars?  This is the route that brings people to the cliff! Apr 19, 2009

This is a great route. It's basically about 40 feet of 5.9 4 inch crack followed by 40 feet of 5.7 flared chimney. To truly be 'well protected' you'll need two of each from 3 - 4 and a 5 for the base of the chimney. A selection down from there, but you don't need anything small. I didn't have all that and it was kind of scary. Next time I will. Sep 29, 2012

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Fell on crux twice but great climb overall. Crux felt like the middle portion where the crack started to flare. Had to trust feet on slab and get feet high to inner side holds to get through. · Lead / Redpoint. Good workout to finish a great day out with perfect weather. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Gotta get better at #4's!! Used 0.2-0.5 + #5, doubles of 0.75-#2 + #4s, and three #3's. · TR. Very fun, it felt like a 5.7 that I did somewhere else in Index? Just very strenuous, but very secure. I’d like to lead this next season (??). · Lead / Onsight. W/ Esteban, Maya, and Sheep. Went into it thinking it was a 5.7 and got a bit surprised when the crack turned into #1 size (thin hands for me). Knowing its a .9 makes a lot more sense. Good climb and satisfying to completely shove yourself into the crack, but not my favorite. · TR. Perfect hands for the massive crack at top. Reminds me of Skywalker but instead of finger jams it’s perfect hands. Remember at the very end look up and you should have jugs on the ‘roof’ right before the anchor. · TR. One hang at the beginning, didnt trust foot jam. Great practice! But also awful · TR. The most fun I’ve ever had on a rope. The off-width portions are sick!!!! Get on this!!! · Lead / Redpoint. Three 3s, two 4s was much better. Still some wide spacing. Another 3 wouldn't hurt. · Lead / Fell/Hung. led from the top of the TR on the left and screwed up the transition at the top. Then TR from the base and it went better. Offwidth section is 5.7 · Lead / Fell/Hung. First index 5.9! Predictably had to take at the wide 3/4 layback. Just climb quick next time! Finally remembered to start the panini press (#5 section) facing out after unsuccessfully thrutching facing in for a while. Placed 1 .2, 3 .75s, 1 #1-2, 3 #3s, 2 #4s, and 1 #5. Fixed #4 is now gone. Didn’t need any finger sizes. · TR. Led from Wild Turkey anchors, TRed below. No more stuck cams and didn't have the wide stuff. · Lead. Wanted three or four 3s and two 4s. Didn't have them, ran it out. Didn't feel great. · TR. Layback the flaky section, could've gastoned + right foot jam, to stay closer to the crack for lead purpose. Entered the chimney too early, body stucked there and couldn't move around. Could've climbed a bit higher until the crack is wider and face holds are available. Chimney climbed (back on one side and feet on the other side) last section. I probably couldn't lead this as the crack is too deep to reach to place pro for me. · Follow. feel like i want at least two 4s to try leading this, two 3s? in addition to the fixed 3 and 4 · TR. Definitely felt battered, last climb of the day, but didn’t slip or fall on TR and felt safe enough to lead next time with fresh arms · Lead / Onsight. Great climb. Has some hands and some wide. Up to 5. Maybe a 6. Could maybe use 2 4s. 0.75 for top. Great climb. With sarah. She said "one of my favorite granite pitches. · TR. Led the last section, but didn't bother to lead the whole thing again. Very fun! Found two big cams stuck firmly in the crack · Follow. One of my favorite granite pitches ever. First part was kind of physical and hard moves, then the offwidth which takes some figuring out. I ended up facing left through the offwidth and that worked. Then a beautiful 2s crack to a slab, sooo fun. Erron led. Would not lead this at this point in time · Lead / Redpoint. Do again. Poor style; bring single rack with double #3s and black totems. 00 and .1 might be handy for the top. · Lead / Onsight. Epic lead. Did it add the sun went down, fought hard at top to not stay pumped. · Lead / Onsight. Major grovel through the second half. Pretty fun! Definitely felt stiff for the grade. Secure but physical · Lead / Onsight. Bruh, climbed it with a single 3, thank god for fixed gear · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bailed but got farther than last time. Still working on foot work in the offhands · TR. don't know if i'd call this fun but it's definitely climbing. fixed 3 and fixed 4. · TR. Max lead clean to SCIS chains. Haley trd. I struggled in the middle where it got wider for me. Next time max needs to lead to the top. I feel like I could lead as gear placement is solid. · TR. Crux was #4 section before the panini press. In the press, nice #2s then narrowing to .75. Right when you’re feeling the squeeze, exit to slab. .2 before the top out, then the top out feels spicy but there are overhead jugs. · Lead / Onsight. Felt 5.9 for normal hands ppl, way harder if you've got smaller proportions · TR. Nice. The "battered" part was not nearly as bad I as I remember it. Just stayed straight in with hand jams all the way till you gotta transition out. The crux for me is before that, when it's kinda wide and laybacky. · Lead. Hung once on offwidth, then found a good patch for my left foot on the edge to start thruching · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hopped on this to clean gear after Jocelyn hurt her ankle. Thought I’d see how it felt compared to the first time, maybe because I was in a rush because it was getting cold/dark, or because I was sloppy, but the crux still kicked my ass! Took me a few times to get my foot situated on a butterfly jam in order to reach the next hold. Top was fun and less hard! · Lead / Onsight. Super great climb. General shoes with sticky rubber were perfect. I only had one 4 and no 5s so I had to take my time and bump up the four a ways. There’s a stuck 3 I clipped too. 4* · Lead / Fell/Hung. Feels more like a 5.9+ because of the off-width section. Great climb though, had to take at knee/hip jam section · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell and injured both heels on the ledge. Need to come back and send this. · Lead / Fell/Hung. I got battered. Would have been nice to have a second #4. Very stuck #3 and #5 were well appreciated. · Lead. Wished I'd brought extra 3's & 4's for the middle. Top chimney takes a rainbow of gear. · Lead / Redpoint. Felt much more confident, smooth, and secure this time around. Uses some knees for squeeze technique but not much. Gear wise, took doubles 0.75-3, singles down to 0.3 and up to 5. Didn’t need the 0.3. Saving some hand sized gear for the top bit would be a good idea. Probably a 2 and 0.75 or a 3 and 1 would do the trick.

routes.route_description: Climb to the fourth bolt of "900 Oil-stricken Waterfowl Taken to Ocean Shores", then follow the seam-to-crack that goes left. The seam part at the start is the crux. The rest is a pumpy hand traverse, followed by a 10a finger crack going up to a belay.
routes.route_location: Just left of the face-to-corner-to-roof routes of "The prairie fire that wanders" and "Imagine your best student here". One has to walk up to an old stump to start the route.
routes.route_protection: After the four bolts of "900", there are three bolts and two fixed pins on the traverse. The rest of the crack takes small finger-tip-sized nuts and cams. To reduce rope drag, use a long sling on the 4th bolt, just before traversing.

routes.route_name: Brad Driscoll Outnumbered His Guests But a Good Time was had by All
routes.route_description: A short, steep face.When it was first put up, Greg Childs reported it (along with a few other routes) as being shorter than its name, and 'by stacking the syllables on top of each other, the first ascentionists found they could bypass the crux entirely'. See excerpt at right. I don't know about that, but given that there were four of us on the first ascent, we might have just stacked ourselves on top of each other to reach the top. I don't recall. Now you can just TR off the bolts at top though.Not much is known about it now, but the 'Brad Driscoll' rock marks the trail turnoff for Private Idaho. It will always be the leftmost route on the cliff.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Leading gear: presently unknown.For TR,  there are two new bolts at the top.

route_comments.comment_text: I did this back in the early 90's and it was fine.  Maybe it was the second ascent!  I learned of it from the same magazine issue highlighted above. I think we slung a tree near the start to protect crux moves onto the bulging face.  Then small gear.  I'm sure it needs a thorough scrub, but it's easy to access the top. Feb 10, 2017
What a great route name. Aug 22, 2022

routes.route_name: Brad Driscoll Outnumbered His Guests But a Good Time was had by All (2)
routes.route_description: The first ascentionists of the original Brad Driscoll route liked the name so much they decided to give the variation to the right the exact same name.
routes.route_location: A few feet right of the original Brad Driscoll.
routes.route_protection: Probably should be toproped.

route_comments.comment_text: Sounds kinda like the route above? even a similar name. Jan 22, 2014
It's a different route, but we thought we'd give it the same name nevertheless. Jan 22, 2014
The iron-clad logic of a future MP Admin! Jan 19, 2020

routes.route_name: Brave the Suppressed Laughter of the Tweeny Maid
routes.route_description: Face climbing with a short corner finish.After doing the crux of Beckey-Stanley, go straight up over the roof/overlap. Then follow the crack-corner to a large ledge. See Beckey-Stanley for suggestions on the start.
routes.route_location: Start is the same as for 900 and Beckey-Stanley.
routes.route_protection: Can be done purely as a sport route, but one can place a medium-sized nut in the crack above the roof/overlap. 8 bolts to get to the crack above the roof, then two fixed pins in the upper corner.

routes.route_description: Istanbul has been cleaned up and the extension awaits your passage.  Climb between Istanbul and Wild Turkey and avoid the left crack until past the "X" marked block.  Then enjoy the wide cracks and hand stacks while thinking poorly of your partners who will get to simply Lie-Back the moves.  When you arrive at the Istanbul anchor, leave your trad gear behind and enjoy the lightness of being that is Sport Climbing.  Pull around the roof and move like a gecko up the arete and slab.  Baseball sized knobs await near the top.
routes.route_location: Private Idaho, Far Right side.  Look for the line-ups onSenior Citizens in SpaceandBattered Sandwich, stop just before them, skip the queue and start up Istanbul.  Conversely, one could got to the Bosporus Straits and go back in time to pre-1930.
routes.route_protection: Cams up to #5 through Istanbul, QD's through Constantinople

route_comments.comment_text: Istanbul has been the neglected route in the climbing squeeze-sector that orbits Battered Sandwich. Constantinople adds a full star quality rank to the line.  The roof move is delightfully awkward and places you on a ledge that is as airy and exposed as the previous portion of the climb is confined.  The next moves look impossible but are really just improbable.  The arete and face are so... more Istanbul has been the neglected route in the climbing squeeze-sector that orbits Battered Sandwich. Constantinople adds a full star quality rank to the line.  The roof move is delightfully awkward and places you on a ledge that is as airy and exposed as the previous portion of the climb is confined.  The next moves look impossible but are really just improbable.  The arete and face are so sticky you'll deny you can climb what you are ascending. The bolts are generous enough to keep you off the ledge and a big flat stance awaits at the anchor. youtube.com/watch?v=BuRizAN… Jun 15, 2019
...And it's a good song too. youtube.com/watch?v=95mSdbG… Jun 15, 2019
What could be better than knobs and an arête? Here we have a more moderate alternative for Spineless, plus some crack. Thanks Douglas and Jonathan for putting this up. Jun 16, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Max lead to 2nd to last bolt. I finished it off. Really fun and well protected. You just have to trust the gritty slab. Max placed 1 piece of gear before stepping up on ledge. · Lead / Onsight. Still not a fan of pulling insecure friction moves right off a ledge. Maybe don’t try this under direct sun · Lead. Made it to the top sport lead not clean but got up it. Body Pinch the arrete · Lead / Onsight. Followed my friends lead on Istanbul. But then continued on to lead the Constantinople extension. · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. W saz. Truly amazing friction! Tr after to move rope to MF

routes.route_fa: Cal Folsom, Dave Anderson, Don Brooks, 1984
routes.route_description: This is already described as a variation of Magic Fern, but it seems to me worthy of it's own designation as a route. And there is confusion about which goes where. Jon's overview map found on this area heading is helpful here. The Clint Cummins book gives it a 11a, SVR gives it the 10d. The start was 5.8 in both books, which seems right once you make it to the first finger lock. The left side crack on the fin above is the thin tips crux. It is short and protects with small nuts and cams. The 2nd pitch is the chimney on the right above the big ledge to flaring hands ( originally considered 5.9) which I would agree with others posting on Magic Fern, that it is 10a.
routes.route_location: right of Wet Dream.
routes.route_protection: standard rack. If doing as one long pitch you may want doubles. offset brass nuts and tiny cams for crux.SS rap ring anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: The hardest move may be the very first move off the ground. Also, above the tips crack section, you can go up the left side or the right side of the next big fin-chockstone. The left side is more natural, and less of a grunt then the right side. Sep 14, 2014

the right hand exit (chimney sort of thing) wasn't bad, probably easy 9'ish if you are used to that sort of thing, but there are several not so great blocks above it, followed by ugly muddy bushwhacking or R/X rated face/arete climbing. this climbing is terrific, but harder than any of the other parts of the route. overall, this route is infinitely easier than spineless, not too far to the... more the right hand exit (chimney sort of thing) wasn't bad, probably easy 9'ish if you are used to that sort of thing, but there are several not so great blocks above it, followed by ugly muddy bushwhacking or R/X rated face/arete climbing. this climbing is terrific, but harder than any of the other parts of the route. overall, this route is infinitely easier than spineless, not too far to the right. Jun 29, 2016

The right side climbs well Slim!? I think that's a height/reach/hand size dependent thing. Granted I've only been sport climbing lately, but that transition out of the alcove kicked my ass. I've got a pretty solid Trex index going and couldn't quite reach up to good jams from incuts and couldn't establish stemming well from the holds within the alcove to get out. If you have a longer reach... more The right side climbs well Slim!? I think that's a height/reach/hand size dependent thing. Granted I've only been sport climbing lately, but that transition out of the alcove kicked my ass. I've got a pretty solid Trex index going and couldn't quite reach up to good jams from incuts and couldn't establish stemming well from the holds within the alcove to get out. If you have a longer reach and/or tight #1 is your jam it's probably relatively tame for the grade, but for me it's a Vawkward. Corner seam climbs easier than it looks at first. I cut right of the tree at the top to avoid the runout arete, it was an easy walk up and not muddy. Agree that spineless is still harder. Jun 26, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. TR was very fun. Smooth and no falls. Could try lead. Perhaps R on fin. Small gear is intimidating but not too far from hero jug to finish. Also Back on left wall, feet on right · TR. Alex led. Great movement. Getting into the lower slab corner is the trick, then it goes. In the upper crack corner stay in as long as you can (right arm in) before getting into the chimney moves with your back against the left wall · TR. Was able to pull the thin crack first go, but at the alcove chimney hung a couple times · Lead / Fell/Hung. Doubles 2 and 3. Save a .4 for the end. Need to figure out foot beta for pulling the last roof. .2,.1 protect the very start. Toon off helmet on the ledge for the last roof move · 1 pitch. TR. One pitch. Hard move off the deck! Finger lock it. Undercling to pull out of the cave. · 1 pitch. TR. Right hand side (Magic Fern?) followed by right hand side exit. Exiting the cave to lieback was the hardest thing I did all day, felt harder than spineless... probably due to my leg length · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Move to come out of alcove to layback is pee’ hard · TR. It was getting pretty hot so didn’t lead. Thin crack crux is mainly just spooky/scary not that hard · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got that ass beat. Had to aid the last crux. Many falls. · TR. Perhaps could lead. Thin section would be intimidating! Shimmy sideways to get into final handcrack · Just great rock climbing too bad there are big ledges would be better is fully sustained · Lead / Fell/Hung. 30+ foot whip from the finger section to the second horizontal of the zig zag below my first piece. Bad belayer. Second fall from the chimney getting to the hand jam. · TR. Corner climbs pretty reasonably, but getting into thin hands out of chimney is fucking hard · 1 pitch. Dope climb. My friend puked up his index general store burrito at the crux

routes.route_description: A bouldery start leads to knob climbing and smearing.  There is an anchor at about 35'.  The route continues up to a second anchor at 70'.
routes.route_location: 50' left of Magic Fern.
routes.route_protection: Bolts.  A hand sized piece if climbing to the top anchors.

route_comments.comment_text: Probably best to do this in mid-summer. From 2010 through 2011, the seam midway up seeped almost all year (except mid-summer). This has been an abnormally wet period (perhaps due to La Nina), so it might be better in other years; however, the section does seem to be the last thing on the wall to dry out. Oct 10, 2011
Freakin sweet ride, with brand new hardware courtesy of ASCA. May 16, 2019
Top section has been rebolted and cleaned as well so you ride this bad mambajama to the top now! Jul 16, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Crazy hard and technical. Worked the route and got the first 3 cruxes figured out. The fourth one though stumped me completely. Guide books not joking about top 10 sandbag. Feels like a 11d or 12a. · TR. still hard AF. watched Anthony climb it to get some beta. At 2nd bolt, LH on sloper rail, right hand on knob as side gaston. move LF onto knob below and move right feet to knob far out right. aim for right hand undercling. Then aim for next good knob via dynamic move for palming with RH and LH to slowly bump LF and RF up to knob. from the knob, stem out, RF on slopers down right. key is to move left feet higher on rail. via RF bumps. Then LH on credit card crimp, then dynamic move to ledge on right. · TR. Ticking for memory. Aided up the bolt ladder with a stick clip "holy fuck people can climb this." · TR. Tried to lead, pulled on bolts to the top then tried to TR. Still couldn't do all the moves! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Woah! Made all the moves to the chains. Try it again. Trim fingernails · 3 pitches. TR. saw this line and immediately got inspired. cole begrudgingly belayed me on “a sport line.” i aided up with a stick clip to setup a top rope. gave two burns and did every move by the end. phenomenal climbing. fucked up levels of improbable friction. current project. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Heelhooked the start to get the pocket statically, my foot just slipped off if I tried to go dynamically from the undercling. Foot swap on knob to undercling at 2nd bolt. Levitate up, going to 4th is crux for me. Shitty crimp, shitty sloper Gaston, foot on knob, gotta work left foot higher up the rail · TR. multiple laps. basically to the point of doing all moves clean except the start. hard · TR. Super technical but fun, would need a lot of time to remember all the sequences. Rail was wet. · TR. Stick clipped 1st bolt. To first anchors - section after first anchors looked dirty and not recently climbed. Hard! · TR. love to try it on a cold/dry day, couldn't get my left foot to stick along the sloping rail · TR. Low percentage friction. Not for hot days. High left foot eases the start. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got thrashed going to the first anchor. Really cool movement, tried again on top rope and felt much better. Gotta go back for the send. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Went to first anchor. Rad friction climbing. Crux was in the sun so... · Lead / Fell/Hung. Used fallen branch and hairties to literally stick clip 1st bolt, then got shut down at 2nd bolt. :/

routes.route_name: I Am In Top a Shader
routes.route_description: A bouldery face move off the ground leads to a bolt. Traverse left on a large edge and go up to a mantle with a bolt (can be done by stepping in from the left). The face crux involves climbing from the ledge to the start of the crack.The crack crux is at the bottom. Soon thereafter, a sequence of two hand pods is reached, providing some rest. But the crack remains interesting and pumpy to the top.
routes.route_location: This is the first route to the left of "900 Oil-stricken Waterfowl Taken to Ocean Shores". It ascends the obvious thin crack on the headwall.It is very easy to set up a top-rope on this route. You can walk onto the top belay ledge from the trail above the cliff. Look for the hand-rail chain - it is in the area below "Peanuts to serve you" at Lookout Point.
routes.route_protection: Four bolts and a fixed pin where the route joins "Beckey-Stanley" near the top. The crack takes small nuts and cams.

route_comments.comment_text: This route has everything.  Some technical face moves to start, an 'indexy', balancy mantel and slabby section, a powerful, pockety crux, then fun finger locks for 30ft.  Do it!  You can pull on the bolts through the slabby section if needed.  Everything is well protected. Mar 5, 2015
A bit height dependent, or at least favoring those with positive ape indexes. Chris is right, you can pull on draws through slab moves, I did ;) Great route. Sep 12, 2016
Love this climb, it's so fun and really tricky.  Really had to work out hyper specific beta. We gave this a pretty good scrubbing in early September '18 hopefully stays clean for a bit Sep 30, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. TR’d Either someone accidentally packed up my shoes or they were consumed by the moss and detritus of Index. · TR. Sheesh. The crack is chefs kiss, not sure about the low crux though. · TR. I made the first move after a half dozen tries and then fell off and gave up but still felt accomplished · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. 5 goes. Forgot my shoes and had to run back and get them got it on second go of the day with Jonathan we both sent back to back send train and music from the art festival! Awesome! · Lead / Redpoint. Bday send with Jack and Brandon! So psyched. Fav index climb so far · Lead / Fell/Hung. Use middle crimp at first crux, middle finger an ring finger at second crux. 2 .3 2 .4s 1 black totem · Lead / Redpoint. Had a bear of a day, perfect way to finish it off. First go today, third session. · 3 pitches. TR. 3 burns, figured out lower slab crux plus finger crack, but definetly not the dyno traverse. Wish the finger crack could just be by itself. So fun. · 3 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Ayyy three full lead burns and it goes down (with Melissa) · Lead / Redpoint. Psyched! Super cool route. First go this day grabbed the draw doing the slab dyno but cruised to top. Send it 3rd or 4th go · 3 pitches. TR. Worked this out on TR solo. First two tries the mantle and dyno felt really impossible, but right foot flat with heel down made the mantle go. 3rd go did it clean didn’t feel too bad. Really sick route! · TR. Not my best attempt. Was dirty and still a bit wet from the recent rain. · TR. got that pistol squat!!! slab dyno still feels impossible, but slightly closer with a left foot rotation adjustment. For starting big crack move, get a VERY high left foot first · 4 pitches. TR. TR solo. Managed to link from the bottom to the top! Just gotta lead it now. · 3 pitches. TR. TR soloed this today. Was able to work all the moves! Very cool! It felt impossible the first time, but I slowly figured out each section. Crazy side · 4 pitches. TR. Multiple laps tr solo. Clean to the 2nd bolt, and clean above the 4th, but between 2 and 4 is completely fucked · TR. Fell off the crimps on the pistol squat crux and on the traverse. Would lead. Hurt shoulder · Lead / Fell/Hung. Chuffed at the pistol squat but sent the rest. Rotate the left heel in, lh out rh up, lean over further than you think, stand up. Probably butt in too. 1 .1, 1 .2, 3 .3, 1-2 .4, 2 .5, 1 .75, 1 1. 2x .2-.5, 1x .1, .75-1 probably goes too. · Lead / Flash. First lead go. Seshed on tr solo to dial moves. Very very fun route. Some of the best movement I’ve done. Favorite climb in WA. · 2 pitches. TR. squat and pockets feel unlikely, rest is doable. good gear good rests. use aggro shoes next time for pocket crux feet. · TR. Hard! Onsighted the low boulder (dyno), couldn’t do the mantle, traverse slab dyno move, or the crack start · Fell a lot working out the slab boulder. Linked from finger crack to top. · TR. with Matt and Victor. really difficult slab. Finger cracks are awesome. pretty hard. need more strength. · TR. TR solo. I fell crossing the slab and a few times at the beginning of the crack. What an excellent climb! · Lead / Redpoint. w/ letty, v proud of this one, slab dino for small bois, v classic · Lead / Fell/Hung. This thing is a hard 11c, but supper safe. There is one 11+ crack move but most of the business is on the face. · TR. Start: side pull out left, get feet up on both littl knobs, pushed my right hand in the razor blade to numb foot up there, then I can get the good hold. Second crux there’s a right undercling, pistol squat hard on right foot Slab dyno, go duckfooted with left foot as far right as possible. Fall into hold, it’s good, don’t fall off on smears. Crack crux, crack right hand pocket, grab next as a side pull/ Gaston, left knobby foot, then good right hand in the same little pod, then you can get jams. Crack is easy from there. · TR. awesome awesome route. steep crack was super fun. hard start. couldn't figure out all of the moves at the face crux traverse before the crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. W Martin. The final exam of “index 11c” - pistol squats, body scums, splitter finger cracks, this thing has it all. Amazing, and hard! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Quadruple .3 and .4 means you never need to worry about gear but is excessive. .2 or .5 protects top out. Green c3 after traverse is nice for the last slab move (can back clean after clipping bolt). A locker draw would be really nice for the second bolt. · TR. Got all the moves, but not sure they will go together without more work. Second crux come in from left. Traverse crux is a dynamic grab and prey move. Start of finger crack is powerful, but quickly drops in difficulty. Beautiful route · Lead / Redpoint. WoooOO with Jess and Maple first go today. —tried it once Friday two hang · Lead / Flash. Flashed! Thanks to a helpful spray down from the index family · with Mateo and Leon. TR, then 2 leads. At best, I hung 3 times I think. Psyched for rematch. · TR. Worked some of the moves. Got the start, couldn’t do the mantle or dead point or finger pocket pull. Crack above was super fun finger locks though · Lead / Redpoint. TRed for first time (once) last weekend. Lead once Thursday and fell. Lead and sent today. · TR. Really good climbing, be fun to work on it a bit in cooler temps · TR. Gotta practice my pistol squats now. Couldn’t figure out the slab lean over after. Alana said “just fall” · TR. Really cool. Two cruxes for me: first was the mantle below the second bolt. Second was after the last bolt in the crack… right hand in the weird pod, some foot beta to work out, then bust to the bad left hand jam/side pull. Lightens up but still challenging fingers crack · TR. sent on TR again, got the crack entry move clean again. pistol squat was a bit shaky this time. · Lead / Redpoint. 5.10 if your under 5’7? One of the best routes I’ve ever done. Yosemite blows · Lead / Redpoint. After Adam’s send! Possibly the best pitch I’ve done in Index. 2nd go · Lead / Fell/Hung. July 2021 - Gave this an honest ground up attempt and got shut down pretty hard, pulled on all the crux draws · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got the moves - fell at crux mantel, dyno, and pocket dead point · Lead / Redpoint. 3rd go. I’m 5’9” and don’t dyno. That move isn’t reachy for me, I just have to be in the right position to trust fall to it. · TR. Unique sequence of challenges. Three climbs combined into one epic. Oddly, my crux was the balance mantle to enter the slab dyno. · TR. hard throughout w/ numerous hangs. mantling onto the rail seemed impossible. sideways dyno low % · Lead / Redpoint. finally sent it! got the boulder moves into the crack. high right foot along rail is key · Lead / Fell/Hung. follow the six steps. use pinks, not tc pros. keep core tension. · Lead / Fell/Hung. crux: rt hd pocket, rt ft goes up high. lt ft goes up small nub. rt ft smears or goes into right hole. Lt ft goes out and up to small insecure dish, weight lt ft. rt ft moves up along mini arete, left hd up into hole. rt ft up to arete, rt hd in jam · 2 pitches. TR. Amazing route! A couple attempts. Did both the crux moves after a few tries on each. TRonsighted finger crack section! · TR. fell at the traverse and finger pocket. need a few more TRs to get this · 3 pitches. TR. Tr solo. I could barely get up it with gravity assist XD. Lives up to the sandbag · TR. It'd be amazing to redpoint or even cleanly TR this climb. I fell and hung a few times. · Lead / Redpoint. top roped this a couple times and then sent, awesome route! classic index slab trickery, reminded me of model worker, to an awesome finger crack · Lead / Redpoint. awesome route! slab move is wild and the finger crack stay on you til the end · Lead / Redpoint. Amazing! For draws and a optional .5 get you to the crack. Gear for crack is straight forward · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. 2nd go blew a foot and ripped out of the top of the finger crack. Ouch.

routes.route_name: I Can See Your House From Here
routes.route_description: Stay on the blunt arete just left of Senior Citizens. Though difficult throughout, the crux is probably around the last bolt, getting to the huge knob at the top.Also, there is not much consensus yet on the grade. The listed "12+" is based on the first leader's opinion, though it might be considerably harder than that.
routes.route_location: Between Senior Citizens and Battered Sandwich.
routes.route_protection: All bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Thought this was called space man spliff. So its open project? Jul 29, 2013

You should go do it Michal. You might want to check out the bolts first. It has been awhile since people have worked on it, I think. I never heard the spaceman name. The one given here is the one Greg gave it originally. Jul 30, 2013

I was able to redpoint this route in 1998 on a cooler, very dry day. I just assumed it had been redpointed as there was no red-tag hanging on the first bolt. This route took me 20 tries over the course of three years to dial in the moves and line up on a day with favorable atmospheric conditions. There was a lack of info for the Index area back then so. This route is very thin and slippery in... more I was able to redpoint this route in 1998 on a cooler, very dry day. I just assumed it had been redpointed as there was no red-tag hanging on the first bolt. This route took me 20 tries over the course of three years to dial in the moves and line up on a day with favorable atmospheric conditions. There was a lack of info for the Index area back then so. This route is very thin and slippery in the most dry conditions. A friend of mine broke one of the thin edges on the crux sequence making the moves less secure and one of the bolts more difficult to clip. I thought at the time the route was mid 5.12... Sep 8, 2013

routes.route_name: I Hear it is Warm in Space this Time of Year
routes.route_description: Simple. Just stem the Seniors dihedral without touching any cracks.Each move is surprisingly easy, the hardest might be only 5.8ish, near the midway apex, but your calves will burn. Consider it great training for El Matador (Devil's Tower classic).Being so close to Spineless, please refrain from doing this route if someone is on that route.
routes.route_location: Between "I can see your house from here" and "Spineless". You are right on top of "Seniors".
routes.route_protection: TR from either the Senior's anchor or the Spineless anchor. If you really want the El Matador stemming practice experience, lead it by plugging gear in the crack.

route_comments.comment_text: This is about as good as an eliminate can be! Stellar stemming the entire way, this is a great way to spice up an already classic line. Aug 16, 2022
So much fun. Sep 1, 2022
So we’re giving gamified variations their own route entries now? Silly. Next it will be “climb Godzilla without using your hands, 5.14c”. Geez. Jun 23, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Several falls. Couldn't do the steep bit at where the crack turns. Used a couple of crack footholds for feet only.

routes.route_description: Climb up a flaring corner to a roof.  Pull the roof on the right and follow knobs to the chains.
routes.route_location: 75' to the left of Magic Fern.  The corner starts behind a tree.
routes.route_protection: A couple of small cams for the lower section.  4 bolts to a chain anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: It's rather hard and sustained for an 11a. Going out the left side of the roof ("The prairie fire that wanders") is a little easier. To toprope it, go up 900 Oil-stricken Waterfowl, then scramble up and left to the upper chained anchor. Or, do prairie fire. Sep 22, 2011
Mussy hooks installed. Not sure how often this gets climbed but it looks quite clean Oct 14, 2020

routes.route_description: Steep, wide crack on left side of the corner left of Battered Sandwich.
routes.route_location: Just left of Wild Turkey, on the steep left wall.
routes.route_protection: Cams, from hand to fist.

route_comments.comment_text: Does this route include the crack with the Tree growing out of it? climb around said tree? we were up there yesterday curious about this line and the other very vegetative crack in between the tree and battered sand... Sep 11, 2015

Someone cleaned this really good.  Fun addition to a great little crag.  This can be TRd from the battered sandwich anchor.  Getting to the battered sandwich anchors while in lead was a bit sketchy.  Now that it's clean it needs its own anchor. May 9, 2016

I top roped this line last year and that snag looks like a log that dropped into the crack from above, you can move it around easily, and removing it entirely might not be all that difficult, some spotters down below would be mandatory though. May 18, 2016

routes.route_description: A bouldery start leads to a right-traversing finger crack with good knobs for the feet.  Continue up the wide left leaning pillar.  From the top of the pillar, continue straight up (5.10) or out left (5.9).
routes.route_location: Approximatley 50' left of Battered Sandwich.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3" with an optional 4" piece. Slung block at the top of the pillar with rap rings for anchor or continue to the top and rap off a a bolted anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: We excavated this route on 3/22/08.  We climbed it on 4/11 and there is now a lot of loose dirt that needs to wash out of the cracks or it may need additional cleaning. Apr 15, 2008

The route actually continues to the top of the cliff.  Although benign looking SVR lists this section as 5.9.  I found it to be harder than any of the 10a's on the ltw.  The crux was moving out of a short chimney into a tight hand crack with bad feet. Its still possible to rappel with a 60m rope from the top of Istanbul.  This is a bolt and sling anchor that did not have rap rings on the... more The route actually continues to the top of the cliff.  Although benign looking SVR lists this section as 5.9.  I found it to be harder than any of the 10a's on the ltw.  The crux was moving out of a short chimney into a tight hand crack with bad feet. Its still possible to rappel with a 60m rope from the top of Istanbul.  This is a bolt and sling anchor that did not have rap rings on the slings. Apr 19, 2009

From the alcove with the sling rap station you can continue straight up (as described above), or move left then up. I found both options challenging for the grade. Going left is similar to Battered Sandwich, only more difficult. Going straight up is as difficult as it looks. Both options protect very well, and can be climbed from the ground to the top in a single pitch. Grades vary in the... more From the alcove with the sling rap station you can continue straight up (as described above), or move left then up. I found both options challenging for the grade. Going left is similar to Battered Sandwich, only more difficult. Going straight up is as difficult as it looks. Both options protect very well, and can be climbed from the ground to the top in a single pitch. Grades vary in the guides, but I'd say straight up is 5.10, to the left .9+ This topo ( rcnw.net/forums/index.php?s… ) calls the straight up option part of Curious Poses, 5.10. Either way, very nice route & you'll reach a bolted anchor at the top with steel rap rings. A 60m gets you to the ground in one rap. Oct 18, 2010

Meanwhile at senior citizens someone’s triple rack is slowly flopping like an amoeba in a tide pool down the side of private Idaho and nine crag dogs are running infinity symbols into the dirt. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell off the right stem box at the top probably mid 10 · Lead / Fell/Hung. Take on a right finish. Bomber 0.5 at the roof. Layback with thin hands. Suck it up and reach the good hand 1.5 m higher. · TR. really hard start for a 10a, couldn't quite reach the fingers so I used the left rail and ended up with feet in the finger crack which would not work on lead. then it sounds like you are supposed to move right into the upper face at the top, which is harder than 10a (I gave up) and has no pro · Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided through the first moves and then the 10a section at the top. Clean otherwise. Ended at a very dirty gulley. Placed a lot (3-4ea) of .75 - 3, plus some smaller pieces and a #4. Led the pillar section much more cleanly: foot up and then R hand jam above the loose block and then stand up. · TR. Clean until I tried to go up the slab instead of the dirty gulley. No idea how that slab is 10a! Probably had some rope boost at the bottom too. · Lead / Redpoint. Took 4-5 tries to get the first move into the finger crack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided off a .2 for the beginning moves / boulder problem. Then hung in the number 3 crack. The hollow blocks are spooky but there’s a good #1 placement above the obvious hollow circle ack at the beginning of the #3 crack. I bailed a few pieces above this. Scott finished the lead by going straight up the curious poses crack. He thinks the combination is 10b/c. · TR. After Scott finished my lead. Very hard. Still aided moves off ground and then aided the crack straight up. The big column in the middle makes for an awkward #3/2 crack but it works to have r foot in and find features on the left for the left foot, and occasionally bring l foot also into the crack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on a red metolius towards the top trying to exit the shallow chimney to the thin hands/finger crack. Really hard climb for the grade I think. Start felt WAY harder than 10a, as did the top. · TR. Took the right variation so a lot of odd width and thought it was TOUGH · Lead / Flash. Did the direct finish with the chimney. A couple of hard moves pulling out of the chimney · 4 pitches. Lead / Onsight. W Ceeg; Ran laps after I put the rope up · Lead / Onsight. Absolutely hosed myself with rope drag. Couldn't even be lowered and had to rap. I did onsight it, though! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Gah! Sooooo close to a clean lead. Just one tiny mistake on 3rd crux where I shifted my foot and popped off. Really really close and am bummed about the fall but I’ll remember beta better for next time! Compared to last weekend I styled the 1st and 2nd crux and felt that bumping #3 on upper half of second crux made it easy. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung a couple times at 3rd crux. Figured out technique though and think I could get it clean. Need to remember to extend draws on top half of second crux and then also use draws on 3rd crux to keep rope out of crack and reduce drag. Knobs, slab, and arete are your friend on 3rd crux. TR’d it clean on second go. · Lead / Onsight. Went up the right side of the pillar, then straight up from the ledge. With Leon and Peter · TR. Didn’t finish because the potential fall was rough, need to either lead or have another piece in · Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux is .75 hands as flare rounds. Just power through, it’s short. · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell transitioning in the upper corner, it will go next time. also the upper anchor situation is less than ideal. · Follow. hard crux first move finger lock with bad feet. tough middle section with flaring crack · Lead / Flash. With Ryder and Robin. Funny/scary death block and good crack climbing. Hardest move at start · TR. with Andrea. difficult to protect start and arete finish seemed hecto. fun flaring hand crack in middle · Lead / Flash. Climbed with Danny Matt park and Alana was super fun top part was pretty spicy · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got a absolutely thrashed on this bad boy. The bottom was cruiser but pulling off the cave ledge into the flaring hands of curious poses was super desperate. Whipped on a #2 just below the jug. Fuck. · 2 pitches. Lead. linked with top pitch of curios poses for super fun 10 splitter. Tricky getting into crack off ledge · Follow. Had to cheat a bunch but made it to top. Lots of hand jams and first time at it, hard af and hands bleeding. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lead to top of pillar, attempted left finish but ran out of gear and lowered. Aidan cleaned on the way up and aided through. So hot out, still pretty embarrassing · TR. TRS hard start, fell/hung on first move, didn't really figure it out. Sent rest of climb. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to aid some parts because it was wet, hard for the grade. · TR. Felt so hard... will be good to be back to get it some day · Lead / Redpoint. Did right 5.10 chimney variation, climbed it in terrible style, Z clipped but still sent! Stoked

routes.route_description: Climb up to a thin crack (~5.9). The lower (splitter part) of the crack can be entered from the left side, either at the very bottom or in the middle. Even the easier way from the middle is probably 11a. The splitter part turns into a groove that is much easier, taking one up to a small roof.  At the roof, where the crack arcs left, climb straight up onto the slab past three bolts (crux). The apparent runout at the top is on much easier slab (~5.7).
routes.route_location: On a small buttress just up and right of Spineless.
routes.route_protection: Thin gear at the bottom. For the top slab, three new 1/2" bolts.Also, a new bolted anchor at the top.For TRing, it may be easier to use the chain on the tree.

route_comments.comment_text: Somewhere I have a picture of a bolt sprouting out of a sea of moss. Jun 15, 2016
Geoff--that was probably not this route, though it was in need for major recleaning. This route is sparkling clean now. Get on it and have a blast. Jul 13, 2021

This thing is one of the coolest slab sequences I've done! Absolutely desperate, but it goes if you trust your rubber. Finger crack is sequency and thin, easy on TR and difficult once the gear is in play (classic). Mar 17, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell getting on the slab, so sick! Lots of small gear · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the finger crack, got the slab clean after that though. R hand undercling under roof, L on arete, R foot horizontal crack to get into position. Switch right hand to undercling crimp the horizontal R of foot. Rock over R foot and TRUST IT! while flag bumping L under roof until able to stand all the way up and lean out to the arete. Us magic to levitate up the rest of it · TR. Hurt shoulder so TR. Pretty delicate slab crux. Crack is no gimme either though · Lead / Fell/Hung. High gravity on this one… insecure around crack to spooky slab runout · 2 pitches. TR. TR solo, couldn't get the crux move onto the slab, or the slab moves... · TR. Couple falls at cruxes, but had a blast. Would be fun to get dialed in. · TR. Slab crux is pretty hard. Could make the move onto the slab but couldn’t figure out how to get past that. Kind of used the arete and some small divots and crystals

routes.route_fa: (Top-rope) Darryl Cramer & Jeff Walker  (Lead, longer version) Jon Nelson 2011
routes.route_description: Go up the shallow corner just right of "900 Oil-stricken Waterfowl Taken to Ocean Shores" to the roof. This part of the route is the same as "Imagine your best student here".Clip bolt over the left side of the roof, then layback the edge on the left side (~10c/d). At the top of the layback is a small bulge. Going over this bulge may be the crux for many (~10d). Continue up face & crack features to a nice finger crack, which ends at a large ledge.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Has 3 bolts. Bring one hand-fist-sized cam for the initial corner, several large brass nuts for the crux at the bulge (can also place a hand-size cam in the flake below the bulge), and small cams and stoppers for the upper section.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Fun top rope with some interesting finger cracks on smeary feet at the top

routes.route_description: Senior Citizens in Space is the obvious right facing corner.  The climbing is consistent with no obvious crux move.  Layback up the corner split by a couple of cracks on the left side.  The angle lessens as you get higher.  One of the best moderates at Index.Belay at the 2 bolt anchor at top.
routes.route_location: Start 20' to the right of Battered Sandwich.Descent:Rappel from the 2 bolt anchor.
routes.route_protection: Heavy on finger sized cams.  Gear to 2". Save a few small pieces for the top.

route_comments.comment_text: We cleaned the route on 3/22/08.  It was still a little wet on 4/11/08. Apr 15, 2008

This is a really good route!  It's the best 5.8 I've climbed and the best 5.8 at Index.  For me the crux was where it steepens near the top, because there was a lot of debris in the crack and that made it a little hard to get jams. Jun 15, 2009
the crux for me was definitely getting into the corner system. after that the climb is a cruise. one of the best leads i've done anywhere! Jun 26, 2010

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Clean send on TR, last half felt like an easy cruise up this time. · Lead / Onsight. Struggled off the ledge a bit Good beta to layback the twin crack until the corner has bigger opening · 2 pitches. TR. Mock trad lead. Gotta do it a few more times til I feel comfortable enough. Layback through the first part, gotta limit myself to 3 or 4 pieces next time to avoid getting too pumped. Tried jamming the crack and stemming the upper part, not sure what I like better. Gotta try to save #0.75's and #1's for the upper part next time · Lead / Onsight. Well. I think I got nervous because of the ‘+’ after the grade and went in with a poor mentality. It ended up feeling like a pretty chill 5.7 TBH but I placed SO much gear I got way more tired doing that than actually climbing! It was very clean, the hardest move was getting into the crack one you’re on the ledge. But it was strenuous! I felt like the whole climb was two movement repeated over and over. Overall very fun (: · TR. 1st half tried different beta with Lani's guidance. cruised the 2nd half. Peter on belay · Lead / Onsight. Wooo second ever trad lead! I dropped a cam at the top (luckily didnt fall to ground) and kindaaa ran it out (placed some questionable protection for peace of mind). Spooky bc trad lead but physically easy · Lead / Redpoint. Such a good route! Took doubles to 2" and only used up to 1. · Lead / Onsight. Very type 1 fun!! Almost forgot to place gear it was so good. · Lead / Redpoint. So good…got back on it for the red point with Kai and Ethan…splitter with amazing rock with tons of texture · Lead / Onsight. Very fun, hardest moves seem to be getting off the ledge · Lead. Took once on gear. Single rack with doubles in blue totem and triples is red and yellow bd if you want to sew it up. I placed minimal draws since it was not much meandery. · 2 pitches. TR. Super fun. Slabby boulder problem, lieback, and then stem. Want to come back and lead this when I have a double rack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ran out of gear and lowered back to piece to finish climb, amazing climb takes gear TOO well · Lead. Belay from Markel (WAC). Early fall before my first placement, Markel helped me land safely. A bit hesitant after that, but a clean and energizing lead followed! · Lead / Onsight. Sustained 5.7 climbing to the top. Save small cams for the top bit, a few 2-3 for the last bit as well · Lead / Onsight. Stellar. All the gear is there up to 2. Could put 4 at top but unecessary · Lead / Fell/Hung. Legs were jello from doing north twin day before. Burned all 1s down low and ran out of gear 10’ from top. I’ll be back · Lead / Fell/Hung. First redpoint on trad. Still learning crack climbing, and gear management. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Laust led on his own! Then Luis. Then I followed, only placed a few pieces, fun layback moves, pumpy, hand jams. · Lead / Fell/Hung. First lead of the day and it felt hard to me. Persevered with a lot of takes. But then I top roped it and I flew up it. Never felt like I was going to fall. Want to lead it again · Lead. So enjoyable I almost forgot to place pro. Single rack 0.4–2 and doubles 0.5-1 should be enough and extra safe. · 4 pitches. Lead. 2x .5, .4, 3x #1, .3 W Wade JV AM CG Nbrune · Lead / Redpoint. Slipped on the first ten feet like an idiot and decked, then clean second attempt · TR. So nice so chill, easy lie back and then the nicest hand crack of my life, smooth and fast the whole way · Lead / Redpoint. Led this twice today. First time was kind of chaotic, felt scared and unsure. Second time I sent it, one of my best leads yet. Climbed above all my pieces! Bouldery and scary start. The layback is solid and takes .75s, then around the corner is mostly 1s. Such a great climb · Lead / Flash. Nice climb. Some corner, some layback, some hand jams. With sarah. She led first. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took once, route eats up 0.5/0.75's. Was a challenge to lead it with just doubles (got creative with nuts the 2nd half) · Lead / Onsight. Felt like a senior citizen climbing this. Cool climb. The sunset summit was stunning. Brought up Jonah to look at the view then we lost the rope and had to jump off the top of the climb. All good though hitting the jack rn

routes.route_description: Climb to a bolt, step right to the start of a flake, layback and undercling up and right to where the flake ends. The crux is making an improbable reach up and right to a ledge.From the ledge, either clip the anchors of Eraserhead, or continue up to the tree.You can also continue up right from the tree (~5.9, two bolts).
routes.route_location: Shares the same start as Prairie Fire and Imagine.
routes.route_protection: Large stoppers, cams, including a large cam (~3.5") for the start of the flake.

routes.route_description: Layback and jam the flake crack between Wild Turkey and Battered Sandwich. Where the left crack peters out, reach right for some rounded holds. End at anchor on the face. Up until about the last 10', it is probably 5.8.
routes.route_location: Both the large RFC of Wild Turkey (with wide crack in corner and fist crack on left face) and the chimney-flare of Battered Sandwich should be fairly obvious. Also, see the photo.
routes.route_protection: TR from the face anchor or the higher anchor. Easy Peasy if you've just done Battered S- or Wild T-.Please do not do this route if anyone is on, or about to start, a route to either side.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Tried sidepulling thin crack to anchors, very hard for me, did not send · TR. TRS, had to use the left crack when the first flake petered out · TR. Set up a top rope by hiking to the top, rock was wet

routes.route_description: Layback up the arete just right of Senior Citizens. For arete climbing, this is a step up in difficulty from Sisara on LO Point immediately above.The crux for many is just below a small overlap. Even though the bolts are all on the right side of the arete on the bottom 2/3 of the route, one may find it easier to sometimes climb on the left side.Even when many crack routes nearby are wet, this one may be dry (as will other arete routes). If, having done this, you seek greater arete challenges, try Noodle just to the right or a half-dozen other aretes in the vicinity.
routes.route_location: Start just right of Senior Citizens in Space.
routes.route_protection: All bolts. Two bolt anchor with mussy hooks.

route_comments.comment_text: Climbing to the left as you approach the overlap works but be aware that falling before you make that clip will send you hurtling into the wall of the dihedral behind you.  At 5'1", I found this to be a difficult clip to reach.
