For those wanting to mitigate this risk, climbing Senior Citizens first and pre-hanging an extended draw at that spot allows you to make the clip from a safer... more Climbing to the left as you approach the overlap works but be aware that falling before you make that clip will send you hurtling into the wall of the dihedral behind you.  At 5'1", I found this to be a difficult clip to reach.  For those wanting to mitigate this risk, climbing Senior Citizens first and pre-hanging an extended draw at that spot allows you to make the clip from a safer position. I am by no means solid at the grade so your mileage may vary. I thought this climb was excellent and interesting throughout. Sep 2, 2013
If you're worried about falling off before the first bolt there's a 0.5 (BD) placement that will protect you nicely to the first bolt. Jul 20, 2015
I really enjoyed this route once i worked out all the beta, the first time up was quite hard.  I think i find a new "hold" every time lol. Jun 19, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. 3 tries, 2nd try morning felt the best. lots of pasty feet. first several moves are pulling feet high onto ledge. other moves utilize the arete to balance up. The arete crux, move onto left face. smear. some okay holds next to bolt, at bolt move right top part is smearing high right feet with sloper hands. clipping is easier higher up often times. · Follow. One fall on the left side of the arete, 3-4 bolts from the top · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at two places about 2/3 up. Moreso a head crux then physical with the Arete for me. · TR. Fell a bunch at the crux but other than that I surprised myself with how good it felt! May have had a little help from Carly belaying · TR. One or two hangs at the crux. Great hard friction slab practice, would love to come back and try and lead sometime. Id be prouder to send this than rainy day lol · Lead / Fell/Hung. Not really an 11a (much harder), might deserve a pg13 due to the rope dragging on the corner in some fall zones, imo not worth the send unless everything else is taken. The first jug above bolt one is hollow and will probably pull off after another season or 2. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Chuffing at the 3rd bolt… took a ton of falls all over this thing it’s super safe · TR. Sooo close to a clean TR. Gave it two burns today. First one was re-figuring the beta and the second I nearly sent it. Crux 1 - left hand on the chip, lean hard right to get fingers on tiny chip, work feet up and get right foot on the tiny chip. Crux 2 - feet on tiny left cracks. Left foot on upper crack. Paste right foot on tiny divot with both hands on the rail. Work hand up rail. Work left foot back in to move right foot high one more time. Farther right is better for right foot. Then able to reach up with left hand to pinch the overlap. · TR. Many takes but figured out all the beta. The crux was working left of arete on tiny feet then friction walking up the spine to a somewhat desperate move to a thin crimp (that maybe flexed?). Would feel good about trying on lead with pre-hung draws. Maybe an extended one at the crux. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couldn’t sort out the friction moves from bolt 6-7, but did the rest · TR. Climbed this route with one hang. Really fun, slabby and insecure with a few good crimps along the way · TR. Fell a number of times. Still feels very difficult and cryptic, especially towards the top of the arete before the mini roof thing. Neither Theresa nor i could figure out how to cleanly send that one. Going the the left side of the arete seemed to work for a bit around there (versus the other side for the majority of the climb) but rocking back around was mystifying. Lots of compression, lots of try hard. Heel and toe hooks on the arete rail were decently effective. · Lead. 2 attempts with plenty of falls at mid crux. Move left when exiting next rp attempt · TR. Attempted, got to hold less part of arete and couldn’t make much progress. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Cerebral slabby arete climbing! V fun. Went left at middle crux · TR. Oh PLEASE!!!! Did ONE move, pulled through the rest. I wonder if a grasshopper grip strategy would work hahahaha · TR. TR, better than a while ago, but still slipped a bunch. Good to go left at the main crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. Sweet. Come back with good conditions and maybe prehang the draws. Free’d all the moves. Go left below mini roof then back right · TR. tipped over backwards in frog step once, followed good crimps left but was a trap. last 8-10 ft before overlap (mini roof) in the middle was the crux, just terrible feet and steeper, slipped a couple times there. not really any defined beta, the dishes are non-existent and the biggest feature for feet is a slippery quartzite knob that's best to avoid. stayed right of arete up high for a few bolts · TR. directionals for TR a must, at least every 2-3 bolts in middle and all of last 3. did better but still slipped at crux twice. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got most of the moves down. Slipped transitioning from right side back to the left face at the top where it gets steeper · TR. was able to do eventuall work out all the moves in unideal conditions. crux still fept too hard to consider leading. major major progress from last time. · TR. loved it! hugging the arete, smearing and small crimps made this very enjoyable · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couple falls at crux (and at the easier section above). Could've climbed better, but glad I tried it on lead. · Lead / Fell/Hung. few hangs in middle third before roof feature. super rad but so so nails. · TR. with Andrea. fun did all the moves would be scary lead. moved to left side at crux overlap. seems like a 4 star route · TR. felt hard, will use softer shoes next time. A lot of fun though! · TR. Top roped this guy after senior citizens and I quite enjoyed it. Fun slab movement. Couldn’t get the one move at the end of the spine before working onto the right side. Everything else felt pretty straightforward with a good amount of friction feet · TR. Haley and max TRd by moving over from senior citizens. Had some takes but made it to the top. There are some face features not to miss in bottom 2/3rds, move left before roofish section-crux. · Follow. couldn't get the crux, 50pct of the time I get it every time · TR. Fell twice at crux on TR before figuring out beta (move to the left side of the arete). Super fun and stout (definitely go when it's cold)! · TR. One slip and then hung to figure out crux. Was trying to go right instead of left.

routes.route_description: A short, steep, thin-edging face climb. It's hard to find the edges on this one. Just three bolts.Ends at anchor in middle of face.
routes.route_location: Just a few feet right of Three Trucks.
routes.route_protection: Three bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: 2 stars? Has anyone actually done this route? Nov 22, 2018

Will did it, at least. I think Greg was with him. But, as with other climbs, we can never know if anyone did it without them having publicized their efforts. I might have been the guy to clean it back when we did Three Trucks, and gave it the name, but never came back to it. Nov 23, 2018

routes.route_name: Three Trucks Stacked on Top of Each Other
routes.route_description: Bolt-protected, thin-edging with high-steps on a short, steep face.
routes.route_location: The start lies just left of the trail highpoint left of "Shader".
routes.route_protection: All fixed.

routes.route_description: Climb to the top of the pedestal that is just left of Wet Dream. Do one undercling-face move (crux) to large edges above overlap. Face climb up holds, trending left towards the short left-facing corner. Climb corner and face flakes to the chains.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Small stoppers and cams to 2". Useful to have very thin-size cam or ball-nut for the crux move off the pedestal.

route_comments.comment_text: A .4 camalot can protect the very beginning. A black alien or black totem can protect the crux move, or just start up wet dream and traverse over which isn't too bad even when it's wet. The flake towards the chains is pretty thin and hollow sounding, .75 camalots can protect it pretty good, just dont fall as the flake might break. Mar 17, 2019
This route is really dirty and quite runout. I didn't find anywhere to place pro above the crux until well into decking territory. May 13, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Bad route. Very dirty. Quite runout after the crux move. Definitely decking potential. · Lead / Onsight. Would not recommend. Climbed wet, but even when dry would entail a bit of a runout, and the pro near the top is mostly flakes that do not inspire confidence. · Lead / Redpoint. Crux felt super sketch. Single tiny cam on undercling, runout until the dirt shelf. Holds/moves aren't bad, but not great when dirty · Lead / Onsight. Gear was utter garbage after the first move (which was fun, and easy to protect). Brief groundfall run-out after that, then two okay nuts at the base of the ramp. Pro after that is in shaky, hollow flakes. Best not to place any.

routes.route_description: A long, left-leaning, left-facing corner.Looking from below, you might think the climbing was fairly monotonous. But actually, you can use all sorts of methods to get up it, and there are quite a few face holds on the left wall to get rests, particularly near the bottom.The crux is probably near the top, just above where the horizontal crack cuts right.The top has a two-bolt chained anchor.
routes.route_location: Look for the obvious, long left-facing corner just right of Eraserhead (the bolted face right off the ground).
routes.route_protection: Gear to 4". A few finger-sized stoppers, and lots of cams.

route_comments.comment_text: First Ascent: John Fisk and Tish Nakia Jul 13, 2013
Also fun to traverse into the top pitch of magic fern at the horizontal right below the chimney. Aug 11, 2013
I think this might just be the funnest, most classic one-pitch 5.9 at Index. The pitch has lots of little rests, and it helps to use a variety of methods. Aug 12, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Climbed with Kat - my fingers and mind wanted to jam the upper part ow but my body wouldn't fit:( Ended up lie backing which felt committing because you'd poke your head in to see the next placement and it would be like three feet into the crack hah just had to keep going to the chains. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Haley lead. Felt proud of myself for getting on this one. The pro is great. I struggled so hard at the chimney though. I had to aid up to get through the bottom half of it. I was trying to go right side in, but max went left side in and said that works much better. Would love to try this one again. Max TRd as it was getting too hot. · TR. Pretty fun but burly at the top! Wouldn't necessarily want to lead it anytime soon lol · TR. Start was cruisy but I fell trying to get up the off-width. I tried to stay in the off-width part in case I wanted to lead it but between being bad at off-width, using the finger crack within the off-width and getting my knees scraped up with the lack of long pants, I ended up having to layback it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Not sure how this is 5.9+. I guess saying goes that 9+ is always harder than 10a. Felt significantly harder than Japanese gardens(first anchor), Gm route, Godzilla and battered sandwhich. Went right side in, maybe will try left side in next time · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lots of dirt off the bat and just way too wiped from the sun to finish the layback. Fell at the top · Lead / Fell/Hung. Scariest 5.9 for me so far...I didn't have a #4 so I had to run out in the middle section, which was not too bad. But the top section really got me. It felt so awkward for my finger to work in the deep crack so finally I took a few rests on #0.75 and #1 to regain the confidence to finish it · Lead. This climb is fucked. Lol. Super dirty crack in the first half, straight up muddy hand jams. Gear was not the most confidence inspiring. The squeeze also just didn’t go down for me. Pulled on and hung on some cams · Lead / Fell/Hung. Left side in the crack & face out at the top. Felt very burly! · Lead / Flash. super very nice oui oui. couple weird pro spots with a lip that blocks a bigger can from entering into an inward flare. but stellar all the same · Lead / Onsight. Save a #3 for the top. Lie back the whole thing · Lead / Onsight. fun but burley for me! the offwidth ish at the top took a lot of my shoulder skin · Lead / Onsight. With Taylor, pretty fun! Climbed the wide part as an offwidth and was hard, bottom part really good · Lead / Onsight. Fun route. Super mixed climbing. Fun jamming and lay backing. Crux just last horizontal getting into and up the ow. Nice to have doubles .5-3 and a 4. Placed a yellow offset low that was nice too. Left side in at top worked ok. Wear pants · TR. Still fucking hard. Lay back the top part was okay but hard and slick. Worked at the top. · TR. Lindsey/Erik put the rope up, trone hung until the offwidth and then got a little fucked up · Lead / Fell/Hung. The bottom half was awesome! Jammed & laybacked, and great gear. I couldn’t figure out the top part! It was like an off width but too wide for my feet to heel toe, and too narrow to use my knees. Ended up aiding that section as it started to rain and I had been there for a while already barely moving upward. Very cool climb! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a couple times in OW. Yarded on gear once or twice but otherwise made all the moves. Left side in, jam with left hand, use rf to scooch upwards · Lead / Flash. Double rack to 3. Save a 0.75 and a 1 for the top · Lead. Hung twice before the offwidth and then many times in the offwidth. Try left side in next time. Was happy to double up on 4s. · TR. Left side in is, in fact, a bit easier. Use right leg against slab wall and push up. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Note to self: don’t do that as a warm up when it’s your first climb of the season and it’s also 30C and in the sun · Lead / Fell/Hung. Did not layback the top and got real awkward. Needs some traffic- muddy · Lead / Onsight. Really fun! Ran through all size and had to work in the offwidth · Lead / Fell/Hung. Get in better shape! Took a lot. Top is definitely the crux. · Lead / Flash. 5.9++. maybe laybacking the top section would have been easier climbing, but harder to place gear. proudest and hardest trad lead to date · TR. Wet dream of a masochist. The off-width at the top was painfully hard. Unique route, but felt very hard for the grade. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tag teamed with partner climbing a little, lowering, then attempting again, cam by cam, until completing route. · Lead. Didn’t get clean. Come re-do to practice wide crack technique. Fun tho! Try laybacking next time? · Lead / Fell/Hung. Would bring three 3s again , brought 2 4s and placed both but one would be fine. Pulled on gear at top crux, need to get left hand high, right arete compression/gaston move left foot up. Right foot is useless. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Aided through the chimney section. Lots of 1-3, found place for 2 4s. Small gear (.5-.75) in chimney. .75-1 above. Bottom part was fun. Mix of crack + lie back. · TR. Fell a couple times trying stuff out. Was able to make upward progress on the chimney facing out, left hand in the crack. First few moves were really hard but then it became much easier. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Challenging overhanging hand to fist crack. Couldn’t figure out the offwidth moves and ended up laybacking the last 10ft Don’t climb this on a 90 degree sunny summer afternoon… · TR. with Andrea. super fun squeeze like climbing. not sure if I did this before with kaiulani · Lead / Redpoint. 3x 0.75, 2x#1&2, 1x#4, blue totem, purp bd offset nut. Left side in upper, still awkward, maybe slightly better for gear but chimney felt insecure but more offwidth than chimney. prob better! · Lead / Fell/Hung. offwidth at the top was really hard trying to get in the crack but popped out · Lead / Onsight. Warm up for the day. Fun climbing with good a nice crack. Crux was up top navigating the hips and shoulders while trying to stay in the crack and not come out and lay back it · Lead / Onsight. Flare was very strenuous with back to wall and trying to jam off fingers. But was able to tall person stretch to victory · Lead / Fell/Hung. Used 2x 0.75-#3, single 0.3-0.5 & #4. Didn't bring nuts but a few spots for them. Took whip on 4 layback, blew left foot leaning in to grab jug. Groveled Rside in flare, wear shitty shoes. Try back against the wall or layback upper section. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Cruiser until the wide section near the top, flailed so hard. Tried to jam the .75 crack right side in. Maybe need better beta, maybe just suck at wide. Will try again · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Matt park Alana and Danny it was quite fun gear was shit tho · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hang dogged it pretty hard on the chimney section before committing to the layback. Fun down low · TR. beta from Bill and Juliet: try looking outwards and chimneying the OW at the top · Lead / Onsight. Got a lil gripped at the layback. Wasn't that bad, still clenchy though. Good gear

routes.route_description: This formerly vegetated corner between Battered Sandwich and Instanbul is now clear of brush and ready to climb.  Start in the corner. Lieback, stem, and chimney your way up the widening crack.  There is an anchor at the platform where the crack ends (thank you to whoever installed this!).  From the top of the crack, you can also continue by making a few moves right to the base of the flare of Battered Sandwich (Turkey Sandwich??).  This adds some great climbing, a little spice, and a grade or two.
routes.route_location: Between Istanbul and Battered Sandwich
routes.route_protection: Singles to a BD #5.  Consider doubling up in the mid sizes if continuing through the flare of Battered Sandwich.

route_comments.comment_text: Darryl and I had occasionally thought about cleaning this line, but it always looked too hard to clean. It is fantastic to hear that someone finally cleaned it. Perhaps Index routes should have two ratings, a user rating for climbing difficulty, and a creator rating to give acknowledgement to the work of the FA party. This one would be u5.7, c5.14. Any photos? May 17, 2016
Thanks Jon, it was a bit more work than I had planned, but I think it will end up being a good one.  Don't have a great picture, but it's probably good enough for now. May 17, 2016
I predict that the route will become very popular, perhaps one of the most popular at the cliff. Fantastic job David. Thanks. May 18, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. I’ve def set up TR on this from battered sandwich, such a fun climb, could totally lead · Lead / Onsight. BD blue was tipped out at the end. Not bad. Move left and past the wild turkey anchors up the dirty slab then swing right to access the battered sandwich anchors · Lead / Redpoint. Super fun, still feels harder than Senior Citizens to me. Used the #4 but not the #5 · Lead / Onsight. Didn’t use a 5. But two #4s would have been nice. It was easy so I ran it out. Single rack up to 4 enough. · TR. Mock trad lead. Felt okay ish with a single rack, would have been doable with a double. Next time! · TR. Belay from Zach (WAC). Last route of the day. Note to self: come back and lead this one! · Lead / Onsight. Great climb! Anchor position makes it awkward if someone is climbing Battered Sandwich. · Lead / Flash. Tricky 5.7, felt like 5.9 in the heat wave 32deg. Need a #4 (#5 even better) for the top · TR. Hard wide crack sections, feel like I mostly worked around the actual crack climbing. Did get a butterfly stack and one heel toe cam · Lead / Onsight. Didn't have #4 or 5, so I just ran out that section. After reaching the anchor I traversed to the right to finish the last part of battered sandwich with two 0.75 · Lead / Onsight. Excellent crack and flake to the right, off width up top is pretty secure · Lead. Nothing particularly interesting. Some stemming at the bottom and hand jam in the second half. There is one or two interesting moves to get on the bulky rock at the top · Lead / Onsight. jams and stemming. classic. 0.4-4. could place a 5 but not needed · Lead / Onsight. Followed top half of battered sandwich needs 1-3 to top out that way · Follow. Set up a belay station at the anchor. Belayed Nate on the 5.9 offwidth next-door. Rapped down. · Lead / Flash. Haley, Max, Ilja and Ksenia led. Great climb. Fun bit of OW at the top. · Very good. Cams .4 , .5 , .75 , 1, 2 , 3, 4, 5 · Lead / Onsight. Would rather bring a #4 for the offwidth part. Not as clean as I would have wanted it.

area_description: This area is somewhat hidden in trees, though has several short "towers" at the top that appear above trees and offer nice views. It has numerous steep, though relatively short, cracks, as well as aretes.
area_getting_there: From the top of Hag Crag, head uphill a few steps and you are there. Alternatively, from LOP's east end walk up the start of the gully to Daddy Wall and go left a few steps.

routes.route_description: The usual three tools hooked in below a lid to protect from rain.
routes.route_location: From the main handline up to Orange Sunshine and Lookout jr, look for the tree behind you.
routes.route_protection: Eye protection and gloves are nice.

routes.route_description: Short but quality layback in a left facing corner.
routes.route_location: From the base of Towers 1 and 2, continue walking east a short distance to Tower 0.  BMG 4573 starts in a crack next to a corner that turns into a left facing corner.
routes.route_protection: Pro to 1".A two-bolt chained anchor lies on the wall immediately above.

route_comments.comment_text: A nice little practice or warm-up crack. Sep 13, 2023
What Jon said. This is a short, easy, and well-protected climb. Please consider grabbing some scrubbing tools as it is climbable but would certainly benefit from some extra love. Mar 16, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. Great little layback! Another 10-20 feet and it'd be three stars.

routes.route_description: This is the crack system right of Orange Sunshine.p1: From Stan's ledge, climb face cracks (crux) to reach a slot with good jams in the back. Near the top of the slot/corner, climb the left arching flake which ends at a ledge with an anchor (5.9).p2: Continue over the chockstone, then up a vertical wall (crux).  Cross over to the south side of the formation and climb an airy arete ending at the summit of Tower 2 (5.10).   Nice variety on this climb.
routes.route_location: From Stan's ledge, the crack and corner system right of Orange Sunshine.
routes.route_protection: Pro to 2", 2 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Climbed last weekend. The upper bit of this route is quite cool - the lower bit is very dirty. It would be worth it to snag a brush from the cleaning station or bring your own and brush on the way down. I, unfortunately, did not think to grab a brush before starting up, sorry! You can definitely do this as a single pitch if you have a 70, and in fact I'd recommend climbing it that way. If you... more Climbed last weekend. The upper bit of this route is quite cool - the lower bit is very dirty. It would be worth it to snag a brush from the cleaning station or bring your own and brush on the way down. I, unfortunately, did not think to grab a brush before starting up, sorry! You can definitely do this as a single pitch if you have a 70, and in fact I'd recommend climbing it that way. If you wanted to clean this route before (or without) climbing it, you can very easily walk to the top anchors and set up a rappel. Jul 2, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Lu and I Trd just the 2nd pitch after lowering down from the top. Super fun movement. More sporty.

routes.route_description: Short but sweet. Thought provoking movement up nice edges on the face, followed by a slab finish.
routes.route_location: From the top of Hag Crag, go up to the next wall (about 15-30 yards), find it just right of the handline.From Daddy Wall and the LOP gully, walk east as if taking the alternate trail up and around Planet Index, see it on your left, just as you are about to pass under Tower Zero.
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts

routes.route_description: The arete on the right side of Tower 1
routes.route_location: Easiest approach is to walk just past Tower Zero, then head up hill and right away you should spot a rope handline in the vegetation heading back toward the towers, follow this, then follow another handline uphill and Tower 1 should be obvious. A third handline runs steeply uphill just right of Tower 1. Fog Hues of Oar climbs the arete which is left of this hand line. Jump on the arete wherever convenient, but right between where the different hand lines meet is a flatish space just big enough for a belayer and is probably the most sensible place to start.
routes.route_protection: Two bolts plus gear

routes.route_description: Climb the flake and corner crack to a small ledge with a 2 bolt anchor. Crux near the top. Climbing the finger crack to the left of the flake/corner crack is 5.8. From the ledge with the anchor, it is possible to continue around the left side of the roof and up a crack to reach Lookout jr and other areas above the Towers.
routes.route_location: Climb the handline to Stan's ledge. Orange Sunshine begins on the left side of the ledge.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3 inches

route_comments.comment_text: I bypassed the second pitch by going left under the roof and up the left-most crack from the small ledge. The wider crack was not protectable without big gear and pretty dirty. The crack I used had more features though was very mossy. Gear was marginal at best. It spit you out at some chains with a tree anchor. Jul 10, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Doubles 0.5-3 and one 0.4 worked well, kind of unremarkable climbing, awkward finish w/some less than average quality rock. Lower goes right over a sharp edge, would escape up and left next time, or do P2, or just skip this one.

routes.route_description: From the p1 anchor, climb up to the right side of the bulge, clip a bolt and pull over. Gain the summit by climbing either a short finger crack or the arete on the right side of the tower.You can rap nearly to the base of the first pitch with a 70 meter rope though you'll likely need to clip into the hand-line and let your rope feed through your belay device to do so.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 1 or 2 bolts,  a cam or two for the finger crack finish, a large cam may be useful for approaching the bulge if I remember correctly.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. Had a hard time pulling up and over the high dive. Exited left after pulling over

routes.route_description: Start on Outta Sight.  Instead of traversing left into the corner, continue climbing up and right along the crack until its possible to cross over the arete to a slab (crux). Climb over a small roof to gain the top of the tower. Climbing slightly right of the bolt is ~10b, left of the bolt is 10+.
routes.route_location: Shares the same start as Outta SIght.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2-3", 6 bolts.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Mock led this. Fun vertical crack. The face is in the sun with zero shade, probably not a great idea doing it on a hot summer day unless it's before 8am. The mental crux is clipping the bolt on the face (third bolt?) as you kinda have to almost be done with the hard moves unprotected (i didn't bring micro cams or nuts)in order to reach the bolt. Fun roof finger crack (jam and then undercling)to help getting up the slab. There is a bomber jub right below the last bolt that I toe-hooked on to release the hand to clip. · TR. Fell going over roof, need to use hand hold off right then go up with left to the jug. · TR. Hardest move for me was the bolt on the face. Good crimps on both sides.

routes.route_description: The splitter hand cracks in slightly overhanging light colored rock.Layback the wide crack on the right side of Tower 1. A few wide moves in a crack, or layback/compression leads to the hand cracks. Finish up the corner. The bolted anchor is set for rappelling Outta Mind which shares the same start as Outta Sight.Short but sweet.
routes.route_location: Climb the handline to the base of Tower 1 and then walk right to the start of the route, or walk past Towers 1 and 0 to another handline which leads to the start of the route.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3", 3 bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: It is also a fun way to get to the climbing above (LO jr & Moai). Jun 29, 2022
A fun moderate multi pitch could start at Hag, then climb something at the Towers followed by Lookout jr. Jun 29, 2022

Hand traverse is super fun! a BD4 is nice to have as a first piece if you are short and can't reach the hand crack right away from the top of the flake. 2024 Edit: It appears the flake that you used to stand on at the start is gone, and 2 bolts have been put in. Jul 18, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Fell once transiting out of the hand crack into thin hand/finger size. Did got over the section by a constriction and an undercling feature in the crack. For TR, i'd put a #3 in the horizontal crack for redirect, as a fall would likely swing backwards. · TR. Use your feet at the bottom. It’s quite good and you can easily reach the hand cracks without any lay backing · Follow. I got lowered back to the ground on the first attempt just after entering the corner since I didn't have crack gloves or chalk. After Sam threw down his for me to borrow, I started again and fell where the crack starts to winden up a bit. Had to rest a bit but was able to finish it afterwards. · Lead / Flash. I TRd first time after Lu put up the route. Then lead on my second go. So fun. A #4 was nice to have to protect the upper crack section before getting up to the ledge. · Follow. Highly varied, fun climb. One akward moment when the face turned vertical. Need to figure out how to make it smoother. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung on the first three pieces lol but cruised in the corner ! Sewed it up with a 3 mid way through horizontal crack. Use a .5 instead of .4 going up through corner · TR. 4, 2, second 2 in the horizontal crack, .5, .4 or .5 in small crack around the corner (or totems) , then a 1 and a .5 near the top · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took on the cross over, got gased. One 4, a 3, a 2, a 0.5 after in thins, then 0.4 in the corner, hand jam the flake, throw a 0.5 or thicker 0.4 in the wide bit and go. · Lead / Onsight. Wished I had three #3's. Maybe one #4. Felt like I went on a mini life journey. · Follow. So so so fun, need to lead it but Belay from the higher up. Rope drag is horrendous otherwise · TR. did not climb this. I belayed Jace from the tree anchor after climbing the rope line to the top. · started from the base. fun hand traverse. 4 helpful for entering the wide but not necessary.

routes.route_description: Climb the thin crack in a left facing corner to a ledge. Continue up a right facing corner to a gain a series of horizontals through the overhang. Bolted anchor with chains.
routes.route_location: From the base of Towers 1 and 2, continue walking east a short distance to Tower 0.  Ron Sneezes starts in an obvious left facing corner.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 3".  Double black totems.

route_comments.comment_text: The lower part can easily be TR'd from the chains at the top of BMG 4573 (accessible by handline). Directional C4 0.3 and 2 recommended. Mar 16, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Sweet finger crack with solid jams. After that the route gets dirty(not sure if it's worth doing). Good climbing option on a hot day as the rock is well-shaded · TR. Varied movement. Crux may be off the ground getting into the finger crack. · Lead / Flash. Max, Jeremiah, Heather and Haley lead. Fun layback finger crack. Then eases up and the top is sporty. · Lead / Onsight. Three 0.3s was nice for down low. Blind 3 placement up high. · Lead. First moves feet is tricky but very very fun !!! Perfect fingers. Z4 .3, blue totem, .3, .5, .4, another .5? Bring a 2 for before the bulge and 3 for the blind horizontal crack. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. I thought it was a fun climb only detractor was the crack was gritty, not sure eight my cams would hold or blow up a crystal and pop. Bring.0.2s and 0.3s for the lower part. Top part was fun.

area_description: At the top of Planet I, between Moonworms and LO jr, this sector has steeper lines than the latter, but easier than the former. The classic line here is the 10b/c One Small Step, but others are just as fun. The area tends to get full sun for most of the day, though one can find some shade behind a huge snag as well as shade at the top.
area_getting_there: From below, do a route at Lolybird or Moai, or rap down from the top rim of Planet I.

routes.route_name: Leaves that are the People, The
routes.route_description: Layback the left side of a flake, to a ledge then traverse left to the start of an RFC.  Nice finger locks and stemming in the corner lead to a flake and then a 2 bolt anchor.
routes.route_location: To the left of One Small Step.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2", 2 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Really fun little corner. Jul 26, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got confused and stuck moving too far right at the final bolt

routes.route_description: Gain the top of the detached flake by climbing either the bolted arete (5.10) or the corner crack to the right of the arete (5.7). Continue up the left facing corner to access the nice finger crack.  At the top of the crack, a few face moves up and slightly right, end at an alcove with an anchor.
routes.route_location: Begin from Moai ledge
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2", 2 bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: Such nice jams on this. It is like doing Pressure Drop except you also get incredible views and a neat platform at the top. Jun 21, 2022
Four F’ing rads. Just as good as Perfect Pitch or Pressure Drop, except easier. Jul 10, 2022
Awesome splitter! Crux was getting into the main crack- made a little more exciting with the possibility of taking the flake to the tailbone:) Jul 25, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Another one in the bag! Excellent climb in an excellent setting. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ran out of talent and had to aid it with cams · Lead / Onsight. Nice finger crack. I just wish the crux wasn’t above a giant pointy flake… · Lead / Onsight. #3, #2, #2, (from top of horn placed .5, 00 c3, 6HB, .1).4, (.4 or . 5), .4, .5,. 75, .3, .75., 6-7 draws. The granite is soooo grippy. · Follow. Followed Zack cleanly after Easter pitch on Moai below. Slab Arete and finger crack are both very high quality. Really wonderful climb! · Lead / Onsight. Cool route. Fun getting past the flakes, cool transition to the finger crack. Had to be careful not to put the gear in the best holds (AL)

routes.route_description: From the belay, pull over a small roof to nice exposure along the arete.  Latch on to Index's biggest jug, then up to a right trending flake crack.  As the crack ends, head up the vertical wall to a crux  mantle on slopers.
routes.route_location: Both Wind and Leaves start from the base of One Small Step.  Layback up the left side of the flake to a ledge and traverse left to reach the climbs.  There is a bolted anchor at the base of Wind.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 2", 4 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Make sure to stop on the buckets after the short roof to look around and admire the position. Nov 23, 2022

Brushed off the key holds today but expect a little moss and grit along the way. We thought the crux was passing the first bolt above the intermediate anchor. Not as good as its neighbors IMO but the position is rad! Jun 13, 2023

area_description: Not to be confused with the Noodle route next to Private Idaho, Noodle wall sits at the top of the LOP gully. The routes here start at nice horizontal platforms, despite the steep slope of the gully. The wall has a bubble-like pattern, with a few cracks.
area_getting_there: Go up the LOP gully to near the top. After passing the leaning log, the routes start. When you get to the huge fir, you are about even with the highest route here.

routes.route_name: Carefully Swallow the Metallic Noodle p1
routes.route_description: Fun crack climb with some big holds on a vertical wall.  Begin by a belay bolt and do a rightward hand traverse to reach a bolt and the start of the crack. Crux at the bolt near the top of the pitch as one moves right on a rail.  Clipping the bolt can be challenging for shorter climbers.From the anchor on Noodle ledge one can continue on Metallic Noodle for more fun crack climbing at a similar grade or climb Space Noodle.As with most routes at Planet Index, it is possible to TR the route from an anchor at the top of the crag or just below the top.
routes.route_location: LOP gully.  A few feet up and to the left from the ledge with the leaning log overhead.
routes.route_protection: gear to 3.5", 3 bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: A direct start is possible (starting immediately below the obvious hand crack). It ups the difficulty to ~10+ if you're tall (6'4"), or probably considerably harder if you're shorter. Jul 9, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Quick TR lap at end of day. Did direct start variation. Little dirty, but pretty fun. Less jamming than you'd expect looking at it from the ground.

routes.route_name: Elliptical Eye of Typhoon Ted, The
routes.route_description: Begin by a belay bolt and follow the obvious line of bolts/ledges up trending slightly rightward as you go. Fun, steep climbing on mostly good holds.
routes.route_location: LOP gully.  A few feet up and to the left from the horizontal ledge with the big leaning log overhead. Look for the belay bolt near the ground.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts (+1 for the belayer). You may want a .75" for the stretch between the 4th and 5th bolts, particularly if you are short, as the 5th clip is a little tough for shorter folks.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Patrick put this thing up and it was pretty hard but kinda cool. A little ambiguous what the right line is because there’s a crack to the right · Lead / Onsight. Little dirty today (moss on slopers makes for some exciting times!), but quite fun climbing. Looks like 5.7 from the ground, but climbs much harder than it looks.

routes.route_description: From the nice wide (for the gully) landing, face climb up and slightly left, then back right past a bolt to the start of a fierce little crack. Near the top of the crack, just before the ledge (with anchors) are two more bolts.
routes.route_location: Look for the huge log that leans against the wall. Below this is a zig-zag crack, and the left of that crack lies this crack. The crack does not reach the ground. Also look for the bolt near the start.
routes.route_protection: Small gear to about 1" cams, 3 bolts.

routes.route_description: This is the striking crack line starting midway up Noodle wall.From a belay at the top of p1 Metallic Noodle or Typhoon Ted, climb a bolted flake to a crux move getting into a hand crack. The crack thins, disappears for a few feet and then opens up again for the final moves to a ledge with a chain anchor. Pumpy.
routes.route_location: Climb either p1 Metallic Noodle or The Elliptical Eye of Typhon Ted.To TR the route, follow the handline at the top of Noodle wall to an anchor.  Do a short rap on a fixed line to a ledge with an anchor.  This is the top of Space Noodle.
routes.route_protection: Singles to 2", double yellow totem, small to medium stoppers.

route_comments.comment_text: Finally! Striking crack indeed. Sep 1, 2024

routes.route_protection: Gear to 2", include black totems or offset cams to protect the moves at the start.

routes.route_description: Start as for Metallic Noodle, then clip the bolt on the face to the right. Step right and go up a short distance before moving right to the obvious ledge.
routes.route_location: Starts at the belay bolt for Metallic Noodle.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts. It is possible to place a nut in the noodle crack before clipping the bolt, but the 10+ leader should be comfortable without gear.  Chains at the ledge.

area_description: Located between the Noodle and Small Steps zones and above Lolybird, you'll find the namesake face and crack climbs in a unique setting.Big thanks to Derek Pearson for showing this area to us.
area_getting_there: The most direct way to access the Moonworms area is to climb Straight Outta Squamish or Mercury Morris.  Alternatively, climb a route on Lolybird and do a short traverse to the left, or rap in from the top.

routes.route_name: Carefully Swallow the Metallic Noodle p2
routes.route_description: Pleasantly pumpy crack climbing.From the p1 anchor, traverse right to a bolt next to a crack.  Continue up the crack system to small ledge.  One can continue climbing on the right or left side of the ledge to reach an anchor with chains.  The top of the crag can be reached in about 30 ft.Alternatively, climb Crickets in Cardboard Box to reach the crack.
routes.route_location: Second pitch of Metallic Noodle. p1 is described in the Noodle wall area.
routes.route_protection: gear to 2",  1 bolt

routes.route_description: From the ledge behind Tower 7,  move left, clip a bolt and climb over a small roof. Upon reaching another bolt, move left along the ramp to the anchor for p1 of Carefully Swallow the Metallic Noodle.  The crux involves some thin laybacking near the end of the ramp.*** Noodle Box variation (10a):Upon reaching the 4th bolt, continue up p2 of Carefully Swallow the Metallic Noodle.
routes.route_location: Climb Straight Outta Squamish or Mercury Morris. Alternatively, climb a route on Lolybird and do a short traverse to the left, or rap in from the top.
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts, gear to 1".

route_comments.comment_text: Fun, varied route. And at the top anchors, you can set up a TR for a few lower Noodle Wall routes. There is also a continuation that goes left and up, though presently it needs another bolt. Edit to add: I nearly forgot the best line here: Space Noodle, which starts at the end of Crickets. Nov 30, 2022

routes.route_fa: J. Ranish, B. Stirling, J. Nelson, D. Pearson
routes.route_description: Climb directly above the belay clipping two bolts, also part of Moonworms face, before traversing left to reach the start of the crack.For an easier start, climb Crickets in a Cardboard box to the crack.Follow the awesome crack to a small ledge and a rest before tackling the crux which involves a thin crack and a traverse left below the small roof-like feature.  Ramble up easier terrain to an anchor.  The top of the crag is about 30 ft above this anchor.*** You Can Take us all Home Now Mr Philosopher (5.10):After climbing most of Moonworms crack and arriving at the small ledge below the crux, follow the thin crack left to easier terrain.
routes.route_location: Begin from Moonworms ledge behind Tower 7.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2", 4 bolts.  Brass offsets protect the crux nicely.

route_comments.comment_text: Put this one on the list of classic 11- Index fingercracks. Great fun in a beautiful, quiet spot tucked between Lookout Point and Planet Index. I only counted 3 bolts. The 3rd is about halfway up and well placed before the first bit of try hard. Crux takes good, small gear. Jul 16, 2022

Following the seam straight up felt like solid 11c/d to me though conditions were warm and a bit greasy.  Great climb!  3 bolts leading up to the crack, 1 bolt at a good rest before the crux Jun 9, 2024

routes.route_fa: M. Rynkiewicz, R. Hoover, C. Davis
routes.route_description: Incredible face climbing in a magical setting.
routes.route_location: Moonworms ledge
routes.route_protection: ~12 bolts

area_description: This sector lies just west of LO jr, just below Small Steps, just east of Lolybird, and directly above The Towers. Look for the long left-facing corner of "Easter" and the flake of the area's namesake.
area_getting_there: The recommended way is by doing a route at The Towers below. Alternatively, approach any way that you may use to reach the base of LO jr.

routes.route_description: p1: 5.10b. Climb a flake to a corner.  Interesting moves up the slabby corner lead to steeper, balancy climbing past 2 bolts.  Finish by moving left to an anchor at the base of a corner.p2: 5.7. Climb the beautiful corner and adjacent face to a bolted anchor.*** Whale to Easter connection (10) moves right after the second bolt of Balancing Beluga, using a horizontal crack to join Easter.  The Easter anchor works well for top roping this climb.
routes.route_location: The corner system left of Easter.
routes.route_protection: p1: Gear to 2”, small offsets or ball nuts useful. p2: 2 larger cams (~3.5") to supplement the gear from p1.

route_comments.comment_text: Bottom of the route has a flaring crack that looks sketchy for pro, but if you bring a nut tool and scrape out some pine needles, there's good finger-size placements deeper in. Sep 21, 2023

routes.route_description: This is the ferocious left-leaning crack on the face between Moai and Lookout Jr. Warm up with some easier climbing to the base of the arching crack and then get ready to pull hard. Eventually find a cool sequence to slap up to the arete but it's not over until you're at the chains. It's a little gritty but a great way of getting thrashed.Easy to top rope from Life on Pi? and variations with a directional or two.
routes.route_location: Obvious left-leaning crack between Moai area and Lookout Jr when you arrive to the area.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 1"

routes.route_description: Climb the attractive flake to a ledge, then move right (crux) around the arete and finish up thin cracks. Alternatively, from the ledge continue up the hand crack finish of Easter (5.8/9).
routes.route_location: The obvious flake located about 100 feet left of the Playground area.
routes.route_protection: One bolt, cables, supplemented with a small selection of small cams and stoppers. 3.5-4" cams protect the Easter finish

route_comments.comment_text: The cables provide convenient clips, but should be inspected. Give them a sharp tug and look at the backside if you are in a secure spot (as you probably will be), but don't clip them on the backside (i.e., inside the crack). Jun 21, 2022
Absolutely amazing route. Lots of good variation. There’s a spot for small gear protection between bolt 1 and 2 Jul 10, 2022
Our party of 3 found getting to the first bolt (wire) to be the crux. Nov 25, 2023

routes.route_description: Climb the Moai pillar using OW/squeeze technique.  Finish on Moai or Return to Easter Island.
routes.route_location: The obvious flake located about 100 feet left of the Playground area.
routes.route_protection: 3 cables,  a small selection of small cams and stoppers, a 5 and 6 inch cam.  3.5-4 in cams protect the Easter finish

route_comments.comment_text: A fun variation and rare treat at index. Arm bars, chicken wings, calf locks and some no hands and feet rests. Wires on the arete paired with a 6 and 5 for the last chunk before gaining the stoop or TR. It's short so enjoy the cheese grater while it lasts (if you're into that sorta thing). Nov 23, 2022
So, no laybacking? I like this concept. The squeeze at the start was always enjoyable, though never thought to continue it. Also, nice name. Nov 23, 2022

No laybacking, Jon! No need when you can chicken wing and knee lock most of it, so cram yourself in and enjoy the granite massage. Plus, you get to enjoy the views as you grunt your way up. May 21, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. Super fun! The upper wire definitely gets in the way of fun knee-jamming, though.

routes.route_description: Probably the most classic line here, though the competition is fierce. Though significantly harder, Easter is roughly what Senior Citizens in Space would be like if it faced left and was a thinner crack.One place down low tends to seep in winter and spring, but this spot can be bypassed using a face variation.
routes.route_location: Look for the broken pillar and flake of Moai. Easter starts just left and down the hill.
routes.route_protection: Small stoppers to about 3" cams (the large ones for the very top).

route_comments.comment_text: I found the transition from the two bolts on the face to the crack to be spicy (had to go that route due to seepage). Also, a purple Metolius Supercam fit amazingly well in the tight-fist (for me) sized upper crack; I placed one cam and bumped it to the top. Jul 10, 2022

I recall placing a cam in a horizontal crack to protect the moves back to the corner. Its too bad that the corner seeps.  Last year I think it was dry by July.  This spring was pretty wet. Jul 17, 2022
Bring some bigger nuts for the upper crack. I found the gear in the upper section a little tricky and wished I had brought them. Great route though. Jul 18, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Thin and spooky. Fell on .75 trying to reach up for the finger crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. Forgot the #4 and the top was kinda scary. Bring two #3's next time too. 0.2, atleast a black totem, and a 0.3/0.4 offset were clutch. · Lead / Onsight. Fun! Save a black totem for the top of the layback section. Can bump a #4 for the upper crack, but take care as it's pretty tight. · Follow. Super fun TR! Small finger laybacking on super grippy rock (truly a harder senior citizens) up to a perfect fist crack corner. Placing tricky gear in the layback will be the leader’s crux. · Follow. Fell right where the crack disappears on the right corner. Next time, left foot on the foot hold, bump right foot as high as possible, crimp with left hand and reach up until fingers fit in the finger crack. Cruisy except for the crux. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 hang going into the tips section, mental got really weak. save a .3 or black totem for the weird crack up high. · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Martin - in the short list with my favorite 5.9 at Index. Super fun! Save a #2 or #3 for the top · TR. Really good climb. Just wish there wasn’t seeping green goo half way up. · Lead / Flash. pro kinda gets real weird on this thing, but the movement is great! also my follower slipped off near the big block that sticks out and almost banged his head into it real hard. · Lead / Onsight. Somewhat tricky gear,black totem and #3 is nice for the top. Nuts useful · stuck to the crack the whole way, bit of a crux in the middle where the crack gets thin and it's a reach to the finger lock, not sure about leading, seems to protect but can't sew it up · TR. never really hard but I feel stretched out and never really comfortable, might be a stressful lead · Lead / Onsight. 5.9, only at Index. big nuts or maybe a passive cam placement in upper part of corner. Save a #3 for bumping in the corner after the ledge, #4 was tiiiight, maybe a 3.5 if you got 'em. tiny stuff too · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Zack Novak. Seep was real in crack. Did face variation. Used single 3 and 4 up top. Stiff for the grade. Quality route. · TR. The description for this route reads, "similar to Senior Citizens but a bit harder" and would like to add that I think this is a much stiffer/harder route. I noticed some really thin fingers halfway up. · Lead. Fell after 2nd slab bolt. Much harder when it’s wet and dirty, which it currently is! · TR. Brutal, I pulled gear, stood on bolts and almost barfed but supper fun · Lead / Redpoint. Clean lead! Needed small AND big pro. Little guys for middle section, 3” and 4” would be great up top. Gear was tricky. · Lead / Onsight. Wet in the middle Face bypass was wet as well but climbable. · Lead / Onsight. Super fun. Crux looks worse than it is, but still a bit tricky (AL) · Lead / Flash. Brought doubles 0.3-3 and single #4, placed #4 near start, used a large nut too (important). Some smaller gear in mide (some 0.3), then onto face slab for a second, then nut and up the crack and place optional #3 at end of that crack before mantling, then finally ends with a #3 wide corner crack that was tiring (bump the #3 up the whole way). Pretty good route, varied! Only used like 6-7 pieces. · Follow. good but not sure how I would protect the upper dual cracks, wet ad well. great climb but not as much as some of the others. · TR. TR'd from Moai, was a bit damp, did slab variation, gear might not be super straightforward but fun to TR

routes.route_name: Secret Scales of Guthrie Govan, The
routes.route_description: Boulder up to a high first bolt on big holds.  An interesting slab leads to an arete (which is also part of the route Just Look at Yourself Earth) and some gymnastic moves out right to gain the huge chockstone. A few moves up the face or arete of the chockstone leads to the chains.  One can also finish up a short crack on the left side of the chockstone.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: ~9 bolts.  One could place a hand sized cam before clipping the bolt on the chockstome.

route_comments.comment_text: Got a story behind the name? Not many Govans around here... And I know a few of them. Aug 10, 2022
It's a nod to the guitarist Guthrie Govan youtu.be/IaH2C2Qe97Y Aug 11, 2022

This route is great addition to the area, some tricky slab down low and cool movement up high, moving around onto the chockstone is good fun! Bolted very appropriately, moves getting to the first bolt are fairly straightforward. Aug 24, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Placed a 2 based on comments but not necessary at all. Fun climb. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell three times trying to clip 2nd bolt. Awesome technical slab climb · Lead / Fell/Hung. Technical slabby start leads to lie backing fun with gymnastic moves up top, clipping the first bolt is easy enough but the second and third can be kinda tricky to keep your feet · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fall down low on 3rd bolt I think. Gave it a TR burn after and sent (barely). Tricky! · Lead / Fell/Hung. sat on the rope to look at the route. good route though, loved the corner pull up top and the bear hug. · TR. Fell once at low slab crux (careful with feet!), once at top slab crux (reach high on arete for okay hold).

routes.route_description: From the start which is shared with That Night the Mountain Grew, enter the cave. From there, clip the bolt and climb directly up into the #3 crack to chains on the ledge, visible from the start.
routes.route_location: Same start as That Night the Mountain Grew, on the far right side of Moai / left side of Lookout Jr.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3"
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Hung on the overhang for awhile before getting a little help from the TR and making it over. I think this one is doable with some practice. · Lead / Redpoint. TR’ed once and then went for the redpoint. Very, very soft for Index. I’d go with 5.8 Index grade. · Lead / Onsight. Fun roof pull. Enough feet all around to make it not too difficult

routes.route_description: Climb a low angle corner crack to the base of the huge chockstone. Undercling the base of the chockstone and then gain the slab to the left of the chockstone on good jams.  Finish on a short hand crack.
routes.route_location: Right side of the Moai area.
routes.route_protection: gear to 3", 1 bolt

route_comments.comment_text: A fun & easy way to Moai ledge. You can then set up TRs for harder lines. Aug 22, 2022
Really fun route moderate route. Good pro with hand/foot holds where you want them. If you’ve made the trek all the way up here for Milkman, might as well lead this too! Sep 10, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Pull over the bulge on the right at the top, don’t finish on the gross ramp · Lead / Onsight. 10a to right absolute classic. kneebar crack glove repair is mandatory. · Lead / Onsight. Fun! Enjoyed the variety in moves. It's not every day I get to kneebar under a roof on 5.7 Trad. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 4 for the start, 3, .75, 2, blue totem, purple totem, 3 Super fun route, holds where you want them! Just search around.0 · Lead / Onsight. Fun route but mostly a one move wonder. TR’d the right variation after also which was more fun but similar one move wonder. · Lead / Fell/Hung. The 8 variant to the right. Hung on the 4 above the bolt then it went. · TR. Clean. Fun. Did the slab ramp to get up and it goes. Then stemmed the upper part to get to the good jam. · Lead / Flash. climbs fine and protects fine, just watch out for spider webs under the block · Lead / Onsight. Fun! Amazing #3 jam to go around the roof. Used 2 #4s on the slab down low. Then a .75 to protect the top out moves (and a 2 and a 3, but the .75 was probably enough). .3 - 4. · Lead / Onsight. lead the right crack in the main picture. solid, may need some cleaning. super fun · TR. Top roped the right side of the chockstone, fun! Rope gets stuck when TRing

routes.route_description: Start on Moai.  After climbing above the second (?) cable, move right following thin cracks, then move right again transitioning to the slab. Rejoin Moai to finish.
routes.route_location: Start on Moai.
routes.route_protection: Small wired stoppers and cams, 3 bolts.

area_description: The most prominent sector of Planet I, LO jr sits on the southern side of the ridge line down the east end, looking a bit like the right side of LO Point. Here lies the longer slab cracks, with plenty of moderates for those seeking 5.8 or easier. Much of this area dries very quickly after a rain, and its top is one of the best hangout view spots around. Also, for those rare sunny winter days, the area is hard to beat--you'll get warmed up on the approach and more easily stay warm in the sun.
area_getting_there: From top of PI:If you are at the top, just walk east along the rim and you'll see the top of the jr. From here, rap down (easiest to use two ropes).From LOP gully (west side):If approaching from the LOP gully, cut across the ledge just above the gully handline. Take care where you descend a section with another handline and walk across the top of Daddy and Inferno.From top of Hag (below Towers):If approaching from below, take the handline up from the west end of The Towers or top out on one of the tower routes. Walk a few steps up through the forest, and you are at the base.   Alternatively, find another handline on the east side of Tower 0 that provides access to the previously mentioned handline as it ascends behind Tower 1.From the east gully (shadier side):Yet another option continues on the trail to the east side of Planet index (a.k.a. the Dark Sides).  As the trail bends back toward the rock, look for a ledge system on the rock.  The ledges lead to the base of LO jr.

area_comments.comment_text: A route update for this area, plus a few others at Lookout Point, in two pdf files (total of 90 pages): Part A: tinyurl.com/2he6k92b Part B: tinyurl.com/2x9auhjp A fundraiser for hardware, other related: gofund.me/d8b48ad0 more A route update for this area, plus a few others at Lookout Point, in two pdf files (total of 90 pages): Part A: tinyurl.com/2he6k92b Part B: tinyurl.com/2x9auhjp A fundraiser for hardware, other related: gofund.me/d8b48ad0 Jun 22, 2022
Wow Jon, I'm just seeing this guide now for the first time and it's so impressive! Did you create it? Nov 20, 2023

routes.route_description: Three tools with a protective cap. The wire brush is the one most affected by rust, so please be sure this one at least is tucked up in the cap.Anyway, the same tools as at other stations: A wire brush, a broom, and a kama (serrated sickle). Be careful with the kama, particularly when still pretty new as it is sharp and prickly.Use for route maintenance, or route creation, then please put back here. Also post a comment if a tool needs replacement, thanks.
routes.route_location: At the base of Lookout jr, close to the start of Life on Pi. See the photo.
routes.route_protection: A biner or two should suffice. Gloves helpful, as is protective eyewear.

route_comments.comment_text: Use it! Mar 16, 2024

routes.route_description: Full name: Be a Stay-at-Home Astronaut, Make 5 Mill/yrNestled between Life on Pi Direct and the ever-popular Oyaji Milkman is a wide, easy crack that ascends upward to a shared anchor with Life on Pi?
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3''
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Easy lead, 3 purple would have been nice but OK w/out, gear to 2

routes.route_description: From the Life on Pi? anchor, traverse up and right to a horizontal crack system which leads to a small corner with good finger pockets. Climb the corner and the slab above it (bolted crux). Follow cracks to join Snow on the Mountain and the top of the crag.
routes.route_location: Start from the anchor at the top of Life on Pi? One can also start from the Oyaji Milkman anchor with a short traverse to the left. Also, easy to TR from the More than 24 D anchor.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3", 2 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Seems to get harder each time I do it. Fun though. Oct 3, 2022

routes.route_description: Layback the arete between Bobcat Overdrive and More Than 24. Crux is the initial bulge.Though Johnny D- may have little problem leading this, the rest of us should enjoy the toprope, which is easily set up off the anchor for More Than 24.
routes.route_location: Start on Buzz's Ledge.
routes.route_protection: TR anchor.

routes.route_name: Here’s Buzz Aldrin’s Plan to Colonize Mars by 2020 [video]
routes.route_description: Start on or just right of More than 24 Dandelions aiming for a low angle corner crack to the right of More than 24 Dandelions.  Continue up cracks and an arete near the top.  Shares the same anchor as More than 24 Dandelions.
routes.route_location: Climb Oyaji Milkman Loves the Sea to Buzz Ledge.  Here's Buzz Aldrin's Plan and More than 24 Dandelions start from Buzz Ledge.
routes.route_protection: Pro to 3".

route_comments.comment_text: Sorry, but we neglected to save the video. Rest assured, Buzz had a good plan. Sep 15, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. A decent amount of lichen and moss is growing on this route. · Lead / Onsight. Off the boulder to the right and into a nice little scramble through brush and low angle crack climbing. I went to the tree off the right side instead of staying onto the face. Cool jaunt up the right side of 24 dands. · Lead. Super dirty and neglected, not worth in current condition. Accessed via 'It Takes a Whole Cloud to Make One Raindrop' due to large party on route. Climbed dirty slab to the duel crack adjacent to Milkman. Belayed from Tree (could be a really nice 5.6 if cleaned). The route is very dirty with Selal growing in it, I pulled out a few. Accessing the anchor without reaching over to 24 requires some moss-slab moves. Just do 24 Dandelions unless you're interested in adventure climbing. · TR. Followed to clean. Took easy ledge around Climbers right (below tree) to finish which made it awkward to get to the bolted anchor. · Lead / Onsight. Fun but 2/3 up is a liggle vegetated. Best to bring follower up on this climb then rap from the top.

routes.route_name: It Takes a Whole Cloud to Make One Raindrop
routes.route_description: Start the climb up the ramp on the left-facing corner a few feet right of Oyaji (if you came to climb 24 Dandelions this serves as another approach). The single bolt (unnecessary for the climb) is visible from the base and will be a few climber's left of your ramp. Cruise the ramp up the crux, which is establishing yourself in the wider crack system above the stepper vertical section. Move up the crack to the top and traverse a few feet left around the large tree (alternate belay with backup 2" cam) near the base of 24 Dandelions.Most of the climb is low to mid 5th with a short crux protected by good gear (1-2") with good jams.
routes.route_location: A few feet climber's right of the main attraction (Oyaji).  It's the further right obvious climb on the far right of Lookout Jr.
routes.route_protection: Singles to 3"

route_comments.comment_text: While not as good as Oyaji (in my opinion), this is no more difficult and a less traveled alternative still providing access to 24 Dandelions. Being less traveled, it would clean up with further use. It's not problematic, but as of early 2024 both the lower section and traverse would benefit from additional climbers and active cleaning. Please consider using the tools available on the ledge to... more While not as good as Oyaji (in my opinion), this is no more difficult and a less traveled alternative still providing access to 24 Dandelions. Being less traveled, it would clean up with further use. It's not problematic, but as of early 2024 both the lower section and traverse would benefit from additional climbers and active cleaning. Please consider using the tools available on the ledge to do some community service. Given the rappel line, this would be best performed by those confident at the grade willing to do so on lead (note, the dirtier sections are generally much easier than the climb's grade). Your fellow climbers will appreciate your service. Mar 16, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. tried thumb push while staying left, as well as layback for the first low angle flake. Jammed up when the wall steepens. Pretty dirty routw · Lead / Onsight. Climbed as alternate to Oyaji due to large party on route. Went climbers-right at at the top instead of traversing left under the roof/boulder, seemed much more straight forward. Really dirty, definitely alpine style currently. Could be a pretty good route but needs some love (cleaning).

routes.route_description: One of three moderate cracks that make a great three climbs for one lead combo. Climb up the leftmost of the three low-angle cracks to the left of Oyaji Milkman. The crack begins around 1 inch (#.75 Camalot) and gradually widens to 3.5 inches (#3 Camalot) at the top. The crux comes at a bulge where the crack is more shallow than the rest of the climb. Bomber pro throughout. Use the same bolted anchor as for Life on Pi at the top of the crack system.Caution when lowering: there is potential to swing out climber’s left off of the large roof resulting in injury. Have a plan to mitigate this such as using a tram on the other side of the rope and leaving a few pro pieces clipped in. The same advice applies to the two cracks to its right. Or, one can do the old-style and belay at the top then rap down, going straight down (not to the route's base).*Embraced Then Fell Helplessly Down the Hill
routes.route_location: The leftmost of the three low-angle cracks just to the left of Life on Pi and to the right of a large drop off to the routes below.
routes.route_protection: Pro with emphasis in the 1” to 3.5” range (.75 to #3 Camalots). Single pieces from .4” to 1” (.2 to .5 Camalot) could find placements as well.

route_comments.comment_text: I gave this route a good scrubbing on 04/30/23. Worth doing if you’re already climbing the two cracks to its right. May 1, 2023
Thanks for the post and scrubbing Kyle. I just added an * to the title for the complete name. May 1, 2023
No problem, Jon. Feel free to correct the name at will. May 1, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Teacup jam for the second wide crack with footjam. Very dirty near the top · Lead / Fell/Hung. Basically aided my way up this at the start lol. The layback was hard for me. Psyched me out after my accident. Good crack at the top but it’s quite dirty. I would bring two-three 3s and two 4s next time I do this. A 5 is really nice to for a wider section. It was cupped hands/fists for me. *bad TR, either have someone follow through with a top belay or leave all the gear in and have them clean on the way up* · Lead / Onsight. Fun crack with a few variations, very enjoyable, a little bit exposed to make some of the moves onto the face · Lead / Onsight. First Index 5.8 clean. The lowering situation sucks. Might consider having a follower clean next time and lowering both leader and follower off cliff on climbers left of route to avoid swing. If leader clean on the way down, anchor belayer to a tree and make sure they’re standing in direction of pull prior to letting climber swing. · Lead / Onsight. Bit wet, with some growth in the crack. Could clean up to 3 stars. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on the opening bulge … it’s just a layback and it’s fine, just go. Alpine sling on the bolt please. 3x #2&3. .75 where I fell. Shallow bit is okay. High jam. Protects with a 3. Went all the way up then traversed down to anchor. Cleaned blackberries. · Lead. Rattly finger bulge was really hard to get toes in, and liebacking/smearing was mossy. Wished I had three 3's atleast for upper.

routes.route_description: Variation to "Life on Pi?" climb. After first moves up the starting flake, clip the bolt, ascend the slab to gain the crack. Follow the crack, clipping the two bolts along the way, and finish at the bolted anchors.Due to the traversing nature, care should be taken in placing gear if the follower is near their ability limit.CAUTION: As noted in the comments, there is a substantial risk of taking a bad pendulum swing while being lowered. To prevent such a swing, follow the natural fall line when lowering. Other ways to mitigate the possibility of injury are to use directionals while being lowered or, if the belayer is secure, clip a long sling from your harness to the other line (that goes to the belayer).
routes.route_location: Same start as Life on Pi?
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2" and a few draws

route_comments.comment_text: Probably harder for shorter folks. Perhaps the borderline is about 5'9" unless one has a big ape index? I'm about 5'8" with a 3-4" index, and it seemed like I barely made the reach. Oct 3, 2022

Take care when lowering/top roping/rappelling, the natural fall line does not follow the route and if you attempt to lower down the route itself or top rope it without directionals you risk a large pendulum fall that also may cause you to deck. Happened 2-3 times to different parties yesterday. May 1, 2023

Thanks for the heads-up Karl. Perhaps an obvious intermediate anchor to clip for a directional would help. On Friday I was over on the east end on LO Point and we heard what might have been a similar incident. Sorry to have heard that, and then your report. If TRing from the bottom, if the belayer is anchored (or quite heavy...), then another way to reduce slams from swinging falls is to... more Thanks for the heads-up Karl. Perhaps an obvious intermediate anchor to clip for a directional would help. On Friday I was over on the east end on LO Point and we heard what might have been a similar incident. Sorry to have heard that, and then your report. If TRing from the bottom, if the belayer is anchored (or quite heavy...), then another way to reduce slams from swinging falls is to clip a runner into the belayer's rope such that it slides up as one climbs. May 1, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Tried the start. Feet are bad. Could be fun heady slab. Potential proj · TR. At 5'5" I had to do a tough but cool no hands step up with my right foot onto a tiny pebble on the slab, to reach the crack. I felt pretty boss after that move, with an appreciative audience to boot. · TR. beta for shorty: look right carefully for small jibs as intermediate footholds, as we can't reach the bolt or crack from the ledge. · Lead / Onsight. Fun route. Slab move was a bit tricky, but not too bad (AL) · Lead / Onsight. Pulled the draw to reach the shallow crack then easy climbing above crack to slab to crack. This anchor placement is unfortunate- when lowering either commit to going off the cliff or clip into the other rope the whole way down.

routes.route_description: This climb starts from the little staging area at the base of Lookout jr.  Climb a flake to a small ledge, then move left to a flake crack.  From the top of the crack, easy friction past two bolts leads to a nice handcrack and a 2 bolt anchor.Life Direct (5.9) climbs past a bolt from the small ledge near the start to gain a crack.From the anchor one can continue on Snow on the Mountain or other climbs on the upper tiers of LO jr/Small Steps.CAUTION: There is a  risk of taking a pendulum swing while being lowered. To prevent such a swing, follow the natural fall line when lowering. Other ways to mitigate the possibility of a swing are to use directionals while being lowered or, if the belayer is secure, clip a long sling from your harness to the other line (that goes to the belayer).
routes.route_location: The base of Lookout jr.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2", 2-3 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: The direct start is nice and well-protected by a bolt. I recall it being quite reachy, so it could be much more challenging for shorter folks. Jul 18, 2022

Be careful when lowering your partner from this climb as it leans slightly. My partner lost his balance while being lowered around the 3rd bolt and fell off the edge of the climb towards Moai. He swung really fast and hit the rock wall and may have fractured his foot which took the brunt of the force. Not sure if anyone else has experienced this on this climb, but we did so please be careful.... more Be careful when lowering your partner from this climb as it leans slightly. My partner lost his balance while being lowered around the 3rd bolt and fell off the edge of the climb towards Moai. He swung really fast and hit the rock wall and may have fractured his foot which took the brunt of the force. Not sure if anyone else has experienced this on this climb, but we did so please be careful. Maybe leaving a piece of gear clipped would've helped. Sep 5, 2022
Thanks for the caution Mer, and sorry to hear about your partner. Same caution should hold for L & P, the next climb to the left (even closer to the edge). Sep 5, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Could have definitely lead it. Crux is the layback/mantle crack at the beginning. But it was easy on top rope · TR. Layback + left foot smear + right foot rand smear for the first leaning crack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the slab part just past the second bolt. I didn't trust my feet enough and the second the crack was barely in reach, I went for it and promptly fell off. Thankfully, no cheese grater. Second time, I was more confident with the feet and put my left foot in the small hole on the crack line and trusted it and it went. Also didn't help that my shoe was covered in dirt and twigs because I stepped on red cherry-flavoured candy (I could smell the artificial cherry). Probably lost some traction because of that. · Follow. Highly recommend rappelling the route instead of lowering, saw a nasty swing and slam over the edge today. If you need to clean/follow/TR/etc use redirects or anchor the belayer and tether into their strand. A 60m will reach the lower trail (climbers left) on rappel but make sure to tie knots. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on initial lie back and getting into hand crack (wet feet slipped) · Lead / Pinkpoint. James lead first up. Added a lot more pieces in addition to ones he placed. Chill 5.8 · Lead / Fell/Hung. Take down low to sort out the feet. Smearing was the answer. · Lead / Onsight. fun movement, definitely lower fall line and avoid the swing potential · TR. crux at start takes a good .75, the upper 3 crack is kind of shallow for hands but the cam was ok. · Lead. Fun climb! Lower is kind of a PITA. Doubles 0.5-2 was plenty, could place more if you so desired though. Jim took a swing on the lower, found best way was to trolley down, lower slowly at bottom, go off belay and clean first bolt at ledge, then down climb to ground. · TR. First move was really hard slab, the rest was really enjoyable crack climbing · Lead / Onsight. Life direct is like the most honest 5.9 at index, a one move slab wonder · Lead / Onsight. Did direct start (under first bolt), "Life, Direct" 5.9 in book. · Started this but really wasn’t into the weird 0.5 layback that is throwing you off the rock. Went back and continued on Life Direct instead.

routes.route_description: From Moai Ledge, go up right on easy face climbing to a shallow right-facing feature on the far left of the wall. About 5.8 to 5.9 climbing takes you to a slightly left-trending double-crack in a shallow corner. Follow this to the ledge (5.8, about 30 feet). Climb up the face to a very shallow, obtuse groove like feature (crux), clipping two bolts, then do some delicate smearing in the groove to the top.
routes.route_location: Ascends the far left side of LO jr, just right of the large open book and slightly up and right of Moai Ledge.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3", 3 bolts.

routes.route_description: Start from Buzz's ledge (big ledge on right side), climb with mixed techniques up the broken corner crack to a small roof with a finger crack coming out the right side. Follow this splitter as it widens to hands and goes to the top. The rock is really grippy and the angle is fairly low, so it may make for excellent practice at finger-to-hand jamming for the new trad climber. Old trad climbers like it too.As others have pointed out, this is easily linked with a pitch below. But if you have the time, belay at Buzz's where you can more easily watch your partner enjoy the jams.A little story about the name. On our last walk together in her old neighborhood, my mom and I got into counting dandelions in the yards we passed. Her counting was very slow, but that was fine with me as the number of dandelions were low, typically 10 or less per yard. Yet there was this one yard at the corner that I thought we should avoid, seeing as it appeared to have thousands. Somehow though, we did get to that yard, and we did start counting. As the numbers climbed, I started to feel a bit anxious. And then, a miracle: once my mom hit 24, she just said "Well, I suppose there are more than 24 there."
routes.route_location: The crack splits the top of this formation. It starts just above "Milkman" and can easily be linked with that pitch.To toprope or rap in without climbing to the route's base (and get down w/o rapping), you can approach by either side of Planet Index.1) Hike up the steep gully between Lookout Point and Planet Index. At the top, follow the trail straight back north that soon bends right. In about 20 paces, a side-trail branches off right and stays near the top of Planet Index. Follow to the obvious top to Lookout jr.2) Near the base of the above gully, and below Daddy Wall, go right on the trail along the base of The Towers. Follow the sometimes faint trail up the hillside just east of Planet Index. When you are level with the top of Lookout jr, cut left, directly over to the top. If you miss this, you go up and over a rise before hitting the side-trail mentioned in 1) above.Also, see the topo in the topo guide.
routes.route_protection: Nuts and cams to 3".

route_comments.comment_text: Four stars?  Seriously?  Should be five!  Very Squamish-esque. Jun 22, 2022
Incredible Jun 30, 2022
Beautiful climb and location! Jul 10, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. One of the best trad routes I’ve climbed. Great position and good placements. Would climb again · Lead / Onsight. Great crack climbing with good views. Dan said it was one of his favorites at Index. Can’t combine raps with a 70m on the way down. · Lead / Onsight. A lovely pitch. Lots of different moves, good views. Total absolute pain to hike to the crag tho. Be prepared for what feels like 1000 feet of straight up. It’s and index 5.7 but feels like a Squamish 5.8. Again, a neat spot. · Follow.
