Has a tricky start with a bulge but a good hand jam does exist to the left deeper in the crack. The 2nd half also was a bit thin, making thr feet not as secure · Lead / Onsight. Linked w milkman. Most finger sizes, only needed 1 #2-3. Super fun, crux is the broken bottom section, the upper splitter is a lovely pitter patter. · TR. Climbed this after Milky Man. First half is sporty and beautiful crack in second half · Lead / Flash. Lead after OM with Nick following. Enjoyed starting in the corner left of the anchor. Fun low angle splitter. · TR. Double team climbed this with Stockton. Seemed a fair bit harder than the 7s at Private Idaho, especially the slab party of Milkman, and getting into a crack on this one. · Follow. Followed ben on this, led 1st pitch. One Bouldery move otherwise fine would lead · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung on upper crack. Tired from day and previous day run. · Lead / Onsight. Led this twice, but the first time cut left halfway up and finished on the cracks that end the 10c sport route. · TR. Would be OK to lead. Top thin crack is the crux but was OK 1 foot and then some small features for right foot. · Follow. Amazing link up with Oyaji Milkman…super fun and the views from top incredible. You can go all the way up to the top and rap down or take hand lines up from Private Idaho area to get to the start of Oyaji · Follow. Patrick led. Seems to be the 2nd pitch of Oyaji? First move off the semi-hanging belay is very precarious. · Follow. Did as 2 pitches with Oyaji Milkman Loves the Sea. W/ Evan and Trudy · Lead / Onsight. fun little splitter, I had trouble with getting perfect finger locks at the beginning with my thinking fingers however the terrain is great both inside and out the crack. the crack (1/3rd the way up) does have a lip towards the outside so it may look thinner than it is for gear so keep in mind.

routes.route_description: He does indeed.This is mainly a layback and jam crack, thin hands to hands, on a relatively low-angle slab.
routes.route_location: At the bottom, start near the right edge, go up to Buzz ledge.
routes.route_protection: Nuts and cams to 2.5". Save some finger sized cams for the upper crack before the anchors. The slab section is protected by a bolt. Depending on how you start, you might clip one or two bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: Very reminiscent of Squamish slab on the apron, but with an amazing crack. It's a little easy to veer off-course, but keeping the in line with the anchor will ensure you stay on track. Jul 10, 2022

-3 routes up to the base of the start (head up the gulley, rope jungle gym, or follow the path) just above hag wall -this is the natural progression following 24 dandelion and could be thought of as the second pitch. You could probably also walk off 24 dandelions -this route and 24 dandelions both have bolted anchors with wrap rings Sep 5, 2023
Fun climb. This area is a great addition to Index. I thought the crux was the slab section but luckily there is a bolt. The beginning starts in a splitter low angle hand crack. Oct 12, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. I feel like I should have laybacked this and it would have been a lot easier but I was trying to crack climb it? ….and I’m not very good at leaning cracks so it was kinda awkward. it was fine but I didn’t feel the hype. · TR. Squamish 10a for sure. Reminds me a little bit of the slab cracks by Shannon falls. Beta is to have your feet in the crack and slowly inch up. Pretty nerve racking even on toprope. Kyle hung on almost every peice. There’s some very trustful slab steps you gotta do. Need a good lead head for this one. It’s a beautiful crag though. · Lead / Onsight. It was difficult for me to trust the slab portion but I got past it with some shakey legs. I stayed in the crack on the obvious layback for practice which was fun but strenuous. overall great climbing. Can be combined with 24 dandelions with a 70m · Lead. Yet another variation, this time moving right instead of clipping the bolt. With Sam. Approach (this time): moved right/east of the towers towards the gully, then followed the handlines up to the base of Lookout Jr. · Lead. Actually pitch 1 that leads to 24 dandelions. Starts easy, then some interesting well protected Slab moves, then a pumpier somewhat challenging small crack lay back. Glad it protected well. · Lead / Onsight. Skirted right at the first ledge, clipping the lower bolt right, (skipping the 2nd half of the splitter hand crack) to the right crack system to bypass the slabby upper bolt section (milkman direct). Crux was the upper layback section. Linked with dandelions, used doubles in fingers, only needed 1 #2-3. · Follow. Go right around the bolt. Payback crack a bit tricky. Hard for the grade · Lead / Onsight. Awkward beta. Stayed on the right side and jammed the crack, which made hands not secure. · TR. Tried the offwidth variation: switch between right chicken wing and right foot jam. Fun · Lead. Led the offwidth variation. Glad to have brought 2#4 and 2#3. maybe attach quickdraws before placing the cams as they might get out of reach deep in the crack. · TR. Second time is more flowy. For the slab, find tiny ripple, trust the foot and bump up, while pushing with the other foot, you'll be able to stand up. For the low angle slab, stay to the left and layback, slab makes the feet secure. Should be fine placing gear that way. · Lead / Redpoint. Followed clean on first go, then led clean on second go. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung on lead at second bolt. Then climbed clean on follow. · Lead. Climbed with Martin - It has a memorable foot smear as it tries and spits you out to the left · TR. Beautiful area. Great climb. Followed my son and cleaned the route while he belated me from the top. Good anchors! I didn't like the the approach while having to use the ropes. Glad they were there but not in my comfort level. · Lead / Flash. Skipped the slab. Little scary in the crack but great climb! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Jackie belay. This was my first ever crack climb, felt awesome to come back and lead it. · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Led p1 insecure slab and tough body position second half of the pitch · Follow. With Lani, would lead. Mock led, above ledge followed the left finger crack. Get feet in, not leanback, to feel more secure · Lead / Flash. Fun fun but man do I need to get better at efficient liebacks and protecting them · Lead / Redpoint. SO GOOD. Felt like Squamish. Bottom is a bomber 1-2 hand crack. After that it’s gross slab that has one bolt. I clipped the bolt then lowered down and went up right because fuck slab climbing. Super fun and tricky layback at the top. Very thin, used a blue and yellow metolious. Gets to like .75 at the top. Could use another 2-3 at the top to protect before the anchor. · TR. Slab in middle was crux and may not be fun to lead. Upper crack would be heady but OK to lead. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Forgot the layback beta and was trying to jam and smear in the crack and needed a couple takes. · TR. Fell at the upper crux on the offset hand-crack. Spooky slab felt heady but held well. · Lead / Onsight. Led this one. Found the slabby section protected by a bolt to be mentally the crux. Had a little bit of everything

routes.route_description: From Here's Buzz Aldrin's Plan, step onto the blank face to the left and friction your way up. Difficulty depends on how low you start, though some difficulty also exists at the very top where you may be tempted to escape left. Look for a key sloper or two and unlock the crucial combination.
routes.route_location: To the right of More Than 24 and left of Here's Buzz Aldrin's Plan.
routes.route_protection: TR from the More Than 24 anchor.

routes.route_description: Start on Moai ledge. Go up right to a small bulge, taking the right side (~8). Once on the sloping ledge, you might fiddle in some small gear here with a sling and then carefully traverse right (sloping ledge). Clip a bolt and climb the face to the start of the crack (~8+). Start jamming or laybacking this crack as it widens from thin fingers to solid hands (10a). Mantle the ledge on the right, move right a short bit to a set of double hand cracks that go up and left to the top (~6).
routes.route_location: Find Moai ledge, then look for the easiest way past the roof band.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3", 2 bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: Made for a good link from Life direct, very fun moves near the top! Jun 13, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Led after climbing Life on Pi? - really fun variety of movement

area_description: A steep wall section just off the LOP gully with a wide ledge cutting across that goes over to LO jr. Most of the ledge stays in the shade, but some routes can be fairly sunny.Routes here range from the 5.9 Punishment through some 10s to the hard 11s of Hell Poodles & Jethro's.
area_getting_there: From the gully, go up past the large three-trunked cedar, to just above the top of the handline. Cut right on the first obvious ledge.From the base of LO jr, walk down to the top of Tower Two then go right (west), being careful not to get too close to the edge. The sector starts from about where you see the handline (a different handline from that in the gully).See guide at left for maps with the approach and full listing of routes.

routes.route_description: Start as for Punishment (some steep face climbing on cool edges to a bolt, followed by a short roof/flake that takes good gear). Break right from the roof, traversing to a shallow, right-facing corner. Follow the bolts up the corner to a shared anchor with Punishment.
routes.route_location: Shares a start with Punishment. Look for the two bolts anchoring a handline down to the Moai area (might be good to anchor your belayer to one of them).
routes.route_protection: 7 bolts, some pro for the roof (.75" and 3" work well). Chain anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: Another steep and fun route. Jul 9, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. tronsite, think the crux was getting the upper crack started, left sidepull and right underclinglet me step up onto the slabby step and then the nice chip, then fingers in the crack and slab feet to the rock over

routes.route_description: Start as for Punishment on some steep face climbing on cool edges to a bolt, followed by a short roof/flake. Layback around the flake and, once on top, cut right through the shallower flake/grooves until rejoining Punishment at the upper bolt.
routes.route_location: Shares a start with Punishment. Look for the two bolts anchoring a handline down to the Moai area (might be good to anchor your belayer to one of them).
routes.route_protection: 2 bolts and gear to 3". Chain anchors.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Didn't know there are jugs around the right side of the crack. · TR. Pretty tired from the precious climbs but made it up with some struggle

routes.route_description: Starts with steep face climbing with a long reach, from where you clip the first bolt. Then undercling, jam, and layback around the flake (a little like a reversed mini Saggitarius). Where the crack runs out, resume face climbing past the 2nd bolt to the belay ledge.The crux may differ by person, though most likely at either of the two bolts.
routes.route_location: Look for the large flake looming above.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 4", 2 bolts.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Fun varied climbing on good stone. First pitch of my season, so felt pretty engaging. Would climb again · Lead / Onsight. With Jackson, pretty fun and scary to pull on the death pillar at the second bolt. · TR. tronsite, rather than put both hands on the ledge face start grab the right side thumb in, the easy reach to left edge. could probably lead this without too much crying

routes.route_name: Tip Your Hat to the Hummingbird
routes.route_description: Look for the groove-like feature at the left (west) end of Lolybird ledge. The crux is near the ground, and unfortunately very arm-span dependent.Start with a layback-undercling move or two on an overlap feature left of the first bolt. Reach right to clip the bolt, then reach a little more to a jug. Follow the jug line in the groove past two more bolts and continue on to the shady ledge above.
routes.route_location: Should be pretty obvious if you are at the west end of the ledge.
routes.route_protection: Three bolts, plus a few nuts or small cams. There is a nice little horn after the last bolt that you can securely sling.

route_comments.comment_text: Perhaps it's very height dependent (I'm ~6'2" with 0 ape index), but I didn't find the start to feel at all 10b or c (to me it felt similar to the start of Punishment and the Bunny next door). The climbing through the first 3 bolts was fun, but the route seemed to deteriorate into dirt and choss (there was a pretty large block that moved when I touched it and I had to be pretty careful to... more Perhaps it's very height dependent (I'm ~6'2" with 0 ape index), but I didn't find the start to feel at all 10b or c (to me it felt similar to the start of Punishment and the Bunny next door). The climbing through the first 3 bolts was fun, but the route seemed to deteriorate into dirt and choss (there was a pretty large block that moved when I touched it and I had to be pretty careful to avoid it). There also didn't seem to be anchors for this climb (maybe I got off route at the top)??? I saw an anchor to the left which didn't have chains (just bolts) and while it would be possible to traverse right to the anchors for Punishment and the Bunny, it would've resulted in the rope running over some trees in a not ideal way. I ended up rapping off to get down and get my gear back. May 30, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. first moves off the ground are good, then the route was dusty, then mossy, then you are reborn through a vegetation chimney. no rap rings. we traversed climbers right 30' on a ledge to rap rings down.

area_description: This is the section of wall along the LO Point gully above Daddy's and below Noodle and Lolybird. It mostly has cracks in shallow grooves.
area_getting_there: Various approaches take you to the gully.

routes.route_description: Start on Up Among the Firs.  After ~15 ft, move right onto a ledge.  Continue right and up to gain a nice right facing corner. Continue up the corner to another ledge and an anchor.
routes.route_location: In the Lookout Point gully, just above the triple cedar tree.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 1", 1 bolt. A 0 TCU and 4" cam could be used.

routes.route_description: Balancy climbing along a series of ramps. At the end of second ramp, climb the right facing corner (crux) to another ramp. Either move left and then up and right to the tree anchor or move right and finish on In the Heat of 2021.
routes.route_location: In the Lookout Point gully, just above the triple cedar tree.
routes.route_protection: 10 bolts. A hand sized cam for the left finish. Small stoppers and a 4" cam for the right finish.

route_comments.comment_text: If you like balancy thought-provoking climbing than this is the climb for you! I felt like an inch worm slowly and carefully traversing my way up the slab. The final moves may be a tad more exciting for shorter folks. Very safe and fun....get on it! Sep 6, 2023

routes.route_description: Engaging climbing along a ramp, then up steeper terrain to another ramp. Near the end this ramp, climb a flake to a final slab move before the tree anchor.Shares the same start as Franklin's Lost Party.
routes.route_location: In the Lookout Point gully, just above the triple cedar tree.
routes.route_protection: 6 bolts, single set of cams from .75-4, small stoppers.

routes.route_description: Start on Up Among the Firs.  After ~15 ft, move right onto a ledge and then up past 2 bolts to another ledge with an anchor.  The crux involves a few tenuous layback moves past the bolts.
routes.route_location: In the Lookout Point gully, just above the triple cedar tree.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 1". 2 bolts.  Bolted anchor.

routes.route_description: The first 30 ft involves cracks, side pulls, and jugs (5.8) ending on a ledge.  From the ledge climb the nice slab starting on the left side of the arete.  Move to the right side of the arete briefly before stepping back onto the left side, using the seam on the right side of the arete for holds (5.9). Belay/TR from an anchor on the large leaning tree at the top of the climb.This area is often shady and cool.
routes.route_location: In the Lookout Point gully, just above the triple cedar tree.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 1". A 0 TCU and 3" cam could be placed. Four bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: A fun link-up involves Up Among the Firs, Punishment and the Bunny (Lolybird area), Crickets in a Cardboard Box (Moonworms area) , and p2 of Metallic Noodle (Moonworms area). Aug 16, 2023
Nice cool spot on a hot summer day, and the route seems to lengthen as one climbs it. Also, good idea about that linkup. Make this part of a 4-pitch route to the top of Planet I. Aug 17, 2023

area_description: A short, shady, and steep wall at the base of Planet I, just west of the Towers. Routes have been done on just the lower part of this wall. The first one here, Bone Daddy, was done way back in 1992.A convenient ledge and handline runs across above the routes, making it really easy to set up TRs.
area_getting_there: Hike up to Planet I, and it is the first wall you encounter.

routes.route_description: Three tools with a protective cap. The wire brush is the one most affected by rust, so please be sure this one at least is tucked up in the cap.Anyway, the same tools as at other stations: A wire brush, a broom, and a kama (serrated sickle). Be careful with the kama, particularly when still pretty new as it is sharp and prickly.Use for route maintenance, or route creation, then please put back here. Also post a comment if a tool needs replacement, thanks.
routes.route_location: As you start up the gully, look for the first ramp cutting across the top of the routes on lower Daddy. See the photo.
routes.route_protection: Best to have a biner to clip and some sort of eye protection. Gloves may be helpful, though the tools are designed to keep knuckles away from rock.

routes.route_description: Do a few moves up a right-arching crack on a knobby wall. Clip the bolt and make the crux move to "the bone". However, it hardly lets up as you must now must try to compression your way up the bone while placing thin wired stoppers in the crack. After reaching the hand jams, the difficulty lets up a little, but remains engaging up the corner to the ledge.
routes.route_location: Look for the thin, right-arching crack to a bolt on the right side of the wall.
routes.route_protection: Lots of small wires, a few small cams up to about 2.5". One bolt.

routes.route_description: Two routes, both short.Mimi Nashi is a nearly vertical fingercrack-layback.The Dilbarian is a scruffy bouldering traverse below it.Both are easily TRed using anchors along the handline above.
routes.route_location: Left edge of Daddy Wall. The handline is reached by the gully trail at the second switchback.
routes.route_protection: Small gear if leading Mimi, though might as well TR it (and the half-dozen or so other TRs on this little wall).A spotter might be wanted at the end of the Dilbarian, though as bouldering routes go, this hardly qualifies as it is more of a warm-up traverse.

area_description: This short slabby wall is located just under the approach trail for Private Idaho and Hag Crag. It has a wide diversity of grades for its size, and most routes are easily toproped from the trail, including the open 5.12ish project
area_getting_there: Fork right from the approach trail to private Idaho just before it begins climbing the last steep hill, you can also set a toprope from the trail which will end up passing above the top of the area

area_comments.comment_text: This wall is a ton of fun, The 5.6 crack would be a quality lead for a beginner trad climber (probably with a pre-placed piece at the start though) and the two bolted routes to the right are short but awesome friction slabs. Definitely stop by this wall on your way to and from Private Idaho. Jul 14, 2019

routes.route_description: From the pedestal, follow a left-traversing seam into Moss Def. Pull some easy moves before setting up for the tricky finishing bulge.
routes.route_location: Far right of the lower buttress. Trudge up to the top of  the pedestal and clip the first bolt.
routes.route_protection: Bolts. One cam in the .75 - 2 range.

routes.route_description: Follow the rightmost seam on the Mossquito wall, thin gear and smeary feet make for an exciting climb, Pull up onto the small ledge 2/3 up the wall, and finish to the same anchors as Moss Def and Hit the Moss.
routes.route_location: Furthest right climb on the Mossquito wall
routes.route_protection: Gear to .4, micro nuts and a red ball nut very helpful, a number 1 for the finish. We used a questionable peenut as the first piece of pro, but a green/purple C3 might be better.

routes.route_description: Stem your way up a corner with a thin seam for the first 20 feet, before moving right to an juggy undercling traverse, and then romp up to the chains. A good warmup, and a nice route for someone early in their trad career.  Protection on the bottom section is thin, but a small nut, 000 c3, or red ball nut fit nicely.
routes.route_location: The buttress that one traverses above to get to Senior Citizens/ the rest of Private Idaho. Just before the hill to approach the main Private Idaho routes, fork right to get to the bottom of the buttress that this route, and it's two neighbors are located on. One can set a toprope on the two rightmost climbs on the buttress from the traverse above the buttress to the main Private Idaho routes.
routes.route_protection: Standard single rack, small nuts/c3/ball nut for the start.

route_comments.comment_text: 5/13/23 Brushed Feet and Cleaned Crack.  This is a fun short crack system. Tons of possible beta variations, jams, fists, stacks, or you can just under cling and walk up it. May 14, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. v. dirty first visit, semi cleaned on top rope. second visit fully cleaned with tools on lead. · Lead / Onsight. Not clean. Avoid this unless if it’s moss-free. Honestly not fun at all, would be better if clean · Lead / Fell/Hung. The first time I've ever fallen on this route, lol. It was mungey, and I was still getting my nerves back in my feet. · Lead. Need little gear for the start, one slab move feels a little tricky and having a small nut or .1 helps. · Lead. micro cams definitely helpful. looks like it can use more cleaning with each lead (used my nut tool to clean out placements). mossy looking slab up high still has good friction

routes.route_description: Almost nonexistant hands and friction feet make for a fantastic 5.9 introduction to Index slab climbing. Work your way up dishes and knobs to the ledge 3/4 the way up the wall, plug a #1 in the horizontal crack, and finish at the same anchors as Moss Def. Shares a start hold/first bolt with Frond Memories
routes.route_location: The route just to the left of Mossquerade, shares a start
routes.route_protection: Almost entirely bolted, a #1 for the horizontal 3/4 the way up the wall

route_comments.comment_text: This is a great route with fun smearing, and balancey rockovers, not a gimme for 5.9. The only negative is that its over too soon! very well protected. Harder than Frond Memories IMO. Jul 8, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Great route to practice friction slab. can go right of third bolt or straight past. .75 or 1 will do. dealer's choice. · TR. well bolted, description is spot on. might take a .75 & 1 for the horizontal. would lead · Lead / Fell/Hung. I've never fallen so much on a 5.9 (lol!) - at the 3rd bolt. And yes, i know how to climb slab · Lead. placed a red matter cam, thought it would sick but it was bomber · TR. french free lead, then clean TR. The moves are all there, just couldn't figure them out on lead.

routes.route_description: Pure friction crux. Bizarre body positions and desperate smears bring you up the center of the slab. All moves have been done but I was unable to send before leaving for the year. Go get it on the crispest of Index days.The grade is anyone's guess but it is significantly harder than Newest Industry, Sonic Reducer, or the slab pitch on And Say.Easily TRable from the trail above.
routes.route_location: Center line on the buttress you walk above right before reaching I am in top a Shader. Cut to the right immediately before the trail rises steeply.
routes.route_protection: Bolts (stick clip the first if leading). One cam in the .75 - 2 range for the top.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Was incredibly difficult, Need a very cold day to even have a chance

area_description: A cliff in the forest left of Rattletale.
area_getting_there: The topo (for School, Work, and Rehab) shows it in relation to Rattletale, so this may be the preferred approach. If so, from Rattletale, keep going left (SW) for about 1500'. Given this distance, it might be closer to the Upper Town Wall trail. More reports are needed.

routes.route_fa: Mike Schaefer, Allen Leber, Erik Snyder, February 2001
routes.route_description: P1: 5.10-. Climb a flaring crack, that is followed by a short vertical crack. Ends at a ledge with a tree.P2: 5.10-. Climb the chimney above. The crux is the exit move onto a ramp. Ascend ramp to corner, stem up corner, and reach for jugs. Belay at the tree above.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3".

route_comments.comment_text: It does seem unlikely to be clean, and also doubtful that anyone else has been here. Finding it would be an adventure in itself, but perhaps easier with all the development on Rattletale the past few years. I look forward to hearing more about this cliff--it looks to have potential. I just posted the above info as I found on the now-gone RCNW.net. Perhaps just in time. Mar 14, 2019
If I am remembering correctly ( a brief conversation 15 years ago in my garage with Erik and Mike) the route wasn't really cleaned before  it was climbed. Mar 14, 2019

I think I have walked by this in the last year. The variety of rock between rattletale and pressure drop wall is generally confusing to me. I know there is an area called "red wall" and "Index Eliminator wall"  I think the 2nd pitch of this route is cleanish as suggested. Mar 14, 2019

area_description: A small block at the top of Lookout Point. The flagpole as well as ancient cable and metal posts remain as remnants of earlier sightseeing times. It still attracts hikers looking for views.
area_getting_there: Most visitors probably come up the steep gully between LOP and Planet Index, though one can approach several other ways as well, including coming up via some of the pitches below.

routes.route_name: Lost Packing Slip for 3 Cases of Beans
routes.route_description: A nice fist crack with a few offwidth moves to the flagpole ledge. This is one of many fun options for finishing climbs on the Lookout Point Apron or Burt's Alpine Dirtbus.
routes.route_location: From Dimples Ledge look for the obvious fist crack in a right-facing corner finishing to the right of the Flagpole.
routes.route_protection: Something smaller for the base then #3, #4

routes.route_name: Sky is the Fly, Little Spider, The
routes.route_description: May be the shortest route at Index, even shorter than that boulder problem just to its right. On the other hand, it is a fun 10' in a scenic spot. Anyway, very overhanging with huge jugs, followed by a mantle (or beached whale move) next to the flagpole.
routes.route_location: Near the flagpole on top of Lookout Point, just right of the wide crack on the western edge of the summit block.
routes.route_protection: Clip two bolts. Then, at the top, just walk around the flagpole and tie off.If you don't have a follower, you can retrieve your gear yourself. Carefully reach over the edge and unclip the top bolt, then walk around and unclip the bottom one.

routes.route_description: Short fingers to hands-sized crack to the immediate left of the #3, #4 crack Lost Packing Slip for 3 Cases of Beans. Harder then it looks from the ground.
routes.route_location: On the Flagpole Block
routes.route_protection: Spring-loaded camming devices

routes.route_description: Climb the rail out of the 60* overhang. Powerful, dynamic climbing on good holds at the very top of Lookout Point, with sweeping views of the Valley. What’s not to like??If this were a boulder problem in Leavenworth it would be one of the area’s best problems. Somewhere in the V6-8 range.
routes.route_location: Just below the flagpole at the top of Lookout Point.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts, flagpole anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: Nice spot to hang out up there. I was wondering if someone would do this line someday. The day came sooner than expected. Good job, guys- Jun 2, 2021
Thanks, Jon! It was Michal's vision to do this one. We had a blast putting it up. When did you think it would get done? Jun 3, 2021
thankfully it ended up being not so hard as we thought it might be. i think it’s a very accessible send for those who like to boulder Jun 5, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Many falls. :) Got really close on it by end of day, but just didn't have the power left. Next time for sure!

area_description: The large, low-angle buttress feature on the east side of LOP. The base has steeper routes on its western edge, the eastern edge merges into a steep gully often used to gain the top flagpole area. The easternmost routes tend to have more shade in the afternoon. An old classic here is Steel Pulse, which has an excellent moderate crack at the start, followed by harder slab and friction above.
area_getting_there: Easiest and quickest from the Trillium trail, coming up just west of Hag Crag.

routes.route_name: All the Fallen Stars, Picked Up, in my Pocket
routes.route_description: Nice long pitch of corner cracks and slab.Climb a low angle groove to a LFC (crux) which leads to a long low angle RFC that curves to the right.  At the end of the corner, move left along a small overlap to a ledge with a 2 bolt anchor.  From here, one can continue up a 1 bolt slab to the Jolly pocket ledge.  The section after the LFC is actually part of the route Bad Reputation.Rope drag can be an issue on this pitch.Also, if it hasn't been ascended in months, it may be nice to have a nut tool in case some good placements have filled with debris. The bottom groove tends to collect tree debris.
routes.route_location: About 45 ft right of Steel Pulse at the east end of LOP.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2.5", 2 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Really nice jams on this climb. Weaving between bulges, the crack curves left, then right, then left. Here there is an anchor if the rope drag is too much for the final slab (8).  Perhaps the best place to extend pieces is at the right bend. Parts of this pitch are on the old Bad Reputation climb. Jul 3, 2022
Great climbing! With extension rope drag was not a huge issue. Takes gear well. Aug 14, 2022

Fun climbing once you get up to the layback, the lower portion of the climb is filled with needles and could use more traffic to clean it up. I stayed in the crack all the way until it peters out and you have to cut back left to the chains, it sounds like this is the finish for Baron Greenback. Are the 3 bolts up to the left on the slab (pink line in JRanish's photo) the intended finish for... more Fun climbing once you get up to the layback, the lower portion of the climb is filled with needles and could use more traffic to clean it up. I stayed in the crack all the way until it peters out and you have to cut back left to the chains, it sounds like this is the finish for Baron Greenback. Are the 3 bolts up to the left on the slab (pink line in JRanish's photo) the intended finish for the route? Sep 10, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Fun; lower parts wet day after rain, upper parts pretty dry · TR. Feels much easier now. Without the slab finish this is easier than Hag Crack. · Lead / Flash. Crux finger crack feels a lot more secure than I expected from below, with solid stances for placements. Save a smaller piece, say .2 - .4 for securing the short undercling slabby traverse right below the bolts. · Lead / Onsight. So good. Looks a lot harder than it is, particularly the last traverse left towards the anchors · TR. Can set a TR from the top of the first pitch of Cloudbeams · Lead / Onsight. Great pitch…especially area around the roof thing…only led to the end of v shaped thing/end of crack then bailed right to bolt · Lead / Flash. Haley lead. I extended almost every piece to reduce drag. It worked pretty well. Finishing chains are to the left. Max tr’d after for ease of cleaning this route. · Lead. Climbed with Martin - I really like this pitch and P2 of Cloudbeams to show visitors who climb in the 5.7-9 range how great Index is. You get great views and very fun climbing. Also by the time I get to the base of Planet Index approach Im like this is just as fun and less hiking lol · Lead / Fell/Hung. Made it to the head point slab at the top. Scott says it’s 5.4 after that but heady. Place doubles .2-3, triples .3-.75 and could have placed more. Watch rope drag. Lay back left crack is the crux but feels quite secure. Slab crack to the right after is also fun and secure. Super fun route will come back and lead. Bring at least much this gear. · TR. Fun climb, the crux on lead is maybe the first leftward crack and rope drag at the end. Zigs left, then right, then left back to the anchor. Last bit of climbing is easy slab undercling trverse on a .2, but with rope drag it'll be a bummer. · Lead / Onsight. First index 5.8. wasn't ready. Almost had a really bad fall · Follow. Lots of lie backing which was simple but a bit tiring. True crux was probably the slab or underling section at the top, but on right top rope it was easy · Lead / Onsight. Really fun route! With Dan. Awesome day. This one had it all: some jams, stemming, lie back, and slab. Took it all the way to the top ledge above first anchors. · TR. Awesome to watch Calvin move through it. Gave it a go for the TR to close out the day, pretty fun sticky slab with a good groove to it. Worth the time. · Lead. Bring a .1 and .2 for sketch slab protection. Double edge sword of “protecting” slab but adding rope drag · Lead / Fell/Hung. Great, long pitch. 1 0.1 and 2 0.2 X4’s were clutch for the slab. A small nut would work well for the final placement. The slab looks more intimidating than it is. No hanging around next time! · Follow. fun! I tried to go up onto the slab midway through the RFC but the slab was very dirty and I think going until the end of the RFC is correct but adds some rope drag · Lead / Onsight. Super fun, bring all small stuff for last bit, was happy to have triples in finger sizes (and .5 or maybe .75). Full 35m · Lead. This was a lot more fun than expected, great jams and some spice at the end. · Lead. Finished Jillian’s bail from the RFC onward. Always more draws including 1-2 doubles · Lead. Climbed with a 69m rope to the Rojo anchors and was able to top rope. spicy moves stepping around to the anchors. · Lead / Flash. Did this once with Adam last year (2022), fun traversy climb with a slightly sketch slab finish · Lead. Never used anything bigger than a #1, was glad to have a lot of .3-.75 . Used a .2, no .1s, bring nuts · Lead / Flash. Super super fun and great views from the top! Doubles 0.2-0.75, single 1,2,3, nuts worked just fine, 1/2 would fit up high if you wanted/needed. Decent 0.2 protects traverse to anchor (undercling makes this pretty easy). Bring lots of slings/draws, 10-12 would not go unused. · Lead / Onsight. Great climb. Got the chance to chat with Jon Nelson on the upper half as he was working on Sastrugi and Cloudbeams · Lead / Fell/Hung. with wren. Took more than needed. Bring lots of .4 and .5's lol · TR. lead the bottom until making the mistake of turning right onto the baron. took a circuitous route to the top, then rapped down to TR the proper route · Lead / Onsight. Really fun climb and will be even better as it cleans up. “RFC” was easier than it looked. 8 slings were not enough! Crux for me was the last bit up and left to the anchors. · TR. first index 5.8. last few moves to anchor were tough. I used a fixed line last 15 feet. great route!

routes.route_description: A three-pitch moderate route on the far eastern edge of Lookout Point. Fairly non-intimidating (low angle, big holds,  plentiful gear, and easy escapes to nearby gully), so probably a good beginner multipitch experience.The route goes into the shade in the afternoon, so it can be a relatively cool outing on hot days. Also, the first two pitches tend to dry quickly after rain.As it it new, leaders in the first parties on it should probably bring a nut tool to scrape dust & debris out of some placements. Each pitch described below has several possible variations.p1 (5.5): Start with some slightly left-trending face to reach a low-angle ramp at the base of a right-facing corner. Jam, layback, or face climb up this corner, which is the crux of the pitch. The crack bends up left while simultaneously becoming a blocky rib. Enjoy grabbing jug after jug on this section, and practice placing nuts (lots of excellent slots). Stay on the left side of the rib. At the ledge on top of the rib, clip the bolt and traverse up and left on a rail to join a jumble of flakes that become the Jolly Pockets ledge. Belay on the right side, closest to the gully. 60m to 65mp2 (~5.5-5.8): Go up the splitter crack ( ~5.5) then friction right at the bulge. Overcome the bulge on the right side, then trend up and left to an anchor. (For the bulge, if you go all the way to the right, then you are going around it, making it 4th class. But if you go over at the crack, it is harder than 5.5, probably about 5.7 to 5.8.)p3 (~5.5): Not the prettiest pitch, but it gets you to the top. For this pitch, you have to cross a groove-gully of poor-quality rock near the start. But if you go up first on solid, but easy, slab to the roof and then go right, you can essentially step over the bad section on a ramp. (Avoid the temptation to instead go directly right from the belay or you will face the sketchy rock.)  Once on the ramp, you have a choice of two cracks. Both take you to a sloping ledge below a roofy section. Avoid the roofy section (if you want, or take the obvious hand crack through it) by going left to the anchor then up on stacked flakes to a steep ramp going up and right, above the roofy section. There is an anchor just above, but to reach the top, go right and up the ramp to the apex. There is sometimes a handline coming down this ramp.  The belay is just over the apex. The handline takes you to the summit pine forest and flagpole.
routes.route_location: Follow the trail along the base of LO Point to nearly the point where it goes left up the gully. About 20-30 feet before this point look up. A log provides a seat if needed.
routes.route_protection: Wired stoppers to 3" cams. On the last pitch, one larger 4" cam could be useful, though not necessary. Also, one can instead take different finishes to avoid the wide crack.

route_comments.comment_text: Nice work getting this done! Apr 28, 2023
Nice multi-pitch mid 5th class climb.  The bulge on p2 felt like 5.7. Apr 29, 2023
Wonderful climb to get up to lookout point with. Protects really well and has some fun moves. Finished on the Jolly Rando crack for p3 which was a nice variation May 21, 2023

The “crux” bulge move on pitch 2 goes very easy with like a couple high foot moves. That said if you’re learning trad leading this one is perhaps even better to practice on than other commonly cited beginner climbs such as Senior Citizens. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Just p1 from ground start. Evan belay. Length of pitch forced me to learn to run out gear placements. Didn’t use anything larger than a #1, wish I conserved the 0.75 a bit longer. · Lead. Lead / Flash. w/ Phillip. Led 2 and part of 3. Accidentally did p1 of jolly rando. Super fun one with Ethan…second pitch is a gem with perfect splitter. Ethan’s first time rapping · Follow. followed lecia’s lead, lead and set up anchor after the last pitch to walk off! · 5 pitches. From there, rappel to lookers right to a flattish ground in the gulley. From there, hike down the steep but obvious trail in gulley. · Lead. Led p 1 super fun. Kate led 2 and 3. Climbing was easy and chill · Lead. Climbed with Zach. Climbed the right hand crack on P3 this time - it was pretty fun 5.9 or 5.9+ move. · Lead. Rope drag was pretty bad on pitch 1, so extend where the line turns; crux of pitch 2 comes at gaining the bulge, I put right foot on the slab and pull on a good left fist jam; large portion of pitch 3 was wet and or dirty, be prepared for rope drag. It started raining on us during P3 and made for a not so fun rap out. · Lead / Fell/Hung. did p3 as either JR3 or AB3 - the overhung .75 crack on the right. couldn’t ring lock the crack, felt like a v2 boulder problem maybe (sequence: grab the dagger with the left, gaston on the low jug with the right, left foot in the crack, heel over the right) · Lead / Flash. Multi-pitch trad graduation climb. TR’d the final layback crack (“4th pitch”) that Kelsey led. · Lead / Onsight. Only did P2 and P3. Came from Fallen Stars and then did the off width to finish it off. I led P2, Zach led P3 · Lead / Onsight. Fun speed route with Austin and Jonathan in approach shoes. Finished by going up the hand crack in the middle of the face. · Lead / Flash. With Ellie. Led p2 and did stars and packing slip variations. 3rd pitch was wet and meh. Didn’t extend enough on traverse · 2 pitches. Lead. Started on P2 after Defeat Baron Greenback. Wasn't sure where to go on P3, so went to the chains under Lost Packing Slip and Dan lead that to the summit. · Lead / Onsight. I accidentally started on Defeat Baron, which was buried in dirt and needles and had me pretty gripped. P1 slightly lose jugs P2 low angle hand-finger crack P3 funk · Lead. Kat lead p1, p3. John p2 Best pitch is p2! Next time I’d just do p1, p2. Pitch 3 ain’t anything · Lead. Climbed with Kat.
