There was an old trail we took down to town that delivered us into the Grafton's backyard. From what I read, Sam died in 2018, so... more Neat to hear of this bit of history, Doug. JT = John Tezlaff? In 2013, Eric H- and I saw some super-ancient looking ropes and a ladder just to the right of that PT Cruiser, though who knows how long the rope took to get a layer of moss, maybe just 10 years. There was an old trail we took down to town that delivered us into the Grafton's backyard. From what I read, Sam died in 2018, so apparently he and Fred had abandoned the crag long before. Probably didn't name it after themselves though. It would be neat to hear more about the early scrubbing missions. The only bolt I noticed was over on what is now Pumpkin Spice, though Ben found others.  Anyway, as this is closer to town than Hag and Zappa, both of which were clearly climbed on by 1980, so I suppose this one too probably had pre-2000 explorers and ascents. Aug 4, 2022

routes.route_description: Named after my paternal grandmother, Carol.This climb starts out a little tough, but the other 90% is just sweet and nice.Begin with a boulder move to stand on top of the boulder. Walk a few steps up the boulder and then enter a well-protected 0.5-ish corner crack. Once you're standing on top of the sloping mini-ledge make a step across right to stand at the base of a solid finger crack seam. Take this up to another ledge, then zig right and zag left to the chains.This all-gear trad climb comprises several small sub-sections of airy fun moves on mostly great holds with well-protected rock. The start may be a little tough and crumbly, but as soon as you get past it, the rest of the climb is incredible.
routes.route_location: Just to the left of Harambe and to the right of Shirlene, this climb begins on the right-side of the boulder that Shirlene starts on
routes.route_protection: Standard Index rack with 1-2x 0.2" cams (black totem useful)

route_comments.comment_text: The crack right after the bouldery start is a bit dusty. Otherwise this route is STELLAR! On-sighting it is especially exciting. There are couple of sections where you don't see what is ahead of you, you climb into unknown and it is all there - holds, gear. Except the bouldery start I would say all the moves on this route is probably not harder then 9+. Aug 22, 2022
0 star start, 4 star route once you get past the crumbly, awkward and strenuous beginning. Rest of the route is 5.9+/10a, start felt at least 2 letter grades harder Aug 30, 2022

The small flake/jug over the lip at the start flexes when pulled on. It's fairly small and seems secure but I would be wary as the belayer. It was pretty crucial for me so I'm not sure if the grade will change if/when it rips off. Great route! Jun 10, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. I thought it was hard for a warm up and I got pretty pumped. But cool climb. Double rack is fine · Lead / Fell/Hung. w/ sam! first climb of climbersfest! fucked myself with rope drag, spent a minute trying to pull up enough slack to clip the chains, rested with an armload of rope in my mouth, ended up having to grab the chains to clip. otherwise was clean! first 5.10 on gear! · Lead / Redpoint. Got the red point! Carol and I are buds now. As I said before, such a good route! · Lead / Onsight. 2x Black totems and 2x #.75. Be careful with rope drag; extend the bottom pieces. · Lead / Flash. Such a good line! I think it’s a classic in the making - pumpy, ended up hanging because I’m weak. But so good · Follow. Followed Stephen’s lead. Dirty, sharp, balance, and gear was tricky. Glad that I was following. · Lead / Onsight. Excellent route, start is not that bad. Take care of rope drag, it gets really bad · Blue & green alien, red alien Orange metolious .3,.4 double.5-2 Maybe extra yellow/grey aliens!? · Lead / Redpoint. Whole thing clean expect pulled chains on the last move… did not extend for rope drag well. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Water coming out of final crack system on traverse to chains. Was difficult not to get your hands drenched in water. Bolder start was more committing that it originally appeared from the ground. Next time consider placing gear from lock off right before you mantle in middle section of climb. #1 C4 was great. Be mindful of the rope drag! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Great climb, felt appropriately spooky for the crag leading this for the first time due to the committing moves. Will come back for the send. Black or blue totem, or #2 slightly higher to protect the low crux - stem into the big round sloper (more positive on the left side as a sidepull). Then R foot on good chip, jam both hands in some order in the crack, L foot rock over onto sloping ledge, L hand up on sidepull edge of strata, stand up. Crux sequence leaving the first sloping ledge: .4 around corner, balance on good foot on face to the right, .3 in finger crack. Work up finger crack with L hand to hidden jug around the next ledge (R hand). Place #1 in horizontal. Instead of mantling, continue left to another good incut hold, work L hand to it, then foot up onto ledge and big move R hand to crimpy sidepull. Stand up and get L hand to good sidepull just above. From there, place shallow .75 in pod on the right. Work up and right on jug rail and place a .4 or .5. Keep working right and mantel. Throw in #2 at the rest. Work R hand into furthest left good jam in crack. R foot up onto small slopey hold, L foot way up and left onto another small foot. Work hands on slopey but decent ledges up and left to anchor. No good clipping jugs so be careful. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Max lead. Had some takes. Haley flashed on TR. would love to lead- only heady part would be mantling above finger crack section. So fun though. Max trd after and also flashed. Beta for boulder problem start, right hand on good left facing hold, left foot out to little spot on face, then reach left hand up and over to great flake · Lead / Onsight. Climbed as warmup with Tim and Jess. Fun route, thuggish start. Would do again for sure · Lead / Flash. Dunno why commenters are hating on the first moves, they're great bouldery fun and the rest of the route is great wandery crack climbing. Good route. · Lead / Onsight. Fun steep climbing great holds and prop where you need it. Boulder move of the ground is the crux but protects well with a .5 then 2 above a perfect hand jam (back clean .5 after placing 2) · Lead. Lead with Fin. Had to come off the boulder to sus things out but hopped right back on and flashed the rest of the climb. First real trad lead, soooo fun.

routes.route_description: An alternate start to Carol that's so good it deserves its own route.Start in the easy left leaning ramp to a short 5.11 crux move.Once through the crux, walk left along a dyke to a rail that takes you up right below the perfect finger crack seam on Carol.
routes.route_location: Just right of the standard Carol start, just left of the start for Harambe.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3", a larger cam bay be useful but not needed. There's generally good gear the whole way.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. Harder than 10a. Loose crumbly rock on the bottom. Top is one fun problem after another that looks improbable but it's there. Clipping chains is tough

routes.route_description: A long fun route on the left side of Halloween. Follow up a sweet 5.8 undercling ramp to a giant ledge then either follow the finger crack or walk 10 ft right down the ramp and climb up the slot to four bolts over a series of overhanging blocks. Pull and work your way up the blocks before you pump out and enjoy the view from the top.
routes.route_location: The farthest left route at Halloween. Walk up a dirty ramp left of Lisle and then scramble over to the base of the ramp near a big tree.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 1, 6 bolts plus chains. Stick clip is probably useful for the first bolt.
routes.route_tick_comments: · 3 pitches. TR. TRS. The undercling before the bolts was wet :( fun moves up top

routes.route_description: A fun sport climb that pulls over an improbable roof on surprisingly good holds for the grade. Once above the roof the fun isn't over as you will find a fun mix of good and challenging holds. If the going gets tough, you can also escape right to a fun rail system for an easier time.
routes.route_location: The first route left of Heebee Geebees underneath an imposing roof about 15-20 feet off the ground
routes.route_protection: 9 bolts to mussy hooks
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. pretty hard. Very reachy (and at 6'2" I don't usually say that). · Lead / Fell/Hung. Dogged and aided to top. Too hot needs colder temps to even have a shot. · TR. Classic cryptic techy index face climbing. Full-on project to our this one together.

routes.route_description: What probably used to be a really cool chimney, but has since largely turned to clay after holding up a rotting tree for a period of time (possibly due to a process called Feldspar Weathering). If someone has the time and energy to clean this up it could probably turn into a perfect chimney practice route, but for now it's just dirty TR chimney practice.
routes.route_location: On the far right side of Halloween
routes.route_protection: There's nowhere good to place a cam or bolt, so this is really just a solo or TR problem at the moment

route_comments.comment_text: Fun and easy first chimney. I used I'll Never Let go to establish the top rope. Oct 16, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. TR. Fun and easy first real-world chimney. I used I'll Never Let go to establish the top rope.

routes.route_description: One of the best routes at Halloween. Start in a short left-facing crack below a slab and then traverse up and right to a bolt. Pull a set of engaging moves at the bolt to gain a flake. Climb the flake to join a set of double cracks that eat gear. Follow the double cracks up and left to an exciting Gorilla Hug at the top of the wall before stepping left to finish on a ramp up and left. There’s a nice granite chair to belay from up top if you want to reduce rope drag.A Couple Notes:1.It is very difficult to clean this route on rappel, given the traverse - it's much easier to clean this while following.2.The majority of this route was originally done in 2009 by JT and named PT Cruiser. One could argue that Harambe is just a variation of PT Cruiser, but given that there was no prior knowledge of PT Cruiser at the time I made this page, the separate crux sections, and the simple fact that I've grown unreasonably attached to the name Harambe, I've chosen to keep Harambe listed separately.
routes.route_location: Starts in a left-facing crack below a large slab and left-leaning double-cracks
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3"

route_comments.comment_text: Beta spoiler: If you're leading at your limit, play this song as you start. If you climb quickly enough, it will power you through the crux. youtu.be/GibiNy4d4gc?featur… Jul 19, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Pulled through the crux and would've certainly had the onsite... if only I'd managed my rope drag better. Extend those pieces below the roof (obviously) I ran outta runners. Came back the next day for redpoint. Cleaning the route was not easy for us, my buddy trammed the whole thing from the pt cruiser anchors, which seemed kinda sketch and he couldn’t unclip the bolt down lower without swinging into a wall. I decided to down/side lead back to the top of the roof and french-free to the Sam (.12a) anchors. The only issue there is that you must trust a huge detached block to gain the ledge where the anchor is. It seems solid, but it looks scary, and there really is no way around it · Lead / Onsight. Slab start could use another bolt… Then some moderate jug pulling to a cool roof crack feature. Then a crazy juggy roof pull! · TR. Followed with one hang at bear hug roof crux. Tim Matsui led. Really good climb, would love to lead on a cooler day · Lead / Onsight. Very fun battle when the hand jams disappeared With Andrew but maple and Jess and woody too · Follow. W gmac. Took a hot second n a couple hangs to figure out crux · TR. Holy cow! This is a gem. Classic features, great flow and an airy position. · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. 1 lap lead, 1 to clean. w Taylor and dogs

routes.route_description: A striking overhung corner crack that stays tough and gets progressively more difficult through the first set of anchors. Start in the obvious crack and work your way up, placing gear mostly wherever you want, until things get a bit more difficult. Finish strong through the top to a set of anchors about mid-way up the wall (this anchor is shared with Pumpkin Spice).A second pitch existed for a short time, but was later removed because the climbing and protection weren't very good. However, if you want to finish at the top of the wall, you can go right and finish on Tower of Terror.
routes.route_location: On the right side of Halloween just to the right of a large roof lies in obvious overhung corner crack.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3"

route_comments.comment_text: There is a large detached block about halfway up that is lodged in the crack that should be avoided for protection, until above. Jun 12, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard and burly. Beta intensive. Loose/Detached block halfway up - better to just not protect and wait for the next section. · TR. Tried it twice and made some progress thanks to Andrew’s beta. Hard and tricky, would be scary to lead. · Lead / Fell/Hung. I think this will go for me with a few more attempts! Remember, look for the good little spots for feet at the top. Can get a cheeky.1 before the top out. · TR P1, Lead P2 Went right at the top since there is no pro for the last 15 feet and the climbing is very far from trivial.

routes.route_description: A slightly harder sibling to I’ll Never Let Go. This 3-bolt climb shares the same first bolt as I’ll Never Let Go before traversing a bit up and left through a couple slabby moves to the chains for Sink Semper Titanics.
routes.route_location: Just to the right of the right-leaning Sink Semper Titanics seam on the far right side of Halloween. This route shares a first bolt with I'll Never Let Go.
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Pinkpoint. Climbed second, so given anchor placement, had to use pre-placed draws!

routes.route_description: An easy bolted romp on good, but just exciting enough holds. This could be a good sport climb for a newer leader or someone who is trying to top rope for the first time.
routes.route_location: Start on easy holds just left of the decaying chimney 'Feldspar Weathering Heights' on the far right side of Halloween.
routes.route_protection: 3 Bolts
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. Fun and easy. Used to establish top rope for Feldspar Weathering Heights.

routes.route_description: Named after my paternal grandfather, Lisle.If you like striking lines, perfectly splitter cracks or trad climbs where every square inch is protected by bomber gear then you're going to like Lisle. You'll probably just wish it kept going. This climb makes a great warmup or option for those breaking into the grade as it's short and almost every inch is well protected.After making it through the crux mid-way, there are two options to finish:1. Follow the crack left on bomber gear and mostly easy moves to the finish2. For a bit more exciting of a finish, go up just after the crux and stand on a mini-ledge then reach up and to the back for layback jugs you can ride to the top (a #6 may be useful, but the moves are 5.7-5.8ish). See the orange line on the topo in the photo gallery.Note: 'Lisle' could reasonably be considered a new climb or an old one. A variation of this climb was likely done decades ago, probably up to the big tree. However, a couple large death flakes were removed to prevent injury. As a result, most of the rock used on Lisle is different from what was done before.
routes.route_location: Lisle is the first route to the left of Reservation for Hubbard.This route begins at the base of a left-leaning splitter crack.There's a large distinct tree growing on top of a ramp about 20 feet above and to the left of the start of the climb.
routes.route_protection: Gear from 0.3 to 3" - a double rack would sew it up

route_comments.comment_text: Pretty. How do we pronounce it? Rhymes with "whistle"? Aug 25, 2022
I would describe it as rhyming with mile, phonetically: lai - uhl Aug 25, 2022

I found this pretty hard. It's basically a finger crack at its hardest part with poor feet. I barely held on with a ring lock after a fall and got onto some sandy slopey rails, but it was a sustained and not so secure sequence. Apr 14, 2024

routes.route_description: A short climb on the right side of the Cauldron, easily visible from the trail when walking out. Start on a block and use cracks and other holds to gain a decent stance where you can clip the bolt. For maximum value, head left from the bolt to an incut and work your way up to the chains, or for an easier time, just pull straight up to the angled ledge and walk your way up to the chains.
routes.route_location: The farthest right route on the Leaky Cauldron, easily seen from the trail on the way out from the base. Look up for the single bolt and start below there.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3", two bolts up top
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. could not figure out where to go after first sport clip. ended up right which I thought was off route · TR. fell again but found the move. the right hand side pull has a jug which if you use you can high foot on the slab · Lead / Fell/Hung. 5.8 if you escape right, harder if you try to go up the face · TR. meh, have to go far right at the first bolt to make it 5.8, bolts should have been closer to the arete or the climb should have been rated harder if your not "supposed to" use the arete · TR. Did a quick lap. Bottom half feels 5.8. Moving past the first bolt may be height dependent. Felt like 5.10b. Potential beta may be to dyno to a hidden jug which could drop grade to 5.9. · Lead / Fell/Hung. felt hard to move past the bolt, but the route was quite dirty at the time · Lead / Fell/Hung. couldn't make it past the bolt, move too far to reach, maybe a 7

routes.route_description: The more technical and challenging alternative to the popular sport routes on the Titanic. This route was named after my maternal grandmother. Start up a slab just right of Tower of Terror and follow three closely spaced bolts to a well-protected crux at a dike. Move up and over trending slightly right through four more bolts and a secondary crux to shared anchors with Resting Witch Face.
routes.route_location: In the middle of the Titanic, start just right of Tower of Terror and left of Resting Witch Face.
routes.route_protection: 7 bolts plus chains
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Okay this route is basically impossible if you’re under 5’6” and makes it ridiculously harder than an 11a · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lead by committee, top roped the bottom crux, but it flowed real smooth, took a take at the top crux to find a foot, then it went real smooth, would be a fun one to go back and lead clean · Lead / Redpoint. I’ll call it a redpoint. Fell on second bolt on onsight attempt. Started from ledge again and sent. · Lead / Fell/Hung. I climbed this back in May with Ansel at the time we thought this was Tower of Terror and thought it was sandbagged. Hah makes sense now. Fun and worth while route! · Follow. Not clean follow. Incredibly hard for 5.10d, in my opinion. Maybe it was just the heat/humidity though. I couldn't stick to anything except incut edges and there aren't many on this route.

routes.route_description: A funky climb on the Peanut. Start left of Harambe and climb a dirty section then head left under the big peanut. Walk the plank and make a big reachy move to a good hold. Then walk right atop the peanut, clip a bolt and head up just right of the bolt. Work your way up and left with slightly tricky gear placements. Finish up the left side of the triangle.
routes.route_location: Just left of Harambe in the middle of the wall
routes.route_protection: Standard Index Rack

routes.route_description: Formerly known as Crybaby BBQ. Climb up the corner onto a sloping ledge and step right up to climb the hourglass crack. Finish above the hourglass through good ledges to the second anchors from the left
routes.route_location: Start in a slabby corner about 25 ft below an hourglass shaped block
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3"
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Good hand jam at the crux. Smear + pull up with left foot, then right foot on good ledge. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Really burly move through the roof is the crux. Protects well i- both crux and easier climbing above · Lead / Onsight. the crack is way easier/less sustained than other Index 5.10 hand cracks. Then just kind of sandy to the top · Fun climb. Getting to the anchor was cruxy for me since I’m short: heel hock the // crack, mantle up to reach the rail below the anchor. Worst really well!! · TR. Fun route. I’ll need to come back to lead it. Middle of route could require a single 5.10 move. Feels easier than Libra Crack (5.10a). · Lead / Fell/Hung. even for index rating felt like a lot harder than 5.9 · Lead / Fell/Hung. aided up this and gave up on top rope, short bit of mid 10 at the roof?

routes.route_description: One of the original routes at 'the Grafton Crag', this climb is the original route of Harambe. PT Cruiser cuts left onto the ramp instead of continuing up the Gorilla Hug pillar of Harambe. The original anchor of PT Cruiser likely used slings on a tree.
routes.route_location: Start on the same slab as Harambe
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3", a 4 may be nice to have
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Pulled through the crux and would've certainly had the onsite... if only I'd managed my rope drag better. Extend those pieces below the roof (obviously) I ran outta runners. Came back the next day for redpoint. Cleaning the route was not easy for us, my buddy trammed the whole thing from the pt cruiser anchors, which seemed kinda sketch and he couldn’t unclip the bolt down lower without swinging into a wall. I decided to down/side lead back to the top of the roof and french-free to the Sam (.12a) anchors. The only issue there is that you must trust a huge detached block to gain the ledge where the anchor is. It seems solid, but it looks scary, and there really is no way around it

routes.route_description: One of the original routes at Halloween, this short pitch was probably put up a good time ago. This short but fun route works up the slab and corner just around from Heebee Geebees. It’s probably a bit easier to climb and clip the bolts if you’re tall, but this route is a joy for climbers of all sizes and shapes.
routes.route_location: On the face right next to Heebee Geebees
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts plus anchors

route_comments.comment_text: Hardware upgraded to 4 bolts at reasonable spacing, though you may still want to stick clip the first if you're not 6'+ Apr 27, 2023

That first to second both is pretty tricky. I ended up doing a cool pivot on my left foot to snag the jug on the left side then pulled up to just go right back over to the other side with a cool palm plant on the opposing face. Jul 28, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Haley and max lead. Super fun. You zig, then zag, then zig across the wall. Max lost steam after 3rd bolt and had to take/ basically after doing all the hard moves. · Lead / Onsight. Goofy route. I started via arete on the left, which definitely felt non-standard. Good time though. · Lead / Fell/Hung. One hang at 2nd bolt - went up the groove until then w/o arete · Lead / Onsight. placed a nut to make the start easier for short people. I wasn't able to remove it, so it's permanent pro · Lead / Fell/Hung. The most questionable lead ever. This seems crazy hard at the grade

routes.route_fa: Ben Hubbard, Michal Rynkiewicz, Jon Tetzlaff
routes.route_description: The best route on the wall according to Michal, for those who are up to the challenge. This well-protected route was named after my maternal grandpa, Ralph Radloff.Start at the perfect hand rail below an enticing crack and follow three bolts through the route's dynamic crimpy crux. (Beta Spoiler: Go Goblin Mode). Work your way through the crack and flakes to a unique undercling finger crack system that presents the routes second crux, which is protected by a final bolt. Pull the crux and finish up and right to the chains on a couple well-protected 5.10 moves. For fun, you can hand jam a perfectly-sized root system as you clip the chains.
routes.route_location: Just right of Sam under a rail with 3 bolts leading to a crack.
routes.route_protection: 6 bolts plus a double rack of 0.2 to 0.75. A single #4 can prevent a small runout after finishing the last crux moves.

route_comments.comment_text: Here's a grainy video of the First Ascent if anyone's curious: youtu.be/IsOFELLHC1o Jul 30, 2023

I find the first crux to be a fair bit harder than the second.  Second crux is quite challenging too but provides a bit more features for the hands and feet.  I really enjoyed the climbing style of the upper crux and climbing leading into it, feels a bit like a dance with all the fancy footwork! Sep 17, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell again. Sent first crux this time, and got twisted up on the entrance to the second crux. I’ve completely forgotten the betta, and my new way is much more strenuous. Swapped the dmm offset for a second blue totem. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Single fall on fist bolted crux, then clean. Comically dialed the top beta and it is pretty easy now · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on both cruxes. Nice route. Single rack .3 to .75 with gold dmm offset nut

routes.route_description: This route is really dumb and not good climbing. It’s literally just tall.Reservation for Hubbard follows the left side of a set of 'piano keys' up 100’. The moves aren’t that hard, but I don't trust the rock quality, so take care to inspect all rock before placing gear or pulling on it.
routes.route_location: Starts at a left leaning ramp just to the left of Shirlene
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3" with one bolt. There is not a lot of great protection on the route, but you can find some decent enough placements along the way.

route_comments.comment_text: I've gotta disagree with the description, this route is awesome! The fact that a 5.6 wanders its way up this beautiful wall is great. You can choose your own adventure too, stay on the ramps for the easier scrambling or hang off the jugs along the ramp edges. I also didn't find any loose blocks, though of course always keep an eye out. After the start, the rock quality looked very good. Aug 21, 2023

routes.route_description: A fun climb that follows straight up the face of the striking ramp on the Titanic. Find the bolts on the right side of the ramp and start below the dyke. Follow the bolts up using the ramp for hands on progressively more difficult moves to a crux about 2/3 of the way up the route. For kicks, you can try climbing straight up the ramp on top rope after.
routes.route_location: Starts below the right-leaning ramp. You should see a couple of bolts near a dyke feature above the start of the route.
routes.route_protection: 7 bolts plus anchor

route_comments.comment_text: This (and other routes on this wall) could really use a 5.10a+ rating. May 21, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Woof, pulled on draw at lower crux (very balancey) and needed a boost for linking moves above second crux.JW led · Lead. Terrifying. I’m too short and had to dyno the around the second bolt · Lead. Finally got it clean!! Tr to find a new sequence thru the crux and it went! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Memory failed me and I forgot all beta from last year:/ · Lead / Redpoint. Crux imo was start getting from 1st to 2nd bolt. Got pumped working on sequence and lowered to rest. routes.route_description: This fun route follows a few bolts up a face to a ledge with plenty of room for both Jack and Rose, before climbing up the back of a leaning block. The first bolt is a little high for some, but if you’re worried, you should be able to stick clip it from the ground. A #6 is also nice to protect the moves up top.Don't Click Here
routes.route_location: Start below a large leaning block
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3" with two bolts, a #6 is nice to have for the top.

route_comments.comment_text: one 0.2-0.3, one #2, one #3.5-4 (or tipped out #3), one #6 (or #5 lower) The gear part is ~5.8 and visible on the right side of mountainproject.com/photo/1… May 21, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Max had to stick clip the first bolt for me. I aided to clip second draw. Was able to do the crux on tr. after. Max flashed on pinkpoint. I’ll have to try again for the flash now that I know the beta. Get left foot up high where little seam is, left hand little finger crack, right hand out to flake, then bump left hand up to higher, good hold. · Lead / Fell/Hung. went up the left bolts instead of the 2 bolts for this route. went off route on that too and had a fall. was able to connect the trad part fine, then did the first 2 bolts of this route on top rope · Lead. Black totem/ .2 protects before first bolt but you’ll want another higher up · Follow. Sam lead this with one fall, I couldn't make the crux move, maybe mid 10

routes.route_description: Named in honor of Sam Grafton. This is probably the most badass of the original routes at Halloween.Start on a short boulder problem below the bolt above the slab for Harambe, or just climb the slab up to the bolt (either start works for either climb). Continue for a few moves up to the double cracks on Harambe and then either move over the lip at the upper bolt (much harder) or head left to the end of the crack system and then continue up and over. Finish up above to the chains.
routes.route_location: Start at a boulder problem just below the first bolt of Harambe.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3" with two bolts
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. this feels like 12c/d. not sure if I even can see a way to even complete this route. doesnt feel possible without some Houdini moves...

routes.route_description: This route finishes right under the sexy nurse log atop the Cauldron. Climb on good holds to a perfectly sized finger crack. Make a couple exciting moves, pull a ledge, and romp to the finish. If only it were longer.
routes.route_location: The second-most right route on the Cauldron, just below the nurse log on top of the Leaky Cauldron.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3"

route_comments.comment_text: Good (short) climb with a fun finger crack crux, very clean route. Also easy to setup TR from above for all the routes on Leaky Cauldron Sep 26, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Oof tried leading but could not commit to the balancey move after hand rail (a bit burly). JB finished. Takes small gear (.1 and .2s)- not excited about coming back and leading · Lead / Flash. climb is still an OK climb, only a couple of moves · TR. Bouldery 5.9. 1-move crux that’s height-dependent and harder than what you’ll find on most Index 5.9s. · Lead / Onsight. I thought this route was a little tough for 5.8 even though the difficulties don't last long. · Lead / Fell/Hung. wasn't able to make the reach to the high left crack off the rail on lead, hung on a .2 a bunch, got it on top rope after a try or two, maybe an 8 if you can reach the crack and don't have to do a big move off a high smear, also it's a bit spooky once you stand up, it's another move or to to a stance for pro

routes.route_description: Named after Shirlene Louie, who died too young. This is one of the best routes at Halloween that zig zags through some of the only good rock on this section. Start by chimneying behind a large feature and work your way up and right through a hand crack to a ledge. Clip the bolt then make some exciting moves left, then up and right to pull onto a ledge. Take a rest, place some cams, then set out into a stunning finger crack crux with a clean fall that takes small gear well (black totem if ya gotem). Finish above on the same anchors as Reservation for Hubbard.
routes.route_location: The start of this route is just to the left of a large overhanging boulder. The route starts by chimneying behind a large rock to the left of it.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3" with small pieces

route_comments.comment_text: Loved this route! Crux for me wasn't the finger crack but pulling onto the ledge right before it. Maybe 5'5 is too short to do it easily? Also curious about the reasoning for the single bolt. Seems random to me as there are plenty of placements around it. Thanks for cleaning up this awesome route/crag developers!! Jun 10, 2024

Glad you enjoyed the route! It's one of my favorites and is very special to a dear friend of mine. The bolt was originally placed while cleaning it when I thought the route would go up and right to the chockstone. However, it ended up being more natural to climb around to the left. There's definitely some gear to be had, but the rock quality in that zone makes me nervous so I figured why... more Glad you enjoyed the route! It's one of my favorites and is very special to a dear friend of mine. The bolt was originally placed while cleaning it when I thought the route would go up and right to the chockstone. However, it ended up being more natural to climb around to the left. There's definitely some gear to be had, but the rock quality in that zone makes me nervous so I figured why not keep it. That bolt has ended up being popular for boulderers to TR solo Speak of the Devil right below. If folks want me to take it out I'm happy to, but haven't ever really felt a need to prioritize it. Jun 17, 2024

For me the physical crux was getting onto the sloping ledge. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pumped out on the traverse. Pulled back on and figured out the sequence · Lead / Fell/Hung. One take before the rest ledge. Awesome. I CAN climb index 5.10 (affirmation) · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell a couple times working the finger crack traverse. Careful not to fill up crux hold with .3 cam. Find another way. Getting an early long step left unlocks the sequence. Lapped on top rope clean. Would definitely have another lead go · Lead / Flash. Best to place some small gear right before the crux then run it out; fun varied route but kinda a one move wonder · TR. Superb climb with the most solid rock on the wall. Alternate of powerful and balancy moves. Crux is hard for the grade but super well protected! Remember the far left foot and don't place the protection where you want your hand to be! Kudos to Ben to set this amazing line! · Lead / Flash. I went the wrong way the first time and thought I was gonna die so scary but the actual route is great With Andrew nice cool cloudy day lil mist · Lead / Fell/Hung. routes.route_description: A fun slab that follows a striking seam up and right. When viewed from afar, it kind of looks like the state of Virginia. There are a few distinct cruxes near the first two bolts, but it gets easier right before the third bolt. An attentive belay will keep you off the ground if you fall at the crux after the second bolt, but if you’re worried you should be able to stick clip the third bolt from the ground.
routes.route_location: Below a right leaning seam with three bolts on the far right side of Halloween. Start in a crack as far left as you feel reasonable.
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts plus chains

route_comments.comment_text: As fun as three bolts can be. Adding an alpine draw to the third bolt dramatically reduces the perceived risk. Jul 16, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Climbed with Zach. I enjoyed this route. A bit cryptic but with the right sequence agree with the 10c grade. · TR. fell while trying to match feet, the. found beta going left with left foot · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to cheat. Should but blank slab section and decking possibility not worth · Lead / Redpoint. fell at first bolt several times trying to go left. started from starting foothold so calling it an rp · Lead / Fell/Hung. Super fun for the length, a lot of fear going from the 2nd to the 3rd bolt

routes.route_description: A short but fun boulder problem to do while you're waiting to rope up or warm up for the harder boulder problems in the area.
routes.route_location: In between Heebee Geebees and Devil's Advocate
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_description: A long exciting route with two distinct cruxes. Start on an easy boulder move from a mediocre hold to a jug and then stand up on the ledge. Walk up and clip a bolt to a mantle out left. As you pull the crux the bolt should be exactly at your hip. From there, start heading up steadily until the holds peter out and the upward motion stops. As you look around and see the hold up above your heart sinks. It’s a big move followed by a mantle. There’s a small ledge below, so try not to fall. If you’re unsure about making the move, you can pull up on a draw and clip a bolt to protect the dyno. Pull the move and romp your way to the top.
routes.route_location: Starts on the face to the left of the right leaning ramp (Resting Witch Face) and right of a short 3-bolt face climb (Pumpkin Spice)
routes.route_protection: 11 bolts plus anchor

route_comments.comment_text: The bolting is safe even with the ledges. The big move is only a dyno if you are really short and is well protected regardless. Jun 22, 2022
This and Resting Witch Face go into the sun mid day from about 11 to 3, but are otherwise shady. Jul 10, 2022

Hi. Short person checking in (5'1" and 0 extra reach.) Contrary to the last comment, bolting felt pretty weird. First bolt is fairly high above committing moves, and the high crux is asking for an ankle injury with the ledges below. Highly suggest a panic draw if you're lacking for reach. Overall, an okay route. May 8, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. fell at mantle move, then had to step on a bolt at the crux. too hot. · Lead / Redpoint. I dabbed on a bolt but it was an accident so I’m counting it! :p · TR. One of my favorite ever outdoor climbs make sure your rope is long enough as mine was about 60m and we just barely had enough rope to make it work by about a foot or two. Not sure about the terror part though this climbs pretty chill. · Lead. Couldn't find a static way to hang the draw couple bolts from the top, ended up traversing left up and back right over the top. · Lead / Onsight. Haley lead and flashed. I was too short to reach the required hold up and to the right. Max made it to that hold, but then was to tired to do the required mantle up onto the ledge. Next time · TR. Climbed clean on top rope with Tim Matsui and Jess. Tim led. Lower Cruz at dish to mantle felt great. Upper crux on reachy mini roof is physical and would be spicy on lead · Lead / Fell/Hung.
