Took many times at upper crust dyno but couldn’t hit it and lowered. Maybe hand ledge for feet next time and won’t need dyno? · Lead / Fell/Hung. Onsight except grabbed draw to clip after pulling second crux. Couldn’t see feet and ended up dangling from one arm to clip bolt. W/ Emma · Lead / Fell/Hung. Excellent pitch. Was at the 2nd to last bolt, stepped up. Two bolts close together and standing up on the slab move the draw of the bolt below (very closely spaced) somehow snagged my figure 8 (way to have an onsight get shut down AFTER the crux) · Lead / Onsight. Reach crux move for sure. With Andrew and Woody and Jess and Maple and a lil bit of sun. · Lead / Fell/Hung. This was hard and took all I had. One section way above the clip (second crux) was horribly insecure and I barely made the next clip. The crimpy dyno section was very height oriented but felt impossible to me. · TR. First crux amazing balancing move, loved it! Second crux seems very hard, unless you find two superb foot placements in the horizontal crack which you can't really see from above. · TR. Two cruxes, harder one up top. Use horizontal crack for feet, muscle up. · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell once near top. it's all there, look around you bozo

routes.route_description: A fun line with a short steep crux. Start on the far-left side of the Leaky Cauldron, clip a bolt and head up through the steepness on decent holds to an easier finish at the left-most anchor on the Cauldron. Shares anchors with ‘What’s Better than 24?’
routes.route_location: The farthest left route on the Leaky Cauldron. Starts around the corner under a short steep face with a bolt.
routes.route_protection: One bolt, gear to 3"

route_comments.comment_text: A boulderers trad line for sure Jun 22, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. I made a bad choice of keep going up on the last part, while unable to place any pros in the flared section. ended up with half of the route runout

routes.route_description: Not very tall, really out of the way, and probably should have just been a boulder problem, but hey it’s there.
routes.route_location: On the far far right side of Halloween, just around the corner of the Feldspar Weathering Heights chimney. Walk up a grassy ramp to the start of this one bolt route.
routes.route_protection: One bolt plus chains

route_comments.comment_text: By far the best MP page for a bomb route I've ever seen! If only there was this much detail for some of the classics. Jul 18, 2024

routes.route_description: Head up the face to the left-most anchor. About half-way up, you can either go left across a ledge and up or head straight up some fun unprotected slab moves. Both ways are fun.
routes.route_location: Start in the dihedral/corner crack just right of Twenty-Five
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3"

route_comments.comment_text: I agree, it is a very good number. Jun 22, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. For the crux, go left and place a .1 in the crack, then go right with balancy moves. · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. 2 laps, 1 tr slab variation. w Taylor and dogs · TR. got a clean top rope, would be different on lead giving up the left pocket for pro, bit of 9 or easy 10 moving up the slab to the ledges

area_description: This is the crag directly to the right of Private Idaho. One way to get there is to walk about 3 minutes along a faint climbers trail from the base of Senior Citizens in Space.Relatively few people visit Hag Crag, but there are some good slab routes on this cliff as well as low-angle cracks.The base of the crag has some huge big-leaf maples, making it shady during summer. This makes it perfect for a busy summer day at Index.
area_getting_there: Park in town, walk to the tracks, and follow the train tracks left until you see a trail on the wall side of the tracks with a wooden bridge. Follow this trail to a crest, then go right (left goes to boulders). A casual, garden-like section takes to to a large boulder (Midnite).From this boulder are two ways to go. The old way is to go straight, passing west of the boulder then uphill through some forest and talus for another 5 minutes to a T junction. Head right. Continue for 5-10 minutes, trending right to the base of Private Idaho. The trail traverses along the base of Private Idaho. (If you miss the turnoff to Private Idaho then when the talus hits the wall, go right and traversing along the base of Lookout Point (just above Private Idaho), then you will eventually reach a gully. Hag Crag is at the bottom of this gully, just to the east.)  If you take the earlier right turn at the talus, then traverse to the end of this wall where there is the popular  Senior Citizens in Space corner crack. Keep going up and right to the next wall and you are there.Since 2019 there has been a quicker trail that goes directly to Hag. At Midnite, take the right turn just in front of the boulder and head east along the meandering trail. Pass some boulders, cross a small talus field, and then go up past two short bluffs (the upper one has a waterfall in winter and spring). The trail gets steeper here and goes directly up to Hag Crag from below.

area_comments.comment_text: I see a lot of "TR" labels on these routes, is this a good place for TR soloing?  Is there decent access to the chains? Apr 20, 2021
Jon - thanks for the input.  I'll probably go check it out this week ... if I can find it haha. Apr 27, 2021

Easy top rope setup. Either walk from climber left or right side of wall, though the left side trail seems more established. Good for TR solo. Can be directly walked from Idaho Private, trail is obvious. Be aware some hangers don't have rappel rings. Jul 17, 2024

routes.route_description: Not a route, sorry.Two stations here: At the top of Hag Crack, on the ledge, and on the big maple tree at the base.Use a tool from any station, but please return to the same station. Post a note here if one needs replacement, thanks.For wide-area brushing, the long handled wire brush here is better than the ones often left at the base (also, the handle bends up so you are less likely to scrape a knuckle). Don't put much pressure on the brush and do too much scrubbing in one spot if you need excellent friction there (e.g., left side friction routes & Free Cat) as the metal bristles can smoothen the rock. If there is thick moss in the way, you might instead use the back side of the "kama" (serrated scythe) tool to scrape it off.The kama will get nearly anything out of a crack, thin crack or thick. Be careful with it while it is still sharp. (Gets dull quick, yet still will be adequate for any crack here.)The broom is useful for the top-out ledge area and places that have loose dirt.
routes.route_location: From the top, walk down carefully near the right (east edge), looking for the knotted handline. From the bottom, go up the east side, then traverse in on the lower handline.Post a comment here if you notice a tool gone missing or worn out.
routes.route_protection: A biner to clip the tool into.For all types of scraping, but particularly wire-brushing, eye protection is a good idea. If you have gloves, you could use them, though these tools are designed to keep your knuckles away from the rock.

route_comments.comment_text: Here's a short primer on the tool use: vimeo.com/820397159 Apr 23, 2023

routes.route_name: A Good Place to Find Frogs
routes.route_description: A straight groove to corner, followed by a short face. You can practice your hand and finger jams, or you can just stem it. After reaching the top of the corner, climb the face on the right side, about 25' to the big fir tree at the top. An anchor lies on the rock just behind the tree.Having the low angle of Hag, and being a corner-groove, it collects tree debris like mad. So it needs a good scraping a few times a year. Certainly worth it for this route and the ones that use its start.
routes.route_location: Look for the obvious groove at the left side of the crag. Several friction routes veer off the start of this line (e.g., Game On), while this just keeps going up the groove.
routes.route_protection: Nuts and cams to about 2" (a slightly larger piece could be used near the bottom). Save a small wired stopper for the top, just before the one bolt.

route_comments.comment_text: Topos for this crag and nearby ones (pdf format, ~90 pgs) at Part A: tinyurl.com/2he6k92b Part B: tinyurl.com/2x9auhjp Jun 22, 2022
This climb attracts leaves and branches.  A kama tool, located near the base, can be used to remove the debris. Jun 22, 2022
Recently re-cleaned out this crack. Really fun moderate that protects well with mostly small gear. Run out at the top could be a little spicy for the new 5.5 leader. Sep 1, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. Great beginner trad lead. My 2nd. My son Ian Hoppis, cleaned it today. It's ready to go! · TR. Was so dirty. Peter R and I rapped in and brushed it out. Top half is dry and goes. Bottom half is still wet and slimy in the crack. Should be dry in a day. Mock trad lead on TR. Peter belay. · Lead. Downclimbed halfway through bc I forgot nuts lol. It’s nut city on this, lots of constrictions. Also bailed early and lowered off of tree without doing top slab. Slab was covered in pine needles and dirt and looked unpleasant · 2 pitches. Follow. We broke it into two pitches and Sarah led both pitches. Her first multipitch trad lead! · Lead / Onsight. fun trad lead, a little runout if you don't bring too many finger pieces

routes.route_description: Crack between Hag Crack and Magicians Apprentice. Follow the crack directly up, which then moves slightly to the right, up onto a ledge, and over on top of a slab. Shares an anchor (2x SS quicklinks) with "Those Two Hummingbirds Who Never Met".Good beginner trad lead with secure jams all the way and solid placements for gear.
routes.route_location: Between Hag Crack and Magicians Apprentice.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack, potentially extra in hand-sizes (BD #2, #3). 2 bolt quick-link anchor is to the right of the tree up top above the rope handline.To TR the route, follow the right side of the crag to the handline on the sloping ledge. This is the handline for Hag Crag Crack, the first set of bolts you come across is the anchor used to TR this route.

route_comments.comment_text: Cleaned this route extensively on 9/20/22 and installed quick links. Fun straight forward climb with some good hand and foot jams, good intro to crack technique for a beginner. Sep 21, 2022

i think this one has probably been climbed quite a few times before.  we climbed it in 2017 or so when it was still super dirty/mossy.  i remember about 10 feet up there was a frog in the crack that startled me. Sep 21, 2022
Gotcha, I added it after talking to Jon as it hadn’t been added yet. If ya have info to add feel free to edit. Sep 21, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Lead first half cause our rope got stuck Felt good and secure on tr. last time might have been too tired · Lead / Onsight. Felt like a 5.7 <- this note is for hag crack Took a mini slide down on a bomber .3 close to the top I felt like I was running low on gear but maybe I was just running low on placements · Lead / Redpoint. AMTL 3: didn't need to extend sling on first piece - should have asked belayed to move iot avoid rope drag/ hard turn. Ran out easy section about half way up after #5. Subjectively safe, but objectively a bit run out. At anchor, I pulled up slack to click about before unlocking carabineers - I dropped the slack to deal with lockers, which was correct (don't hold onto also rope while you need with stuff!!). · Lead / Onsight. First trad lead! Fun climb, was a little dirty but cleaned it as I climbed. Realized I finished the route to magicians apprentice anchor. Peter belay. · Lead / Onsight. Much easier than the other 5.6, #4 was really nice and very run out after that · Lead / Onsight. Cool route, not the best gear, ran it out pretty far on a 0.1 at the top · Lead / Onsight. I liked it! Ran it out a bit in the middle because I’d used my #3s. Good jams · Lead / Onsight. It’s still an onsight if you spend 5-10 minutes at a stance · TR. Practiced trad placement on top rope as part of KAF adventures workshop. Great cracks and foot placements for trad practice · Lead / Flash. Easy. Take a 4. Skip the micro gear at the top and lunge for the jug and place the 3. Vertical bolts with rap ring at top. · Lead / Onsight. Climbed to rescue a draw. Quite dirty overall but the specific hand and feet holds were a bit cleaned up. Very hollow rock up top. Got a great finger lock only to disturb my good friend Lizard Tom. 5.6L Single rack with yellow metolius and extra 0.75 · Lead / Flash. Used thin start to the right, then exited left at the end

routes.route_description: From the base of the cliff, head 20 feet up a trough to reach the start of the route. Clip the bolt and traverse onto the slab with some thin face/slab moves. The next bolt is up and right and a moderate runout will be present to reach this bolt. From here, follow the bolt line up the slab to the chains.The climbing is sustained 5.10a slab most of the way up.It is also very easy to set up a toprope. Walk to the very top of the crag, to a large fir tree. You can use the anchor bolts just above the tree, or use the handline to reach the bolted anchor about 10' lower.
routes.route_location: This is on the left edge on Hag Crag, on the upper slab portion of the crag.  To reach Hag Crag, head right for about 3 minutes from Private Idaho.To reach the start of the route, scramble up 20 feet in a gully-groove feature (not that hard).
routes.route_protection: 7 quickdraws and an extendable draw.

route_comments.comment_text: scrubbed this route last weekend.going to clean out the gully start next weekend Jun 10, 2017
I noticed. It looked great. Thanks Marty. And Mark is right, it is sustained. I thought it was harder than 10a, but maybe just need to get back into slab shape. Jun 10, 2017

This route is a rad example of moderate friction climbing and should be a must do for any slab enthusiast. that being said the bolting is pretty poor on this route so if 5.10 PG13 slab make you nervous its best done as a toprope first. Very easily toproped by walking around to the left of the cliff. It's currently clean where you need it but if running laps please utilize the brushing station... more This route is a rad example of moderate friction climbing and should be a must do for any slab enthusiast. that being said the bolting is pretty poor on this route so if 5.10 PG13 slab make you nervous its best done as a toprope first. Very easily toproped by walking around to the left of the cliff. It's currently clean where you need it but if running laps please utilize the brushing station and do some community service. Jun 6, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Was very mossy but Zach and I cleaned it up! Technical and sustained. Cool moves! Some impossible-feeling friction moves that hold great. · TR. should have brought a brush for this great edging/friction route. felt harder than 10a · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lots of bolts, tugged on some QDs, well cleaned by Marty (thanks!), much harder than expected

routes.route_description: An excellent introduction to classic Index face and slab climbing. Highly recommended.Steeper edging at the start (10b/c), then lower-angle friction moves (10c/d) up higher. The crux may be at the transition between the two, when you are trying to get established on the slightly lower-angle friction section. It might be particularly tricky without the stickier rubber.If you have trouble at the cruxy transition to friction, pull past the move--the top friction section is quite fun.
routes.route_location: Right of Leeper's corner. The start is just 5-10' left of the start to Hag Crag Crack.
routes.route_protection: Five bolts, then a bolted anchor.You can set up a TR from a new anchor on top of the crag, almost directly above Hag Crack. A directional at the lower anchor helps.

route_comments.comment_text: The friction crux on this is desperate (but easy to pull through if need be). You then get some super fun pure friction to the top. Clipping the 2nd bolt is a bit spooky. You can TR this from the 5.7 corner. Jul 31, 2018

Very fun route. Index-type steep face at the bottom (i.e., edging and smears), and then fun friction at the top. I noticed chalk marks that stayed to the right of the bolts, though I found it more straightforward to stay more to the left. Jun 4, 2019
despite the moss, the holds you need are free of it. face climbing on edges to a move or two of 10d pure friction, then easier friction to the top. fun on top rope! Aug 26, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Fucking fun!!!! Pretty dirty so top was trickier than it should be. Relied heavily on the rope, would be fun to try to clean it up. · TR. Where even do I put my feet???? Fell a bunch on crux heehee · TR. Amazing slab. Consistent/sustained and thin. Easy for the grade(?). Consider ground up projecting. Did all moves with two or three falls. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pulling the lip is only possible in mythos. And if you traverse slightly left under the 4th bolt · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to pull on a draw for the crux. Wtf this was all mossy too. Might try in winter when there is better friction · TR. fell at what I saw was the crux, no clue how to make the move....

routes.route_description: Full on friction climb.Start in the crack-groove, then move onto the face, following the bolt line.A walk-up TR anchor exists at the top for easy access. This can be used for several routes in the vicinity.
routes.route_location: Just left of End Run, sharing the same start.
routes.route_protection: Well bolted. Two-bolt anchor with chains at top.

route_comments.comment_text: Sounds great, Marty. That region left of the corner is looking very clean these days. It will be interesting to try 11b friction. Does it start in the groove, together with End Run? Oct 18, 2017
Yes it starts in the groove. I added two bolts there because the crack is constantly filled with fir needles. Oct 22, 2017

It is easy to set up a top-rope on this route and End Run. Possibly, a 60-m rope will do it, but check before you rap. Also, for a fun 5.5-ish variation, one can stay in the groove to the top, going onto the face only when the crack hits the hillside at the top. Jun 7, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Friction climb, was pretty dirty. Top section after last bolt was completely covered in moss. Bring a wire brush!! I didn't and slipped on the moss, took a 30+ ft whipper. · Lead / Fell/Hung. dnf. tough! had a little moss so maybe that was the issue · Lead / Fell/Hung. I will be back. Did not even send on TR! Goddammit

routes.route_description: Bless the climbers -- probably Virgos -- who keep this route clean. The second flake is the crux. Very easy to place gear. Often a choice for first time leaders along with Seniors Citizens in Space which is 200 meters to the left down at Private Idaho.
routes.route_location: Middle of Hag Crag.
routes.route_protection: Nuts and cams to 3". New anchors at the top.Also, if you walk around the right side of the crag, staying close to the wall, you can walk onto the ledge to set up a TR. Look for the sloping ledge with a handline rope and intermediate anchors (for other routes further right). Just follow the handline to the end and you are at the anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: Nothing is PG13 about the route itself... No loose rock, gear anywhere you want it, maybe easier than anything on GNS. PG13 rating may be due to historical dirtiness. As of a few weeks ago it was sparkling clean (and I scraped another few gallons of dirt and pine needles out of the crack to try to keep it that way), but due to its position in the trees and the low angle it looks like it will... more Nothing is PG13 about the route itself... No loose rock, gear anywhere you want it, maybe easier than anything on GNS. PG13 rating may be due to historical dirtiness. As of a few weeks ago it was sparkling clean (and I scraped another few gallons of dirt and pine needles out of the crack to try to keep it that way), but due to its position in the trees and the low angle it looks like it will tend to collect more if people don't keep climbing it. Sep 30, 2014

I've cleaned this route thoroughly each of the last two summers.  It will need a cleaning at the beginning of each summer to stay climbable.  It has new anchors, and is probably the easiest / best / safest beginner lead at Index... if clean. And no, it is not PG 13 in any way. Apr 7, 2015
Climbed this yesterday. Needs cleaning again. I will try and make it back up there soon and clean the rest of it. Fun route in a neat area May 11, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Ok until the top. Got my feet crossed up at the top and took a little mini fall before finishing it. · Follow. Nice 5.6 but I think it would have been a bit of a challenge to lead. Followed Carl Marrs guiding. We linked up Hag Crack, Outta Sight, then Milkman and Dandelions on Lookout Jr · Lead. Crack and surrounding face were nice and clean but starting to fill up with maple leaves. Ah, fall. With Sam. · TR. A bit dirty which made it slippery at the crux. Good gear throughout. · Lead / Pinkpoint. First pink point ever. Kinda mank and a bit scary because of that, but a fun experience · Lead / Redpoint. Second time doing this guy…harder than I remembered but still fun…Kai with the beached whale up high · Lead / Fell/Hung. W/ Tia. Approach shoes were not a good idea. Quite dirty but Tia gave it a brush on her way down. · Lead / Onsight. The route allows placing textbook cams. Face holds disappears at the last bit of crack that becomes shallow finger size, feet either stem or jam, weak finger jam for support. If in doubt, doesn't hurt to sew it up... · Lead / Onsight. Mitch’s first outdoor climb! Shaded area til like noon then top gets in sun. · Lead / Onsight. Jackie belay. Second trad lead! Used the 0.5 too early, wish I saved for top. Mosquitos were heinous. · TR. Tested a bunch of gear placements, then starting climbing right before the crux. Did it clean but still feels really awkward at the crux · Lead / Onsight. First trad lead almost shit my pants and slipped twice at the crux · Lead / Flash. Haley and Ksenia lead. Good practice for feet and good protection and easy to place. · Lead / Onsight. Easy and fun lil warm up. Bring smaller prop for the top part. Black totem would of been perfect but I ran it out · Lead / Onsight. Fun, worth cleaning before climbing, as with everything at this crag · Lead / Flash. First trad lead of the season! Woohoo! Super fun and not too obvious. · Lead / Onsight. with Brian Seo. Got great nut placements, but definitely felt scared when it thinned to fingers at the end. Took a single rack and nuts + .5-1 · TR. I cleaned the crack today, so much crud in it! I fell on my first attempt on TR at the top because it was still wet at 10am, however the crack does dry and should be dry by the afternoon · Lead / Onsight. bring thin blade for clean up. great places for gear when clean. · Lead. Lots of pine needles in crack. Upper crack flares so placing cams a little dicey, but easy to climb. Good for practicing nut placements

routes.route_description: In the middle of the crag, climb up the clean right-facing flaring corner, sort of like Battered Sandwich, but facing the other way and a little easier. Initially, a jam crack in a corner, but higher becomes more of a chimney. I've seen some climb the chimney part with their back to the slab, fighting for every inch. It seems faster and easier to do with one's feet on the slab, ones back or hands against the top. The route seems to leave quite an impression on folks, either they love it or they hate it (this might reflect on which side they had their feet).On a hot day, you might find this one of the coolest routes in the district.One can do a variation that traverses out onto the slab before the chimneying section, clipping three bolts to a lower anchor. Or, one can do the extended finish, going to the top (5.8), though this might presently be difficult to protect except at the start.Shares the same start as On the Rebound.There is a walk-up anchor at the top, about 25' above the old anchor for this route. You can TR from here, doing the fun face moves to the top, or re-direct the rope at the lower anchor. Very easy access.
routes.route_location: The large, right-facing corner near the middle of Hag Crag. Very obvious from the pics.
routes.route_protection: Full range of gear, including wide pieces. But one may get by with just pieces to 3", with several in the 2-3" range.Bolted anchor at the top. If you're doing it with a 60m, don't forget to tie knots in the end of your rope.

route_comments.comment_text: As of today, 9 April 2016, the route has been cleaned thoroughly and is comfortable on lead.  It does, however, lack an anchor and we had to get creative. With an anchor it would be a worthwhile climb for someone looking for something in the 5.7 range. The middle of the portion protects in the overhead crack with 4" and 5" cams but other options are available. Apr 9, 2016
Thanks Rodrigo, it looks nice now. Apr 10, 2016
Buy bolts, hangers and chain and you can use my drill to put in anchor, might as well fully finish the job Apr 10, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Felt harder than. 5.9. Didn’t find good moves and was jamming body up the chimney with left hand and left foot only · Follow. This is a neat route but it might be soul crushing for a 7 leader. kind of a weird slab chimney hybrid. The roof has a huge #5 crack but you can't really use it, a lot of it was slab feet with opposing butt pressure. Take extra big gear, 2s, 3s, maybe 4s · Lead / Flash. Haley and Max lead. I was happy that I got the guts to lead this climb. The pro is really good. And I stood with my back against the chimney and that felt so secure. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Grabbed some gear while fishing the rope out from under my body, but made it up. This one was a battle. Yeehaw. · Follow. Stiff grading, felt like being birthed lol. Climbed facing out for half of the flare, then turned around. Cleaned anchors. Put your back into it! Woody on belay. · TR. Clean TR. Really fun. Did the tall chimney thing with my back to the rock. Would have been challenging to place gear in that position · Follow. Felt a bit easier than last time, still don't want to lead it · Lead. Traversing the mossy slab to the lower anchors for the bolt line didn’t make sense. There is an anchor at the top of the crack. I could have used 2-3 #2’s. I did use 2x #4 and one #5 · Lead / Onsight. Mitch’s 3rd climb outdoors! This is a super fun one with some hand jams, slab, layback and a comfy partial chimney that you can just scoot up · Lead / Redpoint. The line is on low angle slab, interesting with different types of cracks. First part has good hand jam. Overall the cracks are pretty uniform, so I had to be lowered down to retrieve #1,#2, #3 BD, or back clean. I was flowing with layback, but to lead and place gear, I had to use hand jams, left foot jam, and right foot smearing on slab to be able to see the crack. It's a bit awkward and uncomfortable, maybe low angle corner (deep) crack isn't my thing, maybe try layback and placing gear on the crack above next time. The chimney section is super fun. I had my feet smearing on slab, back pressing on the chimney/roof, left hand bar in the big crack and right hand placing gear. I placed a couple gear in the bottom crack, having to reach really far. I never climbed a route like this, but was confident with pro, so ended up sewing it up while exploring different beta. Placed a #4. · Lead / Onsight. Definitely bring three 2's. Didn't realize I was gonna inch worm the entire way up. So glad I was wearing pants. My shoulders on the otherhand took a beating. Don't necessarily think I need to do this again. · Lead. Opted to climb crack with Right side of body on slab. Decidedly unenjoyable chimney-esq climbing. Not horrible because very protectable (so long as you have an abundance of 2s). Placed: one # 0.5, 0.75, 1, 3, 4 and five #2s. · TR. Set this up on TR by going above. Had a bit of a fiasco as i set up on anchors too far to the left so missed the chains. So went back up again and moved over to the 2 bolts to repel 15 feet to the anchors for this climb. Anyway- climb on TR was super cool. Great for practicing different styles of crack and chimney techniques. · TR. Honestly loved this climb. Did it facing the crack as opposed to feet out. Used by right arm to chicken wing, right foot to jam the crack and then used left to scoot myself upwards. Very OW like. A ton of fun. Weird getting to the anchors, I had to turn outward felt kinda fumbly . Need to lead this one · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fine climbing, then went straight in at the flaring corner #2 size. Once it got wider, I placed a #4 then went for the big jug which ended up being a large loose chockstone. I started slipping and had Aubrey take as I down climbed to the #4. After collecting myself, I rerouted to utilize the slab to the right more, with my back against the other side. Easy climbing, but just a bit runout. Finished up fine. · TR. Super fun on top rope!!! Might be a bit heady on lead. Key was to press back against upper wall. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a silly fall low down, and then did the chimney clean. Felt much better than a year ago, now that I actually know how to crack climb. I'm A 5.9 cLiMbEr lololol · Lead. Bailed on route due to pouring rain, made it half way up on lead. · Lead. Faced out in the middle section & loved it. Used 4 & 5 in the roof since I don't possess infinite #2s. · Fucking loved this thing. Maybe not enough to do it again! What a fight! I lead it belly down. Shane followed it belly up with a few turns and he seemed to have an easier time. Maaaaaaybe I'll try it again that way. · Lead / Onsight. One of the funnest routes I’ve done, silly climbing in the chimney · TR. S L A B B Y and felt partly like an intro to off-widths at points, but so fun! I loved it! · TR. Climbed up partway as part of trad lead climb workshop with KAF adventures · TR. Grovelly. Crux at bulge and after where you flip back to face the slab. Take plenty of 2’s · Lead. bit funky. leading and placing pro/being secure requires being deep in the corner. slabbing seems like it'd be great on TR with a clean slab · TR. 1 fall. Lie backing into a crazy overhanging corner requiring a hold behind you · Lead / Onsight. Could use more larger gear. Ran it out a bit towards the top. Cool chimney movement though! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Wack. Bailed off at the lower anchors, got stuck jamming in the corner and didn't like it. Sounds like I just needed to stand up, but the overhead crack wasn't that awe-inspiring. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a while up top, working on efficiently placing & evaluating good gear but felt secure in each move · Lead. I ran this out a shit ton and the 60 foot fall potential was a trip · Lead / Pinkpoint. bailey hung most of the gear, I finished a few pieces · TR. Very fun climb, Lots of stemming and interesting crack. Could set up a top rope from the top but would be nice to be able to redirect the rope with cams · Lead / Onsight. First WA trad lead of 2023! This was a lot for me lol. Climbed the majority of it on my back somehow but was good for the head and alpine season · TR. Fun climb but placing gear would be a little tricky for the second half · TR. Super fun, super burley. If I lead out gear on right hip. Eventually turns to face climbing at the top. Much more fun than the 5.6 or 5.9 we did. · Lead / Onsight. Weirdest 5.7 I've climbed yet. All I could say at the anchor was "What the fuck?" Fun route. · Lead / Onsight. Doubles from .3 to 3 and a 4 felt adequate if you go deeper into the crack. Honestly could have gotten away with just 3s & lower. Eats 2s up · TR. Super fun, set up a top rop from the Hag Crack with a redirect. · Lead / Onsight. takes large gear only (several #2/#3) except for the very start. I had to run it out which made it less fun. It’s basically a chimney 2/3 of the route. · Lead / Onsight. ran out of gear at chimney, came down. Seth climbed, ran out the chimney and lead on 2 more pieces to the anchor. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Several takes. Very awkward climbing and difficult to place gear in the crack which is deep within the cavern. Probably won’t repeat. · Lead / Flash. w/ Defne incredibly unique--in the middle I was just finding it 'annoying' but it's a good challenge. Takes all the gear all the way, ultra safe. · Lead / Onsight. Climbed it horribly wrong but sent it! Ended up with feet in the top crack and climbed inverted for a bit. Fun and burly.

routes.route_description: Start at the obvious crack just to the right of Hag Crack for the first ten feet, then traverse out right into the system of cracks and flakes leading up. A great additional beginner route to the crag.There are two walk-up anchors that one can use to TR this line, both to the right of the Hag Crack anchor. Just walk up the right side of the crag, then follow the obvious handline across the ledge.Or one can set up a TR from the Hag Crack anchor, using a redirect to the route's finishing anchors a few feet below the above-mentioned access ledge.
routes.route_location: The furthest right route at Hag Crag
routes.route_protection: Standard rack, be sure to have some small cams or nuts to protect the crux about a third of the way up.To TR the route, follow the right side of the crag to the handline on the sloping ledge. This is the handline for Hag Crag Crack, but halfway along it you will see another anchor up high. This will work for Magician's Apprentice.

route_comments.comment_text: Looks nice. Thanks for creating a well-needed moderate. Jul 7, 2018
Awesome!  Does this route have its own anchor/rappel station or does it share with Hag Crack? Jul 8, 2018

Nice addition to this crag. Good climbing, gear and rock from the ground through the crux. A slight traverse up to and through the crux has potential for a ground fall, so protect often. As the climbing eases above the crux there is some friable rock and a couple loose blocks but solid pro if you look for it. As mentioned the anchor is new and needs some refining, just check the bolts are... more Nice addition to this crag. Good climbing, gear and rock from the ground through the crux. A slight traverse up to and through the crux has potential for a ground fall, so protect often. As the climbing eases above the crux there is some friable rock and a couple loose blocks but solid pro if you look for it. As mentioned the anchor is new and needs some refining, just check the bolts are tight. Both lowering or rappelling seem appropriate. Enjoy! Sep 6, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Good beginner lead. Easy, felt more like 5.6 if that. Slightly more challenging gear placements vs Hag Crack next door but still easy enough. · Lead / Flash. w/ Defne, could use some moss cleaning, currently I'd give it less stars than Hag Crack · Lead / Onsight. Gave this one another scrub today. It’s not perfect but it’s definitely climbable and worth getting on! · Lead / Onsight. Max lead. Haley lead on pink point. Very fun and more sporty. · TR. TR & placed gear. Need LOTS of wide gear otherwise is v sketchy. A few horns you could sling. Most of the flakes felt hollow & the whole crack was v dirty and mossy. Would not climb again · TR. w/ Marc + Jared, helped Jared set up a mock-lead + rapped w/ him to talk placements · TR. Mock lead with trad gear. At my grade right now, and some interesting slab moves too. · Follow. Could feel heady to lead but plenty of places for placements. Lead next time

routes.route_fa: J. Nelson, D. Lepeska, and FDC Willard
routes.route_description: Start up Leeper's Corner, then move over to the start of the long flake crack. Then jam and layback up the crack. One can belay on the same bolted anchors of End run and Game on.A challenge with the crux is that the flake crack is invisible to you when you have to move over. It is a blind reach. Look for where the left face of the corner has an upper (third) crack that can be jammed or underclung. Here is the place. That crack is actually the other side of the crack you are shooting for. It is a big reach. Some may have to dyno for it. And if you are under 5' tall, it may be physically impossible to make the reach. Doing a two-handed dyno would be very awkward from the way the corner and crack are situated (dynoing around a bulge). So, the given rating is more of a minimum. I suppose most routes are body-size dependent, but this route may be more so than most.
routes.route_location: Middle-left of the wall. Start in the central right-facing corner route.
routes.route_protection: Full range of sizes.At the bottom, a few finger-to-hand size nuts and cams. For the crux, a hand-sized cam is needed. Once in the face crack, one can put another hand-sized cam, and then larger cams above.The crack widens considerably at the top to more than 5", but the climbing up here is low angle and only 5.6 or so.

route_comments.comment_text: Fun climb,  kind of a 1 move wonder.  Did this as a flash for the index climbing fest. BRING A #5!!!! I did not have a 5, the crack gets big a few feet after you pull the hard move.  Expecting easy climbing I kept going on what ended up being a 40 ft run out that would have been ground fall.  Felt harder than 5.6 but there was already some moss growing back so that didnt help.  With a 5... more Fun climb,  kind of a 1 move wonder.  Did this as a flash for the index climbing fest. BRING A #5!!!! I did not have a 5, the crack gets big a few feet after you pull the hard move.  Expecting easy climbing I kept going on what ended up being a 40 ft run out that would have been ground fall.  Felt harder than 5.6 but there was already some moss growing back so that didnt help.  With a 5 would have been just fine bumping it. Sep 13, 2021

Hey Jon, the top was fine, it was the middle.  It not Dirty per say just not clean enough to solo and it is safe with a #5. I maybe misread and thought the beta was "it's so easy you dont need big gear" and hope others dont make my foolish mistake.  Take the 5 (or 2) Just before the easy slab at the top I got a #2 in so that was chill. Sep 14, 2021

routes.route_fa: G. Olsen, D. Cramer, J. Baird, S. Cordery, and FDC Willard
routes.route_description: Joins End Run via a direct start from the base. Clip two bolts, with the crux at the second involving mantles onto dishes.After the second bolt, move to the base of the crack (for On the Rebound), then follow thin edges up and left into End Run.It is rather runout to the first bolt and from the crack to End Run, but in both cases, the runout parts are much easier than the crux.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 7 bolts plus a nut of about 1-2" or a hand-sized cam.

route_comments.comment_text: This looks like a fun, and puzzling, start to either End Run or On the Rebound. The bottom has lots of big knobs, which is unusual for this crag. Jun 4, 2019

When clean, the climbing to the first bolt is trivial compared to the crux.   I remember the crux being well protected but the following moves are non trivial (although they get easier with every move) and there is a possibility of hitting the "big knobs" in the case of a fall.  The climbing if you like slab stuff is actually pretty good. Nov 25, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. In desperate need of some brushing. Too much moss to do the bottom.

routes.route_name: Somedays, Me and My Duck Elmont Walk Barefoot in the Mud,
routes.route_fa: then Go Inside to Eat Toast and Watch the BBC
routes.route_description: Mainly crack, corner, and undercling climbing here, except for the crux. The crux is face climbing on a low-angle seam feature at the very top, and is in need of a bolt for leading. Presently, you can still lead it, but exit to the Hag Crack anchor (5.8 to here). Easy to set up a TR on.If you are the first of the season, you will probably need to do a quick scraping with the small serrated scythe tool ("kama") that had been kept nearby at the brush station. Or, use a nut tool.
routes.route_location: It starts with Hag Crack, then trends left and up, going to the highest point on this little crag.
routes.route_protection: Small stoppers and cams to 3" if one is just going to the Hag Crack anchor. Otherwise, set up a TR.
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. It was alright. Nobs and small gear. Finger crack was nice. With Ryan and Jesse.

routes.route_name: Those Two Hummingbirds Who Never Met
routes.route_fa: Jon Nelson, Adam Starecheski, David Swayne July 28, 2021
routes.route_description: Start up a short finger crack that takes good gear to a stance. Clip a bolt and make some difficult moves onto the face and into another series of discontinuous finger cracks. Place gear then fire onto a marvelous knobby face. Clip another bolt then move through a few overlaps to the final slab that exists on top of a flake. Anchors are at the top on a ledge. Walk off or rappel hag crack.
routes.route_location: The furthest right route at Hag Crag. Look for the bolt about 12 feet off the ground.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 0.75 with extra in the finger sizes and a rack of nuts. 2 Bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: As more of a face, knob, and thin crack climb, this adds some variety to Hag Crag. Being a moderate is also a big plus. The crux for me is a high step getting over the top of the initial finger crack. For TR, it is easy to walk around right to the top (look for the handline across the ramp above the route). Several fixed anchors exist, the rightmost is best for this route. A single 70 m... more As more of a face, knob, and thin crack climb, this adds some variety to Hag Crag. Being a moderate is also a big plus. The crux for me is a high step getting over the top of the initial finger crack. For TR, it is easy to walk around right to the top (look for the handline across the ramp above the route). Several fixed anchors exist, the rightmost is best for this route. A single 70 m rope would work (and probably a 60 m, but please check first). Jul 29, 2021
Whoever cleaned this route, thumbs up for the patience. We had fun climbing it! Aug 1, 2021

Thanks for putting up another moderate on the Hag Jon! Had a fun time trying to solve the bottom portion. Along with the slabby foot based portion at the top. A good warm-up for the others up there. Aug 20, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Left foot in the jam. Reach for a left crimp and a right chicken head. Move right foot to a small ledge. Remove left foot from jam and up to the chicken head · Lead / Fell/Hung. Left hand on knob, reach high to finger crack with right, switch feet to free left foot, left foot on knob, rock over. · TR. Really hard crux move bolted on the slab. Need to throw to the top rail, then bump to the finger jam. · Lead / Redpoint. AMTL 3: tricky move above first bolt was a bit sketchy with my beta. TR'd it first (clean) and then a clean lead. Really full moves lower down. Did the bottom bolt-protected move differently on TR than on lead, but both worked. Used micros #0.2 to #0.5 on bottom 2/3 and a #3 up top. · TR. Low crux: right foot on chalky outer part (further out to right) of foot pocket, right hand out to small knob press, left hand press on the knob (or use the small crack?) to get high enough to use a hand assist to get left foot up to big knob. Not tall enough to get foot high enough without assist! · Follow. Low crux to the first bolt. Eases up after that. Holly on belay. · Lead. Fun crux at bottom protected by bolt. Nervous at first since the gear looks small but it's all very solid · TR. couldn't commit for the crux move but I think the sequence should work: left foot jam, pull on left side crimp, right foot up to tiny ledge, pull up and reach the jug high up right, left foot on the big knob. got to come back for this. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Stout for the grade, safe lead and fun! Probably much easier for tall folk, and far harder for shorties. · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Martin - had a ton of fun on this pitch! First bolt is the crux. · TR. Worked the crux which felt so hard and also reachy. Lots of top rope cheating but I sort of got it · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the first bolt, did the rest of it clean. To get first bolt, get left hand to the nub, place QuickDraw. Then jam left foot in, get right hand on the extremely small crimp, move left hand over to the sideways crimp, then readjust left foot to a bit higher and not a jam. Push up with the left foot, catch the under long with the right hand, put right foot on the non-existent ledge, bump left hand up to a sideways crimp, then reach right hand to the big nub. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux is at the first bolt. The rest of the route is just okay. · TR. Why is this climb always so hard at the bottom. Also wet. Classic index sandbagging a 5.9. · TR. Mock lead, 0.3, bolt for crux, 0.2, 0.2, bolt for slab, 0.5, run out to top? Try matching seam from foot jam instead of pressing the knob in crux · TR. Getting past the first bolt is super hard. Maybe easier with fresh hands. Super fun above first boot. · Follow. ~, stopped and took a couple times in the crux at the start. · Lead / Onsight. Hung after first bolt to take some test falls, but would have been able to send without no problem. · Lead / Redpoint. Punted twice at the bottom. Once before the first bolt, once after. Sent third try with first bolt clipped. · TR. I cleaned inside most of the finger cracks, I tried to climb it but I fell at the first bolt because the crack before it was drenched. So beware that after rain the base is super wet · Lead / Onsight. One super-high foot down low and then some slab spookiness higher up. Good route! · TR. Protects well. I think I'm ready to lead it next time I'm in that area · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell messing around. Would definitely come back and climb clean. Bring smaller cams for finger crack · TR. clean redpoint attempt, took a minute to figure out the crux. trust the small crack. · Lead. Tricky start. Especially while teaching Emilie to lead belay for her first time. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell many times at the crux by first bolt. Eventually figured out good left foot beta · TR. Personal note: lean on hand rail, bring up left foot. Beta for your crux · Follow. This crux!!! Made me wonder if I even know how to climb. Really just climbed it for the adorable name. With Josh · Crux was right after the first bolt. Committing slab move at the top - just trust your right foot. · TR. super fun and more like 5.8-. Gear is good and the moves are great. nice thin finger crack right at the start of the route. · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Did not onsight, start is reachy. More like 10+ if 5’8 · Lead / Redpoint. Super fun! Would do again. Everything after the first two bolts though isn’t very exciting. · Lead / Fell/Hung. First fall on gear! Fell on a .3 I placed above the first bolt. Recovered and sent the rest · Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux after the first bolt, took a couple tries to figure out. Fun route! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Really fun climbing, lots of variety. Felt quite cruxy after the first bolt.

area_description: This wall lies just left of Lookout Point (separated by  a steep, brushy gully) and below the Diamond. At its base lies the Wall of Ten-thousand Insects, and to its left and slightly below lies Rattletale. The upper left side of this wall has a large, left-facing roof. The wall is steeper, on average, than Lookout Point, but generally less than vertical.
area_getting_there: Take the trail to Lookout Point, staying left at the huge Midnite boulder, then right at the next T intersection, heading towards the Private Idaho turnoff. Instead of going right to Private Idaho, continue up left of Brad Driscol towards the Party Zone, the steep, blocky white wall that has a waterfall at its left side in winter and spring. Duck Wall begins just left of the waterfall.From below the waterfall, look for the trail that goes left into the woods. Duck Wall has several lower tiers separated by treed ledges, and the lowest tier is also known as the Wall of Ten-thousand Insects. WOTI has several fun, short crack climbs. For routes on the upper tiers, continue left along the base of this short wall and head up towards the Diamond gully. Several routes start close to this gully.Alternatively, from the T intersection past Midnite boulder, branch off left from the Lookout-Point trail to head towards Rattletale. Upon reaching the boulder field, head up towards the Diamond gully. To reach other routes, take the trail right along a forested ledge below the cliff.

routes.route_description: Five stars. Completely overhung climbing, perfect rock, a proud position, wild, pumpy movement and a sicky gnar gnar crux sequence combine to make this one of the finest routes at Index. You owe it to yourself to get your grrr on and do this thing.Aside from 2 or 3 holds at the top (one of which is a huge jug) the route stays dry in the rain for climber and belayer.
routes.route_location: Approach via Planet Caravan, or walk uphill to the Diamond and head down towards the top of Duck Wall to set up TR.
routes.route_protection: Fixed draws and anchor.

Route is currently equipped with Perm-draws (this is great because the route is a pain to clean). This rig would have a line on it if it was located @ LTW--but that goes without saying for all the... more Endless Skies is SO GOOD. I'd recommend approach through Planet Caravan P1) 5.11,  P2 (5.10-); at which point Endless Skies becomes obvious. There is a short traverse via fixed rope to the belay. Route is currently equipped with Perm-draws (this is great because the route is a pain to clean). This rig would have a line on it if it was located @ LTW--but that goes without saying for all the classics out there that actual require a modicum of hiking and resolve to get off the beaten track. Bring jeans or a knee pad. Thanks Michal and Stig. Jul 15, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. I didn’t tick this, just leaving a note. As to the comment above, couple of loose bolts. Most looked great and tight. I ripped hanger 5 or 6 off the wall when I fell on the undercling move. Seemed fine when I clipped. I left it clipped to the belay anchors below. Great route all in all. Amazing movement way up there. Feels airy. · I did not get the last move, but to me the logical way I see to go is up and left which would make it easier maybe 12b. Currently there’s a lot of dirt there and needs some cleaning, but could ge good. The current 12d way seems counterintuitive since there’s a ledge you can stand on 1ft to your left. But again I didn’t send it so I don’t know for sure. · Follow. Ha! Spent day 1 rapping down the adjacent cliffs looking for the route, and Day 2 getting shut down · Lead / Redpoint. FA with Michal. First go for both of us on my last day in Index for five weeks. Super happy.

routes.route_description: Great route. A nice 5.8 hand crack leads to a crux finger crack section near top of route. Fun route!To descend, you can either rap or walk left (west, away from LOP) to a handline.
routes.route_location: Approach from trail to Private Idaho, cairn marks the turn-off to the left. Trail is easy to miss.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack. You can get a #3 Camalot in down low, and finger size gear protects the crux (yellow TCU).Anchor has two mussy hooks.

route_comments.comment_text: the top out was a bushy, dirty, mossy mess. Now cleaner as of Aug 2013. New sling on tree, but still needs anchor. Aug 20, 2013

Left foot up on chip. With knee into dihedral and back step. Stance should be more narrow than you think

routes.route_description: Walk up forested ledge towards Meadow and Spicer. Near the crest, about 30' from that route, cut left and down slightly on the obvious ledge.P1: Walk the above ledge. From the end of the ledge go up to the base of a clean corner (5.5).P2: Climb the clean, large left-facing corner. Sustained. Traverse out the roof (pumpy) to a rest. Then climb the wide crack with face holds on the main Duck Wall face. Some excitement as you approach the fixed anchor (5.10).P3: Traverse right and up to the base of a roof band.P4: Traverse left, just under the roof band (5.10d).P5: Go up, trending right to the top. This pitch can be combined with P4.Rap from here, or rap down Meadow and Spicer (top rap of the latter is a tree).
routes.route_location: Take the trail to Duck Wall. Where the trail meets the wall (at the large right-facing corner), trend right on a treed ledge system. The trail should have a fixed line near the start, and another one near the end (which goes up to Meadow and Spicer). The route starts just before this second fixed line.
routes.route_protection: Single rack to 3" doubles of BD sizes 1-3. You can place a 4" but a 3" will also work. Include a selection of nuts.

route_comments.comment_text: Got on this over the weekend. Only made it to the top of pitch 2 due to the heat baking us. Pitch 2 is super fun, and not as hard as it looks. Thanks Derek for your hard work putting this up, it's a gem. Hope to get up there and do the whole route when the temps come down, or wait til later in the day when it gets shade. Jul 20, 2015

I only did p1 and p2. Followed p1, lead p2. P1 felt more like 5.7 to me. P2 was definitely 5.10, not easier than it looks. Cruxes are the Crack to get to the roof, and few moves before the anchors. I dealt with bad rope drag from not choosing my placements accordingly before the roof. Besides that, fun fun fun. Stoked to try it again. Feb 5, 2016

Update: 3 of the bolts on P4 now have hangers on them, much safer than before! - 2 raps with a 70m will get you down from the very top. - P3 is dirty/chossy but climbable - Link P4/P5 For a fun, mellow alternative, Do P1-P3 and then go out right from the belay and climb the second pitch of meadow and spicer to the top (look for bolts and a slabby crack). Apr 3, 2016

Whipped after the travers on 4 and scraped my shin good. 2 was sweet and so was 4. We brought a wire brush up and cleaned 1 and 5. · Follow. Led pitch 1. Followed pitches 2-3, fell on pitch 4 traverse… oh boy · Lead. i really enjoyed this climb. Wild down climb to slab and roof pull on next pitch. Also missing bolt hanger. · 2 pitches. routes.route_description: A straight-up, vertical layback crack in a shallow corner. It starts with a few fist jams, but quickly narrows to fingers. Relatively short (~40-50 feet), but quite sustained.
routes.route_location: As of spring 2023, there is an easy access path to the base. As you approach Duck Wall from the gully below LOP, take the usual trail left (west) approaching Index Air Force and Them (also known as WOTI wall). Immediately look for a path going right (uphill) directly to the base of the wall to the east of Them. Upon reaching the wall, walk along the base 10-20' and behind a big flake find the iron rungs. Take these up to the forested ledge and walk east. The route will be obvious.The original access to this route took one to the top anchor. Take the trail along the base of the wall. After the first rope ladder, and before the second, walk right to the obvious ledge with the two-bolt anchor right above the point where the crack reaches the ledge. Lower down from here to the large treed ledge.
routes.route_protection: It is conveniently set for a top-rope, with a bolted anchor on a walk-up ledge.For leading, take a cam or two for a fist-size crack and then an assortment of finger-sized gear for a finger crack (perhaps one hand-sized cam would help).

routes.route_fa: Derek Pearson, Michael Rynkiewicz, Ryan Hoover, Ried Hurtig, Marc Bow
routes.route_description: An excellent climb that stands out by its radical hanging stem box. It also has great corners, fun face and some tricky slab. A total classic!P1 5.10+ - Start face climbing past 3 bolts and traverse right into the corner.P2 5.10a - Climb the stem box.P3 5.11a - Traverse left on the slab.  Continue up and right up the fun blocky overhangs.
routes.route_location: Traverse right at the base of Planet Caravan. Follow up a short hill and the granite stepping stones will lead you to the base.
routes.route_protection: Singles to .75 and a 60 meter rope.

route_comments.comment_text: Got on this yesterday. It’s worth it for the stem box. The first pitch is a challenging onsight. Jul 22, 2018
Climbed the first pitch yesterday. Felt hard, but very cool. Clean route with cool movement. Bolts are well placed! Mar 18, 2019
Really cool movement. The first pitch feels harder than Planet Caravan and has some super improbable moves. Mar 18, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Took p2…. Sooooo FUUUUNNN!! p1 is tricky face climbing

routes.route_fa: Darryl Cramer, Nicola Masciandaro, Jon Nelson
routes.route_description: P1 starts with a stick-clip (see stick lying nearby) to the first bolt. Either pull up on the rope to reach the ledge or do a short V2-3 (5.11c) sequence. From the ledge, follow the corner up to the roof (~10a), go over the roof (~10a/b), face climb up to the crack, and climb the wide crack (~8+/9) to a large, slightly downsloping ledge with a chained 2-bolt anchor.P2 starts up the corner just above the anchor, and goes up to the crack above on the headwall. The crux move is about 5.8, getting into the crack. The crack, which is finger-sized with hand pods every few feet, goes to a nice flat ledge with a two-bolt chained anchor.P3 goes up the short flake/corner system to the top (~5.6). There is no metallic anchor up here, just a bunch of trees. But the view and setting is wonderful.
routes.route_location: Follow trail rightward along base of wall to highest point. Look for the bolt about 12-feet up.
routes.route_protection: Small wired nuts to fist-sized cams. It's useful to have a small brass nut (e.g., RP #5) for the first piece off the ledge on P1.

route_comments.comment_text: Awesome route that has cool granite features, even has a hueco Sep 23, 2011

A nice extension is to wander up the now destroyed by rock fall slope to climb Pork Chop Torpedo 10b. Aug 20, 2013

routes.route_description: A wonderfully physical climb. Start on slopers leading to laybacks and compression. Quite steep for Index. No one move is hard but linking them is the crux.
routes.route_location: Left of Planet Caravan, right of Sweets from Manuel
routes.route_protection: Qd's
