routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. 2 tries for 1 hang for the festival comp. 3: balancey L crimp knob w R high gaston to step up. Lieback R up for 4 (hard to hang) until can lockoff to L sp, clip 5 via drop stem LF off R. Then crux: R up where thumb catch, RF indent, LF smear face, RF out to good foot right, shallow knee bar. LF against right corner, hard lieback L up on smeary feet. Shoulder burner!! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Beautiful route. 3: high R gaston to walk up L ramp w R sps. 4: R lockoff Gaston into good L sp. Hard clip 5 off opposing sps and no LF. Maybe go higher till RF edge, LF backflag, R sp?

routes.route_fa: Ryan Hoover, Michal Rynkiewicz, Stamati Anagnostou, Jon Nelson
routes.route_description: A scrambly approach pitch leads to a large ledge and bolt anchor.P1: Climb the granite AF bolted corner to the base of a large chasm. 5.11-P2: A rarity for Index. Small gear behind your back, a couple of bolts, and some larger cams protect an amazing squeeze chimney. Head out right and up onto the slab. 5.9P3: Splitter! A finger crack in a corner leads to chain anchors. You can top out Duck Wall and combine this with any of the routes on the Diamond for a nice long day! 5.9
routes.route_location: Head up the Diamond gulley and look for an obvious large left facing corner system to your right. Can't miss it.
routes.route_protection: 8 QDs, some long runners, doubles in fingers and singles from #1-#3 Camalot.

route_comments.comment_text: Super fun route! Absolutely worth climbing. First pitch is 11- slab tech. I suck at chimneys so I thought p2 was harder than 5.9, but it's probably a fair grade if you enjoy those sorts of things. I enjoyed it a lot but also sucked at it. P3 was reall fun as well. Maybe 10a/b rather than 5.9. Nice work guys! Jun 22, 2018

Fun route up the Duck Wall. IMO the 1st bolt on the crux pitch would have been better to place up on the R aspect of the LFC in order to facilitate rope management.  Found several loose hangars. Otherwise excellent.  I think most will find 5.11 or 11+ difficulties on the first pitch if they haven't wired it on TR or rope solo. Breakdown 1. 5.11 2. 10- 3. 10- Jul 9, 2019
We broke 2 holds off of the first pitch. But it shouldn't have changed the grade at all. Chimney was on grade for 9+ but I like chimneys so your mileage may vary. Oct 27, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Temporarily stymied by a spot on p1. Led p2. Hail sabbath. · Follow. led p2, wild. slab crux: high l foot, reach down and press with r hand to get r foot up · Lead. 1 and 2 to endless skies. 1st pitch was fun 2nd pitch kinda sucked · Lead / Fell/Hung. Super fun climb. I suck at all of this climbing, slab, stem, chimney. Was amazing to get it handed to me. The first pitch sits in the sun most of the day, so plan to do it early if you’re going for it. Obviously temps help. If you top it out, you can carefully walk down to the left, then up to the diamond wall, then back down the trail. · Lead / Fell/Hung. With Carter, by any means necessary, 0.1 cam blew out while hanging

routes.route_description: Follow a crack-corner system to a small roof. The crux is a fingertip layback about 20 feet up. Go right around the roof, then cut back left.
routes.route_location: On the far-left side of the wall. Immediately upon reaching the wall, locate the obvious, left-facing dihedral directly above. (This dihedral is "Planet Caravan".) Walk left about 30 feet. The route starts in a right-facing dihedral with a hand-sized crack.
routes.route_protection: Small nuts to hand-sized cams.

route_comments.comment_text: Has anyone climbed this route recently? Looks really cool from below. Are there chains or just tat on a tree? Couldn't tell from the ground. Dec 6, 2015
It still has tat around a tree. Dec 9, 2015
Jon, what does the extension go at? Jun 2, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Not bad at all, crux lil heady but fine w a .3 in · Lead. Tried to clean it up a bit. Decent route that need more traffic. · Lead. Blew the move exiting the finger section for no good reason! Fun! (SA)

routes.route_description: This short route is really good. It starts out with a thin corner, followed by a cool traverse to the right, and ending with a short wide section going straight up.To descend, you can walk left (west) and then take a handline for a short steep section. A chain anchor above Index Air Force with mussy hooks could be used to rap if no one is climbing that route.
routes.route_location: Look for the obvious right-facing flake on the right side of the wall (before the wall goes uphill to a chimney). The route's shape resembles Sagittarius at the Lower Town Wall, except smaller and reversed left-right.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 4". chain anchors.

route_comments.comment_text: New (and welcome) rap chains were in place on 6/30/2009. Jul 1, 2009
It looks steep and strenuous, but there are good footholds. Oct 9, 2011
This was a really nice climb. I would recommend it for sure, I found the flake to be easier than I expected, but the start harder. Cams - 4" Oct 4, 2012

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Gretchen Led Fell at the start and took a break at the top before the last section · Lead / Onsight. But hung a few times, trying to get a feel for the moves. Nice route! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Highkey botched the onsight fallin on the first piece had me yellin take like I was a director · Lead / Onsight. would be 4 stars if there was more of it. perfect hands and fists for me · Follow. Too worked- Liza & I both struggled to get up to the undercling & bailed on the lead. Followed Tyler and sent! Go big and flail on the R hand jug instead of delicate. Flake is easy. 2x 4 for upper crack. · Lead / Redpoint. With Lindsey. Took a sec to figure out the beta but got it clean after a few tries. Sweaty. · Lead / Onsight. #1,2,3,4,4. Placed 3 under roof, then another high from next stance, back cleaned 1st and extended higher one with single runner and flick rope outside crack. Could maybe get another 3 higher but ran the layback to the fist crack. Go deep for fist & forearm jams. Short but spicy! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung at one point. Beta: Start: use finger crack and stem on whatever you can, just push through it until you get to good feet. Middle is easy, layback/climb flake and trust feet will be there. Bear hug near end of wide section at end. Last third can only be protected with #3 and #4 cams. · TR. Getting into the roof is tough. Off fists at the top were rad. Threw a few Rosie the riveters and felt cool. · Lead / Onsight. Stellar Crack, so good, don't get your 3 stuck with the rope at the edge. w/ Gretchen · Follow. end of the day but the start felt a little burly + crack at top wider than my fists, take two 4s · Lead. crux is short and committing but good rest. I used a #5 but double s in #4 would be better · Lead / Flash. Flashed. First two place were pre-placed. Had gear beta before hand. .1,.2,.75,1, 3x3,2x4 · Lead / Redpoint. Felt really smooth, ton of fun, great place for taking pictures to the right of the traversing section! · Lead / Flash. Easier than it looks. (1, 2, 3.5, 4x2) sews it up.

area_description: Steep, secluded wall just right of the Beyond.
area_getting_there: 1) From the flagpole on top of Lookout Point:Walk back and down (west) into the woods, first descending down within 20' of the rim, and then going just below the big boulder (Rainy Day). Below this boulder, notice a black bathtub. From here cut across the hill descending slightly, following the faint trail that heads for the big wall to the north in back. Carefully cross the rocky gully (that empties onto Duck Wall) to reach the base.2) From the top of Velvet Pedestal routes and the via thing:Walk up and back (north), following the faint trail that joins the above trail coming down from the bathtub. It crosses the gully and heads straight for the base of the wall.3) From the Diamond:Follow the trail up towards The Beyond, then skirt right and around, just above Duck Wall.

area_comments.comment_text: What is the black bathtub for? My guess is to collect water for cleaning routes, since there's a hose you could connect for directing water. Doesn't look like it has been used recently. Aug 5, 2024

routes.route_description: Steep sport to moderate, left leaning, slab. Cool quartz pockets, to mild chicken heads with a fun stemming/chimney finish.(From Ryan Mullet's description on RCNW.net.)
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 9 bolts and 3 pieces of gear (#2, #3, #.5/.75 camalots)

routes.route_description: Laybacking, jamming, and chimneying in a large, steep, right-facing flake. Like a mirror image to Sagittarius at the Lower Town Wall or a few Thems at Duck Wall.The crack in the slab at the start tends to clog with pine needles.(All info here is based on Ryan Mullet's description on RCNW.net)
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Small nuts and double set of cams (blue metolius to #3 camalot and one #4 camalot. Also, bring lots of long slings.

area_description: This is the wall right of the cave feature, named after the first route done here. On the far right side, with the yellow rock, lies the Fire Wall and several routes listed here.This wall has vastly improved since 2017, thanks to the cleaning and rebolting efforts of Adam Sultan and Douglas Taylor. So, if you haven't visited since then, you might want to check it out again. Pay them some respects with a few stars and comments if you have time.
area_getting_there: From the notch, follow the base of the wall on the south side (Toxic-Tang area) past the cave.

area_comments.comment_text: There are some syntactical errors I noticed on my topo descriptions. Please just ignore them, thanks. Aug 17, 2017

As of now it is okay to use my fixed lines on the lower pitches of Foodbar wall to rappel or TR solo until I remove them. Please do not touch the white rope on the upper pitches, I do not want to be responsible if that rope's core shot fails. Aug 19, 2017
Thanks for all the hard work!! Jun 2, 2021

routes.route_description: A splitter wide crack, a rarity for Index. With its locker fist jams, a few offwidthy moves, and a juggy lieback, this thing is a 4 star climb!A 60m just makes the ground for the rappel. Geoff Georges added a new bolted anchor at the top in 2018.An excellent route to do when it's too warm to climb at the Lower Wall.
routes.route_location: Walk past toxic/even steven area approximately 200ft and look back and left for the obvious wide splitter in a right facing corner.
routes.route_protection: 3,3.5,4,4.5 camalots old sizes, double up or walk them if you want.  A couple med sizes pieces are nice for the dirty top too.

route_comments.comment_text: Got cocky and attempted to do this with only one #4 and #5. Would definitely recommend bringing two #4s or equivalent unless you're very comfortable on wide fists (I'm not, and resorted to a strenuous layback for the first 20ft of the route while trying to walk the #4, not a great combination). A single #5 works fine as the crack widens the stances get better and face holds appear over the... more Got cocky and attempted to do this with only one #4 and #5. Would definitely recommend bringing two #4s or equivalent unless you're very comfortable on wide fists (I'm not, and resorted to a strenuous layback for the first 20ft of the route while trying to walk the #4, not a great combination). A single #5 works fine as the crack widens the stances get better and face holds appear over the lip. I don't think I used any #3s. For the first pitch a light single rack is fine. Would be awesome if the first pitch and topout were clean!! Aug 2, 2016
The top out is basically a pile of moss.  It seems like an anchor on the left side of the small ledge would be a great addition. May 21, 2017
As of 5/21/17 there is a pair of decent fixed ropes leading up to the base of the second pitch. May 21, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Steve lead P1 (mossy and dirty but mostly fine, getting around chockstone on left side was spicy), I flailed & aided some of p2. 2x#4 and 2x#5 for p2. Top out spooky, lots of detached blocks held together by moss and hope, didn't place any gear after the last #5. 10a? Felt at least as hard as 11's in the creek. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Made it all the way through the offwidth to the end but was too gassed to pull final jug. Should have used footholds above roof in this section. Oops. · 2 pitches. Follow. Climbing it as two pitches is recommend unless the leader is confident with off width. The intermediate belay station protects the off width section much better. I led the first half and let my partner lead the second half. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took once after roof. Felt too pumped to bump 5 or run it out to anchors but was only one more move to jugs. TR clean. W/ Emma and Ben S. · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Led p1, top roped p2 twice. Elbow jams were the key · TR. Fell once, took once. Used lessons learned from lead. Use the small feet out left and right, much easier that way! Hand stacks undercling prior to roof allowed me to position feet precisely from stable position. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell a couple times on lead on second pitch. Got pretty pumped out doing bicep/elbow locks before integrating my second arm to facilitate arms locks. Learned not to bump feet too high up relative to hand/butterfly stacks. Moving back up into layback upper hands from that position is not very doable on vertical to slightly overhung terrain, feels very desperate compared to nearly straight lower/in corner leg nearly extended. Layback through the roof. Transitioning back into the crack is challenging but works with knee locks. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lead the first pitch clean. Interesting pulling around the chockstone. Plugged a #3 deep back behind the chockstone with a double length extension and then climbed up around left of the chockstone. Started leading the second pitch. Difficult fist crack, slightly overhung and a little too large for me to get bomber fist jams. Feet felt okay if you get them deep enough. Fell lots of times, leapfrogging the 4s until the roof and then same with the 5s above. Glorious jugs just above the roof. Learned 5s are knee locks for me. 4s are difficult. Ended up arm batting with left arm + pulling into right face with right hand while bumping feet up. I think liebacking the crack would have been more straightforward but too pumpy for me to lead on such slippery feet on the left wall of the right facing dihedral. · Lead / Onsight. Cool climb. Prob tried too hard to OW the moves. Next time need to see if I can get a calf lock (At) · Lead / Fell/Hung. Literally aided my way past the 4”-5” section. Then TR’d it. Gear: single small to 3”, doubles 4” and 5”. Smart to have triple 4”. Feels like 5.10c · TR. Learned a lot. Still took twice but getting closer to being capable of a proper lead. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took once at the roof. .75, .3, .5, 8x alpines, 3x 4, 5. Should go next time · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Followed pitch 1 fell on pitch 2 probably won’t come back but if I do remember to lie back at the top. It seemed very close. · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell, then cheated at crux. did it without falling on toprope afterwards so need to go back and try again. · 2 pitches. Followed the first pitch (no falls). Flailed and fell leading the upper pitch. What an amazing route · Lead / Fell/Hung. at least I didn't have to pull on gear this time... and had energy left to TR the roof clean... · TR. Burly. Used plenty of laybacking. Perhaps try 'elevator door' technique to make prettier attempt another time.

routes.route_description: Quite possibly the best sport line in the Inner Walls and the only multi-pitch in the area as of August 2017. After eyeing this line from the ground for nearly 4 years, I managed to squeeze in putting this beauty up before moving away. Skip the paragraph below if you don't want any beta.BETA: Begin on moderate climbing on blocky holds trending rightwards to a bomber heel hook below the 2nd bolt. After clipping the 3rd bolt, throw out right to a big pinch and then up to a small 3 finger crimp. Match the good horizontal hold at bolt 4 and throw right to a small side pull, then out left to the arete where a jug resides. Rest up on the big jug below the roof and then a hard sequence with an undercling in a horizontal crack out right to the arete. Enjoy the last good rest at the base of the twin cracks and gear up for the pumpy finish. After pulling up onto the sloppy ledge at bolt 9, save some energy in the tank for the "heartbreaker" crux. Using compression, liebacking and finger locks will put you at the hero jug out left. Top out and take in an interesting view of the inner walls.5.11 is not my intended grade because my intent is to leave this route is ungraded. I expect the final grade will be between 5.11b-5.12b and will update the grade after sufficient consensus.
routes.route_location: Climb either Humpback Humpback Humpback Whale, Foodbar, or Sucker Punch (from easiest to hardest) to access.
routes.route_protection: 10 Bolts, leave your rack at the belay. Bolted Anchor. Two 30m rappels to the ground.

route_comments.comment_text: This route should not be missed by those in the area! I did find alternative beta above the 3rd bolt which did not require a throw to the big pinch---though this is exactly what my taller friend ended up using. The crux at the end is quite technical. We both thought 5.12a was quite appropriate --and in comparison with other routes in the area was slightly harder than Tie Me another Length Of... more This route should not be missed by those in the area! I did find alternative beta above the 3rd bolt which did not require a throw to the big pinch---though this is exactly what my taller friend ended up using. The crux at the end is quite technical. We both thought 5.12a was quite appropriate --and in comparison with other routes in the area was slightly harder than Tie Me another Length Of That but much easier than Roadside Floral Curtain. Sucker Punch (just below) felt 12b which I sent just after doing The Breakup. Aug 26, 2019
I also agree that this route is spectacular. The final series of moves is on a really proud feature with great postion. Awesome! Aug 27, 2019

I followed a much stronger climber up this.  Although I hung a lot, it only made me wish I was stronger.  The moves aren't especially hard to figure out, just that there's a lot of them to do.  I've only followed it, but I strongly recommend that better climbers than me get on it.  It's super fun. Jul 30, 2020

routes.route_description: A short chimney route. The beta topo for the wall shows the original name for this route. In 2017, it was extensively recleaned and renamed.
routes.route_location: About 150' right of the cave. Six other climbs are very close, including Sucker Punch.
routes.route_protection: One will have to judge from the ground.

route_comments.comment_text: Wait, now my routes are being "unearthed" retro-cleaned and renamed?!  Haha.  Full circle in one short generation. Chimney Sweep is such a great name.  It works on many levels for that area.  Who came up with it? Aug 19, 2017

Yes, that is a short time for the route to get a new life. Anyway, I was told by Adam and Doug that they got the OK from you about the renaming. It seems though that the amount of recleaning was extensive. I wish someone would do the same for "View from the Bridge". If I were to name it now, I would not choose that name. Aug 19, 2017
Route was good. Burly but what chimney isn't. Gear Beta: Single rack to #4 Camalot,  Extra thin stuff (.2 and .3 X4's) and a Runner or two. Aug 26, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. W Stephen, Ben. Some groveling in the chimney, but my offwidth techniques are really improving. · TR. fun but seems like it would be a hard to protect lead, remember to look up and right when exiting the chimney · Lead / Onsight. Felt substantially harder then the Golden Jug. Save a .3 for the top · 2 pitches. Lead. Tricky gear on lead. Big and small stuff. A 4 was nice for the top crux protected final move with a nut, perhaps save a .2/.1 for the top next time. Lots of little gear (made some nests). Tr after was cruiser

routes.route_description: At the start, place gear to 3.5". Then gain an arete and then traverse right under a roof to a perfect finger crack in a bright yellow corner. Climb to the chains just over a second roof (take several .5 camalots).
routes.route_location: About 200' right of the cave, below a yellow-streaked wall. Just right of Yellow Cake.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3.5".

route_comments.comment_text: I’m not sure who is correct or if it matters too much, but according to the guidebook the climber in the second picture (traversing right on a hand rail) is actually on Yellow Cake. After pulling this bulge and going up a finger crack, it continues up a left trending route, where as China Syndrome (again, according to the book topo) goes up the flake on the left, past a bolt and continues... more I’m not sure who is correct or if it matters too much, but according to the guidebook the climber in the second picture (traversing right on a hand rail) is actually on Yellow Cake. After pulling this bulge and going up a finger crack, it continues up a left trending route, where as China Syndrome (again, according to the book topo) goes up the flake on the left, past a bolt and continues right to the arete. We accidentally climbed the criss crossed variations “Yellow Syndrome” and “China Cake” and thought both were fun. Crux for me was getting past the bolt before the roof and onto the slab. I will second that 3 .5s were nice to have. You can access the climbs via a shitty mossy scramble on the left that goes to the ledge, an obviously climbed thin finger crack dihedral slab (may want to back clean), or easy mossy cracks/ blocks on the right. Just be mindful that both climbs have hard moves not far off the ledge. Jul 9, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · This thing is a bomb in current conditions and likely for a long time. · Couldn’t do the hard moves at the bottom, even on TR, and aided the .1/.2 crack below the anchor. · I climbed a z shaped route with all the cruxes of the wall and lots of rope drag

routes.route_description: The first route on the wall, thus giving Foodbar Wall its name.While I opted to make Humpback Humpback Whale safer for the masses, I left Foodbar in its original spicy state. All gear, no bolts.Start as with Humpback Humpback Humpback Whale but instead of going left to the bolt, pull out your wires or even better, a black totem and protect the thin and technical cruz through the corner. With bad gear below and thin gear protecting you from the ground, this is a heady lead for the grade. Simply put, a more direct, harder, and headier HHHW. Fear not, however, as this variation can be easily top-roped by climbing the safer and easier HHHW.
routes.route_location: Foodbar Wall, right
routes.route_protection: Standard Rack to 4". Black and blue totems are clutch for the crux as well as DMM offsets.

route_comments.comment_text: I seem to recall a knotted piece of webbing for pro on the FA. Completely unnecessary now, I'm sure. Aug 17, 2017
Definitely no webbing on it right now. The gear below the roof is subpar but from the foot ledge I managed to get small stuff in and build a nest. Aug 17, 2017
seemed a lot more than 1-2 letter grades harder than it's neighbor hhhw, but maybe my fingers are just too fat May 16, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · After Humpback W/Alan D. Cleaned while lowering, and glad I did. Was dirty with crud in the placements! · TR. Cruxed out at the strong LB move into the blind left hand pocket. Able to finally get it by finding an edge and shifting out left before pulling to jug. Great area for afternoon shade. · TR. DNF crux haard compared to the two 5.10s Gold Bucket and Humpback to the left. · TR. felt way way harder than humpback humpback humpback whale, would not want to lead this

routes.route_description: Begin up the thin steep crack with a couple bolts to the right of Golden Bucket. Pull a hard move over the techy roof and head up the lower-angle corner above to the HHHW anchors. Alternatively (better) step left after the roof and finish as for Golden Bucket.
routes.route_location: Start as for Golden Bucket but head right to the crack with bolts.
routes.route_protection: SR with smaller gear, several quickdraws

route_comments.comment_text: This is a tricky 5.10 crack with good gear to a stout height dependent boulder problem. I've watched several strong climbers under 6' really struggle. Still stout if you're over 6 feet. Safe and fun though! Oct 9, 2022

routes.route_description: This fantastic moderate in the Inner Walls has been fully restored and retrofitted with a new bolt protecting the potential ground fall at the crux as part of the Foodbar Wall restoration project.Start on top of the large boulder and step across climbing on bomber blocky jugs to the first bolt. A short and fun crux sequence, which can be done a myriad of ways will plop you onto incut jugs. Climb through the splitter 3" corner to the "Golden Jug" and through the 5.10a roof. Continue up ledgy terrain to the tree where a new anchor has been installed.Highly recommend to anyone trying to break through into the 5.10's or stronger climbers looking for the perfect warmup. Get on it!
routes.route_location: Foodbar Wall, center.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack to 3".

route_comments.comment_text: Previously named, "Inner Thigh". After consulting the FA party they agreed to the current name. Anchors and the bolt protected crux were installed on August 10, 2017 by Douglas Taylor. All loose blocks have been removed and the route has been fully scrubbed. Aug 17, 2017

This route is an excellent addition to the crag and is a ton of fun.  The features look imposing but the route protects very well and the movement is interesting and enjoyable, so don't hesitate to give it a go. Aug 18, 2017

Nice work on the retro clean all.  I have definitely come to regret the names I choose for those three routes;  Wall to Wall Fanny, Inner Thigh, and Fuzzy Undercling.  These days I prefer appellations less misogynistic and "locker-roomesque" then the prepubescent(albeit presidential enough apparently) humor that I was sadly and embarrassingly still engaged to into my late 20's. I don't... more Nice work on the retro clean all.  I have definitely come to regret the names I choose for those three routes;  Wall to Wall Fanny, Inner Thigh, and Fuzzy Undercling.  These days I prefer appellations less misogynistic and "locker-roomesque" then the prepubescent(albeit presidential enough apparently) humor that I was sadly and embarrassingly still engaged to into my late 20's. I don't really mind the renaming of routes in general and actually, welcome it in this particular case for the aforementioned reasons.  However, given the proximal, both historic and literal, association to routes with poorly chosen anatomical innuendo, I might suggest a slightly distancing name from any possible misplaced entendre.  Golden Bucket?  Rather than Jug.  It somehow works with Chimney Sweep(formally Wall to Wall Fanny) in a custodial arts sense of the words. Think about it. Aug 19, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. So nice did it twice. Putting rope up for Stacy & crew · TR. Could lead, maybe big something big to protect prior to bolt. My beta was stemming at beginning, made it easier · Lead / Redpoint. Lower roof: get out of the corner via chimney technique -> stemming/ back step against right flake, bump stems up with layback moves until reaching around high for the jug · Follow. Think I could lead this. Thought the moves past the second roof felt awkward and hard! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Misread the second roof -> from the golden bucket don't get sucked left onto the face, layback the crack above the bucket until it gets to be solid hands, then step over. Lower roof was fun laybacking with back step stemming · I liked every part of this with the exception of the “overhanging double crack traverse of sadness” · Lead / Redpoint. Warm up. Committing to the first crux felt hard. Rest was good. What an amazing route. One of the single best 10- pitches I’ve climbed. · TR. Felt much easier. Really good movement. Cruxes are still physical but VERY manageable. · Follow. Clean follow. Gear double to #3 fine? Stem right foot before committing to layback, could put a 0.5 ish cam in slot, L foot transition to foot jam, don't try to stop mid layback for gear otherwise.. Very wild and exposed feeling pitch. · Lead. Super fun! 1 take at second bolt bc pumpy -undercling the first roof w a stem on the right corner, then there is a great jug but fairly high up · TR. easy to get sucked up and right of the bolt. use weird crack system and jugs to get up to bucket, then off to the left and up: · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Clemo - fun route! I thought crux came just after first bolt · Lead / Onsight. dude the bucket is sooo good, also that bolt is very nice to have there. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Slipped at first crux. Smooth on the second attempt. Similar to Tatoosh, varied and pitchy. If Tatoosh is 10b this is 9+ · Lead / Fell/Hung. Felt at the bolt moving out left but felt smooth after finding the holds · Lead / Redpoint. Rp after greasing off a foot at bottom crux a few days ago ha · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fiddled up top with the second roof pull. Great climb! More fun than rogers corner · Follow. Followed clean. Big jugs the whole way with two solid power moves. Achievable one day · Lead / Onsight. I stemmed the crux instead of laybacking into a jam in the left crack. My beta felt much harder than 10a. Look at the roof before climbing again. · TR. Neat route! Crux for me was the lieback above the bolt, and the stem from the bucket to the arete · Lead / Onsight. Had a rope get fucked up stuck in the small crack above the bucket on TR · TR. Pretty cruiser. A little pumpy due to where Tommy placed gear, had to remove midway through strenuous position on second roof. · Lead / Flash. Pretty heady. Stem/chimney through the bottom roof and it’s not too terrible. High feet pulling the second roof to rock over and stand up. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell twice in lower crux, took on second crux. Got rope stuck and learned how to ascend a rope. · Lead / Flash. Got beta watching Kevin. Move pulling the first roof was the crux for me. · Lead / Onsight. Max lead , Haley Trd. Cool climb! Definitely more sporty but exposed so still a little scary of a lead for me.

routes.route_description: This fantastic and varied route is located on the right side of Foodbar wall and has been outfitted with new bolts protecting the previously spicy sections, making it extremely approachable for the average climber.Start on a thin jug horn and pull into secure stemming. Find the great incut finger pod on the broken flake up on the left, allowing you to pull onto the foot ledge to clip the first bolt. From here, enjoy the fun 5.10 climbing until the massively positive jug ledge at the base of the glorious #4 stem box. Cruise to the chains.A good warmup and easiest access for "The Breakup"
routes.route_location: Foodbar Wall, right
routes.route_protection: Three bolts and a standard Rack to 4". The stembox eats up #4 BD and a #2 can be placed at the very top below the massive jug.

route_comments.comment_text: Fixe Stainless Steel 3/8" 5-piece bolts installed on August 16, 2017. Route was scrubbed and trees removed on August 8, 2017. The current anchor is fine but could use a stainless steel update and maybe placed a foot higher to reduce ropes running over the ledge. Aug 17, 2017
Just to be clear, the actual name of this route is Humpback Humpback Humpback Whale.  Yes, that's three Humpbacks.  Please make the correction. Can't wait to see all the upgrades! Aug 19, 2017
Thanks for the catch! I updated all mentions of HHHW in the other routes to the correct name. Aug 19, 2017

routes.route_description: AKA "Foodbar Pitch 2" is yet another brand new adventure to the inner walls. This monumental task of cleaning has yielded a fantastically varied second pitch to the Foodbar. If my initial cleaning job (about 90% clean) is finalized this could easily be 3.5 stars. This pitch has it all: finger locks, hand jams, stemming, liebacking, chicken wings, heel hooks, and mantles.Once you've climbed either HHHW, Foodbar, or Sucker Punch, begin right of the belay up blocky climbing. Move left onto the ledge above your belayer and get a solid #0.5 BD cam. Continue up easy blocky climbing with the occasional crack and stem to a fun lieback switch move in a right facing corner/ramp with a great finger crack. Climb up to the obvious short offwidth that begins at #2's. A #0.3 X4, totem, etc. protects the short 5.10+ boulder problem and mantel onto the ledge out left. From here climb the fun broken arete with good holds and cracks. Save a #0.5 for this section. Head towards the corner above the removed tree and make a few hard-ish moves to the anchors out right on the large ledge. A #4 protects these moves but if confident you can leave it behind.It is possible from the anchors to rappel hard right to the anchors of The Breakup to set up a top rope.
routes.route_location: Above Humpback Humpback Humpback Whale, Foodbar and Sucker Punch.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 4". Heavy on smaller gear #0.2 - 0.75 is nice to have. A single #2, #3 and #4 is sufficient. The #4 protects the last moves but could be neglected if confident. Extend pieces after the crux. 30m x 2 rappels to the ground.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Solo. Rope lead soloed the FA because I couldn't find a belayer. Still counts right?

routes.route_description: This route was described as a project in the Cummin’s guide and ended at rotten slings at  about 40’.  Bolts were added at the top of the cliff to double it’s length.  It is one of the better trad climbs (of any grade) in the area.
routes.route_location: Find Yellow Cake. Cross the fixed slack line.  Some assholes have since spray painted the base.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack

route_comments.comment_text: It’s back to nature as of 2022.. Jul 24, 2022

routes.route_fa: FA: C. Defecto. FFA of current version: James Wyland.
routes.route_description: Further up canyon but still on the left side is a bulging, overhung wall with many features. This is on the right side of the wall and climbs a featured face with several bolts. Although the climbing is easier than the rest of the route, it is somewhat difficult to reach the first bolt and a fall could prove very injurious; therefore use caution, natural gear or a stick clip. The rest of the route is challenging and fun face climbing on good rock.
routes.route_location: Beneath the aforementioned bolted face is a corner with a crack. Sucker Punch leaves the crack when the first bolt can be reached. Short people will find clipping the bolt to be problematic.
routes.route_protection: 7+ bolts, plus a bolted anchor. Consider bringing a piece of gear to protect clipping the first bolt (finger sized through #1 Camalot size) although this doesn't provide a perfect solution.

route_comments.comment_text: the position of the first and second bolts caused the rope to run over a crack and the rope to get stuck when my partner fell.  A fall at the second bolt on a regular draw ended around 10-12ft from the ground with a solid jump catch.   Seems like plenty of space so one option would be to extend the draw on the first bolt and whatever gear, but even then I'm not sure it would be enough to keep... more the position of the first and second bolts caused the rope to run over a crack and the rope to get stuck when my partner fell.  A fall at the second bolt on a regular draw ended around 10-12ft from the ground with a solid jump catch.   Seems like plenty of space so one option would be to extend the draw on the first bolt and whatever gear, but even then I'm not sure it would be enough to keep it out of that crack.  We ended up having to lower off the 3rd bolt to unclip the first bolt and cam below. Great quality climb, highly recommended Aug 16, 2019

I brought a hand size piece with me to protect clipping the 1st bolt & then back cleaned it, I also extended the 2nd bolt with an alpine sling for the redpoint and had no rope management issues. Apr 20, 2021
I had no rope drag issues this is an amazing route one of my favorites in index. Jun 3, 2021

routes.route_description: Follow a crack up left of a detached pillar (5.9). Stem against the pillar (11b), and go through a small roof (10). See the beta image for more info.
routes.route_location: About 60' right of the cave.
routes.route_protection: A single rack from .3-#3 with a selection of small stuff( .1s/ballnuts/brassies for the short section right above the bolt) 2 draws

routes.route_description: Ascends a wall with yellow streaks with two short left-facing corners below. Yellow Cake goes up the left one.Go up a splitter hand crack to start, with a crux move past the first bolt, then to a face crack accepts gear to .75" to chains above.
routes.route_location: About 200' right of the cave.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2".

route_comments.comment_text: The location and description for this route is a bit of a sandbag. Don't read if you want the authentic Index sandbag experience. 200' feet right of the cave - sure, but this ignores the short, steep, loose moss/dirt/rock approach and grungy traverse to actually reach the base of the route. Wouldn't want to step on the wrong square of moss and activate the trapdoor! You might be better off... more The location and description for this route is a bit of a sandbag. Don't read if you want the authentic Index sandbag experience. 200' feet right of the cave - sure, but this ignores the short, steep, loose moss/dirt/rock approach and grungy traverse to actually reach the base of the route. Wouldn't want to step on the wrong square of moss and activate the trapdoor! You might be better off belaying on the trail below and climbing a short right-facing mossy corner to the base, but then you have pretty serious ledge-fall potential past the crux. "Splitter hand crack" = slightly overhung lieback flake, takes .75s down to fingers. Bolted crux moves are STOUT, or maybe I have bad beta. 11c seems spot on even for Index. The face crack after is barely a crack and won't take anything bigger than a .3 - micro cams are useful, it's a face climb. Expect a few sucker holds, veggies, and slightly runout climbing to the chains. Jul 17, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Trone hang at the upper crux. What a badass route! The opener crux is so fun wow.

area_description: This is the high point on the trail, soon after crossing the creek. The walls at the notch are closest here. The cave side is on the southwest side. Generally, a cool and shady place to hang out. The rock is sharper and less knobby than that lower down.
area_getting_there: Follow the Inner Wall trail to the where the trail reaches a high point amongst talus. The Toxic-Tang wall is on the left side, from the start of the notch to a prominent hole (the "cave") about 50-yards further west.

routes.route_description: The set of cracks on the face to the right of Toxic Shock heading straight up from the ledge. Fun moves, fairly consistent difficulty, and distinct reachy cruxes (at least for short people like myself) make this a great climb. Approach the area as for Toxic Shock and climb either of the starts for Toxic Shock to reach the ledge.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Standard trad rack, but with emphasis on smaller gear. You probably want a #2 and #3 camalot for the standard approach (as for toxic shock). For the actual climb, I use 2 green aliens, 1 blue TCU, 1 yellow alien, 1 grey alien, and 1 purple camalot. You want to have stuff in this range, maybe a couple extra of some sizes just in case.

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Need to be stronger, much less pumped this time but I still fell at same spot. Placed .3,.3,1,.2,.4,.3 before crux. Make sure to jam feet in pods at top · 4 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Wear new miuras. Possibly place two blues off deck and black totem up higher from a left hand in the top good part of finger crack and keeping the feet low on the right smudge · TR. Fun follow after Micah led. This rig is exquisite and I am excited to try and lead it · TR. Onsight the route and aid the reach crux move, after reading beta, the move seems interesting - throw to high left hand with good right hand and foot and ok left hand - kinda committing move. Would try it next time. Pretty exciting finger lock/hang jam the rest of route. · TR. Clean 2nd go on TR, would take quite an effort on lead. So much fun. Bouldery cruxes separated by decent rests. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell twice at the lower crux, then sent the upper section clean. Improvement! · Lead. One hang. Get through low crux with 3 small blues, step up feet then into left hand jam - place small purple from jam, don’t place anything in hand jam, you need to match in right hand then get highs feet and up to left finger jam. At upper crux, get right foot into jam, left hand on knob, then right all the way up to good jam. · Lead / Redpoint. Finally sent! It all felt so easy. Just went for it and cruised. My first 11b! · TR. I think I could lead it. Would want lots of small gear, protecting frequent at the bottom of the 11b finger crack to protect from decking on the ledge. Good feet at bottom and top crux sequence. · Lead / Redpoint. Woot! Felt desperate at the top but managed to squeak it out. Met Shannon and Sam. · Lead. Almost took the spike to the head when laybacking the sinker fingers section went awry. Employed technique next go and it was a cruise. Such a great rock climb. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tried to put it together but fell once at top Crux. Fuck! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung twice trying to figure out gear beta at bottom and top hard parts · Lead / Fell/Hung. Two falls at the top (one at crux and one at mantel). Sad bc I thought I would send but so fun!!! Felt great tbh · TR. TRS, didn't get bottom clean but got top clean which was rad . Reachy beta: stand on pedastool at base of first finger crack, the key is to get your right hand into the top of the finger crack where it angles open, thumbs down. Don't reach too high to get this, paw your way up the lower finger crack. There's knobs for feet on the left mini arete and then one good stem foot on your right that like actually maybe isn't that good. Slap that right thumbs down finger jam in and bump the right foot to a high and strenuous but good edge on the right crack and hecking throw that left hand for the hand jam. It doesn't get cruisy between here and the next crux but it's easier. Upper crux, find the sloppy texture on the left wall and remember it. Work your feet up the right cracks knobs and mini platforms kind of lay backing until you can get your left fingers in a marginal pocket. Toe jam your right foot in the pod on the right crack and stand up. In the bigger upper pocket of the crack on the right side there is a deep jug but it's way back there. Smear that left on the texture, bump your right foot up to another jam and launch for the chalky jug above you. From here there is a manky but stellar finger lock to slap before grabbing the finishing jug. · Lead. I am soooo strong. I am soooo cool. Jake is soooo lucky to be married to me. I am a champion of rocks. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Beta: Left hand little pocket right hand finger lock at crux. 0.5 cam above 0.4 below. · Lead / Redpoint. Steve was right. First lead attempt after 1x TR, no mock lead. Lower left crack: #2x2, #3x2, #4x1, clipped tat with locker alpine. Upper crack climb 2 moves, blu tot, blk tot, stepped back down to rest. 0.2 (blk tot better), blk tot (0.4/0.5 off next to), 0.5 z4, 0.3 z4, blu tot, purp tot (flared, careful!), then gun it. Got a full knee jam in pod before upper crux, decent rest but leaning back so not amazing. DO NOT place any 0.75-1 in the hand/foot pods or you're fucked. · TR. TRonsight, no gear placements. Steve scampered over from toxic shock anchors (with some gear & back cleaning shenanigans). Steve says I should lead it. · TR. Fell repeatedly figuring out the beta. Good candidate for a project to redpoint it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ooooooeeeee! Proud I led this without watching anyone, but it was tough. · 2 pitches. TR. Two Tr laps. First crux, 2 .3 totems. High rh finger lock, high left foot. Big move to lh crimp, bump up rf, rh sloper, wedge lf in corner, reach rh to hand jam. .5 and .2 totem then rest. Second crux, red Metolius and .4 totem high. Use smearing lf. Then .75 totem to protect exit moves · Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux is off the ledge. Climb .3s crack with thumbs down jams. Use feet out to the sides. Good dihedral on the left and bad smears on the right. Decent flare jam on the left when 2 cracks start. Can stem between two small dihedrals then to rest and place gear. Top section is easier with high feet into wider jams. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 hang at top crux, messed up the hand sequence and couldn’t recover. See notes 7/17 for details, pic 7/17 for gear beta. · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. One hang, got gassed at top in upper crux, potentially there’s a rest I didn’t get. Knee bar? Bottom crux —-two left feet on arete, right foot close dimple to further smudge to inner indentation by crack to higher seam. Right hand to the bread loaf can use the triangle crimp if needed. Two blues as high as you can with a black totem once you’re on your feet. Upper crux use second hold in seam to two upper parallel spots with left foot on a good face smear. Yellow cam to protect the move in the left slot. · TR. Got it clean the second time. Finger jams up top were neat. Required solid feet to keep weight off the hands. · TR. Fell not too many times, fun route might come back to lead when stronger · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell off the ledge - didn’t focus on feet enough. fell again at top crux big move, slightly missed the right hand finger lock. · TR. w/ vincent and chris. First route in Index! Took a few laps, couldn't get it while placing gear, only on TR. Great finger crack practice · Lead / Fell/Hung. Clean on TR after. Gear: doubles from 0.2 to 0.75. One #1. 3/4 for the start. Look for smaller foot out right off the ledge. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 hang at the finish. Bring 3 .3 . Super fun! · TR. Amazing finger Two cruxes 1: layback and reach for the hand jam 2: Right hand side pull, left foot flag after smear on the left. Left finger jam and bump to the crimp, until right hand reach for the good side pull. · TR. Second TR. aided cruxes with stirrups. Off the ground it’s hard, turns to easier laybacking, turns to finger cracking, turns to two boulder problems. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 2 falls, a bit wet still including the fingers before the final big move · TR. So good. Need to lead. Tried twice, 1st try hard, 2nd try 1 hung With tj · TR. Awesome route. Great rests, use fingerlocks with stemmed feet for right off the horn. Last sequence through crux - stay tight but get those feet up! Great gear · TR. Fell twice cause decided to get desperate instead of being chill and just sending · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell a few times. Felt good I’ll get on it again for sure. · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell at pump crux. high balancey left foot jam gets off the ledge · Lead / Fell/Hung. Top crux: squeeze index finger at the bottom of 0.75-1 crack, reach up right pinky down, bump left hand up to two finger pocket, pull feet up and put right foot in pod to jam. · Lead / Flash. One fall on first go, sent it on second go! Bring triples from .2 - .5, double .75, single 1 and 2, and two 3s for the atart · Lead / Fell/Hung. Sat at crux Undercling hand jam right, left finger pocket Smear left foot, right two finger pocket, left crimp to clip(purple). Move up for rest ring lock/ feet. Pieces -> 4, 3, 2, .3, .3, .75, .3,.4,.3,.75,.4, 1 Singles 4-1 2* .75-.4 3*.3 4 slings · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. heartbreaker fall at very top, then fell once at lower crack 2nd go. lower crack: right finger above left, move left up then right, then get good left thumbs down finger lock at top of thin crack, sloper with right hand, ok thumbs down left hand jam, great thumbs down right hand jam · Lead / Redpoint. Gear 4,3,2,.3,.3,1,.3,.5,.4,.75,.5,1 Undercling above first crux to sinker finger on right Clip one move higher on crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once at the first crux and then once at the second crux, but climbed everything fluidly. Felt much better than the first time I was on it. · TR. W Paul; Lose weight or get stronger locks lol??? Really cool climb 3, 3, AD at Horn, .2, .3, 1, .3, .3, 1, .4, .5 QD · Lead / Fell/Hung. Climbed with Zach. At the upper crux I was getting fairly pumped, put in a marginal piece and decided to take. routes.route_description: This is the first part of Even Steven up to the slung horn right at the base of the .11b finger crack that is Even Steven full. It's a fun little moderate climb to warm up on before trying Toxic Shock, or something to pass the time on while waiting for something to clear up. It is also used as an alternative start to Toxic Shock.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3-4"

route_comments.comment_text: This seems to have become the more common start to access the Toxic Shock handcrack (not sure why). If using this variation please be considerate of parties wanting to do the full Even Steven (probably the most popular Index 5.11 not on the LTW). Additionally if the Toxic area is filled with parties climbing in the 5.7-5.9 grade range please consider doing the actual Toxic Shock start as that... more This seems to have become the more common start to access the Toxic Shock handcrack (not sure why). If using this variation please be considerate of parties wanting to do the full Even Steven (probably the most popular Index 5.11 not on the LTW). Additionally if the Toxic area is filled with parties climbing in the 5.7-5.9 grade range please consider doing the actual Toxic Shock start as that then frees up this route for other parties waiting to climb. Jul 26, 2021

Just did this at described (only up to the horn). Good little warm up climb, and can use both hand-cracks running parallel. Takes a couple BD #1-#2 mostly, placed a #4 near the top. Fun climb while waiting for Toxic Shock! Sep 19, 2022

Just requested that the name of this climb be changed to remove any reference to a Toxic Shock alternative start.  There is no indication from any first ascent team that this is an alternate start to Toxic Shock.  Does that mean you can't do it? No. It just means that you have to use your brain to know that you can climb one thing to get to another thing. Let's not gum up the traffic any... more Just requested that the name of this climb be changed to remove any reference to a Toxic Shock alternative start.  There is no indication from any first ascent team that this is an alternate start to Toxic Shock.  Does that mean you can't do it? No. It just means that you have to use your brain to know that you can climb one thing to get to another thing. Let's not gum up the traffic any more than we need to... climbing this as a start to Toxic means that you are making all three climbs (TS, Slapshot and Event Steven) unclimbable for other parties.  Just dont. Please. Jun 12, 2023

The left crack gets wide on placements/off width. Used only #2 - #4. Good hands and feet. Once it starts widening up, good hands when reaching into the back of the crack. There is a juggy vertical edge that can be combined with a hand jam to be super secure. TR sessioned the left crack once and the right crack one more time to clean. Used #4 up high on lead. · Lead. Didn't like it - probably should have brought 2x #3 and maybe an extra #4 to get great gear in away from the flakes? Wouldn't climb again though · Lead. With Lindsey :) sow wide??? Lots of 3s could bring a 4 but didn’t need it · Lead / Redpoint. Sarah led too. Fun. Can choose between 2 cracks and use both. · Lead / Redpoint. First 5.8-5.9 lead on granite trad!! Tronsight first from the 5.8 start and then led clean. We top roped the original start, the layback would be a scary lead due to potential for decking. Beautiful hand crack up top. Placed .5-3, could have done without the .5 though. Would bring 3 #3s for the 5.8 start and then 1s and 2s for the top crack with .75 in between. · Lead / Redpoint. Kev followed. Next time need to be better about placements for rope drag. A little tricky figuring out which crack to be in · TR. Colin took a whipper on this one in the wide part on left crack to right above the ground. Ty #2 · Lead / Flash. Haley lead. Still stiff at the bottom crux- but it went. · Lead. Climbed with Zach - I would bring a #4 on this next time · TR. Clean. Stay left can hand jam. Just need to watch and plan properly. May need 2 #3 . · Lead / Onsight. Used 3x #3! Probably one could be replaced with #4 slightly lower, but the crack is definitely wider than it looked from the ground · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bottom part only, left crack only. Hung to fix my hand Jammie (but it was also awkward / scary at this point). Big gear, 1-4. · TR. Bottom left crack was super fun. Felt insecure as the crack got bigger · TR. Left crack only. Felt good except at the wide part which was awkward and strenuous. Mercy Hand hold is loose. · Lead / Onsight. Felt a couple number grades easier than the start of Toxic Shock and probably higher quality.

routes.route_description: Follow the tiered corner to the right of Even Steven. Whenever the moves start to feel desperate, face holds magically appear. This route was covered in moss until 2018 and may have gotten slightly easier following heavy cleaning and loose rock removal.
routes.route_location: Corner to the right of Even Steven. This climb shares an anchor with 'Never Have I Ever Used a Stepstool'.
routes.route_protection: Standard Rack with extra smaller stuff (.3 - .5) if you're pushing yourself at the grade. Freshly bolted anchor w/ rings on top.

route_comments.comment_text: You should clean this it would be great addition Jun 6, 2018
no, you should. Jun 6, 2018
If i did not have 30+ active project pitches at index already i would. But i have too much on my plate already. Jun 7, 2018

routes.route_name: Journey to the Other Side of the Bridge
routes.route_description: Let me preface this. Supposedly this route was climbed a long time ago but I cleaned it extensively and it has not been reported officially anywhere. Take it for what it's worth.Description: Follow the rightward leading hand crack with good protection. Grab face holds when you can and pull up into the crack. Once there, follow the face up to a stance. Here, if you are tall enough you can get a yellow alien in the high crack. If not, you might have to run it out. If so, you're looking at a long fall. It is possible to sling a root at chest height but the FA party didn't so it's up to you. From here, pull the flake with marginal feet up to the next flake, with less marginal feet. Then pull onto the top.Start with a steep leaning hand crack that brings you to a good stance. From here work in some protection and climb the face on good holds and sloping feet to the anchor above.The anchor at the top also provides a good TR setup for the classic stemming corner below.
routes.route_location: The Inner Wall at Index Town Walls. Follow the description there. It is two climbs left of Toxic Shock, next to the 5.10d corner.
routes.route_protection: Two number one's and two number two's and a yellow alien. A few handsized cams and a few finger pieces should suffice.

route_comments.comment_text: You can also just boulder up this, no gear needed. Aug 8, 2010

Blame me for the "Journey" name. The route had been done back in the early '80s when I lowered down the stemming corner to clean it. Colin nicely cleaned it up in 2010 and reported it here under a different name. More recently Lucas D- recleaned it together with the stemming corner, installing a nice modern anchor at the top of both lines. May 21, 2018
It looks like it deserves more stars now. A fantastic cleaning job has led to a route that should soon rival its neighbors for fun, moderate trad. May 25, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. It’s aight, make sure to use the flake/ledge holds outside of the crack as you start to traverse. · Lead / Onsight. Punchy for 5.8 but good jams Rack: .75-2.0 and a .3 or .4 · Lead / Redpoint. 0.75x2, 1,2 yel + purp tot (both iffy, flaring shallow seam), #3 good out right. Burly for the grade with my big mitts. · Lead / Redpoint. Good route. Missed a jug and felt like 5.9+. Protects very well with single .3-1, doubles .75-1. · Lead / Onsight. The leaning crack is quite strenuous for me as I didn't quite get great feet in the crack. · Lead / Onsight. connor had some gear in there, some of it was manky lol · Lead / Pinkpoint. Led on David’s placements to save some time and also check his gear · Lead / Onsight. Too short to be called a route, but it was a fun 8 moves from the ground til the ez 5th class finish · TR. Swear I climbed this before. Don’t know how even started this one. It was hard as shit! Even practiced plugging gear. · Lead / Redpoint. Placed first two pieces close together, got pumped and took then lowered. Got it 2nd go still clipped to first two pieces. · Lead / Onsight. Kev followed. Didn't realize there were crimps on the face outside the crack, only used the crack itself (except for ending) · Lead. Felt way more solid this time on lower half. Focused on the jams rather than feet I think. N8 beta was to skip some jams by going for the crimp above the crack early. Ran out second half decently sketchy. · Lead / Redpoint. Spooky at first but the diagonal hand jams are bomb. Short but stout. · Lead. fun climb if you're waiting for toxic. dropped a line on the 10 nextdoor to work it. · Lead / Onsight. Burly couple moves down low; fun lil route overall. Trust the friction. · Lead / Pinkpoint. got scared on attempt 1, nick placed the second piece, i did the rest · Follow. Needed help with the hand jam. It was pretty bad. The rest went fine

routes.route_name: Never Have I Ever Used A Stepstool
routes.route_description: This route is loaded with fun mantles that make the movement interesting for the grade. The line wanders but the drag isn't too bad as long as you don't keep gear in the crack by the 3rd bolt or use really short draws. A 5.10 climber can probably do this with just draws, all hard moves are bolt protected.Begin up a mellow corner and establish yourself on the first of many ledges. Pull a tricky mantle to access the next ledge and traverse to the right. Bring your stepstool or find a way of reaching a protruding horn and pull another fun move onto the next tier. A bolt was added because the gear is behind a hollow flake.Step left and head up a techy dihedral with good edges up high (5.9). Make a final mantle and head up to the 'Geek Corners' anchor on easier terrain.
routes.route_location: Starts in the low angle corner with a bolt 30 feet to the right of Geek Corners / Even Steven. The route wanders its way up the 4 ledges.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts to anchor with rings, consider alpine draws or something like a DMM Revolver.If not super comfortable at the grade:Bring a single rack with emphasis on smaller things, include a #3 to protect your follower getting onto the 3rd ledge (see horizontal crack at back of ledge). Also consider removing the 3rd draw after getting onto said ledge if you're worried about the drag.

route_comments.comment_text: 5.9, oh my god I suck. Definitely use shoulder slings for most of the bolts. Aug 13, 2018

I finally led this one today.  You definitely will be happier if you have a variety of small sized cams.  You'll definitely be happier if you have 5-6 runners.  On several of the bolts that protected mantle moves, I clipped both a QD and a runner.  After pulling the move I back cleaned the QD.  Although this sounds unconventional, it protected any ledge falls while pulling the harder moves and... more I finally led this one today.  You definitely will be happier if you have a variety of small sized cams.  You'll definitely be happier if you have 5-6 runners.  On several of the bolts that protected mantle moves, I clipped both a QD and a runner.  After pulling the move I back cleaned the QD.  Although this sounds unconventional, it protected any ledge falls while pulling the harder moves and then left gear to protect while I moved up easier terrain that didn't create much rope drag.  Alternatively one could used doubled runners, then extend after pulling the move. As for the grade, it's definitely easier if you protect in a manner that reduces drag.  Since I was aware of the potential drag issues and protected the line accordingly, it really did feel like a 5.9.  I watched someone climb it later that only used QD's to protect it and it for sure looked like it made for a grade or two increase in effort and difficulty.  So HOW one protects this one really affects its subjective grade significantly.  If one were to climb this on TR, the grade would feel spot on. Highly Recommended and a good line to go up if you want to try to TR Geek Corner. Aug 16, 2018
fun route but man that first layback mantle move definitely felt hard for 5.9 Aug 26, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. The route getting to first two bolts are very mossy. Other than that, quite fun mantels that are well protected, especially the last one with layback move. · Follow. Didn’t finish, got up to the final ledge and decided to bail as I couldn’t find any good feet and if I fell I believe I’d hit a ledge due to rope stretch. This is one of those routes where a follower with the rope drag and stretch face potential dangerous falls onto a ledge. It may actually be safer to lead climb this · TR. Max lead. Haley trd. A little balancy over the second mantle. Possible lead. · Follow. Second mantle is tricky if you’re short, I stayed left below and reached for the horn with my right hand first. Fun route · TR. TR twice. Crux1: undercling, slight right, good holds above. Crux 2: high foot, sloper layback, watch left face hold. Left hand crimp, then right hand so so jug. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bit scary and mossy. First mantle felt hard the rest wasn’t too bad. · Lead / Fell/Hung. yeah... I aided and back cleaned the crap out of this route. ledge fall potential on every crux, so have an attentive belayer · TR. fun set of boulder problems on top rope when you don't have to wonder about ledge falls · TR. So not worth it. A bunch of ledges with tricky moves and potential for fall · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a few times. Bolting isn’t safe and some moves are strenuous/awkward. Only had a single 3” cam plus draws. GEAR SHOULD BE: draws, doubles tips - .75, singles to 3”. Slings. 5.10- · Lead / Onsight. Fun onsite trickiest one was the first mantle for me. Weird warmup cos it’s just three awkward mantles, not sustained at all · Lead / Onsight. The comments are right. These mantles do not feel 5.9 but they are good and fun so still worth it. The taller you are the easier the climb. · Lead / Onsight. tyler. rescued justin and bill's draw after they got shut down. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 hung to figure out beta. match hands on last hard move. placed a few small cams. · Lead / Onsight. Super fun, rope management and decking are great head games to deal with. Have an attentive belay and that #3 with a double runner. · Follow. So many ledges. Kinda like climbing a layered birthday cake. Heady to follow. · Lead / Fell/Hung. First trad ish lead! Big move w/ 2 bolts, made the clips and almost made the move but downclimbed and grabbed a draw. Placed pro between bolts and below anchor. Pretty dirty, cleaned a lot of cracks/holds. Rope drag bad, be smart about extending. · Lead / Onsight. Very fun, bring singles .2-.75 and back clean between bolts. Drag is bad · Lead / Onsight. Harder than 5.9 Only gear used was a yellow alien at the top and a blue/black offset alien. Rope drag sucked

routes.route_description: A 5.12 boulder problem leads to challenging moves between good stances. Some of the higher sections are beguiling and desperate.
routes.route_location: The route is to the right of Slapshot and Toxic Shock, and is the second route to the left of the large cave feature. It follows a featured face along an arete. The route closest to the cave is Tang, .11c.
routes.route_protection: 11 Bolts; bolted anchor with mussys. Stick clip first bolt. 60m rope.

route_comments.comment_text: We cleaned this route up today and replaced one of the missing bolts. It's awesome and good to go (though some of the old bolts are looking a little rusty). This line dries fast in the winter. Nov 25, 2018

Thanks for cleaning! Got on this yesterday, what a route! Shade at ~10am this time of year. Really cool crimps down low, followed by bigger swats to various features. Quite a few strenuous moves from the deck to the chains, but all have a ~hands free at the doorstep of the business. Feels like fifth force in this accord, but easier of a tick IMO. A worthily suitor for those summer... more Thanks for cleaning! Got on this yesterday, what a route! Shade at ~10am this time of year. Really cool crimps down low, followed by bigger swats to various features. Quite a few strenuous moves from the deck to the chains, but all have a ~hands free at the doorstep of the business. Feels like fifth force in this accord, but easier of a tick IMO. A worthily suitor for those summer sunny days as it’s basically blasted with AC from the huge cave next to it. May 28, 2019

Climbed this with Matt yesterday--and for an 80 degree day, we couldn't have asked for a better option.  The RSFC is comprised of four superb granite puzzles offering a farrago of holds and demanding various styles and body positions. Mad respect to DC and GO. 5.12 seems quite appropriate. Significant jump from any 12a at Index I can think of. Also, we were able to scramble from the top of the... more Climbed this with Matt yesterday--and for an 80 degree day, we couldn't have asked for a better option.  The RSFC is comprised of four superb granite puzzles offering a farrago of holds and demanding various styles and body positions. Mad respect to DC and GO. 5.12 seems quite appropriate. Significant jump from any 12a at Index I can think of. Also, we were able to scramble from the top of the 5.10 route Geek Corners to RSFC anchor and drop a top rope to suss the moves. Definitely glad we did as this beast seems quite beta intensive. Its like the 5th force of Inner walls. May 28, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Fell several times but good onsight link for the second half. For the bottom, climb the blunt arête off L toe jam to start, RH pinch, keep bumping LH. Once standing on the ledge, LH arête, RF angled edge, LF point, RH undercling, RF high, rock and cross LH to jug edge. Match, LF obvious around corner, LH mid sidepull, RF high knob, RH sidepull to stand, bump LH, RH to crimp, bump LH up arête, feet up and RH to gaston. Higher up, LF jam stem, gaston to bring RF up, exit left around corner. Final crux go leftish to get high RF to rock over · Lead / Redpoint. Sent second session, shout out letty for all the beta. Suuuper beta intensive and lots of fun rewarding moves. Crux for me was the actual last move to the jug. Desperate! · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1: ??? 2: R crimp crack near bolt, L slopey edge L side arete, RF step up to good crimp 3: L arete, R hip in for high RF, R up 4?: cool stem 5?: L slopey pinch on arete, R high sp

routes.route_description: A line that climbs a lot like a Gritstone route.Begin with one of two cruxy start options off the deck: Either start directly below the arete and make a deadpoint slap with your left hand using a severely polished left foot, or choose to traverse in from the left. Either way you chose, it is pretty difficult to get established.Once you have gained access to the blunt arete, follow a series of insecure moves up the arete using a large amount of core tension, open-hand slaps and pinches, and inventive heel/toe hooking. Get a no hands rest at the ledge and then finish the final section of the climb using the same arete wizardry you used on the first half, albeit on the other side.After the first 30 feet, however, the first half of the route becomes somewhat contrived, as it is very easy to escape around to the right of the arete and into the safety of the 5.8 crack. However, don't be dissuaded by this contrivance as the upper arete is high quality climbing and more sustained than the lower arete.
routes.route_location: The route starts on the blunt arete directly to the left of the Even Steven hand crack, the route then continues up the hanging arete to the left of the Toxic Shock handcrack. The anchors are located on the face a few feet to the left of the Toxic Shock anchors.
routes.route_protection: 11 Quickdraws (9 Bolts + Anchors) and 1 Alpine Draw to clip to the webbing on the horn on the midway ledge. an optional small/midsize cam can be used to protect clipping the 5th bolt.

route_comments.comment_text: This seems to have been re-bolted. Jul 1, 2014
An exceptional climb on great rock that stays cool all summer. May 12, 2019

Is going to the ledge with the webbing supposed to be 12a or all the way is 12a? I thought the bottom half was pretty hard but still easier than sucker punch. I mostly wanna know if I should wait until Toxic shock is empty and try the whole thing. Jun 3, 2021

routes.route_description: This route has been resurrected from the moss and rebolted using the original holes. It packs a punch in 50', featuring ridiculous stemming, super technical traverses, and a powerful finishing sequence.A TR can easily be setup from Stepstool. This route dries fast, even in the winter.
routes.route_location: Vertical face to the right of Stepstool. Anchors visible on ledge at 50'.Stick clipping the first bolt is recommended.
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts, small nut for upper crack (used to be pin),

route_comments.comment_text: Anyone get on this yet? The corner to the right also goes and is pretty fun but I didn't have time to finish cleaning and equipping it before leaving. Definitely some fun potential for a second pitch linking into RSFC. Jul 19, 2019

routes.route_fa: Jon Nelson, Terry Lien, Darryl Cramer
routes.route_description: Immediately left of the cave entrance, look for a thin line going straight up, near the cave lip.Bouldery start (11c), but stays challenging to the anchor. Pitch two is a hand crack (10d). Or, both pitches can be combined, as shown in the photo.
routes.route_location: Go to the cave, look on the left wall, near the entrance, but right of Roadside Floral Curtain.
routes.route_protection: Thin wires and nuts.

route_comments.comment_text: I just finished scrubbing about 90% of this route today and it could definitely use some traffic. Stellar .llc finger crack into an interesting little roof. The 10% I didn't clean has some vegetation over easy terrain for the last little bit right below the new bolted anchor for roadside floral curtain (.12a). The guidebook says two pitches but it should definitely be lead as one ~30m pitch... more I just finished scrubbing about 90% of this route today and it could definitely use some traffic. Stellar .llc finger crack into an interesting little roof. The 10% I didn't clean has some vegetation over easy terrain for the last little bit right below the new bolted anchor for roadside floral curtain (.12a). The guidebook says two pitches but it should definitely be lead as one ~30m pitch from bottom to the anchors for RFC for maximum fun. Toxic Shock -> Even Steven -> Tang makes for great start or end to the day. This route is super fun hop on it people! Cleaned: 08/17/16 Aug 17, 2016

The full pitch has been cleaned up (11/25/18) and the ancient pin at the start has been replaced by a bolt (with permission). Get on this route, it's an amazing finger crack with some cool moves over the upper roof. Nov 25, 2018
Where was the pin at the start? Nov 26, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. First couple meters are nails, then a sweet layback section. Got a little heady running it out. Cool pitch but very overgrown up top (p2) · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. bottom section through the bolt felt like 5.12 face climbing to me. pulled through on gear eventually. top section is fun ish 5.10+ but quite dirty and the rope kept getting stuck in the crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. Insanely hard start. Pulling through leads to reasonable terrain. Many blue TCUs and nuts

routes.route_description: Toxic Shock is one of the most gorgeous parallel handcracks I've ever seen. For the standard start to Toxic Shock layback the splitter finger crack to the left of the bolted arete of Slapshot. It is possible to bypass this crux layback and start on the 5.8 handcrack of Even Steven. Once on the midway ledge, climb the amazing handcrack.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Standard trad rack with several (2-4) #1 Camalots (or equivalent) unless you are very comfortable on Index 5.9. If you are starting with the 5.8 cracks, some bigger gear (e.g. #3 Camalot) is nice. There is a rap station/anchor at the top.

route_comments.comment_text: The upper crack starts as #1 Camalot, but is mostly #2 Camalot.  The first pitch protects perfectly with Aliens.  There is a rest 1/4 the way up.  Can easily be done as one pitch with the lieback start or one of the two 5.8 handcracks around the arete to the right. Feb 2, 2006

A classic route.  The left (layback) start protects perfectly with #0.5 Camalots or red Aliens.  The upper crack does go from #1-#3 Camalots as the previous comment mentions.  A good rack would be one set of small cams/TCUs, and then doubles of #1-#3 Camalots + nuts.  I also did the right start which was fun, but not as enjoyable as the layback in my opinion. Jul 3, 2006
Lower left crack (before intermediate ledge) is inward flaring, I think that's what the OP meant by 'harder to protect. Mar 25, 2012

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. TR. Water makes the layback more strenuous, couldn't send it without a take. Even so, layback is still easier than jaming where left toe is in the crack instead of right toe, body is sucked into the crack this way and finger becomes immediately less insecure. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on my second and then third piece, a .4 and .5, respectively. One fall on each. Both bomber. Placed (I believe) a .5, .4, and another .5 in the corner finger crack at the start before running out to the jug atop the finger crack. Made it up to the slung horn, slung a doubled 240cm sling to protect the unprotected slab move. Before making the slab move, it started to rain. Pushed through the mental barrier and made the unprotected move. Places a high .75 right after in bottom of the horizontal crack back and to the left of the slab at head level. Made it up to the corner “rest” right before the splitter hands. Took after each piece on the splitter from being pumped and likely going to pull off. The splitter was hands to thin hands and wider hands (#3). A .3 or .4 piece was placed higher up in the splitter to take on and then a #3. Racked evening on left side, remember to rerack before the slab move. Triples from .3 to #1. Doubles #2 and #3. Maybe triples next time on the splitter. · TR. Climbed with Eric Etzell. Attempted to lead but got stuffed on the layback · Lead / Onsight. Struggled way more on the first bit than I should've but was still fun · Lead. One small fall at the top of the layback mainly due to getting in my head and losing body tension. Got back on it and sent after without issues. Top’s tough since the crack leans a bit. Such a good climb. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Gassed out and fell at the top of the bd red crack. Took way too much time placing way too much gear. · Lead / Redpoint. Lower section went super smooth, faffed a bit getting into the upper crack · Lead / Fell/Hung. Chris led it then left a .4 and .5 for me to top rope through the layback start. Possible to place the .4 myself perhaps? The upper .5 was in the way tbh, caused the rope to run right where my fingers needed to be. Led the rest. Clipping the tat before the big step was a marginal idea, caused some rope drag. The upper leaning hand crack took a 3 at the bottom, 2 1s, and a .75 or .5. A 3rd 3 would have really sewed it up before the chains, but there’s a great #2-sized jam as the last move. · Lead / Redpoint. Warm-up. Still 1 L foot slip in layback but nbd. Doubles 0.3 to 3, 1 nut, didn't use blk tot or smaller. Purple offset nut & yel tot before slab corner. Upper crack more annoying with only 2x #1's · Lead / Redpoint. The layback start felt so much easier than I remembered it. Nice finger locks. Very satisfying to come back to a route and be able to tell I’m a much better climber than I was 3 years ago. · Lead / Redpoint. I think I onsighted this a long time ago but I did it again today. Great route · Lead / Fell/Hung. laybacked the lower part of the route. move to get established in the upper crack was heady but fine. used 3 #1s in upper hand crack · Lead / Redpoint. True start, no warmup. Basically double rack to #3 (yes used 2x #3), couple nuts and blk tot. Step up into corner still spooky. · TR. Mock lead. Should be able to lead next time. There is a slabby move transitioning from layback crack to the money crack. It's quite sketchy for short ppl, can place a marginal pro with smallest nut. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the bottom but send the rest - next time will know to just commit to the layback all the way to the right jug · Lead / Fell/Hung. oof, one hang on layback, had trouble on handcrack, need to do more of a layback/jam combo on parts with my thic hands. Finished it up on toprope · TR. Fun, bottom is a lil strenuous. A bit spooked about the slabby traverse - would want really good gear right below the ledge but it's kind of blocky? Upper crack is bomber gear and safe falls though · Lead / Redpoint. Finally got the tr send. Ridiculous that I only felt brave enough to do this after a few beers and sending Even Stevens earlier in the week. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Wiped once on my first piece, I slipped on new shoes, you can protect this low crux by squeezing two finger size cams as high as you can, then grip it and rip it, not too bad if you commit to the moves. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 2 falls at the beginning, tried to finger jam but lie-backing was the move tight hands for me up above! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on lieback move, need to be more efficient on placing pro and liebacking. Used two .5s for start, don’t extend. Brought triples of .75-2. · Lead / Onsight. i’ll give you a kiss if you can get my #3 unstuck · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 hang in the bottom section- hard to sow it up and be comfortable · Lead / Redpoint. Totally clean red point! Beta for next time: 1. get gear into layback as quick as possible and go for it, don’t spend time messing with the gear or waiting, you’ll burn out 2.
