For transition, gotta get the right foot in the right place, as high as possible on the big foothold, kinda of near slung boulder Gear used: .4 yellow totem on layback .5 purple totem as high as possible before committing to layback .2 black totem after layback 3 blue BD before transition 60cm sling to the slung boulder .5 purple BD on the diagonal crack leading into big crack 2 yellow BD at beginning of hand crack 1 red totem midway up hand crack 1 red BD 3/4 up hand crack .3 blue totem in chockstone, 4/5 up hand crack · Lead / Flash. Got it! Pretty cruiser now which feels nice. No gloves is the move. · Lead / Onsight. Such a fun lead. Felt comfortable and well protected. Triples of 2’s, triples of 1s, double of 3s, otherwise a single rack. I climbed the wider crack on lookers right around the arete. Noted on MP as the start of the 11b even Stephen, which goes at 5.8. The finger crack at the bottom was fun but hard for me, high feet · Lead / Redpoint. Second run up with belay device to bring up Brian and then single strand rap to avoid weighing coreshot in rope · Lead / Redpoint. First 5.8-5.9 lead on granite trad!! Tronsight first from the 5.8 start and then led clean. We top roped the original start, the layback would be a scary lead due to potential for decking. Beautiful hand crack up top. Placed .5-3, could have done without the .5 though. Would bring 3 #3s for the 5.8 start and then 1s and 2s for the top crack with .75 in between. · Lead / Redpoint. Alternative start. Fun. Takes 1s and 2s up top. Sarah led clean!! First granite trad 5.9!. · Lead / Flash. Lay back was powerful. Thought the step left was a bit consequential if I were to fall. Don't fall there. · TR. A fun messaround. Lieback start was exhausting and I did it in like 6 hangs. I did some funky reverse dihedral and lieback moves instead of actually jamming most of the hand crack at the top. But we climbed it! · Lead / Redpoint. So fun. Blew the on-site attempt at low crux then redid the boi. · Lead / Redpoint. Step over felt fine this time. Put my foot on a lower step and then reached higher to the crimp after step over. So much fun. Finger crack felt secure. · Lead / Redpoint. Fell on my first piece at the top of the layback crux. Sent from the ground on the second try.

routes.route_description: WeeeeeeeeeeaaaaaaaaaaaahhhhhheeeeeIs it a train? Is it a truck? It’s a train truck!Start with a wake n bake followed by a river dunk. Throw your headlamp, hand jamies, puffy jacket, and maybe a knee pad into your pack then embark on the grueling approach to inner walls.This unique route climbs horizontally (and down) out of the mega cave just past “Tang”.  Begin standing on a small rock in the back of the cave and reach up to the first goodish hand jam. The first 15-20 feet are the crux but don’t let your guard down yet! A few tricky sequences remain in between sections of hanging stem box and horizontal chimney climbing.As of publishing this, dedicated route anchors don’t exist. I finished the FFA by climbing to a restful stem/stance about 10 feet up past the lip of the cave. From here, it’s easy enough to down-climb or down aid a few feet to the first bolt of Tang and lower from there.Obviously the route must be reclimbed (easier to reverse than to follow) to clean.Rock is surprisingly clean and solid but does seep a bit at the start. Doesn’t affect the climbing as much as one would think.Grit, Torque, TrainTruck!
routes.route_location: Begin in the back of the obvious, foreboding cave just past "Tang".
routes.route_protection: doubles #0.2-3 BD (triples 0.3-0.5 maybe nice for on-site and save a #1,2,3 for the end)Headlamplong pantsoptional left kneepadjacket for belayerhand jamies are nice for the couple of wet jams at the start

route_comments.comment_text: Grade is up for debate Jul 13, 2023
Most interesting new route I've seen in awhile. Thanks for putting this up. Did you come across any bats in there? Jul 13, 2023
It's about time somebody did this.  Good job!  We finally have something to climb on 100+ degree days. Jul 14, 2023

routes.route_description: A short, pure-stemming corner.If leading this seems too intimidating for you, then you can climb to the top via the 5.8 just left of the corner, and easily set up a TR.
routes.route_location: Obvious 90 degree open book just left of Toxic Shock.
routes.route_protection: Thin wires. Take particular care to securely set the first few. Originally, bomber RPs (narrow brass, brazed wired nuts) were used, but offset brazed nuts (e.g., HBs) may work even better.

route_comments.comment_text: I started cleaning that left leaning crack above this route and I even put anchors in, but that was before I knew what I was doing. They are stainless and galvanized mix... yikes. I gave up on that project though because of how hollow the blocks sound up there. Fun climbing though. I wonder if TVFTB will ever get cleaned.... May 3, 2017
That line above does look thin and flaky. Perhaps Stamati, it could just be a TR route? May 4, 2017
(Sped up, tall person) lead beta video instagram.com/p/CYzycdRACH5/ Feb 10, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Dropped a line on it. Learned how to stem, sent it twice. Would be an impressive lead · TR. Did most of the moves but spend a long time hanging on the rope. dang hard · Lead / Redpoint. With Letty and Michael. Sew it up with #0.1, blue ballnut, red ballnut, #0, blue alien, yellow alien, #0.5, black totem, red alien, #0.75. · TR. TRS, almost clean, got past the crux but then got real tired and stopped using my feet. · TR. Getting established into stemming position is quite hard; otherwise quite doable as there are descent finger cracks after beginning · TR. TR send! Felt easier. Put left hand in first crack instead of right. · Lead. TRonsight then decided it was worth sussing out gear and was happy with blue ballnut enough to lead! · TR. Wtf, this is a 10?! Got a birthday belay all the way up · TR. 1 hang... might lead it after getting a bit more acquainted with the weird moves on this, though · TR. So fun! Easy to set up on TR from toxic or the 5.8 · TR. TR, tons of falls. Got a lot easier once I started to stem lol. Try again some time, really cool · TR. Hung once. So much easier than in November. Shea got it in two as well. · TR. Sent all moves. Just gotta link em up now. To start, left hand in slot and right palm on wall (gaston?), left foot up first, then kick up high right. Move left hand up to surface. It get’s cloudy from here… but either move feet higher to get undercling, or go for undercling right away, then adjust feet. Forgot the next moves… eventually, from a high right smear and good hands, kick up left foot to positive surface. Move both feet up this surface, press both hands right(?), to gain leftmost nubbin edge. Smear right foot on face, pull on slot with left to transition inti chimneying. Chimney left, watching for wet rock behind until large slot can be gained. Movement gets easier until mantel left for anchors. · TR. Heinous (complimentary). Just need micronuts, a weed whacker, and 10,000 calf raises per day before I lead it · TR. A few takes but seems within range on TR. First half was a grind but once you gain the crack the climbing is great. · TR. tried the moves down low. made it 15' to the first full handhold. didn't throw since left index finger is on the mend. would come back to work it out. · TR. Felt impossible at first but once I got moving it was decently secure. Super burly. Trying this on lead with the available spots for gear scares me · TR. Pretty struggle at the first half. Stem. Some offwidth techniques. Be patient. Maybe have a right foot knee protection is good. Some finger lock in the middle. · TR. Much more chill with chimney technique. Would be down to lead with some bigger rps and maybe a crash pad · TR. Worked this on TR. didn’t get it clean. climbed it left facing, not as bad as it looks, not sure how you are supposed to lead it though. · TR. Someone has to show me that 5.10d beta. Hah I got bullied on this! · TR. This was desperate as all hell. Hung all over it and was the closest I will ever be to doing the splits. · TR. Couldn't even get off the ground lol. Pulled through to a stance and struggled to the top. · TR. lots of slipping, but I did do some moves... Hopefully my body learned something · TR. Crazy sandbagged I felt. Felt way harder than Even Steven. Did not stem but climbed the crack instead. · TR. W Anthony Couple falls down low while figuring out beta. After the side crimps in the corner, a few moves of chimney climbing before going back to stemming. Start: avoid using the block · TR. A test of Granite IQ. Those well versed in shoulder scums, foot changes, hand foot matching / momentum will prevail. Did not lead after cratering a few years back. Makes a stellar top rope for those wanting to put it ALL together. · TR. So hard. I could start easily enough, then linking moves became manageable albeit strenuous, but I could not get past the rock bulge. Maybe try transitioning to a full stem, square hips. Great practice. Hard! · TR. Hard ass, wet stemming. Couldn't stick the lieback move at the beginning because it was so wet. · TR. Super polished in a corner, struggled with the beginning. Gets better up too with some finger cracks · TR. almost trash top rope flash a half fall not fully weighting the rope · TR. 6th pitch of the day, fell a few times, super great stemming practice · TR. clean onsight. hard, improbable climbing to gain the first finger-sized crack. actually climbs very beautifully. · Lead / Redpoint. Did once on TR to sus the moves and gear. Ended up not needing any nuts. Just boulder 15’ up to that first bomber .2 placement. · TR. Took once and fell once at the crux (for me) down low, which was trying to reach the bomber finger jam and transition from stemming to being in the crack proper. Superb movement; I was transitioning from stemming to both feet on the left and both hands on the right to inch myself up. Need to get my left foot as far in on the left edges as possible to be able to reach for the finger jam. Awesome. (HS) · TR. sweet climb, I need to get better at stemming with my feet. I used lots of hands and didn't rely on feet as much as I should.

routes.route_fa: Trevor Wood, Ben Gilkison, Matt Carroll. FFA May 9th.
routes.route_description: Another worthy addition to the Tang area. Potent high steps, crimps, palms, stems and utter desperation will get you past the crux dihedral. Another crux up high may foil your send though. True fact: during cleaning efforts, an upset hornet stung Trevor "right between the eyes""You hit me with a million volts,You nail me with a lightning bolt,Oh, baby, you knock me cold.You're love zapped me, right between the eyes."WAX-
routes.route_location: Gorgeous arete / corner just past Stinkbug.
routes.route_protection: 11 bolts to shared anchor with TANG and RFC. It would be pretty bold to not pre-clip the 1st bolt.

route_comments.comment_text: google.com/search?ei=ici5Xr… more google.com/search?ei=ici5Xr… May 11, 2020
I think this has long looked like the primo line on the wall. Congrats on the route, and fun name- May 12, 2020
Stoked this went down, starting in the "dihedral" just right of stinkbug? Was fun to play around on when I cleaned the neighboring routes but well above my pay grade. May 15, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Opening boulder makes numbah 10 feel like 5.10. Rest was quite fun and not too bad. If I try this again I will need to do some cleaning

area_description: A small east facing wall on the Inner Wall trail. Many large trees guard this dark and mossy patch of land.
area_getting_there: When you are passing K-Cliff, across the stream you will spot this wall. About 10 min. from railroad.

routes.route_description: A climb on the left side of the Shaft consisting of a slab, cracks, and face climbing.I climbed this about 2005 in unclean condition and remember the slings on tree, but I think there was a bolted anchor too.The Clint Cummins book calls it 10a.Cramer calls it 5.9 PG for the run-out bottom. It looks like a good cleaning is in order. Has anyone climbed this?
routes.route_location: left side route, lower bolt then route to the right. I had a hard time finding this with all the fallen trees around it.
routes.route_protection: gear to 2 1/2". 2 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.

routes.route_fa: Dan Carter, Alan Belshaw, Oliver Ochs, 1992
routes.route_description: On the right side of the Shaft. Slab/ face, and cracks.Currently being cleaned up (June 2024). Stay tuned.
routes.route_location: Starts at a corner crack on the right side of the shaft.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 1", 2 bolts, tree anchor- bring sling.

routes.route_fa: June 8 2024 WW, Peter, Jenn, Geoff, Courtney, and Toby
routes.route_description: Start in a corner on the right side of the crag. Placing gear on the left wall until you run into the steeper bolted middle of the route. Techy moves on steeper rock, then,  Be careful with the last bolted move, it has a rock feature that is right under the climber. Finish on a wild steep Layback/hand crack! Easier for taller folk.Stay focused, stem, and look around for the hidden holds.In the shade by 9 am, it’s one of the shadiest and coolest climb at index!
routes.route_location: The far right hand corner of the Shaft crag hosts this cute, fuzzy climb.
routes.route_protection: Single rack from medium stopper to 3” gear. 5 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: The route is now pretty clean, and now outfitted with five bolts and top anchors! Enjoy. Jun 8, 2024
This was in my mental notebook for sometime, thankful it was unleashed. Sitting in plain view of every climber walking to the inner walls. Just look left :) Jun 25, 2024
Sure to become an Inner Walls classic - get on it! So good Jun 25, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Very fun beginning ramp and ending flake. Crux is the sporty middle part but it’s well bolted. “Sloper or jug” usually turns up jug. · Lead / Onsight. I’d call it 5.9 if you are over 5’10”. Maybe for shorter climbers it’s 10a. It’s a treasure hunt for holds but the moves are physically fairly easy. Felt easier than “toxic shock” or “princely ambitions”. Comparable to “behind the tombstone”. · Follow. Fell once near the second bolt. This climb starts with a trad section which is chill, then moves into a bolted section which has a bit of a tricky sequence. Then into another chill trad section · Lead / Flash. Max and Haley lead. Stemmy to start. Then the slabby/sport bolted section, followed by an awesome flake. So fun. Soft for index. · Lead / Redpoint. Soo good!! Placed a black totem, .3, .4, .75, 3 and draws

routes.route_description: Sooo… after the beautiful 5.8 thin crack start, the arete kicks into a series of three cruxes with the second one coming in at 5.11b! It’s a very solid addition to the great climbs of the inner walls. It’s my honor to offer it.After dispatching with the splitter 5.8 thin crack (1 bolt, small gear),  pull into the right side of the ridge on a small cam, and then start clipping the upper bolts. Sweet prow climbing, with more bolts, and another piece of gear or two along the way. Stayon the right side of the arete. That’s where most of the bolts and gear are anyways. Several good rests between stiff moves. Belayers be mindful of the ledge below the lead climber at the crux.In the shade by 9 am, it’s one of the shadiest and coolest climb at index! Wash up in the creek afterwards!
routes.route_location: Approach: The Shaft crag is on the left side of the canyon, soon after the K cliff turn off, and before the creek crossing, The route is visible from the Inner Walls Trail. Approach when level with the base of the climb, crossing the creek down in some boulders.These routes will moss up if people don’t climb them.
routes.route_protection: Six bolts. Gear to 1 inch, heavy on the smallest cams.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once at crux and got it next go. Fun route · TR. Had fun pulling off moves that felt pretty improbable to me. Still clean. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Stout for an onsight! Bring tons of small gear in the .1-.4 range, you’ll use it. A bit dirty now (as expected) but should clean up well · Lead / Redpoint. First ascent. Sent, after one lead attempt, and one top rope attempt.

area_description: A shady neighborhood with a steady gurgling stream. A place to work on your slab skills. The wall faces south and when you climb above the maples shade and leave the mosquitos behind it can be a toasty black slab on a sunny summer day.
area_getting_there: 15- 20 minutes from parking area.Take a left turn at the Great Northern Slab on the Inner wall trail.When you pass K- Cliff on the inner wall trail you'll make a right just before crossing the stream. The right is just after a large downed log that you'll follow. You can see the crag from the Inner Wall trail. This was the original trail, now fully overgrown, needs some work.I had my chainsaw out in January to clear some dead trees, but it needs a trail.At this turn you'll have passed another very overgrown buttress on your right, Gilligan's is the cleaner one left of this, northwest.Sam Hill is the next wall up hill and northwest of Gilligan's.Missing Bottle Buttress is across the stream to the west of Sam Hill

area_comments.comment_text: Hi Jon, if you are monitoring this I think this and Sam Hill should be on the Inner wall area, what do you think? Nov 5, 2022

routes.route_description: This route was named for the rushing stream that will serenade you as you climb and for the Cascade Torrent salamander. The salamander, like many Index climbers, is sensitive to temperature variation and sedimentation. Luckily for you, this climb is almost completely in the shade the entire day and the developers cleaned off the moss and sediment on the route.The climb starts with a left-trending ramp. Enjoy a variation of movement types, ending at the chains in the sunshine.
routes.route_location: This is the first climb you'll come to when approaching the crag from the main trail. Look for the left-trending ramp with a bolt at the upper part of the ramp.
routes.route_protection: 6 bolts, gear up to 1. To prevent drag, extend the bolt under the roof and any gear near the undercling.

routes.route_fa: Greg Olsen, Darryl Cramer, Erik Thixton, Ron Dedinas, early 90's ?
routes.route_description: You will see the big right facing dihedral with the line of bolts running up the right face on the southern toe of Gilligan's Toe.This route follows a waterfall that is dry in the summer but very wet all winter.Start up face climbing passing 3 spaced out bolts till you reach the corner.Cramer describes the corner as insecure and difficult chimney/ stemming, with the top out being 5.9
routes.route_location: on the low end south side of wall, most right.
routes.route_protection: It is described as being only bolts. I located several good gear placements but it has plenty of bolts.11 lead bolts in 100'.All rusty but in surprisingly good shape for being steel in a waterfall. The rusty anchor still needs replacing, but you can pass it and go to my new anchor 10' further.

route_comments.comment_text: this is mostly very clean now. Wow hard. the lower blocky 3 bolt section is described as 10c, passing the first bolt was impossible for me, and just getting to the corner after a little ledge was super blank, then the corner, described as chimney/stemming ????? If someone wants a project replacing bolts, I will not be able to get to this for a while. Jun 7, 2019

routes.route_fa: Ron Dedinas, Greg Olsen, Darryl Cramer, Erik Thixton, early 90's ?
routes.route_description: This is the middle route with a left facing corner flaring groove.The upper face climbing is the crux.10a/10b in the Cramer book.Which is either 5.10 or much harder if you don't find the easier path.This stays pretty dry and dries off quickly after rain.I also cleaned a alternate start even lower that pulls up through a burly undercling layback.This is clean as of 6/5/19, but still has some maple branches up against the wall.
routes.route_location: Start at top of detached flake/boulder  traversing ledge to the right.Or start below boulder with layback around a flake ( might be 10c )
routes.route_protection: The Cramer book calls this a bolts only route, but the LFC takes good cams from fingers to hands.There are 6 lead bolts ( all rusty, but look reasonably good )There is a rusty anchor at about 90', I added a new SS anchor above this 1/20/19 ( the rope does not drag over the slab this way)
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. many falls at crux. did not find the "easier path". great route!

routes.route_description: The variation starts with chimneying up the face and giant boulder. Once on the comfortable ledge above the crack and bolt #5, go right around the arete to the anchors of Cascade Torrent. Look for a good hold to help with moving around the corner.The original, much harder, climb goes straight up the bolts on the face.
routes.route_location: Look for the chimney created by the boulder and face.
routes.route_protection: 5 bolts, #0.5 - #3 gear for the crack and a #1 for the section between bolt 5 and the anchors.

routes.route_fa: Greg Olsen, Darryl Cramer, Erik Thixton, early 90's ?
routes.route_description: this is a slab climb with thin face holds and big committing moves passing bolts. I did not think it was quite as well protected as A Date with Dale, but the cruxes are protected.Start at the top of the big detached flake that forms a chimney below you. Start up a somewhat loose flake and face climb 1st crux( 12a ). easier face climbing ( 11a to 5.10 ) trending right to a ledge, another crux that is committing steep and blank ( 12a ). 3rd crux near top with lower angle friction and reachy face holds trending right to shared anchor.This route had just a exploratory cleaning, still very dirty as of May 2019.What I scrubbed in 2019 is fully remossed in 2023.
routes.route_location: furthest left route above big flake/boulder. Very wet on the left.
routes.route_protection: 8 lead bolts, all need replacing, rusty bolts with SS hangers that were all buried in some deep shag moss likely untouched for 25 years.

area_description: A lower angle crag further up the trail to the Inner Walls. Shaded.
area_getting_there: Hike just past K-Cliff, stay to the right.

area_comments.comment_text: this is a great place to see the curious sight of bolt hangers sticking out of a sea of moss. May 23, 2014

routes.route_description: Still very dirty, hard to say, parts of it are very fun and interesting.I am guessing they meant it to be just bolts, because there is a bolt next to a good crack.The anchor is low ? and very ugly rusty one. I guess because the climbing however good above is too easy and runs into the Siderinder.It starts near the middle of the face with some thin face moves on a steep slab ( 1st crux ), traverses right with undercling, then follows a crack and face to the anchor (2nd crux after the hand jam slot), I cleaned the corner above the anchor and think it is a logical finish to go to the top. After passing old anchor inside corner with some dike  holds, arete pulling then ramp up to meet Siderinder at it's last mashed head rusty bolt.I would have to add 1 or 2 bolts to this extension.
routes.route_location: right side
routes.route_protection: 6 lead bolts,  all very rusty. There is a seep that seems to be year round at the overlap/ undercling that is easy to step over but adds to the rusty bolts. One could use some cams but it has plenty of bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: what my description is not enticing ? Aug 12, 2019

I climbed this again in 2023, it is good, the start is the crux. I wanted to add the continuation past the lower anchor. But there’s a large loose rock I didn’t want to remove because my stuff was below and have to wait on that. It started raining when I was up there and it poured hard, I was soaked. Oct 30, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. fell so many times, cheated the crack and the lower crux. not as fun as it's neighbor, very dirty

routes.route_fa: Darryl Cramer, Greg Olsen, Erik Thixton, 1992?
routes.route_description: Why is it that when the climbing is hard the route is really well protected? Is it because 5.10 is damned easy you can run it out?I was greatly relieved when I found most of the bolts and hangers to be SS. There are a few that are rusty steel.This is a great route, I could not climb parts of it ( the 5.12 crux ) but it is really cool.You go straight up a blank slab to a roof, traverse right to a dyke/seam (12b ), follow line of bolts, and as Cramer says- Dyno.Upper slab is fun- book says it is 11c.
routes.route_location: left side of wall.The lower slab start was very mossy, the upper half stays pretty dry and only needed thick lichen scrubbed.
routes.route_protection: 12 bolts, I think 3 were rusty steel and the anchor????? is rusty steel, but I found a nice SS bolted anchor about 10' higher up.

route_comments.comment_text: I have given up cleaning this route, mostly just the start slab needs scrubbing. This is a really fun route with several short cruxes that are beyond my ability. Jun 6, 2019

Hi Jon, sad that this wall has been so neglected, this route took just a few hours of scrubbing and all but one bolt ( if you pass the rusty anchor) are stainless steel. My guess is that the lower rusty anchor went in first when it was top roped then the stainless bolts were added for leading. I had 6 ropes up but needed to steal the one on this route and don't think I will be back. Jun 6, 2019

routes.route_fa: Fred Grafton, Sabrina Kettle, Jim Gransky, July 1992
routes.route_description: UPDATE AUG/ SEPT. 2023 this got a good scrub and bolt added to run-out top. Crux is getting past the first two bolts.. I am probably the first person to visit this wall for at least 20 years based on the anchor slings, vegetation and dirt.It was given a 10a rating, and I think there are 2 crux moves around the lower and upper bolts that is more like 10b.This is a mix of slab with some run-out bolts and flakes with cracks, there are 4 lead bolts and if it were up to me I would add 1 or 2 more bolts.All but one of the bolts are badly rusted ( 1 bolt is SS )The hangers are all SS.It is cleaner now ( 11/11/18 ) and again in ( 2023).I added a new SS anchor a bit higher then the old one. 1/21/19
routes.route_location: This route is on the center of the wall and wanders to the left following a big flake, and then back right .The start is face/slab climbing past 2 bolts, the middle is the flake, 2 bolts protect the upper slab. Cramer's guide mentions that a fall after the last bolt, 10a run-out would be injurious and I would agree- also is some insecure face climbing looking at the last bolt over 10 feet below your feet.
routes.route_protection: the crack portions would take small cams up to a #34 lead bolts ( 5 bolts now, safer)New SS anchor  ten feet above old rusty anchor on the slab.

route_comments.comment_text: I would like to add 1 bolt to the top of this route if nobody objects. Jun 6, 2019
I cleaned this more in 2023 and added the bolt to the run-out top. Oct 30, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. fell a couple times, crazy fun route. good gear placement in the flake up above, went right to what I assume are the anchors? bit traversy with a couple of commiting moves

area_description: Short crag just up and right of Grandeur Buttress. Also known as Trap Balls Buttress after the name of its first route.
area_getting_there: From the Inner Wall Trail, cross the stream with the cave boulder and make an immediate right before reaching the Toxic Shock area. Follow the small stream up into the gulley. The MBB will be on your left side as you walk up.If you can see the hand crack on Toxic Shock you have gone too far and need to turn around.From the notch area near "Journey..." and Toxic Shock, start up the gully just right of Quarterflash. Look for the buttress on the right.

area_comments.comment_text: My partner and I found the 4th to low 5th class step that the guidebook suggested to be a bit too treacherous for our liking, so we roped up and climbed a short dirty chimney to get to the base instead. Jun 22, 2019
Maybe it needs a handline. Jun 22, 2019
Is it ok to leave a handline there? I have some chopped rope ends I could install if I find myself there again. Jun 30, 2019

routes.route_name: Doug Thompson gets the First Ascent
routes.route_fa: Doug Thompson, Abraham Lincoln, Steve Irwin
routes.route_description: Start from the trail and begin just to the right of Happy Puppy. Fun 5.6 Jug Jumping, 5.9 face and crack (use the tree to chimney if you want) onto the ramp, followed by a 5.8 finger crack through a roof and short crux. Then scramble to the anchor shared with Happy Puppy.
routes.route_location: Missing Bottle Buttress (Trap Balls Buttress).
routes.route_protection: Trad pro to 3". A good selection of small/finger size cams for the cruxes.

route_comments.comment_text: Nice one Doug. And also great to have Mr. Lincoln get his revenge. Nov 8, 2017
Fun little climb. The crux felt a bit stiff at 5.8 but I probably botched the sequence since there are a lot of options. Mar 11, 2018
Great route, found the crux to be down low getting established into the finger crack. Another great additional to the MBB! Thanks Doug! May 23, 2018

routes.route_description: Leading this is not recommended as ropes could be cut by the flake in a fall. Stick to Top Roping it.  All Off-Widths are 5.15d.
routes.route_location: Lead  "Doug Thompson's Unicorn" to set up a TR.
routes.route_protection: Top Rope, Long Pants, Long Sleeve Shirt
routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Fun on top rope. The crack just feels weird but that’s probably because I’m not used to off-width. Not too bad. · Lead / Redpoint. Do we g cd former a un to m con sees Wes w nn a

routes.route_description: This climb is a little contrived but has lots of fun movement.  Start up the same crack as "Doug Thompson Gets the First Ascent" then head right toward the Crescent Cave.  Pull around the cave roof using rock and roots then climb right of the giant maple to a ledge.  Climb back behind the maple and directly up the slab past the bolt.  Alternatively one can avoid the crux slab moves by escaping right up some easy 5th class.  The anchor is obvious and up a couple ledges from the final slab.
routes.route_location: Missing Bottle Buttress between Doug Thompson Get's the First Ascent and Doug Thompson's Unicorn
routes.route_protection: Single rack including nuts, a runner and 2 QD's. Shorter folks will like having a stiff extended QD for the top bolt.

route_comments.comment_text: Fun Moves! Especially the thin face/slab near the top. Oct 5, 2018
This Doug Thompson is starting to sound like Brad Driscol. I wonder if they have met? Jul 10, 2019
Pretty sure they climbed together a lot. Jul 10, 2019

routes.route_fa: Doug Thompson, Ariel The Little Mermaid, My Little Pony
routes.route_description: 5.8 Sport Lines at Index are as common as Unicorns and Doug Thompson found  both with this line.Climb the obvious monster flake, clip the bolts, finishing to the Right of the crack,  and RIDE THAT UNICORN!!!
routes.route_location: 50 feet right of "DT's Root Canal".
routes.route_protection: Quick Draws and a Pleasant Disposition

route_comments.comment_text: Great route, definitely worth doing in its own right and a great addition to missing bottle buttress  . Thanks for the effort Jul 25, 2018
Awesome route and unique climbing.  Thanks for the work, Doug. Jul 27, 2018
I counted 7 bolts then the chains, does that sound about right? Aug 6, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Great climb, thought provoking and . Distinct crux at 2 bolt. Maybe a tad bit reachy for shorter climbers. Bolted perfectly, great stances at every clip. · TR. Tried leading, could not pull past second bolt. Did fine on TR but get super insecure. Not my favorite at all. · Lead / Flash. Super fun climb! Don’t know if I did the right beta, I used the offwidth for some heel-toe cams, a heel hook, and a chick wing at the start. Probably could be done with more lay-backing · Lead / Flash. Ilja,Ksenia, Haley and max lead. Super fun climb. Soft for grade but definitely do it · Lead / Onsight. Felt hard going left, easy going into the crack, not sure which was right (AL+) · Lead / Onsight. cool route, fun flake w a dash of half-body OW (if you don’t layback), optional .75 before the last bolt, easier climbing but would be a swing of a fall · Lead / Fell/Hung. Huge flake, nudged body in the crack, mossy toes. Crux was at 4th bolt! · Lead / Flash. Can get 0.4/0.5 C4 in horizontal at top of flake to protect b/w bolts if wanted. · Lead / Onsight. Good route. Interesting if a bit awkward in places. Could use a .5-.75 plus sling for extra pro. · Lead / Onsight. Fun sport and seems good to do if waiting for another route. · Lead / Redpoint. My second time on this. It felt much smoother this time around. · Lead / Onsight. On site. No beta. Awesome route and fun lead. Plugged on .75 Camelot after the top of the flake. · Lead / Onsight. caught doug on the way out with a leaf blower, told us to climb this route he just put up!

routes.route_fa: D. Cramer, G. Olsen, E. Thixton, R. Dedinas
routes.route_description: This route climbs the obvious steep flared chimney with the handcrack in the back.  Start by scrambling up to the base of the crack below the chimney, then lieback it to a rest at the base of the chimney.  Now jam the perfect splitter handcrack for 40 feet, then scramble up to the bolt anchor.This route doesn't see a lot of traffic, but is very good.
routes.route_location: Hike the Inner Wall trail up towards Toxic Shock.  Just after the cave look for a faint trail heading up the gully to the right towards the right end of the Missing Bottle Buttress.  Scramble along the edge until you encounter the first ledge with the moss scraped off.  Traverse across to the left here then up to reach the base.
routes.route_protection: 1 set of cams to a #3 camalota #4 and an extra #2 is nice50 meter rope

route_comments.comment_text: IMO, this is not a hand crack unless you have BIG hands. #4 and #3 C4 Camalots most of the way getting narrower as you go. Thanks, Doug, for the anchors! Jun 21, 2015

Agreed, not hands until the top of the "hand crack." A #4 and #3 C4 were required to protect the crack. The first time I found it hard for 5.9. After a repeat it felt more reasonable for the grade. This route is also considerably cleaner now than when this description was written. One can approach the climb with some technical climbing from directly below the start of what would be the climb... more Agreed, not hands until the top of the "hand crack." A #4 and #3 C4 were required to protect the crack. The first time I found it hard for 5.9. After a repeat it felt more reasonable for the grade. This route is also considerably cleaner now than when this description was written. One can approach the climb with some technical climbing from directly below the start of what would be the climb if you scrambled around from the left. While a bit more cleaning is in order, it's looking much better. Worth climbing if 5.9 or slightly harder is your limit. Apr 4, 2016
Also, that crack at the back of the chimney is much shorter than 40ft. Super fun route. May 15, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Just a tad wide for my fists at the start but still my kind of 5.9. BD 3, 4, 2, yellow metolius (and maybe another smallish piece?) With Sam. · Lead / Onsight. Painful through the meat of the route, but ultimately pretty fun. 4 to 3 to 2 at the top for sizing · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hands aren’t big enough for fists. Butterfly and stacks were rough down low. Eases up the higher you get. · Lead / Redpoint. Straightforward crack climb. Singles to #4 except maybe two #2s. Place a #2 at the first difficulty. Place a #4 as high as you can in the “hand crack”. Walk the 4 up as high as you can stem, then commit to jams in the crack. Can sew it up with a #3 then #2 or possibly #1 at the top of the crack. · Lead / Onsight. A little tricky at the fours but good fists than I’m in · Lead / Redpoint. Had some trouble figuring out the wide part but once I got my chimney system dialed it was all good · TR. Ilja, Ksenia, Haley and max trd. The two shorties had to cheat and go left at crux. · Lead / Onsight. Great wide practice! A couple heel-toes get you through the bottom. Big hands, so I had fists pretty much right away which made it easier. · Lead / Onsight. Fun. Nice wide-ish crack. AL effortlessly chimneyed the whole flare, lol (AL+) · Lead / Redpoint. Felt a little harder on lead but not significantly so. Definitely want a #4 to bump through the bottom flared section. Two #3s helpful, one for pulling through the bottom pre chimney crack section, one for in the flared chimney. · Follow. Clean follow. Started on broken cracks furthest to the right of start options. Nice little squeeze chimney/chimney warmup. Continued up into main flaring chimney. Faced away from main wall. Squeeze chimney technique (knee into wall plus pressing against opposite wall) on left (narrower) side of the body to rest, upwards progress using more strenuous foot counter pressure with right hand on same side as back on right side of body. Probably would just barely allow for placing gear in the crack? · Lead / Redpoint. First Index .9 lead - sweet. Wasn’t as pretty/ smooth/ elegant as I wanted but whatever; start was most difficult part, followed by stepping on the rope while door jamming. Index is cool · TR. was able to get fists when stepping off the flake into the corner, then it narrows to hands, kinda get stuck in the corner at the upper section, shoulders jammed in. surprisingly secure but it might be awkward with pro and rope in the crack. ii was straight in, maybe better to have left in and face right? · TR. wasn't able to use the crack in chimney and I used the arete instead · Lead / Flash. #4 very good to have. was able to get fists in pretty early. "shoulder jam" · TR. This route was tricky! I had never done a chimney before. Had to have some help (a boost) from my belayer at one part out of the chimney. It was fun though. I faced right while going up the chimney. I think? With mullet Andrew · Lead / Onsight. Pretty fun gruntfest, if a bit short. Takes doubles in 2-4. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung at the first butterfly move but should’ve kept going b/c it turns to fists real quick · Lead / Onsight. Great climb! Rock is super soft. I didn't even need tape. · Lead / Onsight. #4, #2 or 3, #2 for whole route. stacked at start of chimney then went up by jamming shoulders in flare · Lead / Fell/Hung. try chimneying whole way, or hand stack + knee or to get feet up better. · Lead / Onsight. #1 off the deck for Jesus, then green Tot. Crux crack 2x#4 but 2nd was tight, 1x#3, 1x#2, yel & blu Totem coming out of slot, red Tot before chains. Could do another #2&3 in main crack, maybe a low #5. Awesome!!! · Lead / Fell/Hung. So glad I went for the lead! 5-4-3-2. Had trouble getting from the stem into the crack and hung at the 4 to reorient the scum. · Lead / Onsight. Awesome climb! Crack definitely isint a hand crack the whole way. Offwidth to fists yo hands for my medium size hands · Lead / Flash. super fun. starts at butterfly stacks, narrows down to hands at the end. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pulled on gear to get through the chimney, struggling with the "hand crack" · Follow. baffled and humbled by Rick's lead on the off width chimney section of this one. More off width technique needed · TR. Clean TR. Only did one fist jam move, mostly chimneying and kneebaring. Want to lead · Lead / Flash. Walk far left before the crack in the offwidth. Get your foot in and trust it then go up for wobbly fists. It gets better quickly. 4,4,3,3,2 for the crack. .75 for the root · TR. Great climb! Can stem off feature to get above the wide hands part of crack. · Lead / Onsight. Tipped out #3 was a bit unsettling protection for the first 1/3rd of the crack. Bring a #4 and 2 #3s · Lead / Onsight. Singles .5-2 doubles of #3 and a #4 will get the job done · Follow. With Hank. Clean. Forsook the crack for a bit and just chimneyed up a lot.

routes.route_description: Starts in a shallow, left-facing dihedral, which is part of a large flake-pedestal. Goes to the top of the pedestal then straight up the face crack.
routes.route_location: Center part of the buttress.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3".

route_comments.comment_text: Tried to climb this yesterday and we're still unsure if we were on the right route or not. The second pitch seemed right, although very, very dirty, but the 5.10d crux Cramer describes never happened. The information here, including the rating, does not square at all which what the book says. from the alcove there is a huge undercling that we thought might have been it, but we didn't want to... more Tried to climb this yesterday and we're still unsure if we were on the right route or not. The second pitch seemed right, although very, very dirty, but the 5.10d crux Cramer describes never happened. The information here, including the rating, does not square at all which what the book says. from the alcove there is a huge undercling that we thought might have been it, but we didn't want to do the upper part again so we didn't check it out. Oct 27, 2013

routes.route_fa: Dan Waters, Ron Miller, Dave Hutchinson
routes.route_description: Face climb with bolts and small gear. The crux is fairly low and the gear is easy to place. As of early 2015, there are new bolts and new anchor so the climb is easy to protect.Can easily be TR'd from the shared anchor of "Who Put the Purr..."The 2017 guidebook rates it 11a, the previous guide, 10d. On TR, it may feel easier.
routes.route_location: Immediately left of "Who Put the Purr in my Pussy" on Missing Bottle Buttress.
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts, Small cams, nuts

route_comments.comment_text: Great route! tough onsite. Would recommend taking 2 purple mastercam size pieces. Apr 6, 2015

Fun sequences to figure out and balancy movement that let you flow up this steep face = Good Stuff.  The gear-placement opportunities are not always obvious since some of the moves can take you to the right when the gear is behind something on the left, or vice versa, but there are sufficient placements to be had if you look for them, especially where you want them between the upper two bolts.... more Fun sequences to figure out and balancy movement that let you flow up this steep face = Good Stuff.  The gear-placement opportunities are not always obvious since some of the moves can take you to the right when the gear is behind something on the left, or vice versa, but there are sufficient placements to be had if you look for them, especially where you want them between the upper two bolts. A few .00 to .4 cams will do the job.  Maybe you could fiddle in a nut or two but easier just to plug a cam and go.  You could protect the finish with a larger cam but probably not worth dragging it up there since you have a good bolt just below your waist by that point. Jun 14, 2019
Fun movement. Felt 10c on top rope. Imagine it would feel significantly harder on lead. Aug 12, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Soooooo fun!! Amazing route! Came off at the top but otherwise got all the moves and felt awesome · Follow. Didn’t complete this. Was my second route next door to “who put the pure.” It was a reach for my first day— 5.11, only made it one third the way up · TR. Hung twice near the top. Once my feet got mixed up and the second time I forgot that I could pull off the corner! Super fun · TR. Tricky but fun movement. Pumped out at the crux and had a tough time at the top. Greasy holds · Lead / Redpoint. Used .2, .3, .1; bring nuts next time! Tiff on belay · TR. James any I climbed clean on Tr. Calvin fell multiple times. Mike skipped it · TR. TRonsight, no gear except maybe ball nut between B2 &3. lots of step left &right, side pulls, pretty good cracks for gear up high. Pumpy! lots of good feet if you look, good finger jams too! finish is slopey, take your time. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Stopped & lowered off right before the last bolt. Was sketched on small gear in the flares. · TR. w/A. No chalk. 3 hang. Could TR clean pretty easily with chalk. Don't think I could place gear cleanly though. · TR. Fell once before the third bolt and took once after the third bolt; so tired. (HS) · Lead / Onsight. The dumbest climb to do ground up onsight lol never again amazing climb tho · TR. Balancy with small slopers, finger pockets, and flakes. Climbed smooth and felt great until the last bolt where I had a hard time making the last moves. · TR. TRed this since we wanted to know what is bolted and what isn't. No bolts after ~3rd bolt (I think) until the top bolt and anchor. Enjoyed it a lot and will come back to lead. · TR. 3 takes, super pumped. certainly lost fitness with gyms closed. think i could get this tho. · TR. Fun! Took lots of breaks and it was a tad wet at the bottom · TR. Fell at the last bolt, started off right and traversed to the first bolt (maybe off route?) · TR. Move to move. Had but just had a foot slip at a rest. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got clean to top then fell on top out!! Super fun delicate climbing, would be 4 stars if not so dirty. Placed blue & black alien, .75/1, & yellow alien.

routes.route_name: Who Put The Purr In My Pussy
routes.route_description: This route features some interesting varied climbing with a combination of face holds and cracks.  Climb directly up the face staying between the 2 aretes then finish on the upper crack. Bolted anchor at top (shared with Troubled Waters to the left).
routes.route_location: Hike the Inner Wall trail up towards Toxic Shock. Just after the cave boulder, look for a faint trail heading up the gully to the right and towards the right end of the buttress. Scramble along the edge until you encounter the first ledge with the moss scraped off. Traverse across to the left here then up to reach the base.
routes.route_protection: 1 set of cams to a #2 Camalot, optional #51 set of nuts50 meter rope

route_comments.comment_text: I enjoyed having a #5 C4 Camalot for the beginning of the upper crack. Otherwise, I agree, gear to 2". Thanks Doug for the shiny new anchors! Jun 21, 2015

Very fun. One of the best 5.8s at Index. Stays cool on hot summer afternoons. Descent beta: best way to get down from the missing bottle buttress is to lower from the top of the climb to your pack/belay spot and then rappel ~15 feet back down to the trail. This avoids a mossy 5.4 slab or 5.6 block down climb. Aug 29, 2017

The scary flake that's wanted to fall on your belayer from near the top of the climb has been reunited with Mother Earth and no longer a threat to climbers.  The last bit of climbing is a tiny bit more difficult now, but much safer. The Troubled Waters anchor to the left is the best to use for this climb. Nov 1, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Fun if good w ok gear and gunks climbing, otherwise little heady · Lead / Onsight. Doubles to #2, single 4 & maybe 5. #4 goes in a perfect slot in the left chimney. Save a .4 for entering the upper offwidth and a .75 racked on the left for the top. Seems intimidating but keep looking for moves. Good rests. · Really fun! Holds magically appear just when things start to get awkward, and I usually hate awkward chimneys. Bumped a 5 up high, though there were other options around if in a pinch. · Lead / Onsight. Super fun for the grade. Lots of creative movement possible (AL+) · Lead / Flash. Ended up only using 0.4-0.75 with double 0.5-0.75. Wide crack at the top had a few features, but overall meh · Lead / Onsight. The confidence boost I needed after flailing all day yesterday :P fun creative climbing · TR. funky crux crossing the fin, i stepped up on a far lefT foot and then rather than going up left of the middle flake i traversed right to a nice foot hold on The riGht flake · Lead / Flash. tricky offwidth section, but not hard to protect. didn't actually need anything bigger than #3 but it was fun to use 4 & 5 · TR. My first offwidth! That was hard but I made it up. Did a butterfly jam with two hand jams and a calf lock. With Andrew mullet · Lead / Onsight. With tiff, 4 helpful for up top (also used a 4 down low) · Lead / Redpoint. #4-6, 0.2-#2 single rack. didnt sling chockstone, bring a fern to clear spiderwebs. high right foot and kinda chimney the dihedral. · Lead / Onsight. varying route quite fun, interesting creative pro. looks harder than it is. don't forget to go left · Lead / Onsight. FUNKY, every move! Slung block in first chimney (first pro), 6 is $$ at top of 1st chimney, #1 in right small dihedral, then 0.2, 0.3, 0.4x2, 0.5, went up right grabbing aretes and thin jams. Small tot nest before wide, #5 great #4ok bump both to chains. · Lead. Wow really fun!! Interesting rock angles down below. Very glad to have the #5 up top (bump bump) · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. led right variation. TRed left variation. super fun to bump the #5. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. had to aid the first part of the OW on lead. clean on TR. too many ledges. stuck rope on TR · Lead / Onsight. bump #5 low, 2 #4s for the top, climbed up right side middle, top out off width move crux · Lead. Got it clean but was going to give up on last few moves. The Big Man told me to go for it. I got it. · Lead / Onsight. OW at the top was interesting, I did several knee jams · Lead / Onsight. Big cam (BD #4) was nice to protect the final chimney

routes.route_description: Left-leaning corner with wide hand crack in the back. Short route, but clean.
routes.route_location: On the left side of the buttress.
routes.route_protection: Cams to 3.5".

area_description: The rock here is generally near vertical with lots of large, rounded features and small cracks. The exception is 'Cornerflash' on the far right end, which is a lower angle wide crack.
area_getting_there: Hike up to the notch (high point of the Inner Wall trail), and then look right. It is across the canyon from the Toxic-Tang-Foodbar areas.

area_comments.comment_text: Finally got on these!!! Wow!!! Excellent job to all involved. Lots of cob webs. They deserve SO much more traffic. These routes are great for challenging your onsight skills. Jul 31, 2019

routes.route_fa: Isabel Melchor, Ben Egbers, Maria Hines, Doug Taylor
routes.route_description: It's a good first trad climb.Lots of hand holds and good feet.  The pro is mostly small with key placements in horizontals along the way.  Tops out with a super fun 5.6 finger crack that takes nuts really well.The FA was Isabel Melchor's First Trad Climb.
routes.route_location: To the right of Corner Flash.  Go back down the trail from Corner Flash about 20 feet, then head up a subtle trail that will get you to the base.
routes.route_protection: Nuts and Cams to .75. Alternatively, you could also use multiple #6's in addition to the Nuts and Cams.

route_comments.comment_text: Super fun! Good gear all the way up, solid hands and feet, great rock quality. Thanks for putting it up, DT! Jul 14, 2018

Was climbing in the area and Doug encouraged us to give this newer route a try.  Fun and easy route at the end of the day.  Significantly easier than corner flash or the 5.8 variant to Toxic Shock.  Stay right as you go up to find the finger crack at the top. This would be a good first trad lead.  You pieces can be a bit spread out distance wise, but the climbing is super easy.  If you were... more Was climbing in the area and Doug encouraged us to give this newer route a try.  Fun and easy route at the end of the day.  Significantly easier than corner flash or the 5.8 variant to Toxic Shock.  Stay right as you go up to find the finger crack at the top. This would be a good first trad lead.  You pieces can be a bit spread out distance wise, but the climbing is super easy.  If you were really nervous you could plug a couple #5's low, but not really needed for the movement on the low portion. Jul 27, 2018
The forest has started to reclaim this route. Jul 23, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Honestly not a fun route. Dirty and not a good first trad lead. · Lead / Redpoint. Got nervous at the crux. After some beta from below (look for face holds on the left), it was easy. Takes nuts well. · Lead / Onsight. Kinda dirty not great pro. Saw a green frog jump across the route

routes.route_description: Climbs through a series of horizontal cracks on vertical to slabby terrain. Nice balancey climb with a variety of small features: mono, undercling, sloper and crimps. Probably tricky to protect on lead. May be missing fixed pin.
routes.route_location: Look for series of horizontal cracks left of the slabby arete on Grandeur buttress across from Toxic Shock. I climbed Corner Flash and set a toprope with gear.
routes.route_protection: gear to .5 with microcams/ballnuts?

route_comments.comment_text: Very fun, thoughtful face climbing. Jul 25, 2013
There are new anchors 10ft below the old AO anchors. Oct 4, 2014

The new anchors are solid bombproof stainless steel bolts, and the new location avoids unimpressive dirty climbing at the top.  This is definitely not an R rated route, but definitely requires heads up climbing.  Unless you are super solid at the grade, it might not be a bad idea to suss out the gear (especially for the first 20 feet) on TR after climbing Corner Flash. Dec 29, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Spent way way way way too much time fiddling around with gear and got very pumped. · TR. Incredibly fun on top rope, perhaps the most fun I’ve had at index, trust the slopers, they will hold you. · TR. Tricky start w/ long reach to a mono on not great feet. Beta intense middle crux, move LEFT to ledge for rest, don't go UP from the pinch/sloper, fell there a few times. Clean from ledge thru upper crux to chains, mantle painful on left fingers stuck in horizontal jam. · TR. took a long time to figure out the crux but really enjoyed the process - much technique · TR. Sooo fun. One of the best routes I’ve climbed. Fell a few times at the crux and also below the anchor (I think due to pump!). Would love to try again on TR. · TR. TR flash. Really fun thoughtful climbing with good holds where you need them. Would be a spooky but prb safe lead · Lead / Fell/Hung. finally nutted up and led this johnson after numerous top rope burns. tested the .2 mid crux and its bomb. feeling confident to RP in the coming week. · TR. figured out the beta on the proper line, gonna give it a lead burn soon. also found new gear beta that comes in clutch. · TR. Super major struggle for me, but a pretty cool route nonetheless! Set a top rope after leading Corner Flash next to it. I left some blood on the route, and stepped on the piton to cheat up the crux. Even if I was a stronger climber, this would be terrible to lead, infrequent & small pro opportunities. · Lead / Redpoint. .2, .2, yellow totem, yellow totem, purple totem, purple totem, black totem · Lead / Redpoint. 1 TR to suss gear then sent first lead go @ comp. Stellar w/excellent gear. Not PG13 if you have the gear dialed. Gear: Purple small metolius, x2 blue totems, x2 purple 0.5s, clip the piton, black totem. Run it out to the chains after that. · Lead / Onsight. Reminded me of the climbing back home. Not PG at all. Gear abounds and the smallest piece needed is only a .2. · TR. Took few times. Start right hand, others beta left hand finger lock? I moved left a bit, then seemed better. Then lean left, some holds, then back to right. Then look some good holds around the corner. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Ground up, but fell trying to avoid ledge. Bailed after broke totem. · TR. Straight up moves at ledge are fun, but but you still wind up just above it and it's contrived to not step down. · TR. Patrick hung a rope and had his first top rope send! I followed and slipped off on the mega right hand cross into the pinky down lock right before the chains. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Last move feels very insecure above the pin spooky for the on-site · TR. lots of small gear from 0 to .3, trickery crimps and undecling traverses. · TR. TR soloed. The crux felt like the last moves. Everything else was chill, just beta intensive. · TR. Felt pretty manageable on TR. One hung with some bad beta.. keep moving left down low. Red point crux would certainty be the top moves. · TR. Fell once at top crux. Tried to climb straight up instead of liebacking the sloper. · TR. need to practice gear placement, then try to lead. felt slightly easier than upper crux of slow children, so 10c? · Lead / Redpoint. this one felt good! with Alana and Dave 3x Send Train baby! · Lead / Redpoint. 2 TR burns (one for move beta, one for gear beta) then sent on first lead go. Got sprayed down by Alana and Hank which helped a bunch down low. Blue totem felt mandatory for the second piece · TR. Awesome climb. TR only, unless you have something to prove. First pro is a small cam (blue #1 or yellow #2 mastercam). Potential broken leg fall if you don't get that first piece clipped. · TR. Fun but hard. Couldn’t figure out crux up top. Then Aimee just waltzed up!! Wut. · TR. The bottom where it starts horizontal and curves up left was tough for me. Sustained in power on slab feet makes it a little scary. Up top I did the crux in one go! · Tr. gear is better than it looks from ground would be scary to OS tho! · TR. First crux: wide pinch and tiny fingertip slot Second crux (piton): layback on tiny flake, high toe over piton · TR. Work way around to left with balancey moves. Use thumb of right hand and go up to rail on left side · Lead / Redpoint. Gear is super solid and right where you need it. Having smaller offset for the start is super nice.

routes.route_description: Looks harder than it is, fun jamming with good gear and rests. good first trad lead. Something fun to do when your waiting for toxic shock.
routes.route_location: across from Toxic Shock
routes.route_protection: cams to 3 inches

route_comments.comment_text: Better than Klahanie Crack mountainproject.com/v/klaha… Jul 16, 2015
agreed with Stamati. Wide range of sizes in a classic setting. you MUST get on this Jul 19, 2015

It's something good to do while waiting to get on Toxic Shock, I wouldn't say it's a good first trad lead unless you know your hand-fist jams well though.  GNS is much better suited to a new leader IMO, it's much easier to fiddle around with gear with all the no hands rests on a slab. Aug 24, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Flash. Led with Tadashi for the day. Rope stuck when getting pulled. Tadashi led on the backside to get it unstuck. Bring #5 next time and stay in the wide crack! · Lead. Good warmup but wouldn’t be my top rec for a first trad lead · Lead / Flash. I heard it was better than Klahanie ;) Definitely more varied and I would say tricker, I think I’m with Stamati on this one · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took twice. Didn’t need to. Did it on TR after clean · Lead / Onsight. My third trad lead, a proud onsight! Got a bit spooked in the middle figuring out the fist jams, ended up just shoving my whole arm in the crack and going up · Lead / Onsight. Climbed with Brian. Good start, but wide in the middle. Powered through with bad technique in the off width. Started with a #2 or 3. Next piece was a #1 in the back of the crack. Once through the crack, climb our on the face with good mid-size gear (.5 and .75). TR multiple times. · Lead / Onsight. The route is cruising, except two moves getting over the wide crack are quite struggling, roughly #4 BD size. The pro is good. · Lead / Flash. Nice and flow-y, climbed the face instead of the off-width and it was way easier · Lead / Flash. Big gear 1”-5”. Doubles 2”-4” maybe. And single rack of med-small. No nuts needed · Lead / Onsight. First trad lead, probably dumb and dangerous, probably undercammed. Definitely got very scared · Lead. Warmup with Lindsey, wished I had the 4 but just fired through anyways · Lead / Onsight. Off width section was tough mentally, should’ve brought bigger gear FS but also some .5s would’ve been nice to feel extra safe · TR. Could lead, would want big gear. way to set up TR on agent orange · Lead / Onsight. Fun warmup after being out of the game. Bottom super fun into a tricky crux (for 5.7). · TR. Too wide for fists before the face climbing option started. Had a little breakdown about it. After getting pulled past that, the rest is super easy · Lead / Redpoint. w Brian. Bump a #2 at the start, then use a 3 or a 4 a little higher for the crux. Then use a 3 and either place a 5 or find a small placement on right, or climb higher and slung the chockstone. My minimum gear would be #2, #4, #3, double sling. Could swap a 3 for a 4 if needed · TR. Climbed with Clemo - bit of a grunt fest but short with wide jams · Lead / Flash. Clean lead. I’m sure I led it before, but don’t remember. Hard for a 5.7, 5.8 would have better set my expectations. I used singles #0.4 to #5 & a second #3, no nuts. A less experienced crack climber would want doubles of a few more sizes, even a second #4 could be nice-to-have. This route would be harder for someone with small hands, as wide fist-jams were key for me. Fun route! · 2 pitches. Lead. One take, poor .75 placement cost the clean send. Too much faffing with it, should have made the move. Caught the rope end on the chock twice when cleaning. · Lead / Onsight. Really the third time I've done it but apparently didn't tick before · Lead / Redpoint. Rope got stuck pulling after rappel! Had to re-climb. Next time should pull from the far left to avoid. One of the parties after us also got rope stuck in the same way. · Lead / Redpoint. warmup for Golden Bucket. More fun the second time. Probably tricky for less experienced climbers, but really fun. Placed 3 pieces. · Lead. Really fun. Dodged the upper offwidth and did the mellow face on the top right. · Lead. Pinkpoint but had to take once at the start of the fists. First half was tricky for me second half is super easy. Was helpful to have a #4 for the first half · Lead / Fell/Hung. So fun! Better than the Columns. Opposite side of Toxic Shock · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung halfway to check on a piece. Can do cleanly for sure · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell during a tricky fist jam, that move made the route feel 5.8+ to me but that might be from my thin hands

routes.route_fa: July 2018  Gabe Webster, Jonah, Ashley and Dan Wiseman, Doug Taylor
routes.route_description: Here's another gem sitting hidden right next to the Index Classic "Agent Orange".  Balancey traversing moves, protected by small cams are followed by a bolt protected slopey crux mantle.  Then easy wide crack is topped off with a second, thought-provoking crux to finish.  Finger pockets appear every time you need it, but might be farther apart than you like.  This climb can be previewed/TR'd by climbing Corner Flash and scrambling to the anchor.  Easier than Agent Orange, it's a good transition climb as one scales the grades on the Inner Walls.The climb is in the shade most of the time so good for hot days.
routes.route_location: This climb starts just below Agent Orange Arrette and continues parallel to it.
routes.route_protection: You'll want a #3, #2, 2 draws, and a good variety of small cams up to .75 . Whether natural or installed, the pro is generous. No reason to be scared on this one.

route_comments.comment_text: Super fun climb, get on it! This route may feel easier after a few attempts but I think the grade is solid for onsight efforts. Jul 31, 2018
This climb is awesome! Great movement and good thoughtful gear Aug 3, 2018
Good climb. I would definitely bring a #2 for the down low section. Similar movement to Agent Orange just a little easier. Aug 4, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. took a while to figure out the mantle, should have just looked at the pics but what fun is that · Lead / Fell/Hung. A couple falls on the very end :( big sweaty and cryptic. Pretty fun but not the best ever · TR. First crux was wet. Felt like it would not be too hard when dry; 2nd crux though is typical granite stuff that I need to learn to do · TR. small gear to bolts. crux sloper was wet so no beta. some wide gear and a .2 for top, sloper match and then switch to undecling · TR. jugged up two sections. hard to get onto slopey ledge, finished it too far right · Lead. need small gear (doubles 0.2 to 0.5; single 1-2; 3.5 for wide crack) · TR. Much easier than a few years back. I like this climb. The top out is delicate 10d/11a easier in the shade. · 2 pitches. tr, lead 1 fall .4, .2, .2/.3 offset, 3 bolts, #2, #3 optional #5 optional .5 2x.3s for the top. the panic would also be nice · TR. Awesome. Slightly easier than Agent Orange to the right. Better protection opportunities down low too. · Follow. .75 3rd piece. stay left of bolts up to sloper rail. #4 at mantle, .5 last piece. undercling left to reachy slopey jug rh topout. w/ jackie · TR. Need to go back and tick on lead. Cool moves. Good pro. Too bit feels bouldery · TR. Practice more before lead. Mostly very fun! Finish confusing he suggest flipping hands for undercling · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very close to sending. Fell at first mantle crux and top crux. Mantle crux: left jug into slap sloper and then high right foot. Top crux: need high right foot and Rickover · TR. Hank and sain had a tr set up on it. Pretty soft for the index grade. Use left hand undercling beta for the top. · 3 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Balancy. .4, black totem, blue alien, 3, 4, black totem · So damn good I had to try it twice. Crux is at the end. · 11a moves are at the the very end. cryptic moves to mantle to the chains.

routes.route_fa: G. White, J. Nelson, S. Strong '82
routes.route_description: A long steep face and crack climb in the middle of Grandeur Buttress. Ends near the small tree on top. Sustained, pumpy climbing on unique rock.The route may be revegetated and need a recleaning.
routes.route_location: From the right edge of Grandeur Buttress, at Agent Orange and Cornerflash, go downhill and left to near the center of the face. The base region may be highly overgrown. The start is significantly lower than that of the routes on the right edge.
routes.route_protection: Full range of sizes, from wired stoppers to 3".

route_comments.comment_text: I think this is what I have a fixed rope on right now, work in progress, may not have been climbed for 30 years, extremely overgrown. I uncovered 2 old pins, one came out when the block it was against came off. There were a few ancient slings on the cedar at the top that popped when I cut them. The main concern I have right now is that the entire top area seems to be exfoliating with very... more I think this is what I have a fixed rope on right now, work in progress, may not have been climbed for 30 years, extremely overgrown. I uncovered 2 old pins, one came out when the block it was against came off. There were a few ancient slings on the cedar at the top that popped when I cut them. The main concern I have right now is that the entire top area seems to be exfoliating with very large loose rock. Jul 31, 2018

Douglas, I think after climbing many variations and consulting the Cummins guide that the Delusions route goes to the cedar tree further left, described as middle of the wall. It makes sense too because it is the only line I can climb after cleaning the other leftward trending crack system that starts at the boulder at the base. Maybe Jon remembers? There are two distinct cruxes. 20 feet up... more Douglas, I think after climbing many variations and consulting the Cummins guide that the Delusions route goes to the cedar tree further left, described as middle of the wall. It makes sense too because it is the only line I can climb after cleaning the other leftward trending crack system that starts at the boulder at the base. Maybe Jon remembers? There are two distinct cruxes. 20 feet up is a hard to figure before you pump out sequence of find the holds and move left of small maple. Then the top out to the anchor is the other crux. I thought about bolts on this, with several spots hard to figure out how to protect, but I feel like it protects ok if you think hard enough. Several in the .5 size and the #3 camalots fill the flaring cracks well. There are great toss in over your head nuts too. Currently a couple of my pins as well. Sep 2, 2018

My work is done on this, pulled the fixed rope. There is a bolted anchor right of the cedar tree now. I left a couple of pins for now. I don't think it needs any bolts and all the loose rock is gone. It would be handy to have a double rack on this, but not required. Nov 11, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Easiest of bunch, could be warmup? JW said he felt lose rocks at top but way I went was solid, still be careful.

routes.route_fa: Sept 2018, Doug Taylor, Matt Trabun, Geoff Georges, Gabe Webster, Nate Redon
routes.route_description: This climb starts generously bolted to just below the crux, where the natural pro becomes more trustworthy. Pull the crux and continue through easier, but thoughtful terrain.  Follow the natural line to a ledge, then meander to the right to a bolt where you'll continue straight up to another bolt then a hand-crack in a pod which takes you to the anchors next to the tree.
routes.route_location: The EXTREMELY obvious boulder at the lowest point of the Grandeur Buttress marks the start.
routes.route_protection: 5 QD's, Single Rack to 2" including nuts and some runners.

route_comments.comment_text: Here's a poor video of the FA.  Use it to get psyched to climb! This is a really cool climb that's easy to get to, with an attention getting crux, and thoughtful but safe climbing throughout. youtube.com/watch?v=QzIC7fk… Sep 28, 2018

My friend Steve and I top-roped this route yesterday. It was pretty tricky at a couple parts and a little slick. We both fell while figuring out the sequence to the crux. We both also fell on our first attempt to gain the ledge (before the traverse right). The ledge is pretty slopy and we were both already a bit pumped from figuring out the lower part. Pretty fun, and nice that it can be... more My friend Steve and I top-roped this route yesterday. It was pretty tricky at a couple parts and a little slick. We both fell while figuring out the sequence to the crux. We both also fell on our first attempt to gain the ledge (before the traverse right). The ledge is pretty slopy and we were both already a bit pumped from figuring out the lower part. Pretty fun, and nice that it can be climbed on lead or easily top-roped with a 60m by scrambling up the south side of the buttress. Hopefully continued traffic will help keep the moss/dust at bay. Here is a fast motion video of Steve Climbing the route. My camera was set to only get the lower section (which is the most difficult) so there is actually about 20ft more of the route above this. youtu.be/UPb7jPqB2DY Oct 21, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got thrashed on the crux move.. I don't know what to do there. · Lead / Onsight. Full on quest. Super weird that the route goes right at the ledge. Could easily go straight · Lead. Screwed up the crux and came off. Bummer. Probably sweat a liter of water just on this pitch. So hot (At) · Lead / Fell/Hung. I don’t think this would be good even if it were clean · Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux is cryptic and hard when sweaty, biffed the onsight. Good line tho · Lead. Very obvious line. A little slick on the feet after the bolts. Good for pushing the grade.

routes.route_description: A boulder problem past a bolt leads to pleasant face/crack climbing on slopersand pinches. The middle is easy, the roof to the top is on slighlty overhung jugs and pinches. The wall is a bit flakey and exfoliating. Did the best job we could to get clean and safe.
routes.route_location: Middle left side of the wall.
routes.route_protection: Doubles to #2 camalot. QDS

route_comments.comment_text: This thing will be a total gem after it gets some more traffic.  Thanks for putting in the work! Sep 5, 2018
Can this be hiked around and toproped for rope soloing? Jul 25, 2019
Would be a proud onsight. Gets beta intensive above the first bolt. Really fun finish and great gear throughout. Aug 6, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. TR. Tricky... Clean on second lap. Far left finger slot for first crux. Go left out to under/sidepull, then right hand sidepull-jam in center, then use pinch. · TR. Was very dirty when my buddy got on lots of excavating cobwebs with nit tools and a decent number of loose blocks · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got the bottom crux minus one part, struggled with the top due to running out of daylight. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Seeping past the first bolt made the boulder problem impossible for me · TR. Crux : use undercling, turn right foot inward and step on outside of foot, then you're in good position to use the sloper · Lead / Redpoint. boulder crux down low with pumpy red point finish feels like NRG goodness · TR. TRash. Epic battle from Caleb putting up the TR. The route itself is fantastic. Cruxy through the bottom but with tons of rest but pumpy in the bolts. Will need to come back to lead. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell and took a bunch. Hard Boulder problem above the first bolt and then tricky slopers after. Eases up and then gets medium hard past the roof. I guess a reasonable index/ michal sandbag · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. Hard to read movement throughout the route. Delicate and intricate moves for the first half, eases half way up then finishes on some pumpy good holds. Sick route! · TR. One of the best climbs I’ve been on. Would go for a lead after one more tr · Lead / Fell/Hung. hard when you do t remember the moves. harder than even Steven for sure. · TR. tricky finding the right holds. once you know, it's fairly easy. hard for the grade. · TR. w Cameron and another. I think this is it. I remember it feeling slightly harder than 5.10, a couple bolts, and steep finish. · Lead / Onsight. One of the coolest routes. Pumped out of my brains. 10+ · Lead / Fell/Hung. I’m lacking in power endurance at the moment. Great climb to practice foot work. · TR. Would be a proud onsight. Gets beta intensive above the first bolt. Really fun finish and great gear in the middle.

area_description: Well past the Grandeur Buttress on the same side of the notch are other walls. Like all Inner Walls routes, the area tends to be shady and cooler than most other walls at Index.
area_getting_there: Various ways are possible, but easiest from the base of Grandeur Buttress, skirting the right side of the canyon.

area_comments.comment_text: There is a rough trail if you hug the canyon to the right coming from the toxic shock area.  Watch out for holes and teetering boulders hidden by moss. Sep 11, 2019
The original name for this area was the Velvet Underground because of all the moss covered boulders. Sep 11, 2019
I like it, Darryl. I wasn't trying to force a name, I just figured those routes should not be listed with the stuff on Foodbar Wall. Sep 11, 2019

routes.route_fa: Evan LovleyMeyers and Dylan Butterfass, Sept 7th 2019
routes.route_description: A fun layback crack, a little off the beaten track. Climb the hand-sized, right-facing dihedral to a large ledge. The crack then widens to 4-5 inch for the upper crux section.   Be careful, a ledge fall on the crux is possible. Pull up over the second ledge to a bolted anchor.
routes.route_location: The climb is 200 feet to the right of 'Tie me to a length of that'.  Its GPS coordinates are N47-49.189'     W121-34.659'.
routes.route_protection: .75-#2 and two #4.  bolted anchor.

routes.route_name: Tie Me to a Length of That
routes.route_fa: Dave Haavik, Darryl Cramer, Greg Olsen, Erik Thixton
routes.route_description: A destroyer of a route that both epitomizes an aesthetic rock climb and will make you want to show up taller and stronger than you are. The line takes an obvious clean path up a steep arete starting with moderate face climbing which leads into a powerful and well protected crux. Being tall may ease difficulties.
routes.route_location: This spectacular gem is found on its own solitary feature. The climb is about 8-10 minutes of bush walking past Foodbar then Fire wall on your left side. You will continue down the canyon via path of least resistance until the wall is visible on right (east)? Side of the canyon, it easier to stay on the left (west) side and cross once you can see the climb.
routes.route_protection: Quick draws. Some suggest a single red camelot as you approach the crux.

area_description: Large wall just right of the Cheeks.
area_getting_there: The most direct way is via the trail to Duck Wall. To reach Duck, see the Duck Wall page. From Duck wall continue up the gully, which has water running down it most of the year.You can also approach via the Cheeks. Just continue along the trail that goes along the base of the lower Cheeks.  This takes you to the top of R.O.U.S., so you would have to rappel that to get to the right half of the wall.The third way is from the top of Lookout Point. Go back and left (southwest) until you hit the Collegium, then skirt the base of the wall going towards the Cheeks. Be careful at the point where the top of Duck Wall is very close to this upper band of rock. You will cross under the Beyond, and then hit the Diamond.

area_comments.comment_text: The "Kyle and Amy" route.  I remember teaching them how to bolt on that line. It never got cleaned well. But could clean up to be a decent line! Sep 9, 2023

routes.route_description: A National Acrobat is beautiful route that connects The Diamond's most striking features. It is a physical journey that is sure to test all of you're granite skills.P1 5.9: Climb R.O.U.S., a fun, dark bolted chimney.P2 5.11: The fight begins. Start up the Dark Crystal (Seasonally wet, usually dries in early June), climb to where the original route breaks left. Instead, climb straight up, clip a bolt and pull the roof. A couple boulder moves lead to a pumpy hand traverse. Save a hand size piece of gear for the end.P3 5.10: Climb the short tricky arête of the Dark Crystal. This could easily be linked into P4.P4 5.12- (5.10+ A0): The pitch of eternal sadness. Break right from the ledge into a shallow right facing dihedral. After a somewhat moderate start, a short but devastatingly granite crux, followed by more easy climbing brings you into the Dihedral.P5 5.11-: Dubbed the Book of Earth Mother, this pitch offers some of the best corner climbing Index has to offer. Perfect.P6 5.11d: If the corner didn't get you giddy, this slightly overhung 40 meter pitch leads up the glorious Zebra Headwall. Discontinuous cracks, jugs, and a sloper crux is sure to grab your attention.P7 5.0: Move belay up and right to the next anchor.P8 5.11: Climb steep rock to a slab crux. Continue up the slab and pull the fat roof on sexy slopers.P9 5.9: Fun climbing top's you out on the highest point of The Diamond."Just remember love is life and hate is living death. Treat your life for what it's worth and live for every breath. Looking back I've lived and learned, but now I'm wondering. Here I wait and only guess what this next life will bring"
routes.route_location: This route starts on R.O.U.S., which is the dark bolted chimney uphill and left of the y intersection at the top of the Diamond Gully.
routes.route_protection: Standard Rack to 4", a 5" cam can be used for the Dark Crystal if so inclined. A FULL 70 meter rope.
