routes.route_protection: Quickdraws

area_description: Shorter, more south-westerly facing wall than the Diamond, but essentially on the right end of the Diamond.
area_getting_there: Two ways.From the west, hike up to the base of the Diamond, then walk east (right) and uphill till reaching the huge corner. The Beyond is on the right.From the east, first reach the Collegium, which can be reached either from the top of Lookout Point or from topping out on a route in the Velvet area. Once at the base of the Collegium, continue traversing along the base of the wall, going west past a slightly exposed region above Duck Wall, and then immediately going uphill to the huge corner. Alternatively, from the Collegium, pass through the rock buttress via a huge chimney. To do so, head up the via ferrata to the big chimney and traverse the chimney. At the chimney's exit, you'll have to push your pack out in front of you. You are now at the southern edge of The Beyond.

routes.route_description: Starts by following a left-leaning thin crack, protected by thin wired stoppers. Then goes up the face, trending right. Crux is at the end.
routes.route_location: On the left side.
routes.route_protection: Thin wired stoppers, bolts.

routes.route_description: Ascends the main arete of the Beyond.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 4 bolts

route_comments.comment_text: this looked like it would be fun if clean, some loose rock, funky bolts. at least they are 3/8". Not so much the arete as the left side of the arete, on the west face. May 29, 2014

routes.route_description: Left facing corner.  Finger to fist , layback.  Steep and fun.  Stays clean.
routes.route_location: Anchor at top needs replacing (1/4" rusty), (update 2024-apparently it has been replaced), recommend rappelling to the right off nearly naked bolts, easy walk across top to bolts. Fun day is to climb something at Duck Wall and hike up wooded ramp at the top to get to the base.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 4", optional 5".  Beware of a few expanding flakes.

route_comments.comment_text: rap off route climbers right of this. Sep 6, 2020
Anchor has been replaced. Oct 24, 2024

area_description: The right end of the country area, with all routes starting within a minute walk of the leveled surface area at the end of the road.
area_getting_there: Park at the Lower Wall parking area. Cross the tracks, and follow dirt road to the right. In a few minutes you'll pass the Lower Wall and turn left into a wide, level area.

routes.route_description: Climb the off-fingers to hand splitter crack up to the roof.  Bolts protect the crux roof and the surprisingly fun climbing to the anchor just below the lone cedar.Two 70m rappels to the ground, or use two 70 m ropes and set up a BIG Top Rope for the hordes at the base.
routes.route_location: From the top anchor of "Tunnel Vision", scramble easy up and right to an anchor at the base of a splitter off-fingers to hands crack.
routes.route_protection: Lots of QD's and some cams from .3 to .75.

route_comments.comment_text: This is an enjoyable line packed with variety and well-protected, interesting moves.  If it were at ground level, it would be every bit as popular as Cunning Stunt, if not more so. Aug 18, 2013

The bolt protecting the roof move ( below climber's left foot in the photo) is visibly corroded. Other bolts on this thing may be bad as well - they have the same KONG hangers which lead to total failure under bodyweight on an UTW route or two. There are adequate gear opportunities to lead this without worrying too much, but I wouldn't place much faith in the bolts themselves. Nov 10, 2013
The bolts next to the splitter crack have been removed and old bolts above replaced with SS a couple years ago.  Get on this awesome line. Apr 26, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. Followed Andrew. Several falls. Crack was a tough size, slabby mantle felt very improbable · Lead / Fell/Hung. Absolute classic. So many different types of 5.10 moves crammed into this climb. Pure awesome. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Only lead the second half, which was an absolute blast. Lots of burly moves, yet still surprisingly interesting body movement · Lead / Fell/Hung. Off fingers are awesome!!! Finally got to do a proper ringlock · 4 pitches. TR. Laps in the rain. Ring lock or layback up the flake. Sweet kneebar just after the crux.

routes.route_description: Start by climbing straight up from the ground through knobs and face holds (5.11-) just right of Little Jupiter, or by traversing in from SS Ultrabrutal (easier although unprotected for the first 25 feet or so. Climb the flake system up to the small overlap, clip the bolt and get ready to pull.
routes.route_location: Just to the left of the giant tunnel, look for the bolt on the overlap (it may be hard to see as it is painted black).
routes.route_protection: I placed 1 Black alien, 1 Blue alien and 2 Green aliens (be sure to sling these appropriately), along with 3 quickdraws for the bolts. The anchor is bolted with chains. I gave it a PG13 rating as the start requires a bit of soloing before you get in the good gear about 25 feet off the ground, if you are capable of climbing the crux, this section will feel very very easy for you.

route_comments.comment_text: Really fun climbing on igneous inclusions. Last move reach took me like an hour to figure out--and the hardest move of the route for me. Placed a long runner on the 1st bolt of Indexstacy... Mar 12, 2019

More folks should give this short potent climb a go! Two challenging cruxes; one quite physical pulling the overlap and the other tenuous and technical on the upper knobs. One of my favorite climbs at the Country. Dec 5, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Linked from the start of the business all the way to the top. Psyched · Sorted beta for J, and figured out top out to anchor for short beta. Good left crimp side pull, move R hand, R foot high knob, left hand to shallow bump, balance, mantle straight up, R hand index finger press to stabilize. Done. · 2 pitches. TR. First crux feels good now, still don’t have a good sequence for second one · TR. Took forever to figure out upper crux but can do on command now. completely obliterated my skin on the crux knobs · TR. Original route from the right. Never figured out the last move to the anchor. · Lead / Redpoint. Really good and probably not PG-13, but the bolting sorta sucks. Better with preplaced long slings.

routes.route_description: To the left of Steel Monkey are two lines of bolts, intended as both free climbs and aid climbing practice. The right route has about half the bolt spacing of the left and would make an easy first bolt ladder. There was already an anchor above, we added a bolt for security given the nature of the hardware.The route was bolted near free climbing features in the event someone is interested in doing the FFA.
routes.route_location: Left of Steel Monkey
routes.route_protection: Bolts to bolt anchor.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. most reachy bolt ladder I've ever done (foregoing the retro bolts). The one going past the horizontal dirty dike was nearly impossible · 2 pitches. TR. Aid (right bolt line). Top stepping is not enough, need hooks and aggressive throws to barely reach the bolts · 2 pitches. TR. Aid (left bolt line). Need to top step pretty hard to reach next bolt.

routes.route_fa: Greg Collum, Cal Folsom, Larissa Collum
routes.route_description: This fully bolted climb is a good addition to the rest of the routes at the country.  Probably soft for 5.11c.  It is a one move wonder with a weird mantel move.
routes.route_location: This sport route starts just right of the large test tunnel, and left of cunning stunt.
routes.route_protection: 10 bolts & fixed biners

route_comments.comment_text: can be climbed fairly comfortably with gear (if a 25 foot 5.9'ish runout above the crux to the anchors seems comfortable). awesome route. Sep 5, 2008

Typical "The Country" type climbing with cruxes followed  by rests after each.  Well placed bolts protect each crux, with one short section being the true crux.  Originally led as a pure trad line, it's now almost exclusively led as a sport climb... by lots of people. One of the easier 5.11c's at Index and a good climb to get on to inch into the grade. Aug 17, 2013
The sloping ramp/mantle crux is hard, but much more manageable than Wham. Could see why there'd be an argument for calling it 5.11b... fun though. Mar 2, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Super fun TR. Tried to climb carefully and thoughtfully, but went right where I should have gone left (at the first non obvious spot) so I fell. David pointed out I should go left and I was able to piece it together (beta: right hand in side pull pocket, crimps (can't remember exact sequence), eventually left hand to slopey far left hold, then bump feet and go for better higher hold with right hand). Also fell at crux (beta: left hand on the last super good hold before slopers, high feet (I think right foot on the really good really high foot), right hand for first slopey thing, then left then right, now keep right on the good-ish shelf because the next sloper is bad. Keep it there till move feet up, *then* go for slopers and mantel. Still not home free from there but the rest is all very doable and not as tricky with good effort). · TR. Nice to get to try this one again the same day. Still fell at the crux, but that's because I wasn't being careful. Should have kept right had on that pretty-good diagonal shelf while I bumped feet before going for slopers. Next time... · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 fall at crux. Left foot popped right at the last possible moment · Lead / Fell/Hung. Flashed up to sloper then had to stick clip up. Hard and insecure! · TR. At crux, get left foot up to nub, right foot in corner, hands up to blocks eventually getting right hand to right block, right foot up to edge in face just right of crack, left foot out wide to ledge, left hand to first slopy crimp, right foot in to edge in crack, left hang up to better crimp, right foot uo to good ledge, right palm down on sloper, stand up, bring left foot in · Lead. Morning temp mid 40s, start at 8 am. Hands went numb immediately, very painful. Grabbed draw at top crux, next time just look down for better feet. · TR. 1st Crux at left block: high right hand, high left foot. Reach high right then left hand, high left foot then use nub on face to rock over. 2nd Crux at bulge: right side pull to left pinch, left under up. Walk right foot to side pull. Bump left foot, left hand crimp, match with right , high left foot then rail, match, bump right foot up. Crux 3: corner. Left pinch right side pull, high right foot, bump right hand up, high left foot, high left hand, rock over, high left foot, high hand, bump right over then get left hand on, right foot out on face , walk hands along sloper weight right foot the.n high left foot and step yp · Lead / Fell/Hung. Blew the onsight after pulling the crux. It should go next time. · Lead / Redpoint. Forgot how to index mantel for a second but remembered just in time lol · Lead / Fell/Hung. Damn! Foot popped right as I was starting the crux. Felt good otherwise, thought I had it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Go straight up on the mantle and keep right foot to the right of the bolt. Tried three times and finished on cunning stunt. · Lead / Redpoint. 1 fall pre crux (corner compression moves). Mantle crux not bad at all. Sweet climb · Lead / Fell/Hung. Super good, fell a few times working out the crux and completely missed the left crimp. Managed to do the sloper mantle without it · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at the crux. Hot sweaty day so hopefully it would be easier with better conditions · Lead / Onsight. Unreal, so many cool moves and holds on this climb. So good I did it twice, just kidding, while pulling our rope somehow jiggered itself into an autolocking belay device using the two permadraws, looked something like this when I lead back up there (https://www.vdiffclimbing.com/carabiner-brake/) first ever for me... · Lead. Almost onsight! Did the mantle and then tried to clip and thought I’d fall so I grabbed the draw. Ugh. Quick take and then finished it! So close! · TR. First time I've done this in the direct sun where it felt very smooth · Lead / Fell/Hung. Jeez! Cool climbing, punted at the mantle many times in the sun. Got pooped on by a bird and then pulled the move · TR. Got up to crux sloper with no falls. New beta for sloper: grab it a bit further right than before, using slightly more positive spot on the pinky side (turn wrist slightly in the thumbs out direction). L foot on positive diagonal crimp works well for mantel move. · Follow. Few hangs, crux was wet, then hands were greasing off the mantle sloper. Cross R foot into toe jam at start of crux to avoid barn door, then left foot up on chip. · TR. Hung at upper crux, sloper rail got soaked in the light rain that started · TR. need to come back and lead! Super sick climbing, all the moves are chill, just need to link them · Lead / Redpoint. Project finally goes down!! Early birthday present from Index. Also had great vibes from Leah Salinsky and George Bieker (on belay) at the crag!! 10/10 would do again · TR. From CS intersection: L hand good pinch, R hand good side/undercling, feet up, L hand to slopey sidepull higher -> must keep L foot high for it, R hand deadpoint to worse side/undercling, L foot high to slopey ledge, R foot higher, L hand deadpoint to positive sidepull crimp. Then, work R foot into toejam and clip? Both hands on diagonal crimp, R hand first sloper, L hand second sloper, R hand on slopey ledge (find groove w/fingers). Feet up on bad feet, L hand on slopey crimp. Stand up and get R foot on bump below ledge (crux). Stand up on that and you're done. · Lead / Redpoint. First go but had tried a few seasons ago. Not hard · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux went with layback/mantle on right side - get foot high. Feels tenuous, condition dependent. · TR. Super fun route. Got through the first crux then tripped up on the slope-y ledges. Figured it out though and want to try it on lead! · Lead / Fell/Hung. whipped off the mantle a few times before getting it. gotta move right on the slopey rail then get the high left foot · TR. Fell at roof, didn’t realize there was a good crimp. 3ish hangs trying to figure out mantle. · TR. 1 hang on TR, could project. From where it meets CS left hand on big side pull, right hand undercling above CS flake. work feet up, go to positive side pull. then next positive crimp match, right hand small sloper, left hand better hold, right on mantle ledge. feet up, left foot on diagonal hold, spiral up on it right hand ledge left hand small crimp push with foot to stand up ending with left hip in wall. get right foot on small hold on arete and you're done · Lead / Redpoint. Dialed on TR then sent back to back with Mikey OC · TR. Clean up to sloper moves, which felt hard after settling on some beta. · Lead / Onsight. mmmm sporty and juggy <3 feels true to the grade, despite being quite soft by Index standards · Follow. Conceivably leadable due to close bolting, although mantle off the sloper really sucks. lf intermediate and hop up? In lower slopers go left first then high feet. Higher up, l crack sidepull, higher r crack sidepull, bump to good l sidepull always with good feet · Lead / Fell/Hung. One take and one fall at the crux. So fun, could rp for sure. Use those tiny crimps!! · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Hella whips w/ Kiera :) Better second time on TR · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tried a few times since the draws were hung. Fell a couple times then lowered · TR. TR’d from top of cunning stunt. Cool but crux is pumpy and short

routes.route_description: This is a right facing corner with a finger crack. Go up the slab and into the crack in the corner. The crux is near the end.
routes.route_location: This and Sweet Virginia lie above the other Country routes. The most direct way to its base is by doing P1 of Zoom, Leave my Face Alone, and then P1 of 116 Orc Tower Rd (see Orc Tower routes).You can also walk or climb to the top of GM/Heart of the Country. To the climber's right of the final set of anchors there is a red fixed rope. Follow this rope and some others up and to the climber's left. The trail branches at one point and leads to a large ledge under an overhang. Stick with the main trail and it will take you above the ledge and further left. You will pass a number of cracks that are recent first ascents, but keep going.You will find two bolts with chains at the base of the climb. (One hanger might be missing.)
routes.route_protection: Small cams.

route_comments.comment_text: When it was first reported, the first bolt to protect the slab move off the ledge had a missing hanger. Am not sure if this still holds. May 12, 2013

routes.route_description: Bolted climbing leads to a crux fingerjam in a bulge. More climbing up cracks and corners leads to a two bolt anchor.
routes.route_location: Starts to the right of Steel Monkey and just to the right of a steeper bolted face climb. Descend with a 60m rope.
routes.route_protection: Bolts and gear to #3 Camalot. Fixed anchor; however, bring webbing and a knife in case the in-situ pieces aren't viable.

routes.route_description: The second bolted line to the right of the tunnel, identifiable by the fixed pin at the start.  Follows a discontinuous line of flakes up a steep face.  The crux comes about  halfway up at a slabby reach move before getting into a juggy flake that leads to easier climbing above.  Sustained, fun, thought provoking climbing.  It is exposed and dries quickly, and is climbable in low temps.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 7 bomber new bolts and one fixed pin. Fixed biners at the top.

route_comments.comment_text: The second bolt (third fixed piece, including the pin) is bad.  THe stud spins in the hole!  Anybody feel like doing a public service? I think the thing must've been over-torqued when it was placed, because it is a new bolt.  Bummer. Mar 13, 2006

The route also has a 20-25 foot extension that is fun climbing, however the rock is less than perfect, in fact a bit rotten in places. It climbs the obvious prow (in a contrived way) standing above the first anchors, probably around .10a Mar 20, 2006
Though the above-mentioned bolt needs to be replaced, you can place a yellow metolius in the flake to its left.  Don't fall too hard, though.  It would suck to have that flake blow. Mar 20, 2006

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bahhh! So close to clean, got nervous on the finger traverse in the middle. Can definitely send it next time. Did the extension to top rope fifth force · TR. Top roped and unclipped as I went to follow Nathan’s lead. Probably the best the climb as felt, minus one foot pop · TR. Two cruxes. Left hand crimp traverse. Rest. Followed by a right hand dead point. · TR. Clean! Some beta tips: before the stem bar thing step left on that slopey thing in order to clip. For the traversal left, just need to move quickly through small crimps, but I am strong enough to hold on to them just fine. For the upward right diagonal crux: take a good long rest, don't get sidetracked by the jug thing out left (I actually forgot about it during this burn which was a good thing). I can't remember the exact hand sequence I used, but just look at it and you'll figure it out. I liked what I did and think my brain could recreate it upon another look. It actually didn't feel bad at all. High left foot for sure though. Trust it... And for the love of god please try to lead it next time. The beta and strength are dialed.... · Lead / Fell/Hung. Finger pully kept me from finishing last two bolts but was stellar otherwise · TR. Amazing climb, quality rock, great movement. Crux for me before standard crux- getting the jug on the right of the traverse. Had to get feet stemmed high for left hand 3 finger ledge, bump right to bad left side of jug, then to the jug (now I know it’s there) · Lead / Flash. Ethan, Haley and max led. Great climb with some delicate movement through the crux. · w dees boys. soft 2nd. don’t use arete- commit to smol feet and it’s chillin. · Lead / Redpoint. w/ sam. so fun to repeat this! second 5.10 of the day · Lead / Fell/Hung. Huh, got stumped by the crux moves on the first go. · TR. Crux starts in blank corner. Walk left up left ramp, right foot high in corner. Left hand small crimp, right to rail. Walk feet up, left foot under clin, right side pull. Right foot small lip, left foot way out. Bump left two pockets, right to small pocket. Bump to left rail. Both feet over use left Gaston and right on rail. Right foot high left foot up to lip. Twist right hip in both hands to rail, left reach high to next rail, high feet and go! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a bit to work out the beta. Great route. Would be a proud onsight. Used a .3 cam to supplement bolts. · Lead / Redpoint. SEND. Great route. Would repeat anytime. Liked having the .3 in addition to the draws. · TR. Interesting route, beta intensive moves. Really fun jugs on a flake with minimal feet. It’s a tough one but rewarding to get it. Crux for me was moving across the finger pockets, for others it is the next set of moving a getting to the flakey jug. · TR. Very doable, but got pumped on lead and switched off, need to work on my lead game! · Lead / Onsight. Through the extension, fun! Kept to the arete at the end · Lead / Onsight. Climbed this at night - so fun! Great route with an obvious crux. Last couple moves were tough for me too · Lead / Fell/Hung. One burn. First crux is confusing but not hard with the right beta. Second crux is straightforward but you actually have to be good. Barely avoided a wasp hiding in the crack after the second to last bolt. Wish I had tried for the redpoint but it was the end of the day. Also I managed to sprain my ankle on this route without noticing somehow??? Bizarre · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 fall on the reachy crux. Got it second time with higher foot position. Must come back for the redpoint. Best climb of the day. One of the bolts is too high and very reachy at 5'8 · Lead / Fell/Hung. Dammit.. fell at the first traverse crux. I did a foot swap that seemed to really work for next time · Lead / Fell/Hung. Unsent this from a few years back. Had to hang twice. Still rusty from offseason. · Lead / Fell/Hung. One hung, went right at 3rd bolt on onsight attempt. Very fun route · Lead / Flash. Got scared between the bolts but felt totally fine on the moves. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once at middle crux. Spent 10 min right below the anchor trying to figure out how to reach jug. Traversed right with sketch slab moves to ascend. · Lead / Onsight. first climb in index! a little committing in spots, me and harrison both got spooked. relearning to trust sticky granite · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tricky and pretty spooky. Also got hot up on the face in the sun · Lead / Redpoint. part after traverse felt a bit hard to find the feet. spaced bolts

routes.route_fa: Darryl Cramer, Greg Olsen, Jeff Walker
routes.route_description: This begins with the start of Fool's Gold. After climbing the large flake at the bottom (either side), face climb up and right past two bolts (includes a fun mantle move) to a large orangish flake with rippled rock texture. Jam and layback the left side to the top of the flake, then do a few power moves left to the shallow corner (perhaps the crux) and go up the corner past two more bolts. Near the top, there is another cruxy move involving a palmy layback. Belay or lower from the chains in the alcove.
routes.route_location: Starts as for Heart of the Country and Fool's Gold via either side of a large flake. You can barely lower to the start with a 60-m rope.
routes.route_protection: Bolts and gear to #3 or 4 Camalot. Long slings are needed to reduce rope drag. The start is either a 5.9 squeeze or an unprotected 5.4 lieback/jam. Bring bigger gear if these options seem intimidating. Fixed anchors, possibly with old webbing.After the first two face bolts, you need small wires, a finger-sized cam to protect the upper traverse left (possibly the crux), and a few cams to 2.5" for the gold flake. Four bolts total.

route_comments.comment_text: Now that the start has been cleaned up, this is a fantastic route! The 5.9 starting option can be well protected with one each of #4 and #5 camalots (or avoided by soloing the left side of the flake at 5.4). Thereafter, you don't need anything larger than a #1 camalot. A small nut (e.g. HB #6 offset) can be placed between the two bolts on the upper section. All the bolts and the anchor are... more Now that the start has been cleaned up, this is a fantastic route! The 5.9 starting option can be well protected with one each of #4 and #5 camalots (or avoided by soloing the left side of the flake at 5.4). Thereafter, you don't need anything larger than a #1 camalot. A small nut (e.g. HB #6 offset) can be placed between the two bolts on the upper section. All the bolts and the anchor are solid as of 7/13. Jul 21, 2013
A big thanks to Derek Pearson for cleaning this one up and replacing bolts. Jul 25, 2013

Oh I only added one at the top of the flake . I never got around to doing the rest. I think mike did it . Mike, where the two bolts are that protect the mantle move to get to the crack , I wanted to move that clip up higher so it protects the move better . And did you replace the carabiniers with links at the anchor ? Moving from the top of the flake left I wanted to add a bolt there . And... more Oh I only added one at the top of the flake . I never got around to doing the rest. I think mike did it . Mike, where the two bolts are that protect the mantle move to get to the crack , I wanted to move that clip up higher so it protects the move better . And did you replace the carabiniers with links at the anchor ? Moving from the top of the flake left I wanted to add a bolt there . And then reposition the next two bolts . This one of my favorite climbs . Thanks Jon for the props but I'm not responsible for the all work it seems there are a few people that like to help with route clean up. Jul 26, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Aaron lead RP today... I fell at top and scratched at it.... super fun... scary lead for aaron · Lead / Fell/Hung. Goddamn rope drag thwarted my send. Do not place gear in the flared chimney · osl. The elegant upper part was easy after frightening myself by inelegantly chimney-ing the unprotected 5.4.

routes.route_fa: Greg Collum, Greg Child and Greg Olsen
routes.route_description: An area classic, possibly the best or second best sport route I've ever done. Vertical climbing with hard cruxes and great rests. Very intriguing climbing!One can fairly easily set up a TR on this by lowering off the anchor of the extended version of Cunning Stunt.
routes.route_location: Start on Cunning Stunt but cut right before the first pin and clip a bolt...head straight up from there.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: All bolts are SS as of 2015.  Get out there and SEND IT... or fall, it doesn't matter now. Mar 28, 2015

Thanks for putting in the new hardware! For anyone getting on the route soon, note that the slopey rail above the 6th bolt is a little slippery from the rock dust from the bolt replacement. I gave the area above the rail and rail itself a good scrubbing, but it will probably take a bit more rain to clean it off all the way. Apr 22, 2015

Thank you for the fresh hardware Doug. What a great pitch. Powerful granite face climbing with intricate sequences separated by good rests. The crux definitely becomes harder the shorter you are and a rating is thus hard to give. For some reference, Siegrist called this .13, "and hard at that!" Nov 24, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Made it to the top! Stepped on two bolts and did a metric butt ton of takes. Feels within the realm of distant possibility. · TR. Omg this is so hard and I freaking love it. I definitely need to work through the moves around the third bolt a little more but managed to figure out the rest of the moves on top rope (with tons of falls of course) I think this is definitely a climb I’d love to do top rope laps on, get the beta down and go for the red point. I just really enjoyed the moves and had a total blast on it, even if I was flailing. I flailed my way to the top at least. · Lead / Redpoint. 3 boulders separated by rests, all desperate until you know what your doing and relax into it, and then it’s not too bad. Like every 12b at index it would be 12d anywhere else but whatever it’s rad! · TR. Many falls working out sequences. Such a fun route. Have to take the Gilkeson low and right beta for the first crux. · Lead / Redpoint. 4 days of effort probably a 13 at most other crags · Clean tr first go!! Sweaty ass day and hadn’t been on in a couple weeks!! Hell yeah! Lead next time prb, scary last bolt! · Lead / Redpoint. So psyched to put this down, rigwise of course. #2 iron horse 5 aka the fifth horse … it’s forever · 3 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. First burn a TR for betas n what not, ykwii Second burn is a dirty AF lead in the sun. Talked to mom and dad on the phone and then went for another lead. Sent it this go and I’m psyched!! Ps this is my second horse but ultimately the fifth. Pps it is forever! Put this rigamortus down with quantanamo bae…. 4ever (NO DUDE) · TR. Figured out all 3 cruxes, super cool climbing. Gotta get back so I don’t forget! Some temps would be nice · TR. Shut down above the third bolt due to a lack of technique. Should be able to work out the beta or just be tall. · TR. Make a good progress on it today. Did the second crux without falling and then went right at the first Crocs. · TR. Crux 1 goes better with foot-swap - jump from left foot on right rail. · 2 pitches. TR. Super fun - crux 1 goes with high feet, thumbs, and leaning far-right to jump to jug. crux 2: shit feet to get RF up to edge, bump RH from first sidepull up to decent one under roof, bump left hand and stand up until can reach jug. crux 3: use shit sidepulls in crack, LF far out edge, RF on jug sidepull, LH last crimp, RH shallow sidepull and crank to stand tall on RF · Lead / Redpoint. Tried once in July then got it second go of the day! · 4 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Apparently doable with perfect condis! Biffed from last crux, then again from last move, before send. W Jamie Crux 1: lean to leaned foot switch. L on right crescent, R on incut minicrimp just above Crux 2: L sp, R sp, RF smear, L heel, bump up hands, foot swap for RF on edge, R bump to bad 2F. L to corner, R flip to slopey pinch, feet up, bump to jug Crux 3: can’t clip, go right. R match L sp, R arete. RF heel, R to crimp. LF press turned away holds for L to sp. core up! Press for R match, LF way left insecure, RF press right, to crimp · Lead / Redpoint. Did each crux first attempt as I lowered down to brush the route. Sent first lead try of the day. Felt oddly easy, V5- to V6 to V5+ instead of the usual V5/7+/6+, conditions really matter I guess. The end of my longest standing project and the reason I moved to Washington. Index provides. Index is choss. ❤️ · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Led 3 times, twice to top, including hanging draws. First go fell at 2nd crux then did second try then fell mid 3rd crux. Second go with new shoes fell at second and lowered - not enough feeling for smears. Third go heartbreaker, took a mega whip exiting the third crux - left hand hit between the two spots of the crimp that marks the end of the hard climbing - definitely make sure it is ticked. It was actively misting/raining so I think this should go in the dry… hopefully. Crux 1 - LF good edge, fully lean into right palm, LH comes off then up to undercling corner for balance, RF stems high, then lean back left using RH thumbercling Crux 2 - LF heel, LH highish, RH lowest sidepull, RF sharp white, RH mid sidepull w/ thumb, LF right dimple, RF rose edge, RH bad top sidepull, LF arête, LH bottom corner, LF high smear, RF lowest sidepull, RH jug Crux 3 - from jug flake, RF good edge, LF heel, LH arête, RH bump near max span, RF smear, LF really high to good smear, RF toe arête, RH crimp, angle LF to smoothly bump LH to second spot from top of arête, RF swap, LF stab, RH to top of arête, really squeeze RH and rock left and hit the ticks!! · Lead. If TR by headlamp last time was a bad idea, leading by headlamp was even dumber. Made it to the second crux and almost stuck it before lowering off · 3 pitches. TR. Lead first lap in sun - stupid. TR lap x2 didn’t fall until second crux on both. Second TR lap that was the only time I fell - stuck LH triangle but fell bringing LF in. 64 degrees and 62% humidity on last attempt - not worth leading on anything higher than that. Crux 1 - LH good sidepull, RF high to good foot, crank up and RH to good corner to shift weight over foot. LF to thin corner and bring LH up. Match feet then LF up to good edge. Lean out right, RH spanned to opposing “corner” and bring RF up, LH to undercling flake, match - thumbdercling RH to left of LH, RF up to good indent on corner, LH on good corner, deadpoint RH to bottom of U, LF up, match LH right of RH, RH to jug. Crux 2 - LF heel hook ramp, LH kinda high sidepull but comfortable, RH bottom crimp sidepull, LH bump, RF to scoop, RH to triangle, LF to scoop just right of RF, RF high rose edge, LF toe top of ramp, LH throw to triangle, LF in to lighter crystally smear, RF pull with toes on sidepull crimp, RH to crimp then jug crimp Crux 3 - fridge hug to jug sidepull, then feet on hood edges/smears, LF heel to bump LH, RF heel LF good smear to get RH to crimp high in middle of fridge, bump LH, swap feet, stab LF to far edge, RH to good gaston on fridge left side to rock onto foot · TR. Didn’t make it past the 3rd bolt - super height dependent climb, don’t bother trying again · TR. Tall guy climb, figured out the moves and will come back to lead · TR. first time on it. feels impossible ATM first crux isn't clear need more work on the beta. · TR. Made it to like maybe bolt 3 lol. Too tired to figure out a beta that worked after that (also i may not be good enough to get past that part even with the right beta) · TR. When in doubt, lunge up right! First crux: delicate to fall right, crescent to lunge into R crimp. Second: meh R crescent to L corner, hard spread out w bad feet lunge into R crimp. Third: lieback w bad smears, lunge up to R crimp and traverse hard left · TR. Sussed. Three distinct cruxes involving shitty techy feet placements with rests in between · 3 pitches. TR. Figured out beta for everything, ready to lead. 1st go meh. 2nd go fell first crux traversing, then no falls to the anchor 3rd go fell once on 2nd crux. Make sure to use the worse right foot on the face when putting heel up. · 2 pitches. TR. 2nd go felt pretty good. First crux traverse low, iron cross middle 2 fingers each hand. Lh on 2nd crimp (is better), rh side pull above lh, Rf at highest good foot near ledge thing, lf on nubbin left of the vertical thing, rh up, · TR. Finally did all the moves “for real” climbing into and through the cruxes instead of preplacing feet when pulling back on. If conditions are good, time to start RP burns! 2nd crux right foot grey scoop, left foot grey scoop up left, RF rose edge, left toe arête & throw. Third crux - fridge hug, left hand jug, work feet to RH crimp, fight barn door and stab LF across to edge · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got the rite of passage smack down on this one… crux 1: move up w high RF and LF in corner, swing to match R hold, up small crimps. Crux 2: Move high L, bad smeary feet, R bump up bad, jump L into block, R crimp. Crux 3: hugging to barndoor transitions · 2 pitches. TR. 2x. First crux hit Index finger in bottom of U. Second crux finally stuck LH triangular block with RF good rose edge. Weird angling groove above toe down heel-toe cam. Third crux finally feels linkable · TR. this might be the hardest thing I've ever tried to climb-and I failed miserably · 2 pitches. TR. Tough conditions; no real progress today. 2nd crux still seems close to impossible. · TR. I had to pull through all three cruxes. The high temps and humidity certainly didn't play in my favor. I think I can get through each crux with some practice. The first and second crux seem easier than the third to me. · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Twice made it clean to the second crux, which I still haven't figured out (so, so hard!). Getting to the last bolt was kinda scary! I think I could maybe get it, but it's going to take A LOT of work. · TR. Fantastic. Spectacular movement! I honestly wish it hadn't been so fun, b/c now I feel like I have to come project this thing. Lots of falls, but figured out all but 1 move on TR. Sooo good. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had better conditions. DNF. Figured out first crux - go right, much easier. New high point at top of second crux, super cool movement, but blew tip and didn’t want to ruin skin more · Lead / Fell/Hung. Felt way out of my league. Had to pull though multiple cruxes. Clipping bolts was scary · TR. i got shut down. felt harder than stern, bcat cringe, and bat skins. · TR. Remember to get the left foot over as much as possible before bringing the right foot up below the bulge. Toe hook with left foot, sliding the hand up high is really key. Second crux is all about using the arete out far right, then a high foot left · 1st lead attempt on my 3rd sess. Great route! As 'my style' as them come. · Lead / Redpoint. With Keith. Wore spandex just for fun. Perfect granite route. Found beta for 5'8" height. · Lead / Onsight. So we did this ground up. Kind of a unique approach it would appear nowadays.

routes.route_description: This is a good alternative to approach the first anchor of the GM route if the bottom is wet. Varied climbing with an athletic finish. Start as for Heart of the Country on either side of the large detached flake (no pro). Sling the top of the flake and step right and up to 1/4" bolt. Runout 5.8 on small ledges to the base of the second detached flaked with rust-colored surface. Finally put in some good gear and shake out. Climb left side of flake with a couple of thin hand jams. Once at the top of flake, hand traverse 20ft right to the large ledge at the anchor for the GM route. Rating is height and lichen dependent.
routes.route_location: Right of the Hatch and Left of the mossy third class ramp.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack to thin hands and several long slings to reduce rope drag. Can place a 3.5-4" piece at the beginning of the first flake.

routes.route_description: This route is the middle of the three bolted routes on the left side of the country.  It is definitely a one move wonder with the crux coming around the 2nd or 3rd bolt.
routes.route_location: Just left of "Just say no to Frank Sinatra"
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: The route is a great first pitch for Kite Flying Blind. The belay at the end of the pitch is directly below KFB, and the climbing from the belay is fun bolt-protected face climbing that leads up directly into KFB. The first bolt is a little high up, particularly considering the elevated start. It is helpful to put a nut or cam in the crack before the first bolt. The crux is just after the... more The route is a great first pitch for Kite Flying Blind. The belay at the end of the pitch is directly below KFB, and the climbing from the belay is fun bolt-protected face climbing that leads up directly into KFB. The first bolt is a little high up, particularly considering the elevated start. It is helpful to put a nut or cam in the crack before the first bolt. The crux is just after the second bolt - the rest of the pitch is fun ~10a continuous face climbing. Sep 26, 2011

Broke a pretty large block off of the section between the last two bolts of the pitch yesterday (should see a fresh scar on a very useful foothold). Just make sure your belayer's aware in case more of it wants to come off. This is still a great route though! Oct 23, 2016

Could definitely get it clean now · Lead. One fall. Make sure to place right foot precisely at crux (helps to turn hips to right and to place LH closer to bolt. · Lead / Redpoint. Lowered and then went to the top. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux felt balancy and out of reach. Not super inspiring but also was very tired · Lead / Flash. Pinkpoint flash after Ethan worked out the beta for the crux move. Really fun pitch, first Index 5 11! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Really hard high step for me right after 2nd bolt. Figured it out a little on TR afterwards. · Lead / Fell/Hung. red cam for bottom. crux: left hand crimp pocket near bolt, right hand large knob, hight R foot and then r hand to overhang and press hard. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Crux: right foot, left foot, high right foot (just under right hand · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fun short beta. Deeeeeeeep back flag after spanning the flake. Then really trusting the slippery dike stepping into the under gaston. Low percentage but sendable. · Lead / Fell/Hung. As fun as I remembered, better to save the numb climbing for cool days. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1st pitch only, and soo close to the flash. One cruxy move; rest of route was straightforward. Used aid for the crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at second bolt. Knob where left foot rests popped off, delicate shift to high right foot. · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell once right before crux, should try again for clean ascent · Lead / Redpoint. An awesome project. routes.route_description: From the chains of Spooner, keep going.  The lower bolts protect the crux moves.  Higher up the grade mellows and gear is needed.  It’s really good and it’s a little harder than Spooner.  That’s about all you need to know.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: A few pieces up to 1”.

route_comments.comment_text: “A little harder than Spooner” That’s why it’s 11c. So anyways, the crux off of spooner anchors is really tough, probably pushes the route in the 5.12 hard range. Awkward crux, fun climbing above for sure. Nov 5, 2022

routes.route_description: A fun route with great rock and varied climbing.Right of the tunnel is a large flake. To the right of this flake notice the ledge going across to the right, about 20-feet up. (The ledge become a large ramp on the right-most side where it intersects the hillside.) The first pitch starts at the two-bolt anchor about 1/3 of the way across this ledge.To reach the start, you have a few choices. The easiest is to hike up the trail to the left of the ledge and then walk out the ledge. Some parties may not want a rope to get to the bolted anchor, but if the ledge is wet, it might be nice to have a short belay.P1: (5.8+) Climb up the corner past a bolt to a long ledge. Traverse to the left end of the ledge, where you will find a bolted belay by the tree. Uses face and layback moves plus the occasional jam. Protects well with nuts and cams.P2: (5.9) Continue directly up the corner and then up an easier flake section. This pitch can take big gear to protect the easier section, but cams to 3" would be fine for those comfortable at the grade. The moves between the corner and the crack/flake above can be hard.P3: (5.9)Head left and then up a crack to bolts at the top.A fun variation is to follow the crack up and right from the belay (Heart of the Country, 10b).Descent: Rap the route. You can reach the ground from the top of the second pitch with 2 60-m ropes.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Standard trad rack to 4 or 5" be sure to bring at least 2 big pieces (e.g. #4 and #5 camalots) for the second pitch. All belays/rap stations are bolted. Make sure to have runners for the first pitch to help reduce rope drag.Multiple #3's (nice if one is a 3.5) for the original P3.

route_comments.comment_text: There is a great varition from the top of the 5.10b pitch on heart of the country that continues for about 40 more feet.  The Cramer guide calls it 11a, but its not any harder than 5.10 with great gear. Mar 13, 2006
i agree with jesse, the final pitch on hoc is 10.  the last 3 pitches are short and link up easily with a 60 making it a great full-value pitch. Aug 12, 2006
i'll second the full value. and i'll have seconds please. John thanks for showing us the route, say hey to Michelle :) Sep 3, 2006

routes.route_description: From the top of the first pitch of zoom step right and follow bolts to the top of the wall, 12 or 13 clips.  The crux is a single face move but there are also three unique mantels along the way.  A 60 may or may not get you down, a 70 definitely will.
routes.route_location: above and right of zoom.
routes.route_protection: bolts

route_comments.comment_text: 60m WILL NOT get you down. Oct 19, 2008

If you can climb ZOOM, which you have if you are at the base of "Hairway", you should continue up "Hairway".  12 bolts and 34 meters of manteling fun. There is one move that if you are under 5'10", you might as well clip the bolt and pull the draw onto the rail.  I'm 5'10" and I can just barely reach the rail.  It doesn't change the difficulty other than one A0 move. I'd give it 2.75... more If you can climb ZOOM, which you have if you are at the base of "Hairway", you should continue up "Hairway".  12 bolts and 34 meters of manteling fun. There is one move that if you are under 5'10", you might as well clip the bolt and pull the draw onto the rail.  I'm 5'10" and I can just barely reach the rail.  It doesn't change the difficulty other than one A0 move. I'd give it 2.75 stars.  It would get more but the first 30 feet tend to be dirty.  Not so dirty that you shouldn't climb it. Jul 13, 2013
Just have to jump if you're under 5'10", and there is a good stance for it.  But if you're under 4'10", you'll need a 2' vertical.  Good times. Jul 11, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Rope solo. In the dark. Choking on a swarm of gnats. Questy. Foot slipped on some crunchies on the last hard-ish slab move on the last bolt. · Follow. Followed Cooper and got it clean. Was a little dirty but clean where it counts. I could lead it. Rests between several cruxes to mantle. The mantles are not the cruxes but feel hard after making the hard tech moves after the bolts. Protection is good. Footwork is key of course. · TR. Lead the first third then got spooked and switched off, very doable on top rope, would be great to come back and get it clean · Lead. Quite a bit harder than leave my face alone just to the left. No chalk on route and quite dirty. Hung on a draw while doing a slab move left · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got suckered too far right at last crux (stay left and use right hand on the arete instead of going left). Great route other than the very dirty start. · Lead / Onsight. Mantle after balancy mantle, this climb is pretty sweet! I even had to full on dyno at one point.

routes.route_description: A fun three pitch line, unfortunately it seems that only the 3rd pitch gets climbed frequently.The first pitch starts right of the cunning stunt area, it goes up a large block and climbs to the golden flake(obvious).  Climb the left side of this until you can traverse right to the gm belay. (5.10)The second pitch climbs a crack to the left of the dihedral, that is the 2nd pitch of gm.  Climb the crack to a stance at the base of the arete.  From here you traverse right to the gm belay via two options.  Shorter folks will want to traverse low protecting this crux traverse with a solid black alien/grey tcu.  Taller folks may want to climb up the arete to a fix pin before traversing right.  Doing the higher traverse maybe wingspan dependent.(5.11-)The third pitch tackles the classic heart of the country splitter hand crack, reaches a ledge and boulders up another short classic hand/thin hand crack. (5.10)You can bypass any of the pitches by climbing the gm route since both routes share belays.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: standard rack, black alien/grey tcu

route_comments.comment_text: If you follow the guide books way of doing this route the first pitch is "10a-10d reach" PG...I tried it this weekend, it's hard for the grade and well covered in moss and lychen(only the crux, the rest is clean)...though a little bit less dirty now.  The crux is really reachy, I'm almost 5'11" and was completely tipped out at the crux.  At the very start, do the right side of the first... more If you follow the guide books way of doing this route the first pitch is "10a-10d reach" PG...I tried it this weekend, it's hard for the grade and well covered in moss and lychen(only the crux, the rest is clean)...though a little bit less dirty now.  The crux is really reachy, I'm almost 5'11" and was completely tipped out at the crux.  At the very start, do the right side of the first pillar, it's a 5.8/9 chimney that's pretty fun. May 27, 2008
Climbing the combo route of GM and HOTC is very nice. Last "pitch" is definetly not .11a though. Maybe .10a. May 11, 2009

i have been on this route a couple of times and have to say that a medium small nut(#3 WC rock is a perfect fit) works much better that any cam could in the seam/pod at the crux of the second pitch. it flares open inside so to get good camming action you have to pull the cam near to the edge of the crack causing the solid stem just before the axle(alien) to rest over the edge of the crack,... more i have been on this route a couple of times and have to say that a medium small nut(#3 WC rock is a perfect fit) works much better that any cam could in the seam/pod at the crux of the second pitch. it flares open inside so to get good camming action you have to pull the cam near to the edge of the crack causing the solid stem just before the axle(alien) to rest over the edge of the crack, back farther is no good as the cam is fully open. take some smaller nuts, fish them in on the right hand side of the pod and set them to the left, now you have bomber pro for the crux!  this is a good pitch that deserves more traffic edit, this is for the low traverse on pitch 2 Aug 3, 2009

Seems like that entire full third pitch coming from GM is more like solid 10c. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Did the 10a start of P3 after GM. Delightful. · 1 pitch. Lead. Led P3 after the first two pitches of the GM route. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Linked pitch one and two together. Onsight pitch one. Fell on knob low traverse pitch two sad. Flew into tree · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Climbed third pitch after doing p1 and p2 of Gm route. Might be my favorite pitch at Index! · 1 pitch. Followed Darwin on the final pitch of this after two pitches gm route · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very cool. Led all P. One silly but big (30’! Slab) fall on P1, but 4s crack is sick. Thought for sure I was off on P2 but held it together, did some insaneee sequence (back step+rose move!) on the final traverse. P3 is soooo classic, 2 amazing splitters. Great day out! · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. Pitch 3 after doing first 2 of GM. Did the full pitch 3, last time I stopped at the first anchor because I was out of gear. · 1 pitch. Follow. Followed Andrew up p3. Super fun, clean follow, but at this stage couldn’t fathom placing the gear · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Linked GM route into the third pitch of this, and it was a very good pitch. Well-protected and fun climbing all the way through. Second pitch looked fun too · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Led P3 after the first two pitches of the GM route. · TR. lowered off the anchors to give the top pitch a shot. took once, it is sustained! · 1 pitch. Follow. just p3. fantastic splitter although it was quite clammy with the temp and humidity. Solid 5.10 seems about right for that pitch. maybe 10+ · 1 pitch. Follow. Lead / Redpoint. With Vivienne, Star, and Zack. P3 only, linked with GM P2, to the lower anchor. · 1 pitch. Follow. Just the last 10b pitch as a finish to gm route. Didn’t love it, but see why people do. Too much jamming lol. Fell 3 maybe 2 times · Lead / Redpoint. Just pitch 3. Took at upper bulge. Want (3)2” cams for this pitch. So good. · Lead / Fell/Hung. P1 Big whip. Not sure I went the right way. Try again on a cooler day. Lots of ants and spiders. P2 cramping so downclimbed. Ran out of gear to do second crack on P3. Fun day but not quite what I was expecting! · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. linked 2nd pitch of GM Route into 3rd pitch of HoTC, no need for #4 or #5 · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. Only Pitch 3 as GM HOTC linkup. Everything you hope it is. · Lead / Onsight. Very cool line - more folks need to climb. P2 traverse was challenging - had to pull gear to get on ledge - awkward AF!! Haha · 1 pitch. TR. Tr last 10b pitch only. felt it was relatively easy on its own on TR compared to OW 3rd pitch of GM. · 1 pitch. Lead / Onsight. did the last pitch from gm route and it was the most splitter! awesome pitch · 2 pitches. Follow. P3 only with Kyle’s lead. Seemed like it should’ve been easier. Still figuring out fingers and leaning cracks. Had to split it for #2’s. 2nd part was ok · Lead / Onsight. First two pitches GM route then last (2) pitches of heart of the country · Lead / Fell/Hung. led p1&3 onsight with Will H. Fell on the 11b Crux traverse. higher looked easier to me... · TR. TR Solo. Don't recommend this route for TR soloing, Kept getting pulled off traverse. · Started on GM. Pitch three and four are tough but manageable. Third starts finger thing to thin hands. Try to save a two of you want to link three and four. Four is hand wide to thin. Super short. · Lead. Great route! Started on GM route (first two pitches). routes.route_description: This route is a laughable sandbag.  I would call it 5.11c, R, A0.  The very first move is the crux and has a bolt clippable at head height...it involves a one armed leap off okay feet and an okay crimp, HUGE move. For getting a PG-13 rating in one book and R in the online guide, it probably isn't too bad on lead, huge jugs to clip from, crux's are very well protected.

routes.route_protection: Quick draws

routes.route_fa: Mike Massey and Jon Peake, September 10, 2017
routes.route_description: The route starts as per Big Science. Move up jugs to an undercling to clip the first bolt, then the route trends up and right past 5 bolts to a chain anchor. All the bolts are painted brown.

routes.route_name: Just say no to Frank Sinatra
routes.route_description: This fun climb has been retro-bolted and is now a easily protected trad climb.  A boulder problem at the third bolt leads to easy crack climbing and a chain anchor.  Some of the bolts may be hard to clip for shorter people.  Soft for 11d.
routes.route_location: Located almost at the left end of the country, just left of the Mourning star chimney.
routes.route_protection: Bolts at the start, gear on the much easier finish.

route_comments.comment_text: If you're 6'3", you might find this climb more like 11a.  The crux is for sure harder the shorter you get. Sep 12, 2012
At 5', I didn't have the requisite reach to make the "move".  Great looking route.  Was almost able to climb the crux by using some small knobs. Aug 7, 2015

Underappreciated pitch. Disregard the guidebook description entirely. It's out of line with most Index 11d's, certainly better than one star, and there are no "dubious nuts" that might rip out on you. Stupidly positive holds and mostly juggy fun start to finish. A hand-size cam makes the crux undercling clip a little less dicey. That said, it is certainly reachy with no intermediate holds... more Underappreciated pitch. Disregard the guidebook description entirely. It's out of line with most Index 11d's, certainly better than one star, and there are no "dubious nuts" that might rip out on you. Stupidly positive holds and mostly juggy fun start to finish. A hand-size cam makes the crux undercling clip a little less dicey. That said, it is certainly reachy with no intermediate holds to supplement. I'm 5'11" with the same wingspan and 11b seems fair. Feel free to toss on a letter grade for every couple inches shorter you are! Jun 13, 2019

routes.route_name: Kaboom aka Jesus take the wheel
routes.route_description: Pitch starts at the indextasy anchor and goes up and right, following the flakes. You can rappel to the ground with a 70 m rope

route_comments.comment_text: You’ll have to climb it to find out where the crux is! Nov 19, 2018

A really fun climb.  The traverse into Kaboom is really entertaining on it's own... easier than it looks with great footholds appearing when needed.  The rock is typical "Country" and the loose and dirty will disappear with a few storms and a few dozen ascents.  The last few moves make the grade. Nov 20, 2018
Thanks for the great new pitches guys! Mar 15, 2019

routes.route_fa: P1: Greg Child, Greg Collum, P2: Greg Collum, Kurt Schmierer
routes.route_description: Yet another Index classic, first pitch follows various features to a slab section(11a), then jugs to the top...excellent climbing. The second pitch goes straight up from the anchors, through a roof/layback (11c) to huge jugs and a fun technical finish. Soft for the grade.

route_comments.comment_text: Both pitches feel 11b to me.. Aug 17, 2009
I also thought the first pitch was stiff for 11a. Mar 21, 2012

What a Fantastic climb!  I think the 5.11c grade is closer to spot-on than way-off.  Easier than Japanese Gardens but harder than Even Steven or Phone Calls from the Dead. The climb is perfectly fine as a clip-up sport climb.  However, one could supplement or even skip the bolts in the final corner with a handful of small cams.  Either way is fine as long as you climb. If you want to... more What a Fantastic climb!  I think the 5.11c grade is closer to spot-on than way-off.  Easier than Japanese Gardens but harder than Even Steven or Phone Calls from the Dead. The climb is perfectly fine as a clip-up sport climb.  However, one could supplement or even skip the bolts in the final corner with a handful of small cams.  Either way is fine as long as you climb. If you want to project P2 via TR, you can skip the crux by entering in from the "Leave my Face Alone" slab into the final "Kite" corner.  A Super-TR can even be made from the ground with two 70m ropes. Aug 17, 2013

routes.route_description: From the chains of Fifth Force, keep going.  Kind-of-boring, not-so-amazing climbing ends with a showstopper, heelhook-dyno before the anchor.  It makes up for everything you just endured.  So good.  Best rock climbing move in the Country.

routes.route_description: This the bolt line that leads up and left from the Zoom anchors. After the lower section, pull a roof (5.10) onto a slab (huge hand- and foot-holds that gradually get smaller), crux is the very last move.  Fun moves.
routes.route_location: This is the bolt line that leads left off the top of Zoom.
routes.route_protection: All bolts, 14 including anchors? Give or take a few.

route_comments.comment_text: This enjoyable line has received a recent scrubbing (thanks Doug T!) and is ready to go on your ticklist. The start is juggy fun, followed by a committing roof pull which delivers you onto the steep, uniquely featured face with moves that build in difficulty to an attention-getting finish. Jul 24, 2013
This would be a 4 star route if not for the first half of the pitch (alpine scruff). The Headwall slab is stellar. It has 1 tough clip where it is a little run-out, and a tricky finish. May 18, 2015

For the record, this route is longer than 90 feet and a 60m doesn't quite reach. It MIGHT reach with rope stretch, but I didn't test that theory so can't vouch for it. Best just to bring a 70. Jun 17, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Very smooth face climbing. One tech traits reach through left hand to get on the face then a spicy but tech manageable finish move to huge hold. Get set w good feet and step out right to dish then reach far right to side bar, step tech smear and pop to top jug. Can do in one pitch with zoom if feeling good. Not pumpy at all. · TR. very cool, felt a lot like Moondance. very technical and thin - dunno if I'd lead with such spaced bolts. the top 5 meters were the hardest for me. · Lead / Onsight. great pitch! really wish I had stiffer shoes but got through it. · TR. hehehehe real fun, some distance between the bolts but if you consider that it's more or less featured slab it's overbolted · Follow. Last move is the crux, stepping through on ok smears to get to the arete out right. · TR. that top crux at the last bolt is amazing, using the combo of the 5mil edge plus the sloppy pinch makes for an exciting finish. · Lead / Onsight. Linked w/ Zoom. Chonky start, but the upper crimpy face is a blast! · Lead / Onsight. Accidentally hopped on this w Corey thinking it was the 5.9. Don’t regret it! Crazy square cut calcite(?) after the round knobs of Zoom. Great face climbing · Lead / Onsight. Maybe just a little harder than Zoom, but definitely the easiest 11 I've been on at Index. Doesn't change the fact that it's an excellent line on the most uniquely featured rock at Index. · Lead / Onsight. Excellent climb. Featured like the Reiter Foothills tetris boulder. Bolts are spicily spaced. · TR. not clean, did get it though. well protected, fun roof and amazing quartz slab · TR. TR’d the upper slab. Sharp on the fingers but quite good! Need to figure out the last left foot on the crux to climb it clean. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Dam that last move got me! not sure of the best path but ended up laying back the left hand rail! · TR. routes.route_fa: Tavish Hansen & Chris Owen, Spring 2018 (flake pitch)
routes.route_description: Index's only multipitch 5.8 that doesn't involve climbing the buttlips chimney!Pitch 1: ClimbMourning Star(5.8) and continue 20 feet up right to the anchor of Zoom.Pitch 2: Start up Leave My Face Alone, following fun blocky terrain on bolts.  Supplemental gear is available in places.  Move right under the small roof to a triangular belay ledge, which is often mostly taken up by a sizeable puddle. (5.7, 70', ~7 bolts)Pitch 3, The Flake: Tricky and reachy right off the belay.  You may want to just climb on your belayer to reach better holds.  Follow the nice flake system to the top. (5.7, 50')3 raps to get down with a 60 or 2 raps with a 70.  Toprope the slab of Leave My Face Alone while you're up there!Originally climbed many years ago as a second pitch variation to Zoom, these two pitches on top of Mourning Star make a fine addition to Index's limited selection of relatively beginner friendly multipitches.  Climbed but never actually cleaned, the third flake pitch is labeled 5.9 in Sky Valley Rock.  Significant excavation there in the spring of 2018 yielded fun and wholely new climbing.  We decided the ledge below the flake was a natural stopping point, allowing for one fully bolted pitch and descent with a 60 meter rope, and more digging and the addition of anchors in spring of 2019 completed our vision of the route.  Though not a classic, this is a worthy route for the budding Index climber.  Enjoy!
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 7 or 8 draws, single rack to 4"

route_comments.comment_text: Nice work, Tavish. Not many three-pitch 5.8s around Index. There could be lots more, but most would likely involve a lot of cleaning work. You should add your name to the FA box above. Jun 30, 2019
Besides the dirt covered ledge this one was relatively ripe for the picking compared to some of the other recent cleaning work Jun 30, 2019
Fantastic Name.  Definitely a gem everyone missed.  Plus it's an easy way to TR Leave my Face Alone. Jul 1, 2019

routes.route_fa: Jim Purdy, Greg Olsen, Max Dufford
routes.route_description: Crux comes down low, in gaining the bolt above the chain draw. The route continues for another 15 meters to a set of mussys with the climbing clocking in somewhere in the low 5.11 range. This puts you right below the unrepeated 5.13 section. Stopping at the ledge out right is also 11d and accesses Scientific Americans (12a). From this anchor one can set a top rope on Big Science or move over to work Indextasy.
routes.route_location: Just left of the tunnel this line goes up knobs and levitation moves.  Go straight up from the obvious dihedral.
routes.route_protection: Rack of quickdraws.

route_comments.comment_text: The upper section needs some cleaning and probably some hangers...looks awesome though. Mar 7, 2011
Anybody know what conditions the bolts and anchor are in on the upper section of this pitch? Jan 4, 2016
It is all clean to continue past the big science ledge. That said, above the "5.12" chains it's dirty and still devoid of hangers. Apr 2, 2019
