Sent to the second anchor in a session after having tried it once last year. · TR. hard start, cryptic moves on knobs, more thoughtful leg press moves on knobs. feet hurt./ With Anthony · TR. Not really a tick lol. Struggled and huffed and got assisted to below the mantle crux. Didn't get above it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Worked on the 12a variation instead of bushwhacking to the 11d anchor. 12a is much nicer. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Go right at hook, up is a lie. If this is index 11d I feel pretty good about rehab · Lead / Fell/Hung. Lots of work. First three bolts dialed. Crux is weird friction and the knobs after it are not my style. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couldn't figure out crux at perma. First crux is savage laybacking/palm pressing. · Lead. Back to the perma draw to work that funk part. No real progress · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Sent second try today. Fairly hot and sweaty but good enough to get it done despite messing up the crux beta. To middle chains · TR. More fun for the shorties. Hand foot match to press to dyno!!! Way to end off the day. Turns out the crew doesn’t normally just put up a bunch of 11s. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bailed off the perma draw. Really cool slab problem there that I wanna try when it’s in the shade · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. One hang! Lh lf rh rf, rock over (squeeze), up into undercling, clip. Lh crimp, lf stem, rh press, rf knob, rh cross to crimp, lf to big knob, crank up, stay low, go right to side pull, lf to closer higher knob, press up, clip. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Climbed to the crux, above the chained draw. It was really difficult, ended up lowering off the draw. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Beta for opening sequence was a Dyno to the jug. Mantle at the Permadraw feels impossible when hot and muggy. · TR. Rh arete, lh up to knob, lf knob, rf on right knob, rh cross to left knob, lf onto ramp, stay low and slide over to lh crimp/pinch, reset feet and stand tall to lh crimp, stem lf to clip. It’s on >:) · Lead / Fell/Hung. Shut down at mantle. Oof. Opening stem feels p good tho. · Lead / Redpoint. Second session, third go total. First go of the day. First session was like 8 months prior. · TR. Fell a few times. Super hot day. Come back when it’s cold. Really sweet climb - like a bigger, badder Wham! · Lead / Fell/Hung. W Jamie. Fun start (juggy R & arete L, walk feet up highest r, stem to fall into L sp). Hard past slopey ramp - crank on R bad seam to ok knob move right to get two knobs off R toe hook (R around corner, L further knob, R better closer). “Levitation” - up & right up knobs to overhead gastundercling in roof to juggy sp? · TR. Fun and hard. At permadraw, right hand on positive side pull around corner. Cross lf over rf, lh crimp rail. Foot and hand moves somewhere, end up with lf on knob, rf on knob, rh to right knob, rf up on blob, lf to far left fat knob, · Found the 12 extension to be much easier than bottom crux honestly easiest part of the route. Just go for those middle anchors. · Lead / Fell/Hung. My partner led to the third bolt, lowered off, then I led the rest. I ended up stick clipping the 4th bolt to try the heel rock move. This route is hard, but I'd feel comfortable leading it with the second bolt stick clipped. · TR. Pretty sure this is 12c/d. Damn difficult, and I love slab and techy/crimpy/balancy climbing. Super dirty the whole way up, it could use a good scrub!

routes.route_description: A neglected route just left of Zoom, safer now thanks to rebolting. Give it a scrub, climb it, and let the rest of us know more about it.
routes.route_location: Immediately left of Zoom
routes.route_protection: Small cams, RPs, and draws

routes.route_fa: Fred Grafton (FA), Fred Grafton, Lou Jam (FFA, 1991)
routes.route_description: Scramble up some easy ledges to a flake and clip the bolt (on Longlife?) if you want.  Head right up a finger crack that morphs into a chimney.  A little dirty but fun!
routes.route_location: Right of Just Say No to Frank Sinatra, left of Zoom.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 2".

route_comments.comment_text: Long neglected, this climb has recently become a much enjoyed climb for the grade and common warm-up for the next level of difficulty of climbs in The Country. It makes for good practice for the chimney on Saggitarius. Gear to 1.5" Mourning Star is also a quick approach to the first anchor of Zoom, making it easy access to  Hairway to Stephen and Leave My Face Alone, or a Zoom or Wham TR. more Long neglected, this climb has recently become a much enjoyed climb for the grade and common warm-up for the next level of difficulty of climbs in The Country. It makes for good practice for the chimney on Saggitarius. Gear to 1.5" Mourning Star is also a quick approach to the first anchor of Zoom, making it easy access to  Hairway to Stephen and Leave My Face Alone, or a Zoom or Wham TR. Jul 15, 2013
Fun route! Chimney is pretty tight even for a small person. Used mostly small gear, up to #2. Route is fairly clean today. Jul 17, 2016

i cleaned up a second pitch for this route. it continues over to Zoom anchors then continues up Leave my Face Alone to the roof. The climb right and up crack to Leave anchor. i would rate it 5.8 it makes for a nice two pitch climb. Jan 31, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Happy with how easy the squeeze felt. Remember really struggling with it way back when · Lead / Onsight. first time sharing a rope with spencer! followed him up the next two pitches · Lead / Onsight. sick off width climbing at the end. almost whipped on the beginning flake! · Lead / Onsight. Middle bit is scarier than expected. Okayish pro with flaring crack that isn’t super jam-able with almost bad feet on the steepish ramp. · Follow. traverse and chimney were fun. the middle section had some insecure hands and slopey feet. · Lead / Onsight. Kinda dirty but not too bad. Didn’t really super enjoy it, but the chimney was actually kind of fun. · Lead / Fell/Hung. took a big whipper out of nowhere on this one! feet were challenging in the middle ramp section. tons of gear! · Lead. With Fede. I psych myself up about the 0.4 section and then always hate it. · 2 pitches. Follow. second climb of the day with Tom, Sunday 9 2023. second pitch was absolutely amazing. 10/10 climbing. · Lead / Onsight. Easy ramp to silly chimney- can move rope to zoom chains · Follow. Didn’t get it on the first go, middle section on the slab was weird. · Lead / Flash. Brian bailed off this so I lead it. the moves are 5.8 but it's a solid lead. for the crux section you have good left hand/foot jams and have to make one or two right foot smears to move up. it protects and the rock quality is mostly ok aside from one of the easy flakes before the chimney, though you have to be thoughtful about placements so you don't block the key jams. the chimney is a tight squeeze. · Lead / Flash. as part of Leave My Flake Alone, w/ Darren. A little spicey getting off the ledge into the flake. · Lead / Flash. Fun! But not as chill as I expected for 5.8, since it’s index I guess haha. Couple tricky moves in the finger crack, but the chimney is fun and there’s some good feet · Lead / Flash. Fun! Finger crack was a bit intimidating, but takes as much gear as you can place and ends at a good resting stance. Chimney isn’t too bad, is short and has perfect hand crack in back and good edges for feet/hands. #3 was nice to have to protect entry into chimney but not necessary. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Much more intense directly after the bolt than I was expecting, need advice on gear placements to feel confident pulling up and into the crack system with marginal feet options. Still psyched I fought to the end and only really needed 2 rests in the same position to sort out gear · Follow. felt pretty ok. a couple hard hand moves. pretty gassed by this point, left hand did a weird spasm thing. can climb the top offwidth different ways. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Made myself take a few falls on gear. First falls on gear for me in a few years, I believe. · TR. Jeff lead Trad route and I did top rope. Do again on trad lead. V fun. · Follow. nice route with a little bit of everything. Felt a little easier than the other 5.8 routes at Index. Takes good gear all the way and ends with a narrow chimney.

routes.route_description: This line has approximately twice the bolt spacing of the adjacent Butters Ate My Sandwich, and you need to get into the second step of your ladders. The bottom has an anchor so you can practice hauling and rope management. A free move of 5.2 near the top allows you to clip the anchor. A nice place to set up a ledge.The angling crack/roof to the left was also aided on lead into the bolt ladder. Thin cams and beaks, one hook move off the ground.The route already had an anchor in place at the top, and the route was bolted in the line of the most features for a free ascent.
routes.route_location: Two lines left of Steel Monkey.
routes.route_protection: Bolts to bolt anchor

route_comments.comment_text: Did this today, 2 laps, EXTREMELY reachy for a 5'6" person. I did not use any rock protection, only aggressive and somewhat harrowing top-stepping. To reach the second bolt, I had to top step in both aiders and clip an alpine draw to use as a cheater sling. For most of the other bolts, I was using the first or second step in one aider and sometimes a foot or hand on rock features. Good... more Did this today, 2 laps, EXTREMELY reachy for a 5'6" person. I did not use any rock protection, only aggressive and somewhat harrowing top-stepping. To reach the second bolt, I had to top step in both aiders and clip an alpine draw to use as a cheater sling. For most of the other bolts, I was using the first or second step in one aider and sometimes a foot or hand on rock features. Good practice for this technique, definitely more challenging than other bolt ladders I've encountered. Oct 15, 2023
Climbed yesterday.  Fun and reachy!  Most were 2nd step clips.  Loose block just below the anchor chains.  don't pull on or place gear behind or you might yank it off! Jan 9, 2025

routes.route_description: Thin, steep laybacking, protected by nuts.
routes.route_location: The obvious flake about 30' right of Crowbar.
routes.route_protection: Thin nuts to small cams.

routes.route_description: Fun face climbing capped by a very difficult mantle.This route is immediately right of the second pitch of GM.  From the anchors, walk right several feet on a ledge to a wide crack.  Climbing this leads to an undercling.  Heading rightward leads to the real business, face climbing on chickenheads, jutting intrusive stones, and tiny edges.  Climb mostly straight up until you reach a sloping, narrow ledge, then hand-traverse right to the anchors.The final mantle to the chains is rumored to be impossible for humans.
routes.route_location: To the right of GM's second pitch.
routes.route_protection: A couple of pieces of trad gear would protect the very bottom moves, after that pro is 3 bolts.Can be easily toproped after climbing GM.

route_comments.comment_text: If your leading this take along some small stoppers or maybe small cams to protect the mantel.  I had a harder time gaining the rail then pulling the mantel. Jul 1, 2008

I TRed this route today after climbing HOTC, and thought it was pretty difficult in the grade.  I made two separate attempts at the mantel and finally pulled it off, but was left standing to the left of the anchor, face against the rock.  Great route, though, with sustained knob climbing all the way to the sloping ledge below the anchor. Jul 29, 2008
I have observed that this route is now protected by shiny new bolts, placed right next to the partially-removed old mank. Jun 29, 2009

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Was able to piece together most of the moves on TR, didn't try final crux because our anchor setup was wonky (this route's anchor is in a bad spot for TR, should have belayed from Heart of the Country's anchor instead). Good practice, still feels far away. · TR. Super fun. Figure 2 on mantle and need to sus gear for last move · Lead / Redpoint. Sent second go. #6 DMM brassie and blue totem protect the mantle well, but still glad I never fell trying to do that mantle! · Lead / Fell/Hung. goodness this is a spooky climb. the first part pulling the lip with that heal hoke then a dead point to the rail followed by the mantle.

routes.route_name: Phone Calls Full (Long Distance Phone Calls from the Dead)
routes.route_description: Climb Phone Calls from the Dead, clip and pull the bolt above the anchor and when you can grab a hold, get back to free climbing.  Climb into the stem box (crux) with powerful stemming and crimping.  This is followed by  less technical but off balance climbing in a shallow corner.  Finish at the Heart of the Country anchor.This can be easily TR'd from the HOTC anchor.
routes.route_location: Extension of Phone Calls from the Dead.
routes.route_protection: 3 bolts, small wires and small cams to fingers to supplement bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: I'm claiming the FA, but it's possible that it's been led before.  If someone knows otherwise, let me know so I can give credit where it's due.  It's been TR'd many times I'm sure. I think the crux may be height dependent.  Also, the A0 is an open project.  It was clearly beyond my abilities while the climbing past the A0 was barely within. Get on it and post your thoughts. Oct 3, 2014

Alright Doug, great job! I'll give it a try next time I'm over there. I don't know of anyone who had led that, and the first time I even heard of a TR of the upper part was upon reading Ryan's comment on the regular Phone Calls page. Oct 4, 2014

I'll take credit for perpetuating the name of this often looked at project. In the early 90s I looked very hard at this project and did some cleaning but never placed any bolts and felt it was over my head. The suggested name was Long Distance Phone Calls From the Dead. Nice job! Oct 11, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. DNF. Just scoped if I could free it… not now at least - blank!

routes.route_fa: J Tetzlaff, D Gamache 7-9-13 FFA G. Shank 7-12-13
routes.route_description: This is a nice variation to the finish of the first pitch of HOTC.  It adds 20+ ft. of climbing to an already excellent climb.After clipping the 3rd bolt, continue up to the crack, follow the crack until it peters out. Move up easy ground to GM anchors.  The "crux" is where the crack thins down and is easier if you are under 5'6''.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Slings and gear to 1''

route_comments.comment_text: The short section of bad rock that could hurt you and moss and lichen that might mess up your feet are GONE.  HOTC and Right Ventricle Variation are ready for you to CLIMB.  Get on it! FA: John Tetzlaff and Danielle Gamache FFA: Gabe Shank Jul 15, 2013
Classic fun, thanks for the work guys Jul 27, 2013
Lots of fun even if the lichen has grown back a bit. Will clean up well with a quick scrubbing. Nov 13, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Did this post whipper and aided the last bit because I was hot and worked

routes.route_description: This climb weaves a path up the wall to the right of Total Seawash Calypso. I believe the current interpretation is a combination of the beginning of Savage Gardens and the end of Willing Slave (see below), but I'm not sure. The climbing is exciting and has short cruxes between stances throughout. The climb falls under the 'slab climbing with features' category and has some classic Index moves!
routes.route_location: Head out the ledge past Total Seawash Calypso to a bolted belay anchor. The ledge thins considerably, so use care! This route is one of a pair (Savage Gardens and Willing Slave) that start on either side of the lower belay anchor, converge midway for a couple of bolts, then diverge again and end at different anchors. The current climbable (recently cleaned?) line heads right at the beginning, then finishes at the left anchor up top.
routes.route_protection: Bolts, at times well-spaced. In particular, be careful with the third clip. The climbing is somewhat bold and there are places throughout the climb where falling could have consequences, especially at the beginning. Anchors at top left have new chain and bolts are good throughout.

routes.route_description: A.K.A. Little Science. This is the direct start to Big Science. Awesome.
routes.route_location: Start on the Little Jupiter ledge following the bolts to the right and head into Big Science.
routes.route_protection: A few finger size pieces, draws and a couple slings for the top.

route_comments.comment_text: Are 2 of the bolts new with an existing bolt (previously w/o hanger) down low? Aug 25, 2022
Thanks Ryan, I've always stared at the old stud and wondered about this! Aug 26, 2022

... in Clint's topo posted here on MP this variation is specifically shown and given a name, in another topo (again posted on MP) this route is again shown and not shown name.   Both topos were in published guides as well. The 12b rating must be for the entire route, the lower section is significantly easier - at least in my memory. Aug 26, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Not at all dialed but conditions were stellar and I had the fight in me. · 2 pitches. TR. 1 hung it the second time. First time numbed out. Crux - use crack on R to stand up to good knob and clip, RF mini knob, LF mini knob, RF big foot, LF backstep ramp, LH to knob, RH to sloper gaston (higher part), LF to knob just under arête and bump LH to good knob, walk feet up and fall RH into arête and then stand up LH to good undercling. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Was no longer warm so I numbed out. Definitely grabbed some draws and even a bolt, but lowered back a bit to do all the moves. .4 and .3 are bomber. Also placed a nut out left prior to cams but seemed unnecessary in retrospect. Very tenuous climbing and certainly needs good conditions at my current level. Benefited from a good brushing · TR. 2 hang. Once at bolt before crux because fingers numbed out. Once at final bolt because I was sweating too much and sliding off. Makes a huge difference to not have numb toes lol · TR. Spent hella time trying to figure out the top knob crux. Super cool climb and hope to send at some point.

routes.route_description: Another rad pitch that sees almost no traffic. It was given .12a in the original Clint Cumins guide, which I think it definitely earns in relation to other lowertownwall classics. Begin on tenuous knob climbing via Little Jupiter (short version) or Big Science - Both of which end on a ledge 50' up. These are rated .11d or .12b respectively to the 50' ledge/anchors. From the ledge, clip a bolt and climb up and right into a fun and juggy flake (.10) which takes great finger-sized gear. After the flake ends, a few bolts lead past a very tenuous crux crimping on perfect stone, with a few hero jugs over the roof to the chains.This pitch used to have a huge railroad spike bashed into a pocket up high (a drilled angle piton on steroids) and girth hitched for pro- this has been removed and replaced with a normal bolt. I wonder if the FA team ran out of bolts (or just wanted to save $) and simply walked over to the tracks and robbed the railroad for the final fixed piece.There is an extension which feature an immediate crux (chipped right hand pocket) rated .12b or .12c in the various books, and which then passes a couple more bolts and a remaining railroad spike "piton" before anchors up and right. The full version to there would be a 45-50m pitch and is almost certainly very dirty.
routes.route_location: Begin in the small corner just left of the door to nowhere (or begin in the flake just right of the door). The independent section of this pitch starts from a ledge 50' off the ground.
routes.route_protection: 10-12 QDS, and 3-4 cams from .4-.75BD

route_comments.comment_text: The crux section on this pitch is fantastic.  Excellent moves between crisp crimps see you through the blankest section.  Quite worthwhile. May 30, 2015

Worthwhile pitch! Led it from the ledge, however I think next time I'll go full value from the ground through Big Science. It could use a little more traffic but is quite climbable in its current state. The crimp rail section seems atypical for Index. I think an OS of this hanging draws would be pretty tough. Mar 12, 2019

Really fun, I climbed in from a top rope on little jupiter. I'd recommend bringing an additional cam, .3 BD or equivalent. I placed every cam I had (.3-.75 BD) before the bolts began. A little scruffy but well worth cleaning up! Get ready to crimp! Dec 8, 2020

routes.route_description: This route is reached best by traversing across the ledge at the base ofDead Bobcats Travel West.(Itself a fun route) There should be an anchor at the base of the route. Move left and follow knobs up a steep wall. Typical Index knob climbing. The crux is passing a bulging section around the 3rd bolt. The bolt is close but care needs to be taken in falling due to the slabby undulating nature of the rock. After this two more bolts lead to an easier crack section (~1.5” cam is used here – 1.5 rigid friend was used on the FA) After passing another bolt a traversing crack system leads  left (gear needed here)  to join theHeart of the Countryroute.
routes.route_location: This route is reached best by traversing across the ledge at the base ofDead Bobcats Travel West.(Itself a fun route) The route has been reached more directly by climbing up from theG_M Route; however, this is usually guarded by blackberry vines.
routes.route_protection: Mostly quickdraws but a small rack is needed.

routes.route_description: A powerful start leads to a cruxy balance move. Sustained, delicate climbing leads past several small corners and a small roof to finish on a ledge.The fact that this route has been flashed by Lynn Hill should be enough to silence any complaints about the reachy climbing. The crux is 100% Index and is more than enough to keep almost any ego in check.The second clip is powerful and a fall from that point would be a ground fall. Also, my diminutive 5'10" reach was just barely enough to get the first quickdraw on from the ground, so bring a tall friend (AKA a stick clip) along if your arms are shorter. The bolt after the crux is even more reachy unless you are bold.
routes.route_location: Located to the left of Heironymous Bosch. It is the leftward trending line of bolts that approaches Fifth Force and then arches back right. A 60m rope should be sufficient for the descent.
routes.route_protection: Six bolts plus a two bolt anchor. If you are short (under 6 ft.) a couple of the bolts will be very difficult to clip (from stances) without quickdraws hanging.

route_comments.comment_text: Now (as of June 2011) has a second and third pitch. P2: "G is for Giners", 12a (or one letter grade harder than P1). P3: A 5.8 splitter crack. I have done neither, so if someone reading this has more info or corrections, please add here. Apr 23, 2012

Drew, Ben, or Mike Patz - have any of you guys sent this thing?  I tried it today and found the crux foothold to be impossibly far away.  The route definitely felt more difficult than 5th Force, Narrow Arrow, Like honey, Orc Tower, Engines of Archimedes, and pretty much every other Index 12 I've tried!  I assume the 5' climber was Lynn? May 15, 2014
Chris, I recall the crux of P1 as an all-out dyno. Or are you referring to the next pitches? May 16, 2014

routes.route_description: The right-arching crack/ramp just to the left of the tunnel. The route is short, protects fairly well, and can be a good easy warmup.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Standard trad rack to 3". There is a bolted anchor at the top and you can easily lower off with a 60-m rope.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Pinkpoint. Nathan placed the gear cause I’m a scaredy cat on trad and I just lead. I placed one redundant piece of gear for practice. · Lead / Onsight. Got scared and almost got a .4 stuck. Great first lead of 2025 · Lead / Onsight. W Quincy at the post art festival country rave. Did it really high and naked at night around 11pm/12am. Scripted a slip that people still don’t believe was scripted LOL. Then candle lit rave with the homies. · 2 pitches. Lead. cruiser. unfortunately had to do this 4 times as we accidentally pulled the rope! · Lead / Onsight. Led to access tunnel vision. Didn’t enjoy that much, tricky feet in places. · TR. Super fun route. A little scary but not hard. And the swing isn't as bad as you think. Tight belay but didn't really fall at all. Good rests in spots · Lead / Onsight. First trad lead at Index! Fun and a little funky positioning. Proud of this one! · Follow. With Tom, first of the day on Sunday July 9th 2023. very scared at the anchor, good climb for a warmup. · Lead / Flash. climbs like a 7 and though some of the flakes are hollow there are good options for pro · Lead / Onsight. Nothing special but relatively fun for as easy and accessible it is (AL+) · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Rope gunnin for Sage & Cam Fun as always, just a tad wet · Follow. Fun little warm up, would make a good first trad lead, at some points you can go hands and feet free by laying down, to really experiment with piece placement.

routes.route_description: A fun, short, steep thin crack near the quarry area.  Distinct cruxes on thin fingerlocks and highsteps with good pro on small cams and nuts makes this fun.  Up until yesterday (3/12/06), this was a 12a.  I pulled off the big jug on the route at the end of the day, though.  What's really scary is everybody has been yarding on the thing for years - it's the best hand and foot on the route, and a great spot to place gear.  It was a 50 lb. block held in by mud.  Wow.So the crack now awaits a first ascent! Get after it!
routes.route_location: The furthest left route at the Country.  Go uphill past Elvis-Nixon, etc. until you are at the start of the quarry.  It's the obvious thin crack on the orange, vertical wall with slings on the anchors at the top.
routes.route_protection: Thin cams, especially Metolius #1 TCUs and small nuts.

route_comments.comment_text: So the route is still .12a, but the process of placing gear is definitely harder and the climbing a bit more sustained. Go do it, a fun bit of climbing. Mar 20, 2006
Not bad as a short clean aid climb. Aug 7, 2006
Great climb that stays dry and doesn’t need scrubbing. Seemingly  rare to climb this grade at index without clipping bolts. 12a....sure. Apr 2, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. AMTL 3: mock aid lead. Estimate at C2. Used 11 pieces of gear: 4* small nuts, #0.5, #0.75, #1 and the rest was #0.1 to #0.3 · TR. AMTL 3: mock aid lead. Estimate at C2. Used 11 pieces of gear: 4* small nuts, #0.5, #0.75, #1 and the rest was #0.1 to #0.3 BD cams and totems. Took over 30 min. Fun. · Lead. Aid, v scary for me, squeak squeak cam hook definitely no free move · TR. wow only had to rest about 6 times on my 2nd go, once I figured it out. Painful on the knuckles and super fun Best Possible Rack (in order): green micro below right lock possibly black totem in the lock? grey micro below left jam .5 by right hand jam red micro (gear crux)? purple micro? will be one of these not both .4 in finger jam below undercling .4 in finger jam ABOVE undercling .3 in finger jam (next to crux feet) small nut by left pinch (hard to place/see)? red micro Z4 between crux finger locks #7 dmm offset in final crux lock? .4 or .75 also goes well here horizontal.4 in to protect final moves to anchor (optional) Rack: set of micros cams BD Red micro-.75 doubles .3 - .4 optional triples .4 Probable Rack: black totem, purple totem, yellow totem, yellow totem, blue totem, red microcam or small nut for crux?? green totem Don't forget you can bump at the crux New beta: keep your right foot low on the good rail and strrretch and statically reach the bump hold, then clop your right foot onto the original slopey edge and bump. For the mono pocket you can either dig your index finger in there or pinch it, thumb pressing. Idk if there's a term for it

routes.route_fa: Darryl Cramer, Greg Olsen, Jon Nelson, Larry Kemp
routes.route_description: This is a somewhat short but very engaging edging problem. A crux right off the ledge surmounting the first bulge is guaranteed to get your attention. The rest of the climb is sustained crimping and edging with another hard section near the top.
routes.route_location: From where the trail continues to Steel Monkey, head right onto a grassy ledge. Use caution: the drop from this ledge would be fatal. The climb starts under an obvious scooped overhang from a comfortable but unprotected belay stance. A 60m rope descends.
routes.route_protection: Bolts. There are newly bolted anchors above and below the tree at the top.There is now a belay bolt on the ledge, however the first and/or second bolt should still be stick clipped.

route_comments.comment_text: I think there might be a hangerless 1/4" bolt(or two) on the left side of the ledge. When originally climbed there was a large flake at the base that made the first clip and the start of the traverse really easy.  Later some rascals trundled it along with a bunch of other rocks in the area.  As a result the ledge has become much smaller than it was when the routes were first climbed.  Resist... more I think there might be a hangerless 1/4" bolt(or two) on the left side of the ledge. When originally climbed there was a large flake at the base that made the first clip and the start of the traverse really easy.  Later some rascals trundled it along with a bunch of other rocks in the area.  As a result the ledge has become much smaller than it was when the routes were first climbed.  Resist the urge to trundle. Seawash west to Steel Monkey is a great place to climb in cold weather (if the sun is shining).  Seawash was first climbed in the low 30s with snow all around.  The winds were howling a few feet away from the rock but the person actually climbing was virtually wind free. Dec 31, 2008

This is a good pitch with cool boulder moves. As of 12/7/14 one of the bolts in the middle of the pitch has been smashed by rock fall. This route would be a good candidate for re bolting anyway. Dries super fast and is a lot of fun! Dec 8, 2014

This route is now cleaned and fully rebolted minus the original 1st bolt (which is pretty impossible to clip and requires two ropes to avoid drag). I was able to reuse the old holes on everything except the damaged bolt Jens mentioned which still needs  some camo work. Get after it! Jan 28, 2019

routes.route_description: From the anchors of SS Ultrabrutal, head straight up the bolted line.  There are cruxy moves between the first and second bolts (wide dihedral and thin traverse left) as well as immediately past the second bolt (long reach off a side-pull/undercling).  After the crux, enjoy varied climbing with some moves that still require attention, but are easier.
routes.route_location: Directly above SS Ultrabrutal
routes.route_protection: Bolts and chains on the anchor

route_comments.comment_text: This climb is typical of The Country, with its crux/rest/crux/rest sequence.  Finger size and height might determine how hard this is for you.  Frequently Top-Roped in combination with SS Ultrabrutal with a 70m rope. Jul 16, 2013

If you climb Tunnel Vision, you will be selling yourself short if you don't continue on to do Angora Grotto, which is a gem of a route situated just above it. AG's grade is slightly harder (.11a) but there is only one well-protected move at that grade.  The most efficient way to link these is to clip the Tunnel Vision anchors as you go by on lead and continue to scramble up and right (15ft?)... more If you climb Tunnel Vision, you will be selling yourself short if you don't continue on to do Angora Grotto, which is a gem of a route situated just above it. AG's grade is slightly harder (.11a) but there is only one well-protected move at that grade.  The most efficient way to link these is to clip the Tunnel Vision anchors as you go by on lead and continue to scramble up and right (15ft?) to the anchors at the base of the Angora Grotto crack.  Belay your second up from here. Mountain Project--Angora Grotto mountainproject.com/v/angor… Aug 18, 2013
Short and very fun, especially if linked with SS Ultrabrutal using a 70m. The moves are bouldery and well bolted. Jun 15, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Tough!! Fell at the first crux. (I was kinda rushing because it was getting chilly!). But kinda need to slowly fall left into small finger gaston. The next crux went smoothly as I was being careful. Basically just need to get a really high left foot, then as you step up catch the undercling with left thumb till you can get up to grab the really good ledge hold with right hand. Actually the rest of the climb continued to be challenging with many balancey and burly mantels. Would certainly be challenging on lead. · Lead / Onsight. Cruxy first bit leads into enjoyable climbing. Did the tips crack exit, adds some more difficulties. Crazy gaston on the crux. Lila did an insane cross/splits/match thing. Added a half star for the length from SSUB · Lead / Onsight. This thing was fun I thought, pretty bouldery and a lil scary going far right (same or worse for the follower) def harder than cunning stunt for me but cool to figure it out · Lead / Redpoint. Hardest outdoor lead thus far. Mentally hard on the traverse after that the big moves went better · Lead / Fell/Hung. Not my ideal warmup, pulled a draw to get though the first hard mantle · Lead / Fell/Hung. Went how I used to up and right then back left from first chains and came off gettin spooked going left. Beta going straight up is better - high left foot, bump RH to arete and reach with LH up to flake. W/ Kaz and Emma · Follow. Bailed on the lead above 1st bolt. Followed Andrew. Clean traverse to the 2nd bolt on follow, but struggled considerably up the rest, exhausted · Lead / Fell/Hung. One hung right at the crux.. stay right then move left. · Follow. Sent with direct off the chains for p2 and also direct up finger crack near end · Lead / Fell/Hung. Did everything but the opening move, need to get right foot up somehow. · Lead / Fell/Hung. pulled on draws for first crux. could not figure out. go more right by using the left arete drop knee to high right crimp. move left feet far left. linked with tunnel vision · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very cool climb, the bolt spacing may seem scary if this is near your limit, but the hard moves are all well protected. A high foot during the second crux makes it feel much better. · Lead / Fell/Hung. First cruxy bit wasn't too bad. The second one after the second bolt was pretty desperate, at least in the summer heat. · Lead / Onsight. Went straight up through crux rather than going right and traversing back left. Felt harder than 10d that way, but fun. · Pretty sure Ive climbed this before. Body dependent grade. I’m 5.10 and cut feet to a dyno above 2nd bolt. It’s all there regardless. Never trust 10d at the dex. · Follow. fell quite a bit. big moves to big holds and damn the big moves are big, my height you kinda have to launch for them · TR. Went right then traversed left at the crux. Pulled on draw for 2nd crux · TR. Oof. Had to aid past a couple cruxy bits. My first real multipitch tho · Lead / Fell/Hung. Sweet climb. Difficult moves getting from bolt 1 to bolt 2 · Lead / Fell/Hung. Finally figured out the two cruxes today. La cabrona se vá en la próxima visita! · Lead / Onsight. pretty fun! made it a bit hard on myself a few times with choosing harder beta. Great crux! · TR. Fell after big ledge, need to get right there... Almost lost glasses several time. Dirtbag weekend · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell at crux after Gaston... Finger still.numb. Didn't get feet high enough. With Aaron,Sapphire,Jim and Jose · took me two tries to get the cux down but I feel and RP is due.

routes.route_description: Follow the bolts leading straight up from the top of Tunnel Vision. A tricky mantle, funky body positioning, and some big moves will bring you to an anchor. The movement on this pitch is excellent!For full value, finish up and left via the steep bolted flake as per Conditioned Response. This gets you to Angora Grotto's anchors and does not change the grade.
routes.route_location: Top of Tunnel Vision. Can be TR'd from Angora Grotto's anchors.
routes.route_protection: Bolts.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. didn't plan on doing it, so we didn't bring enough draws. yo-yoed to reuse draws...great moves... the opening mantle move is harder if you're under 6' as my partners would attest

routes.route_fa: Greg Collum, Greg Child, Tim Wilson
routes.route_description: Is it a face climb? Is it a slab? Its the bolted knob route to the right of zoom.  Boulder up onto a ledge, clip a bolt and make an insecure lieback sequence to jugs.  Trend right and up to a crimp rail.  At the end of this rail is a difficult clip.  Moving off the sidepull at the end of this rail is the crux.  A few more moves off bad knobs lead to the anchors.
routes.route_location: right of zoom
routes.route_protection: 8 bolts, mussy hooks on the anchors

route_comments.comment_text: If you can imagine that the hand holds and foot holds exist... and then pull and stand on them, you'll enjoy this climb for all its worth.  Once it was mostly protected by the equally imaginary natural protection.  With it's current non-imaginary protection at each crux, it's a fun test of balance, flexibility and puzzle solving. Jul 15, 2013
Layback not too bad But the crux is in the knobs Dynamic last move Nov 22, 2020
Layback, layback thin Crimpy cranking right, head up Trend left hard knob moves Nov 25, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Telling kids I onsighted this 25 years ago when I'm geezed out · Lead / Fell/Hung. Bolt to bolt. Very fun but tricky upper section slabby type moves on knobs. At left traverse, smear feet, match on left sidepull then wide balancy step left to knob. Huge jug out left after. At blank hands section, get left foot high, rock over onto it and press up smearing right foot for more friction. Press up on left foot allll the way to small right hand knob, then step through with right foot. At top, lean out right and get left foot up high, use little left hand crimp right below lip, then pounce to good part of top hold out right. · Lead / Redpoint. Happy!! Really tore the skin up. Next time wait till it’s true cold temps - possible climb for Ben and Natalya? · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Tried it on Tr first, got it mostly clean except for a move getting past the bolt after the karate kick move. Tried again on lead and sent! Really cool bouldery slab cruxes separated by good rests · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took a fall on the 4th bolt and noticed the hive up high. Bailed and whipped my way back down. · Lead / Redpoint. Second go with Jordan he solved beta. Grab side pull and pinch knob to step down low · TR. Cruised first 3 bolts. Cruxed out on the traverse and barn doored. Upper section goes. · Lead / Fell/Hung. First crux- go farish right and use the knob that’s almost on the other route Second WHAM crux- after matching, move right hand down to knob before the big kick move · Lead. Almost onsight. Fell once lunging left for ticked knob with minimal feet. Hard! · Lead / Redpoint. Yay!! I finally sent this thing. I always have a really hard time redpointing. I get on a climb and feel so flummoxed, like I’ve never been on it before. Even though I’ve climbed the thing half a dozen times before. Same same this time. But I let my body take control on all the crux moves, not my brain. The moves that felt so insecure before were like second nature. After feeling beat down on this thing, I’m so glad to have sent. WHAM! · Lead / Fell/Hung. First go of the day on the project, fell at the crux, cruised the rest · Lead / Fell/Hung. First go of the day, cruised it past the crux to the next clip. Fell on a part I’d onsighted before, Got through the rest totally fine · Lead / Fell/Hung. Second go of the day. Kept fucking up on the first move. Once I finally got it I fell at the crux and came down · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tried it in the morning. Fingers hurt a lot. Came down at the crux · Lead / Fell/Hung. Tried this climb once today. Hung the last three draws. Struggled at the crux. Felt super good on everything at the top · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard! I think I have ok beta, gonna downsize the tc pros and try again · Lead / Redpoint. Let’s go! Second 11c of index. Feels way easier than so many other 11s. The grading here is weird (with Melissa Kevin and Stefano— an MP find) · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard to clip crux bolt and I found it to be very shoulder intensive move through that bolt and hard crux for me little reachy to the finish · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Doggy OS burn into 1fall lead burn. Maybe next time it goes · Lead. Second go! Tricked by the beta at the hard clip on the first · TR. Fell on 3rd crux doing the traverse thing over. 2nd crux had to gaston and get right foot high on knob · TR. UGH SO FUN!!!!! beta notes: nubbin section go a little right, right foot on horizontal edge (kinda bad) left foot super high, press into flat thing you wish was a undercling and statically reach to good nubbin. karate kick can be done slightly more statically by inching your feet/smearing. top bit get right hand on okay hold, left hand palm far left good nubbin reach statically to top · 3 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Second go one-hung it, third go fell up it, tired I guess? · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. Not the smartest thing to start with but it's what was open. Finally got it, if barely! w/ Karissa · Lead / Redpoint. Finally stuck karate kick second go of the day. So fun such good route · Lead / Redpoint. psyyyyyched. incredible climb. clip after kick? use high traverse at first crux. kick went with matched hands, try swing leg next time. high crux went easily with slopers · Lead / Fell/Hung. 2 hung. it was hot and cruxes were tough. Want to redpoint · TR. Still felt very hard, was also a like 80 some degrees and super humid today. Unlocked the initial layback, really high right foot next to the first bolt. Got close to the traverse, but couldn't figure it out still. Did the side pull pistol squat move, and couldn't do the final move to the chain. Gotta palm out left shuffle feet and work the hands then go for the jug. Super fun. W/ Dale and Mike · Lead / Redpoint. Wow so cool! At first the route is like “oooppffhh” and then it’s like “Wham!” And then you’re doing some moves to the chains and “yippee!” Then I was done and talked all about it for hours with my friend, Zach. Such a good route. I love the variety of techniques that need displaying. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hard! Want to come back for the redpoint. Multiple cruxes of many different styles · Lead / Fell/Hung. hang draws for kick clip. bolt 2 look for tiny footchip out right. at kick match hold, r foot dish, l foot high crystal. l hand to next tiny knob, kick out to high knobs, press. at next slab right foot in horizontal, l foot up to knob, l hand up to sloper dish, bring r foot up. · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 slip and fall, not on one of the hard parts! oh well haha · Lead / Redpoint. Third go to send after a heart breaking o/s attempt. Sent after shanty one p started the boiler · Lead / Fell/Hung. Cliff put up the route to the traverse. Whipped my way up to the chains. Challenging and engaging throughout. Tried a lot of different things for the karate kick before trying the karate kick. Can’t believe that stuck. Pulled the draw on the first layback crux down low. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Almost got it onsite just took a couple times to figure out beta · Lead / Redpoint. Not great condies but at least wasn’t in the sun. Hung the draws myself on lead. The least dialed it has ever felt, accidentally skipped second bolt, somehow still sent. Sick! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Hung draws. Felts strong, and sent to the crux traversing back left. · Lead / Fell/Hung. couldn't figure slab crux after kick or clip at kick, rest went OK. · TR. Pulled all the moves but the high step(?) up top. Hung many many times · Lead / Fell/Hung. slipped off the bottom due to wet feet from snow. got upper crux beta: bring right foot up to very small lip directly under right hand knob (not the larger lip farther right), stand up, moveleft foot up to lip on the arete, match hands on knob, move left hand up as you stand up. for lower crux, keep left hand low so roght can get a good lip and keep core tension. · Lead / Redpoint. Sent after ~10x on route. Soft / sticky shoes and cool temps preferred · TR. struggled at pinch, moving right after jug, struggled with crimp rail. slabby feet. pulled up on rope · 2 pitches. Lead / Redpoint. In the final photons of dusk my headlamp gave out as I committed to the crux. Shoutout Thaddaeus and other homies for the backflag extendo crux clip beta! Hardest sport climb yet. · 2 pitches. Lead / Fell/Hung. Beta burn and silly one-hang. So close! So sick! · TR. Leon put up wham. Tried, moves are damn hard. Got the layback start and traverse right and the bolts up to side pull. After side pull was desperate and pulled through · Follow. made it though the lieback start clean, couldn't make the final moves out of the traverse · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couldn’t do like two moves of the crux but made it up the rest. Cool nubs to climb on · Lead / Fell/Hung. Had to swing through the crux, as my feet weren’t sticking :( · Lead / Fell/Hung. Kick for higher [big] knob. Go up then left rather than low percentage throw out left. Condies matter! · Lead / Fell/Hung. progress with french Jonathan's beta! at left traverse, left good sidepull engaging thumb on bump, right hand on knob, get body low and reach foot out left and low, then match left sidepull · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pulled on crux draw to clip it (little hesitant climbing by headlamp), but clean otherwise. Fun! Will get it clean next time for sure. · Lead / Fell/Hung. several hang plus a couple aid moves. cool but so sandbagged at least in summer humidity. · Lead / Fell/Hung. every sequence feels improbably impossible, but goes, except the two that are actually impossible. · 2 pitches. Lead. one hung at first crux hanging draws. then clean tr lap · Lead / Redpoint. Got a surprise send after years of trying, the friction was superb · Lead / Onsight. High friction day. Amnesia onsight only climbed it in once like 2 years ago · 2 pitches. TR. first lap no falls, second lap fell at the step over gaston move · TR. still working out the traverse. feels like both hands on left facing edge, then kick out foot to far left foothold. · TR. fell once at the end of the traverse. fell few times at upper knob crux. remember hidden feet. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Knobs look so good, but it’s on!!! Wild route featuring insecure laybacking, an improbable karate kick, and very delicate standing up on knobs (fell here). Oh, and a big ol sloper to finish it off · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 fall down low moving right into jug. Top was tenuous but held it together cleanly · Lead / Fell/Hung. 1 fall just before the crux; pulled on a couple draws after that. Feel pretty good about the lead. · TR. TRedpoint. Key at crux was to go low after the sidepull at crux bolt: stretch to lower LF (not the gigantic knob, but a smaller one directly below it), and then LH into the huge flake jug. · Follow. The crux is super reachy...I'll have to wait for better conditions to try getting both hands on the side pull so I can maybe reach a toe out to the key foot nub.

routes.route_description: Sport climb on the far right of the Country. Crux is at the first bolt, which should either be stick-clipped or clipped by reaching over from the nearby tree. Also a tricky knob section near the top.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Four bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: Spent an hour wire brushing this yesterday. Honestly probably needs another couple hours of work to be in good shape. Interesting that the upper 3 protection bolts were replaced recently--but the initial bolt (well over 15' off the deck) is an old rusty 3/8" wedge type and very corroded.  Currently this route is mostly shady until mottled light infiltrates the Maple canopy around 1pm. Jul 23, 2019

routes.route_description: Start from the anchors of kite flying blind and break left.  Start with a tricky dynamic move and climb into well protected index trickery around a seam.
routes.route_location: Left of Kite Flying blind, accessed with Elvis Nixon or Frank Presley
routes.route_protection: 1 bolt, bolted anchors + standard rack

route_comments.comment_text: Another bunch of thought-provoking moves, starting with a strange layaway/lunge to get off the belay ledge.  Bring a few small cams for the finish. May 30, 2015
Four stars! Nov 14, 2018

routes.route_fa: Jon Nelson, Steve Strong, Tom Michael.
routes.route_description: Starts with a hard, bolt-protected mantel(10d), then follows two more bolts up easier climbing. Go slightly right over the small roof with a few finger jams. Then follow the knob climbing (10b) with natural gear for pro. A slight runout to an overlap near the top, but you can place a finger-sized nut immediately after. At the overlap, look for sidepulls on the left.It is possible to skip the bottom mantel by climbing up to the right (~10a), then stepping onto the mantel ledge. Be careful of the landing though if you fail.
routes.route_location: left of the tunnel, a stump makes a good belay rest
routes.route_protection: Bolts at the start, gear to number 2 camalot to finish.For the 10b climbing on knobs, bring small wires.

route_comments.comment_text: I agree this is a really good pitch (the route actually stretches for three pitches) and one of the better 5.10s at Index.  The upper half of the climb has great movement and flow, especially through the knob section.  A little more detail might be nice, though. For instance, bring along RPs/HBs or some other kind of micronut, because they're mandatory to protect the upper half of the climb,... more I agree this is a really good pitch (the route actually stretches for three pitches) and one of the better 5.10s at Index.  The upper half of the climb has great movement and flow, especially through the knob section.  A little more detail might be nice, though. For instance, bring along RPs/HBs or some other kind of micronut, because they're mandatory to protect the upper half of the climb, which mostly uses an incipient seam for pro.  There's also a moderate runout to end the route.  Right in the middle of the seam is God's Most Perfect Nut Placement (medium wired) to make things chill. Nov 8, 2007

If you climb one 5.10d at Index, make it this one.  Slow Children may be more sustained, but this one makes you feel more ALIVE. Here's Lukic pulling Zoom.  The first part of the video is good beta for the very cryptic first moves.  The later part is good for inspiration. youtube.com/watch?v=bGIkHMa… more If you climb one 5.10d at Index, make it this one.  Slow Children may be more sustained, but this one makes you feel more ALIVE. Here's Lukic pulling Zoom.  The first part of the video is good beta for the very cryptic first moves.  The later part is good for inspiration. youtube.com/watch?v=bGIkHMa… Jul 4, 2013

Yesterday a friend told me he heard from a local that Orc tower above is deteriorating and may be coming down soon, have not verified, but seems reasonable since rockfall occurred recently when I was there and you... more While at the base and preparing to climb, an unexplained rock came sailing from above.  Also noticed very recent rockfall at the base of morning star (to the left of this climb).  Yesterday a friend told me he heard from a local that Orc tower above is deteriorating and may be coming down soon, have not verified, but seems reasonable since rockfall occurred recently when I was there and you can see evidence of very fresh rockfall near-by.  Something to consider while in the area. Aug 19, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. #1 *2, black totem (optional), purple nut (#4), gold offset nut, yellow totem, blue totem, optional metolius purple. Use tiny knob out left for lf, rh on leftmost part of giant knob , rf as far left on shelf as possible, throw to lh sidepull low part, then rf heel hook At the middle layback part use smeary foot in middle to step up · Lead / Fell/Hung. Almost had the onsight. Fell once pulling at the top of the seam. I did indeed feel more alive on this than slow children. Scary committing chicken heads. Had to dyno the start · Lead / Onsight. Missed a hold at the start, heady mantle off the ground · TR. Nailed upper crux, just flailed around at the start had to cheat today · TR. Bottom Crux: jump for sloper. Walk feet up, left foot on nub, left hand side pull, right foot on white spot. Pull hard with left hand and dig in with right toe, reach up for pocket, sink it high. Feet on sloper and rock over · Lead / Fell/Hung. Pulled through the mantle but did the rest. Bring tiny nuts! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very hot day, sweaty hands. Great climbing, but run out of morale at the last move of the face. Protection is skinny but there, but you gotta trust your moves. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Went right near the top. Was too scared to climb above gear there. · Lead. Started pouring right before getting to the finger lock lol, bailed to the zoom anchors · Lead / Onsight. Dyno into the first sloper, hike feet, right hand to side pokey crimp, tilt body, left hand to second crimp, mantle. The middle is tricky. (Tech redpoint but didn’t remember climbing prev) · TR. Many hangs Start beta: good L side pull, step through R foot on small knob, flag L; stand R and mantle on R sloper · Lead / Redpoint. Have to jump to ball, then move left hand to left side pull, right foot step through to knob on left, flag left foot, then right hand slowly up to hole/sidepull up and right. Pretty chill if I do it right. The rest is just good footwork and balance totally in my wheelhouse. 1 small brass nut and another medium nut later regular finger ant tip cams. No 00 needed. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell on the mantel and restarted. Then had trouble closer to the top · Lead / Fell/Hung. Caleb led it up to the run out. I TRed up to that point. Took a reminder fall above the nut. Then worked my way through the crux. Had to take a breath to finish the route. Headier than when I TRed it. · Lead / Fell/Hung. took hella whips (3 of which were on the 000) and got a lil spooked and got it dialed. first time tying in with the homie Nina! Connor also kicked it with us and gave a TR lap as well! · TR. Aside from the boulder start this was somewhat cruiser. I went left at the mini bulge roof. Probably ready for a lead go · Lead / Redpoint. Fell a couple times at the start. Lowered down and then sent it. · TR. This thing was so fun, but holy fuck it would be so heady on lead. Maybe one day. No falls though · Lead / Flash. Should have saved a .3 and a gold dmm offset nut for the pro before the final runout · TR. TRonsight! gear dialed too!! very stoked to come back and lead this bad larry. with spencer · Lead / Redpoint. So proud of myself for this one! Brought the wrong piece for the top and had to run it out (last placement was the #.4 in the seam/finger lock). · Lead / Redpoint. With Erik and Ryan. Hard crux at the bottom and exciting movement on amazing features above! · TR. Difficult mantle. Had to match it get the right crimp put the left back to continue · TR. A few falls on start, but then did it through. Mantle with side pull then go for small pocket crimp · Lead. First go: oh shit I’m gonna die Second go: chill. Amazing nut. Had to jump for the start · Lead / Fell/Hung. Chickened out on the run out section and took a shorter fall. Sent it after a quick rest. There is a jug and decent pro right after the run out. · TR. Clean TR, but my left foot slipped during the "mental crux". I'd stick clip the first two bolts if I tried to lead it. I have to jump off the right foot and grab the first left hand (go for far left on the bulge). David's gear beta: #3 + alpine sling, #1, #2, small nut, #.4, (mental crux), #.3. · Lead / Fell/Hung. #3 alpine draw, #1, #2, smallest bd nut, .4, .3 totem · TR. Struggled on the cruxes more the second time, but did better at the top. Still did it "clean" on TR after a false start. · TR. We set a top rope w/o leading. I probably could not lead this season especially without aiding. · TR. boulder start: left hand lockoff, smear right foot and mantle left hand. then right hand to pocket (higher pocket to left, ignore the right pocket). step up right foot and pistol squat! · Lead / Redpoint. Linked into Leave my face alone for one long fun pitch · TR. awesome route! I couldn't reach the start hold so had to jump for it. would have to have the gear dialed to lead it because it felt pretty committing at the top section. · TR. Did not find the knob climbing particularly easy, had a hard time trusting feet. Fun though otherwise · TR. fell off the mantle a few times but once I got it the rest of the route went, super cool rock, seems well protected, would recommend! · TR. First pitch of the day. Right hand into the Mono thing after establishing the good side pull that’s far left as you step onto the wall. After, throw a heal-to-toe smear and swing into a mantle · Lead / Onsight. Proud onsight. Heady climbing above but not bad. Not a gimme though, and above a small wire and small cams · Lead / Redpoint. Opening sequence beta: left foot on a knob, left hand up into left pocket, use the mono, right foot into some shitty dish directly below NOT out right, right hand up, get left foot up onto mantle and stand up. · TR. 2 laps, few hangs at the beginning the first time, otherwise clean. Right hand sloper knob, left hand side pull, left foot on nub, right foot back flag, right hand deadpoint to crimp, foot up and mantel · Lead / Flash. Very fun and a little scary with the small nuts. Jess went to the first thin crack and bailed so had some gear in there. Almost blew that last lil sequence. Maple good dog. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Couldn’t get the step up after mantel to 2nd bolt. Fell above brassie on face. · TR. Opening move is desperate, would love to put it together but the gear is *run out* · TR. Hard start, i guess i missed a mono or something. Excellent route otherwise! · TR. Birds nest with chirping babies in a crack in the middle of the route, avoid for a while · TR. Lower section was ok. Slipped an the insecure knob up high. Trusted it the second time around. Finally trying 10s in Index · 3 draws, then 0.75 (sling), 2, 2, small nut, bomber offset 0.3/0.4 cam or medium nut in finger crack below crux, 0.3 after crux

area_description: Exposed, blocky tower to the left of the Country.
area_getting_there: From the Country, hike up the talus on the left side. To reach the base of the tower, you must do one of the routes underneath, such as Patrick's Flake, Savage Gardens, Kite Flying Blind, or Leave My Face Alone.

area_comments.comment_text: If you are considering climbing Orc Tower by any route, be aware that there is a large amount of loose rock at the base of the tower. Anything knocked down will rain down onto the popular routes below in the Country (e.g. Zoom, Wham). Even if you're really careful, pulling the rope while rappelling will still knock down some rocks, so it's probably best to only climb on Orc Tower on... more If you are considering climbing Orc Tower by any route, be aware that there is a large amount of loose rock at the base of the tower. Anything knocked down will rain down onto the popular routes below in the Country (e.g. Zoom, Wham). Even if you're really careful, pulling the rope while rappelling will still knock down some rocks, so it's probably best to only climb on Orc Tower on weekdays when there are not as many people around. Aug 26, 2013

routes.route_description: P1: 10b. Follow a crack/flake. The pitch has one bolt.P2: 10c. Go straight up the east face of Orc Tower. This pitch is all gear. The photo shows the position.Unlike other routes that go directly onto Orc Tower, this is reported to have no loose rock.
routes.route_location: Can be reached from the top of either Leave my Face Alone (11a) or Kite Flying Blind (11c) or by walking in. Also see overview on main page.
routes.route_protection: A rack of tiny gear to 4".

route_comments.comment_text: The first pitch is quite dirty (8/23/13), it would be fun climbing if it were clean though. The second pitch requires a lot of thin gear (e.g. #0 and #00 C3s, micronuts). It finishes with a very burly offwidth, so don't forget to bring a #4! There is a lot of loose rock at the base of the tower, consider only climbing this route on weekdays to reduce the risk of hitting climbers below... more The first pitch is quite dirty (8/23/13), it would be fun climbing if it were clean though. The second pitch requires a lot of thin gear (e.g. #0 and #00 C3s, micronuts). It finishes with a very burly offwidth, so don't forget to bring a #4! There is a lot of loose rock at the base of the tower, consider only climbing this route on weekdays to reduce the risk of hitting climbers below with falling rock. Aug 26, 2013

routes.route_description: Goes more behind Orc Tower than on it.Start from the ledge of "cream of the country", also the start of the second pitch of "116 orc tower road". Crawl through the hole accessing the seldom visited Orc Tower chamber room. Make your way to the back pedestal and get ready for some action.P1: 10b Wild stemming protected by a thin crack on the main wall leads to a massive roof. Traverse left (west) and then up through a flaring fist crack to the notch between Orc Tower and the wall. A two bolt belay is on the Orc Tower side.P2. 9 Traverse west out of the  gap and onto the wall, joining the upper hand cracks of what is probably Orc Wall (rusty pins were spotted at the alcove down and to the left of the obvious triple cracks at the top of the wall). Follow the crack.A fine route with a high dose of adventure. Cool even on the hottest of days.
routes.route_location: See description above and the overview image.
routes.route_protection: A wide range of sizes.

route_comments.comment_text: This is a fun, adventurous, and quite unique route. After a belly crawl to reach the "Chamber Room", wild stemming leads to some even wilder overhanging moves to surmount a roof. Bring gear from #0 C3 to #4 C4. We didn't climb the short second pitch but it looks worthwhile as well. Due to all the loose rock at the base of Orc Tower, avoid climbing this one on weekends to minimize the risk... more This is a fun, adventurous, and quite unique route. After a belly crawl to reach the "Chamber Room", wild stemming leads to some even wilder overhanging moves to surmount a roof. Bring gear from #0 C3 to #4 C4. We didn't climb the short second pitch but it looks worthwhile as well. Due to all the loose rock at the base of Orc Tower, avoid climbing this one on weekends to minimize the risk of hitting climbers in the Country with falling rocks. Aug 28, 2013

The stemming is rad and keeps the climbing relatively moderate. Moving through the roof felt hard! It looks like there is a hand crack line to the right of this (in the chamber room but on the main wall). Aug 28, 2013

routes.route_fa: Greg Collum, Mike Massey, Matt Kerns
routes.route_description: This route is fun and well protected, though the ledges are often covered in loose rock. Care must be taken to avoid knocking anything onto climbers at the Country. Avoid this route on busy days.P1 (11b): From the belay ledge head leftwards on a steep but mellow traverse before cutting hard back to the right at a horizontal break. An oddly positioned bolt protects the crux and brings you to the base of a short OW leading to the belay. Consider using alpine draws to avoid drag.P2 (12a): A gnarly layback (crux) brings you to a stance below...a gnarly layback. Continue upwards over a tricky roof to an anchor just below the summit of the tower. Features some exposed and desperate moves.Walk off using the rungs or rap the route. Best rap route is straight down to Savage Gardens from the top of P1.
routes.route_location: From the top of the country, locate a trail leading to the left toward the base of the tower. A belay bolt and hanging chain mark the base of the route.  The most direct approach is from Kite Flying Blind or Leave my Face Alone.
routes.route_protection: ~ 12 draws. Bolted anchors.

route_comments.comment_text: If you want to access the crux pitch only, consider taking the via ferrata inside Orc Tower, exiting at the ledge halfway up and traversing into the pitch. As I recall it was pretty straightforward to do. Dec 7, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Kite flying blind into this one. Got stumped on the second crux of the last pitch on lead, then sent on tr. need to go back for the send. It was surprisingly chill after figuring out the beta · Lead. Fell on one approach pitch but OS all pitches on the tower. Wild route!

area_description: A huge wall sometimes called the quarry area by older climbers. Generally clean, dry, and exposed. The top of the wall ends near the base of the Mid Wall, providing several walk-off possibilities.Prior to 1982, it had a huge roof near the top (with a bold A4 route out it), but in the winter of that year, the roof fell down, depositing the huge boulders below. Now, except for the huge chimney route on the very left end, the wall is reported to be quite solid.The top of the wall is one of two places at Index used by BASE jumpers, the other being the central part of the Upper Town Wall.
area_getting_there: Either hike up from the Country, or from the Lower Town Wall.

area_comments.comment_text: The Quarry is the  most underrated sector at Index. Aside from the bottom pitch, the rock is immaculate and unique to Index. Crisp edges, cracks, overlaps and protruding features provide interesting movement. The almost entirely flat wall lends to a feeling of incredible exposure with a view rivaling or surpassing those from other walls. Jul 12, 2016

routes.route_fa: FA J. Tetzlaff, J. Wyland  FFA. C. Allen, J. Wyland
routes.route_description: Starts as a variation finish to the third pitch of "Tales From Zahajko".P1: From midway up P3 of Tales, traverse right to the left overhang of the right set of "eyes" on the headwall.P2: 11d. Climb out a flare to thin face climbing past bolts and two pins in a discontinuous crack to a belay. This with the headwall pitches of "Humble Pie" and perhaps the last pitch of "Tour of Duty" are the best pitches on the wall.P3: 10a. Climb up a knobby overhanging block past a bolt to easier gear climbing through ledges and roofs to the top.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Gear to 1" plus quickdraws.

route_comments.comment_text: For those of you who don’t want to deal with any of the hassles to get to this pitch, simply traverse in from above and lower off the chains 60’ to the start of the route.  This pitch is absolutely perfect. Nov 18, 2024

routes.route_description: An alternate last pitch for Tour of Duty.Exit the left side of the overhang, go past three bolts, then up a finger crack.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Pro for the finger crack. Gear for Tour of Duty should cover it.

routes.route_name: Jonah Benkert's World Famous Homemade Humble Pie
routes.route_description: The first pitch is the same as "Tour of Duty". To repeat that info:Start from a gold-colored bolt atop a pedestal on the left side of the wall.P1: 11b. Bouldery start up clean rock (5.11b) then turns to fourth class for the second half of the pitch.P2: 11b. Also a bouldery start. Go under an overhang then up to the right side of an obvious boulder to a large belay.P3: 10b. Scale the black pillar to the base of the headwall.P4: 11c. Here the fun really starts. 11c face climbing on an otherwise blank wall leads to a belay in an alcove.P5: 10b. Moderate climbing to a ledge that then traverses right (5.10b) on a large rail to a belay on a large ledge with two trees. Here you can join the last pitch of "Tales From Zahajko" or rappel.Every pitch on this route is good.
routes.route_location: The overview image shows the entire route.
routes.route_protection: Quickdraws with one optional blue tcu

route_comments.comment_text: The Crown Jewel of the Quarry routes. Approach pitches 1 and 2: total choss. What little redeeming qualities pitch 3 may have had are squandered on appallingly dirty and loose rock in, and proximal to the line of poorly placed bolts that invite ledge falls and avoidable awkward clipping stances on rusty non-stainless sub-grade hardware. Pitch 4 may be worth walking to the top of... more The Crown Jewel of the Quarry routes. Approach pitches 1 and 2: total choss. What little redeeming qualities pitch 3 may have had are squandered on appallingly dirty and loose rock in, and proximal to the line of poorly placed bolts that invite ledge falls and avoidable awkward clipping stances on rusty non-stainless sub-grade hardware. Pitch 4 may be worth walking to the top of the cliff and rappeling down to the hanging belay, but why bother? A better option would be to climb elsewhere.  Or consider staying home and watching TV.  If you live in Seattle, you may enjoy traversing the outside of the water tower in Volunteer Park.  Challenge someone to a foot race up the stairs to the top.  The views are spectacular. Jul 19, 2015
That's a pretty funny comment Tom. Oh my though, I didn't know those bolts were rusting. Jul 20, 2015

Most people will have a better time if they rap down the headwall after traversing in off “the thing”.  Pull your rope to keep it sporty.  While I liked the first three pitches, I must confess: it’s true most everyone else will not. Nov 18, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. True diamond in the rough! moving from one dirty boulder problem to another you constantly ask yourself.. why am I here. getting to the top of pitch 3 where the hanging belay is and you realize why you will never see a line on this route.

routes.route_description: P1: 11b. Start up "Whipnatize" (5.11b), then climb fourth class to a bolted face leading to a large treed ledge (5.10a).P2: 10c. A fun sport pitch on jugs leads to a hanging belay below a triangular roof.P3: 11c. Climb up and right from the belay with one 11c move to get onto the headwall. Continue to a small ledge belay to the right of the lone tree on the headwall.P4: 11b. Climb a discontinuous crack to a two-tree ledge. There is an open project to the left of this pitch.P5: 11c. The fifth pitch uses gear in a crack to start then traverses left under a roof to a flare with bolts to the top.
routes.route_location: See the beta image.
routes.route_protection: Quickdraws with one red camalot and one green camalot for the final pitch.

route_comments.comment_text: This is a good route on mostly solid stone.  Pitches 2 and 4 particularly stand out and are excellent on their own.  Mind the ringing flake at the top of pitch two.  It’s probably still okay, but really gives you that last little rush after pulling the crux bulge. Nov 18, 2024

routes.route_description: Start from a gold-colored bolt atop a pedestal on the left side of the wall.P1: 11b. Bouldery start up clean rock (5.11b) then turns to fourth class for the second half of the pitch.P2: 11b. Start in a finger crack, then pull left around a corner to friable face climbing past two bolts (5.11b). This is the lowest quality pitch on the route.P3: 5.9. Finger crack to face moves past a bolt (the last on the route) and back into splitter hands to the base of the obvious black corner on the left side of the headwall.P4: 10b. Corner crack with small to large gear.P5: 10c. Leave the right corner of the left overhang through a hand crack that then angles left through an undercling to the top. Superb.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3.5"

area_description: The Cheeks comprise the large white formation on the right side of the Upper Walls. It is left of the Diamond, and above and left of Duck Wall and Lookout Point.The Lower Cheeks is the bottom half, and ends on the large ledge splitting the formation called The Beach. As this ledge is huge and easily accessed by a cable, the Lower Cheeks is perhaps the best place for toproping at Index. And like the Upper Cheeks, has routes that stay dry during rainfall.Routes here include such classics as The Zipper, (.10b) and the spectacular Clay, (.11+), as well as several quality sport climbs such as Friendly Fire (10b), Engines of Archimedes (11d), and all Dogs Go to Heaven (.12c).
area_getting_there: Upon reaching the Upper Wall via the trail (about 30 minutes from the Country), you will see a water streak and/or waterfall. Turn right and cross the stream, following a path downwards and eventually back up. You will pass many routes to your left, eventually reaching Clay, which is an obvious left-facing corner. Total: about 40 minutes from the Country.

area_comments.comment_text: Can these routes be climbed with a 60 or do I need to bring a 70m up here?  Thanks Aug 20, 2020
I gave everything from Cornucopia to Electric Funeral a quick scrub last week. Everything you need is sparkly clean again. May 13, 2021
Gerberding anchor had no lowering hardware, and it appeared neither did Green Room. There were just fixe hangers. Is this the case for the rest of the area? Jun 8, 2024

routes.route_description: After doing the initial corner of the Zipper (5.9), place gear and move up and right to the bolted face. For many, the crux is after the second bolt. After the third bolt, you can either move up and into the corner crack, or stay on the face and trend left to the belay.
routes.route_location: Same start as the Zipper. Also, the same top anchor as the Zipper.
routes.route_protection: Small pieces for the start & three quickdraws for the bolts.

routes.route_description: Short but sweet. To the right of Clay is a slab leading to a roof and steep corner above. Climb them past 8 or 9 bolts to a two bolt anchor. The crux is pulling over the roof above the starting ramp but the corner above is really tricky and sustained.
routes.route_location: If you can locate Clay, this route is just to the right.   Start on slab to the right(original) or climb past two new bolts(June 2019) up bouldery steep flake directly into the climbing above.60m rope.
routes.route_protection: Bolts; two bolt anchor with chains.

route_comments.comment_text: The powerful boulder problem over the first roof is hard.  I also found the end perplexing!  Overall a quality pitch that would get another star with more traffic.  As it is, bring a stick to dig spider carcasses out of every hold. Feb 11, 2016
Cleaned. At least 13a for those really short folks. About as close as I get to bouldering. Oct 28, 2018

Added two bolt direct start(June 2019).  Climb the obvious steep flake.  All other bolts replaced with stainless 3/8"(June 2019). This route is excellent.  It's steep, powerful and perplexing right to the anchors.  The new start adds a bit of pump leading into the crux.  One of the best routes in the grade at solid, honest 12d.  No sandbag.  No bullshit.  Definitely harder if you are unable... more Added two bolt direct start(June 2019).  Climb the obvious steep flake.  All other bolts replaced with stainless 3/8"(June 2019). This route is excellent.  It's steep, powerful and perplexing right to the anchors.  The new start adds a bit of pump leading into the crux.  One of the best routes in the grade at solid, honest 12d.  No sandbag.  No bullshit.  Definitely harder if you are unable to make the crux dyno.  The alternative is micro crimping through the roof section.  Ouchies. Jun 16, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Very hard roof pull, harder than NAD for me. Top is hard but cool indexy movement

routes.route_description: A fun route with interesting, balancey moves.  Weird, because the rig overhangs about 35-40 degrees, but it's technical and tricky.  The redpoint crux is clipping the anchor. But the best part is that is is ALWAYS dry for both climber and belayer because of the huge roof overhead.  Bring some sticky shoes you like to smear with.  To get there, take a right at the base of the Upper Town Wall and follow the trail along the base.  In about 5 minutes, you will reach the huge A Frame roof overhead.  You can't miss it.  It's the leftmost steep sport route in the alcove to the right.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Closely spaced bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: 12c in the guidebook. 13a here. Might be 12d with some funky shoulder scum beta. A good route and a solid send Feb 4, 2012

Clipping the anchor ended up being the crux as I fell 3 goes in a row trying to clip from that completely drilled pocket. Many bolts are quite rusty but they all seem to be adequate at sustaining whippers for individuals around 110lb. A climb that really packs a punch stringing everything together. Oct 1, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Actually super fun. Geometric climbing. Was getting dark so stopped at bolt below chain, didn’t find the pocket and fell off some big not jugs. Will be fun to come back and try it when it’s rainy

routes.route_description: There is a flat spot to belay from as the trail turns the corner under Snowblind. Start here and climb to a ledge at ~15 feet. Climb past the horizontal break to the left trending splitter and follow this to the top.Amazing splitter seriously crazy good knobby rock. One of the most splitter lines at Index.
routes.route_location: Obvious splitter on right side of cheeks where wall starts to turn parallel to Diamond Gully
routes.route_protection: Standard rack of cams with micro cams to protect the start. Mostly .4 camalot. Bolted anchor with chains. Shares anchors with Snowblind.

route_comments.comment_text: Awesome crack climbing!  A little gritty and would be 5 star if a little cleaner--but as is, very climbable and I didn't think anything too cruxY at the end as suggested. SPLITTER! Aug 26, 2018
My gear beta: Protected the bottom with .1 and .2 X4s (or 0 C3). Placed a #2 in a horizontal break just before the splitter. The splitter eats up .4 and .3 camalot, with optional .5. Jun 16, 2019
when does this route get shade? Jul 20, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. felt very hard. the upper crack was loose fingers with bad feet · Lead / Fell/Hung. One stupid ass fall near top. No chalk hands soooooooo wet. Fuck. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Top crux: Get highest handjam with RIGHT hand, then bad left lock, then good right jam. Bring .1 and .2 for very start · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell right before the chains. Small nuts protect the opening moves, a #2 for the horizontal before the finger crack, and save a 0.5, 0.4, 0.3 for the crack at the top as it pinches down. · Lead. OS upper crack after coming in from cornucopia. Climbed the lower bit trying snowblind · TR. there was a black and white frog sitting on the knob in the crack at the top. seam to the right was seeping a bit but didn't prevent from climbing the crack. · Lead / Fell/Hung. quite flared.
