Should have worn crack gloves to get more secure jams. 0.5 and 0.4 sized cracks. bring triples of them. one 0.2 for the top, double 0.3, one 0.75,2. 0.0 and 0.1 and nut for beginning. okay jams getting to ledge in the middle. from there aim for left hand jam above the next ledge and them right hand lock in next constriction. bump feet on the various knobs out left and right. get right feet on top of knob left of crack to bump left hand to knob and crack high up, get left feet to another knobs. To pull the final move, left hand pinky and ring finger lock and then to jug rail. had multiple takes and falls · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fell once pulling over the bulge. Fun crack! Some of the jams are a bit hard since it flairs at the top. · TR. Very hard wide fingers. Need to figure out how to properly jam up top. Route isn’t as long as it looks because bottom is easy. Would love to project if not for the heinous approach. · Lead / Fell/Hung. great pitch. fell at the crux but wasn't due to lack of effort! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Adventurous first 20 feet. Crack was slightly wet. Flaring jams at the top all felt insecure.

routes.route_description: Start on Snowblind/Bravo Jean Marc. Climb up toward Snowblind arete on splitter cracks and knobs. Once on a night ledge climb up stunning crimps and bolts. Save a .3 or .4 piece for just under the anchor
routes.route_location: Right side
routes.route_protection: cams and bolts

route_comments.comment_text: This is my least favorite of the routes in the vicinity but does provide an easier way to throw a rope on Cornucopia - Snowblind. If you're short, getting off the ledge could be a shut down. Edit: Re-climbed recently and I take it back. It's still quite reachy but very fun. May 6, 2021

routes.route_description: Pitch one is fairly well-travelled. Pitch two may not have seen an ascent in the last fifteen years. The first pitch corner has it all; well, almost! Thin, funky climbing off the ground leads to a lieback past two bolts to a crack and a stance under a roof. Crack, face climbing past wild jugs and finally stemming leads to a tricky crux finish. Spectacular climbing.P2 climbs a slab up to the Beach. 5.10+ R; most likely not equipped for ('safe') free climbing.
routes.route_location: From the waterfall, this area is to the right and past a subsidiary wall and the entrance to the Cheeks, which is accessed from a long ledge (the Beach) via 4th and 5th class scrambling and climbing.
routes.route_protection: Nuts and small cams to a #4 Camalot, I believe. The bolts on the route are old but have continued to hold falls. Fixed anchor.

route_comments.comment_text: As of last spring (2008) p2 was maybe only bit dirtier than I remember it being in the 80s.  It was never "cleaned" and never had fixed pins.  I think I placed two pins while leading it in the 80's.  The top bolt midway up p1 is a 20+ yo Star Drive that is probably not strong enough to withstand a long fall, so be advised if you decide to run it out to the bomber jams at the roof. From the... more As of last spring (2008) p2 was maybe only bit dirtier than I remember it being in the 80s.  It was never "cleaned" and never had fixed pins.  I think I placed two pins while leading it in the 80's.  The top bolt midway up p1 is a 20+ yo Star Drive that is probably not strong enough to withstand a long fall, so be advised if you decide to run it out to the bomber jams at the roof. From the Beach it is easy to descend this route and set up a TR.  Look for a single safety bolt used to protect reaching the real anchors atop p2.  Birds occasionally nest near this route in the spring. If they are around it is best to stay away. Like many other Index routes if it was located in Yosemite it would be a world famous classic. (Only a slight bit of hyperbole) Dec 30, 2008
I cleaned some old webbing off the p1 anchor and added a nice new shiny bolt now there are three 3/8 bolts. P2 looks really cool. Mar 8, 2013

No sweat Drew I enjoy fixing up anchors when I can . You know Clay would be an ultimate link up with p3 and 4 of the zipper . A real testpiece for someone looking to on sight five eleven at Index . Jun 13, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Every part is the crux. Burly! Bouldery start to power liebackinf around bolts on small feet. Fist jams at roof, some hard stemming, and finally a heartbreakingly slopey ledge for the finish mantle · 3 pitches. TR. TR Soloed this thing 3 times. Need to rebelay just below the final move off a .3 and .4. Place plenty of directionals or you'll spin off into space as the route overhangs like 10 feet and traverses about 15 feet. I was able to link from ground to just below the roof. I didn't figure out how to do the last move. Gear seems solid, however I'm unsure how to protect the opening moves. · TR. So good! With good conditions, it wouldn't feel too bad. Slipped out of a handjam after the lieback and fell a few times at the top crux before figuring it out. Gotta get the right foot up to the knob on the right wall · TR. First round of the session didn't get a proper warm up. First section felt okay then just need to work out the beta and move faster on the lay-back section. And the top Crux is nuts. Real fun roof. Hand jam move. · TR. What an ass kicker. Fell at the sloper on second burn! Amazing pitch. Stem up (set feet right and push hard) to reach lh crimp on sloper ramp, rh to hidden crimp (order may be reversed I forget), work feet up, rh to sloper, lh to good further knob, feet, rh to Gaston sloper, pop to anchor jug. · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. Save .2 and .3 for top, 3 for roof. No 1s needed, but several .75s used · 1 pitch. Lead / Redpoint. With Rio. P1 only. 7 TR laps, 1st lead go. Didn't have the gear totally dialed but still sent. Must be a low gravity day. · TR. Made it to top crux, but had to hang and get sprayed down to figure it out. Felt good! But would be a hard lead · 1 pitch. TR. Hung a lot but did all the moves clean. Thuggy and so good! · TR. 3 TR burns followed Ben’s first lead burn with dying light on the last. · 1 pitch. TR. Top roped twice. Was able to figure out all the moves, it definitely goes. Lieback is only really necessary necessary for like two moves to move right foot up and stem higher. Below the small roof/no hands rest the beta is to stay mostly straight in the crack until possible to move left foot up. Then more stemming to jug, to get to the chains, stem from top of jug, stay low and hand traverse left on slopers until finding a good left hand and getting left foot up on ledge. · 1 pitch. TR. with Aaron. did all the moves except wet top out boulder problem. pretty cool route.. stemming, laybacks, fist and hand jams · 1 pitch. TR. W/ Ben hung a few times, but did all the moves to the wet last 15 ft. Super inspiring route!!!

routes.route_description: A short chimney with slashes of quartz. A good warmup for other lines in the area. Fun chimney moves. Extend the anchor over the lip if planning to toprope. Still a little loose rocks in the back of the chimney but quickly cleaning up
routes.route_location: Far right side of the Lower Cheeks near the Diamond
routes.route_protection: Gear to 4"

routes.route_description: Climb a slightly overhung thin crack down low to a bolt and work in small but good gear carefully. Do a bouldery move to gain a ledge and go left to a big hollow flake with bolts.
routes.route_location: Left of Bravo Jean Marc
routes.route_protection: Small Cams and nuts, Qds

route_comments.comment_text: The opening crack is fantastic and very clean. The exit to the ledge can either be Indexy or a wild dynamic leap. May 6, 2021

Fun route, lots of knobs on the side of the crack for feet. Once the crack tapers off where your finger can't fit in, I found a combination of chicken winging to shift weight left and right a way to inch up the crack. Jun 26, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. I came out of the first move and ended at the start then sent. So not technically an onsight. · TR. quite hard to reach the first bolt because ledge could be mossy. knobs help for the feet, lots of small finger jams but also chicken wing and transfer weight from side to side. final move was left hand undercling slap right hand and also smear left feet to jug. lots of 0.1 and 0.0, or nuts. top flake seems quite hollow and thin

routes.route_description: A mostly bolted climb with wonderful bouldery moves . The bottom moves are fun and balancy. The true crux is a tough techy reach.
routes.route_location: Far right side of cheeks
routes.route_protection: QDs, finger sized cams

route_comments.comment_text: Bolt added at the crack switch now it is very safe. One could still place an optional cam above the third bolt for pulling onto the ledge. Jul 16, 2018
the tough techy reach is very tough and techy. cool little route. May 21, 2019

routes.route_description: Great sport climb, starts with technical slab with thin layback 11-.This leads to a 10+ mantel which brings one to large ledge. Jugs lead to a bulge with a powerful crux 11+. A climber has fallen from near the top and slammed into the wall hard enough to crack a rib, so don't blow the final moves... Its all there just slightly committing if going for the onsight.
routes.route_location: To the right of Friendly Fire starts on same ledge system
routes.route_protection: Handful of quickdraws

route_comments.comment_text: Easy & dry access for setting up a TR, and the route tends to stay dry in wet weather, so it is a great route for working. It has somewhat slabby, technical moves at the bottom, a thoughtful mantle, and then a pumpy finish (which I haven't yet gotten). Apr 1, 2013

Also thought this pitch was high quality, 3.5 stars. The opening slab-to-mantel is classic slab dancing requiring precise and powerful movement. I blew the crux clip with rope out and my belayer's attentiveness kept me off the slab below but caution is certainly warranted.  The clip is tricky and the sequence is hardest at that point. Mar 11, 2015

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Only putting the right foot on and flagging the left at the beginning of the start of the Crux is the move and then you go right left right hand to the bench and then left hand up on the ball. Rotate right foot into a toe from a heel hug that felt good. · Solo. New high point to the base of the Crux. Going out left for the small crimp with lh , rh okay pinch , rf slot ,lf smear high. Then toss lh up to get the okay rail. Step rf up to top of pinch rh into crimp pocket then move rf out to smear and compress the left side and right side and rock over. · TR. Bottom slab feels good now, make sure to grab the highest left hand crimp before reaching up for the rail. Can't reach if not there. Approach mantle from left side and get right foot up. High. Move fast through jugs on the bottom. Toss right foot heel. Hook up quickly till get right hand high and the first crack left hand pulls through the second crack. Stand on heel step left toe through and smear right foot while going up for the left hand and then right into the bulb. Right foot toe jam in the upper slot right hand in the cramp left hand goes way out into bad sharp crab. Stand up smear left foot stand grab ledge left hand p · TR. first go, made it over the slab, up over the mantle and then up into the jugs into the big move to the right hand. from there some beta needs to be figured out but its pure power for the next 10 moves! Soooo COOL · Lead / Flash. Watched Vinny go up first was able to hold the flash together · Lead / Fell/Hung. This route slaps. Gotta focus on getting a higher but bomber left foot at slap crux. Reaching rail was tough too. Don’t mis crimps up and left. I was very pumped at the end, try to get left hand on knob. Twist foot in crack and grab next hold with. Squeeze arete and get right pinch, right foot up. Last move was desperate as well, just trusted some really bad feet and cranked on crack. Thankfully there was a good hold up there

routes.route_description: Climb powerful moves on "Not Sheer Strength" (AKA LaBomba Roof) and finish up a forearm intensive rail using heel hooks or a more simple campus technique. Actually pretty fun.  Originally graded 13a/b. 13a seems appropriate. Personally the crux moves on NSS is the crux. ALWAYS DRY.
routes.route_location: Same start as Attractive Nuisance. Both routes starting just right of the Zipper pitch 1.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: hell yeah Oct 3, 2018
How are the bolts on these? I remember them looking a little questionable a couple years ago. Oct 3, 2018
They seem to be holding falls rated at 110# :-> Oct 8, 2018

routes.route_fa: Michal Rynkiewicz, Ryan Hoover, Chandler Davis
routes.route_description: Start up juggy climbing too a boulder problem throwing to two big knobs. From there classic slab moves lead to a shallow corner. Stem and press your way up the fantastic knob studded corner to a small roof, face climb to another corner and anchor
routes.route_location: Left of less than zero, right of short bolted climbs near "outdoor hang board".
routes.route_protection: Quickdraws, cam's, stoppers work really well

route_comments.comment_text: ~12 draws I ran out and there's two pins and a bolt at the top I couldn't see. Small gear and stoppers for the crack. Awesome mixed line, boulder problem is not impossible for an onsite attempt. Definitely harder than the wizard! Sep 6, 2016
Pins are on less than zero, that finishes up at the same anchor but is out of reach from this route. There is a bolt or two up there though! Sep 6, 2016
As good as Act of Strange Boar, there should be lines waiting for this climb Sep 9, 2016

routes.route_description: Start on a flake just left of The Zipper. Pull up onto the slab. The crux is a little above the level of the corner on the Zipper P1, after which is a long leadout. Trend up and right back to the Zipper P1 anchor.Can be TRed using the Zipper anchor.
routes.route_location: About 20 feet left of The Zipper.
routes.route_protection: Five bolts.It has been rebolted since its old X-rated days, but it still might be a good idea to first check it out on toprope.

route_comments.comment_text: Should we possibly re-bolt? May 23, 2018
Indeed, someone should. The existing bolts seem pretty useless. May 24, 2018

I was thinking about it in the Fall, any idea how to contact the FA? Update: I was able to contact the FA thanks to Jon, he is fine with it being rebolted as long as it retains some of its original character. I'll happily do this when I'm back in town late June/July but if someone beats me to it that's fine by me! May 24, 2018

routes.route_description: A short but worthwhile route on quality stone.  Makes a good warm up or combines well with the Zipper, Sideshow, Davis Holland for a moderate day of UTW craging.Start by climbing up the right side of a large flake, no pro but its easy and juggy.  Clip a bolt and pull on to a slab (easier than it looks).  The climbing above in the corner involves stemming, liebacks, high steps, and the usual Index trickery.
routes.route_location: On the left side of the Lower Cheeks. The start is on a mound that sits higher than the rest of the routes in the vicinity.
routes.route_protection: Six draws plus biners for the anchor. The anchor is the start of the Perverse Traverse.

route_comments.comment_text: The route has very fun, somewhat tricky moves between good rests. There are only six bolts, but they are in just the right places. The route can stay dry in a light rain, as do a number of other nearby routes. Mar 12, 2013
The big flake at the start moves quite a lot.... tread lightly Mar 20, 2024

We mantled onto the flake (which isn't attached to the wall at all) to start, which may not be the right way to do the route. If the flake fell it most likely wouldn't hit the belayer, but could potentially hit a leg or the rope. Jun 4, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. Honestly love it, don't forget to go straight up from 1st bolt...mono is angelic · Lead. Climbed with Burgess - the flake to the first bolt is ready to go I ended up pulling on the draw and not messing with it. Fun stemming and an enjoyable route. Dont fall to the first bolt! · TR. fun climb was hard on TR solo with the rope pressure pulling me off the wall. Really good corner climbing · Lead / Onsight. first corner was quite hard to read. move to the right. · TR. Had to rope pull up the stemming section, just couldn't get it started

routes.route_fa: (TR) Darryl Cramer, Terry Lien (Lead) Steve Gerberding
routes.route_description: Use knobs to step up and into the corner to start the route.  Follow cracks up to a small roof near the top and move right to join the last moves on the Green Room.This route received a thorough retro cleaning in May 2013.  All loose blocks were dislodged and it is now a solid, protectable and quality lead for the grade.
routes.route_location: This is the obvious corner crack between Black Planet and the Green Room directly below the huge detached block on the Ledge above.It can be lead on gear or easily set up as a top rope by walking out onto the ledge above.
routes.route_protection: Standard rack to 2.5"Two bolt anchor(4/2013) on wall above Perverse Traverse ledge.

route_comments.comment_text: Nice to hear that it got easier from its old 10+ grade. I guess that tends to happen when routes get fully cleaned off. And it's great to have another moderate route in the area, with Black Planet and Friendly Fire nearby. May 13, 2013
Fun little route, make sure to save some small gear for the top (BD #.2ish). Sep 15, 2016
can this be rope soloed by hiking around and setting a rope from on top? Jul 22, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Onsight. The cracks were all soaked until the traverse, fun and adventury · Lead. Gear pre placed by partner up to roof. Took at roof for a look, made traverse first attempt, ran it out to the anchors. Could have probably done without clipping the bolt to the right on the next door route, it caused rope drag to the finish. Great first route at index. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Save black totem for top. Extend piece before roof moves. First Index 5.9 lead! · TR. decent climb. bit funky at parts. blowing the Cruz moves has potential for a ledge fall. · TR. First clean send at Index. Woo! Super fun to top out into the perverse traverse

routes.route_description: Climb up knobs past bolts to a difficult stem at a small bulge.  Finish up left facing corner.
routes.route_location: The route starts just right of the Gerberding Route on a large knob.
routes.route_protection: Bolts and a few small cams for the final moves.Uses a two bolt anchor (April 2013) on the wall above the Perverse Traverse ledge.  Can be easily set up as a toprope from the PT.

route_comments.comment_text: Awesome knobs! Instead of finishing on gear in the left facing corner, you can go right and climb a sweet knobby arête with a couple bolts. I think that this is the finish of Heat Seeker. Stays dry in the rain except for the start. Apr 8, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Felt really easy except for choreographed crux (undercling right hand to drop knee left foot important) · Lead / Redpoint. Did not use rail out to far right after first sloper at crux. · TR. TRS. Not sure whether the rail out to the right after crux move from undercling is in but... I assume not? · TR. Weird stem + hard mantle crux. For the stem move get rf up first onto big undercling block. Then drop knee lf. Rh side pull crimp in crack, then lh to big crimp on slab. Then lunge for sloper/jug · 2 pitches. TR. 2 laps TRS. Many of the moves seemed inobvious and I feel that this would be a pretty hard onsight for the grade. · Lead / Fell/Hung. with Aaron. felt stupidly hard and scary. don't try again not worth it · TR. hung once or twice at crux, but figured it out. it would be hard to make the crux clip on lead

routes.route_description: Step off block and climb up and left.One bolt followed by some thin cracks brings you to a good stance below a steep bulge.  Another bolt gets you past the bulge with difficulty and on your way to the finish.
routes.route_location: Start off large block 15' right of The Green Room.
routes.route_protection: Two bolts and a small handful of small cams as well as a #1 and #2 Camalot.There is a two bolt anchor on the wall above the Perverse Traverse ledge.  This route can be easily set up as a top rope by walking out onto the ledge above.

route_comments.comment_text: An overlooked gem. Sep 30, 2016
Fantastic sequences and very accessible at the grade. Aug 28, 2020

Id say this route is criminally underrated, if the boulder problem at the second bolt was on the ground it would likely get 3-4 stars in Leavenworth, the rest of the climb has really good movement on it as well. May 2, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. Climbed with Burgess - Took me 4 attempts to get through the boulder problem - it seems repeatable after figuring out the sequence. The layback to thin fingers I think will be the crux for me - never quite felt comfortable. Gear seems pretty manageable if I come back to lead it. Fun top rope session! · TR. Dam this thing is hard. The first crux has with the compression move is a show stopper at the moment need some new beta

routes.route_description: Obvious steep line between Heat Seeker and Friendly Fire
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Alright Tom! I remember this beautiful line. More pics please- Jun 27, 2016
I tr'd this thing last week.  Absolutely amazing line!  One of best fully bolted pitches at Index. Jun 29, 2016
Fantastic, aesthetic line. Congrats, Tom! Jul 3, 2016

routes.route_tick_comments: · TR. With Anna, got all the moves at least!! So hard, doable but also impossible. Tape on right hand back two helped immensely for the finger crack crank. Don’t think I’ll use a pad but pants is also nice, I think getting a knee bar/ scum for the last moves to the slopers could be useful. · Lead / Redpoint. The first boulder is a really cool one. The second boulder I found easier to face left. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got to last move, with two or three falls I think....

routes.route_fa: Michal Rynkiewicz, Ryan Hoover, Derek Person
routes.route_description: Clip a bolt down low and make a few moves to a flake. Place a small stopper or two and make a powerful move to a jug.
routes.route_location: Far right side of cheeks
routes.route_protection: Qds. small/medium cams, nuts

route_comments.comment_text: I've done this climb a few different times now and I think it's worth sharing some gear beta: Bring your brassies! You'll want the brassies since the bolting at the crux makes this climb tough for people who are shorter than 6 feet. It's impossible to clip the bolt by the crux move off of any of the decent holds. I am 5'8" and my partner is 5'10" and neither of us could reach the bolt at... more I've done this climb a few different times now and I think it's worth sharing some gear beta: Bring your brassies! You'll want the brassies since the bolting at the crux makes this climb tough for people who are shorter than 6 feet. It's impossible to clip the bolt by the crux move off of any of the decent holds. I am 5'8" and my partner is 5'10" and neither of us could reach the bolt at the crux from the obvious "clipping undercling" (we were several inches away.) Luckily, you can place a bomber brass nut while on this undercling. You could try to clip the bolt from your next stance, but it will still be very difficult to reach (The move is full wingspan and harder than 5.10- ... but do keep in mind that the climb is a one-move wonder) Anyways, it definitely works to haul on your nut to get that bolt clipped if you are under 6 feet tall... or you could just clip using the climb's crux hold! Sep 4, 2018
But the nut is bomber!! Get on Supernaught/Electric Funeral! Those are great. Snowblind is brilliant. Sep 4, 2018
The nut is very bomber and there is a good position to clip the bolt before reaching. Get on it, the crux is rad! May 6, 2021

routes.route_description: I don't know anything about this climb other than it is chipped and looks very cool. The climb follows and obvious crack up to and through a roof, just to the right of Attractive Nuisance.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Perhaps this is chipped--but it certainly is difficulty to see exactly where. Originally rated 12C I believe--but honestly feels more like 12d in real sport thug grades Oct 1, 2018

routes.route_tick_comments: · with Aaron. put draws up with stick clip. felt crazy hard couldn't do a move · Lead / Redpoint. 2nd go, felt more like 5.12d, I've climbed comparable 5.13- in other areas

routes.route_description: This is the obvious extremely overhung prow of La Bomba Roof. It was inspected ages ago by Max Dufford and currently has two bolts. If it were possible it would be climbed via huge compression moves. A totally sick feature, but does it go???
routes.route_location: Right of Not Sheer Strength
routes.route_protection: Two bolts at the moment

routes.route_description: A thin crack that snakes up to a ledge. From the ledge step right and clip a bolt following a thin balancy dike to the top with a small tcu or two. The bottom of the crack takes good small nuts and small tcus but are difficult to place. A bolt has been added since the FA so now it no longer has the spicy start.
routes.route_location: Far right
routes.route_protection: Small cams, Quickdraw, nuts, hb offsets

route_comments.comment_text: A bolt has been added at the tricky thin start so now it is safe with no pg rating. Jul 16, 2018

Did this last Sat. Was a nice short route...perhaps more like 55'?  It did seem harder to me than Bravo Jean Marc crack which I did after; and I'd say not easy fodder for the 5.10 climber. Perhaps micro cams help, but I couldn't seem to protect the last 15' between the last bolt and the anchor--couldn't find any purchase with micro nuts. Aug 26, 2018
Ben i recall placing a purple tcu up high. I can also go back and add another bolt. Aug 27, 2018

routes.route_description: This is a linkup of the bottom half of Cornucopia and the top half of Bravo Jean Marc. Climb Cornucopias slightly overhung bouldery splitter. From a small ledge break over to where you can traverse over to Bravo Jean Marc insanely amazing crack. Unfortunately Cornucopia tends to grow over with brush seasonally
routes.route_location: Starts just Left of Bravo Jean Marc
routes.route_protection: Doubles of cams. Small nuts for down low

route_comments.comment_text: Nice name. Rather tranquil. Jun 27, 2018

routes.route_description: Start up Bravo Jean Marc and after 15ft head up toward the chimney at base of knob-studded arete. Slap heel hook and balance up the sharp arete with an interesting movement. Once it slopes out make a engaging sequential move to an often wet crimp. Then a few more  amazing slopey body tension moves to the top.
routes.route_location: start on Bravo Jean Marc
routes.route_protection: cams, Qds.

route_comments.comment_text: Have yet to redpoint this but holy smokes it's good! Perplexing but cool slab crux up high Nov 21, 2018

This thing is loaded with fantastic movement and it's easy to pull through the slab crux up high if needed. I thought this was a big step up from any other 5.11 in the area but only for one sequence. May 6, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Damn the crux is hard. Crazy compression and smearing out to the good crimp. Then I had to do a ridiculously high hand foot match.

routes.route_description: A thin crack with a bolt down low. Great bouldery movement that keeps one on their toes!
routes.route_location: Far right side
routes.route_protection: cams, nuts

route_comments.comment_text: This thing is very awkward but the off-balance movement keeps it super fun! I found the crux to be a quite a bit harder than 10b. May 6, 2021

routes.route_description: Follows and awkward, left-leaning, flaring corner just right of The Zipper.Has its harder sections near the ground and up near the end. Joins the same belay as The Zipper.
routes.route_location: Obvious corner forming the right side of the slab.
routes.route_protection: Gear to 3".

route_comments.comment_text: Looks worthy of a cleaning. This would add to the list of dry enough to climb routes for the wet season. Nov 28, 2016

routes.route_fa: Michal Rynkiewicz, Chandler Davis, Ryan Hoover
routes.route_description: Start by walking your feet up the groove of Less Than Zero and laybacking the left arete of the pillar. Once you can reach around the right arete slap up the right side until you can compress.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Bolts

route_comments.comment_text: Awesome sport climb! What's up with the thin crack above?? Sep 6, 2016
That's where we wanted to finish. Much harder then the moves below. An extension may be possible. Sep 6, 2016
There's a bolted route on the right of the arete and this route. Anyone know what it is? Jun 26, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. with Aaron. dog and stick clip. tricky after clipping 3rd bolt have to get right foot up using a left foot smear and crimps · Lead / Onsight. Feel like I stayed in the corner too long. Started climbing the face around the 3rd bolt · Lead / Fell/Hung. Took at bolts 3, 4 and 5. Probably could have done without taking at 4 or 5 but was scared of whipping on Aimee and didn’t trust the side compression just yet. · TR. too hot. weird climb, seems like it isn't bolted for the way that's obvious to climb it in the lower section. stick clip would be a good idea given that the start is on an exposed hillside.

routes.route_fa: (P1): Mark Weigelt, 70 (P2-4): Dennis Fenstermaker, Brent Hoffman, Karl Kaiyala, 71
routes.route_description: Start on the free climb "Zipper".For P2, aid the roof, continue to the Beach.For P3-P6, follow the description for "Up'er Zipper", which is in "The Beach" section of the Upper Town Walls. Or, click here:mountainproject.com/v/uper-…
routes.route_location: Same as the Zipper. Just left of the severely overhanging routes. Look for the corner crack at the start.
routes.route_protection: From small wired stoppers to 3" cams. The aid roof requires small pins.

routes.route_description: The first pitch is often climbed as it is a fun .10 slab/thin crack.Pitch 2 is the obvious roof that is visible from the road. Pitch 4 starts from the Beach, so is technically on the Upper Cheeks.For pitch 1, climb a steep 5.9 corner with a crack to access the slab. Thin crack and crux slab climbing lead to a bolted, chain anchor below the roof. Continue via aid or descend. One 70-m rope is more than enough to rap off or toprope.
routes.route_location: Around the corner to the right of Clay and All Dogs Go to Heaven is this slab with an obvious corner below it. Descend with a 60m rope.
routes.route_protection: Gear small to 2 inch. Fixed rappel anchor on top of P1. Other pitches probably require pins, etc. and the condition of their anchors is unknown.

route_comments.comment_text: The first pitch is a fun mix of slab and crack climbing. Another big plus is that it, as well as several routes just to the right, can be climbed in a light rain. Mar 12, 2013

Pitch 3 (5.10) is great and pitch 4 (5.11 a or b)  is absolutely classic. There is also a new pitch that brings the route all the way to the top of the wall. This route is not to be missed! Jun 13, 2013

I completely agree about pitches 3-5: they should not be missed. But they are best approached via the Perverse Traverse (no need for a rope now - just clip into the cable) and walk along "The Beach". May 17, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. very fun start. took after getting big spooked on the seam. top stepped off brass offsets and ballnuts for two body lengths and then free climbed the finish. will definitely come back. exceptional pitch. · Lead / Onsight. Bring 3+ bd 0.4, small nuts and offsets, plenty of draws. Placed a 5 at the start for Derrek. You never know. · Lead / Redpoint. Save .5 & .75 for top next time. Used all the brassies. W/ Ben · TR. at crux where you can place a 0.1 in the pocket about 2/3rds of the way up, use undercling just above that, use right hand crimp, get left foot to left side of the crack and step up into that foot and then get right foot up. lots of gear below 0.3, bring nuts (small ones). · Lead / Flash. Tried a bunch of stuff around the wall after this but it was all wet and licheny so it was a lot of downclimbing · Lead. Fell just below the anchors. Caught my ankle in a nut causing multiple fractures. Almost a week had passed r extraction of involving crawling, butt scooting, and using people as crutches. Heading into surgery currentoy · Lead. Whipped on black totem near top. Sad. Come back on a cooler day · Follow. Fun route and I loved following Logan and Josh after an awesome pancake breakfast at Josh’s fancy book mobile rig · Follow. funky corner to thin crack. finger lock and smearing crux. would probably feel easier and hurt my pinky less if I trusted my feet more. · Lead / Onsight. Got it on first go. Rather tricky gear placements and a bit greasy after being in the sun. A proud onsight for sure. · Super fun and did this one clean on TR. the bottom has finger cracks but good features on the face for feet, and up top got really thin and slabby. · Lead / Fell/Hung. fell at crux, couldn't commit. bring triples black thru .5, then not as much time in stances fiddling nuts in. · Lead / Fell/Hung. .75 for after the easier Corner, then Thin. Lots of brassies! · Lead / Redpoint. Tried this a year or 2 ago and got nervous about small gear and nuts and hung a bunch. Went great this time. Red ball nut. Didn’t place as many small nuts as Bring a 1 a maybe 1or 2 number 2’s. Lots of smal stuff like . 3. Red alien and two .5 · Lead / Onsight. I left the small nuts on the ground. That was a mistake. · TR. TR'd 2x. Hung once 1st, clean on 2nd. FUN CLIMB! will have to lead when comfy @ grade.

area_description: The Beach, specifically the wide ledge at the base of the Upper Cheeks, stretches from the Perverse Traverse rightward to the gully next to the Diamond. The white faces of the Upper Cheeks house some of the steepest climbs in the area.Because of it's lofty position, rock here stays relatively cool in the summer heat when the lower walls are unbearable. Yet the area does not retain cold pockets of air on clear winter days. Sunlight strikes the walls in the morning, leaving the rock in the shade from the early afternoon.With the adjacent areas of The Black Sea and the Lower Cheeks, this area has a concentration of climbing that rivals in quality and surpasses in scenic beauty any of the more traveled classics of the Lower Wall.For instance, the 2nd pitch of the Up'er Zipper is as good as steep crack climbing gets in an astounding alpine position. Normandy overhangs 20' and stays completely dry even in a steady rain. As do the top rope-able routes directly below on the Lower Cheeks.
area_getting_there: A common approach from the left side is via the Perverse Traverse.As of March 2013, one can just clip into a thick cable and shuffle across to the Beach, completely protected. No rope is needed, and no perversity.

routes.route_description: A hard boulder problem guards an intricate, technical lieback, arete, overlap on perfect, clean rock.
routes.route_location: This is the first route to the right of Apes and Ballerinas. There is a large, fin-shaped flake of rock just above the first bolt. The route follows the clean, white arete.
routes.route_protection: Seven quick draws (if my memory serves me) and an optional purple or purple/blue tcu (this cam will only shorten a fall by a foot or two. Not really necessary).Steel shuts at the top.

route_comments.comment_text: No repeats yet Jun 8, 2019
Stamati Anagnostou repeated A Wisdom that is Woe today. 2nd ascent? Feb 12, 2022
Great pitch. It's like a V7 boulder to a good rest to another V7, the first powerful and dynamic and the second insecure and specific. 8a all day. Feb 15, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Finally! 5.5 years in the making lol. Great pitch, super technical and specific.

routes.route_description: Pull off the ground on slightly gritty rock.  After a few moves, the rock quality improves and becomes some of the whitest at Index.  Several stem and balance cruxes guard the chains. A crux for shorter climbers comes lower and a crux for taller climbers comes higher on the route.
routes.route_location: Technically on the Upper Cheeks.  This sport route is the bolted line immediately left of Apes and Ballerinas.
routes.route_protection: 8 bolts to chains.

route_comments.comment_text: Quality!  Keeps comin' at ya with the Index trickery. May 14, 2016
The rock is pretty gritty (cat litter); however this climb is really unique with three hard 5.11 cruxes.  Its on the verge of being a four star classic. Nov 6, 2019
Only the first 5 feet of the climb are slightly scaley. The rest is absolute perfect rock. Jan 29, 2025

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Fun climbing on very nice rock. A few cruxes. At 3rd or 4th, undercling knob with left, Gaston crack with right, left foot up on slippery knob. Next crux have left hand in lower juggy side pull? Right hand gas toning higher chalked one, right foot on small king on arete and go for jug. Higher crux I pressed left hand out on seam/ slab, Gaston arrowhead hood right, move right up and get left hand on that hold, scum shoulder and bump right foot up and get the pinch. Then I gastoned left hand out and stemmed my feet up to next pinch/ jug · Lead / Redpoint. Slipped before clipping the first bolt, then stickclipped and onsighted the rest of it.

routes.route_description: P1: Climb a fist crack in a corner. The crux is a blocky overhanging section. Belay on a ledge on the right side.P2: Climb up and right, then follow a left-leaning thin crack through a knobby wall.
routes.route_location: On the right side of the Upper Cheeks, about 20 feet right of Upper Zipper.
routes.route_protection: Wide pieces for P1, mostly thin pieces for P2. P2 has several fixed pieces.

route_comments.comment_text: P1 has an anchor on the left side of the route. This confused me, so I kept climbing, linking the two pitches into 1 amazing climb! At the top of the finger crack, traverse right 15' to an anchor with fixed locking carabiniers. Lower to the ground with a 70m rope. Good warmup for the area. Oct 1, 2016

Beware the choss. Belayer should probably stand off to the side a bit. There's a bit of chossy rock toward the top. I stood on a particularly solid-looking chunk a few years ago and it ripped out. I came back and rapped it and bashed out some of the choss, but it would take more dechossing efforts to really remove the rockfall danger. Sep 1, 2017

Cool climb in an awesome position, very similar in style to the Upper Zipper p2. Linking into 1 long pitch is definitely the way to go- you’ll remember how strong ballerinas are at the end! Multiples of 0.4 won’t go unused. The rock at the top is somewhat grainy but could clean up nicely with a wire brush or more traffic. The top anchor is just 2 old SMC bolts (no rap rings), but traversing... more Cool climb in an awesome position, very similar in style to the Upper Zipper p2. Linking into 1 long pitch is definitely the way to go- you’ll remember how strong ballerinas are at the end! Multiples of 0.4 won’t go unused. The rock at the top is somewhat grainy but could clean up nicely with a wire brush or more traffic. The top anchor is just 2 old SMC bolts (no rap rings), but traversing 15 feet right allows you to reach a more modern anchor. Does anyone know what the low-angle knobby face above goes at? It looks like it could top out the Cheeks at a moderate grade, but it looked mossy and we weren’t sure what kind of anchors (if any) lie above. Sep 24, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead. Ok route. Not sure I would do it again. Bottom was fine but friable rock up higher

routes.route_fa: Chandler D, Michal R, Ryan H
routes.route_description: P1 - Start in the cave right of Between the Cheeks. Exit the cave right (straight up is Levee) and you will see an intermediate anchor after a couple more bolts.P2 - There is a couple ways to go about the 2nd pitch. The arete above the P1 anchor is a closed project!Option 1: Mega Pitch - use long slings or skip bolts to link the first pitch into the second. Rest up and continue to the right and up through some of the best stone index has to offer.Option 2: Project P2 without P1 - My favorite option. Set up a fixed line at the anchor and jug up to P2 while the belayer enjoys the good life on the beach ledge. Probably the most fun way to tackle p2 and takes out any rope drag issues.Option 3: Pitch it out and belay at anchor - Probably the least fun option, but you could do this. You and the belayer would be tight.
routes.route_location: Start in the cave right of Between the Cheeks
routes.route_protection: Fixed

routes.route_description: Climbs the left wall of a large chimney. The crux is near the middle.If the bottom is wet, consider aiding past to get to very enjoyable sport climbing above.
routes.route_location: About 20 feet right of the start of HREV POBTAZ.
routes.route_protection: About 12 bolts.

route_comments.comment_text: A fun, interesting route with a tickling position up a unique feature high above the Sky valley. Can feel quite a bit harder when the start is wet... Jun 10, 2013
Excellent climbing with a steep exposed lower off. Fairly  clean considering how little traffic this probably gets. Jul 29, 2019

routes.route_description: Thuggy 5.11 leads to a sit down rest below an amazing steep finger tips layback through beautiful white rock. Entirely bolted. One could climb the crack with cams but the expanding appearance and corresponding fracture line leave little confidence that the entire enchilada wound't calve with enough leverage. This route originally ended at the 8th bolt--and provides an opportunity to lower off before the moves get even harder.  Likely to have fixed draws in place.
routes.route_location: Just left of "Wisdom That is Woe".
routes.route_protection: Bolts

routes.route_description: Amazing.Steep.Clean and FUN.P1 is 11b/cP2 is 11d
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: small to #2#3 optional for P2

route_comments.comment_text: Start R of a chain anchor (currently the right-most anchor on the Beach) in a short LFC, then angle L to finish on prow.  I couldn't do all the moves on P1 (time to train pistol-squats), but thought it was brilliant nonetheless. Jul 13, 2018

That photo is very informing, with two ropes would have the length, but might be off the edge. Also hard to tell exactly which route is being rappelled. I did notice a fixed nut on p2 with a carabiner on it, one may be able to clip into that on rappel and make it back to the p1 anchor, or simply clip the chains and lower back down, using a quickdraw attached to the other side of the rope to... more That photo is very informing, with two ropes would have the length, but might be off the edge. Also hard to tell exactly which route is being rappelled. I did notice a fixed nut on p2 with a carabiner on it, one may be able to clip into that on rappel and make it back to the p1 anchor, or simply clip the chains and lower back down, using a quickdraw attached to the other side of the rope to avoid swinging out. I will go back and check it out for sure. Mar 10, 2015
Kerwinl, go to the beach photos and look at "index steep" photo . That should answer your question . Lol. I think you need two ropes . Mar 9, 2015

routes.route_name: Heaven's Rear-Entry Vehicle, Parked Out Back, Tow Away Zone
routes.route_fa: Isao Fujita & Jon Nelson (p1), Nicola Masciandaro & Jon Nelson (full)
routes.route_description: The easiest route up the Cheeks formation and featuring an interesting range of climbing, including passing through a chimney.The first pitch is short, but steep, with the crux (~10a) being awkward hand jamming over a bulge. Despite the appearance at the bottom, you do not chimney here -- the start has a layback flake on the left side of the chimney. Ends just below the chimney, or continue by linking it with P2.Pitch two goes through the chimney (that is "through", not just up -- you kind of vanish inside of it). When you exit above the chimney, follow the fist-wide hands crack (crux) to a ledge in a corner system.For pitch three, follow the corner to the top.Descend either by rappel via the gully between the cheeks and the Upper Town Wall, or use the recently installed anchors on God's Bones. If you do the latter, remember to swing into the rock at the end, otherwise you'll be left dangling.
routes.route_location: Starts near the end of the Perverse Traverse.
routes.route_protection: Full range of sizes, up to fist-sized cams.

route_comments.comment_text: nice story, not every day one gets the FA team story. I would like to see this some more. Is a fist size cam a #4 camalot? Mar 21, 2016
Thanks Geoff. We have the space here to add some history, so why not? The fist-sized cam was a #4 friend, which I think is smaller than the #4 camalot. Mar 22, 2016
oh good I have 2 #4 friends.- a #4 camelot is more fists for me. Jan 21, 2020

routes.route_description: Easy fun bolted OW. Once this dries out it's actually quite enjoyable and not even that painful. Pop a TR on Merman and make it double for some good crack climbing.
routes.route_location: Right of between the cheeks, left of Merman.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

routes.route_description: Fun steep crack climbing that protects well. Easy to set up a TR from the Mermaid. These climbs take a bit to dry out, but are quite fun when they do!
routes.route_location: To the right of between the cheeks and left of Under-medicated
routes.route_protection: Standard Index Rack

route_comments.comment_text: You finally adding these routes to MP? LOL Feb 21, 2022
For your pleasure! Maybe one day we will get to the rest lol. Feb 23, 2022

routes.route_description: Multiple cruxes requiring a variety of skills. This route overhangs 20' feet over 90' and stays dry even in a steady rain once it has stopped seeping after the winter months.Fun climbing on clean rock with incredible exposure. Use a 70-m rope and be careful while lowering off.
routes.route_location: The route starts off of a large boulder just at the end of the Perverse Traverse and just left of Heaven's Rear Entry Vehicle Parked Out Back, Tow-away Zone. There is a lone bolt on a rock below near the top edge of the lower cliff that makes a good belay position when it's not raining. From here it is possible for the belayer to see the entire climb.
routes.route_protection: 12-14 quick draws and a #2 Camalot.

route_comments.comment_text: I am pretty sure that a 60m will get you down, but DO tie a knot in the end of the rope. Also... This route is classic! If it were at the lower wall it would be as popular as anything else. -b May 29, 2013
Someone said Tom did the FA just using gear, but added bolts so others would climb it. Jul 23, 2013

Pretty awesome climbing, but quite hard and cryptic at the roof.  It took a really long time to get the rope up.  The rock is still a little flaky at the bottom, but should clean up with time.  If the route was a little cleaner and more continuous, I would give it four stars. Oct 3, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Redpoint. Modern classic. Stays clean and dry. This is an exceptional climb imo. · Lead / Redpoint. Nice to see some progression. This felt so hard in 2022, but now seemed reasonable. 3 Sessions. · Lead / Fell/Hung. Got all the moves on my first quest up.:. And it was truly a quest

routes.route_fa: Open Project. Bolted by Nathan Hadley
routes.route_description: I bolted this in the spring of 2023 and was not able to do it before I became a dad in the fall 2023. I returned to in January 2025 and it still felt very hard for me despite the great conditions! At this point, it's been almost two years since I bolted it and other folk should give it a shot.It climbs the first 2-3 bolts of Up'er Zipper P1 then traverse left (V5 or V6) to an undercling jug. Then it's a long V11 or V12 back into the Up'er Zipper. Pretty rad knobs for your feet until they run out!
routes.route_location: Starts on the Up'er Zipper then heads left after the second bolt.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

routes.route_fa: Open project bolted by Max Dufford
routes.route_description: Max Dufford bolted this one in the early 90s. To my knowledge only he and I have given it any efforts, but it is really worth a look for the ambitious ones.Climb the overhung face in lovely pink and white stone, making strenuous moves on edges and pockets to the knobby face above. Extremely bouldery and sustained on some good holds and some poor ones, with three classily enhanced grips to make it possible. This thing is always dry, 24/7/365. Would make a great winter project since it gets sun all day.
routes.route_location: Just east of the notch separating the Cheeks.
routes.route_protection: Bolts

routes.route_description: At one time this crossing (from the Black Sea to the Beach) was mocked by calling it a 5.5 belly crawl. Now it is a clean 5.2 A0 or 5.8+. Perhaps not yet celebrated, but definitely a lot more fun. Try doing it without grabbing the wire or bolt hangers and see how hard you think it is.
routes.route_location: Start in the 'cave' behind the Guardian block, just  above Ted, Ted Nugent and Black Planet, and just below the Black Sea route.
routes.route_protection: Just one piece -- a cable that spans the crossing. Attach a runner or two to your harness and then clip the cable with a locking biner or two. Then slide the biner(s) along as you traverse. When the biner hits an attachment point that holds the cable, just lift the cable up and slide the biner past.If you want to be more sporting, lead it traditionally, hooking your rope over the half-dozen or so attachment points. Belay at the cable anchors.

routes.route_description: Fun little route with some powerful opening moves. Shorter folks may want to stack a rock to reach the first move.Extensions are closed projects!
routes.route_location: Directly right of Normandy and HREV
routes.route_protection: Draws

routes.route_fa: Terry Lien, Tom Michaels (FFA: Michal Rynkiewicz)
routes.route_description: I was lucky enough to get the FFA of this line. Sweet climbing and surprisingly juggy. Wonderful position and features will make anyone smile. Should be done as much as the ltw classics!!!P1 Start of the Terry-Micheals up to the obvious horizontal that takes you to a short roof crack. Pull a moderate boulder problem v4/5 to get established above the roof then enjoy the cruiser .12- splitter tips to hands. .12bP2. Climb the crack off the belay up and right to a left facing corner that you layback to a areteish feature, eventually arriving to a finger layback that leads to anchor. Up 20ft is a block that I could not trundle with just a hammer. It's likely solid. .11I never cleaned the top of p1 and spent very little time cleaning p2. Its climbable but a little grainy due to being so steep. The crux is very clean. This climb is mega and its position is some of the proudest at Index. Make sure to redirect when rappelling p2 to top of p1 or you'll be stuck in space.
routes.route_location: To the right of Terry-Micheals
routes.route_protection: Doublesish to 2"

route_comments.comment_text: Finally!  Never been on this but I did spend an hour watching Tom and Terry thru binoculars from the river. Looked really amazing from there and given the four stars I am guessing you're agreeing from up close. May 10, 2019
Good work on Soulfinger! May 10, 2019
Striking crack that you can see from town without binoculars. May 10, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · Solo. Cleaned the top a bunch, still a bit dirty but at least the moss is gone

routes.route_fa: FFA Thomas Ramier, Derek Pearson, Jon Nelson, Bradley Lignoski
routes.route_description: Amazing pure splitter crack climbing after the first pitch of flakes and bolts. Generally follows the upper 3 pitches of the Zipper aid line.P1: Some semi-strenuous laybacking at the start gives way to fun knobs and flakes, finishing up at a small overlap with a hanging belay (chained anchor). About 10c/d.P2: A crack starts up from the overlap. The first few jams are wide fists, but then the crack becomes thinner, ranging between fingers and hands. Pumpy. The crack continues into a shallow right-facing corner and then meets another overlap with some thin jams. By itself, this is 11a/b.  Can be combined with P1 as one long pitch, it is probably 11b.P3: Follow the same crack line. Climb a steep rib and stem in a short corner. This short pitch is about 10a. Ends at a luscious belay cove.P4: Take the bolted face on the right to the summit. Has some interesting moves to an amazing lofty summit ledge at the top of the cheeks.  about 10a.DecentIf rappeling from the summit: Two raps straight down(stations added 9/4/16).Note: The first rap is a rope stretcher.  If using a 60m rope be very careful.  Tie knots!Alternatively, if using a shorter rope, the descent can be broken into three rappels, stopping first at the top of pitch three.If rappeling from the top of the second pitch: Two short raps straight down(station added 9/4/16)
routes.route_location: Start off the Beach about 25' left of Apes and Ballerinas (aka Stock Options).
routes.route_protection: Standard rack to 3" with extra finger and hand sizes.

route_comments.comment_text: For those with small hands: Gear tip: If wide fist cracks (#4 BD) are very challenging for you, you might want to carry a #4. It is possible to place TCU's in the back of the wide sections, but if you like the security of pushing a cam when you are off-widthing, consider yourself warned. If this route were on the lower wall it would be easily as popular as Sloe Children (Which is amazing,... more For those with small hands: Gear tip: If wide fist cracks (#4 BD) are very challenging for you, you might want to carry a #4. It is possible to place TCU's in the back of the wide sections, but if you like the security of pushing a cam when you are off-widthing, consider yourself warned. If this route were on the lower wall it would be easily as popular as Sloe Children (Which is amazing, don't get me wrong). Recently cleaned this route. Go do it! You won't be sorry. (Be careful about the flake low and to the right near the very end of the route... I stood on it and it held, but be ginger... Now I just don't touch it. You can work around it using chicken heads and such) -b May 29, 2013

Amazing route. Continuously interesting flake & knob climbing up to a short overlap at the end of P1, then a long straight crack for P2. Some leaders combine the two pitches. Pitch 2 is mostly thin hand and fingers, but also has some hand jams and a few fist jams at the start. Pumpy crux at the bottom, more of a technical & power crux at the end. The last two pitches are short, but a blast... more Amazing route. Continuously interesting flake & knob climbing up to a short overlap at the end of P1, then a long straight crack for P2. Some leaders combine the two pitches. Pitch 2 is mostly thin hand and fingers, but also has some hand jams and a few fist jams at the start. Pumpy crux at the bottom, more of a technical & power crux at the end. The last two pitches are short, but a blast as well. Jun 10, 2013

You can link the first two pitches, or endure the hanging belay at the chains on pitch 1.  What may be better would be to climb past the chains on p1, pull the crux OW section, and belay at a good stance above. Jul 24, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · 2 pitches. Lead / Onsight. P1 + fitness lap. Gotta go back for p2! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Linked pitches 1 and 2. Last two pitches were kinda dirty. Fell on the first moves of pitch two. Sent everything else. Crux beta was right fist jam, left ring lock, right gaston, left finger lock, get the feet higher, bump the left to a thin hand jam · Lead. link 1st 2 pitches. bring #4. got 1st pitch clean, come back to get 2nd pitch clean

routes.route_description: Starting in the cave right of Between the Cheeks, follow perma-draws up and right. After turning the corner follow steep jugs straight up for the arm bar crux that protects the chains.The start is shared with Moby Dick (closed project) and The Barnacle.The extension is a closed project!
routes.route_location: Start in the cave right of Between the Cheeks
routes.route_protection: Fixed Draws

route_comments.comment_text: I haven’t climbed it. Just looking at the photos and features. Folks really should put this on their list for the spring. 215 views of this route and 1 tick? I hope this one gets some chalk this summer. Also, 3 stars from Ryan is really five stars. Humble man. Feb 13, 2025 · Temporary Report

area_description: The Black Sea includes all the routes from Jesters Of Chaos over to the route The Black Sea and all routes leading off the giant detached block above Ted, Ted Nugent.This area is sunny, steep and well protected.  Most of the routes above the block require only quick draws, runners and a few small cams from .25" to 1.5"
area_getting_there: From the Lower Wall parking, follow the train tracks to the Country area. Walk to the far right of the clearing, near the start of GM (there may be a notice board up) and follow the obvious path uphill.  After 10min you will come to a fork.  The left fork leads to Blues Cliff and Middle Walls.  Follow the right fork.  After 3-5 more min you will come to a second fork.  The left fork leads to the Upper Wall summit (also Little Elvis and Pajama Rock).  In 8-10 more min you will be at the base of the Upper Wall.  Cross the talus right and continue on the trail until it forks just before dropping downhill steeply.  Take the left fork leading up hill toward the cliff.

routes.route_description: A strenuous and sequential boulder problem ends at a fixed point of aid(V7) and guards the start of this long multi-crux pitch.  Don't rush!
routes.route_location: Climb a short, dirty but unpleasant connector pitch that leaves from the top of the 1st pitch of The Black Sea.  Climb up and left through a small over overlap to a large comfortable grassy ledge with a two bolt chain anchor.  The route starts on the arete.  There is a brass point of aid(the turtle) that marks the end of the bouldery start and the beginning of this long pitch.
routes.route_protection: bolts.  Many.  14-16 maybe...Single 70' to get off.Rap Black Sea or top out and walk to Madsen Ledge and climb Good Girls or Technicians for a 7 pitch stack up

route_comments.comment_text: Fantastic route. Deserves more attention. Sep 1, 2017
Interesting that 12- = V7 Jan 12, 2019

routes.route_description: P1It is best to pre-clip the first bolt then start climbing from the right at an under cling.  Follow bolts, a few small cams and a fixed 1/2" rod behind a flake.  Climb up and right for more bolts, multiple small cruxes and a short layback up an arete past a few good cams to a few more bolts and a final difficult move just before the anchors.P2Goes straight up the corner then steps left passing a bolt to gain another corner/Arete.  Climb Arete and face past some huge knobs then head left past two more bolts through a steep bulge then up a corner to the belay.  A short dirty third pitch can be lead to gain the summit.  There is a bolted rappel about 5m to the right of the top out or Rap back down the route from here.
routes.route_location: Climb up from just inside the "cave" onto the top of the huge detached block above Ted, Ted Nugent.  There is a bolted belay.The route can be rappelled with one 70m from the first or second belay.  Be very careful returning to the Perverse Traverse as the wall is undercut and you must maintain a swing to get back to the ledge.  Tie knots!
routes.route_protection: 14-16 draws and runnersCams from .25"-1.5"  (#2 or #3 Camolot for Pitch 2)Chain anchors at top of both pitches

route_comments.comment_text: Fantastic route. The first pitch was sustained, yet quite varied. I can't wait to try the second pitch. May 12, 2013
Sorry Jon!  I keep changing the name... first time using this thing. May 12, 2013
Nice name -- I'll update my photo captions. May 12, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · Lead / Fell/Hung. Did first pitch twice for photoshoot. Would be fun in cooler temps. 3 bolts, 1 nuts + opt 0.1, 1 alpine draw on rod, 3 bolts, 0.2 (extend), 0.3, 1 bolt, #2, #1, 0.75 (extend), 3 bolts. didn't get start, first traverse is balance, a mantle into a sloper, remember hidden side pull. Good knob on next sloper rail, then next traverse has a sinker pocket, · Follow. great line with a hellish start. everything else felt good except that last dam move. also why not sink a bolt towards the top on the left facing arete. little run out imo · 1 pitch. Lead / Fell/Hung. amazing climb, took a few times. kinda scary on the arete, didn't have a 0.5 or 0.75, so just levitated in the corner to get the bolt

routes.route_description: Two steep corner pitches that can be combined into one.Awesome stemming!
routes.route_location: Climb a short connector pitch up and left of the belay from the top of Black Sea P1(5.10-)to a large ledge at the base of a left facing corner.
routes.route_protection: a few small cams and bolts.

routes.route_description: Knobs all day!  Two distinct cruxes.  One for the tall and one for the rest of us.
routes.route_location: This Route leaves from the top of the 1st pitch of The Black Sea.  Clip a bolt then step down and right around the corner.  Follow bolts through KNOBS up and right to a chain anchor.Two single 70m rope rappels takes you back to the Perverse Traverse.This is a free hanging rappel.  You MUST maintain a swing to get back to the ledge! Tie Knots!
routes.route_protection: 12-14 Quick draws/runners#2 camalot optional

route_comments.comment_text: Those knobs look amazing. And the route looks nicely bolted. Can't wait to give this one a try. May 13, 2013

Yeah nice work Tom . Now with the rain this week you can get some rest from all your projects ! That wall is sweet  the free rap to the traverse is pretty wild ! But the knobs are way better . May 14, 2013
Strong work Tom and crew! May 28, 2013

routes.route_tick_comments: · Follow. after the long reach I got stuck on the move off the big knobs. · Lead. first crux was easy-ish, just pull up on left hand. fell at second crux, can definitely send next go. second crux, get your right foot as high as possible, then stand up on it and the move to the jug is almost static. next move is really delicate and another crux, after that romp to the chains. did it in 50 degree weather with Jason, was great friction

routes.route_description: Two distinctively different pitches of ridiculously fun, airy climbing at the top of the wall.
routes.route_location: This two pitch route starts off the left side of the poop deck.  A large ledge in the middle of the wall down and right of the the P1 anchors of Black Sea.  The ledge can be accessed most easily by rappeling or lowering in from the anchors of Echolocation(11+) or from just about any bolt on that route(<10+).  It is also possible to climb half way up Echolocation then move right at the overlap onto P1 of Gods Bones midway up and lower off of bolts there.  This allows the second to clean all the gear off of Echolocation before lowering down to the poop deck and pulling the rope for a lead, leaving two of the bolts on Gods Bones hung.Hung gear may offend the sensibilities of...some people.  For those a third option exists.  Admiral Harrington, his Jolly Boys and the Code of the Sea(11-) combines the first half of Echolocation and sails on past to anchor below P2 of Gods Bones.
routes.route_protection: 12-14 draws and runners

route_comments.comment_text: Is this the one further right of Echolocation? May 21, 2013

Yup, up and right of Echolocation. Look for the distinct compression arete that angles up and slightly left, pretty awesome thuggery after the previous two techy pitches. First crux comes right after the belay as you move up and right over the bulge with some blind knobs. Second crux is not getting too pumped on the second half of the line after the rest. Awesome route, sure to get more... more Yup, up and right of Echolocation. Look for the distinct compression arete that angles up and slightly left, pretty awesome thuggery after the previous two techy pitches. First crux comes right after the belay as you move up and right over the bulge with some blind knobs. Second crux is not getting too pumped on the second half of the line after the rest. Awesome route, sure to get more awesome as it gets more ascents! May 24, 2013

Remember that you're screwed if you rap off of the poop deck without maintaining a healthy swing. Definitely tie knots in the ends of your rope on that last rappel back to the perverse traverse. Apr 30, 2014

area_description: Oz is the small upper left quadrant of the Cheeks beginning at "Lions, Tigers, and Bears" and ending at "Jesters of Chaos"; and encompassing a wide range of corners, splitters, & arete's that distinguish it from the Black Sea---which is mostly homogenous geology on a sweeping knob studded shield. Home of the immaculate Quad Crack.
area_getting_there: Take the left branch when headed from the UTW to the cheeks. If you are going way down hill, then head back up. On approach, marvel at the Incisor, Wilman's Walkabout, and the lurking tsunami of Quads lurking above a beautiful submarine like feature.

routes.route_description: O so short but o so stout! Slightly overhung climbing, that's kinda painful. Don't use the cheater stone for the full points. Named in honor of one of Index's most accomplished climber's.
routes.route_location: Left of Jesters of Chaos. Short but steep and right on trail.
routes.route_protection: Qds

route_comments.comment_text: Looks like a fun type of pain. Would it be easy to go around it and set up a TR? Jan 30, 2021
It would be easy to set up a toprope. But not worth the effort. This was a little consolation prize one afternoon after getting shutdown on the main projects. Jan 30, 2021

routes.route_description: Cramer calls it a "lower angle, thinner, City Park." Thinner is the key word there, aside from the first six feet and the last ten, virtually the only solid pieces will be lost arrows and knifeblades.The climb starts with some semi-mandatory free climbing. If it was clean and dry this would be mostly unprotected 5.9, but you can aid through almost all of it, be careful though, as the right facing corner crack expands a little and decking is a real possibility.Farther up there are a couple loose blocks and flakes to avoid, being good at high-stepping and cam hooking is helpful, in the absence of these skills, be tall.Fairly unrelenting thinness leads to a small lip and eventually a gradually easing finish.
routes.route_location: Just before the huge block by the Perverse Traverse
routes.route_protection: Standard aid rack, including specifically -Single set of cams to .75, doubles of .3-.5Small offset nutsCam hooksLost arrows, shorter ones more useful than longerKnifeblades, all sizesBeaks/TomahawksNew anchor bolts were installed in April of 2015, but bring tat because there are no chains and this climb is seldom done.

route_comments.comment_text: My first nailing route! As of 8/24 there are good anchors with chains at the top. The loose flake on the right about a 1/3 of the way up came off when I stopped to check it out again in rappel. See my full write up here: mountainproject.com/forum/t… Aug 5, 2024

Be like Cameron and nail this route. Great write up and way to get on a super cool obscurity. A few people, including myself, have messed around on free climbing this thing and it seems damn near impossible, if not outright impossible. Perhaps that would change of more people approach this climb in the style in which it was first ascended. Aug 6, 2024

routes.route_description: P1 - Strenuous climbing 10d leads to a nice ledge.P2 - Many 1.5 and 2 for this pitch supposedly the crux is the traverse move and it can be easily aided to bring the grade down to 11d.
routes.route_location: The route is the first route you come to on the Cheeks.
routes.route_protection: Large cams are useful on p1

route_comments.comment_text: The first pitch is classic Index tight fingers in a corner. Fantastic climbing, deserving of much more attention. The first person to do it after a period of no ascents may find the top jams need cleaning. Fir needles tend to fall down and clog up the crack. Sep 5, 2019

routes.route_tick_comments: · 1 pitch. TR. topdawg. P1!!!! It’s fun! Still dirty/not recommended but it’s cleaning up nice :)

routes.route_fa: FA: Darryl Cramer and David Gunstone
routes.route_description: p1 - Follow thin cracks up and right to where the crack enters a flared corner chimney.  A few knifeblade/bugaboos were used on this section which is steep and usually dry.   Follow the chimney up to a lower angle section of rock and a nice belay.  This section will most likely be wet - really wet.p2 - AKA Quadruple Cracks.  Climb the face crack up ever steepening rock to join Wilman's Walkabout at the p2 belay ledge.  At the time of the FA there was a loose block - perhaps it has been removed now.  Clean aid.  The cracks can be wet but the climbing is dry due to the exposed position unlike the chimney below.
routes.route_location: Just right of Wilmans P1
routes.route_protection: A few thin pins and a regular rack - perhaps bring extra stoppers.

routes.route_fa: June 25th. FA Ben Gilkison, Tavish Hansen, Stig Anagnostou
routes.route_description: An update on this one, I added a bolt at the end so only quick draws needed. Also, I moved a bolt around towards the upper crux which improves safety. No longer pg-13 rating. This is an excellent pitch, and a great way to finish a three pitch climb by doing the first couple pitches of Wilman's walkabout. (p1 11+, p2 11-, p3 5.11).  When I updated the gear end of 2023 I also gave it a quick scrub, so totally climbable now.
routes.route_location: starts on nice ledge at the top of Wilman's Walkabout P2.
routes.route_protection: 7 or 8 bolts. 1-2 finger size pieces.

route_comments.comment_text: youtube.com/watch?v=6KSiyaq… Jun 26, 2020
Jon, this begins just above quad cracks, and takes you to just under the top of the crag. In reference, it is just 15' right of Wilman's P 3 Jun 26, 2020

routes.route_fa: First aid ascent Darryl Cramer, David Gunstone. FFA TR Gilkison 8/2022, FFA Lead Anagostou 7/2023.
routes.route_description: Once an obscure aid line, Quadruple Cracks is now free, one of Index hardest gear climbs, and its quality cannot be overstated. In the vanguard, Stamati sent July 1st on a rare & cool breezy evening, which I heard had his belayer Trevor bundled in double layers----while I cheered on in spirit, from a far off family camping destination. Yesterday, Sept 23rd I also free climbed to the quad summit after placing all gear on lead, just before a soaking rain descended on the valley. The grade may settle in the 13+ range for those 6' climbers, but on a personal note, I am convinced it was 14a for me, which would make this my most difficult gear lead, something I'd never imagine I could do at 47 with kids and profession.  But, the greatest joy of this project by far was the sense of mutual support I felt working it with Stamati ...cleaning, the beta mining sessions, figuring out the gear, believing in the gear, and of course the route itself which is perfection.Thanks to all the folks whom contributed to the process: Tavish, Nate, Adam, Trevor, Cindy, Monica, Brock, Mark, Hunter and likely other I may have forgot. Huge thanks to Stamati---fellow Quadling.

routes.route_description: An excellent thin crack. Start on P1 of Wilmans Walkabout but cut left and climb the obvious finger crack in the face instead of staying in the corner as for Wilmans. The lower part of the crack has really good holds, but it peters out as you near the top. When you reach a bolt at the top of the crack, cut right to the anchor for Wilmans Walkabout.

routes.route_description: Wilman's Walkabout is a delightful three pitch route on the left flank of the Cheeks, now all FREE including a new variation on pitch 2, and also the final crux corner pitch 3. The first pitch stays dry in a light rain, quickly dries after, and stays cool on most sunny days till noon.  The final corner stays in the shade till 10 or 11am.Pitch 1: Ascend the large left facing corner clipping 3 bolts before a potent crux on good gear. Mantle up to the ledge (original ending of P1 --can still see the old pin), negotiate past seasonal vegetation, and dance up a knob studded corner, palming and stemming to a final 10' of harder than it looks open book climbing.  5.11+Pitch 2 variation: Ascend past 1 bolt up the clean featured face to regain the corner. Mantle up onto the sweet 2x2' perch and check out the views, surrounded by steep granite. After clipping another bolt, match a huge sloper and pull over left into another small RFC with an engaging finish, leading up to the Sky Lounge Ledge. 5.11aPitch 2 original: stay in the LFC the entire way. Gear looks sketchy up high, hard to place, and it is dirty still despite me scrubbing on it for hours. 10+?Pitch 3: Ascend the aesthetic corner requiring classic index chicanery.  If you're tall it might feel 11d, if short more like 12+. SO GOOD!!!! Memorable finish with backwards facing chimney. 5.12All anchors are equipped with chains. Rappel the route. 60m rope is sufficient. Or... you can also move right on the Sky Lounge Ledge to climb Mysteries of the Lollipop Guild 11+. From here you can rappel from the Quad Crack anchor and easily TR it with a few directionals.P1. FFA: Darryl Cramer, Terry Lien, Nicola Masciandaro, Jon Nelson 1987. P2 FFA: Darryl Cramer, Terry Lien, Max Dufford 1987. P2 Variation FFA: Ben Gilkison, Chris Kalman, Dan Kluskiewicz 5/23. P3 FFA: Ben Gilkison, Jeromy Markee, and Eli Chance.
routes.route_location: Midway between Jesters of Chaos and the Perverse Traverse. An obvious, white, left-facing corner.
routes.route_protection: For P1, bring thin stoppers (e.g., down to RP #3 or ~3/16" width), some small cams (finger-tip size), one hand-sized cam, and mid-range stoppers. The first third of the pitch has three 3/8"bolts. P2: single rack to #2, draws. P3: draws, optional #2

routes.route_description: A cool variation that I haven't seen mentioned anywhere, so I figured I'd give it a name and put it on MP. Not the most obvious line considering it shares a lot of holds with the other routes, but it climbs super well and has some unique movement.Sit start with right hand on the horn low on the arete, and left hand somewhere in the seam in the middle of the face. Make a tricky move out left to the rail, then figure out a way to get your feet over and finish up Zelda Rails Right, or (slightly harder) Zelda Rails.

route_comments.comment_text: Did a starting left foothold break? The first move, properly pulling on from a sit and not dabbing, feels wildly hard for V6. Maybe I’m just missing something, but I could not for the life of me do what the current beta videos show. Jun 8, 2023

I'd be surprised if something broke, there were really only smears and tiny dimples there to begin with. I've seen the first move done a couple different ways, either with the left foot directly below the right hand start hold, or about a foot to the left. Both ways involve really opening the hips and getting a lot of weight on the right hand. Jun 9, 2023

A lot of the crux first move is in the feet, out of view. I found an "okay" low dimple for the left foot and used a right heel low on the arete to help pull my butt off the ground. Regarding dabs, just keep moving the pads farther back until you stop dabbing! instagram.com/p/Cx1zABDrN-0/ Oct 2, 2023

routes.route_description: Formerly known as the Zelda Roof Project, Temple of Time stands proud as one of the area's most prominent and striking features. The Prow juts directly out over a shear slab, creating a blank roof that climbers must overcome through a unique and challenging set of moves.Start matched on a jug at chest level. Then climb easy moves up the slab into the roof. Use creativity, tension, and pure gumption to gain a massive pinch on the arete and top out the prow on an airy lip traverse with a spicy mantle.Temple of Time has stood the test of time, having been a long-standing project in the Zelda Boulders. Featured in the Western Washington Bouldering guidebook as a project in 2016, it remained undone for eight years until July 24th, 2024, when it saw its first ascent.If you are interested in seeing a video aboutThe Processbehind this bloc, here you go:https://youtu.be/1_XnRnB-5mYUncut BetaVideo:https://youtu.be/gjBi4WwstqM

routes.route_tick_comments: · The beta was annoyingly difficult to figure out, but once I did it was actually pretty easy. A bit technical for a V0 in that you need to understand body positioning and weight distribution. Beta: start with right hand high on the arete, left hand resting on the wall. Left foot on whatever little dimple you can manage to stand on. Throw right foot up high to the obvious nice big spot (it’s chalked as if that’s where a starting hand would be, but I started with my hand higher at the second chalked up spot). Stand up on right foot. Bump right hand higher. Cross left foot in front of body to the next obvious step on the arete, while leaning all your body weight to the left so you don’t barn door. Stand up on left foot and flag right foot out right (remember to keep leaning left). Grab the top of the lip with left hand. Place right foot on little step created by the drill marks. Mantle up.

routes.route_location: The left most problem on the Open Book boulder.
routes.route_protection: N/A
routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Meh, short not too sweet. A knee bar in there makes the reach ez. Can also dyno-ish to the lip too

routes.route_description: Fun slab up to a nice top out.
routes.route_location: The obvious slab ramp in the middle of the Open Book boulder.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: friken slippy but you gada May 3, 2021

Some of the spots are pretty slick, you've gotta find which dishes you can trust your feet in and create some pressure with your palms (at least I did), but overall a fun slab route! I'd rate it equivalent to a V4 -V5 indoors. Jun 19, 2021
The foot holds are way slippery. Aug 3, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. gave myself nerve damage in my right palm trying to do this barefoot for 30 min · Flash. Again high feet, left hip in and stand. Not hard if you start high · Send. Variant: Run up with no hands until the top (ninja warrior style). Pretty easy, but it looks really cool. V0 · Send. Sent on third attempt, and then dialed it after a few more laps. Very sketchy feet, no real solid footholds. · Send. Some of the spots are pretty slick, you've gotta find which dishes you can trust your feet in and create some pressure with your palms, but overall a fun slab route!

area_description: Small boulder resting above a slope
area_getting_there: After passing the Engineer and the Open Book Boulder, the Majula Boulder will be slightly uphill to your right. Next to the Majora's Mask Boulder.
