routes.route_description: Start on the obvious low jug, go left hand to a crimp, swap the feet, slap up, and mantle. Simple and fun.
routes.route_location: Next to the Majora's Mask Boulder
routes.route_protection: A pad
routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. Did not figure this out at all, might need to work on starting feet placement, slap to the sloper felt really hard · Send. High right heel hook. Left toe down low. Throw right hand to jug then climb up from there.

routes.route_description: Same start as Majula on a low jug. Cross right to a small crimp, throw for an obvious jug out left and top out. Could possibly be done statically with long arms.
routes.route_location: Next to Majora's Mask boulder
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_fa: Shane Steinert-Threlkeld / Erin McGinnis?? LMK if sent already
routes.route_description: Start far left on the lip with a good right foot, traverse right into a mega jug and then top out.  Easier if taller
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads

area_description: Picturesque wavy slab, with an obvious L cut into the right side.
area_getting_there: From the approach trail, walk past the Engineer and just after you pass the Open Book Boulder, the Majora's Mask Boulder will be slightly uphill to your right.

routes.route_description: Start sitting on the bottom right of the giant L. Make interesting moves up the right face to position yourself for the jump mantle (crux).
routes.route_location: On the far right side of the Majora's Mask Boulder
routes.route_protection: N/A
routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Kinda techy high feet lead to a simple jump and mantle. Done in approach shoes w no problem

routes.route_description: Start in the scoop and traverse right, finishing via Majora's Mask.
routes.route_location: On the Left side of the Majora's Mask Boulder
routes.route_protection: N/A
routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. Got all the moves with a slight dab in the middle. Go get it clean next time.

routes.route_description: Start in the scoop on the far left side of the slab as for Majora and Majora Direct. Traverse right to the center of the slab and climb up on crimps and a sloper.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Traversed right, used crimp and left foot to stand up and switch feet. Bumped left hand up to high crimp and left foot out onto good rail. Not sure which problem this qualifies as

routes.route_fa: Shane Steinert-Threlkeld (please LMK if already sent)
routes.route_description: Start in the scoop as per Majora, but continue straight up instead of traversing right
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads
routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Used scoop to left a lot, not sure if that's right but meh

routes.route_description: Climb the face left of the dihedral, slabbing up using a right hand rail and left crimps to a cruxy top-out.
routes.route_location: The middle of the Majora's Mask Boulder, on the left side of the obvious L shaped dihedral.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: What's the rules here for what's on? Are you disallowed from using anything to the right of the rail? Lots of features to the right of the rail (footholds, the top jug) potentially make this easier so would be good to clarify Jun 25, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Techy at the bottom, but more physical through the top out with only slopers to press down on. Not bad, but being long is definitely an advantage here · Flash. A bit contrived, not clear how much of the boulder to the right of the L-rail is on (can you heel hook it? Use foot chips to the right of the rail?)

area_description: Tall boulder with 4 problems on it. The center line is Face Crack V5, there's a 3 to the left of it and a 0 on the right side + a slabby climb around the corner that's rarely done.Please send a page suggestion if you have knowledge about the first development of this boulder or have a better idea about the name of the boulder. Thanks-
area_getting_there: This will be the first big boulder you see from the trail to the Zelda Boulders. You'll recognize it from the obviously striking line of "Face Crack" going down the middle.

routes.route_description: Start with a chest-high left pinch and a good waist-high right side-pull. Work your way up delicate feet to the good slot, and then follow the seam all the way up for an airy top-out.
routes.route_location: On the left side of the face of the first boulder you come across.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: This thing is confusing, generally I am reluctant to call things contrived but it is pretty unclear what left hand holds your actually supposed to use and not supposed to use, the picture in particular makes me think the side pulls just off the shelf are okay which is crazy since the shelf is about 3 inches away. The crack is filled with moss and seeps quite a bit. Mar 17, 2021

Here is a video of how I climbed it if it helps to have a video example. I believe all of the holds I used are intended to be used, but if not feel free to correct me. youtu.be/MXTCjtwMdz4 Apr 20, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. Couldn’t get past the slot. Also added a left low side pull to the start. · Lead / Fell/Hung. I have no idea if I did this, there is a tiny layback hold at the top you can avoid the right crack entirely without touching the arete · Send. Finished off full send with an actually dry top :)). Did some fun/funky beta for the top, with left hand high on side pull and high left foot · Send. The ledge is off, bummer its somewhat contrived but makes the climb much better · Send. Top of crack and lip were soaked, so had to gaston the last side pull and exit btn ledge and lip :(

routes.route_description: Start with a good head-high left edge on the arête and a right pinch. Work your way up the to the deep right-hand slot and top out on the ledge to the left.
routes.route_location: Left arête of the obvious face.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Part of the arete broke off Mar 17, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. One pad, TC pros, and no rest cause bb said “LET’S GO (home)”. EASILY A V4 UNDER THESE CONDITIONS · Send. ~6-8 goes. Go right to the slot w left on the higher slopes jug. Really fun. Didn’t really do the top out tho lol · Super small edges for feet, gotta trust them though! There's a small foot chip under blocky part (idk how to better describe it) that really helps with getting to the fantastic deep slot.

routes.route_description: Begin seated with your left hand in the crack, and your right foot on the obvious start hold down low. Work your way upwards on positive holds to a short rail and grab the jug to top out.
routes.route_location: First boulder upon entering the Zelda area. This problem is to the right of "Face Crack".
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Good warmup youtube.com/shorts/qNeCs_XV… Aug 9, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Done with no topout since super mossy up there. Don't wanna risk it for a v2

routes.route_description: Follow the obvious feet up to a good dish for your right foot. Commit for the top.
routes.route_location: This is around the corner from "Face Crack".
routes.route_protection: Little bit of a weird landing. Pad would be good.

area_description: Large, flat-topped boulder with a slab having a built-up landing.There is one bolt and hanger on the top. Larger face is on the south side, where the hillside drops away.
area_getting_there: Go down the Zelda trail, and bear left.

routes.route_description: Start on the right side of the arête that the Engineer starts on. Make a few moves up the arête on good feet then until you can span to the right arête. Compress on improbable slopers and smeary feet, then make an insecure throw to the lip. Traverse left along the lip and top out as for the Engineer.
routes.route_location: The Architect is the first boulder on the left as you approach the Zelda boulders.
routes.route_protection: Lots of pads and a couple attentive spotters. If you miss the throw to the lip you will probably land on the large block so make sure to toss some pads on it and put a spotter behind it. It's safer than it looks.

route_comments.comment_text: We made a video! Jake and I found beta that removed the final toss to the lip, and which makes use of the quartz at the top! So hype! youtube.com/watch?v=1eubJ7e… Enjoy! Dec 2, 2020

Stunning line. Height dependent. Feels like a v8 for my very average size, technical climbing style, and comfort with highballs. Bring pads. Bring friends. Bring your friends with pads. And don’t forget your stick brush. Oct 11, 2021
youtu.be/dnBf6T40LJc Apr 27, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. Slightly below previous high point. Did a RF match to RH on good edge to rock over to R arête this time. I like the LH on the second from the top on the arête. Not the best conditions · Attempt. Made it fairly high up, but thin skin and conditions coupled with fear made me back down. High point was right foot on highest good edge, right hand not yet in dimple deep around corner · Send. Had to take the digger slapping the lip once for full value. Makes the top 5 v8's in the state on aesthetic alone.

routes.route_description: Follow the Engineer's arete all the way up. Less technically demanding than the Engineer but much scarier.
routes.route_location: Start as for the Engineer.
routes.route_protection: Most of the danger is from the jump to the lip. Pad around the arete, particularly on the right side. Falls at the top will land you in the left side of the Architect's landing zone.

routes.route_description: Start on the right side of the slab and work your way up the arête. Set up on a pinch out left, then either throw to the hueco, or make a tenuous reach on smeary feet. Work your feet up and throw to the lip. It's a jug!The hueco seems to be a ball of quartz that has eroded away to form a hold. The rock inside is friable, but there is a good crimp on the left side as well as a bomber undercling on the top right. With more traffic it may hollow out even more.
routes.route_location: Look straight ahead as you approach the Zelda boulders and you will see the striking arête of the Architect. The Engineer climbs the left side of this arête.
routes.route_protection: The landing for this problem is a true feat of engineering! Bring as many pads as you can.There is a bolt on top that seems bomber enough.There are a collection of sticks and logs directly under the boulder that make it a more or a less flat landing to place crashpads on. Please be mindful not to step on/break them because without them the problem would be significantly more dangerous.

route_comments.comment_text: Here is the Christmas video we put out for this route! Turned out to be one of my favorite videos on our channel! youtube.com/watch?v=yNLOsAy… Enjoy! Feb 19, 2019
youtu.be/GS7rA4nBOQU Apr 27, 2022
How did this get downgraded.... May 24, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Definitely easier than the V9 it gets in the book but what a climb! · TR. Did it twice on TR but was too spooked to do it with the pads we had. With more pads and more skin I’ll do it next time for sure. Very stoked just to climb on this thing.

routes.route_description: Start standing with a left hand on the bottom of the drill mark. Reach up to a thin crimp and then make an insecure move to the better crimp above. Reach for the lip and commit to the airy top out. A fall from the lip could result in a tumble down the bank.
routes.route_location: On the left side of boulder with the obvious vertical drill mark.
routes.route_protection: 3 pads, spotter

area_description: This heavily shaded boulder sits nestled next to a small creek with views ofThe Cheeks & The Diamondthrough the trees. It’s name is a nod to the larger butt shaped formation that looms above. It is obvious that this site was used for quarrying around the same time that the Zeldas were. Drills used to split the index granite at one point left residual marks from the process across the boulders right side.This is an excellent warm up with three climbs ranging from v1-v3. Make sure to incorporate this into your circuit before hoping on “Ocarina of Time” or “Zelda Rails”.(If anyone has further information about this bloc please contact me)
area_getting_there: Face the “Zelda Dyno” boulder. Walk 150 yards to your right at the same elevation as the Zelda Boulders.If you have walked for more than 5 minutes you have gone too far.

routes.route_description: Climb the only arête on the boulder using the obvious ledges to gain the top.
routes.route_location: The far left arête on the bloc.
routes.route_protection: Pads

routes.route_description: Jump for the eye shaped jug hold at the nine foot level from a stand start, or with your right foot stemmed into the finger crack. This problem becomes easier the more pads you stack.
routes.route_location: Start standing or stemming with your left hand at the bottom of the obvious drill shaft feature. Generate for the obvious jug. Match and top out.
routes.route_protection: Pads

route_comments.comment_text: Cool boulder (not problem) that I suggest working on variations instead of the proposed climb that is kind of contrived. Jun 4, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Fun little jump, but seems a bit contrived with an obvious height advantage

routes.route_description: Start with a leap to the ledge just to the left of the large drill-hole. Smearing with feet, lift yourself up to the top ledge and top-out. 1 move V2. To make it a V1, use the bottom of the drill hole as a foot hold.
routes.route_location: Go past Zelda boulders and the 'between the cheeks' boulder should be to the right across the small stream-bed. Rock is split and has a 90 degree angle where it was cut.
routes.route_protection: 1 crash pad

routes.route_description: Traverse left past the finger crack and continue until you reach the end of the horizontal rails where the moss begins. Top out at the apex of the boulder.
routes.route_location: Start with your right hand on the sixth drill hole from the right and your left hand on the ninth.
routes.route_protection: Pads
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Our group interpreted it as the roof being off for the traverse. Doing the traverse on just the main rail (removing the jug from Drill Shaft Dyno) probably adds a grade.

area_description: Boulder behind the Sun Sail boulder. Has a a couple climbs, most notably Yin Yang (V7). Distinguishable by a sloping circular shelf in the center.
area_getting_there: Once you reach the Sun Sail boulder, turn left and walk around to the backside of that boulder, then you will be at the base of the Yin Yang boulder.

routes.route_description: Start matched on a head-height sidepull. Make balancey moves upwards to the slopey lip and finish with a tricky mantle.
routes.route_location: The furthest left line on the Yin Yang boulder.
routes.route_protection: N/A
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. also worked yin yang for a while but don't want to go for it without spots.

routes.route_description: Begins crouched matched on a side pull near the bottom of the circular circular shelf feature. Use poor feet and technical skills to get set up for a tricky move to the sloping lip.
routes.route_location: Center of the Yin Yang boulder, distinguishable by a sloping circular shelf feature.
routes.route_protection: N/A
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Use the tiny crystal for your right hand to pull yourself up JUUUST enough before you hop onto your right foot and slap that left hand on the top. · Attempt. Touched but couldn’t stick the top twice - tried both left and right top bits - right is better but harder body tension perhaps. Full on raining so despite trying hard, eventually had to call it - surprised I even made it that far when wet. Key beta was good high RF and RH undercling to get LF up, then LF closer/further from wall and flip RH after matching then deadpoint to top · Attempt. The one that got away! 3 more burns and it would have been done :( come back for it someday

area_description: This triangle shaped boulder has some easier slab on the left, and the classic Sun Sail (v3) on the trianglular face.
area_getting_there: From Flying Honey Badger, walk right past The Network Boulder, and trend left for 1 minute and you will pass the obvious triangle face of the Sun Sail Boulder.

routes.route_description: Climb beautiful slab left of the tree stump from a good foot shelf in the dish and continue up the goose bumps. Finish left of the notch
routes.route_location: center line of the slab wall to the left of sun sail
routes.route_protection: 2ish pads
routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. Felt within range, but scary, still learning to trust those tiny index feet · Send. stand up on high left foot bump, bump feet up until right foot is on second higher bump. Stand up hands free and get positive top · Send. Day flash after getting shut down last year. One of my favorite slab problems to date.

routes.route_description: climb the slab left of Goose Bumps on broken edges
routes.route_location: left line of the slab wall left of sun sail
routes.route_protection: 2ish pads

routes.route_description: climb large granite features right of the stump
routes.route_location: right line of the slab wall left of sun sail
routes.route_protection: 1 pad

routes.route_description: Start on the right arete of Sun Seeker, use a crimp to make a big reach to the left arete of Sun Sail and top out as per
routes.route_location: Connects Sun Sail and Sun Seeker
routes.route_protection: couple pads

routes.route_description: Climb up the left arete utilizing lay backs and pinches.
routes.route_location: The left arete of the next boulder behind Dreamscape.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: A block fell out of the arete feature circa 2020 leaving better thumb holds and feet. Still classic but easier than it used to be! Aug 29, 2022
Fun youtube.com/shorts/KA-cReqE… Oct 17, 2023
youtu.be/YG6ZpnwpDqU?si=YY0… Dec 25, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Nice little dynamic slap to the finish, probably not mandatory, but great fun · Attempt. Got to the top but used some holds past the arete on the V0? They're so close bouldering is a contrived sport · Send. Find good feet and go high with your right hand, before a good left hand foot match. · Send. Start fully on the face, get a high left foot and grab with the right hand in the incut as a pinch. Match, then bump right hand up to a notch. Get left hand up high too, get a solid right foot and then get a high left foot in that pinch! Once you have that high left foot it’s over. Don’t go over onto slab · Attempt. Keep body tension and put the left foot as soon as possible on the crack. Make sure to find good right foot first. · Send. crew got psyched on the low start from the heel hook. got it together and sent. lots of tension

routes.route_description: climb the slab left of the tree
routes.route_location: to the right of sun sail
routes.route_protection: 1+ pads
routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. A little mossy, might be a way through but would have been smart to bring a good wire brush

area_description: This lowball boulder has the amazing Where The Wild Things Go (v2), and the more difficult than it looks, Solaris (v6).
area_getting_there: From the Flying Honey Badger Boulder, walk left for 15 feet towards the Mr. Hollow Head Boulder. The lowball boulder on the left is the Solaris Boulder.

routes.route_fa: Pablo Zuleta, Ben O'Connell. Var, Keath Suchy. Low, Ben Herrington
routes.route_description: Start this fun exercise matched on a large sloping square shelf. Continue right to a diagonal rail before making a reachy move to the lip. A tougher variation (V9) exits left to a right-facing edge below the lip while a low start (V10) begins on small edges.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: A couple pads

routes.route_description: Begin under Where the Wild Things Go on a low left facing sidepull and higher right pinch along the flake. Finish on Where the Wild Things Go
routes.route_location: left of solaris
routes.route_protection: 2+ pads
routes.route_tick_comments: · One of the most amazing moves I’ve done on rock. Start in double toe hooks, then realease all points and catch the lip as you swing out. Rad. Some spiders though

routes.route_description: Begin on the far left, inside the cave. Move right along the lip for a top out left of the steep lip section
routes.route_location: left of solaris
routes.route_protection: 2-3 pads and maybe a spotter for raise section of rocks

route_comments.comment_text: Pretty chill boulder! youtu.be/o-ZaA_1siN8 Oct 7, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Fun kneebar before top out. Get a good rest for the sketchy top out. · Send. Worked top out first and that helped a ton. Got heel way over so basically hugging rock that helped too. Stoked !!!! · Send. Got it second try! Stayed outside the clamshell, super tough, heel hook plus difficult mantle. Pretty cool once got it! · Flash. Got in that slot thang like ol’ off width Timmy. Very easy this way

area_description: A steep overhanging face that holds one of the hardest problems in Washington.
area_getting_there: Walk on the trail to the cluster left of Sasquatch.

routes.route_description: A little bit 'o traverse on this smaller boulder. Start with a heel hook and matched hands on the left, then traverse right to top out at the apex.
routes.route_location: West side of the west boulder.
routes.route_protection: Twoish pads.

routes.route_description: A steep son of a gun. Start with a left crimp and right pinch, work your feet up until you can reach and slap the high crimp, then make the big throw for the 'gram.
routes.route_location: The south side of the central boulder.
routes.route_protection: Pads and a spotter.

area_description: This highball boulder features my favorite moderate in the area (Appa) as well as some excellent harder slab and face climbs. Unfortunately the moss reclaims these problems every season, bring your wire brush and spruce them up!
area_getting_there: After passing Sun Sail continue straight on a faint path toward large mossy boulders (left goes to Yin Yang, right (uphill) goes to Robot Heart). After weaving past two of these, the large mossy face of Appa will beckon to you. A large tree hugs the boulder's right arete and Sky Bison's face tends to stay moss-free.

area_comments.comment_text: Downclimb on the back is currently a little annoying due to a fallen tree. Worth having a pad in place to hop to. Aug 29, 2022

routes.route_description: Tackle the center of the large imposing slab when you arrive at the Sky Bison boulder. Dance your way upwards through overlaps and sloping feet to a "comfortable" stance high on the face.The lip lies just out of reach above...and the landing (flat and good) is far below.
routes.route_location: Center of large slabby face.
routes.route_protection: pads

route_comments.comment_text: This climb regrows fast! If it looks a bit mossy it's worth carrying a brush with you and going for it! Aug 29, 2022

routes.route_description: From high crimps, oomph your way up and trend right to follow the right side of the arete to the top.
routes.route_location: The blunt slabby arete when you first arrive at the boulder.
routes.route_protection: pads

routes.route_description: Find two somewhat miserable crimps high in the center of the face. Pull on and make a reachy move to a good hold about 10 feet up. Fight your way up the left arete and continue to the apex for a dramatic exit.
routes.route_location: Steep triangular face of the Sky Bison boulder.
routes.route_protection: pads

routes.route_description: From sharp edges on the right side of Sky Bison's face, make a few painful moves up and right to the arete. Surf your way to the top without bailing onto Cycle of Life.
routes.route_location: Right side of Sky Bison's face
routes.route_protection: pads

area_description: This highball triangle shaped block sits higher up on the edge of the Sasquatch area.
area_getting_there: From Flying Honey Badger, walk right past The Network Boulder, and keep walking straight up the hill for 5 minutes. Trend slightly right, past the Sun Sail Boulder, and keep a look out for the highball triangle shaped Boulder that is the Robot Heart Boulder.

routes.route_description: Climb the aesthetic, tall left arete on miserable feet.
routes.route_location: Follow the trail to the Roulette Dares area, pass under the suspended Roulette Dares boulder and keep following the trail. This will take you to Robot Heart.
routes.route_protection: Landing is good but the boulder is fairly tall, may want 4 pads or so.

route_comments.comment_text: High quality slab problem! youtube.com/shorts/BqgGnP38… Sep 12, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. This is a must do, but had to wait for more ambitious folks to manage a beehive nearby. Eeked it out before the rains! 2 pads, after work! · Send. Stoked to put this one down on the first sesh of the year! Start beta came back quickly. For the top, just dig into the left toe scum / hook to get LH just below the good notch and RH out to crimp · Send. Chill summer session send. Unlike when I tried this problem last year, the individual moves felt remarkably in-control and good. Just had to get everything dialed once for it to go down. Stoked! · Attempt. Sick problem. For next time, come back with better skin, stand-up and trust feet, and try earlier in the session. Got to high notch. · Send. Thanks for the mega spot and psyche, R! I think we were booth a bit delusional from the heat

area_description: Tall boulder with some interesting man made features.
area_getting_there: From Flying Honey Badger follow the trail north past the Network until it exits the boulder field. The trail kind of disappears at this point, but the boulders are easy to find. Keep going north at about the same elevation for 300 yards until you hit a cluster of smaller boulders and see a cliff up above you. Head straight up to the base of the cliff and go right until you spot a boulder leaning up against the wall with obvious drill marks. This is Pipeline.

area_comments.comment_text: We scrubbed off the V3 on 8/1/20. It would be worth it to bring a brush so you can hop on the V2 or the V6. They look fun. Aug 4, 2020

routes.route_description: Begin matched on the sloping shelf and move left into the crack/drill feature and work up to the lip. Jam optional
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_description: Start on the rail just below the scoop feature. Work your way up the lip between the drill shaft and the pocket.Make sure you plot your escape before attempting. There is a reasonable down climb, but it needs some cleaning to be considered safe. Until then I suggest lowering from the lip and dropping on to pads.
routes.route_location: Obvious line between the right drill mark and the pocket.
routes.route_protection: 3 pads

area_description: Spire-shaped boulder with a perfect arete.
area_getting_there: From Flying Honey Badger follow the trail north past the Network until it exits the boulder field. The trail kind of disappears at this point, but the boulders are easy to find. Keep going north at about the same elevation for 300 yards until you hit a cluster of smaller boulders and see a cliff up above you. Head straight up to the base of the cliff and go right until you spot a boulder leaning up against the wall with obvious drill marks. This is Pipeline. Desperate Attention is a few yards further just around the corner.

routes.route_description: Start standing with your hands on the arete. Paste your feet on and start walking up. Can you make it to the top before you barn door around the corner, or will you have to make a desperate leap for the lip? Great fun either way.Make sure to throw a pad or two over the talus to the left of the boulder. When you catch the lip you may find yourself swinging wildly out over to the left.
routes.route_location: The obvious arete.
routes.route_protection: 3 pads

area_description: This very large boulder has many problems all the way around it with the uber classic, The Network (v5).
area_getting_there: From the Flying Honey Badger Boulder, walk right for 5 feet and The Network Boulder is the largest, closer boulder. Keep walking around it to find the namesake The Network (v5), or walk left to find yourself in the cave with the Dreamscape Boulder.

routes.route_description: Start on the obvious head height rail (used to be pretty wide, now is just about large enough for one hand) and bust up through small crimps to the lip. All that moonboarding is finally about to pay off.
routes.route_location: From Flying Honey Badger follow the trail right to the next boulder. Grog is the first problem you pass on the Network Boulder next to two large trees.
routes.route_protection: 1 pad

route_comments.comment_text: Big start rail broke, so this climb is significantly harder now since that was a crucial hold. Sep 18, 2023
Can confirm this climb is almost completely gone.  May still go at double digits or a alternative start but would be an entirely different climb. Aug 13, 2024

routes.route_description: A variation to The Network that starts on an obvious crimp rail a few feet left of the stand start holds.
routes.route_location: Network boulder
routes.route_protection: Several pads

routes.route_description: To navigate this network of holds, begin matched on a protruding diagonal rail and make fun layback moves right on good features. Finish on a rail over the lip and mantel. A low start variation (V7) begins matched on the thin rail to the left.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: A few pads and a vigilant spotter to cover the large boulder in the fall zone.

route_comments.comment_text: downclimb uses an obvious ladder at the lowest point of the boulder. Sep 11, 2019
Have somebody hold the ladder as you come down! It's not the most stable after the it got smacked by the tree! Aug 23, 2022
This problem is pretty sick! youtube.com/shorts/d4D1gkG0… Oct 4, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Sent second try. Spotter dab on OS go, but probably would’ve come off the end anyway maybe · Send. Heel high and crank for small crimps. Slap to a good rail and commit to the high foot for the topout. · Flash. Felt very casual today. Crazy to think I fell off the top 4 years ago! Sorta a flash (I didn’t remember much). · Attempt. Requires a powerful and high left heel hook. Powerful crimps for the next 3 moves and then a gaston/pinch to the right. · Send. I can see why this is a classic. Fun movement and a perfect example of V5 in my opinion. · Send. 2nd go, sad. Foot popped on first move, pulled back on, and sent. Great problem! · 3rd go. Crux RH gaston move isn’t that fun. Lots of pads and spotters is nice · Attempt. after a few tries was abple to get hands situated on gaston and high crimp, but left foot blew

routes.route_description: Start on the large diagonal rail, same start as The Network, but climb straight up using vertical rails.
routes.route_location: Climbs straight up from the starting rail of The Network. Look for a large diagonal rail near the bottom of an overhanging face.
routes.route_protection: N/A

area_description: This Boulder is the large block behind the Flying Honey Badger Boulder.
area_getting_there: Head left around the Flying Honey Badger Boulder for 15 feet and keep a lookout on your right for the tall highball that is the Mr. Hollow Head Boulder.

routes.route_description: This intimidating line begins on the head-height holds and continues up through the center of the slab via technical and committing movements. Think of the name of the climb when you are working the spooky slab moves above.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Pads and a vigilant spotter.

routes.route_description: Mr. Hollow Head, the famous wood figurine around sasquatch says: start matched on the left-facing sidepull and pop up to a stem on desperate feet. Reach up to a horizontal crimp at the base of the broken right-facing fin and continue up. Stack a few pads if you are having trouble pulling the start.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: A pad or two.

route_comments.comment_text: Bit of a burley start, but definitely a climb! Here's my recent send: youtu.be/85F6akuSuT8 Oct 18, 2022
youtu.be/ZBNWcs7fu2g?si=0sJ… Dec 25, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Starting flake is a tiny bit loose, make sure to have spotters Incase the hold pops. · Send. Get right foot on nub, then shoot left foot out wide in a lil incut (marginal). Shoot right hand up, tense hard, then bump left hand up the rail and put left foot where left hand start is. Then with hands matched on flake and left foot on rail, commit to a high right foot and rock onto it. Then you’re basically done. First v4!

routes.route_description: Climb the broken arete left of Mr. Hollow Head. Start on a deep left-facing sidepull and make a series of reachy moves to the top.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: A couple pads.

route_comments.comment_text: Start has broken off. Aug 18, 2024

area_description: The first Boulder you come across in the Sasquatch area. All the boulders stay out of the sun, as the area is very wooded.
area_getting_there: After the 25 minute hike which involves braving the relatively sketchy river crossing, you'll come face to face with the Flying Honey Badger Boulder.

routes.route_description: Begin this excellent problem matched using the large V-scoop at the center of the boulder face. Crank on the heel and move left to a diagonal crimp before reaching a narrow incut real that sets you up fora  throw. An easier variation (V6) eliminates the throw by using a high left foot. (Though, to me as a short climber, it seemed like the only optimal way to climb this beautiful route.)
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: A pad or two.

route_comments.comment_text: the high left foot is a natural feature on the main line, the version that excludes it is a contrived eliminate if you're into that kind of thing Aug 5, 2023

routes.route_description: Sit start just left of the arete and pull some burly moves to decent edges. Make sure to save your energy for the slopey topout!
routes.route_location: The arete left of Flying Honey Badger
routes.route_protection: Several pads and maybe a spotter
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Started with a left hand pinch with right hand below it on a crimp. Maybe I was doing it wrong but this felt hard for v4!

area_description: Enter a description of this area.
area_getting_there: Provide some directions to this area.

routes.route_description: Steep and powerful arete problem over a built-up landing. Start seated with a left hand and heel low on the arete, and a small right sidepull.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: N/A

area_description: Steep face with a obvious low rail in the cave-like alcove behind the Network Boulder.
area_getting_there: From the Network Boulder, walk around the right side and you will see the obvious overhanging face on your left. Can also be approached by walking right from the Solaris Boulder.

routes.route_description: Start at the right end of the obvious low rail feature. Traverse left to the jug and then move to gain a good rail midway up the face. Move straight up from there. Such a good problem, one of the best.
routes.route_location: In the cave-like alcove on the opposite side of the large Network boulder (opposite side of the large boulder from the actual Network climb).
routes.route_protection: You may want quite a few pads for the last move...

route_comments.comment_text: What a solid problem! Took it down on a solo sesh and thankfully brought just enough pads to protect! youtube.com/shorts/sk6TTXA_… Sep 17, 2023
One of the best around! instagram.com/reel/C-EGyiQy… Oct 15, 2024

routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. A big uninviting group crowded and hung out at this problem for over 8 hours. By the time they were leaving it was getting late so I only had a few good attempts before it got dark. Obviously no one owns these boulders but to me that’s just poor etiquette. · Attempt. Hit the dyno first try then couldn’t do it again… got the lower part worked out decently · Send. Felt super dialed and chill today - sent on my second go. Crazy how easy climbing feels when you figure out the microbeta haha! Legendary problem, super stoked to take it down! · Send. Felt good to walk this after not quite having it in me 4 or so years ago. -0.5 stars for the dabby start, but otherwise very enjoyable. · Attempt. All the moves are dialed, just need to link the bottom to the top. For future, pull bis, rotate heel, low toe press. · Send. Mega line, bump felt hard in the heat. Had a blast with a good crew! · Attempt. Stuck all the moves. Only stuck the crux once w a RF pogo. Last move is q hard too but top out is chill. Suuuper powerful and awesome problem!

routes.route_description: "Begin standing on the right of the boulder on the Dreamscape rail, crimping the lower of two rails just below the lip.  Move up and traverse left before topping out."
routes.route_location: Right side of Dreamscape boulder
routes.route_protection: A few pads

routes.route_description: Climb the steep arete left of Dreamscape starting on low opposing sidepulls. An interesting variation (V7) exits right as for dreamscape.
routes.route_location: The arete just adjacent to dreamscape.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Super fun! youtube.com/shorts/LPeWEWVf… Oct 17, 2023

area_description: Two slab warm up walls that face each other
area_getting_there: You can either go to the network and turn left after it and you will see the two slab walls past Money Badger, or you can go to solaris and continue along the trail to reach it.

area_comments.comment_text: Dude.....just one picture would be awesome Sep 17, 2020
Didnt take any, wasnt planning on adding this till i saw it wasnt on here after i came back. Planning to take some pics but havent been back since Sep 17, 2020
These slabs are awesome for hands-free climbing. The arete of Camel was particularly stimulating. Aug 13, 2021

routes.route_description: climb left arete to the apex of the boulder
routes.route_location: left of giraffe
routes.route_protection: 1 pad

routes.route_description: Climb center of the shallow face via vertical rails
routes.route_location: center line. right of camel and left of pony
routes.route_protection: 1 pad

routes.route_description: Climb the center of the slab
routes.route_location: left of Tic Tac & right of Tamarak
routes.route_protection: 1 pad
routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Best climb in the corridor despite the name and 1 star. Good slab move up top, way better than tamarack

routes.route_description: Climb slab features left of the tree from a chest-height rail
routes.route_location: right line of the boulder. right of giraffe
routes.route_protection: 1 pad

routes.route_description: Begin standing on a large foot shelf and walk up the slab on good edges. Try Kerwin Loukusa's no hand variation for extra entertainment
routes.route_location: right of Meh!
routes.route_protection: 1 pad

routes.route_description: Climb the slab left of the vertical edge in the center of the slab
routes.route_location: left line of the boulder
routes.route_protection: 1 pad

area_description: Big split boulder with moderate climbing.
area_getting_there: From Flying Honey Badger follow the trail north past the Network. The Ass Jam boulder is just a little further up and to the right. The backside of the boulder has a very obvious wide crack that can be seen from below if you walk past it.

routes.route_description: Obvious diagonal fingers to hand crack on the south face of the boulder. Start as low as you can.
routes.route_location: In a little pit on the south face of the boulder.
routes.route_protection: Two pads.

routes.route_description: Start from opposing side pulls on the face to the right of the hand crack. Head up and left staying right of the crack the whole way.
routes.route_location: On the south face of the boulder to the right of the hand crack.
routes.route_protection: two pads

area_description: Boulder with a few good warm-ups (Arete and River Warm-Ups) and a wacky gymnastic climb (Wonder). Centrally located and a good place to start your session.
area_getting_there: This boulder is downhill of the All of the Above Boulder. If you are at Claustrophobic, then go downhill and you should see the chalked rail facing the water.This boulder is also between the Mr. Smooth Boulder and the Hittin' The Rails Boulder.

routes.route_description: Starts standing on adjacent rock with hands on high rail and tops out straight above. Careful with feet since there's no edges so you're smearing on smooth rock.
routes.route_location: right side of south east face
routes.route_protection: 1 pad, potentially a spotter

routes.route_description: From the river-facing platform perform a difficult run and jump to the west arete.I'm submitting this with the FA's proposed rating but grade varies significantly with height and hops. Ignore the number and give it a try, it's a lot of fun.
routes.route_location: Below all of the above. Faces the river.
routes.route_protection: N/A
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Repeat. Got to the lip easily having done it before, but the top was much harder in 85 (versus 55 when I was here the last time). · Send. Use the seam as a tick mark and it’s not that bad if you got hops or reach. · Send. Did not run. Key right foot beta Evan discovered enabled passage without tooooo many attempts (maybe 15-20). 8a says V10, I have no idea. Felt V8, but maybe easier if you’re tall? I’ll give it the benefit of the doubt, though I could see it being downgraded in years to come as the comp kids get outdoors more.

area_description: Polished low ball boulder sitting next to the river with a sloped left arete and sloped lip. Boulder is slightly overhanging and sits between the Hueco Rock boulder and Chutzpah boulder.
area_getting_there: Walk down the river past the Hueco boulder and the Vagabond boulder sits right before the Chutzpah boulder.

routes.route_description: Fun low ball squeeze boulder. Start sitting with left heel on the left arete and right foot smearing on the face. Left hand starts low on sloped left arete, and right hands starts far right on the right arete. Compress and gradually slap your left and right hands up the arete until both hands are on the lip. Mantle up the left side of the lip. Mantling up the right could be harder line.
routes.route_location: Boulder sits between Hueco rock and the Chutzpah boulder.
routes.route_protection: 1 pad
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. High heeling right side feels way less difficult than v4. Possibly going up left is a lot harder.

area_description: Incredibly polished black granite boulder that will most definitely be at least partially underwater for most of the season. Surprisingly good to climb on.
area_getting_there: Right on the water behind you if you're looking at the hueco boulder straight on - about 30 feet away.

routes.route_description: Start as low as you can on the crack feature on the right side of the boulder by the sand bar (when the water is low enough) Go up the crack using a good crimp to a huge hueco jug and topout above.Down climb is just left of the this route and is debatably harder
routes.route_location: Water must be very low for the boulder to be climbable!From the hueco boulder go down to the shore and right about 30 feet. Right side of the boulder - see photos to see which boulder.
routes.route_protection: don't fall

route_comments.comment_text: Not sure if this is an FA or not - wouldn't be surprised otherwise. Let me know if you know anything about it! instagram.com/reel/CwNnhAPq… Aug 21, 2023
I've climbed this in the past when the river is low and imagine others have as well. Great to give it a name and post it up though, it's fun! Aug 21, 2023

area_description: In the river. Downstream of kid hops and high and dry.
area_getting_there: Walk past kid hops and look for the boulder in the middle of the river with the seam running through it.

routes.route_description: Climb the seam from a stand start. Difficult feet, a cool dish and a sloping top round out the experience.
routes.route_location: Walk past kid hops and the high and dry slab. In the river...
routes.route_protection: Harvest some sticks and branches

area_description: Closest river boulder to the railroad. Not sure if there is an official name
area_getting_there: First boulder on the trail to All of the Above, next to Claustrophobia.

routes.route_description: Stand start on the opposing arced side pulls and climb up to the lip. The funky landing adds some excitement.
routes.route_location: To the right of claustrophobia
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Anyone know if this already has a name? Hard to believe it hasn't been done many times though it was covered in moss. Seemed like there was an awkward low start to the right as well. Jul 6, 2020

area_description: Boulder hidden by two large big leaf maples behind Leggo My Ego boulder.
area_getting_there: Approach as for Leggo my Ego. Once at the base of Leggo my ego. Turn 90 degrees to your right and follow the faint climbers trail into the woods.

routes.route_description: With a L hand crimp and an ok L heel make your way to the lip and traverse left towards the tree.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Pads

routes.route_description: Start seated on the large fallen log with your left hand on a good jug, right on the poor sloper, and your left foot on the obvious start chip. Move up and right to the right facing in-cut. Traverse climbers left around the boulder to a small crack and climb to the top.
routes.route_location: Only clean line on the Oyster Mushroom Boulder. A lower start exists but is cramped due to the fallen log.
routes.route_protection: Pads

routes.route_description: Start on the faint rail and work towards the lip.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Pads

area_description: This is a small Boulder sticking up from a small basin created by a few other boulders. It's directly upriver from Chuptzpah. The small basin is below the river's water level at times. The boulder is only about 8-9ft tall, but is a good rock to warm up on. The rock is like everything else here, smooth granite. There are a few easy problems on the rock, and a possibility for a sit-start problem as well.  Careful of the fall-zone, it's not very flat. The downclimb is obvious and uses a rock next to NBD.
area_getting_there: Right behind Chutzpah boulder.

routes.route_description: The start and first couple of moves are the trickiest here, then it becomes an easy slab, basically. I mostly did this out of a lack of being able to find anything else that was climbable, and in my skill level, due to a very high river. Hands on the left corner of the rock, and one foot on the big, sloping base near the bottom of the boulder. Then move up from there, working your feet up slopey pockets and hands along the edge, avoiding the moss that lives on the rock. It's a quick climb with only a few moves, and a fun little start. Nothing particularly special, but it's something to do that's on the easy side. Good for a beginner.
routes.route_location: Facing NBD, looking at it in the direction of the river from the small basin this climb starts in, you'll see it. I started as pictured (see photo). The downclimb off the top uses a rock to the left.
routes.route_protection: Bring a crashpad. Possibly 2 to help with the awkward landing zone.

area_description: The proud lowball sitting right under the warmup boulder. There's a good chance this thing's underwater.
area_getting_there: Sitting on the edge of the river (or under depending on the season) right below the warmup boulder.

routes.route_description: Sit start as low as possible compressed with left on a rail and right hand on the arete. Compress and slap your way up this font style mega lowball. Get creative with high heels, alpine knees and/or a knee wrap. Oddly enjoyable if you're into this kind of thing.
routes.route_location: When facing the boulder from The Warmup Boulder, this problem lies on the right side.
routes.route_protection: Pad

route_comments.comment_text: youtube.com/shorts/uuOPAX5x… Sep 1, 2022

area_description: Shady spot, lots of features with several problems. The first prominent boulder you see in the woods.
area_getting_there: If approaching from the east drive approximately 2.2 miles down Reiter Road from the three-way intersection of Avenue A and 2nd street. If approaching from the West drive approximately 5.5 miles down Reiter Road from the intersection of US-2 and Reiter Road. There is a green gate with a brown sign on it on a little downhill gravelish slope. The parking for the area is a pullout that is just past this green gate from the East and just before it from the West. The Leggo My Ego boulder is found by hiking downhill for approximately 3 minutes on this gravelish road and then taking a faint trail off to the right which leads to the boulder in the woods. If you've hit the train tracks you've gone too far.

area_comments.comment_text: Video featuring the routes on the Leggo My Ego boulder youtu.be/2ZLiSnIVfBU If you haven't climbed here, you really must, its an amazing area. Nov 3, 2018

routes.route_description: Start matched on the head height sloper around the corner from Leggo My Ego. There are some small smeary feet and an obvious sloper/start hold. Move out left to a sloping shelf and mantle or throw a heel up to a good right hand hold. Top out from here.
routes.route_location: On the Leggo My Ego boulder around the corner from the problem of the same name. Obvious chalked up slopers.
routes.route_protection: Landing is fine if not a little angled downwards. A pad or so and you should be fine.

route_comments.comment_text: Correct, but this side of the boulder has not. Feel free to look at any photo or guide book from the last 20+ years for reference. May 11, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. the key is to keep moving and really reach for that jug. after that your home free. took me maybe 3 attempts. freind said it was hard so maybe it is v3, just my type of climb I guess. · Send. Fun sloper start, easy to get derailed trying to find marginal feet, you just gotta throw the leg up and drive at the jug · Flash. Easy for V3 imo. Fun for such short moves, but i like slopers · Send. Second session and probably fourth or fifth try. Slopers didn’t feel that bad considering 80 degree heat. Sick rig!!!

routes.route_description: Start matched on the far left side of the obvious sloper rail with more or less non-existent feet. Traverse right by either campusing on the tacky slopers or smearing/heel hooking. This will take you to the mantle on the far right side of the boulder. Top out from here.
routes.route_location: On the Leggo My Ego boulder around the corner from the problem of the same name. Obvious chalked up slopers.
routes.route_protection: Landing is fine if not a little angled downwards. A pad or so and you should be fine.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. every time I climb on wet rock I say I’ll never do it again but here I am · Flash. wet so couldnt heel the rail so i campused till the link up w chinook. still felt like a 4 tho

routes.route_description: Sit start on good crimps and feet. Follow and short but Interesting sequence straight up. (Most likely dirty, I didn’t brush that well)
routes.route_location: Looking at the obvious lego my ego face, it is around the right corner near the back arete
routes.route_protection: 1 pad

routes.route_description: Start as per DUPLO but avoid the right arete. When standing use a high right facing crimp and gaston to traverse left, then top out.
routes.route_location: Right next to DUPLO
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_description: This long technical traverse starts at the far right corner of the Leggo boulder with a sit start, right hand on a good sidepull/jug and left hand either matching or on a small left nubbin,  move up to obvious left jug above and do most of Sigmund Freud in reverse which leads into the intro moves of Gimme Back My ID - once through that,  take a breath and continue on to tip toe through the delicate moves of Stackin' Leggos to finish out on the top of Leggo My Ego.  A nice enduro test piece to give a more difficult spin to such an excellent boulder!  I think we've grown way outta V-grades, so I call it an SBP "white" (or somewhere between v8+/9) For those rare folks who enjoy the sweet pain of Stackin Leggos but need the next level.  If someone has done this in the past,  don't be shy and lets see the steezy footy.Link to youtube vid: youtube.com/watch?v=P8KKyCZxF3g
routes.route_location: Leggo Boulder
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: I love that this traverse just keeps getting longer and graded harder and harder. Can someone please start on Hagakure, do that entire boulder and then backflip from the top to the jugs from Leggo and then do all of Stackin' Leggos in reverse to the start holds of Sigmund Freud? Then Washington can have its first V17. Sep 30, 2021

routes.route_description: Sit start on a left-facing ramp feature. Get standing, then use a coarse pocket to get to a jug up and right.
routes.route_location: A few feet to the right of Leggo My Ego.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Any ideas on how that mono was created? Such a strange hold(s). Oct 26, 2020
There are similar features on a few climbs around Index, the first one that comes to mind is the crystal pocket on Racer-X. Oct 26, 2020
just as good as leggo imo, if not a tad harder youtu.be/ZOZZba694_I Jul 3, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. A few tries. I think this one is really fun. Really cool move at the end. · Send. Taught me a lot about just jumping for the jug even if the stance is uncomfortable · Send. Funky and fun. Opted for a dyno last move which I don't see people do too often on this one, but it just felt right for me · Send. Crucial left inner thigh press on the low Arete to get the right hand inverted thumb hold. Cool climb. · Send. Rocking onto the left foot was really hard. Wasn’t even physical, just tough hip positioning I couldn’t seem to replicate every time. · Woohoo! Three sends! Second go. Jump to the mega jug. Not as good as the 4 · Repeat. Turn RH to mantle and right knee / thigh scum in corner to get right thumb into pocket. Use right thigh to push left into LH undercling. Cool beta! Makes it predictable. Feels tough before unlocking the beta, casual after! · Cool! Felt hard for me. Used the thumb-dercling to get over to the left · Attempt. Bottom section scrunchy. Use right hand side pull crimp and left undercling crimp. Top is tall · last day out with AU in the PNW, sad. Decent line on good rock.

routes.route_description: Stand start on the arete left of Leggo My Ego with great holds and marginal feet. The crux is pulling up from the first lip to a slopey hold near the top. Once you've made it there, you have to climb right, following good holds to the top.
routes.route_location: Obviously climbed corner of LME boulder, left of the v7 route. Downclimb off the back.
routes.route_protection: The landing is flat. One pad should be fine.

route_comments.comment_text: How do you access this site from the main city of Index? Trying to head out there come March. Feb 22, 2023
FYI B Fox this probably wont be dry for you in march as it is in quite the forest. You might luck out but I would definitely have a back up plan. Feb 23, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. beautiful cimb on a beautiful mossy boulder. wasn't paying attention So no flash, but definitely do able . · Flash. Nice warm up, didn’t see the left hand crimp after the initial move so it was probably more balancy than it needed to be · Flash. This thing is pretty good...and it's also harder than both Chinook and Chinook Traverse imo · Flashed it ! Feels good to come back and do something (and for to fee easier) that you struggled on/were unable to do previously

routes.route_description: Sit start matched on a low right flake and climb up and left to a fun mantle, using an excellent undercling pinch hold.
routes.route_location: Backside of the Leggo boulder. Also serves as the downclimb
routes.route_protection: One pad

routes.route_description: Start low matched on a ball shaped jug. Find your feet, move up to another ball shaped jug and then move up to a slopey sidepull rail. Dyno for the lip out left and rock over. Trickier than it looks.There is also a hand far out left and a small crimpy sidepull up high on the right. I have heard this problem can be done statically but I've only ever seen it done with the dyno so your mileage may vary beta wise.(Description by Shlomo B, on Aug 28, 2020)
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Landing is good but it's a big move to the lip so 2 pads isn't the worst idea just for coverage of a broad landing zone.

route_comments.comment_text: If you stack pads/step off of the adjacent boulder this climb can be done as a “stand”. Very awesome. I was able to flash the isolated last moves at 6’0” without cutting feet. When I sent from the bottom I had to jump but if you’re tall it’s all about commitment as the swing gets better the further left you land. Nov 6, 2019
youtu.be/9TXC2Ga3T-k Oct 26, 2020
Crimps, balance, tension, high feet, + a no hands dyno to a slopey jug? Full on classic! Oct 30, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Last move got pretty infuriating after a while but a cool one to tick off · Attempt. spent some time on this today, got it all down but couldn’t bring myself to 100% commit to the move to the lip, cool movement, lot of micro · Attempt. Struggled with getting my right leg up in a small box. Didn’t try the jump that many times · Send. very high quality. Diverse movements, but hated having to double dyno so much. · Attempt. tried the static beta. might have to go dyno though. super classic, come back for this one · Send. Repeat. Not sure I’ve ever repeated, always felt kinda hard / committing. Manifesting the theme of better vs. stronger…was not ready for Hag today. · Send. August 15, 2023 I fractured my radius by falling on the landing zone boulder. Finally got revenge and sent this great rig! · Attempt. getting close to the send, slapping the top, the trick is a slow left foot pistol squat to stick the left hand and hold the barn door. · Send. One of my proudest sends to date. Second of the grade for me · Send. Sent on third session. Bottom felt much easier after dialing in the moves. Top still felt impossible while staring down the lip (just like it always did while sticking the move in isolation). · Send. day 2. so fun! thumb on that side pull was super important. also placing the initial toe correctly. · Send. Somehow dry enough to climb in Jan. Top of the boulder was a swimming pool so the mantle was a lot harder. · Attempt. Got to the jumping position a few times, think going to left hand is best. This one is all in the legs, basically 3 pistol squats in a row. Skin was bad and tried taping tips of middle two fingers in LH and helped so much · Send. Blew the flash. Slipped on the jug after dynoing. Didnr have it deep enough. All star line · Send. Press beta babyyyy. I'll come back and do the full dyno version later · Attempt. Usually don't tick attempts but I need to come back for this classic. So close! Good enough to have stayed all day projecting · Send. Great problem! Probably 6 or 7 attempts to figure out the beta. Felt very hard at first, but felt casual once dialed (heel hook is def the beta at start). · Send. The moves necessary to send Leggo are balancy and committing. So, naturally, I thought it was great! · Lead / Fell/Hung. Can’t commit to the jump! Got the right pad placement beta down now for next tims · Send. Took me a session and a half just to figure out beta for the bottom that worked. Dyno didn't feel that hard. Maybe harder than V6 as a whole? Very good problem. · Send. Very good problem. Kinda scary for me. Used the Left hand to go for the huck · Attempt. got bottom dialed but couldn't commit to top throw dyno. Night session with Pat. · Feels like a solid V6, definitely easier to stick the dyno using the left sidepull. · Rather than throwing for the lip with the left hand, I felt it better to get the left hand over to the good side pull on the left and then hit the lip with the right hand. · Solo. Finally sent. Maybe two dozen attempts? Almost equally close for the last dozen before sticking the left hand. · Annnd sent using right variation/tall guy beta. Sick dyno to the lip! SO GOOD · No send but very close. Hit the lip multiple times. Need fresh skin to try again. Awesome line

routes.route_name: Leggo What's Left of my Ego
routes.route_description: Begin matched on the jug as for Leggo Arete. Delicately traverse right into the rails of Leggo my Ego and awkwardly dyno to the lip, as per.
routes.route_location: On the Leggo my Ego boulder.
routes.route_protection: 3 pads.

route_comments.comment_text: Beta video: youtu.be/z8hqgwHKyNA Sep 1, 2020
Low variant beta video instagram.com/p/CJZV7IDjhak… Dec 29, 2020

routes.route_description: Begin matched on the jug as for Leggo Arete. Dyno to the top.
routes.route_location: Arete on the Leggo boulder.
routes.route_protection: 3 pads

route_comments.comment_text: Great dyno, especially with the one handed catch. Set by an all around solid dude. Get on this!! Aug 13, 2023

routes.route_name: Ouch I stepped on a Duplo
routes.route_description: Start matched on a good sidepull/undercling and a nice foot rail. Bump to a better sidepull/undercling, then bust up high left for a crimp, then to a high sloper and top out.The start seems harder for tall people (find a tiny left foot in the middle of the moss if you need to).
routes.route_location: To the left of Duplo Left.
routes.route_protection: One pad

routes.route_description: Start seated as for Gimmie Back My ID. Work your way right around the arete to a low jug at shin height, and then climb straight up.
routes.route_location: Shares a start with Gimme back my id on the right arete of the boulder. Gimme back my id goes to the left and Sigmund Freud goes to the right.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Actually starts all the way to the left on the rail feature used for Gimme Back My Id the start from the right jug as depicted in the photo is equally good though probably around a V3 Oct 1, 2020

Deserves more stars in my opinion due to the unique movement. It's worth stopping at this area for this one (or a good diversion while working one of the harder problems on this boulder)! Agree with Tristan, the sidepull jug out left is a natural start (and I believe the guidebook mentions it as well). May 30, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Surprised myself with this one. 2nd try after trying out some individual moves · Send. Fun climb ! Hand kept slipping off the right sloper at the end but it finally went ! Cool to see the progression, being able to send 4s in a day/fairly quickly · Send. A really good climb with great movement. One of my favorites. It felt really hard for the grade and took me awhile to get it · Send. Took several tries, just had to dial beta. Fun shouldery moves then delicate mantles, fun! · Variation going up the mantle move starting at the jug on the lower right side. I’ve heard it goes at V3 · Attempt. Sent from the right jug (felt v3), wish I would've read the description instead of just looking at the pic. Can't wait to come back and try real start on the left. · Flash. Woah so much better than it looks. Watched the beta then got the flash. Tricky top out. Low gravity day! · Send. Really fun movement; felt pretty stiff for 4, but was also end of the day · Send. Hard at the start, definitely not quite my style but was a decidedly good time by the time I was slapping the sloper. Send train with Emily and Mike · Send. Harder than slopey v3 on other side of boulder, I thought. Cool moves

routes.route_description: A wonderful line that starts with a techy slab traverse and ends with an all out dyno. Classic!Start sitting on the right side of the Leggo my Ego boulder with a good left hand pinch. Establish on the slopey foot ledge and then traverse left on tenuous underclings and smeary feet until you can reach the rail of Leggo my Ego. Finish with the Leggo my Ego dyno.
routes.route_location: Just right of Leggo my Ego.
routes.route_protection: A few pads. The landing is good.

route_comments.comment_text: youtu.be/76ozPGisRrU Sep 11, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. That jump…so committing. Top was wet, extra spicy oo. Slab sequence is very cool! Movement better than OG line. Do emojis work here? Answer: no. Haga went poorly, the epic continues. Tactics, concentration and mindset to be developed. Not sure I’ve ever experienced regression on a rock climb - a new challenge. · Attempt. Very techy (with some powerful moves to establish at start). Great problem. Really close. Should definitely come back and finish. · Attempt. Powerful and slabby. The opening moves and traverse are as good as Leggo my Ego direct. I got close to the send. This BP is def going on the TODO list.

routes.route_description: Sit start on the low sidepull jug as for "Everything is Awesome",  pop up and left making the reverse moves of Sigmund Freud to end at the top of "Gimme Back My ID" where you do tricky static moves or full on dyno your way to the top mega-jug.  Exciting little extension!
routes.route_location: Far right corner face of Leggo My Ego boulder
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: According to the posted route count for Index, this is route #700. Jan 12, 2021
That's a lot o' routes! Jan 12, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. first time figuring out beta by myself on a V6! transition from extension to V5 was crux, but sent in one send burn after that part clicked · Flash. Not an actual flash since I’ve done the 5 many many times. Never reversed the 4 moves though.

area_description: The first boulder you get to on the approach, after turning right down the tracks the first and second trails will bring you down near Hueco Rock. The beautiful river-polished granite offers unique wavy features and is super fun to climb. Bring multiple pads for anything besides the slab to even out the rocky landings.Not accessible when the river is high.
area_getting_there: Take the first side trail while walking down the tracks.

routes.route_description: Walk up the center of the low-angle polished slab on the upriver side of the boulder. Do not bail out right to easier features.Unlike other problems here, this one has a great landing!
routes.route_location: Upriver slab.
routes.route_protection: pad

routes.route_description: Mantle into the high hueco to the left of The Tube and top out rightwards. Fun!
routes.route_location: NW (trackside) arete of Hueco Rock. Left of The Tube.
routes.route_protection: pads

route_comments.comment_text: No falling! Move quick through this burly two-move wonder V0 and pretend your spotter will catch you if you blow a foot Jan 26, 2023

routes.route_description: Step into the low scoop and follow the huecos up and left to the top.
routes.route_location: Starts in the lowest scoop on the downriver side of the boulder.
routes.route_protection: pads

route_comments.comment_text: FYI, the top out is not trivial and the fall is...bad. Maybe it was the heat, maybe because I was in the dark (with floodlights). Either way, this is a serious boulder. Aug 20, 2020
Shouldery crux getting up into the scoopies, with an engaging but easy mantle at the end. Aug 5, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Took a couple tries to get the beginning and top out made me a bit nervous · Send. Put a V0 climber on this if you want them to have a meltdown or die. · In the dark with floodlights. Very scary top out. Spent what felt like 15 minutes up there

routes.route_description: Jump off a small rock to a good edge. Make a powerful mantle and follow the slightly spooky arete to the top.
routes.route_location: See beta photo. Jump off the small rock to the right of Hueco Man.
routes.route_protection: pads

routes.route_description: Make a tricky move into the tube-shaped feature to the left of Hueco Man and continue up and left to the top.For full value don't use any of Hueco Man's starting features when you're stuck in the tube.
routes.route_location: Left of Hueco Man
routes.route_protection: pads

area_description: Just below “All of the above”. Has an obvious vertical rail running down the middle of the face.
area_getting_there: Just a couple feet down from the All of the Above Boulder.

routes.route_description: Start with left hand on the arête and right hand as low as possible on the finger crack. Work your way up to good holds for the mantle.
routes.route_location: Obvious seam on the left arete of the Hittin' the Rail boulder.
routes.route_protection: 2 pads

route_comments.comment_text: youtu.be/ac2U95vF0ds Apr 24, 2021
For extra fun try only using the crack without the arete. Probably around V5-V6 depending on how you feel about ring locks. May 12, 2021

routes.route_description: Start on the lowest part of the right facing rail. Move up and then lunge for the lip of the horizontal rail.
routes.route_location: On the obvious face of the Hittin The Rail Boulder.
routes.route_protection: A pad or two
routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. So close. Left hand gaston, right foot far smear, right hand up to divot, left to sloper, right in slightly, left up, then right to start of stand · Send. this is V8+ no cap. last trip I sent midnite in like 5 goes and this shit took me no less than 2 hours · Lead / Redpoint. Throw left hand up into slot (tape left index) keep right hand on start then get feet below the. Toe hook right

routes.route_description: The stand start to Hittin' The Rail. Start on the high sloper and crimpy seam just above the start holds of the low start. From here find some way to get your foot up, move your hands up the seam and then if you're shorter use a very high foot and if you're taller make a big lunge for a better hold right before the top of the boulder. Top out from here.
routes.route_location: On the obvious face of the Hittin The Rail Boulder.
routes.route_protection: Probably the best landing of any boulder in the area. Two pads would be good. The landing is a little bit angled but it's mostly flat.

routes.route_description: Start on sidepulls at the horizontal holds and slap up to the big slopey ledge. Then reach up to the edge just before the lip for the top out.
routes.route_location: The furthest left problem on the boulder.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Cool little problem. Feels a little sketchy especially depending on how far the reach is for you. Jan 13, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Right hand sidepull, left hand bottom ledge, left foot small foothold, right foot flag. Right hand up to top ledge, match Left foot up to bottom ledge. Lift body up and grab small sidepull with left hand. Match feet, right heel-hool. Pull self up MAKE SURE TOP IS NOT MOSSY, COULD BREAK ANKLE IF YOU FALL FROM THAT HEIGHT ONTO THE ROCKS.

routes.route_description: Started matched on the ledge and head straight up for the top out.
routes.route_location: Left around the arete of Finger Crack.
routes.route_protection: N/A

area_description: Boulder after kid hops. About 40 feet down the river and on the right side. Big obvious slab off the beach in the trees
area_getting_there: Walk past kids hops and look to your right and back by the trees. If you walked longer than 2 minutes past kids hops you are probably too far

area_comments.comment_text: In need of a good scrubbing, I didn't have the means at the time but I feel it would be worth the elbow grease!! Really cool feature and deserving of more traffic. Great landing. Can also get there by hiking up into the woods west of the Gemstone boulder and continuing west on the faint trail about 30-50 yards. Jul 29, 2024

routes.route_description: Start on the very right of the boulder with right hand on the arete and left hand on the face. Climb up and right to the jug at the start of the crack. Follow the crack up and left, then gain jugs and grab the lip. A little high, landing is great though!
routes.route_location: From right side to left on the High and Dry boulder
routes.route_protection: At least 2 pads. Better with 3

routes.route_description: Push off the the slaby foot to gain the crimpy sidepull. Move dynamically to the sharp but good jug higher on the face.
routes.route_location: Left side of the boulder. Starts at the crimpy sidepull on the face.
routes.route_protection: 2 pads

area_description: Shady.
area_getting_there: In the forest, right side of the trail, just as the trail starts to bend and parallel the tracks.

routes.route_description: Start matched on a head-height sloper and move powerfully through the seem and up to the lip. A more difficult  variation starts on a right-facing edge 3 feet to the left of the normal start.
routes.route_location: Directly in the middle of face.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: youtu.be/doS8im4N_ak heel hook beta way easier for me then the shoulder beta the shoulder beta is probably proper 12 heel hook beta more like v10 at least for me May 16, 2023

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Had perfect conditions when I sent only took 2 days of effort for the send so i think the 12 grade is soft if you have good conditions probably the nicest boulder ive ever done quality is amazing

routes.route_description: Adds 2 moves to the start of Hagakure. Establishing is difficult.
routes.route_location: Start on a left hand sidepull and right hand crimp / non-hold.
routes.route_protection: Pads

routes.route_description: Start on a sloper and low undercling left of the arete. Climb the arete.Possible lower starts/harder exits?
routes.route_location: Left arete of Hagakure.
routes.route_protection: Pads

route_comments.comment_text: Either very contrived or I broke the beta? instagram.com/reel/Cp6xflxs… Aug 9, 2023
Interesting slabby movement but some of the holds are still a bit crumbly and a couple of parts could use some wire brushing. Mar 12, 2024

routes.route_description: Start on the obvious non existent sloper and work your way up to more non existent Slopers. Mantel on the non existent holds and your done. Pretty much just friction gets you through this one! Bonus if you do it in approach shoes!
routes.route_location: On the right side of the boulder. Should be obvious
routes.route_protection: A pad or two. The top out is pretty overgrown so take caution when topping out. Otherwise it will probably take 20 minutes to clean/ reclean?

route_comments.comment_text: Drew Ruana put up this problem last year or the year before and called it Bear Hug. Doesnt feel v2. May 11, 2020

Based on your comment above I would highly recommend keeping your opinion to yourself. While this area is CLASSIC to Sky Valley bouldering not all of the lines were scrubbed or climbed during the initial development. May 11, 2020
Is this Brother Bear? Starts on high crimps and does throw to lip? Mar 17, 2021

area_description: Opposite "Flower" on the Big Rock boulder.
area_getting_there: Turn around when facing Flower on the Big Rock boulder (on MP referred to as the Flower Boulder).

routes.route_description: This is the low start to the Jewel (V3) on the Gemstone boulder. Sit start under the roof with the good 2-finger pocket on the lip. Work your way through the bulge without dabbing, and finish on the Jewel. Could be 4 stars without the dabbiness. Thin pads help.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 3 pads

route_comments.comment_text: youtu.be/0vnafXrrJXw Apr 24, 2021
Definitely tried from a 2 finger pocked and a small undercling crimp under it. maybe that should be the sit start? Wouldnt have started where the video showed... Sep 12, 2021
Oh yeah what the heck that video starts after the crux, lol! Sep 28, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Maybe the lightest graze of a dab as I was entering the stand, but dab police said they saw nothing - maybe just the insane wind and pants flapping. So nearly blew the top since I didn’t retry it. Crazy beta where I press through left toe on far wall beneath roof and find right heel really far out. No knee pad and started matched at the pocket (LH in pocket and RH immediately adjacent on the sloping lip) · Send. Awesome problem. Went in a few goes. My crux was moving from the pocket to the lip, and then not dabbing as I brought my feet around. Great climb, a lot of techniques at play! · Had a minor dab, but I’m counting it for myself. Agree that it would be 4 stars without the dab risk.

routes.route_description: From the guidebook "start standing using an incut right-facing sidepull and a low left hand. Top out straight up." I started with my left hand around the arete since I wasn't exactly sure which "low left hand" the guidebook was referring to. I'm pretty tall, and the move to the lip felt reachy.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: I started this with the lowest right hand sidepull and left hand palming the sloper on the low bulge. Seems v3 from there. Aug 21, 2019
youtu.be/BT1J5b1UFvI Apr 24, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Low left hand, right side pull, left foot small ledge, right foot flag.

routes.route_description: Start matched on the far left side of the wave, campus or use your heel to work your way right. Top out directly above the start of the wave.
routes.route_location: Gemstone boulder, far left of the wave, under the massive tree
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: This has been done. Unknown v2 Feb 14, 2022

routes.route_description: Sit start to the wave, left hand under the roof compressing against right hand on the arete.  You actually start sitting on the little rock at the base of it to the right.  Adds some good squeezing into the wave and is about a grade harder.  A variation starting matched in underclings to the left is also possible.
routes.route_location: Sit start down and right of the wave
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_description: Start crouched under the roof with your left hand on an incut edge and right hand on the nose / arete. Go left to the seam and top out straight up (or out left). The guidebooksaystop out left via the seam, though the line drawn in the picture goes straight up. Don't think your choice will affect the difficulty.Starting with your right hand lower on the arete is also possible. I watched a friend do this variation, though I never tried.
routes.route_location: Around the corner from the Jewel.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: youtu.be/H6Yue7hKKrM Apr 24, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. Could finally do the first move multiple times. Punted out left a few times.
