Realised working the move out left is tricky because the heel isn’t in the same spot. Left toe in on chip is key. Went left bumped up to good hold then right heel contortion and leaned out right. Tick underneath next time · Gotta train the one arms and core. Starting off the hang is much easier and still really cool. Try R heel on then bump RH to lip first · Attempt. Worked a lot. Could go with better core strength and contact strength. ß: Start right hand high on arete. Right foot heel hooked. Slap up and squeeze.

routes.route_description: Variation of The Wave:Campus start matched on the bottom of the nose feature, finish as per The Wave. I threw left hand straight up to the good hold and had to do a nasty swap. Felt similar in difficulty to The Wave, but with a much less spanned/more obvious (to me) start.
routes.route_location: See directions for the wave
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: This thing has been done In every imaginable way. Good vision though! Feb 14, 2022

area_description: About the 11th major boulder downstream, it may partly stick out into the river.
area_getting_there: Trail down from tracks.

routes.route_description: Sit start with bad feet, and make a big move to the sharp mono crimp. Work your way up with more bad feet from there. The holds you need are clean, but there is lots of moss elsewhere.
routes.route_location: Left of Flower on the same face (downstream side of boulder)
routes.route_protection: 2 pads

routes.route_description: The cover shot of the original Sky Valley Bouldering Guide featured this rad climb. Step onto the vertical face and move right and up to the good edge where the arete zags. Make committing moves up the arete and top out leftwards.
routes.route_location: Visible from Hitting the Rail / Finger Crack on the backside of the flower boulder. Look for the zigzagging arete.
routes.route_protection: Don't fall on the jumbled rocks
routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Unique and spicy. River was high… a fall early might send you swimming · One of my favorites I’ve done at Index. Final moves are a bit airy and committing.

routes.route_description: About 3 moves to the top.
routes.route_location: In the photo, the problem starts on the lowest chalked hold, middle right side, then up to the left-leaning sidepull.
routes.route_protection: none

route_comments.comment_text: The Western Washington Bouldering guidebook gives this V7. I agree. First move is quite hard though. Aug 21, 2019

V7? Lol. I normally try not to get into "grade wars" and can't wait for the day when the old school "V" grade is replaced by color grades with a scale, but felt compelled to comment for those who are projecting this thing and use grades as a way to grow and inspire themselves.  Flower is a short but incredibly engaging rig with a unique combo of tension, foot technique, delicacy,  lots of... more V7? Lol. I normally try not to get into "grade wars" and can't wait for the day when the old school "V" grade is replaced by color grades with a scale, but felt compelled to comment for those who are projecting this thing and use grades as a way to grow and inspire themselves.  Flower is a short but incredibly engaging rig with a unique combo of tension, foot technique, delicacy,  lots of power and a little luck needed.  Aside from climbing Flower myself,  I've invited many stronger buddies,  as well as some world-class climbers who I've been lucky to give the "index tour" to, and we all have agreed this thing is as solid as they come.  Maybe we're missing some easier beta or Washington is breeding some beasts who are way stronger and more talented than they wanna admit?   Long story short,  enjoy the powerful core tension moves of Flower Jan 19, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. Need more working to go. Maybe better technique or beta. Not worth projecting.

routes.route_description: Start left in the quartz crimp, right on the arete, and climb up and left; make sure top is clean first
routes.route_location: Right corner of the boulder
routes.route_protection: Several pads

area_description: The furthest boulder to the right when facing the river.
area_getting_there: Continue upstream for about  2 minutes after reaching the path that cuts down to the stream for All of the Above. The path eventually curves down  toward the river. This is the boulder pictured inmountainproject.com/photo/1….

routes.route_description: Start matched on the massive ledge and make your way up, dynoing to a crimp edge half way up.
routes.route_location: Starts on the obvious ledge on Flattop Boulder
routes.route_protection: 2+ pads. Falling on this boulder is super sketchy, but two pads towards the water ensures that, if you fall, you won't smash your face. Pads below the start is not necessary
routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Mantled then spent 10 minutes lamenting the fact that I was an inch off of reaching statically before finally committing. Felt like a fall might not end well. 4 points for difficulty + 4 for commitment = 8? Grades are weird - the whole experience felt V8, the movement difficulty felt no where close to that. Interestingly, I could only in good conscious recommend this climb to those climbing >V8…you want the margin. · Send. Sent on 2nd go. Dynos are hard to grade and this problem seemed super easy for me. The book gives this problem the grade of V8 and I've talked to others who have thought this was V8, but maybe it's my style.

routes.route_description: Start on the the jug and make a huge dyno to the rail out left.
routes.route_location: Start right about where the river meets the sand.
routes.route_protection: N/A

area_description: The third major boulder from the east.
area_getting_there: From the railroad tracks, take the first trail down to the river.

area_comments.comment_text: I made an edit of the v10 featuring Kai Poff. Might be a good source for those who want beta! youtube.com/watch?v=xNUlvwY… Dec 1, 2024

routes.route_description: Follow the holds on the left side, just above the climbers in the photo.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: none

routes.route_description: Start standing on the right hand pinch and left hand sidepull crimp (2 hand moves into Chutzpah). Pull up and paste your left foot on. Continue to the top as for Chutzpah.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 3-4 pads. Top out is committing.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. The sit’s still hard. Haven’t squeezed in a while so I’m sure I’ll be sore from the fitness burn on the stand. Maximum burl. · Send. Directly in the sun. Helpful right heel beta from Evan and Matt - after both hands are on the lip, bring right heel close to and slightly above right hand (as opposed to further out right). Very messy top out. For when I come back for the full line: LH to second meathook, L heel to toe, RH mantles to get R foot on, RH crosses above left.

routes.route_description: Arete on the right side, as viewed in the photo, nearest the river.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: none

route_comments.comment_text: its all clear and the sand is HIGH so the start is much less awkward Mar 16, 2020
Here is a video of this river polished granite. youtu.be/T27f3wm4Mh0 Enjoy! Sep 3, 2020

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Great friction today! Second try of the day! right shoe on. Big stoke · Attempt. Made some good progress here- stand on left foot, right toe arete, mantle left hand down, match feet, left foot up. You pushed up once on your left foot, but blew it. You’ll get it next time. Left foot bare, right foot shoe · Flash. Much easier if you use a high right heel hook after mantling the start · Sent! Wow this was a cool one to work. Felt easy on the send go · Took a lot of falls before figuring this one out. Great body position and balance required. · Tried this repeatedly but just couldn't make it happen first try. super fun, will have to come back

routes.route_description: Starts on the rib feature in the middle of the face in the photo.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: none

route_comments.comment_text: Nothin like polished granite. Oct 18, 2013

Checked this boulder out today (May 28, 2014). I'm guessing I saw it, but if I did, it seems unclimbable with a higher river. Spring likely makes this a no-go unless I totally missed it and was looking at something else. edit: Checked again. The water level is just low enough to make this do-able now. Definitely not a climb to be done when the river is high. May 28, 2014

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. + attempts on mr smooth. Video beta helped but still not really getting established

area_description: The giant, aesthetic riverside boulder visible from Highway 2, home to the immaculate Built To Last (v8) featured on the cover of Pablo Zuleta's 2014 Western Washington Bouldering guide book.
area_getting_there: From the Boulder Drop boulders, continue hiking down the railroad track approx. 20 minutes to the obvious small meadow on the south side between the tracks and the river. Walk to the river, the boulder is riverside and hard to miss.

routes.route_description: Start on obvious crimps on the low right side of the face (sitting on the small boulder?). Climb the rails up and left to a committing finish and mantle.The fall zone is pretty big and the boulder is tall, so make sure to bring plenty of pads and attentive spotters. Also this boulder is sun-baked during the summer and the landing is underwater most of the year, so stay alert for the rare ideal late-fall conditions.
routes.route_location: The biggest riverside face. You can't miss it.
routes.route_protection: lots of pads and spotters

route_comments.comment_text: Vid: youtube.com/watch?v=_VN2fp_… Dec 8, 2022

area_description: About the 7th boulder downstream, from the east. Further from the river.
area_getting_there: Take a trail down from the tracks.

routes.route_description: Compress the hanging aretes, as shown in the photo. Powerful, technical and tall.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: pads

route_comments.comment_text: FA:Johnny Goicoechea Here is Kelly's video vimeo.com/19153325 Jul 29, 2013

Linking a video (not mine) that gives a good perspective of this problem. youtu.be/VgjXi21UnPw?t=19 Looks like you need some serious wingspan... Does anyone know roughly what span you need to do that beta? Dec 29, 2021

Likely at least 5'10" for it to be as comfortable as shown in the video (not entirely maxed out) . Carlo Traversi is 5'7" and according to an interview he did with power company climbing his wingspan is +3 or 4" powercompanyclimbing.com/bl… more Likely at least 5'10" for it to be as comfortable as shown in the video (not entirely maxed out) . Carlo Traversi is 5'7" and according to an interview he did with power company climbing his wingspan is +3 or 4" powercompanyclimbing.com/bl… Feb 11, 2023

routes.route_description: Start sitting on the low left of the bulging rock, climb up on crimps, grab the slopping lip of the boulder, and traverse left to the two horns to top out. The crux might be swinging your feet over left and up before the mantel.
routes.route_location: On the back side of the All of the Above Boulder. To the left of Claustrophobic (v2).
routes.route_protection: A couple pads and a spotter.

routes.route_description: Begin crouched with a waist-high rail at the center of the blank face. Traverse right into two slopers, and mantle onto the bulge. At the lip, shuffle your way back left to two horns and top out with a high foot.
routes.route_location: On the backside of the All of the Above boulder, to the left of Camel Spotting.
routes.route_protection: 3 pads and a spotter.

routes.route_description: The climb starts on the obvious ledge and moves to small, but good holds and is a layback most of the way up.
routes.route_location: On the back side of All Of The Above on the side facing the Chutzpah downclimb. This problem is where AotA boulder comes in contact with another small rock.
routes.route_protection: a couple of pads would be ideal here due to the uneven landing zone.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. Did the first few moves, but it was dark, wet, and mossy - so no top out for me

area_description: Two small boulders above Blues Cliff
area_getting_there: Park at the Lower Town Wall lot and hike up the Upper Town Wall trail. Take the second left for Mid Wall and follow the trail past the turnoff for Blues Cliff and Rhythm. Shortly before you reach the rickety bridge you will see two small boulders on the right, close to the top of Starfish.

routes.route_description: A tall, fun, easy boulder crack. Follow the obvious crack on the left side on good holds.
routes.route_location: Hike the Mid Wall trail from Lower Town Wall. These two boulders are on the right just before the top of Starfish.
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads

routes.route_description: A fun line on the right side of the boulder. Not too hard.
routes.route_location: Park at the Lower Town Wall lot and hike up the Upper Town Wall trail. Take the second left for Mid Wall and follow the trail past the turnoff for Blues Cliff and Rhythm. Shortly before you reach the rickety bridge you will see two small boulders on the right, close to the top of Starfish.
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads

routes.route_name: There's Money in the Banana Stand
routes.route_description: A fun easy climb on a short boulder
routes.route_location: Park at the Lower Town Wall lot and hike up the Upper Town Wall trail. Take the second left for Mid Wall and follow the trail past the turnoff for Blues Cliff and Rhythm. Shortly before you reach the rickety bridge you will see two small boulders on the right, close to the top of Starfish.
routes.route_protection: 0-1 pads

routes.route_description: An easy line up the right side of a small boulder
routes.route_location: Park at the Lower Town Wall lot and hike up the Upper Town Wall trail. Take the second left for Mid Wall and follow the trail past the turnoff for Blues Cliff and Rhythm. Shortly before you reach the rickety bridge you will see two small boulders on the right, close to the top of Starfish.
routes.route_protection: 0-1 pads

area_description: Smooth boulder with low-angle face.
area_getting_there: On trail between the start of Pisces and Princely Ambitions.

routes.route_description: High-angle friction climbing to the right of the arete. Do not use the arete.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: none

routes.route_description: Layback the left side of the arete.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: none

route_comments.comment_text: I had to pinch the arete pretty hard at times, the feet aren't good enough to fully lay back the whole way up. Slabs are tough to grade, I'm sure there's someone who could climb this with no hands at all. Also I cleaned up the top a bit. Sep 21, 2023

routes.route_description: Ascend the lower angle face right of the arete. Use the arete for hands.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: N/A

area_description: Tall and shady. Off the beaten path.
area_getting_there: It is below the Sentry Box overhangs at the right side of the Lower Lump.

routes.route_description: An old aid boulder now clean highball
routes.route_location: In the woods just east of lower lump underneath Sentry Box Overhangs
routes.route_protection: pads

area_description: Right at the conjunction of the trails near the bathroom. Unclear to us if this came down in the recent Nov. 2023 rockfall or existed beforehand, but we didn't find any chalk on it nor descriptions in the guidebook or here. Has some potentially tough routes if one can campus through no feet.
area_getting_there: Right above the bathrooms where the four trails meet.

routes.route_description: Start on the two good crimps on the side of the boulder facing the rockslide and away from the bathrooms. Use the nub or dyno straight up. Has 3 different V1 variations for different heights.
routes.route_location: On the side of the boulder facing where the rockfall damage is
routes.route_protection: 1 pad
routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Kinda boring and just really soft. Not even really a V0- to be honest. Plus it really on like 1 move and then you top out.

area_description: Short boulder directly below the Great Northern Slab.
area_getting_there: Near the intersection of the trail, where the Inner Wall trail takes off left.

routes.route_description: Mantle on sloping holds at the left end of the traverse problem.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: none

routes.route_description: Traverse the steep face.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: none

area_description: Small boulder in the talus field with a surprisingly fun single mantle route and a very safe fall zone to chill at. In the winter, the blackberry thorns mean death, in the summer, it's a nice midday snack. Name comes from the fact we thought this was the diamond boulder from afar and were surprised to discover this fun climb instead.
area_getting_there: Directly below the railroad tracks. If coming from the parking lot with the bathrooms, its approximately 50 feet past the turn off for the Boxcar boulder on the left side of the tracks. Bushwhack through a short blackberry bush directly to the boulder about 20-30 feet down from the rail road tracks.

routes.route_description: Start two hands on the left side of the point of the boulder facing boxcar boulder. The two hands will be on two different sharp, thin flakes that feel slightly slopey on top but can be pinched well. Work your way up directly on a single powerful move and that's it! The single move packs a punch. Can be done solo or as an intro to the grade for someone liking low ball boulders.
routes.route_location: When coming down the trail from the tracks and looking at the boulder, will be on the left side of the boulder near the pointy bit. Has a wide safe landing area even though the route finishes at basically 5 feet high.
routes.route_protection: 1 pad

area_description: Lower Wall area.Massive obvious boulder at the bottom of the slope below Thin Fingers, just below the railroad tracks.
area_getting_there: Either drop down from the Thin Fingers area, or from the railroad tracks on an obvious trail.

routes.route_description: Along the beginning of the trail connecting the lower wall with the country. Find this low roof that finishes on a slab. Start on the lowest crimp rail above the lip, move hard right, and roll over onto the slab.I don’t know much about this line or it’s history, I think the grade fluctuates quite a bit so take the grade I put down as only what I’ve heard… my impressions upon climbing it were maybe V8??
routes.route_location: Talus field below Thin Fingers at the Lower Town Wall. Find the marked path, cross the bridges, and find the low cave. This line climbs the right side, finishing on the tall slab.
routes.route_protection: 3 pads

routes.route_description: Fun steep arete on the northwest corner of Boxcar Boulder (nearest arete to Main Wall), starting low off a sit start. Work your way up the arete, finally committing to the highball exit moves (scary!).
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: none

route_comments.comment_text: I climbed this thing back in 01' or '02, early spring. The thing was completely overgrown with moss, and I gardened a very strategic path through the greenery. Someone later denuded the entire thing alas, ridding the route of its original garden stroll aura. I assumed it had been done back in yesteryear, but after talking to locals with a rather keen knowledge of historic local events,... more I climbed this thing back in 01' or '02, early spring. The thing was completely overgrown with moss, and I gardened a very strategic path through the greenery. Someone later denuded the entire thing alas, ridding the route of its original garden stroll aura. I assumed it had been done back in yesteryear, but after talking to locals with a rather keen knowledge of historic local events, came to the conclusion it had probably not been done (that, and the fact it had no traces of chalk anywhere, a very un-trafficked look and feel....) Oct 28, 2007
Is this the same as the Boxcar Arete in Kelly's new guide?  Cool problem, if that's the same one... Nov 16, 2007
i think so. V7 in his book? Nov 17, 2007

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Very fun! Scary up high. Note to self: don't wear ankle brace on foot you have to smear to mantle that high up. Great movement down low, though dab rock at start takes away a star

area_description: Nestled below the trail, Space Cadets is a large boulder with a couple of striking lines. I'm not sure what the route on the backside is called, or its FAist or difficulty so if you have any information on it, please let me know. Additionally, if the boulder had another name before I came along, I'd like to edit that as well, but for now, this is the name it has.
area_getting_there: Head past Holy Smoke and up the hill. As the trail crests, look down and to the left to see Space Cadets, a striking crack that rises from a recess in the rock. You can also access a route around the corner on a nicely established trail a little further up the hill.

routes.route_description: A truly striking crack feature that exits a deep recess in the rock. Space Cadets is a pure power problem, having essentially one move: a big throw to a small gaston.
routes.route_location: Start standing with hands on the first pocket of the crack and a crimp lower and to the right. Hike feet up and toss for the small gaston.The low start is currently an open project that will be significantly harder than the stand, perhaps V3+.
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads

routes.route_description: Take crimps and rails to a juggy mantle.
routes.route_location: This route is around the backside of the boulder, down a nicely established trail.
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads.

area_description: Hidden for years until the trail got redirected by the Rock Project crew, this nugget of a boulder in the dank recesses of the forest reeks of top shelf quality.
area_getting_there: This small boulder is located a few meters to the west of Rattletale Trail, shortly after the T junction.

area_comments.comment_text: Completely buried in moss as of Dec 2023. It will take some work to make this climbable again. Dec 19, 2023

routes.route_description: This technical and powerful route requires total trust in your feet and the ability to move dynamically while maintaining stability. Very hard for the grade.
routes.route_location: Start on the obvious rail and small crimp on the far left side of the boulder. Slap up the rail, mantle on your fingertips, and go for the lip.
routes.route_protection: 2 pads.

routes.route_description: This fantastic, powerful route tackles the stunning arete of The Pipe Boulder and is perhaps its finest route.
routes.route_location: Begin to the left of the arete. Sit start.
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads

routes.route_description: Start as for Pipe Right, but turn the arete down low.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads

routes.route_description: The namesake route. Start on low holds, heading up the quartz dike to top out.
routes.route_location: The first route you come to, in the dihedral.
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads

routes.route_description: Stem up the face right of the blunts rail to a cool mono pocket and topout straight up.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Pad

area_description: This is the large block encountered directly adjacent to the Lookout Trail. It sits in a nice little glade and has at least three problems on it, the best being the namesake problem, Midnite.
area_getting_there: Approach as for Lookout Point trail. The boulder is the first one reached and sits just adjacent to the trail.

routes.route_description: Start on the same rail as for Midnite. Move out right using the two high side pulls then top straight up, avoiding the rails for Right Arête.A great problem requiring power and precision.
routes.route_location: Starts on the same rail as Midnite
routes.route_protection: Pads + spotter

route_comments.comment_text: Felt hard, if your short and hot. Aug 20, 2022

routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Scary top out with one pad and no spotter had to frantically push leaves off the top out while locked off · At 6’2” +2, this was by no stretch of the imagination on the same level as midnite. 2nd go, shoulda just committed on the flash burn

routes.route_description: Climb the left edge of the boulder, as viewed from the trail. There are two variations. Bail left on the spooky slab or move right on the exposed face, both ways quite spooky.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: none

route_comments.comment_text: Was warming up on this last night and broke off one of the incut crimps about halfway up. Probably still goes, but maybe harder and more committing now. Jul 16, 2020

routes.route_description: Start on the lowest part of the obvious rail feature (not the smaller edge below it). Make a few moves left on the rail with increasing difficulty, finishing with a dynamic move to the top of the boulder. The last move is deceptively hard. Shorter climbers may be able to use an intermediate knob to some advantage while it might be easier for taller folks to keep their feet on for this move. The ambiance of the surroundings and quality of this problem make it one of the best around at the grade.
routes.route_location: This is the obvious problem on the side of the boulder that faces the trail. It climbs a rail feature on nice edges to a throw for the top of the boulder.Approximate GPS Coordinates: (47.8234867, -121.5583472)
routes.route_protection: A few pads and a spotter or two.

route_comments.comment_text: Here is a video of Jake and I projecting this beautiful climb: youtube.com/watch?v=o9KwWjT… Dec 22, 2017
One of the best boulders I've ever touched! Apr 7, 2021

routes.route_tick_comments: · Attempt. Felt kinda fucked. Much harder than I thought. Got like 1 or 2 moves off the start · Attempt. Finally swapped the R heel to a toe and threw for the top, but came up quite a bit short. RH on best part of start. LH next to it. LF smear dimple next to black dot. RF heel in cup. LH straight to middle gaston crimp - fingers high and thumb on bump. LF flag hard and down to bring RH to bottom and then to top gaston crimp. LF flag hard just below good foot edge to get LH to good top crimp - best furthest left. Crazy back toe LF to release RF heel and bring to toe at left end of starting rail. Try harder! Skwama felt better for heel than solution comp, but didn’t try comps again once fully warmed up. · Regained high point atop rail. Feel moving foot in to good spot. Conditions less than ideal, so pretty happy with this still. Hard on skin so make every go count! · Attempt. A move short of the top of the rail, but decent effort given I was hungry/dehydrated/fingers weren’t warmed up properly for this level of crimping · Send. 4 sessions, couldn’t latch the top sloper till I learned the direction of the well! Need to be more thoughtful of micro beta in the future! Felt amazing to finally hold on · Attempt. So fun! Have to come back for the send. Start beta that finally worked for me: Start with hands crossed on starting jug, LH on the good part, RH higher (there's a tiny dime edge to help). Bump LH to shallow crimp. RF high to the ramp at end of starting rail. Push hard and bump LH past next crimp to the third on the rail, then cross RH to good crimp. Bump heel to ledge, LH to final crimp. Jump!

routes.route_description: Start on the big rail just right of the arête. Make a powerful first move to another rail and then top out.
routes.route_location: On the right side of the Midnite boulder.
routes.route_protection: N/A
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. Dig deep into heel hook and commit to mantle to get to “jug” · Send. Was so fun I had to do it a second time right after · Send. Third attempt got it after a nice man offered beta. Fun little dyno for my first outdoor v3 · Attempt. Tried big deadpoint from left but couldn't keep my feet on anything and then couldn't hang on next rail with one hand. Not strong enough, watched Casey basically do a one arm pullup on 2nd rail with dangling feet. Then tried starting hands to the right, heel hooking rail and reaching up, seems possible but really need to rock over to almost flat foot. · Flash from right side of rail. Then traversed in from left side of rail, and also went straight up from left side of rail. Hard to get off the boulder, ended up down climbing this. · Send. So satisfying to finally get this after it being one of the first problems I ever attempted solo outside. Date uncertain

routes.route_description: Start on jug go to obvious slopey crimp throw a heel and lockoff to the jug on banking the pig and.finish that problem
routes.route_location: Right of midnite.
routes.route_protection: A few pads.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. The dirty moss mantle spooked me and I topped out right instead. Whatever. · One session. Used high left foot but no heel to bump LH to gaston. Eventually went back a bit right to top out as the mantle was mossy / sketchy. I don’t think this changes the difficulty.

routes.route_description: Follow the obvious chalked up feet to a mellow top-out. Basically a smeary slab staircase for those who like alliteration. Very fun.
routes.route_location: On the backside of the Midnite boulder.
routes.route_protection: A pad will do you fine.
routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Fun no hands slab. Not sure if this is the climb as described in the guidebook.

area_description: This boulder is quietly nestled in the woods and is more substantial than it first appears.
area_getting_there: Head past The Pipe- as the trail switchbacks left, the boulder is a few meters off the trail to the right.

routes.route_description: Walk down and up the slab, but only with your hairy hobbit feet.
routes.route_location: The slab just above Holy Smoke.
routes.route_protection: None.

routes.route_description: The obvious line of the boulder, obscured for eternity by a heavy layer of moss and an inconspicuous location.Move quickly up the steep and flat rail, using crimps and edges at the finish: a juggy mantle to the top. Pumpy!
routes.route_location: Start by the tree that touches the boulder.
routes.route_protection: 1-2 pads.

area_description: Boulder with two slab climbs just past midnite
area_getting_there: Take the trail past midnite towards upper lookout. After 1-2 minutes there should be a faint trail to your left with a thin fallen tree next to it. Go left at this fork and you'll reach the boulder in less than a minute.

routes.route_description: Start left of tree. Right hand starts on arete and left hand on a side pull. Start can be a bit barn doory, but try to get onto the slabby face and top out straight above.
routes.route_location: Left of the face with a scoop. Starts left of the tree.
routes.route_protection: 2+ pads and a spotter
routes.route_tick_comments: · Send. perfect slab imo. scrunchy start to tenuous full value slab w a dynamic & commiting move to a jug

area_description: A dragon of stone sleeps in the woods. Who will wrestle it?
area_getting_there: Head past Space Cadets and look for the dragon's spine feature as you approach Rattletale Wall.

routes.route_fa: Michal Rynkiewicz, Chandler Davis, and a dude named Ben
routes.route_description: Climb the ultra juggy arete.
routes.route_location: Look for the slumbering beast.
routes.route_protection: Pads.

area_description: Shady wall visible from the tracks. This is also listed under "Side Walls" due to it having several longer routes.
area_getting_there: Few minutes from the LTW parking lot. Just follow the trail to the Inner Walls. You will soon be facing "Knob Job".

routes.route_description: This beautiful route can also be climbed as a boulder and it is definitely highball. Probably bring a lot of pads.
routes.route_location: Directly on the trail, about 100 meters away from the LTW intersection.
routes.route_protection: Pads on pads on pads.

route_comments.comment_text: This used to have a bolt in the middle of the face and was rated 5.10d. I think it also had a pin near the end, in the crack that traverses left. Jun 1, 2017
There is indeed a bolt on the face. I don't remember there being a pin, but I certainly could have missed that. Jun 1, 2017
Oh, I think the pin vanished long ago. Jun 1, 2017

routes.route_tick_comments: · Flash. Onsight with bolt, redpointed without it right after. Doesn't need to be there. Sure, it frees up some of the slot you want to be using for your hand, but that's rock climbing. Bring a z4 .3 · TR. If I were to place pro, a black totem in the horizontal and .2 x4 fit well in the high horizontal

area_description: Spaceship sized boulder with clean landings. The Cramer guide suggest's several “good to excellent” boulder problems. This was clean in 2017-18 bring a brush.
area_getting_there: 3 minute walk from the parking lot. Walk 25 feet past Knob Job and turn left and walk out on the terrace above the Garden Wall look west and up hill. The Garden boulder will be obvious.

area_comments.comment_text: Looks like it should have some moderate problems. I used to like the hangout on top of Garden Wall, but I can't remember this boulder. And yet the Cramer guide mentions it. Maybe Darryl can tell me if I've been there... Feb 8, 2020

Not sure if you've been there of not Jon but I think you must have.  This boulder has been cleaned off several times over the years and lots of problems done by various climbers at least as far back as the 80's. Feb 10, 2020

HA not just this thing!  Keith's Crack was first cleaned in the early-mid 80s I think and just a few years later Cal was really working on the Mid Wall and was telling me about a great new crack he discovered and as he described it to me I realized he was talking about Keith's Crack. He was surprised and probably a bit bummed to find out it was already a route. Feb 10, 2020

routes.route_description: Climb the crimpy face up the center right side of the V2 Boulder.
routes.route_location: On the V2 Boulder, just up the hill from Knob Job. Take a left on a small trail and follow it to the right.
routes.route_protection: Paaaaaads

routes.route_description: Same start as Carpet Muncher, but head out left to an interesting dihedral. Climb that and edges to the top. The holds get bigger the higher you go and thus ward off the fear a bit.
routes.route_location: On the V2 Boulder, just up the hill from Knob Job. Take a left on a small trail and follow it to the right.
routes.route_protection: Piddly diddly PADS!

routes.route_description: From the sloping shelf go up and a bit left and climb the blunt arete above a stepped landing to an easy top out.This may have been climbed already — I can update if anyone has info.
routes.route_location: Ten feet to the left of The Mouse, start on a blocky pinch on the sloping shelf with a far left foot.
routes.route_protection: Two or three pads.

routes.route_name: From the Cradle to the Grave
routes.route_description: The beautiful arete to the right of the mouse techy arete climbing
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Pads

route_comments.comment_text: This line starts on a jug under the landing. Pull an awkward mantel and step over the landing then commit to very fun technical arete climbing on the left side of the arete. May 15, 2023

routes.route_description: From the same jug start as Cradle to the Grave climb the right side of the arete till you can reach over to the Austrian Butt Plug at about 2/3 height.Insecure slopers laybacks and shallow pockets.
routes.route_location: Left side Garden Boulder
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_description: Seriously awesome overhung prow. Start on a pinch with smeary feet and use edges, heel hooks and a tough mantle to reach the top.Could be a low start to this that would likely add several grades.
routes.route_location: Around the corner from ABP.
routes.route_protection: Two or three pads.

routes.route_description: Low start for the mouse a tricky start leads to amazing compression ending up in a extremely insecure knee bar before entering the mouse
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_description: Start on Cradle to The Grave pull the mantel and set up on the arete near edge of landing. reach over to a small crimp <6 mm and match. Do a flexible move to get a high heel and throw over to the start holds of the mouse. Rad line requires some finger strength and power as well as a little flexibility.If you can't hold the 6 mm micros, don't even try this line it'll eat your skin up
routes.route_location: Garden boulder left side
routes.route_protection: pads

area_description: Shady area with tilted flake.
area_getting_there: (From Matthew's description for the arete problem):Follow the inner wall trail past K-cliff to the base of the Missing Bottle Buttress. (mountainproject.com/area/10…) This is the gully climbers right of the toxic shock area. If you hit the splitter hand crack of toxic shock you have gone too far. The boulder is located in the gully below Happy Puppy, and Doug Thompson Gets the First Ascent.

routes.route_description: Start as low as possible on the arête. Move off the arête and match on a good shelf in the middle of the boulder. Reposition your feet and move back out to the arête. Traverse climbers left topping out on the apex of the boulder. Make sure to check out the small cave below the route! Big enough for one person to sleep for sure!
routes.route_location: Follow the inner wall trail past k-cliff to the base of the Missing Bottle Buttress. (mountainproject.com/area/10…) This is the gully climbers right of the toxic shock area. If you hit the splitter hand crack of toxic shock you have gone too far. The boulder is located in the gully below Happy Puppy, and Doug Thompson Gets the First Ascent.
routes.route_protection: Pads

area_description: This boulder sits right next to the ridge trail. Please be courteous and do not cover the trail with pads when people are hiking through.
area_getting_there: Hike 0.6 miles up the main trail. The boulder is immediately adjacent to the trail.

routes.route_description: Same as Incisor, but use the left wall for feet and kneebars.
routes.route_location: Obvious arete
routes.route_protection: Pad

routes.route_description: Start with an undercling on the large triangular flake and climb the arete directly without using any features left of the arete.
routes.route_location: Obvious arete
routes.route_protection: Pad

routes.route_description: Lieback the obvious crack to the right of the Incisor flake/arete until you can match on a large positive hold. Either drop off here (recommended) or mantel and top out through vegetation.
routes.route_location: Right of Incisor
routes.route_protection: Pad

area_description: The base of the wall offers some nice bouldering options. There are also boulders away from the wall, though presently undeveloped.
area_getting_there: The usual trail to Halloween. It starts on the Lookout Point trail, then veers off right at Midnite boulder, veering right again at the 'Happy Halloween' sign.

routes.route_description: Compress up the narrow fin from a sit start. Only the fin is on.
routes.route_location: Under Reservations from Hubbard
routes.route_protection: Pads

routes.route_description: Same start jug as Speak of Then Devil climb up and right on nice incut crimps and reach to the jug. Top out up the ramp.
routes.route_location: Under Carol
routes.route_protection: Pads

routes.route_description: Sweet compression line that took some digging to expose. Crouch start on lowest compression stance. Slap up the steep prow and top out on jugs. At 6ft tall this felt v8 to me. The left wall is off so just squeeze up the prow.
routes.route_location: Obvious prow left of Lisle
routes.route_protection: 4+ pads

route_comments.comment_text: Super fun! I give it V9- because it won’t feel any easier than this for those with shorter wingspans then me. Jan 19, 2025

routes.route_description: Start on the obvious big ledge for hands climb up the 55 degree prow. Once at the jug you have a few choices I wanted to have the full experience so I slapped up the arete. So from the jug I went lh to the undercling and climbed the arete to the lip. If you want to skip the best part of the climb and grab chossy rock above a bad landing you can reach way left to a side pull and throw to the lip. There are other ways of doing it as well. Dont cheat yourself going left. Go straight up. This being an FA I wanted to climb it in the most proud badass way so I went to the arete. From the lip climb slopers up and right to the apex of the prowThis is a badass line, requires a little power endurance and power. There is no one hard move but it all kinda adds up.
routes.route_location: Under Shirlene
routes.route_protection: Many Pads

area_description: Tall slab boulder with some intricate problems and a good landing. South facing and sunny.
area_getting_there: From Jelly Bean head up and right. Wizard Shit will be the first obvious boulder you see.

routes.route_description: Tricky and/or hard! Sit start matched on the good check-marked shaped edge in the middle of the face. Somehow establish yourself standing on the start edges using the undercling about two thirds of the way up. Then continue to the lip for the airy mantle.
routes.route_location: Center of the Wizard Shit Boulder.
routes.route_protection: N/A

area_description: Sunny boulder with some good moderates and a couple of harder problems. In March of 2020, Square Root, Mama Bear, Gas Chamber, and the project were all cleaned and scrubbed, so go get it!
area_getting_there: From the Index Bridge continue east on Index-Galena Road for 5.2 miles until you see a gravel road on your right just before the washout. Park at the blockade or just up the gravel road. Take an immediate left from the parking area and continue following the lumber road around a couple of switch backs until it straightens out with Trout Creek on the right. About a mile into the hike, you will see the Anansi Boulder down the hill on the right, just before a fork in the lumber road. Stay right at the fork and continue for another half mile until you see the hard-to-miss Jelly Bean boulder just off the road on the left. The Moth boulder is just a little further down the road about 10 meters into the forest on your left.

routes.route_description: Start with good opposing holds on the blocky feature under the left side of the overhang. Work your way to the lip with tensiony moves, throw a leg over, and prepare yourself for a tough mantle. After that, it's easy slab to the top.
routes.route_location: Center of the Moth Boulder when facing from the lumber road. Gas Chamber starts under the left side of the overhang.
routes.route_protection: N/A

route_comments.comment_text: Known in the book as Gas Chamber Mar 11, 2021

routes.route_description: Start somewhere on the slopey ledge on the left side of the boulder. Mantle on to the ledge, reach up to some high edges, and then top out above.
routes.route_location: From the lumber road head around to the left side of the boulder. Mama Bear starts from the slopey ledge.
routes.route_protection: At least two pads.

routes.route_description: Open project. Start seated on the right facing rails. Somehow establish yourself, and then dyno to the lip for the easy mantle. At least a V9, but how would I know?
routes.route_location: On the right side of the Moth Boulder when facing from the lumber road.
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_description: Start matched from the left corner of the slopey ledge. Work your way left using the mostly left facing edges and top out above. The smaller boulder to your left is off.
routes.route_location: Facing the boulder from the lumber road, Square Root is around the left side as far back as you can go.
routes.route_protection: N/A

area_description: Tall boulder with some stellar lines. South facing, but mostly shaded in the forest.
area_getting_there: From the Index Bridge continue east on Index-Galena Road for 5.2 miles until you see a gravel road on your right just before the washout. Park at the blockade or just up the gravel road. Take an immediate left from the parking area and continue following the lumber road around a couple of switch backs until it straightens out with Trout Creek on the right. About a mile into the hike, you will see the Anansi Boulder down the hill on the right, just before a fork in the lumber road.

routes.route_description: Start standing from the rail and work your way up diagonally to the left for a spooky top out.
routes.route_location: In the center-right of the downhill face starting from the right facing diagonal rail.
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_description: Start seated from the low rail and work your way up and left.
routes.route_location: On the left arete when facing the downhill side of the boulder.
routes.route_protection: N/A

routes.route_description: Begin with two opposing pinches seated under the overhang. Make tough compression moves to a crimp and then top out above.
routes.route_location: On the right side of the boulder under the small overhang.
routes.route_protection: N/A

area_description: There is a single decent quality boulder in the country area as well as another decent-looking warmup boulder (a bit dirty) a bit further down in the shrub.
area_getting_there: About a 50 foot walk from wham/little Jupiter towards the lower town walls a few feet to the left of the trail. The trail that passes through wham, not towards the railroad tracks.

routes.route_description: Obvious left arete feature with just enough edges to be climbed. Start standing in the pit with a small incut righthand crimp and left hand on lowest good slopey dish around the corner on the slab. A couple punchy moves out of the gate lead you into a more technical sequence and an interesting mantle on the square block up and right. The landing cleans up better than it looks with at least 4 pads. There are a handful of obvious holds lower for the full value sitstart but it didn’t feel as natural as the stand.
routes.route_location: If you are at the country this boulder is located ~50ft to the left, it is the biggest most obvious block.
routes.route_protection: 4+ pads

routes.route_description: Start matched on the large horizontal edge near the bottom of the slab and traverse up and left on the arete, using heelhooks and edges, eventually mantling over to the left side and topping out at the apex of the boulder. Mantling early can be anywhere from 6a-6b+.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: N/A

area_description: A couple boulders tucked away in the forest right next to the highway.
area_getting_there: On US-2 at about milepost 39.6, pull over onto the shoulder north of the highway. Don't block the gravel service road that crosses the railroad tracks. Cross the tracks and go north into the forest for 5-10 minutes until you reach the dense cluster of boulders. Approach can be steep, bushwacky, or thorny depending on the season and whether or not you get off track.

area_comments.comment_text: has anything else out here been scrubbed? Went out there, the routes are in good condition but nothing else is worth the scrub. Mar 2, 2022

Some more approach beta: Enter the forest directly straight across from where you cross the train tracks, there are dense thorns on either side and this should be the least-bad option. Continue more or less straight, bushwhacking until you get the vertical wall of dirt. Straight ahead there should be a pile of large boulders about 30’ tall, recognizable by one large Boulder at the top... more Some more approach beta: Enter the forest directly straight across from where you cross the train tracks, there are dense thorns on either side and this should be the least-bad option. Continue more or less straight, bushwhacking until you get the vertical wall of dirt. Straight ahead there should be a pile of large boulders about 30’ tall, recognizable by one large Boulder at the top which has a huge hole beneath it (see photo). The trail goes up and LEFT from here and is quite steep and likely the only part of the trail that looks established. It might be tricky getting to this part but is MUCH preferable to going to the right of the floating block (trust me). Once on top of the boulder pile, head left for 3-5 minutes across the boulder field and you’ll hit the problems. The “Almost There” graffiti is mostly gone now and the problems are likely mossy and dirty. Jul 12, 2022

routes.route_description: Start on the large rail and move up and left to the arete via a heelhook. Top out above.
routes.route_location: Southwestern edge of the boulder cluster, near the steep southern facing slope
routes.route_protection: A couple pads
